site_title: Vincent Hoong named as judicial commissioner of Supreme Court
summary: Vincent Hoong, 61, has been appointed as judicial commissioner of the Supreme Court for a year, starting April 10. Teh Hwee Hwee, the current deputy registrar, will succeed him as registrar, and Phang Hsiao Chung will become deputy registrar. Hoong, with over 34 years of experience, is the most senior legal service officer.

site_title: European firms dust off 'no-deal' Brexit plans
summary: European firms are intensifying preparations for a potential "no-deal" Brexit, fearing higher import duties and border delays if the UK leaves the EU on March 29. Companies such as LVMH, Eurotunnel, and Banco Santander are stockpiling inventory, expanding parking spaces, and hiring more customs staff. A hard Brexit could cost the EU and Britain 58 billion pounds annually in "red tape" expenses, with the financial services sector expected to be most impacted. Firms are scrambling to prepare for the worst-case scenario, with some already shipping goods ahead of the deadline to avoid higher duties.

site_title: China to combine financial schemes, expand foreign investment scope: CSRC
summary: China's securities regulator, the CSRC, has published draft rules to ease foreign investment in its capital markets. The new rules combine two inbound investment schemes, QFII and RQFII, and broaden their scope to include derivatives, bond repurchases, and private funds. The move aims to "promote high-quality opening" of China's capital markets and attract more long-term overseas capital, with CSRC predicting $120 billion in foreign inflows in 2019. The rules also simplify the vetting process and lower the threshold for overseas applicants.

site_title: World's biggest pension fund reports record US$136b loss amid market turmoil
summary: Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) reported a record loss of $136 billion in the three months ended Dec 31, with a 9.1% decline in value. The decline was the steepest based on comparable data since 2008, due to a global equity rout amid a trade spat between the US and China. Domestic stocks and foreign equities were the fund's worst-performing investments. The GPIF may need to invest in equities due to low fixed-income yields, but this poses risks for pensioners.

site_title: Indonesia set for mega bank shake-up in bid to create national champion
summary: Indonesia plans to create a national champion bank by putting four state banks under a holding company, PT Danareksa, in May. This move aims to boost the sector's competitiveness, marking the sector's biggest shake-up since the Asian financial crisis in the late 1990s. The holding company will oversee the four state banks, aiming to create a lending powerhouse in South-east Asia's largest economy.

site_title: Schroders acquires Singapore-based Thirdrock Group's wealth management business
summary: Schroders has acquired Singapore-based Thirdrock Group's wealth management business for an undisclosed sum. Thirdrock, founded in 2010, has client assets under management of approximately $3 billion. The deal will see Thirdrock's wealth management arm merged with Schroders' existing Singapore business and operate under the Schroders brand. Jason Lai and Melvyn Yeo, co-founders of Thirdrock Group, will join Schroders as leaders in Asia, aiming to grow the business across the region. The acquisition aims to combine Schroders' institutional investment expertise with Thirdrock's entrepreneurialism and personal service.

site_title: Lo Hei for the arts
summary: Hotel Jen Tanglin Singapore is donating 3% of sales proceeds from its Chinese New Year takeaway goodies to support young creative talent in Singapore through The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. Customers can enjoy premium yusheng and Fortune Pen Cai dishes, with specially animated angpao designs created by students from Little Arts Academy. The hotel is also giving away these angpao to dine-in and takeaway customers.

site_title: Thai baht outperforms in emerging Asia amid favourable domestic, foreign factors
summary: The Thai baht has outperformed in emerging Asia, rallying 4.2% against the dollar this year, the largest gain in the region. Strong foreign direct investment, a current-account surplus, and subdued inflation are supporting the currency. The Thai central bank is expected to raise interest rates, boosting the baht, while a likely pause in tightening by the Federal Reserve also supports its strength. Analysts predict the baht will reach 31 by year-end, but some warn of potential risks from Chinese growth slowdown and political uncertainty.

site_title: US banks shifting some London staff ahead of Brexit deadline
summary: US banks are shifting some London staff to continental Europe ahead of the Brexit deadline on March 29. Around 400 Bank of America employees will transfer to Paris and Frankfurt starting in February, with about half already set to arrive before the deadline. JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs are also relocating staff to Europe, while Citigroup has transferred 63 London-based employees to the continent. The moves are in preparation for a potential "hard" Brexit, which could restrict EU work for British staff.

site_title: Hyflux asks creditors to file proofs of claim by Feb 15
summary: Hyflux, a water treatment firm, has asked creditors to file proofs of claim by February 15 to participate in debt restructuring. Holders of bonds, perpetual securities, and preference shares will be treated as proofs, even if they don't file claims. Failure to submit proofs by the deadline may result in exclusion from voting and potential payments. The company filed for bankruptcy protection last year and owes S$900 million to preferred and perpetual shareholders, with potential recoveries ranging from 3.8% to 8.7% in a liquidation scenario.

site_title: Chinese engineer charged in theft of Apple car secrets
summary: A Chinese engineer, Jizhong Chen, has been charged with stealing Apple's self-driving car project secrets. Chen, an electrical engineer, was hired by Apple in June 2018 and given "secrecy training" to avoid leaking information. He was caught taking photos of the project and backing up files to a personal computer. Chen was suspended from his job and faces up to 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. The incident is unrelated to a previous case involving an ex-Apple engineer, Xiaolang Zhang, who was accused of stealing trade secrets from the same project.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open modestly higher on Wall Street rally
summary: Tokyo stocks opened slightly higher on Friday, driven by rallies on Wall Street and a stable yen-dollar exchange rate. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.49% to 20,874.86, while the Topix index increased 0.12% to 1,569.32. This follows the US market's recent record highs, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh levels despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,187.03, down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday, down 0.1% at 3,187.03, with decliners outnumbering advancers 161 to 131. Heavyweights UOB and DBS supported the index, while 777.17 million shares worth S$540.07 million changed hands.

site_title: Amazon profit jumps on strong holiday quarter
summary: Amazon reported a 63% profit jump in the fourth quarter to $3.0 billion, driven by strong holiday sales and its cloud computing business. Revenues increased 20% to $72.4 billion, with growth in online retail and Amazon Web Services. The company's digital assistant Alexa played a key role in the holiday season, with Echo Dot being the best-selling item globally. Amazon's profitability is expected to continue, but some analysts question the company's future growth path as sales slow.

site_title: China vows increased US imports, IP protection at trade talks
summary: China has agreed to increase US imports and boost cooperation on intellectual property protection during trade talks in Washington. The two sides also agreed to further strengthen cooperation on technology transfer. China will increase imports of US agricultural products, energy products, industrial manufactured goods, and service products. This marks a shift in China's trade policies, with a focus on expanding imports and protecting intellectual property.

images.alt_text: China agreed to increase imports of US goods and boost cooperation on protecting intellectual property during trade talks in Washington, Beijing's official news agency said Friday.

site_title: AGV Group's full-year loss almost triples to S$12.1m
summary: AGV Group reported a net loss of S$12.1 million for the full-year ended Sept 30, tripling from a year ago, due to a surge in zinc prices and structural damage to its zinc kettle. Revenue more than halved to S$8 million, and the group's total liabilities rose 15.3% to S$25.6 million. Finance costs increased, and two directors resigned. The company is negotiating with creditors to extend repayment terms and ease cash flow.

site_title: Venezuela's Maduro loosens private sector, currency red tape: sources
summary: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro has loosened private sector and currency controls amid US sanctions on the country's oil industry. The government will allow companies to buy foreign currency directly, reducing reliance on the complex system of exchange controls. However, this move is seen as too late to revive the economy, which is still grappling with hyperinflation and recession. The changes come as Maduro faces opposition leader Juan Guaido's claim of presidency and US sanctions that have cut off key revenue sources.

site_title: SGX RegCo urges caution in trading of Sevak shares
summary: SGX RegCo is urging caution in trading Sevak shares due to a 61% price rise from Sept 17 to Oct 19, 2018, despite a broader market decline. The regulator is reviewing trades and will take necessary actions. Suspicion surrounds price movements between Oct 4-16, and a group of connected clients accounted for 70% of Sevak's buy volume from Dec 14, 2018 to Jan 25, 2019.

site_title: US Midwest gripped by bitterly cold temperatures but relief ahead
summary: The US Midwest experienced record-low temperatures, with tens of millions shivering for a second day. The mercury dipped to sub-zero levels, causing power outages, canceling flights, and straining natural gas supplies. Ten deaths have been attributed to the extreme weather, with Michigan reporting a high number of fatalities. Schools and businesses remained closed, and authorities asked residents to reduce heat consumption. The cold was expected to lift on Friday, but the region was bracing for another 24 hours of hazardous weather.

images.alt_text: Brutally cold temperatures gripped the US Midwest on Thursday, freezing water mains, causing power outages, canceling flights and straining natural gas supplies.

site_title: Lazada to migrate RedMart onto its platform on March 15
summary: Lazada, an Alibaba-backed e-commerce platform, will integrate RedMart, a Singapore-based e-grocer, onto its platform on March 15. This move aims to accelerate Lazada's supermarket business in South-east Asia, catering to rising consumer demand for online grocery shopping. Shoppers will be able to purchase groceries and fresh produce alongside other products on a single platform, enhancing their shopping experience. The integration is part of Lazada's plan to expand its supermarket offerings and compete in the growing online grocery market.

site_title: Singapore has a shipping rival less than 30km away
summary: Indonesia aims to reposition Batam island as an alternative shipping and manufacturing hub to Singapore, with a potential to attract $60 billion in new investment. The island has already attracted $20 billion in investment since the 1970s and is home to thousands of local and foreign firms. Authorities plan to expand the island's free-trade zone by reclaiming 8,000 hectares of land to offer to exporters and producers of import substitutes. This move aims to boost exports and help curb Indonesia's widening current-account deficit, as well as capitalize on the US-China trade war's disruption of global supply chains.

images.alt_text: Indonesia wants to re-position its Batam island as an alternative shipping and manufacturing hub to Singapore with a potential to draw US$60 billion in new investment.

site_title: Gojek said to raise over US$1b in funding round led by Google, JD and Tencent
summary: Gojek has closed its initial portion of its Series F round, raising over $1 billion in funding led by Google, JD, and Tencent. The investment values the company at $8-10 billion. The funds will be used to expand its businesses in Southeast Asia and strengthen its presence in Singapore, Vietnam, and Thailand. Gojek is also furthering partnerships with JD.com's e-commerce ventures, enhancing payment solutions, marketing, and IT collaborations. Founders will maintain control, while the funds will support increased market penetration and logistics coverage across the region.

site_title: Trashed mail a sign of deeper issues at SingPost?
summary: SingPost, Singapore's only public postal licensee, has been warned by the regulator, Info-communications Media Development Authority (IMDA), to improve its services after recent lapses, such as a postman dumping mail into a dustbin. The regulator may impose a fine of up to S$1 million or modify licensing terms, but an outright cancellation of the license is unlikely. Analysts predict that SingPost's aggressive expansion into e-commerce logistics may have overstretched its resources, leading to a decline in postal services. The company's management may need to focus on its postal segment, monetize assets, or divest overseas operations to turn around its profitability.

site_title: Japan's labour shortage hits 45-year high
summary: Japan's labour market has hit a 45-year high, with an average of 161 jobs available for every 100 jobseekers in 2018. The ratio was even higher in December, at 163 jobs per 100 jobseekers. The tight labour market is attributed to Japan's rapidly ageing population and low childbirth rate.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust Q4 DPU up 2.1%; to swap malls in Inner Mongolia
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 2.1% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter, driven by 7.7% year-on-year growth in distributable income and 8.8% growth in net property income. The trust's portfolio occupancy was 97.5% and rental reversion was 10.9%. CRCT also announced a swap deal to acquire a new mall in Inner Mongolia, China, in exchange for its CapitaMall Saihan asset, which is expected to minimize income disruption and maximize benefits for unitholders.

site_title: Emerging markets now back on strategists' radar
summary: Emerging markets, which were battered last year due to US interest hikes, are now expected to rebound as strategists foresee a less hawkish Federal Reserve and a weaker US dollar. Pundits recommend going overweight on emerging markets, the yen, gold, and the Chinese yuan, and some even suggest shorting the US dollar. This favorable environment could benefit these markets, which have been on the radar of strategists again.

site_title: AA Reit's Q3 DPU down 4.6% to 2.50 S cents
summary: AA Reit reported a 4.6% decline in Q3 DPU to 2.50 Singapore cents, down from 2.62 cents last year. Gross revenue rose 3.3% to S$29.8 million, driven by rental contributions from new properties. Net property income increased 1.1% to S$19.4 million, and distribution to unitholders edged up 0.8% to S$17.2 million. The Reit's portfolio occupancy increased to 93.9% and ongoing redevelopment projects remain on track for completion in the second half of 2019.

site_title: London hedge fund giant looking to build low-income homes
summary: Man Group, the world's largest publicly traded hedge fund manager, plans to start a fund to finance the construction of affordable homes in the UK, addressing a severe shortage of subsidized housing for low-income families.

site_title: No Signboard halts trading after 24% price surge
summary: No Signboard Holdings halted trading in its shares after a 24% price surge on January 31, 2019, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange. The company had not responded to the regulator's queries as of Thursday evening.

site_title: SeedPlus bets on Neuron Mobility to zoom ahead of e-scooter crowd
summary: SeedPlus, a venture firm, led a $5 million seed funding round into e-scooter startup Neuron Mobility in December. Neuron, founded in 2016, is expanding in Asia-Pacific with over 1,000 scooters and plans to secure a sandbox license from Singapore's transport regulator. SeedPlus partner Chirayu Wadke attributes Neuron's success to its unique advantages, including designing its own scooters and controlling its supply chain. Neuron's focus on regulatory compliance and efficient operations is expected to help it avoid the pitfalls of the bike-sharing industry.

images.alt_text: In December 2018, SeedPlus led a S$5 million seed round into e-scooter startup Neuron Mobility.

site_title: Millions in American Midwest suffer Arctic-like temperatures
summary: Millions in the American Midwest experienced record-low temperatures, dropping to nearly 50 degrees below zero, causing widespread disruptions. Governors in Wisconsin and Michigan declared states of emergency and closed state offices due to the extreme cold. The polar vortex led to numerous deaths, power outages, and school closures, with temperatures expected to thaw by Thursday afternoon. The cold exacerbated health issues for vulnerable populations, including the homeless, and forced some residents to seek shelter in warming centers.

site_title: Beyonce, Jay-Z offer chance of lifetime tickets to fans who go vegan
summary: Beyonce and Jay-Z are offering a chance to win a lifetime of free tickets to their concerts by encouraging fans to go vegan for a month through the Greenprint Project. One lucky winner will be chosen at random from online sign-ups and receive a pair of tickets annually for 30 years, valued at $12,000. The contest aims to promote adopting a partial vegan diet to limit environmental footprints.

site_title: Plane skids off runway, closing parts of Tokyo's Narita
summary: A Japan Airlines plane from New Delhi skidded off a snow-bound runway at Narita Airport in Tokyo on Friday, briefly closing part of the airport. The Boeing 787 jet, carrying 201 passengers and crew, sustained no serious injuries. The cause of the accident was unclear, but a rare patch of snow on the runway may have contributed. The airport's runway was closed for an hour, and the plane was later moved out of a safety zone. No damage was apparent, and the incident was deemed minor.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday, STI up 0.17% to 3,195.71
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 5.54 points, or 0.17%, to 3,195.71 at 9:05 am on Friday, driven by gains from Thai Beverage (1.37%) and other active stocks. Gainers outnumbered losers 59 to 54, with about 60.2 million shares changing hands. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: More working in Singapore; median income up 3.3%: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore reported that more people are working in the country, with a lower annual average unemployment rate compared to the previous year. However, median income rose only 3.3% compared to the previous year, a slower pace. The improved labour market also saw fewer retrenchments.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as China, US agree to further trade talks
summary: China and the US agreed to further trade talks after a gathering, with both sides expressing optimism and setting up more meetings. Donald Trump hailed "tremendous progress" but warned of a March 1 deadline for imposing US tariffs on Chinese goods. Despite no deal, markets were mixed, with Tokyo and Shanghai rising, while Hong Kong fell. Analysts say the talks signal limited progress, but the statement also includes a threat for China to offer more concessions for a deal.

site_title: Deutsche Bank swings to first full year profit in 4 years after tepid Q4
summary: Deutsche Bank reported its first full-year profit in four years in 2018, despite a fourth-quarter net loss of 409 million euros. The bank's return to profitability was attributed to cost-cutting efforts and focused investments in growth. CEO Christian Sewing stated that the bank aims to grow profitability substantially in 2019 and beyond, with a focus on saving costs and making targeted investments. Revenue in its key bond-trading division declined by 23% in the quarter, highlighting ongoing challenges in the bank's trading business.

site_title: Helping shops sell better with smart tech
summary: Singapore's brick and mortar retail stores face competition from e-commerce, with many struggling to adapt. Despite the presence of four global skincare giants and top food companies in the region, store closures and bankruptcies continue. To compete, retailers are exploring new ways, including using artificial intelligence to personalize customer experiences and optimize store operations. AI can provide insights on customer behavior, staff effectiveness, and campaign effectiveness, enabling stores to differentiate themselves and maximize operational efficiencies. However, widespread adoption of AI is still in its early stages, and retailers must have a clearly defined use case and seamless integration with workflows to reap its benefits.

images.alt_text: Of 161 highly cited AI papers in South-east Asia, 97 were derived from Singapore - outperforming the global average.

site_title: Japan's wagyu beef looks to conquer the world
summary: Japan's Hida brand of wagyu beef is seeking to expand its international presence to boost sales, following declining consumption in Japan. The renowned meat is known for its melt-in-the-mouth tenderness and marbled fat. Producers are targeting overseas markets to capitalize on the growing global profile of wagyu beef.

images.alt_text: With consumption of the famed meat known for its melt-in-the-mouth tenderness and marbled fat on the decline in Japan, producers are looking overseas to boost sales instead.

site_title: Zodiac Cookies
summary: Mdm Ling Bakery has released a limited edition Auspicious Cookies Collection featuring 12 gold 'barrels' of snacks corresponding to each animal in the lunar new year cycle. The collection, priced at S$128 per set, includes personalized cookies representing the zodiac sign of the individual. Available until February 4, customers can order online or call 8787-4142.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index ends flat as investors seek fresh clues
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index ended flat on Friday, closing up 0.07% at 20,788.39, as investors sought fresh clues on corporate earnings and watched individual shares. A weak Chinese manufacturing data release also had a negative impact. High-tech shares were higher, with Sharp and Murata Mfg surging, while Nintendo fell despite a profit increase. The US dollar fetched 108.86 yen in Asian trade.

site_title: Accuron Technologies to spin out medtech business to Temasek
summary: Accuron Technologies, a subsidiary of Temasek Holdings, announced plans to spin out its medical device business, Accuron MedTech Group, to be directly owned by Temasek. The group, South-east Asia's largest medical device business, will focus on urology and become a leading vertically integrated business. The spin-out aims to leverage Temasek's resources and expertise to drive growth and innovation in the medical device sector.

site_title: Châteauneuf-du-Pape finds its balance anew
summary: A stylistic shift towards balance and nuance is underway in Châteauneuf-du-Pape, a southern Rhône Valley wine. After a period of over-ripeness and oakiness, the 2016 vintage is showing a return to form, with wines characterized by potent fruit flavors balanced by savory herbal notes and tannins. While prices remain high, many producers are now offering more nuanced and complex wines, with some exceptions including 100% grenache cuvées. The tasting panel selected several standout wines, including the Bosquet des Papes Chante le Merle Vieilles Vignes and the Château Beaucastel, which suggest a correction towards a more traditional, Mediterranean style of Châteauneuf.

site_title: Factory activity shrinks across Asia as cooling China threatens global growth
summary: Factory activity shrank across Asia in January, with China posting its weakest readings in almost three years, and Taiwan, South Korea, and Indonesia experiencing contractions. The US economy remains a bright spot, but global growth forecasts have been cut due to trade tensions and cooling demand. The International Monetary Fund warned of a potential trade recession, and China is under pressure to implement stimulus measures to boost its economy. US President Donald Trump is set to meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping to try to reach a comprehensive trade deal, which could avert a trade recession.

site_title: Modern Asian Reunion
summary: The Capitol Kempinski Hotel Singapore's 15 Stamford restaurant, led by Chef Alvin Leung, offers a unique Asian-themed Lunar New Year reunion dinner experience. The menu features auspicious yu sheng dishes, including hamachi and salmon options, and a variety of communal-style dishes and mains. The 6-course reunion dinner menu is priced at $128 per person and is available from January 19 to February 19. The hotel also offers Chinese Set Lunches and Lunar New Year packages, and a Prosperity Hamper can be purchased at the adjacent Boutique.

site_title: Tesla CFO leaves as automaker promises profits and cheaper cars
summary: Tesla CFO Deepak Ahuja is leaving the company as the automaker promises cheaper Model 3 sedans, Chinese production launch this year, and profits in every quarter of 2019. The departure comes after missing Wall Street profit targets for the end of 2018, causing shares to drop nearly 6% after hours. Zach Kirkhorn, Tesla's vice-president of finance, will replace Ahuja. The company's efforts to improve profitability and reduce costs are seen as a positive step forward, despite the recent share price decline.

images.alt_text: Tesla says plans to lower the price of the Model 3 are contingent on quickly building its factory in China. It hopes to produce 500,000 vehicles a year there by the last quarter of 2019 and the second quarter of 2020, a goal it originally expected to meet in 2018.

site_title: Facebook takes down vast Iran-led manipulation campaign
summary: Facebook has removed 783 pages, groups, and accounts from Iran for engaging in a coordinated manipulation campaign in over 20 countries, including the US. The campaign, which dated back to 2010, used fake identities and fake accounts to promote Iranian interests and influence public opinion. The operation was linked to Iran and was followed by approximately two million users. Facebook is taking steps to detect and stop such activities, stating that it does not want its services to be used to manipulate people.

site_title: US Senate chief rebukes Trump over Syria pullout
summary: US Senate leader Mitch McConnell rebuked President Donald Trump over his decision to pull US troops out of Syria, stating that the withdrawal would acknowledge the threat posed by Al-Qaeda and ISIS in the region. The amendment, which passed with bipartisan support, highlights the need for diplomatic engagement and political solutions to the conflicts in Syria and Afghanistan. McConnell's rare criticism signifies opposition from both parties to a rapid removal of US troops, amid mounting pressure from various quarters, including intelligence chiefs who warned of the Islamic State's ability to rebuild in a vacuum.

site_title: US seeks full account of North Korea weapons, offers ties
summary: US negotiator calls on North Korea to provide a detailed account of its weapons to seal a peace deal, with President Donald Trump set to hold a second summit with Kim Jong Un in around a month. Trump said he's ready to offer diplomatic relations and economic aid, but the exact date and venue will be announced early next week.

site_title: US urges Venezuela's Maduro to accept amnesty
summary: The US has urged Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro to accept an amnesty offer from opposition leader Juan Guaido, whom Washington has recognized as president. National security advisor John Bolton tweeted that Maduro and his advisors should "take advantage of President Guaido's amnesty and move on" to a quiet retirement. Bolton's comments came after the US reiterated its recognition of Guaido as Venezuela's interim leader, citing concerns over Maduro's legitimacy.

site_title: China may cut rates today, says economist who called 2014 move
summary: China's central bank may cut its benchmark interest rate as early as February due to deteriorating economic data, according to Barclays Plc economists. This prediction comes after the central bank's measures failed to lower financing costs in a down-cycle with rising credit risk and falling producer-price inflation. The forecast is notable as Barclays' Chang Jian correctly predicted a 2014 rate cut, and economists at Citibank expect a possible cut in the standing lending facility rate from February. A cut in benchmark rates would be China's first since 2015.

site_title: Australian, kiwi dollars steady as dovish Fed keeps lid on US dollar
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars held steady against the US dollar on Friday due to the Federal Reserve's dovish stance and improved prospects for a US-Sino trade deal. The Fed held interest rates steady and expressed patience before making further moves, boosting investor risk appetite. US President Donald Trump's announcement of meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping also contributed to the positive market sentiment.

site_title: Trump says US-China talks 'going well'
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that US-China trade talks are going well, with a future meeting with Chinese leader Xi Jinping to finalize a deal. Trump said a final deal would be made when the two meet, leaving nothing unresolved. However, administration officials and others familiar with the talks said the two sides remain far apart on key issues, with the US still debating how to proceed. The talks come amid a US trade war with China, which has affected financial markets.

site_title: Cooking showcase at Restaurant V
summary: Restaurant V, located next to Swiss appliance company V-Zug's showroom, offers upscale dining with a focus on creative, modernist cuisine. Chef Ryan Clift has conceptualized a six-course menu, with dishes featuring foams, jellies, fermentation, and textures. Highlights include a comforting watercress soup, steamed hamachi, and sous vide pigeon. While the cooking is solid, the desserts are nondescript, and the experience is still developing. The restaurant is a welcome respite from temperature-controlled cooking and serves food hot, a welcome change. Rating: 7.

site_title: Fed keeps interest rate unchanged, will be 'patient'
summary: The Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, citing a weakening case for further rate hikes amid low inflation and uncertainty about the US economy. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell emphasized the need for patience in evaluating the economy before making any future policy adjustments. The decision reflects growing concerns that the US economy may have peaked, with the Fed citing "solid" economic growth rather than a strong rate of growth. The Fed also signaled preparedness to adjust its massive securities holdings, which had been reducing at a steady pace.

site_title: SingPost's Q3 profit up 15.6% to S$50.2m on one-time gain
summary: SingPost's Q3 profit rose 15.6% to S$50.2m, driven by a one-time gain of S$28.2m from the dilution of interest in a Chinese associate. Operating profit declined 8.5% to S$42.2m, despite revenue growth of 7.6% to S$441.4m. The company expects its post and parcel business to benefit from global e-commerce growth, while its US e-commerce segment faces challenges due to increased competition and customer bankruptcies.

site_title: Australia government says credit a priority in bank inquiry response
summary: The Australian government will prioritize maintaining credit flow through the economy when responding to a landmark report on misconduct in the financial sector. Treasurer Josh Frydenberg stated that ensuring consumer protection while considering the broader economic implications is the government's focus. The report, released next week, is expected to recommend tougher enforcement of responsible lending laws, which may lead to a possible credit crunch. Prime Minister Scott Morrison expressed concerns about avoiding a credit crunch, emphasizing the importance of access to credit for the economy's health.

site_title: US: Dow gains 7.2% in January, best performance in 30 years
summary: US stocks finished January with a 7.2% gain, the best performance in 30 years, reversing the 2018 decline. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 24,999.67, up 7.2% for the month, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also saw significant gains. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite rose 9.7% for the month, driven by strong results from Facebook. Worries about a US-China trade war and global growth concerns have receded, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell emphasizing a "patient" approach to interest rate hikes.

site_title: 'Future-proofing' Singapore's Copyright Act
summary: Singapore is revamping its Copyright Act to better protect creative people and society in the digital age. The proposed changes include a right of attribution for authors and performers, allowing them to be recognized as the creator of their work. The law also liberalizes fair use, making it easier for individuals to share and discuss copyrighted material without permission. The overhaul aims to address the challenges of the Internet Age, including the lack of attribution and the misuse of copyrighted material. The proposals, which include 15 changes, are designed to be "platform independent" of technology and ensure that the law remains flexible and dynamic enough to protect creative people and society in the years to come.

images.alt_text: In today's Internet Age, Singaporeans have been trying to apply provisions of the Copyright Act to new and developing situations, which writers of the 1987 Act never dreamt of.

site_title: Fed policy turn not good news for Trump as risks mount
summary: The Federal Reserve's policy twist has raised concerns for the Trump administration, as the central bank's narrative on the economy suggests shaky confidence, a potentially weak recovery, and increasing risks. The Fed's decision to pause interest rate hikes and maintain a loose monetary policy may be a response to intensifying economic dangers, including US-China trade tensions and Brexit uncertainty. The move may indicate that the best days of Trump's economic policies are behind him, and the next few months will be crucial in determining the economy's trajectory.

site_title: Boeing revenue tops US$100b for first time, says it's bullish on 2019
summary: Boeing reported a strong fourth quarter, with profits of $3.4 billion and revenues of $28.3 billion, up 14.4% and 3.1% respectively. The company's annual revenues topped $100 billion for the first time at $101.1 billion. Boeing remains bullish on China, citing air travel growth, and expects to deliver 895-905 commercial planes in 2019, up from 806 in 2018. The company projects 2019 profits of $19.90-$20.10 per share, above analyst expectations.

images.alt_text: Boeing projects 2019 profits of US$19.90 to US$20.10 a share, well above the US$18.31 seen by analysts.

site_title: Almost half of Americans have heart disease: study
summary: A US study found that almost half of Americans have heart disease, with 121.5 million adults affected in 2016. The increase is largely due to a revised definition of high blood pressure, which now includes readings of 130/80 mmHg. Excluding high blood pressure, only 9% of US adults would be classified with cardiovascular disease. The American Heart Association attributes the rise in cardiovascular disease deaths in the US, which increased to 840,678 in 2016, to the growing presence of high blood pressure.

site_title: Make multi-stakeholder partnerships a force for good
summary: A global partnership between governments, industries, NGOs, and consumers is crucial to addressing pressing issues such as access to basic needs and environmental sustainability. However, the effectiveness of multi-stakeholder partnerships (MSPs) is often average due to a lack of common vision and action. To improve MSPs, three recommendations are proposed: establishing a common vision with unique actions, implementing a robust monitoring program, and leveraging innovation. Successful examples of these approaches include P&G's partnerships in Asia, GAVI's vaccine program, and Singapore's "National Steps Challenge" initiative, which demonstrate the potential for MSPs to drive positive impact and sustainable outcomes.

site_title: Singapore-based maritime tech accelerator launched, said to be world's first
summary: Singapore-based Eastern Pacific Shipping (EPS) and Techstars launched the world's first maritime tech startup accelerator, EPS MaritimeTech Accelerator Powered by Techstars. The accelerator, starting in April 2019, will select 10 startups to participate in a three-month program in Singapore, focusing on maritime technologies like regulations, fuel efficiency, and digitalization. The goal is to disrupt the maritime industry and facilitate investment in promising ventures, with a demo day in February 2020 to showcase their polished businesses to investors and industry experts.

site_title: Football fans team up to fight hunger
summary: Football fans across the UK have joined forces to combat hunger, inspired by a Liverpool initiative that started in 2015. Fans of teams including Newcastle, Manchester, and Sunderland collect food and funds for the needy, with donations reaching over £200,000. The West End Food Bank in Newcastle, one of the largest in Britain, benefits from the efforts. The surge in demand is attributed to the UK's Universal Credit system, which has led to widespread poverty and food insecurity. Fans see their actions as a way to give back to their communities and highlight the importance of football in local identities.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds quotation results were not mentioned in the provided articles. However, key events include NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer being 9.8 times oversubscribed, US stocks opening lower amid a fresh tariff salvo on Canada, and OCBC's incoming CEO Tan Teck Long being a former DBS veteran.

site_title: Big Screen Comeback
summary: Schindler's List is re-releasing in theaters to commemorate the 25th anniversary of Steven Spielberg's black-and-white masterpiece, which tells the true story of Oskar Schindler saving over 1,100 Jews during the Holocaust. The film has been digitally remastered in 4K and Dolby Atmos for a cinematic experience. The re-release coincides with International Holocaust Remembrance Day, and screenings are now available at select theaters in Singapore. Director Spielberg emphasizes the film's enduring importance in countering hatred and remembering the magnitude of the Holocaust.

site_title: Moscow luxury real estate sales are soaring
summary: Moscow luxury real estate sales are experiencing a surge in demand from wealthy Russians, driven by Britain's anti-money laundering measures blocking many from London and other international cities. This trend is attributed to Moscow's growing appeal as a luxury destination.

site_title: Budget 2019 will continue government's strategy for navigating global uncertainty: Indranee
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 aims to navigate global uncertainties through innovation, internationalization, and worker capability building, according to Minister Indranee Rajah. The budget will focus on helping small and medium enterprises (SMEs) scale up and partner with larger entities, while addressing technological disruption through education and training. The budget also has a social focus on education, healthcare, and volunteering, with a special emphasis on the underprivileged. The government will fund spending through a combination of sources, including the Goods and Services Tax hike and investment returns.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Government will keep its 2019 Budget aimed at helping the economy navigate global uncertainties through innovation, internationalisation and capability building for workers, said Minister in the Prime Minister's Office and Second Minister for Finance and Education Indranee Rajah on Friday morning.

site_title: Let users sell their data to Facebook
summary: Facebook is paying users between 13 and 35 years old up to $20 a month for installing an app that grants the company access to their smartphone usage data. The app, called Facebook Research, is offered through third-party beta-testing services and allows Facebook to collect highly granular data, including private message exchanges and location data. Facebook claims users gave their permission and signed parental consent forms, but critics argue the company has a poor record of explaining data collection and targeting. A proposed business model could allow users to sell their data to Facebook, with a retail market for personal data, but this would require users to sign a waiver and potentially compromise their privacy.

site_title: Construction service provider Reclaims Global seeks Catalist listing
summary: Reclaims Global, a Singapore-based eco-friendly construction service provider, has lodged a preliminary prospectus for an initial public offering (IPO) on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. The company posted revenue of S$13.1 million for the first six months of fiscal 2019, down 6.2% from a year ago, and expects a loss of S$92,000 for the same period. Proceeds from the IPO will be used to expand its operational capacity and fund expansion through acquisitions. The company faces risks including a slowdown in the construction industry, greater competition, and regulatory changes.

site_title: Bear market bounce expected in H1 2019 but recession risks persist: JPMAM
summary: JPMorgan Asset Management predicts a "bear market bounce" in the first half of 2019, citing positive catalysts such as a dovish US Federal Reserve and improving investor sentiment. However, the outlook also highlights recession risks and limited central bank ability to stimulate the economy, leading to a more cyclical bear market with shallower corrections and quicker recoveries. Longer-term investors are advised to de-risk their portfolios, considering more bond exposure, and to be cautious on emerging markets and US corporate bonds.

site_title: Deutsche Bank sees merger by mid-year if all else fails
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering a government-brokered merger with Commerzbank by mid-year if it fails to turn around its business, amid concerns over a potential economic slowdown. The bank's top executives are bracing for a difficult fourth quarter and a potential eighth consecutive decline in group revenue. The German government thinks it's impossible for Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing to turn the bank around, citing a slump in revenue and losses sustained by investors. A merger would add scale and slash expenses in a competitive domestic market.

site_title: The Future Of Chinese Food
summary: Chinese cuisine is poised to become a global culinary phenomenon, but it has yet to gain widespread recognition. Despite a growing number of talented chefs in China and abroad, the cuisine remains underrepresented on international culinary lists. However, interest in Chinese food is increasing, with several restaurants and chefs gaining international recognition for their innovative approaches. To elevate Chinese cuisine globally, training and education are key, and chefs must understand the intricacies of regional cuisines and techniques. With the right approach, Chinese cuisine could join the ranks of Japanese and Nordic cuisine as a leading global culinary movement.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Clearbridge Health, an integrated healthcare company, plans to raise S$11 million through a convertible bond issuance to seize acquisition opportunities in South-east Asia. The bonds will bear a 7% interest rate and are convertible into new shares at a price of S$0.28 per share. The funds will be used for investments, mergers and acquisitions, and general working capital purposes. Key investors include Coop International and Clearbridge's management team members, with the proposed subscription by CEO Jeremy Yee and chairman Johnson Chen requiring shareholders' approval.

site_title: US home sellers in 2018 see biggest gains in 12 years
summary: US home sellers in 2018 achieved the largest gains in 12 years, with an average realised gain of $61,000. Homeowners who sold in the last quarter stayed in their properties for an average of 8.3 years, the longest since 2000. Coastal cities saw the most gains, with California leading the way, but growth rates are slowing in some areas, including Seattle. In contrast, 12 metro areas saw home sellers lose money, with the largest average loss of $26,000 in Montgomery, Alabama.

site_title: Decked Out For Chinese New Year
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

To celebrate Chinese New Year, consider decorating your home with auspicious items such as a Golden Pineapple Teapot, Happy Go Lucky piglet, and Phalaenopsis flowers, which symbolize good fortune and prosperity. Luxury brands like Lalique and Gresko offer exclusive pieces, including pig sculptures and embroidered drum stools. Practical items like personalized red packets, Gresko pillows, and Peranakan floral tile fabric coasters are also available. These decorations can add a touch of luxury and festive spirit to your home, making it a welcoming space for visitors during the Chinese New Year celebrations. Prices range from S$13.80 to S$950.

site_title: 'Tremendous' progress in US-China trade talks: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump announced "tremendous" progress in US-China trade negotiations, with talks set to continue in early February. Chinese leader Xi Jinping described relations as at a "critical" stage, with both sides expressing a desire to work together with mutual respect. The White House and Chinese delegation spent a second day of talks, with no specific details on agreements or concessions released.

site_title: Dubai Holding to begin development of new tower
summary: Dubai Holding is set to announce a development project in Downtown Jumeira, featuring a 550m-tall Burj Jumeira tower, homes, office space, and hotels. Construction will start immediately, with the first phase expected to be completed by 2023. The project comes as Dubai Holding explores international investment opportunities amid a prolonged property slump in Dubai, with residential values having declined by 25% from their 2014 peak. The announcement is expected to be made later this week.

site_title: Raising CPF rates for older workers a tough balancing act
summary: The People's Action Party Senior Group has proposed raising older workers' Central Provident Fund (CPF) contribution rates to equal those of younger workers. Currently, rates decrease progressively with age, but the group argues that this disparity is no longer justified, given the changing employment landscape and the importance of mature workers in sectors hit by stricter foreign labour laws. However, raising rates could add a burden on firms, particularly small and medium enterprises, and would need to be carefully calibrated to balance concerns about the impact on employers and the transformation drive.

images.alt_text: The call to raise older workers' Central Provident Fund (CPF) contribution rates is not new, nor are the common objections to it. What does change is the economic context surrounding each instance of this call.

site_title: India's shadow banks face fresh cash shortage risk: Citibank, Credit Suisse
summary: India's shadow lenders face a fresh cash shortage risk due to concerns over debt at conglomerate Essel Group, according to Citibank and Credit Suisse. This could spread through India's money markets, similar to the fallout from landmark defaults last year. The potential shortage could impact the recovery of India's shadow lenders, which were recovering from previous defaults.

site_title: Festive Flicks
summary: Festive films are taking over cinemas, offering alternatives to Jackie Chan's "The Knight of Shadows: Between Yin and Yang". Pang Ho-cheung's "Missbehaviour" features an offbeat plot about friends hunting down breast milk, while Stephen Chow directs "The New King of Comedy", a reboot of his 1999 classic. Both films are set to release in February.

site_title: Europe: Shares flat, macro gloom saps early Federal Reserve boost
summary: European shares ended flat on Thursday, despite a strong January performance, as disappointing economic data and concerns over the European economy weighed on markets. Technical recession in Italy and weak economic indicators, including a decline in German retail and British car production, dampened the mood. Higher crude prices and strong results from Shell and Diageo partially supported the market. Analysts have been cutting profit expectations for European firms, with fourth-quarter earnings expected to grow less than 4%.

site_title: Fresh Face
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several beauty treatments are available for Chinese New Year, promising to give the skin a glowing effect. The d'skin 99.99 Karat Gold Facial Treatment uses gold to improve skin metabolism and reduce wrinkles. Kew Organics' O² Facial Treatment uses hyaluronic acid to boost skin vitality. Hanbang Anti-Glycation Care targets premature aging by infusing nutrients to support skin structure. Rejuran Healer Treatment uses salmon DNA to promote cell growth and collagen remodelling. Prices range from S$99 to S$1,000, with treatments lasting 105 minutes to two hours. Regular sessions are recommended for optimal results.

site_title: Chinese tech firms expand R&D reach into Singapore
summary: Chinese tech firms WeBank and Yitu Technology have expanded their research and development (R&D) reach into Singapore, opening research facilities to explore fintech and artificial intelligence applications. WeBank partnered with Nanyang Technological University (NTU) to establish a fintech research centre, focusing on machine-generated personalized financial insights and services. Meanwhile, Yitu Technology launched its Singapore-based R&D centre to develop AI solutions for smart buildings, natural language processing, and medical diagnostics. The partnerships aim to drive innovation and optimize the financial services space, with a focus on inclusive finance and creating a better quality of life for citizens.

site_title: RHB appoints new Singapore country head
summary: RHB Bank has appointed Danny Quah as the new country head for Singapore, replacing Mike Chan Cheong Yuen. Quah, a veteran banker with nearly 25 years of experience, previously worked at Standard Chartered Bank and Fullerton Financial Holdings. His appointment is expected to bolster RHB's strengths and capabilities in Singapore, with the group managing director stating that Quah's experience will drive business growth in the country and collaboration across the region.

site_title: GuocoLand Q2 profit plunges 83.6% to S$10.9m
summary: GuocoLand's Q2 net profit plummeted 83.6% to S$10.9 million due to lower sales of completed residential units and higher progressive revenue recognition. Revenue fell 61.4% to S$142.9 million. The company attributed the decline to the completion of Sims Urban Oasis and reduced inventory of completed unsold units. Despite this, the group maintains a balanced pipeline of projects, including Guoco Midtown.

site_title: Wellness pack
summary: A Singaporean wellness company, Huiji, offers a Chinese New Year wellness hamper filled with products to promote vitality and well-being. The hamper includes the Huiji Waist Tonic, Fatt Choy Tea, TropiCool, and Huiji Honey, a natural sugar substitute. The gift set, priced at S$78, is available online and aims to help elderly relatives maintain health and energy during the festive season.

site_title: EU-Japan trade deal comes into force to create biggest trade zone
summary: The EU-Japan Economic Partnership Agreement and Strategic Partnership Agreement came into effect on February 1, 2019, creating the world's largest trade zone. The agreement reduces tariffs between the EU and Japan, paving the way for simpler and faster trade, and increasing volume. It also commits to security cooperation on issues such as nuclear proliferation and cybersecurity. The deal stands in contrast to US President Donald Trump's "America First" trade policy and is seen as reaffirming the rules-based international trading system. The agreement is expected to boost the global economy and deepen EU-Japan relations.

site_title: Manufacturing, services firms gloomier about next six months
summary: Manufacturing and services firms in Singapore have become more pessimistic about business prospects in the next six months, with a net weighted balance of 14% and 4% respectively, indicating a worsening of sentiment compared to previous surveys. Most manufacturers expect similar conditions in the first half of 2019, while services firms expect business activity to remain the same. The gloom is attributed to trade tensions between the US and China, with electronics and precision engineering firms being the most downbeat. Experts warn that failure to reach a trade deal could lead to a severe manufacturing collapse.

site_title: Shell's 2018 earnings soar to four-year high
summary: Royal Dutch Shell's 2018 earnings surged to a four-year high of US$21.4 billion, a 36% increase, beating the forecast. The company reported a sharp rise in cash generation, with cash flow from operations reaching US$53 billion and free cash flow rising to US$39.4 billion. Shell's production increased slightly to 3.666 million barrels of oil equivalent per day, while its cost savings continued to filter through operations. CEO Ben van Beurden vowed to maintain discipline on capital investment and grow cash flow and returns in 2019.

site_title: Are stock exchanges really gouging traders?
summary: A study by IEX Group found that Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange charge up to 1,800% more for stock market information than IEX pays for a similar product. The study suggests the exchanges are abusing their power as market leaders due to their high data fees, which could be harming smaller traders. However, critics argue that cost should not be the controlling factor and that supply and demand should dictate prices. The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating market issues, including data fees, but an expert, Brad Katsuyama, questions the effectiveness of simply focusing on cost.

site_title: Dutch historian and author forces discussion on tax avoidance at Davos
summary: Dutch historian and author Rutger Bregman criticized the lack of discussion about tax avoidance at the World Economic Forum's annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland. Bregman argued that wealthy individuals use tax avoidance schemes to evade paying their fair share, and that this issue is a significant contributor to global inequality. His comments sparked a debate with panelists Ken Goldman and Winnie Byanyima, with Byanyima pointing to the struggles of workers in the US and the need for higher taxes to address income inequality. The discussion has resonated with the wider public, with Bregman's remarks being viewed over 6 million times on video.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.90% to 28,193.28, following positive trade talks between the US and China. The US and China hailed the talks as a "tremendous progress." Meanwhile, shares in other Asian markets, including Singapore and Europe, also rose, driven by a focus on US-EU trade talks and strong US economic data.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sevak, GuocoLand, Astaka, AA Reit, CRCT
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation urged caution on trading shares of Sevak due to its rapid price increase. GuocoLand's second-quarter net profit decreased 83.6% to S$10.9 million. Astaka Holdings warned of a net loss for the second quarter. AA Reit's third-quarter distribution per unit dropped 4.6% to 2.50 cents. CRCT's fourth-quarter distribution per unit rose 2.1% to 2.42 cents. These developments may affect trading of these companies' shares.

site_title: Oil prices rise on drop in Saudi crude supply to US
summary: Oil prices rose for a third day on Thursday, driven by lower US imports of Saudi crude, amid OPEC efforts to tighten the market and US sanctions on Venezuela. US WTI crude futures rose 24 cents to $54.47 per barrel, while Brent crude futures increased 36 cents to $62.01 per barrel. The drop in Saudi crude supply, combined with supply disruptions from US sanctions on Venezuela, has led to increased oil prices.

site_title: US- North Korea summit details to be announced next week: Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the details of his upcoming summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un will be revealed early next week. A date and location have been set, despite criticism that Kim has not made sufficient progress toward denuclearization. Trump dismissed concerns from intelligence leaders, saying time will prove him right, and touted "tremendous progress" made with Pyongyang.

site_title: For A Relaxing Valentine
summary: One Farrer Hotel in Singapore is offering a Valentine's Staycation Package at S$485 nett for two persons, featuring a Skyline Studio Room with club benefits and 60-minute couple indulgence treatments at its Spa Retreat. The package includes access to a private pool, gym, and five complimentary meals daily. The Spa Retreat has been awarded "Best Value for Money" by CLEO magazine for its Lifestyle Retreat Getaway.

site_title: Tulip Garden S$907m collective sale to Yanlord, MCL successfully completed
summary: The sale of Tulip Garden, a freehold condominium in District 10, Singapore, has been successfully completed at S$906.9 million. The sale, which was the fourth attempt, was completed on January 31 after market talk of a snag. The condominium, comprising 162 apartments and maisonettes, will yield up to 670 residential units upon development. Each unit owner will receive between S$4.3 million and S$7.6 million, depending on unit size. The sale concludes a long and anxious journey for the owners, who first attempted to sell the property en bloc in 2007.

site_title: Canadian dollar leads currency winners in buoyant Jan
summary: The Canadian dollar led currency winners in January, driven by a 15% rally in oil prices and strong gains in risky assets. The US dollar weakened after the Federal Reserve pledged to be patient with interest rate hikes, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars also gained against the greenback. The Norwegian krone, Australian dollar, and New Zealand dollar have all gained roughly 2% against the dollar in January, despite some investors being cautious about buying these currencies aggressively.

site_title: The Hit podcasters are breaking down Harry Potter, chapter by chapter
summary: Podcasters Mallory Rubin and Jason Concepcion are concluding their 70-episode run discussing every chapter of JK Rowling's Harry Potter series, after a successful run covering HBO's Game of Thrones. The duo, who have a cult following of 17,000 fans, have analyzed the series' themes, rehashed memorable passages, and identified foreshadowing. Their unique approach, similar to Game of Thrones, has allowed for Netflix-style binges. Rubin and Concepcion have read the series multiple times, with Rubin estimating over 30 reads, and attribute their rapid growth to the insatiable appetite for thoughtful discussion about fantasy stories.

site_title: Building a future-ready and smarter Asean
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) has established the Asean Smart Cities Network, aiming to achieve smart and sustainable urban development through the harnessing of disruptive digital technologies. 26 cities from 10 countries are working together to equip people with the right skillsets to build a future-ready and smarter Asean. The project involves integrating socio, political, and technological elements to drive this goal forward.

site_title: Pakistan unexpectedly raises rate for fifth straight meeting
summary: Pakistan's central bank unexpectedly raised its key rate for the fifth straight meeting to 10.25% from 10% as the nation seeks foreign aid to avoid a balance-of-payment crisis. The decision was made by Governor Tariq Bajwa amid a surge in inflation. The move is seen as a step to curb inflation and stabilize the economy, but it may also impact borrowing costs for consumers and businesses. The decision was a surprise to economists, with only one predicting a 100-basis-point hike.

site_title: Blooming Wealth
summary: The Flower Dome at Gardens by the Bay features a "Dahlia Dreams" floral display showcasing over 5,000 dahlias in 100 varieties until February 24. The display includes a Chinese garden landscape and a "Thousand Blooms" chrysanthemum arrangement featuring 500-1,500 flowers from a single plant. The event highlights dahlias as auspicious flowers for Chinese New Year, symbolizing good luck and wealth.

site_title: Parag Khanna
summary: Parag Khanna, a 41-year-old global strategist and author, has written a new book, "The Future is Asian," which advances a theory about Asia's leading edge in economic and technological progress in the 21st century. He argues that Asia, particularly Singapore, is at the forefront of this progress, and that the continent is on the path to a multipolar world order. Khanna, who holds degrees from Georgetown University and the London School of Economics, has previously written bestselling books on geopolitics, including "The Second World." He has worked at various think tanks and has advised governments, and has become a prominent voice on Asian affairs, with a growing confidence in investing in each other and ASEAN becoming the market maker for Asia.

site_title: US, China hail major 'progress' in trade talks
summary: The US and China announced significant progress in their trade talks, with US President Donald Trump hailing "tremendous progress" and Chinese President Xi Jinping expressing hope for further cooperation. The two sides agreed to increase Chinese imports of US agricultural, energy, and industrial goods, as well as services, and to cooperate on intellectual property protection. The talks ended with a March 1 deadline to avoid further escalation in tariffs, which could harm the global economy. US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin will travel to China in mid-February for the next round of talks.

images.alt_text: The United States and China said their trade war negotiations resulted in major progress as the clock ticks on a March deadline to avert a massive escalation of tariffs that could bruise the global economy.

site_title: The seeds for a new Orchard Road are already taking root
summary: Singapore's Orchard Road shopping and entertainment belt is undergoing revitalization efforts, aiming to become a comprehensive destination that pays homage to its history while innovating and evolving. The government seeks feedback from stakeholders and the public to gather ideas for the revitalization, which includes making the strip more pedestrian-friendly, introducing local retail showcases, and enhancing the identities of its four sub-precincts. The goal is to create a lifestyle destination that attracts visitors beyond shopping, addressing stiff competition from other cities and adapting to changing retail trends.

site_title: Airbus says in talks with Emirates on vital A380 deal
summary: Airbus is in talks with Emirates over a deal for 36 A380 jets, with discussions potentially involving conversion to A350s. The order, made last January, was a lifeline for the A380, which has struggled to win new orders since its commercial launch. Deliveries are due to start from next year, but if the deal doesn't materialize, Airbus may need to shut down A380 production. The A380's future is uncertain, with Airbus hoping to secure new orders in China and the US to sustain production for at least the next decade.

images.alt_text: Airbus said Thursday it was in discussion with Emirates over a deal for 36 of its A380 jets made last year, amid reports the Gulf carrier is considering converting some or all of the order to the smaller A350, potentially casting doubt on the future of Europe's superjumbo.

site_title: Goldman Sachs offices ditch single-use plastics
summary: Goldman Sachs has announced that it will no longer provide single-use plastics such as water bottles and cutlery in its offices and cafeterias. The bank has replaced these items with aluminum cans, glass bottles, and compostable cups. This move is part of Goldman's push to reduce the amount of trash it puts in landfills. The change was implemented globally starting last week, according to Cindy Quan, the bank's global head of Environment, Social, and Governance.

site_title: Firm that sold fake social media activity settles with NY state
summary: New York Attorney General Letitia James announced a settlement with Devumi, a company that sold hundreds of millions of fake Twitter followers. Devumi, which went out of business last year, had at least 200,000 customers, including celebrities and politicians, who bought fake accounts to boost their online profiles. The company was found to have sold fake accounts using stolen identities and misled customers about the authenticity of its products. The settlement requires Devumi to pay a $50,000 fine and could set the stage for further crackdowns on social media consumer fraud.

site_title: January was Australia's hottest month ever: govt
summary: Australia recorded its hottest month ever in January, with temperatures exceeding 30°C for the first time in recorded history. A persistent high-pressure system and global warming trends contributed to the unusually warm conditions. The heatwave exacerbated an already severe drought, fueled bushfires, and caused mass fish deaths, with over a million fish killed in the Murray-Darling river system. The country's eastern states experienced below-average rainfall, with a late January monsoon bringing flooding to the northeastern state of Queensland.

site_title: Fed rate pause keeps gold near 8-month highs
summary: Gold prices held near eight-month highs at $1,320.65 per ounce, rising 0.1% on Thursday, after the US Federal Reserve paused its monetary tightening cycle, citing rising uncertainty about the economic outlook. The dollar weakened, boosting gold's appeal. Central banks' surge in gold purchases, the highest since 1967, drove global demand up 4% last year, with China and India expected to remain key markets.

site_title: ThaiBev beefs up stake in Vietnam F&B to 99% for US$14.7 million
summary: Thai Beverage (ThaiBev) has acquired a 50% stake in Vietnam F&B Alliance Investment Joint Stock Company for US$14.7 million, increasing its stake to 99%. The acquisition was made at 10,000 Vietnamese dong per share. The deal is not expected to impact ThaiBev's earnings per share and net tangible assets. The remaining 1% is held by existing Vietnamese shareholders.

site_title: Genting Singapore says casino licence of Resorts World at Sentosa renewed for three more years
summary: Genting Singapore announced that the casino licence of Resorts World at Sentosa has been renewed for three more years, starting from February 6. This renewal is a significant development for the company, allowing it to continue operating the casino.

site_title: Cities need to grow up, not out, to survive, researchers warn
summary: Urban areas worldwide are expected to grow by 80% by 2030, but cities may struggle to survive unless they focus on vertical growth, prioritizing development within existing city centers, rather than outward expansion. Poor land records and weak regulations contribute to inefficient land use, increasing inequality and environmental risks. A study combining satellite and radar data found that access to municipal services drops sharply just 5km from city centers, highlighting the need for more efficient urban planning.

site_title: Dovish Fed gives relief to equity bulls
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.5% on Thursday, driven by dovish US Federal Reserve comments and positive tech earnings in the US. The Straits Times Index gained 15.79 points to 3,190.17. Analysts say while the Fed's shift may provide short-term relief, other factors such as a weakening global economy and US-China trade tensions need to be resolved for the bull market to be sustained.

site_title: Lo Hei Redux
summary: Several restaurants in Singapore are offering unique reunion dining experiences for Chinese New Year. Burnt Ends & Meatsmith features Smoked Mandarin Jujubes and Mandarin Sorbet, while Salted & Hung offers Maple Cured Roast Pork Belly. Labyrinth serves Pen Cai with braised abalone and grilled oysters, and SKAI presents the edible Piggy Bank dessert. Level 33 offers a modern yusheng dish, and Jaan reinvents the traditional yusheng with smoked trout and vegetables. Meanwhile, Mythz & Myths serves an inspired yusheng with a combination of Chinese and Western ingredients.

images.alt_text: Burnt Ends & Meatsmith: Smoked Mandarin Jujubes, Mandarin Sorbet, and Buah Keluak Pork Belly
Salted & Hung Maple: Cured Roast Pork Belly, Lamb Neck Char Siew and Suckling Pig
Nouri: Peach, Prawn and Scallop Tartare, with Prickly Ash, Sancho, Pistachio and Pine Nuts

site_title: Tesla's shrinking growth machine
summary: Tesla's fourth-quarter earnings show positive revenue growth, more than doubling from the previous year, despite missing earnings expectations. However, the company's capital expenditure (capex) in the quarter was significantly lower than expected, at 65% of depreciation. This has raised concerns about how Tesla will fund its growth, particularly with a US$920 million convertible bond due soon. Despite a low capex, Tesla's free cash flow was about US$910 million, and operating expenses were also lower, with sales and general administrative expenses being the lowest since 2017.

site_title: East-West Reunion
summary: Expat and western-trained chefs in Singapore are incorporating traditional Chinese New Year (CNY) dishes with their own twist, creating a unique fusion cuisine. This phenomenon is seen as a reflection of foreign-born chefs immersing themselves in local culture and ingredients. Examples include Italian octopus yusheng and suckling pig brined in citrus and herbs. This blending of ideas is not seen as opportunistic, but rather a creative expression of personal style and cultural assimilation. The result is a "melting pot of ideas" that showcases the diversity of Singapore's culinary scene.

site_title: Art Week 2019: Drama At Its Finest
summary: Singapore Art Week 2019 was marred by chaos and conflict, culminating in the last-minute cancellation of Art Stage by its president, Lorenzo Rudolf. However, the event's organizers and participants came together to create an interim fair, ARTery, to rescue stranded galleries. Despite the drama, the week showcased various exhibitions, including the successful debut of SEA Focus, a government-backed platform promoting Southeast Asian art. Key awards included the Machiavelli of the Month for Rudolf, Accidental Heroes for Mae Anderson and Usha Chandradas, and Breakthrough Prize for SEA Focus and Alvin Ong's solo show.

site_title: Astaka warns of second-quarter losses on weak property sales
summary: Astaka Holdings, a Malaysian property developer, has warned of a net loss for the second quarter ended Dec 31, 2018, due to weak property sales. The loss is attributed to allowances for losses at the Bukit Pelali @ Pengerang project and lower sales of unsold units at The Astaka @ One Bukit Senyum project. The company's financial results will be released by Feb 14.

site_title: Mortgage growth in Dec hits record low
summary: Mortgage growth in December reached a record low of 2% in Singapore, according to preliminary data. The slowdown is attributed to property cooling measures, which have led to a 64.9% decline in new mortgage loan applications. Overall bank lending is expected to remain soft in 2019 due to cautious business sentiment, with consumer loans growing just 1.5% and business loans steady at a three-month high of 4.1%.

site_title: Classic theatre
summary: A 26-year-old Singaporean play, "Off Centre", tackles the theme of how mentally-ill individuals fall in love, exploring the struggles and discrimination faced by minority groups. Written by Haresh Sharma and directed by Alvin Tan, the play follows a pair of mentally-ill lovers as they navigate their place in the world. This revival features the original 1993 cast and has become a classic Singaporean text, studied by thousands of students. It is considered a powerful exploration of the human experience, transcending its focus on mental illness to address broader social issues.

site_title: Reversal of policy risks lifts market in January
summary: Singapore's stock market experienced a 3% increase in January, with the total market capitalization rising by S$27 billion to S$919.4 billion. The recovery was driven by a dovish US Federal Reserve stance and positive trade negotiations between the US and China. Key sectors such as mining, manufacturing, property, and construction firms saw significant gains, with some analysts attributing the market's positive performance to a "Capricorn Effect", where January typically sees a market turnaround.

site_title: Lions In The City
summary: The lion dance originated in China as a way to scare away the monster Nian, with villagers dressing as lions and making noise to frighten it. Today, the dance is performed during Chinese New Year to bring good fortune, with two types of lion dances: northern and southern. The southern style, commonly performed in Singapore, involves a lion being taunted by a clown, overcoming obstacles to retrieve a red packet. Performances have evolved, with modern lion dances incorporating acrobatics and human pyramids, but still maintaining their cultural significance.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ascendas Reit secured a S$181.2 million development project for Grab's headquarters in Singapore, with a 6.4% net profits interest yield. The 11-year lease includes a renewal option. Starhill Global Reit's Q2 2019 gross revenue and net property income fell 2.7% and 2.4% y-o-y, mainly due to lower rentals from retail spaces. Despite negative rental reversions, the company expects slight negative rental reversions in the future.

site_title: Extended June 30 deadline for banks to meet e-payment user protection guidelines
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has extended the deadline for banks to meet e-payment user protection guidelines from January 31, 2019, to June 30, 2019. The guidelines aim to standardize duties for secure e-payment transactions, simplify error resolution, and apportion liability between financial institutions and users. Consumers are encouraged to enable notification alerts for transactions and report unauthorised transactions immediately. The MAS also plans to implement a comprehensive notification alert process and framework for unauthorised transactions after the guidelines come into force.

site_title: Offeror for LTC to exercise compulsory buyout of shares from dissenting shareholders
summary: LTC Corporation, a Singapore-based steel trading and property group, has received sufficient valid acceptances to exercise its right of compulsory acquisition of shares from dissenting shareholders. As of the close of offer, the offeror and its concert parties own approximately 91.01% of the total shares. Trading in LTC's shares is expected to be suspended on February 1, and the company will delist from the Singapore Exchange following the acquisition. Mountbatten Resources, the investment vehicle for LTC's controlling family, will proceed with the acquisition on or after February 21.

site_title: Singapore employment up in 2018 with retrenchments at 6-year low: MOM data
summary: Singapore's employment increased in 2018, with retrenchments at a six-year low. The annual average unemployment rate also decreased compared to the previous year. Despite a slight easing in economic growth from 3.6% in 2017 to 3.3% in 2018, the labour market improved. However, Singaporean workers saw slower income growth compared to the previous year. The Manpower Ministry reported these findings in its latest estimates released in January 2019.

site_title: Trump says US-China trade talks 'going well' but wants to see Xi
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed optimism about high-level trade talks with China, stating that meetings are "going well" with good intent and spirit. However, no final deal will be made until he meets with Chinese President Xi Jinping. Trump's comments come as US-China trade talks aim to address intellectual property and technology transfer issues, with a March 1 deadline agreed upon by both sides.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, indicating strong investor interest. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to fresh tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower H2 revenue and similar operating losses compared to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing a former DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC are deepening cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Rolls-Royce gets German passport for jet engine designs ahead of Brexit
summary: Rolls-Royce, a UK-based aerospace company, has relocated the design approval process for its jet engines to Germany to avoid potential regulatory delays and sales disruptions after Brexit. The move, approved by the European Aviation Safety Agency, will allow Rolls to sell engines outside Europe without needing new regulatory deals. This shift will enable the company to continue selling engines globally, as EU and non-EU regulatory frameworks differ. The move is part of Rolls' efforts to ensure smooth operations in the event of a "no-deal" Brexit, set to occur on March 29, 2019.

site_title: GE reports 4Q profits, sees US settlement on mortgages
summary: General Electric reported a profitable fourth quarter with a profit of $574 million, despite a large annual loss due to one-time expenses. The company reached a $1.5 billion settlement with US officials over subprime mortgages and is working to turn around its power division, which suffered a $872 million loss.
