CEO H Lawrence Culp stated that a turnaround is on track, with a focus on de-leveraging the balance sheet and strengthening businesses.

site_title: US: Facebook lifts Nasdaq, S&P at open; downbeat earnings weigh on Dow
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq opened higher on Thursday, driven by Facebook's upbeat earnings, while the Dow fell 0.24% due to downbeat earnings reports. The S&P 500 rose 4.44 points to 2,685.49, and the Nasdaq gained 25.09 points to 7,208.17. This follows the Federal Reserve's pledge to be patient on further interest rate hikes, extending a rally.

site_title: China calls for harmony as it welcomes Qatar emir amid Gulf dispute
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping welcomed Qatar's emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani, calling for unity and harmony in the Gulf region amid a long-standing dispute between Qatar and its Arab neighbors. China has largely stayed out of the dispute, but has played host to senior Qatari officials and expressed support for diplomatic efforts to resolve the issue. Xi and Al Thani signed memorandums of understanding on diplomatic training, trade, and the Belt and Road initiative, with Qatar agreeing to supply China with liquefied petroleum gas.

site_title: Dress to Impress
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Chinese New Year fashion trends feature bright pops of color and psychedelic patterns. Designers incorporated mid-century modern Scandinavian styles and hippie tie-dye prints into their collections. To make a style statement, wear a colored bottom. In other news, a new restaurant, Thevar 2.0, showcases mod-Indian cuisine, while NCSS rallies partners to better engage volunteers. Additionally, CMC Markets partners Sophia Women to drive financial literacy for women, and a CEO's salary can be up to $1.39 million for a comfortable retirement. These stories highlight various events and initiatives in Singapore.

site_title: Clearbridge to raise S$11 million in convertible bond issuance to fund acquisitions
summary: Clearbridge Health, an integrated healthcare company, plans to raise S$11 million through a convertible bond issuance to fund acquisitions of medical clinics, centers, and laboratories in South-east Asia. The 7% per annum interest-bearing bonds are convertible into new shares at S$0.28 per share, representing a 78.1% premium. The funds will be used for acquisitions, joint ventures, and working capital purposes, with part of the proceeds going towards the proposed investment in PT Indo Genesis Medika. The company's management team, including CEO Jeremy Yee, has subscribed for the bonds, demonstrating confidence in the group's growth prospects.

site_title: Anson House to be put on market soon
summary: Anson House, a 13-storey office block in Singapore, is expected to go on the market soon with agents anticipating offers in the region of S$218 million, translating to about S$2,500 per square foot. The property is currently 80% occupied and has a high yield of 2.7% based on its recent expansion and the sale of nearby Twenty Anson for S$516 million. The building's location is set to improve with the upcoming Shenton Way and Prince Edward Road MRT stations, and it has been boosted by its proximity to the Greater Southern Waterfront area.

images.alt_text: Car park space on the fourth level of the 13-storey building was converted into office space late last year.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower amid President Trump's new tariff on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss for the second half. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC are planning to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, ahead of Singapore's GDP data release.

site_title: Thai party ousted in 2014 coup picks Thaksin loyalist for PM in elections
summary: Thailand's Pheu Thai Party, ousted in 2014, has chosen Sudarat Keyuraphan, a Thaksin Shinawatra loyalist, as its main candidate for prime minister in upcoming elections. Sudarat, a 57-year-old veteran politician, is a longtime ally of Thaksin and has accepted the leadership role. Pheu Thai has vowed to abide by electoral laws, which bar Thaksin from influencing the campaign. The party's main opponent, the Palang Pracharat Party, has nominated junta leader Prayuth Chan-ocha as its leading candidate, who may accept the nomination. Elections are set for March 24.

site_title: Singapore shares gain on Thursday's close
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.5% on Thursday, driven by gains in real estate investment trusts (Reits) following a Fed pause on interest rate hikes. The Straits Times Index closed at 3,190.17. Mapletree Logistics Trust, Ascendas Reit, and Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust saw significant gains. The rally marks a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: GuocoLand Q2 bottom line falls 83.6 per cent to S$10.9m
summary: GuocoLand's net profit for Q2 2019 decreased 83.6% to S$10.9 million due to completed residential project sales and lower completed residential sales. Revenue fell 61.4% to S$142.9 million, attributed to higher progressive revenue recognition. The company has a balanced pipeline of projects, including Guoco Midtown, and maintained a stable gross profit margin of 30%. Net profit for the first half fell 84% to S$37 million.

site_title: British MPs' break scrapped as Brexit clock ticks down
summary: The British government has scrapped MPs' February holiday to prepare for Brexit on March 29, amid chaos and confusion over strategy. The decision comes as the UK and EU still have not agreed on a withdrawal pact, and lawmakers are working to pass vital legislation. Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman stated that the government is taking steps to ensure the Brexit deadline is met, but Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt suggested that extra time may be needed if a deal is approved days before the deadline. European leaders have rejected the UK's bid to rewrite the divorce deal, warning of a potential no-deal Brexit.

site_title: UBS bets on investment banking, wealth tie-up in bid for growth
summary: UBS, the world's largest wealth manager, is expanding its corporate offerings for entrepreneur clients by creating a new wealth management team. Christian Rosset, a corporate banking veteran, will lead the team. The goal is to increase crossover between UBS's investment and corporate banking capabilities in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa, targeting entrepreneurs and their firms. This move aims to boost business and strengthen corporate offerings, with a focus on building a bridge between wealth management and corporate banking.

site_title: India's jobless rate hit 45-year high in 2017/18
summary: India's unemployment rate surged to a 45-year high of 6.1% in 2017-2018, according to a withheld government survey. The data, released by the National Sample Survey Office, showed 65 million youth were jobless, with 7.8% unemployment in urban areas and 5.3% in rural areas. The rate of labor force participation declined to 36.9% from 39.5% in 2011-2012, sparking criticism of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's economic policies ahead of the general election.

site_title: Mastercard quarterly profit rises 33%
summary: Mastercard Inc reported a 33% rise in adjusted quarterly profit to US$1.6 billion, or US$1.55 per share, in the fourth quarter. Net revenue rose to US$3.8 billion, beating analysts' estimates. This growth was driven by increased transaction volumes during the holiday shopping season. In contrast, rival Visa Inc reported an 18% rise in quarterly profit. The results mark a positive start to the year for Mastercard, despite the ongoing impact of tariffs on global trade.

site_title: RHB appoints new Singapore CEO
summary: RHB Bank has appointed Danny Quah as its new country head for Singapore and CEO of RHB Bank Singapore, replacing Mike Chan Cheong Yuen. Quah, a veteran banker with nearly 25 years of experience, will bolster the bank's strengths and capabilities in Singapore. His extensive regional leadership experience and deep understanding of the Singapore and Asean markets will drive business growth in the country and across the region.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's manufacturing and services sectors expressed pessimism about their business prospects in the first half of 2019, according to surveys. The labor market improved in 2018 with low retrenchments and a lower unemployment rate. Bank lending remained flat in December. China's WeBank partnered NTU on a fintech research center. Economists expect a generous and expansionary Budget 2019. The Straits Times Index gained 0.5% on Thursday, driven by a rise in Singapore shares.

images.alt_text: Manufacturing and services firms have grown more downbeat about their business prospects in the first half of this year, with both sectors now expressing overall pessimism, according to two separate surveys released on Thursday.

site_title: MAS delays banks' implementation of e-payment user protection guidelines to June 30
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has delayed the implementation of e-payment user protection guidelines for banks and credit card issuers from January 31 to June 30, 2019. The guidelines aim to set standards for secure e-payment transactions and simplify error resolution processes. MAS has granted more time to banks to implement the guidelines due to the complexity of system changes required. Consumers are encouraged to monitor notification alerts for transactions and report unauthorised transactions immediately to their banks.

site_title: My SME Story Ep 1: Limited Edt
summary: Singapore's small-medium enterprises (SMEs) contribute significantly to the country's economy, generating S$200 billion in gross value added in 2017. The Business Times' "My SME Story" series highlights six SMEs, starting with Limited Edt, Singapore's first specialty sneaker boutique, which has shaped local sneaker culture and expanded to multiple stores across the island. The series will run from January to April and be available on various platforms.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Thursday, following strong gains in Tokyo and on Wall Street. London's FTSE 100 index climbed 0.4% to 6,967.01 points, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices advanced 0.7% and 0.4% respectively. The rally was attributed to gains in mining and healthcare stocks, as investors continued to monitor US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Banks drag on Australia shares ahead of inquiry report; NZ rises
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index closed down 0.4% on Thursday, weighed down by financial stocks' 1.5% decline ahead of the Royal Commission's final report on Feb 4. The "Big Four" banks lost between 1.6% and 2.5% each, while Janus Henderson shares fell 3.3% after closing three Australian equities funds. Mining stocks rose 1.0% and energy stocks climbed 1% on higher commodity prices and oil price jumps. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.7%.

site_title: China's first digital-only bank WeBank partners NTU on fintech research centre
summary: China's digital-only bank WeBank has partnered with Singapore's Nanyang Technological University (NTU) to establish a fintech research centre. The five-year collaboration aims to develop machine-generated personalized financial insights and services. Researchers will focus on behavioural science, advanced analytics, and blockchain technology to provide accessible wealth management advice to the general public. The partnership is part of WeBank's efforts to drive inclusive finance through fintech innovation.

site_title: US, China take the lead in race for artificial intelligence - UN
summary: The US and China are leading the global competition in artificial intelligence (AI), according to a UN World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO) study. The US has the largest AI patent portfolio, with IBM holding 8,920 patents, while China is strong in "deep learning" and accounted for 17 of the top 20 academic institutions involved in AI patenting. Despite accusations of intellectual property theft, China has embraced the global intellectual property system and is a "serious player" in AI.

site_title: Unilever Q4 sales miss expectations
summary: Unilever reported lower-than-expected fourth-quarter sales, with underlying sales rising 2.9% compared to 3.5% expected by analysts. The company attributed the miss to inflation in Argentina and flat volume growth in developed markets, particularly in the Americas and Europe. Unilever expects 2019 market conditions to remain challenging, with underlying sales growth in the lower half of its 3-5% forecast range. The company remains on track for its 2020 goals, despite reporting full-year sales growth of 3.1%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.58 points to 1,683.53. Volume reached 2.3 billion lots worth RM2.4 billion, with gainers narrowly outnumbering losers 425 to 384.

site_title: Shell's 2018 profits soar to four-year high
summary: Royal Dutch Shell reported a 36% rise in 2018 profits to US$21.4 billion, the highest since 2014, beating forecasts due to cost savings. The company's net income for the fourth quarter rose 32% to US$5.688 billion. Shell's deep cost cuts introduced after the 2014 market downturn had filtered through, exceeding forecasted figures. The company's full-year forecast of US$20.98 billion also surpassed expectations.

site_title: Secura Group names new chief
summary: Secura Group has appointed Barry Kan Kheong Ng as CEO and executive director, effective February 1, 2019. Ng, 63, has nearly three decades of experience in regional management and business development, previously working at Wearnes Automotive and Fastrack Autosports (Iskandar). The company also appointed Joey Matthias Lim and Christina Teo as non-executive and independent directors, respectively. Tan Wee Han has resigned as executive director and chief financial officer due to increased work and personal commitments. Ng's appointment marks the end of a nearly year-long search for a new CEO.

site_title: There's no stopping Thailand's baht
summary: Thailand's baht has rallied 4.2% against the dollar this year, its largest gain in emerging Asia, driven by factors such as strong foreign direct investment, a current-account surplus, and subdued inflation. The Thai central bank is expected to raise interest rates in the second half of the year, boosting the currency. Analysts predict the baht will reach 31 by year-end, but some warn of potential risks, including the impact of China's slowing growth and the country's first general election since a coup in 2014.

site_title: India's largest lender is finding fear can be a potent weapon in recovering loans
summary: State Bank of India (SBI) is finding success in recovering loans by leveraging fear of the two-year-old bankruptcy law in India. With 1.8 trillion rupees in bad corporate debt, SBI is negotiating with founders who prefer to avoid court proceedings. The lender is offering one-time settlements of up to 40% and is willing to take a haircut. However, consensus building and fresh funding from investors are challenges in the fledgling law, which is better suited for cases involving multiple lenders. SBI plans to raise provisioning to 70% by March 2020 to clean up its balance sheet.

site_title: UK house prices stagnate ahead of Brexit: Nationwide
summary: British house prices rose 0.1% in annual terms and 0.3% in monthly terms in January, according to Nationwide. This slowdown in the housing market is attributed to Brexit uncertainty. Economists had expected flat prices and a 0.2% monthly rise. The data adds to signs of a slowing housing market ahead of Brexit.

site_title: Singapore real wages expected to grow 3% in 2019: Korn Ferry
summary: Singapore's real wages are expected to grow 3% in 2019, driven by demand for highly-skilled workers. This is up from 2.3% in 2018 and outpaces the 2.6% Asian average. However, pay increases for sectors lacking talent, such as engineers and IT staff, are not in line with demand. Additionally, performance ratings and variable bonus payouts are not aligned, with little differentiation in actual bonus payouts between employees with above and below expectation performance ratings.

site_title: SGX RegCo urges caution when dealing in Sevak shares, citing unusual price movements
summary: SGX RegCo urges caution when trading Sevak shares due to unusual price movements, despite a 61% rise from S$2.51 to S$4.05 between Sept 17, 2018, and Oct 19, 2018. Sevak's market capitalization increased by S$14.8 million to S$44.4 million on Jan 25, 2019. The regulator is reviewing trades and will take necessary actions. Sevak announced its intention to exit the watch-list on Jan 24, 2019.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower on institutional sell off ahead of holidays
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index ended lower on Thursday due to institutional sell-offs ahead of Chinese New Year holidays. The decline followed data showing China's factory activity contracted for a second straight month, raising concerns about global economic growth. The South Korean won gained, while bond yields fell. The US Federal Reserve's dovish stance on future rate hikes also weighed on the market. Despite this, the Singapore stock market rose 0.4% on Thursday, with investors remaining positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: China offered to nearly halve cost of Malaysia's US$20b rail project: sources
summary: China has offered to nearly halve the cost of Malaysia's $20 billion East Coast Railway Link (ECRL) project, potentially saving the country millions of dollars. However, the government's decision to cancel the contract remains uncertain due to conflicting statements from Malaysian ministers. The project, which was launched by the previous administration, has been marred by ballooning costs, lack of transparency, and concerns over Malaysia's sovereignty. Negotiations with China continue, with the finance ministry indicating a desire for cheaper proposals.

site_title: Hundreds more Chinese companies just warned on profits
summary: Hundreds of Chinese companies have warned on profits, with 373 out of 2,400 firms reporting losses or deteriorated financial results. Airlines, brokerages, and manufacturers have been hit by soaring fuel costs, a weak yuan, and an economic slowdown. The number of firms warning on earnings is expected to rise, with many opting to take a hit from stricter accounting rules rather than report years of losses. Analysts predict the outlook for some companies will remain bleak, even if the economy strengthens.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,188.85, up 0.46%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Thursday afternoon, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.46% at 3,188.85. Advancers outnumbered decliners 203 to 115, with heavily traded counters including Ezion Holdings and Rex International. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data, with investors brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: China company that paid debt in ham instead of cash is running low on pigs
summary: A Chinese company, Chuying Agro-Pastoral Group Co, is facing a cash crunch due to a low pig supply, exacerbating its existing debt issues. The company, which paid bond investors in ham last year, now revised its 2018 performance forecast to a net loss of 2.9 billion yuan. Chuying Agro has 2.3 billion yuan of bonds to repay this year and is struggling to buy enough feed for its pigs, leading to a higher death rate. The company's debt woes are part of a broader economic slowdown and deleveraging drive in China.

site_title: LG Electronics Q4 profit plunges 80% as rivals crowd TV business
summary: LG Electronics' Q4 profit fell 80% to 76 billion won due to higher marketing costs and intense competition in the TV business. Revenue decreased 7% to 15.8 trillion won, with the mobile business contributing to widening losses. Analysts attribute the decline to Chinese rivals and global economic headwinds. The company's share price dropped 1.5% after the results were released.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing, services sentiment turns gloomier for H1 2019
summary: Singapore's manufacturing and services sectors have become more pessimistic about their business prospects in the first half of 2019, with a weighted 76% of manufacturers expecting similar conditions to the fourth quarter of 2018. In the services sector, a weighted 12% of firms are optimistic, while 16% foresee slower business, resulting in a net weighted balance of 4% expecting worse conditions. The biomedical and transport engineering clusters are exceptions, with biomedical manufacturing expecting a favorable operating environment and transport engineering anticipating an improvement in business conditions.

images.alt_text: Manufacturing and services firms have grown more downbeat about their business prospects in the coming six months, with both sectors now expressing overall pessimism, according to two separate surveys released on Thursday.

site_title: Central banks buy most gold since 1971: industry body
summary: Central banks purchased the most gold in nearly 50 years in 2018, adding 651.5 tonnes to their reserves, a 74% increase from the previous year. Total gold demand rose 4% to 4,345.1 tonnes, driven by central bank buying and investment in bars and coins amid trade tensions and Brexit uncertainty. The World Gold Council attributed the surge to a multi-decade high in central bank buying, with European bar and coin demand declining 11% and UK demand jumping 12% in 2018.

site_title: Alibaba stock rallies on handsome profit beat, optimistic commentary
summary: Alibaba reported a 37% increase in quarterly profit, beating market expectations, with shares rising 6% on the news. Despite a slowdown in Chinese economic growth and US tariffs, Alibaba attributed its growth to domestic consumption and corporate transformation. The company's cloud business showed promise, with revenue rising 84%. Alibaba's executive vice-chairman Joe Tsai downplayed concerns about the trade tensions, stating that the company's exposure to tangible effects of trade tariffs is small.

site_title: Indonesia set for mega bank shake-up in bid to create national champion
summary: Indonesia is set to create a mega bank by putting four state banks under a holding company, PT Danareksa, in May. The four banks, Bank Mandiri, Bank Rakyat Indonesia, Bank Negara Indonesia, and Bank Tabungan Negara, will be overseen by the holding company, which aims to support the government's development agenda and improve competitiveness. The move is expected to streamline decision-making and raise capital, but some analysts worry it may make the sector less attractive to foreign banks, potentially impacting returns on investment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end on a high
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.08% on Thursday, tracking regional gains after the Federal Reserve signaled it would slow down interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index closed at 27,942.47, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.35%. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.70%. The gains follow recent regional rallies, with Singapore stocks notching a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares rose Thursday, tracking regional gains after the Federal Reserve signalled it would slow down its pace of interest rate hikes.

site_title: Budget 2019 likely to be generous and expansionary: Maybank Kim Eng economists
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 is expected to be generous and expansionary, with a possible early general election in mind. The government is expected to register an overall deficit of around 1.5% of GDP, with a focus on boosting pre-election and social spending. Key measures include the Merdeka Generation Package, estimated to cost S$8 billion, and increased funding for national security and defence. Major tax increases are also likely, with foreign worker levies to be raised by S$50 to S$100 per month.

site_title: AI startup Avanseus eyes US$8m to US$12m series A round after TNB Aura-led S$1.5m bridge
summary: Singapore-based AI startup Avanseus Holdings has raised S$1.5 million in a convertible bridging round led by TNB Aura to support global expansion, new customer delivery capabilities, and additional development of solutions. The startup is eyeing a US$8 million to US$12 million series A round, following a previous seed capital raise of US$2.5 million. Avanseus uses AI technology to predict faults in telecommunications and other networks, with projected revenue growth of four to five times in 2019.

site_title: Singapore bank lending flat in December: MAS preliminary data
summary: Singapore bank lending remained flat in December, with loans totaling S$671.7 billion, unchanged from the previous month. This is a decrease from a year ago, when total lending rose 3%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore attributed the slowdown to broad weakness across both business and consumer loans.

site_title: India's still-reeling shadow banks face fresh cash shortage risk
summary: India's shadow lenders face a fresh cash shortage risk due to concerns over debt at conglomerate Essel Group. Essel's billionaire founder Subhash Chandra has increased debt levels and reduced ability to service borrowings, prompting worries about potential defaults. Mutual funds holding Essel debt may face redemptions, leading to a sale of non-bank financing company debt and tightening liquidity in the corporate bond market. This could exacerbate a cash shortage, posing a threat to India's still-reeling shadow lenders.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close up more than 1% on dovish Fed
summary: Tokyo shares rose over 1% on January 31, 2019, following overnight rallies on Wall Street, as the US Federal Reserve expressed caution about future rate hikes. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 20,773.49, and the Topix index at 1,567.49.

site_title: Malaysia swears in new king after historic abdication
summary: Malaysia installed a new king, Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad Shah, after his predecessor, Sultan Muhammad V, stepped aside following reports of a marriage to a Russian ex-beauty queen. The 59-year-old sports-loving sultan took the oath of office in a televised ceremony, marking the first time a king had abdicated before the end of his term. The new king, who is also the ceremonial ruler of central Pahang state, will serve a five-year term as Malaysia's 16th king.

site_title: Feng shui masters say Trump secrets could be nosed out in Year of Pig
summary: Feng shui masters predict turbulence and division for world leaders, particularly US President Donald Trump, as the Chinese zodiac turns into the Year of the Pig. They foresee past secrets and scandals being exposed, potentially leading to impeachment. Hong Kong-based masters also predict a challenging year for politicians, with Britain facing internal problems and a potential "hard Brexit." However, they believe the US-China trade war may not yield breakthroughs due to conservative thinking. A good year is expected for Prince Harry's wife Meghan, who is expecting a baby.

site_title: Foxconn changes could dent Trump's re-election effort
summary: US President Donald Trump's re-election hopes may be dented by uncertainty surrounding a $10 billion Foxconn factory in Wisconsin, which the company plans to shift from manufacturing to research, despite promising 13,000 jobs. The project's shift could fuel criticism of the already unpopular deal, which has sparked deep division in the state over $3 billion in subsidies. Polls show Trump faces a tenuous situation in Wisconsin, with 49% of registered voters planning to vote for someone else and 46% strongly disapproving of his handling of the job.

site_title: Yitu Technology opens AI R&D centre in Singapore; to add some 70 staff over 3 years
summary: Yitu Technology, a Chinese AI solutions provider, has launched its first R&D centre in Singapore, with 30 staff members. The centre aims to develop AI solutions for smart buildings, natural language processing, and medical diagnostics. Over the next three years, Yitu plans to triple its R&D staff count to around 100 employees, with a focus on attracting top talent through an AI hackathon. The centre will collaborate with industry partners, local universities, and research institutes to drive R&D and innovation in the region.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS ups OUE Commercial Reit to 'buy' on upturn in office market
summary: DBS Equity Research has upgraded its call on OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) to "buy" due to an expected upturn in spot office rents. Analysts Mervin Song and Derek Tan raised their target price to S$0.60 from S$0.47. The upgrade comes despite the potential 18% dilution from the conversion of convertible perpetual preferred units (CPPUs). As of the publication, OUE C-Reit was trading 1.02% higher at S$0.495.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday, STI up 0.6% to 3,192.41
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.6% to 3,192.41 on Thursday, driven by gains from AEM and Venture, with 101 gainers outweighing 24 losers. Trading volume was 88.3 million shares worth S$128.9 million.

site_title: Firms that sold fake social media accounts settle with New York state
summary: New York state has reached a settlement with four companies that sold fake social media accounts, marking the first time such activity is considered illegal. The companies, owned by German Calas, sold fake followers and likes on platforms like Twitter and YouTube using bots and stolen identities, earning around $15 million between 2015 and 2017. The settlement, announced by Attorney General Letitia James, prohibits the companies from engaging in similar behavior again, but does not impose fines.

images.alt_text: Companies that sold fake social media activity have reached a settlement with the state of New York in a case that, for the first time, established such activity as illegal, the state's attorney general said Wednesday.

site_title: 7 men arrested for suspected marine oil theft off Singapore's southern coast
summary: Seven men, aged 33-44, were arrested on January 29 for allegedly stealing 2.7 tonnes of marine gas oil off Singapore's southern coast. The men, three crew members from a marine service provider and four from a foreign-registered tugboat, were detained in a joint operation with the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore. The oil was sold to the tugboat crew without the service provider's knowledge. The tugboat has been seized for further investigation, with the police vowing to prevent and detect illicit activities in Singapore waters.

images.alt_text: The tugboat has been seized for investigations.

site_title: S&P upgrades New Zealand's outlook to positive
summary: Standard & Poor's upgraded New Zealand's credit outlook to "positive" due to expected budget surpluses in the early 2020s, allowing the country to reduce debt and provide resilience to future risks. The sovereign credit rating remains at AA+, the second-highest rating. The upgrade is a positive for Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern's Labour Party-led coalition, but economic risks persist due to high levels of external and domestic leverage, and the impact of US-China trade tension and Brexit.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with a 0.72% gain, rising to 27,842.05, following the Federal Reserve's signal to slow interest rate hikes. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains of 0.43% and 0.34%, respectively. The rally comes as investors remain optimistic despite ongoing trade uncertainty and conflicting views on the Fed's future moves.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally, dollar down as Federal Reserve signals slower rate hikes
summary: Asian markets rallied after the Federal Reserve signaled it would slow down interest rate hikes, boosting equities and the dollar's value. The US central bank chairman, Jerome Powell, said the case for lifting rates had weakened, and the Fed may slow down the reduction of its securities holdings. This move provided relief to investors and led to a surge in Wall Street and Asian markets, with Tokyo ending the morning 0.9% higher. The news also had a positive impact on trade talks between China and the US, with China's yuan reaching a six-month high.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on Federal Reserve guidance, mining gains; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 5,906.80, driven by the Federal Reserve's dovish commentary, firm iron ore prices, and strong domestic earnings. Mining stocks extended their rally for a fourth straight day, with Fortescue Metals Group reaching a 16-month high. Energy stocks also gained, boosted by rising oil prices and improved production guidance. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.7%, with dairy giant a2 Milk Co leading the gains.

site_title: UK car investment stalls amid Brexit fears
summary: UK car investment fell by 46.5% in 2018 to £589 million due to Brexit uncertainty, according to the Society of Motor Manufacturers. This decline, combined with a 9.1% drop in car production, has raised concerns about the industry's future. Chief Executive Mike Hawes warned that leaving the EU without a deal would be "catastrophic" for the industry, emphasizing the need for a deal to unlock investment and avoid friction at borders and a loss of competitiveness.

site_title: UOB, Grab kick-start partnership with digital initiatives, customer benefits
summary: UOB and Grab have launched a partnership with digital initiatives, offering UOB Cards privileges directly on Grab's mobile app. UOB cardmembers can apply for the UOB One Card via the Grab app or QR codes in Grab cars, and enjoy perks such as up to 10% cashback on Grab rides and a credit card sign-up offer of S$100 in Grab vouchers. The alliance aims to make banking more accessible and create greater value for customers, with plans to integrate rewards and dining programmes, and embed Grab's booking function into UOB's mobile banking app.

site_title: Lazada to migrate RedMart onto platform in ramp-up of supermarket plans for SE Asia
summary: Lazada, a subsidiary of Alibaba, is integrating RedMart, a homegrown e-grocer, onto its platform as part of its plan to accelerate supermarket growth in Southeast Asia. The integration will enable shoppers to buy groceries and fresh produce alongside Lazada's other products on a single platform. The migration will take place on March 15, with existing RedMart customers able to continue shopping until 11:59pm on March 14. The move aims to capitalize on the rising demand for online supermarket shopping in the region.

images.alt_text: Alibaba-backed Lazada will be integrating homegrown e-grocer RedMart onto its platform on March 15, as part of the group's plan to accelerate the growth of its supermarket business in South-east Asia.

site_title: US Midwest gripped by deep freeze blamed for several deaths
summary: A deep freeze gripped the US Midwest, causing three more deaths and halting mail and classes in many cities, including Chicago. Temperatures plummeted to -28°C in Chicago, with wind-chill temperatures reaching as low as -41°C in Minnesota and -35°C in North Dakota. The extreme cold was caused by a displacement of the polar vortex, leading to record-low temperatures and widespread disruptions. Over eight deaths have been reported since Saturday, with residents forced to huddle indoors and seek refuge at warming centers.

images.alt_text: A woman walks along Michigan Avenue above the frozen Chicago River in Chicago, Illinois, on Jan 29, 2019.

site_title: From Rings to Ringo: Peter Jackson helms Beatles documentary
summary: Peter Jackson is working on a documentary about the making of The Beatles' album "Let It Be," 50 years after its recording in 1969. The film, based on 55 hours of unseen footage and 140 hours of audio, will showcase the band's creative process and interactions in the studio. Jackson says the documentary will dispel myths about the band's final album being marred by rivalries and infighting, instead highlighting the camaraderie and creativity of the Fab Four. The project is being made with the cooperation of surviving band members and their families.

site_title: Budget 2019 expected to register deficit of S$2.5b for FY19: DBS economist
summary: Singapore's FY19 budget is projected to register a deficit of S$2.5 billion, down from an expected surplus of S$3.3 billion in the previous financial year. Despite this, policymakers have a "solid position" to roll out expansionary fiscal policies, with a total forecast budget surplus of S$19 billion for the term. DBS economist Irvin Seah suggests the government can be "slightly more aggressive" in its fiscal policy, but fiscal sustainability remains paramount, particularly due to escalating health and social spending and reliance on Net Investment Return Contributions.

images.alt_text: The fiscal balance for FY2019 is projected to register a deficit of S$2.5 billion, down from an expected surplus of S$3.3 billion in the previous financial year, according to the final report in a three-part series by DBS.

site_title: Facebook sees higher profits, more friends
summary: Facebook reported a record quarterly profit of $6.9 billion, with revenue increasing 30% to $16.9 billion and the number of monthly active users rising 9% to 2.32 billion. Despite scandals, the company's image has not been dented, and its global user base continues to grow. Net profit rose 61% from the same period last year, with daily active usage in North America and Europe increasing. Facebook plans to invest in new technologies and hire thousands of employees to address concerns about manipulation and abuse.

site_title: China January factory activity shrinks for 2nd month in a row: official PMI
summary: China's manufacturing sector activity shrank for the second consecutive month in January, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 49.5, below the 50-mark separating growth from contraction. Weak demand, job cuts, and new orders pointing to further pressure in coming months contribute to the slowdown. Analysts predict the Chinese economy may experience a sharper-than-expected slowdown if the trade war with the US drags on, raising concerns about global growth and prompting policymakers to reassess stimulus efforts.

site_title: US would feel disruptions from hard Brexit: Federal Reserve's Powell
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated the US economy would feel disruptions from a hard Brexit, despite expecting the impact to be "material" to be minimal. The US has been monitoring the Brexit situation closely, and a hard exit would likely involve disruptions. While the situation is unprecedented, the Federal Reserve is watching it "very carefully".

site_title: Over 300 China firms flag full-year losses: state media
summary: Over 300 Chinese listed firms are expected to report full-year losses of over 100 million yuan each, with 129 firms anticipating losses exceeding 800 million yuan. The losses are attributed to asset writedowns and late payments from suppliers, resulting from China's slowing economy and trade frictions. This is the latest sign of pressure on Chinese companies, which face reduced profit growth and tough access to loans.

site_title: Axiata caught in a bind as it mulls future of its investment in M1
summary: Axiata Group Bhd, Malaysia's largest wireless giant, is weighing its options on its decade-long investment in Singapore operator M1 Ltd. Axiata must decide by February 18 whether to tender its shares into a takeover offer valued at S$1.9 billion. The company considers it unlikely a rival bidder will emerge, and Axiata may have little choice, as a rejection could leave it holding a significant stake in an unlisted company. M1's board has urged investors to accept the offer, which has been extended by two weeks.

site_title: Samsung net income misses estimates as chip demand slides
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a fourth-quarter net income of 8.3 trillion won (S$10.05 billion), missing analyst estimates. The decline in memory chip demand, coupled with weakening smartphone sales, contributed to the results. Operating profit from the chip unit was 7.8 trillion won, while the smartphone division posted 1.5 trillion won in operating profit, down from 2.4 trillion won a year earlier. Samsung expects a rebound in demand for memory chips and OLED screens from the second half of this year, but the company faces intense competition from Chinese rivals and struggles to maintain growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher after US rallies on dovish Fed
summary: Tokyo shares rose 1.34% on Thursday, following overnight US rallies, as the Federal Reserve expressed a cautious stance on future rate hikes. The Nikkei 225 index climbed to 20,832.91, while the Topix index gained 1.28%. The US Federal Reserve's dovish stance on interest rates boosted global markets.

images.alt_text: Tokyo shares opened higher on Thursday following overnight rallies on Wall Street, as the US Federal Reserve voiced a cautious stance about future rate hikes.

site_title: Singapore Academy of Law rolls out new initiatives under innovation programme
summary: The Singapore Academy of Law (SAL) is launching new initiatives under its Future Law Innovation Programme (Flip), marking its first anniversary. Flip aims to redesign the delivery of legal services, providing services to small and medium law firms to adopt technology and improve efficiency. The program also includes Asia's first accelerator to groom legal tech startups and a new course at Singapore Management University (SMU) to reskill legal professionals. Additionally, SAL and SMU will release an annual report on innovation in the Asia-Pacific region, aiming to be an innovation roadmap for the legal industry and encourage discussion and collaboration among stakeholders.

site_title: Accuron Technologies to spin out its medtech business to Temasek
summary: Accuron Technologies, a subsidiary of Temasek Holdings, will spin out its medical device business, Accuron MedTech, to be directly owned by Temasek. The move aims to allow Accuron MedTech's management team to focus on global medtech growth and investment opportunities. Accuron MedTech will be a leading vertically integrated urology business, with the spin-out expected to be completed by March 2019. This will enable Accuron Technologies to focus on aerospace and industrial businesses, while Accuron MedTech pursues growth and technology commercialization.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Capital World, OUE C-Reit, Ascendas Reit, Frasers Hospitality Trust, IPC
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean stocks are under watch due to new developments. Minority shareholders blocked Capital World's plan to issue new shares to a convertible bond holder. OUE C-Reit's distribution per unit decreased 34.2% for the fourth quarter, while Ascendas Reit posted a 0.7% increase. Frasers Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security fell 4.3% for the first quarter. IPC Corporation recorded a net profit of $25 million for the full year, reversing a loss the previous year. These developments may impact trading of these companies' shares.

site_title: Who wants Trump to be president? God does, says White House
summary: President Donald Trump has support from above, according to White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders, who stated in an interview that God "calls all of us to fill different roles at different times and I think that he wanted Donald Trump to become president."

site_title: Bangkok is choking on air pollution. The response? Water cannons
summary: Bangkok, Thailand's capital, is experiencing severe air pollution, with vehicle emissions accounting for 60% of the city's chemical haze. To alleviate the smog, officials have deployed water cannons, which have flooded intersections but failed to disperse the pollution. The city's chronic air problem is attributed to unchecked industrialization, urbanization, and lax regulation, with the government's ineffectual solutions and lack of public transportation exacerbating the issue. The World Health Organization estimates that outdoor air pollution caused 4.2 million premature deaths in 2016, and Bangkok's smog has become a rallying cry for citizens, who are criticizing the junta's slow response to the pollution.

site_title: Construction service provider Reclaims Global seeks Catalist listing in Singapore
summary: Reclaims Global, a Singapore-based eco-friendly construction service provider, is seeking a listing on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. The company, which specializes in recycling, excavation, and logistics services, posted revenue of S$13.1 million for the six months in fiscal 2019, down 6.2% from the previous year. It expects to incur a loss of S$92,000 for the period. Proceeds from the listing will be used to expand its operational capacity and fund expansion through acquisitions or joint ventures.

site_title: Nico Steel invests 3.83m yuan to ramp up production facility in Suzhou, China
summary: Nico Steel Holdings' subsidiary, Nico Steel Technology (Suzhou) Co, has invested 3.83 million yuan (S$768,000) to expand its electroplating facility in Suzhou, China. The new production line aims to increase capacity by 120% to 44 tonnes of metal alloys per month, while a wastewater treatment system reduces discharge by 27% and may lead to 20-40% cost savings. The move aligns with the Chinese government's efforts to reduce pollution in the city.

site_title: Fans call out Ariana Grande for misspelled Japanese tattoo
summary: Pop star Ariana Grande's new Japanese tattoo, intended to represent her hit single "7 Rings," has sparked controversy after fans pointed out a misspelling error. The tattoo, which translates to "shichirin" - a small charcoal grill, was posted on Instagram before being widely shared on Twitter, with many mocking the mistake. Grande acknowledged the error and joked about it, but some users defended her, calling the tattoo "good." The incident has led to a lighthearted online debate about cultural sensitivity and the importance of double-checking tattoo designs.

site_title: Federal Reserve keeps US interest rate unchanged, says will be 'patient'
summary: The Federal Reserve kept the US interest rate unchanged at 2.25-2.5%, with Chairman Jerome Powell signaling the central bank will be "patient" in evaluating the economy before making any further adjustments. The decision comes amid concerns about the economy, including low inflation and global economic developments, and reflects the growing uncertainty about the outlook. The Fed also indicated it may alter the pace of reducing its massive securities holdings.

site_title: Japanese factory output falls amid trade war worries
summary: Japan's factory output fell 0.1% in December, marking the second consecutive month of decline, amid concerns over the US-China trade war's impact on exports and global growth. Economists expect fragile factory activity to deteriorate further as overseas economies slow, posing risks to Japan's export-reliant economy. The US and China are in high-level talks to ease trade tensions, but policymakers remain worried about the ripple effects on the economy. Factory output is forecast to decline in January, with some expecting a possible decline in February as well.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda warned of growing risks to the economy from trade protectionism and faltering global demand last week as the central bank cut its inflation forecasts and stuck to its stimulus programme.

site_title: UK consumers are most pessimistic on economy in seven years
summary: UK consumers are the most pessimistic about the economy in seven years, with a GfK gauge of expectations approaching levels seen during the 2008 financial crisis. The lack of clarity over the UK's exit from the European Union has led to widespread worry, with confidence in the economic outlook remaining at its lowest since 2013. The uncertainty has also affected businesses, with a separate report showing a decline in confidence. The situation is expected to remain turbulent in the coming months, with the UK's EU-exit date looming on March 29.

site_title: Microsoft delivers robust profit, but shares take a hit
summary: Microsoft reported a profit of $8.4 billion in its fiscal second quarter, driven by gains in cloud computing and business services. Revenues rose 12% to $32.5 billion, slightly below market forecasts, resulting in a 3.5% drop in after-hours trade. The company's transformation has led to a market valuation of over $800 billion, tying it with Amazon. Key highlights include a 29% jump in LinkedIn revenues, a 20% increase in intelligent cloud services, and a 39% gain in Surface hardware revenue.

site_title: Boeing bullish on 2019 despite US-China tensions
summary: Boeing reported a strong fourth quarter with profits of $3.4 billion and revenues of $28.3 billion, up 3.1% and 14.4% from the same period last year, respectively. The company remains bullish on 2019, anticipating higher profits and delivering 895-905 commercial planes, despite US-China tensions. Boeing expects China to account for nearly one-fifth of new planes built over the next 20 years, driven by air travel growth in the country outpacing global trends and overall Chinese economic growth.

images.alt_text: Boeing reported a strong fourth quarter on Wednesday and offered a bullish 2019 outlook as executives expressed measured confidence in the prospects for a US-China trade agreement.

site_title: Samsung Electronics forecasts weaker 2019 earnings on slowing chip demand
summary: Samsung Electronics forecasted weaker 2019 earnings due to a slowdown in demand for memory chips, citing "macroeconomic uncertainties" and inventory adjustments by major customers. The company's fourth-quarter operating profit dropped 29% to 10.8 trillion won, with revenue falling 10% to 59.3 trillion won. Sales of memory products and OLED panels are expected to revive in the second half of the year, but overall annual earnings are expected to decline. The decline is attributed to a global slowdown in chip demand, China's economic growth, and the ongoing US-China trade war.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics warned of weaker earnings in 2019 as it posted a 29 per cent drop in fourth-quarter operating profit on Thursday, hit by a slowdown in demand for memory chips.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare gets demand letters from ex-CEO for payment of S$3.4m
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare received demand letters from the solicitors of former CEO and major shareholder Fan How Kin, seeking payment of approximately S$3.4 million for allegedly owed loans through a corporate vehicle. The company is consulting with legal advisors on addressing the claims. This comes after Fan was made a bankrupt in 2017 and is a defendant in proceedings for breach of fiduciary duties and unlawful conspiracy.

site_title: Oil gains on tighter US supply, Venezuela sanctions
summary: Oil prices rose 1.73% on Wednesday, settling at $54.23 a barrel, as US crude inventories rose 919,000 barrels and gasoline stocks fell 2.2 million barrels. The gains were driven by tighter US supply and investor concerns about supply disruptions following US sanctions on Venezuela's oil industry. Market participants remained worried about global economic growth and the potential for supply disruptions due to the sanctions, which aim to freeze sale proceeds from Venezuela's oil exports.

site_title: US raises questions about Chinese subsidies in trade document
summary: The US has raised questions about Chinese subsidies in a trade document, accusing China of hiding some programs and disclosing others it does not need to. The document, circulated at the World Trade Organization, lists 70 questions about Beijing's subsidy programs, including subsidies for China's fishing industry and government guidance funds. China is fighting a trade dispute at the WTO over its export prices, and the US has called for improved transparency about trade policies. The US has teamed up with Japan and the EU to push for improvements in international trade.

site_title: Confluence of factors sends oil prices 2% up, but outlook is choppy
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Wednesday due to a convergence of factors, including the Venezuelan crisis, renewed optimism over US-China trade talks, and OPEC's supply cuts. The US sanctions on Venezuela's oil industry and the pledge to slash output aim to ease concerns over a supply glut. However, analysts caution that the market is still volatile, with concerns over demand growth, refining margins, and US shale output. The outlook for oil prices remains choppy, with some expecting a slowdown in US output growth and others warning of potential price drops if refining margins weaken.

site_title: Facebook sees higher profits, more friends
summary: Facebook reported a record quarterly profit of $6.9 billion, with revenue rising 30% to $16.9 billion and a 61% increase in net profit. The company added 209 million new users, reaching 2.32 billion monthly active users, despite facing data protection scandals. Facebook's shares jumped 7.7% after the earnings release, with co-founder Mark Zuckerberg attributing the growth to the company's focus on social issues and investment in new technologies. Analysts say the trust issue remains crucial for Facebook's future growth.

site_title: Digital Realty to build third Singapore data centre in Loyang
summary: Digital Realty Trust announced plans to build its third data centre in Singapore, located in Loyang, adjacent to its existing Digital Loyang I facility. The new 12,800 sq m facility is expected to be operational by Q3 2020 and will offer 50 MW of IT load. The project is part of a significant expansion of the company's Loyang connected campus, with a total footprint of 34,000 sq m. The facility will provide critical power capacity to regional and global customers, including IBM, Facebook, and Uber, and is strategically located near the Changi North Cable landing station.

site_title: Airbus hit by 'cyber incident'
summary: Airbus detected a cyber incident that resulted in unauthorized access to data in its commercial aircraft division, but did not affect commercial operations. The incident involved the unauthorized access of some Airbus employees' personal data, including professional contact and IT identification details. Airbus experts are working to understand the incident and reinforce system security. The company reported the incident within 48 hours of its discovery, as required by the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation. Airbus employs around 129,000 people worldwide.

images.alt_text: The European aerospace group Airbus said Wednesday it had detected an incident that "resulted in unauthorised access to data" in its commercial aircraft division.

site_title: World's first Michelin star for a Pakistani restaurant
summary: A Pakistani restaurant, New Punjab Club, in Hong Kong has achieved the world's first Michelin star for a Pakistani restaurant, 18 months after opening. The restaurant's success is attributed to its use of traditional tandoor ovens, frequent trips to Lahore to perfect recipes, and a kitchen overseen by head chef Palash Mitra. The Michelin star recognition has been a source of pride for Hong Kong's Pakistani community and is seen as a step towards shedding light on the country's often overlooked cuisine.

site_title: US: Stocks rally on earnings, dovish Federal Reserve
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, driven by a dovish Federal Reserve announcement and strong earnings from Apple and Boeing. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1.8%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 1.6% and 2.2% respectively. The Fed kept interest rates unchanged and signaled a cautious approach to further rate hikes, offering "reassurance" to investors. Apple's quarterly profit of $20 billion and Boeing's better-than-expected fourth-quarter results also boosted the markets.

site_title: Europe: Luxury stocks sparkle, Wirecard weighs on Dax
summary: Luxury stocks in Europe surged on Wednesday, with LVMH shares jumping 6.7% after upbeat results, boosting the Stoxx 600 index 0.25%. Britain's FTSE 100 rose 1.6% due to a weaker pound, while Hermès, Gucci owner Kering, and Burberry also saw significant gains. However, Wirecard fell 13.3% after denying allegations of financial wrongdoing, and Frankfurt's DAX index declined. Earnings growth expectations have been lowered, with analysts predicting 3.6% year-on-year earnings growth in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Fed likely to delay further rate hikes as it grapples with delayed data
summary: The US Federal Reserve is likely to delay further interest rate hikes due to the delayed release of key economic data following the recent partial government shutdown. Analysts expect the Fed to leave its benchmark overnight lending rate unchanged, as the sudden economic fog makes it difficult for policymakers to assess the economy. The Fed's decision comes after a strong US economy was followed by a decline in consumer confidence, weakening wholesale prices, and a slowdown in home sales, with global trade also experiencing a downturn.

site_title: HiDoc launches telehealth mobile app
summary: Singapore-based telehealth startup HiDoc has launched its mobile app with a flat consultation fee of S$120, allowing users to consult medical specialists via video conferencing or receive a report within 24 hours. Founded by Singapore Medical Group (SMG) executives, HiDoc is seeking angel investors and small private equity funds for pre-Series A funding and is in the final stages of applying to join the Ministry of Health's regulatory sandbox. The platform currently has 15 specialists, mostly from SMG, and offers a Patient Health Records function and delivery service for prescriptions.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: M1's Q4 2018 results showed softer revenues, driven by equipment sales and lower wireless service revenues. Despite a 17% increase in staff costs, analysts maintain their target prices, with Maybank Kim Eng raising forecasts and CDL Hospitality Trust expecting 4% compounded annual growth in distribution per unit over the next three years. The companies also express optimism for 2019, with potential upside if Konnectivity implements structural changes to revenue generation and costs.

site_title: The sun is setting on ultra-cheap solar panels
summary: China's ultra-cheap solar panels are set to become more expensive, with prices expected to rise by 10-15% within two years, according to Eric Luo, president of China's GCL System Integration Technology. The price drop, which reached 30% last year, was triggered by China's shift in solar policies, but the market is now adapting to consolidation and higher costs. Despite this, the global solar industry is expected to continue growing, with China, the US, and India driving demand, and renewables accounting for 31% of US electricity generation by 2050.

site_title: Will EU bend to May's mandate for changes to Brexit deal?
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May has secured a mandate from Conservative MPs, Northern Ireland's Democrat Unionists, and some Labour and independent MPs to renegotiate the Brexit deal with the EU. However, European Council President Donald Tusk and other EU leaders have refused to change the withdrawal agreement, instead hinting at alterations to the non-binding "statement of future relations" after Brexit. May will meet Tusk and Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadker to open the door to further negotiations, aiming to avoid a "no-deal" exit from the EU.

images.alt_text: If Mrs May achieves a new deal she can take it back to Parliament for a vote in a fortnight's time.

site_title: Aussie dollar surges on inflation data; euro drifts
summary: The Australian dollar surged more than half a percent against the US dollar on inflation data, which exceeded forecasts and prompted some speculators to unwind short positions. The data led to a stabilisation in interest rate expectations, boosting the Aussie. Meanwhile, the euro remained in a tight range around US$1.14 levels, and the Chinese yuan reached a six-month high. US-China trade talks begin this week, and markets expect the Fed to keep interest rates on hold in 2019.

site_title: Time to wean the people off expecting goodies from the Budget?
summary: The Singapore Budget 2019 is expected to focus on key areas such as education, healthcare, security, and defence, with Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasizing the need for fiscal responsibility. Economists and experts predict that the Budget may include tax breaks or rebates, but the Ministry of Finance is trying to shift the focus away from one-off generosity. Eliminating handouts from the Budget could help wean Singaporeans off expecting goodies and reinforce the government's push for expanded revenue sources.

site_title: Egotistical billionaires dream of presidency
summary: Former Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz is considering a presidential run as an independent candidate in 2020, following in the footsteps of other wealthy business figures such as Michael Bloomberg and Mark Zuckerberg. The trend of big-ego billionaires entering politics is rooted in the 1970s, when voters sought out "outsiders" after scandals like Watergate and the Vietnam War. A Supreme Court decision in 1976 allowed unlimited self-funded campaigns, giving wealthy candidates an advantage. The rise of 24-hour news cycles and social media has created a platform for high-profile businesspeople to explore presidential runs, often blurring the line between qualifications and wealth.

site_title: PAP advocacy group proposes equal CPF contribution rates for all age groups
summary: A People's Action Party (PAP) advocacy group has proposed equal Central Provident Fund (CPF) contribution rates for all age groups in Singapore, aiming to boost older workers' retirement adequacy and ensure they are paid the same as their younger colleagues for the same job. Currently, CPF contribution rates decrease progressively after the age of 55. The PAP.SG report also includes recommendations on flexible work arrangements, volunteering, healthcare, and social support for older workers.

site_title: China pushes through changes to foreign investment law as US trade talks start
summary: China has accelerated plans to introduce a new foreign investment law, which will ban forced technology transfer and better protect intellectual property rights. The law, set to be voted on by the National People's Congress in March, aims to boost legal protection for foreign investment and attract more foreign investment to China. The move comes as US-China trade talks began in Washington, with the US setting a deadline of March 1 for a deal or further tariffs. The new law is seen as a significant step towards creating a more equitable playing field for foreign and domestic companies in China.

site_title: Trade drama, Fed meeting keep investors on alert
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index retreated 0.42% to 3,174.38, with 1.4 billion shares worth S$1.17 billion changing hands. Investors were on edge due to US-China trade talks and the US Federal Reserve's policy review. Despite a pause in expected Fed hikes, senior investment strategist Esty Dwek warned that markets shouldn't be complacent, predicting a possible hike in June if data stabilizes and trade tensions escalate. Index heavyweights including DBS and OCBC led losses, while offshore and marine stocks, such as Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, gained.

site_title: Top 1,000 firms in Singapore clock record profits, revenue: DP Info study
summary: Singapore's top 1,000 firms achieved a record-breaking combined earnings of S$210.7 billion in 2019, surpassing the previous high of S$182.8 billion in 2018. This represents a 13% growth from 2018, with total revenue reaching S$3.15 trillion, the highest since the ranking began 32 years ago.

site_title: Home prices in 20 US cities rise at slowest pace since 2015
summary: US home prices in 20 cities rose 4.7% year-over-year in November, the slowest pace since 2015, with the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller index falling short of median estimates. Nationally, home-price gains slowed to 5.2%. The housing market slowdown is attributed to declining sales and affordability issues, but economists expect it to stabilize due to tax cuts, rising wages, and economic health.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ASL Marine Holdings received consent from bondholders to extend maturity dates of their notes, including a 5-year extension to March 28, 2025, and a 5-year delay to October 1, 2026. Frasers Hospitality Trust reported a 4.3% decrease in distribution per stapled security and 1.2% decline in net property income for the first quarter of 2019, mainly due to weaker performance in Malaysia and Japan portfolios. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: Japan's retail sales up more than expected in December
summary: Japan's retail sales rose 1.3% in December, exceeding expectations and easing concerns about private consumption amid economic pressure. Sales increased 4.1% on clothes and 4.4% on home appliances. The boost may ease policymakers' worries about the impact of a sales tax increase scheduled for October. However, a sustained rebound in private consumption is uncertain due to a slowing global economy and unresolved trade disputes, including the Sino-US trade conflict.

site_title: Volvo releases brake on special dividend after good Q4 results
summary: Volvo reported a fourth-quarter operating income of 10.60 billion crowns, slightly ahead of expectations, and will pay a special dividend of 5 Swedish crowns per share. The company reiterated its 2019 market demand outlook, citing robust demand in Europe and North America. Volvo had previously warned of a provision due to emission limits, but the results exceeded forecasts. The company's strong cash generation and positive Q4 results led to the special dividend proposal.

site_title: Where Europe's biggest fund manager is putting its cash
summary: Amundi Asset Management, Europe's largest asset manager, favors emerging markets such as India, Russia, and Chile due to their stronger fundamentals and lower political risks. The firm also likes China, Indonesia, and other countries with high-yielding currencies and sustainable debt levels. This stance contrasts with some other analysts, including HSBC, which believes developing economies need to improve to justify higher returns. Amundi is cautious on Turkey and guarded on South Africa and Argentina due to balance-of-payments deficits and upcoming elections.

site_title: US$150m plot of land hits Bel Air market, house not included
summary: A 10.6-acre plot of land in Bel Air, Los Angeles, has hit the market for $150 million, with the option to build a 60,000-square-foot house. The land, previously divided into eight separate lots, was acquired by Domvs London and Junius Real Estate Partners in 2014 and rezoned into three larger properties. The property has been improved with "tens of millions" of dollars in investment, featuring a level, shovel-ready plot with potential for a large subterranean level.

site_title: VW keeps its global sales crown over Toyota
summary: Volkswagen retained its global sales crown in 2018, delivering 10.8 million vehicles worldwide, surpassing Toyota's 10.6 million. The German car maker credited demand from China, but noted the market is slowing down. VW's sales were bolstered by its top position in the world's largest market, China, while Toyota's sales rose 2% due to demand outside its domestic market. The shift towards electric and self-driving cars is expected to pose challenges for manufacturers, with VW and BMW warning of trade spats and stricter emission rules.

site_title: Lawyer sues Apple over FaceTime bug
summary: A Houston lawyer, Larry Williams II, has sued Apple over a FaceTime bug that allegedly allowed an unknown person to eavesdrop on his private conversation with a client. The bug, discovered in iOS 12.1, allowed users to hear the other person before they picked up the call. Apple has since remotely disabled multi-person FaceTime and promised to release a software update to fix the issue. Williams is seeking unspecified punitive damages for negligence, product liability, and other claims. The lawsuit comes after Apple mitigated the problem, but Williams believes his privacy was intruded upon without consent.

site_title: Wurst night ever? Taste takes a holiday at German sausage hotel
summary: A German sausage hotel, the Bratwurst Hotel, has opened in Georgensgmünd, offering a unique experience with sausage-themed decor, food, and workshops. The hotel aims to promote local butcher shops and combat declining meat consumption in Germany. Owner Claus Boebel, a fourth-generation butcher, has invested 700,000 euros in the renovation and has seen brisk business since its opening last September. The hotel caters to foodies and tourists, offering a blend of local colour and traditional German cuisine.

site_title: Shopping to lifestyle destination: New plans unveiled for Orchard Rd
summary: Singapore's Orchard Road is set to become a lifestyle destination with new plans unveiled by the Singapore Tourism Board and other authorities. The plans include more green spaces, a car-free zone, and enhanced pedestrian connectivity. Four sub-precincts will be created, each with distinct identities to cater to various interests. The Orchard sub-precinct will remain the retail heart, while the Somerset and Dhoby Ghaut sub-precincts will feature youth-oriented and family-friendly offerings, respectively. The plans also include tree-planting initiatives and rejuvenation of Istana Park.

site_title: Four hotels fined for anti-competitive behaviour: CCCS
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has fined four hotels, including Capri by Fraser Changi City Singapore, Village Hotel Changi, Village Hotel Katong, and Crowne Plaza Changi Airport Hotel, a total of S$1.5 million for exchanging commercially sensitive information and infringing the Competition Act. The hotels shared confidential corporate customer-related information, including preferential non-public rates, from 2014 to 2015, which likely influenced their conduct in the market and placed them in a position of advantage over their customers. The CCCS noted that such practices are injurious to competition and can result in higher rates and less competitive terms.

site_title: Oil industry braces for turmoil from US sanctions on Venezuela
summary: The US has imposed large-scale sanctions on Venezuela's state-run oil company PDVSA, freezing its assets and requiring US firms to pay for oil using accounts controlled by the opposition party head. The sanctions aim to drive President Nicolas Maduro from power, amid economic collapse and an exodus of millions of Venezuelans. Oil traders and US companies are seeking work-arounds, but experts doubt they can evade the restrictions, which could have a minimal impact on the US consumer but could have unanticipated effects on the US economy.

site_title: Myanmar's progress towards a bond market boon to private, state firms
summary: Myanmar is making progress towards establishing a bond market, but faces challenges in attracting corporate bond issuers and foreign investors. The country aims to end its reliance on central bank loans by 2020 or 2021 and fund its debt through the bond market. Currently, the government is the sole issuer of bonds, with local banks purchasing most of them. Foreign investors are allowed but have not yet entered the market. To overcome challenges, the government is working to improve investor protections, clarify regulations, and develop a secondary market for bonds. With ambitious expansion plans and a growing pool of potential companies, investors see opportunities in Myanmar's bond market.

site_title: UK consumers rein in borrowing as Brexit looms
summary: UK consumers showed restraint in borrowing, with unsecured consumer lending growing at its slowest pace in four years in December, at 6.6% from 7.2% in November. The slowdown comes ahead of Brexit, with retailers indicating households cut spending due to uncertainty. The Bank of England reported a decrease in mortgage approvals and credit card lending, while foreign investors increased their gilt purchases. Prime Minister Theresa May seeks changes to the Brexit deal, with the prospect of a no-deal Brexit looming in under two months.

site_title: Air NZ flags weaker earnings as revenue growth seen slowing
summary: Air New Zealand has revised its earnings forecast for 2019, expecting pre-tax earnings of NZ$340-400 million, down from NZ$425-525 million, due to slowing tourism and domestic trips, as well as issues with Rolls-Royce engines. The airline's shares dropped 13% to a three-month low. CEO Christopher Luxon stated that the company is reviewing its networks and costs to ensure a strong footing. Revenue growth is expected to remain positive but slower than anticipated, with domestic leisure travel and inbound tourism showing signs of softening.

site_title: Eric Trump urges his father to declare national emergency to build border wall
summary: Eric Trump urged his father, US President Donald Trump, to declare a national emergency to build a border wall if negotiations with congressional Democrats fail. The president's son, executive vice president of the Trump Organization, made the statement during a Tuesday night interview on Fox News, where Sean Hannity agreed that the president would likely declare a national emergency. The move would allow the president to secure $5.7 billion in funding for the border wall without congressional approval, despite concerns from Republicans and potential legal challenges from Democrats.

site_title: OUE C-Reit Q4 DPU down 34.2%
summary: OUE Commercial Reit's (OUE C-Reit) fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) decreased 34.2% to 0.75 Singapore cents due to higher interest expenses from a recent acquisition. Net property income increased 5.6% to S$36.6 million, while revenue rose 9.2% to S$48 million. The full-year DPU slid 25.5% to 3.48 Singapore cents, and distributable income increased 1.9% to S$71.3 million.

site_title: Chinese pork prices to rebound next quarter, world's top exporter predicts
summary: Chinese pork prices are expected to rebound in the second quarter due to a shortage of domestic supply, according to Danish Crown Chief Executive Jais Valeur. The Chinese government has encouraged pig farmers to replenish their herds and bought more pork for its reserves to curb price rises later in the year. The country is battling African swine fever, which has led to the culling of over 900,000 pigs and reached 24 of its provinces.

site_title: US, China officials resume critical trade negotiations
summary: US and Chinese officials resumed critical trade negotiations in Washington, led by Vice Premier Liu He and US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, with a March deadline looming. The talks aim to resolve a trade dispute threatening to plunge the world's two largest economies into a deepening trade war. Despite optimism from US officials, the two sides remain far apart on key issues, and internal US debates over how to proceed may hinder progress. The talks come amid market turmoil and a period of public claims of progress to calm investors.

images.alt_text: Top Chinese and US officials met Wednesday in Washington to negotiate a resolution on a dispute threatening to plunge the world's two largest economies into a deepening trade war.

site_title: Ascendas Reit Q3 DPU up 0.7%
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 0.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.998 Singapore cents for Q3 2018, driven by a 6.6% rise in net property income. The company will develop and manage Grab's new S$181.2 million headquarters, providing a stable income stream. The building, set to complete in 2020, will feature energy-efficient design and is expected to achieve Green Mark GoldPlus certification.

site_title: Malaysia fines Deloitte for failing to report 1MDB irregularities
summary: Malaysia's Securities Commission has fined Deloitte PLT 2.2 million ringgit for failing to report irregularities in a 1MDB Islamic bond sale, which may have affected the state fund's ability to repay creditors. The breaches were described as serious and the fine is the maximum imposed on the accounting firm. Deloitte had failed to obtain enough evidence to determine if advances to 1MDB could be recovered from sukuk proceeds.

site_title: India watchdog members quit over jobs data dispute
summary: India's National Statistical Commission members, Acting Chairman PC Mohanan and member J Meenakshi, resigned over a delay in releasing jobs statistics, sparking controversy amidst an election in the world's largest democracy. The delay, coupled with alleged interference in GDP data, led to criticism of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's job creation record. The commission's vacancies now stand at five, raising concerns about autonomy and state interference in institutions.

site_title: China unveils draft regulations for Nasdaq-style technology board
summary: China has published draft regulations for a Nasdaq-style technology board in Shanghai, aiming to support the development of core technologies and innovative capabilities. The board, targeting tech firms in sectors such as high-tech equipment and biotechnology, will have a registration-based system and less stringent listing criteria, including allowing unprofitable companies and start-ups with weighted voting rights to list. The move is seen as a response to US curbs on China's technology development and aims to make Shanghai an international financial center and hub for technology innovation.

site_title: Big US real estate moguls win as smaller investors denied tax break
summary: US real estate moguls will benefit from a 20% tax deduction, while smaller investors, including part-time property owners and investors with limited hours of involvement, are denied the break. The Treasury Department's final rules restrict the deduction to businesses with significant capital investments and active management, effectively shutting out casual investors and those with less than 750 hours of direct work per year. The decision has been criticized as a giveaway to the wealthy, with some lawmakers and tax experts expressing concern that the IRS may eventually expand the barring of triple net leases to professional developers.

site_title: Shareholders block Capital World from issuing settlement shares
