Both companies' dividend yields are seen providing downside support, but upside is limited, making them unattractive in the short term.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts Q4 DPS down 2.1% to 2.77 S cents
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) reported a 2.1% decline in total distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 2.77 Singapore cents for its fourth quarter, primarily due to lower revenue and net property income (NPI) from three properties. The company cited divestments and renovations as reasons for the decline. However, RevPAR rose 2.6% and average occupancy rate increased by 2.3 percentage points, with Singapore hotels showing a 4.3% year-on-year increase. The company's overall distribution to stapled securityholders was S$33.4 million, a 1.5% drop from the year-ago period.

site_title: Keppel Corp selling 70% stake in Vietnam township project
summary: Keppel Corp is selling a 70% stake in its Vietnam township project, Dong Nai Waterfront City, to Nam Long Investment Corp for S$136 million. The deal is part of Keppel Land's strategy to recycle assets for higher returns. The sale will be done in tranches, with Keppel Land retaining a 30% stake. The transaction is conditional upon regulatory approval and the completion of a demerger.

site_title: Australian businesses ended 2018 with worrying downturn: survey
summary: Australian businesses ended 2018 with a worrying downturn, according to a survey. The National Australia Bank's index of business conditions weakened sharply in December, sliding 9 points to +2, below the long-run average of +6. Sales, profits, and employment all declined, raising concerns for 2019. The survey's business confidence measure held steady at +3, softer than recent months. The disappointing end to the year adds to existing economic concerns, with the index's decline marking a disappointing end to the year.

images.alt_text: A closely-watched index of Australian business conditions weakened sharply in December as sales, profits and employment all took a turn for the worse, a disappointing end to the year that will only add to concerns for 2019.

site_title: Oxley, partner to sell 268 residential units at Dublin Landings for 175.5m euros
summary: Oxley Holdings' wholly-owned subsidiary, Oxley Docklands Quay Three Limited, and National Asset North Quays DAC agreed to sell 268 residential units in Dublin, Ireland to Greystar Europe Holdings for 175.5 million euros. The sale includes units in Blocks B and E of Dublin Landings, as well as external common areas and 210 carpark spaces. The sale is expected to be completed on February 27, 2019. This marks the second major sale by Oxley in Ireland, following a 204 million euro deal in January.

site_title: US charges Huawei in technology theft, sanctions violations
summary: The US Justice Department has charged Huawei with technology theft and sanctions violations, including 13 charges against CFO Meng Wanzhou and three affiliates related to violating US sanctions on Iran. Ten US federal charges were also filed against two Huawei affiliates for stealing robot technology from T-Mobile. The charges, which do not allege Chinese government involvement, are expected to escalate tensions between the US and China. A hearing is set for February 6, with the US requesting extradition of Meng Wanzhou by January 30.

images.alt_text: The US Justice Department on Monday unveiled sweeping charges against Chinese telecommunications giant Huawei in two cases likely to ratchet up tensions between the two superpowers - including that of a top executive arrested in Canada on a US warrant.

site_title: North Korea's push to use more coal clouds environmental future
summary: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un has announced a plan to increase the domestic use of coal, despite its toxic air pollution effects, due to the country's economic struggles under international sanctions. Coal power plants and oil-fired plants produce nearly 50% of North Korea's electricity, with households relying on coal for cooking and heating. The increased reliance on coal could worsen pollution, with North Korea's air pollution mortality rate being the world's highest at 238.4 deaths per 100,000 population. Experts warn that the plan could have deadly implications, both domestically and in neighboring countries, particularly South Korea, where up to 20% of air pollutants are estimated to originate from the North.

images.alt_text: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un sees coal as a key way to boost the economy, but burning more coal may worsen pollution in a country already choking on some of the world's most toxic air.

site_title: Singaporeans urged to plug into Asean to tap geographical edge
summary: Singapore needs to be more plugged into Asean to tap its geographical advantage and stay ahead, according to Economic Development Board managing director Chng Kai Fong. Many Singaporeans prefer to study or intern abroad, particularly in the US and Europe, rather than in Asean. This lack of understanding and engagement can lead to missed opportunities and talent being lost to other countries. Chng identified four key areas for Singapore to work on, including understanding Asean better and promoting inclusivity and unity.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as big earnings week kicks off
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, starting a heavy week for earnings reports. The Dow Jones dropped 0.9%, the S&P 500 fell 0.8%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 1.1% after Caterpillar and Nvidia reported weaker-than-expected profits due to China's slowing sales. This week's earnings calendar includes major companies like Apple and Amazon, and a Federal Reserve meeting. Analysts say China is the key topic in the market, despite rising expectations for a cautious interest rate approach and hopes for a US-China trade deal.

site_title: Ascott Reit DPU up 5% in Q4 to 2.15 S cents
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) reported a 5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.15 Singapore cents in Q4 2018, driven by higher revenue and gross profit. Revenue rose 2% to S$136.5 million, while gross profit increased 3% to S$63.4 million. The company attributed strong operating performance to the US, China, and Japan markets. For FY18, DPU rose 1% and revenue grew 4% to S$514.3 million, with gross profit increasing 5% to S$239.4 million.

site_title: Powell put on the spot after Fed's monetary messages
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell will face questions after the central bank's monetary messages caused market volatility. The Federal Open Market Committee's two-day meeting concluded with interest rates expected to remain on hold. Investors will scrutinize the policy statement for hints about future rate hikes. The FOMC's forecast of two rate hikes this year remains unchanged, despite recent market fluctuations.

images.alt_text: Mr Powell must avoid the communication pitfalls of last month.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Great Eastern Holdings has entered into a share and purchase agreement to divest a 5% stake in QBE Indonesia for $1.4 million. The transaction is subject to approval by Indonesian and Singaporean authorities. Meanwhile, SIIC Environment Holdings has signed an operation and management agreement for a wastewater treatment project in China, valued at $0.158 per tonne. These moves follow Great Eastern's announcement to sell a minority stake in QBE Indonesia to meet Indonesian shareholding requirements.

site_title: Outlook for Asia's emerging markets seen brightening this year: survey
summary: Asia's emerging markets are expected to brighten this year due to a less aggressive Federal Reserve, but the US-China trade war saga will continue to impact growth. Strategists favor Malaysia's ringgit and China's bonds, while India is the top pick for equities. The Bloomberg JPMorgan Asia Dollar Index has risen 0.8% so far this year, and the MSCI Emerging-Market Asia Index has gained 5.6%. Respondents expect Asian central banks to keep rates unchanged due to abating inflationary pressures and currency stabilisation.

site_title: Too ugly to save? Singapore weighs fate of its Brutalist buildings
summary: Singapore's Brutalist buildings, once a symbol of national identity, are facing a potential demolition due to private developers' interest in selling them. The government's Land Titles Act requires 100% owner approval for conservation plans, compared to 80% approval for en bloc sales of buildings over 10 years old. Advocates argue that the buildings' unique architecture and artistic value make them worth saving, but owners are prioritizing financial gain. The fate of Golden Mile Complex, a prominent Brutalist landmark, will serve as a bellwether for the city's Brutalist buildings.

site_title: Saudi Aramco to pay US$1.6b for 19.9% stake in Hyundai Oilbank
summary: Saudi Aramco plans to invest up to $1.6 billion in Hyundai Oilbank, gaining a nearly 20% stake in the South Korean refiner. The deal is part of Saudi Aramco's expansion into downstream projects ahead of a potential initial public offering. The investment aims to boost crude oil sales and cut reliance on crude as demand slows. The move is also seen as a strategic move to increase market share in Asia, with Saudi Aramco planning to list by 2021.

site_title: China's December industrial profits fall for second straight month
summary: China's industrial profits declined for the second consecutive month in December, falling 1.9% from a year earlier, due to weak factory-gate prices and soft demand. This trend may continue as the Producer Price Index turned negative, putting pressure on industrial enterprises. The decline in profits is attributed to a slowdown in the country's manufacturing sector, exacerbated by a protracted US-Sino trade war, economic growth slowing to its weakest in nearly three decades, and government efforts to reduce debt risks.

site_title: Saudi Arabia remains confident that it will pump world's very last barrel of oil
summary: Saudi Arabia remains confident that it will continue to pump the world's last barrel of oil, despite predictions that global oil demand will peak by 2040. The country's low production costs and vast oil reserves make it the most profitable oil producer in the world. Saudi Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih stated that Saudi Aramco's cost of production is just $4 a barrel, making it the lowest in the world. The Kingdom expects oil demand to rise again after the US shale production peaks in the late 2020s, with OPEC forecasting demand to reach nearly 40 million barrels per day by 2040.

site_title: 'Radical rethink' needed to tackle obesity, hunger, climate: report
summary: A major report by The Lancet Commission on Obesity calls for a "global treaty" to tackle the intertwined pandemics of obesity, hunger, and climate change. Experts recommend curtailing corporate influence, overhauling economic incentives, and promoting sustainable food systems. The report aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, which currently contribute to 25-30% of global emissions, primarily through cattle production and transportation. To achieve this, the experts propose a Framework Convention on Food Systems, high taxes on red meat, and a philanthropic fund to support grassroots action.

site_title: Islamic browser promises better Web experience
summary: A Malaysian startup, SalamWeb, is launching a mobile browser designed to provide a Muslim-friendly internet experience. The browser, which includes features like prayer times and Qibla direction, aims to capture 10% of the global Muslim population. SalamWeb uses community-vetted content filters and is certified compliant by the Amanie Shariah Supervisory Board. The browser is built on the Chromium software and aims to offer a safer and more positive online experience, addressing concerns over privacy, bias, and online abuse.

site_title: M1's Q4 profit down 21.4%
summary: M1's Q4 net profit fell 21.4% to S$25.2 million due to higher expenses on customer acquisition and infrastructure. Headline revenue grew 3.7% to S$312.8 million, driven by handset and equipment sales, but service revenue dipped 1.8% to S$125 million. Fibre broadband subscribers increased 10.7% to 209,000, contributing to a 8.6% rise in fixed service revenue. The group's net profit for the year fell 6% to S$130.7 million, with a final dividend of six Singapore cents per share recommended.

site_title: Black Panther's Oscars chances rise with win from Screen Actors Guild
summary: Black Panther won the top Screen Actors Guild (SAG) award for best movie ensemble, beating out A Star is Born, boosting its Oscars chances ahead of the ceremony on February 24. The film's victory is seen as a milestone for diversity in Hollywood, with stars praising the movie's celebration of African culture. The SAG awards also honored Glenn Close for best film actress and Rami Malek for best film actor, with Green Book taking home one award. The Oscars will closely follow the SAG results, with Black Panther's ensemble win signaling its potential for broad support.

site_title: Why Trump will now look abroad for victories
summary: US President Donald Trump may shift focus to foreign policy after struggling to pass domestic legislation, potentially drawing parallels with Richard Nixon's second term. Nixon, like Trump, faced domestic turmoil and intense scrutiny, focusing on foreign affairs to achieve successes, including landmark meetings with Chairman Mao Zongding and nuclear agreements with Moscow. Trump's recent decision to reopen the US government may mark a turning point in his presidency, as he seeks to capitalize on foreign policy achievements to boost his prospects in the next two years.

site_title: Ex-Nomura trader starts hedge fund at Tencent-backed firm
summary: An ex-Nomura trader, Desmond How, has launched a long-short hedge fund focused on emerging market corporate bonds at GaoTeng Global Asset Management Ltd, a Tencent-backed firm. The fund aims to capitalize on emerging credit market volatility, targeting a bear market and dollar-denominated debt. With over 22 years of investment experience, How believes the market is due for more downgrades and sees opportunities for his fund to hedge out risk. The fund has a capacity to manage up to $3 billion.

site_title: 2nd major breach may further dent Singapore's data hub push
summary: A data breach involving confidential information of over 14,200 people with HIV has raised concerns about Singapore's position as a data hub. The breach, which occurred in 2013, included the names, identification numbers, and medical information of those affected. Experts say the incident highlights the need for better information governance and cybersecurity measures, particularly among public agencies. The breach comes on the heels of a similar incident at SingHealth, where 1.5 million patients' personal data was stolen last year.

site_title: What more is needed to spur innovation in Singapore SMEs?
summary: Singaporean SMEs are facing challenges in innovation, with local SMEs experiencing a decline in R&D expenditure and growth rate compared to large enterprises and foreign companies. The government-backed R&D incentive schemes, including the IP Development Incentive (IDI), can be modified to better reward SMEs for their R&D commercialisation efforts and continuous investment. By offering a non-taxable cash benefit, the scheme can provide additional cash flow for businesses to iterate their new products and solutions. The government can also consider liberalising the IDI award to make it accessible to both big and small companies, promoting software-based and digital IP creation and commercialisation.

site_title: US-China ties at 40: Competition likely in all spheres
summary: US-China ties are at 40 years, marked by increasing competition in various spheres. In 1979, China established diplomatic relations with the US, with Deng Xiaoping expressing interest in purchasing US-made weapons. However, this has not been a celebratory milestone, given the current trade war between the two countries.

site_title: Rex International unit to divest stakes in two Norway assets
summary: REX International announced a deal to divest its interests in two Norway assets through its subsidiary Lime Petroleum. The company is selling 30% stake in Rolvsnes discovery and 20% stake in Goddo prospect for US$43 million and US$2 million contingent payment. The sale is pending government and regulatory approvals, and the company will use the proceeds for exploration and production activities. The transaction will increase net asset value per share and earnings per share, with Rex expecting to close the sale by January 1, 2019.

site_title: Money FM marks its first birthday with 60% surge in listenership
summary: Money FM 89.3, Singapore's first and only business and personal finance English radio station, celebrated its first birthday with a 60% surge in listenership. Since its launch on January 29, 2018, the station successfully covered major events, including Budget 2018, and achieved significant growth. Despite initial doubts from the media and industry, SPH Radio's general manager Sim Hong Huat said the team is proud of their accomplishments and aims to continue growing listenership by at least 30% year-on-year.

site_title: Rising interest in Singapore Savings Bonds is a sign of investor maturity
summary: Singapore's Singapore Savings Bonds (SSB) programme has gained acceptance among savers as an alternative to traditional savings methods. Since its introduction in 2017, the monthly issuance of bonds consistently crossed the S$200 million mark in the second quarter of 2018. This indicates a sign of investor maturity, as retail investors increasingly prefer SSBs over bank deposits. The programme's success is a testament to its superior form of savings.

site_title: UOB brings Chinese New Year cheer to 150 beneficiaries
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) hosted a Chinese New Year carnival and reunion dinner for 150 disadvantaged children in Singapore, as part of its Festive Cheers@Central Singapore initiative. The event, led by UOB deputy chairman and CEO Wee Ee Cheong, provided Lunar New Year goodies and red packets to the beneficiaries. The event culminated in a charity dinner on February 12, where funds will be raised through an art auction and donations. The beneficiaries included local community development councils and funds supporting underprivileged children.

site_title: Cautious day of trading in Asia
summary: Asian markets started the week on a cautious note, with the Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) shedding 0.1% to 3,199.50. Investors are bracing for key events including US-China trade talks, Brexit plans, and the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. Defensive counters, such as gaming stalwart Genting Singapore and food and beverage player ThaiBev, performed well, while oil and gas firm Rex International rose 16.1% after announcing a deal to divest its interests in two Norwegian assets.

site_title: Deutsche Bank gets Qatari commitment for more funds
summary: Deutsche Bank has secured a commitment for additional investment from Qatar's sovereign wealth fund, Qatar Investment Authority (QIA), to bolster its finances. The investment is expected to be made through QIA, which already owns a stake in the German lender. The discussions are at an advanced stage, but no final agreement has been reached. This comes as the German government seeks to fix Deutsche Bank, which has seen its shares slump by almost half in the past year, amid scrutiny over money-laundering practices. A final deal's timing and size remain unclear.

site_title: Linda Lim appointed to strategic marketing role at SPH
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has appointed Linda Lim as chief of Advertising Partnerships and Market Development, effective February 1. Lim brings over 12 years of experience in media and will report to Ignatius Low, chief marketing officer. Her role marks the next stage of SPH's evolution as a media solutions provider, focusing on building relationships with media agencies, content producers, and other partners to meet client needs. Lim will oversee international sales, outdoor advertising, and content marketing, aiming to expand SPH's media solutions proposition.

site_title: The rich didn't always need US$238-million penthouses
summary: Chicago hedge fund manager Ken Griffin purchased the most expensive US home, a $238 million, 24,000-square-foot penthouse in New York City. However, this trend of massive residential real estate isn't new. In the post-World War II era, wealthy Americans like cereal heiress Marjorie Merriweather Post and socialites like Brooke Astor preferred more modest homes. The wealthy didn't always prioritize opulent living spaces, and instead focused on giving away their wealth through foundations and philanthropy. The current taste for huge residential real estate is a departure from this past era, reflecting changing attitudes towards wealth and conspicuous consumption.

site_title: Bicentennial a time to reflect on how Singapore came into being: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong marked the official launch of the Singapore Bicentennial, commemorating 200 years since Sir Stamford Raffles' arrival in 1819. Lee emphasized that 1819 was a pivotal moment in Singapore's history, leading to its modern nationhood, independence in 1965, and multicultural society. He stressed the importance of reflecting on the country's past to move forward, with over 200 groups and organizations planning commemorative events throughout 2019.

site_title: Yamada Green's plantation sales a 'neglect of fiduciary duties' by executive director
summary: Yamada Green Resources, a Chinese supplier of bamboo shoots and canned mushrooms, has faced a scandal after it was discovered that two subsidiaries had sold two plantations without the board's knowledge. Executive director Lin Weibin resigned after an investigation found he had neglected his fiduciary duties by entrusting a third party with the sales. Lin admitted to being busy and having personal family problems, leading to a series of miscommunications. The board ultimately deemed the disposal was in the group's commercial interests, with proceeds applied to settle debts owed to subcontractors.

site_title: JustCo to open six co-working spaces in Korea and Australia
summary: JustCo, a Singapore-based co-working space provider, plans to open six new locations in Melbourne, Sydney, and Seoul, expanding its regional footprint to over 1 million sq ft by Q1 2019. The expansion includes JustCo's first ventures beyond Asia, marking its entry into the Australian market. The firm's growth is driven by a joint investment of US$177 million to develop a co-working space platform across Asia, with a 42% growth in its member base over the past year.

site_title: US Treasury to borrow US$1t for 2nd year to fund deficit
summary: The US Treasury will borrow $1 trillion for the second consecutive year to finance the government's widening budget deficit, with new long-term debt sales projected at $84 billion. This follows record-high levels of debt issuance under the current administration, driven by tax cuts and increased government spending. Despite a surge in supply, Treasury yields remain under pressure due to strong demand for the world's safest securities. Experts warn of a fiscal outlook worsened by rising entitlement-programme expenses, higher debt costs, and the Federal Reserve's balance-sheet runoff, with some predicting a potential debt crisis.

images.alt_text: A heightened supply of Treasury securities follows tax cuts and government spending increases implemented under the current administration.

site_title: More 'forceful' help expected for vulnerable PMETs: DBS economist
summary: DBS economist Irvin Seah expects the upcoming Singapore Budget 2019 to implement "forceful policy measures" to tackle the rising vulnerability of professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs), who face difficulties in maintaining employability. The budget may include enhancements to reskilling schemes, increased wage support, and additional training grants. It will also focus on mitigating the challenges of an ageing population and managing healthcare costs, with potential measures such as a sugar tax to encourage public health consciousness.

site_title: The day Trump took up residence in Loserville
summary: President Donald Trump learned about the Founding Fathers' views on disruptive leaders when he took up residence in Washington, DC. The 18th-century men who created the US Constitution were conservative and conservative in their temperament, disliking "political disrupters, angry populists, and demagogues." This perspective contrasts with Trump's populist approach and could impact his ability to navigate the system, as he has been known to rock the boat. Trump's style may be at odds with the constitutional system he inherited from the Founding Fathers.

site_title: France to toughen 5G telco hardware access, citing security
summary: The French government is preparing to toughen access for equipment makers to its 5G telecommunications networks, citing security concerns. The government is readying an amendment to the existing economic Bill, which will make the vetting process for gear more stringent and increase oversight of suppliers and locations. The move does not target China's gear maker Huawei, but rather aims to ensure the security of France's 5G network. The government aims to have at least one major city operating on 5G by 2020 and all main highways and railroads connected by 2025.

site_title: OUE puts US Bank Tower in LA up for sale
summary: Singapore property developer OUE has put the US Bank Tower in downtown Los Angeles up for sale, reportedly seeking over $700 million. The building, known for its Hollywood movie cameos and outdoor glass slide, was acquired by OUE's parent company in 2013 for $367.5 million. The sale comes amid concerns about OUE's finances, following a liquidity crisis in the Singapore bond market and a 9.8% decline in the company's stock over the past six months. OUE has completed enhancement work on the building, which features an open-air observation deck and glass slide 1,000 feet above ground.

site_title: Making it work: managing finances as a freelancer
summary: Freelancers in Singapore face challenges in managing their finances, including fluctuating income, taxes, and insurance. To ensure a steady flow of income, freelancers can negotiate payment terms with clients, such as upfront deposits or payment based on project milestones. Protecting health and finances involves researching private insurance policies and factoring costs into hourly or project rates. Additionally, freelancers should save for emergencies, holidays, and retirement, aiming to save at least six months of living expenses. By mastering these financial aspects, freelancers can achieve financial stability and enjoy the benefits of self-employment.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.53 points to 1,697.50. Losers outnumbered gainers 550 to 301, and volume reached 2.3 billion lots worth RM1.9 billion.

site_title: Completed condo prices up 0.1% in Dec, first increase since August: NUS index
summary: Singapore's completed condo prices rose 0.1% in December, the first month-on-month increase since August 2018, according to the National University of Singapore's (NUS) Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI). The central region saw a 0.2% increase, while non-central region apartments declined 0.1%. Year-on-year, prices are 3.2% higher than in December 2017, with central region larger apartments up 2.7% and small units climbing 4.1%.

site_title: US: Wall St drops at open on weak Caterpillar, Nvidia forecasts
summary: US stocks fell at open on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 0.57% to 24,596.98, the S&P 500 opening 0.74% lower at 2,644.97, and the Nasdaq Composite falling 1.25% to 7,075.01. Disappointing forecasts from Caterpillar and Nvidia led the decline, with a Federal Reserve meeting and US-China trade talks also set for the week.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower amid a fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of possible revenue and operating loss below targets. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, will become OCBC's incoming CEO after Helen Wong's retirement. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Oon Jin Teik calls it quits as Sports Hub chief executive
summary: Oon Jin Teik, CEO of the Singapore Sports Hub, is leaving his post after the April 13-14 HSBC Singapore Rugby Sevens. He will be succeeded by Bryn Jones, the facility's chairman, who will act as CEO until a global search for a new leader is completed. Teik, who joined the Sports Hub in 2014, expressed his gratitude for the opportunity to lead the facility and wished the staff and partners well in their future endeavors.

site_title: China's real estate loan growth slows further in 2018
summary: China's outstanding yuan property loans grew 20% in 2018 to 38.7 trillion yuan, slower than the 20.9% growth in 2017. Lending to property developers expanded 22.6% in 2018, compared to 21.7% in 2017. Mortgage lending rose 17.8% to 25.75 trillion yuan, below the 22.2% growth in 2017. The slowdown in property market growth is attributed to tightened home-purchase rules, with policymakers aiming to ensure "stable and healthy" development.

site_title: UK, Germany may shed thousands of jobs as retail rout deepens
summary: UK retailer Tesco plans to cut 15,000 jobs and close meat, fish, and delicatessen counters, while German department store Galeria Kaufhof will eliminate 2,600 jobs amid the retail crisis. Online shopping is accelerating the decline of traditional brick-and-mortar stores, with concerns over the future of UK retailers such as Debenhams. The shift to internet shopping, economic growth slowdown, and Brexit uncertainty are contributing to the crisis.

images.alt_text: Tesco's job cuts of about 15,000 positions will probably affect the majority of its 732 larger stores, according to the Mail on Sunday. The retailer will also overhaul in-store bakeries, and replace staff canteens with vending machines, the newspaper said.

site_title: Tesla seen forecasting first-quarter loss after Musk warning
summary: Tesla Inc is expected to forecast a loss for the first quarter after CEO Elon Musk warned of a "very difficult" road ahead. Analysts now expect a loss of $2.5 million, down from an initial profit estimate of $62.80 million. The company's production of Model 3s has been steady, but analysts fear tougher competition, reduced electric car tax credits, and lower profit margins due to the price cut of Model 3s after the federal tax cut. Musk's forecast of a "tiny profit" with great difficulty also raises questions about the company's ability to make profits.

site_title: Guarding the guardians of financial probity
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) proposes a new power to order a second audit for listed companies in exceptional circumstances, despite their clean audits. The second auditor will jointly sign off on the year-end audit with the existing auditor. The move aims to address auditor failure and regain investor confidence in Singapore's capital market. The proposal also requires companies to appoint a Singapore-based auditor for significant overseas operations, with a foreign auditor. This interventionist approach seeks to restore public trust in companies, directors, and auditors, and potentially mitigate valuation losses.

site_title: Billionaire Cheng family said to be exploring a bid for Varo Energy
summary: The Cheng family, a Hong Kong billionaire family, is exploring a bid for European fuel supplier Varo Energy BV, valued at approximately $3.08 billion including debt. The companies have held talks, but no final agreements have been reached. This move comes as the family, led by tycoon Henry Cheng, continues to pursue acquisitions beyond their property roots. Varo Energy has hundreds of fuel stations in Europe and significant fuel-storage capacity, and its shares had been planned to be sold by each of its three shareholders.

site_title: US shutdown subtracted US$11 bn from GDP: congressional report
summary: A US congressional report found that the five-week government shutdown subtracted approximately $11 billion from the economy, about twice the amount President Donald Trump sought for a border wall. However, losses will largely be recovered as the government resumes operations. The report noted that individual businesses and workers will experience lasting effects, with some private sectors never recouping lost income. The partial shutdown, the longest in US history, left 800,000 federal workers without pay or on furlough.

site_title: US$ dips as investors brace for volatile markets, Fed meeting
summary: The US dollar fell 1% since late December due to investors' concerns over a potential slowdown in the US economy and the Federal Reserve's upcoming policy decision. The euro reached a 10-day high against the dollar, while the offshore yuan and Australian dollar also gained against the dollar. Investors are awaiting the outcome of US-China trade talks and the Fed meeting, which may signal a pause in the Fed's tightening cycle.

site_title: Y Ventures shares continue to sink; price has halved since damaging revelation
summary: Y Ventures' share price has plummeted 15.8% to S$0.101, halving since accounting errors were discovered in its H1 2018 financial statements. Analysts at DBS Equity Research cut their earnings estimates and suspended coverage of the stock, citing a net loss of US$1.2 million for the period. The company's CFO resigned 17 days after the announcement, sparking questions about whether directors or management were aware of the errors. Regulators have called for a proper investigation and those responsible to be held accountable.

site_title: Smart Buildings: What 'smart' really means
summary: Smart buildings lack standardized metrics to quantify their value and contribution to urban environments, hindering their adoption. Various indices have been developed, such as the Honeywell Smart Building Score, but these are often biased towards corporate interests. Public indices, like the European Smart Readiness Index, focus on sustainability, while others prioritize performance and cost-effectiveness. However, these indices often overlook the interactive dimension of smart buildings, failing to capture their role in smart cities as data collectors and connected platforms. Moreover, cyber-risks posed by smart building technologies must be addressed, as real estate has been targeted in numerous cybersecurity breaches, posing a significant threat to occupants and corporations.

images.alt_text: Stakeholders should be involved in defining the criteria that make a building smart, not just vendors with a vested commercial interest. Sound smart building certifications will be an important component of a functioning market for smart real estate.

site_title: India's Gandhi pledges 'minimum income' for poor
summary: India's opposition leader Rahul Gandhi has pledged a "minimum income guarantee" for the poor if his party returns to power in elections this year. The promise, similar to universal basic income, involves giving a flat lump sum to every poor person to help eradicate poverty and hunger. Gandhi's announcement aims to steal a march on the ruling party ahead of the final budget announcement. This move is seen as a key plank in his party's campaign to unseat Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

site_title: Indonesia palm oil tycoon who built US$9b empire dies at 98
summary: Indonesian palm oil tycoon Eka Tjipta Widjaja, founder of Sinar Mas Group, has died at 98. Widjaja built a US$9.3 billion empire after overcoming the 1998 Asian financial crisis, restructuring debt and rebuilding his business. He started as a 15-year-old coconut and palm oil trader, selling biscuits and sweets by bicycle. Widjaja's business empire now operates under his children and grandchildren, with holdings in paper, pulp, real estate, and telecommunications.

site_title: Vibrant subsidiary disposing of warehouse for 29m yuan
summary: VIBRANT Group's subsidiary, Sanlu Logistics, is disposing of a 13,667 sq m warehouse property in Jiangyin, China for 29 million yuan (S$5.5 million). The sale results in a gain of 1.3 million yuan, which will be used to repay debt and bank borrowings.

site_title: Nick Clegg uses debut as Facebook lobbyist to win over EU
summary: Facebook will begin vetting political advertisers in Europe and displaying ad information, including who paid for ads, demographics, and performance, starting March. The company will create an operations centre in Dublin and archive ads for up to seven years. This announcement follows scrutiny over user data, misinformation, and hate speech, particularly in Europe. Facebook has also proposed an independent external appeals body to address content decisions. The move aims to combat misinformation and increase transparency on its platforms, particularly ahead of European elections this spring.

site_title: Saudi Arabia in talks with businesses to adjust economic reforms
summary: Saudi Arabia's Economy and Planning Minister Mohammed Al Tuwaijri is engaging in a constructive dialogue with the private sector to adjust economic reforms, which have been challenging businesses. The government is open to revising fees on foreign workers, currently under study, and is moving ahead with privatization plans, including electricity sector privatization. The kingdom's sovereign wealth fund, the Public Investment Fund, will not be pressured into paying dividends yet, as it is seen as a diversification engine. The government aims to achieve its objectives through these adjustments.

site_title: Singapore is first stop abroad for Lufthansa's innovation hub
summary: Lufthansa launched its first innovation hub outside Germany in Singapore, with the goal of building strategic partnerships within the region's dynamic transport, mobility, and tech ecosystem. The Lufthansa Innovation Hub (LIH) aims to plug into this ecosystem and drive innovation. A partnership with a ride-hailing player is also in the works. The move is seen as a significant step for the German carrier, highlighting Singapore's attractive business environment and favorable policies for innovation and technology.

site_title: Yamada Green's asset sale arose from 'miscommunications'
summary: S-Chip Yamada Green Resources sold two bamboo plantations in China's Fujian province in August 2017, but its board didn't discover the sale until a year later due to a series of miscommunications. An investigation found that executive director Lin Weibin had given his written approval to dispose of the plantations, but he didn't realize the full implications of his actions. The sale allowed the company to settle outstanding debts and was deemed in the company's best interests. Lin Weibin resigned and admitted to neglecting his fiduciary duties as a director.

site_title: Olam wants its stock mojo back, but it won't be easy
summary: Olam International, a Singapore-based agri and food giant, is seeking to regain investor attention with a new six-year plan to simplify its portfolio and focus on more profitable businesses. The company aims to generate $1.6 billion by exiting four underperforming businesses and doubling down on 12 others. Its stock price has surged 3% since the announcement, with analysts citing a "bullish" sentiment towards the company. Olam's efforts to reorganize its business and improve its capital structure have been seen as a step towards regaining investor confidence, following a tumultuous period marked by concerns over its volatile cash flow and high debt.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.1% on Monday
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.1% on Monday, closing at 3,199.50 points, with 1.32 billion securities changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 198 to 163, while DBS Group Holdings closed flat and OCBC added 0.4% to S$11.52. Other notable stocks included Rex International, which rose 16.1% after resuming trading, and United Overseas Bank, which dipped 0.2% to S$25.83.

site_title: EU's Vestager opposes renewed Siemens, Alstom deal
summary: EU antitrust regulators, led by Commissioner Margrethe Vestager, have rejected a revised remedy package for Siemens AG and Alstom SA's proposed rail merger, citing inadequate measures to address competition concerns. The proposed deal would see Siemens and Alstom combine to form a European rail champion to compete with Chinese companies. Vestager's decision comes despite pressure from France and Germany to approve the deal, which is set to be reviewed by the European Commission on February 6 or 12.

site_title: JustCo to open 6 co-working spaces in Korea and Australia
summary: Singapore-based co-working space provider JustCo is expanding to Korea and Australia with the opening of six new locations in Melbourne, Sydney, and Seoul. The firm's first venture beyond Asia will include a 90,000 sq ft space in Melbourne and a two-space operation in Seoul. JustCo's growth is backed by a US$177 million investment from Frasers Property, GIC, and the company itself. The firm expects to grow its headcount by 60% and has secured 50% pre-lease commitment from large corporates.

site_title: Ex-Starbucks CEO aims to oust Trump in 2020
summary: Former Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz is considering running as an independent presidential candidate in 2020, citing concerns over Donald Trump's qualifications and the country's debt. Schultz, a self-described "lifelong Democrat," believes he can unite the American people and win the election. He dismissed fears that a third-party candidate could split the opposition vote and help Trump win re-election. Schultz's bid could potentially impact the 2020 election, but his chances of success remain uncertain.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end flat ahead of Fed meeting, trade talks
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index ended flat on Monday ahead of the US Federal Reserve policy meeting and Sino-US trade talks, with investor sentiment turning cautious. The Korean won rose, and shares of shipbuilders ended firmer after Qatar's energy minister outlined plans to order 60 new liquefied natural gas carriers. The Kospi index is up around 6.7% so far this year.

site_title: Saudi says Venezuela crisis could hit oil market
summary: Saudi Arabia's energy minister, Khalid al-Falih, warns that the ongoing crisis in Venezuela, which has led to a power struggle between President Nicolas Maduro and opposition leader Juan Guaido, could impact the global oil market. Venezuela's oil production has dropped to 1.4 million barrels per day, affecting the balance of the oil market. Al-Falih stated that developments in Venezuela may have an impact on oil markets, and the situation is being closely watched.

images.alt_text: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro(R) and opposition leader Juan Guaido have been locked in a power struggle since Mr Guaido proclaimed himself "acting president" Wednesday amid angry protests over the country's economic woes.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 is expected to implement "forceful policy measures" to support vulnerable Professionals, Managers, Executives, and Technicians (PMETs). Completed condo prices in Singapore rose 0.1% in December, reversing a sharp drop in November. Rex International will divest stakes in two Norwegian assets, while Keppel will sell a 70% stake in a Vietnam township project for S$136m. Singapore shares fell 0.1% on Monday, closing at 3,199.50 points.

site_title: Europe: Stocks sag at open
summary: European stock markets began the day with a decline, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.3% to 6,786.31 points, and the Paris CAC 40 index dropping 0.4% to 4,903.95 points. The decline followed a similar trend in the eurozone, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 index shedding 0.3% to 11,246.79 points. The US stock market, however, continued its upward trend, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Michael Jackson family slams documentary renewing sex abuse claims
summary: Michael Jackson's family strongly condemned a new documentary, "Leaving Neverland," which renews allegations of child sex abuse against the late singer. They described the documentary as a "public lynching" and an "easy target" for Jackson, who had previously faced a lengthy investigation and acquitted in a 2005 trial. The family also pointed out that Jackson had faced similar allegations in 2005, which were not pursued further. The Jackson family expressed outrage and disappointment over the renewed focus on these allegations.

site_title: UK could avoid US$1.5 Billion EU tax bill on no-deal Brexit
summary: The European Union is poised to order the UK to repay approximately $1.5 billion in tax breaks granted to dozens of UK-based companies, potentially avoiding a US$1.5 billion EU tax bill. A no-deal Brexit would complicate the enforcement of the decision, as the UK would no longer be bound by EU courts. The EU has been investigating companies such as Diageo and Pearson for allegedly unfairly profiting from a UK tax break, and a decision is likely to be made before the scheduled Brexit date of March 29.

images.alt_text: A no-deal Brexit could create yet another headache for the European Union as it prepares to hand dozens of UK-based companies a tax bill that is expected to top US$1.5 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down on strong yen
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday due to a strong yen, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.60% and the Topix index down 0.68%. Investors are bracing for corporate results from major companies. The article does not provide further details on the companies or the results.

site_title: Data of 14,200 people with HIV leaked online by American fraudster:MOH
summary: A confidential HIV registry database containing 14,200 individuals, including 5,400 Singaporeans and 8,800 foreigners, was leaked online by American fraudster Mikhy Farrera-Brochez. The leak includes names, contact details, medical information, and test results. Farrera-Brochez, who was jailed for fraud and drug-related offenses, had access to the registry through his boyfriend, a doctor. The Ministry of Health has contacted affected individuals and worked to disable access to the information, while Farrera-Brochez remains outside Singapore.

site_title: M1 Q4 net profit falls 21.4% on higher costs
summary: M1's Q4 net profit fell 21.4% to S$25.2 million due to higher customer acquisition and retention costs, staff numbers, and repair and maintenance expenses. Handset and equipment sales grew 13.3% to S$125 million, while service revenue was down 1.8% to S$187.8 million. The company reported 1.96 million mobile customers, down 4.1% on the year before. A final dividend of six Singapore cents a share was recommended, down from 6.2 cents last year.

site_title: SIIC inks deal for new wastewater treatment and constructed wetland project in Zhejiang, China
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings signed an operation and management agreement with Cixi City Drainage Co for a wastewater treatment and constructed wetland project in Hangzhou Bay New Zone, Zhejiang Province, China. The project, with a design capacity of 100,000 tonnes per day, will be operated at a fee of 0.739 yuan (S$0.158) per tonne for a two-year period with an option to extend. The agreement is expected to positively contribute to SIIC's performance.

site_title: Deep freeze grips Midwest with record-breaking low temperatures
summary: A deep freeze grips the Midwest, with record-breaking low temperatures expected to last until the end of the week. Chicago is forecast to see its lowest daily high temperature ever, minus 12 degrees Fahrenheit, with wind chills reaching minus 40 degrees. The cold air is causing hazardous conditions, including frostbite, hypothermia, and frozen pipes, and energy use is expected to spike. The National Weather Service has issued a "potentially record-breaking push" of Arctic air, which has already prompted Delta to issue weather waivers for 18 Midwest airports.

site_title: Halal Internet? Islamic browser promises better Web experience
summary: A Malaysian startup, SalamWeb, has launched a mobile browser designed to provide a Muslim-friendly web experience. The browser, compliant with Islamic values, aims to deliver a safer and more neutral online environment, particularly for users in Malaysia and Indonesia. SalamWeb's features include community-vetted content filters and Muslim-specific functions, such as prayer times and Qibla indicators. The browser is built on the Chromium software and is certified compliant by the Amanie Shariah Supervisory Board, with the goal of capturing 10% of the global Muslim population.

site_title: Boris Johnson tells UK's May: Ditch the Irish backstop and get support
summary: Boris Johnson urges UK Prime Minister Theresa May to ditch the Irish backstop, a key component of the Brexit deal, in order to secure widespread support. Johnson believes that removing the backstop would allow May to pass the deal in parliament, which was defeated two weeks ago. The Irish backstop aims to prevent a hard border in Ireland if no other solutions can be agreed. Johnson claims that with the backstop removed, May would have the full support of the country, but Ireland has expressed opposition to any changes to the backstop.

site_title: ADCB's chairman, CEO to fill top positions in new Abu Dhabi merged bank
summary: Abu Dhabi Commercial Bank's (ADCB) chairman and CEO, Eissa Mohamed al Suwaidi, will fill top positions in the new bank formed by the merger with Union National Bank and Al Hilal Bank. The new bank is expected to have around $113 billion in assets, making it the third-largest lender in the UAE. Ala'a Eraiqat, ADCB's CEO, will assume the role of CEO of the new bank, with al Suwaidi holding the same position. The merger is part of a larger tie-up among UAE banks, with First Abu Dhabi Bank and Emirates NBD already established as major lenders.

site_title: 'World's loneliest duck' Trevor dies on tiny Niue
summary: A lone duck named Trevor, known as the "world's loneliest duck," has died on the Pacific island nation of Niue after being attacked by dogs. Trevor gained fame last year when a visiting journalist discovered he was used as a directional landmark. The island's 1,600 residents and 9,000 annual visitors were saddened by his death, and the chief executive of the Niue Chamber of Commerce described it as a "sad time for Niue." Trevor's death has sparked an outpouring of grief from as far away as New Zealand.

site_title: China regions losing 'momentum' in pollution fight -minister
summary: China's environmental minister, Li Ganjie, stated that some regions have lost "momentum" in their fight against pollution, with economic downturns attributed to overzealous campaigns against smog. Officials blame this on hype about environmental protection's impact on economic growth. However, Li emphasized that China is still on track to meet its environmental goals, citing progress in converting to natural gas and cutting foreign garbage imports. He called for regional officials to resist the notion that pollution efforts hinder economic development, and instead, promote both environmental improvements and economic growth.

images.alt_text: Some regions in China have lost "momentum" when it comes to tackling pollution, with local officials blaming the country's economic downturn on overzealous campaigns against smog, the environmental minister said in remarks published on Monday.

site_title: Bing outage in China was technical error, not censors' block: source
summary: Bing's outage in China was attributed to a technical error, not a censorship block, according to a Microsoft source. The outage occurred when internet users in China attempted to access Bing's domestic URL, resulting in an error page. The disruption was not intentional, and Microsoft had received no prior notice from Chinese authorities. The cause was determined to be "black-holing," a technique that blocks traffic at the Internet service provider level, rather than domain name service poisoning. The outage occurred after a Chinese journalist criticized the quality of Bing's search results.

site_title: Canadian arrested in Macau for US$284m fraud attempt
summary: A 61-year-old Canadian man of Chinese descent was arrested in Macau for allegedly attempting to defraud an entertainment company out of US$284 million. The suspect used bogus documents to try to transfer funds from the company's bank account. The arrest occurred amid a diplomatic row between Canada and China, following the December arrest of Huawei's CFO Meng Wanzhou on a US extradition request. The suspect's true intentions and the company involved remain unknown, but the arrest highlights Macau's role as the world's largest gambling hub.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI downgrades Keppel Corp to 'hold' on challenging outlook
summary: KGI Securities downgraded Keppel Corp to 'hold' citing a growth slowdown in key markets and cautious macro views. The brokerage cut its fair value from S$9.43 to S$7.50. Keppel shares were trading at S$6.16, down 0.6% on the day, after the company reported its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings. The downgrade was attributed to the property and infrastructure segments accounting for most of the full-year earnings growth, despite weak performance from its offshore and marine business.

site_title: Berliners see red over Karl Marx Allee sale
summary: In Berlin, a plan to sell 700 apartments on Karl Marx Allee to another company has sparked a fight against gentrification, with tenants fearing rent hikes. The controversy led to a re-nationalization of the apartments, bringing the ownership back to the city, and sparking debate on whether authorities can requisition apartment buildings. The move comes at a cost of 90-100 million euros and raises concerns about property rights. The city's mayor has vowed to reclaim more apartments from private hands, and a referendum is being pushed to allow the government to requisition properties from large companies.

site_title: Sterling slips before key Brexit votes in parliament this week
summary: The pound slipped 0.25% to US$1.3162 on Monday ahead of key Brexit votes in parliament, reversing its 2.5% weekly gain last week. The decline comes after lawmakers rejected Prime Minister Theresa May's EU withdrawal agreement, setting up a series of votes to find a way forward. The outcome will impact the UK's economic stability and the pound's value.

images.alt_text: The pound drifted lower on Monday after posting its biggest weekly rise in more than 15 months last week as investors consolidated positions before crucial votes in the British parliament that will aim to break a Brexit deadlock.

site_title: With cameras everywhere, sometimes it gets a bit embarrassing
summary: The Australian Open has installed a network of cameras throughout the Melbourne Park venue, monitoring players and their entourages without explicit warning or consent. The cameras provide a feed for television broadcasts and online streaming, capturing mundane moments and occasional poignant scenes like Petra Martic's breakdown in the tunnel after a loss. While some players, like Serena Williams, find the cameras intrusive, others, like Stefanos Tsitsipas, are fascinated by them. The tournament director, Craig Tiley, views the cameras as a "rich source of content" that complements match coverage and reveals the sport's culture.

site_title: New Zealand shares flat, holidays in Australia and Auckland shrink trade
summary: New Zealand shares remained flat on Monday due to thin trade, with holidays in Auckland and Australia limiting investor activity. The S&P/NZX 50 index rose 3.97 points to 9,114.52. Consumer and industrial stocks gained, while healthcare fell, with Fisher and Paykel Healthcare declining 2.1% and Telecom services provider Spark New Zealand Ltd losing 0.9%.

site_title: Retail rout deepens as UK, Germany may shed thousands of jobs
summary: Retailers in the UK and Germany are set to cut thousands of jobs as online shopping continues to erode traditional sales. Tesco will eliminate 15,000 positions in the UK, while Galeria Kaufhof will cut 2,600 jobs in Germany. The German fashion chain Gerry Weber International AG has begun insolvency proceedings. The shift to internet shopping and economic uncertainty are driving the crisis, with concerns over the future of retailers such as Debenhams Plc. The UK's shopping districts have already been decimated by retailer collapses, and local politicians warn of wastelands in inner cities if the trend continues.

site_title: Four wives, 17 kids and wrangling for control of a casino empire
summary: Billionaire Stanley Ho's 17 children are battling for control of his Macau casino empire, with eldest daughter Pansy Ho forming an alliance with some siblings and the Henry Fok Foundation, giving her a 53% stake in the company. This move puts her at an upper hand over fourth wife Angela Leong, who is the co-chairman of the company. The alliance was announced as the family saga continues, with Pansy, who has experience in marketing and business, and her siblings, including Lawrence and Daisy Ho, vying for control of the nearly $6 billion business.

site_title: Rex International unit to divest stakes in two Norway assets
summary: Rex International has agreed to divest its 30% stake in the Rolvsnes discovery in Norway's PL338C and PL338E, and 20% stake in the Goddo prospect in PL815, to Lundin Norway for US$43 million and a contingent payment of US$2 million. The sale is part of Rex's business model to sell mature assets, with the proceeds to be used for exploration and production activities. The transaction is pending government and regulatory approvals and is expected to increase net asset value per share and earnings per share.

site_title: HNA's Hong Kong property arm hits near 4-week high, eyes sale of land
summary: HNA's Hong Kong property arm, Hong Kong International Construction Investment Management Group, has seen shares rise 2.5% to a near 4-week high after announcing talks to sell a land site in Kowloon. The move follows HNA's recent asset disposals to ease a cash crunch. No binding sale agreement has been reached, and the company has underperformed the Hang Seng Commerce & Industry Index sector by 9.5 percentage points in the past month.

site_title: Completed condo prices inch up 0.1% in December, first increase since August: NUS index
summary: Singapore's completed condo prices rose 0.1% in December, the first month-on-month increase since August 2018, according to the National University of Singapore's Singapore Residential Price Index. This follows a revised 0.5% drop in November. Central region apartment prices increased 0.2%, while non-central region prices declined 0.1%. Year-over-year, prices are 3.2% higher than December 2017, with central region prices up 2.7% and non-central region prices up 3.5%.

site_title: Apple's partners quicken shift from China as trade tensions rise
summary: Apple's main assemblers, including Foxconn and Pegatron, are shifting production to India and Southeast Asia due to rising trade tensions with China. Foxconn is investing over $200 million in India and Vietnam, while Pegatron has moved to Indonesia and is exploring bases in Vietnam and India. The shift is seen as a response to escalating costs in China, with Pegatron's CEO stating that the US tariffs on Chinese imports could impact the company's diversification plans. This move could fundamentally change the arrangement that has served Taiwanese companies since the 1980s.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc.'s main assemblers are shifting more output to India and Southeast Asia as trade tensions threaten to escalate costs in their longstanding production base of China.

site_title: Thailand welcomes a record 38.27m tourists in 2018
summary: Thailand welcomed a record 38.27 million tourists in 2018, a 7.5% increase from the previous year. The Tourism Ministry expects 41.1 million tourists in 2019, with 11.69 million projected to come from China. Foreign tourist receipts account for 12% of Thailand's gross domestic product.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start the week with marginal gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed flat on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 7.77 points to 27,576.96. Investors await key events including China-US trade talks, Brexit, and a Federal Reserve policy meeting. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.18% to 2,596.98, while the Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 0.38% to 1,314.99. The flat close follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data and a new funding round for eSIM platform Airalo.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks finished flat Monday after swinging in and out of positive territory as investors look ahead to a key week that includes China-US trade talks, another Brexit vote and a Federal Reserve policy meeting.

site_title: Aramco's US$1.6b Hyundai Oilbank stake deepens refiner ties in Asia
summary: Saudi Arabia's state-owned oil company, Aramco, is purchasing up to 19.9% of South Korean oil refiner Hyundai Oilbank for $2.2 billion, deepening its ties in the Asian refining market. The deal, expected to be finalized this year, will make Aramco the second-largest shareholder of Hyundai Oilbank. The move is part of Aramco's strategy to expand its customer base in Asia and increase its presence in the region's refining industry.

site_title: Aureus Group acquires Ossia Music School in seven-figure deal
summary: Aureus Group has acquired Ossia Music School in a seven-figure deal, expanding its locations from 10 to 18 and student count from 5,000 to 8,000. The acquisition nearly doubles its workforce to almost 400 employees. Lawrence Homefjord-Sarabi aims to become the dominant music education provider in Asia and the Middle East. Ossia Music School operates eight schools in Singapore with over 3,000 students and 150 teaching staff.

site_title: Tesco may cut thousands of fresh food counter jobs - report
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest supermarket chain, may cut up to 15,000 jobs by closing in-store meat, fish, and delicatessen counters and replacing staff canteens with vending machines. The changes, expected to affect most of its 732 larger stores, aim to simplify and increase efficiency. Tesco has set a goal to reduce operating costs by 1.5 billion pounds over three years, and has already cut 2,200 jobs in the past two years. The company has declined to comment on the report, but said it will inform colleagues of any changes.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB downgrades Golden-Agri to 'sell' on weak fiscal 2018 performance
summary: Broker RHB Research has downgraded Golden Agri-Resources to 'sell' and lowered its target price from S$0.39 to S$0.23, citing the company's weak fiscal 2018 performance. Despite this, RHB expects fiscal 2019 to be a better year, with the bottom line recovering after revamping its landbank through aggressive replanting and cost management. The analysts project a 3% year-on-year growth in fresh fruit bunches output for fiscal 2019, below Golden Agri's guidance of 5%.

site_title: Transit-Mixed Concrete unit to sell RM1m worth of underused assets at a loss
summary: Transit-Mixed Concrete announced the sale of underutilized assets to Perfect Readymix for RM1.02 million, resulting in a loss of RM315,000. The equipment, valued at S$442,000, was sold due to poor market conditions. The sale proceeds will be used for general working capital. The buyer is a Malaysian company owned by unrelated directors and shareholders.

site_title: US growth outlook weakens in survey of business economists
summary: US business economists have become less optimistic about the country's growth outlook, with two-thirds expecting growth to exceed 2% this year, down from 90% in the prior survey. The National Association for Business Economics survey also found that business investment has cooled, with fewer firms increasing capital spending. The results follow reports of US manufacturing slumps and weakening consumer sentiment, and are in line with recent cuts to first-quarter growth projections by JPMorgan Chase & Co and Barclays. A recession is still expected to be avoided until at least 2020.

site_title: US lifts sanctions on aluminium giant Rusal, other firms linked to Russia's Deripaska
summary: The US has lifted sanctions on aluminium giant Rusal and other Russian firms linked to oligarch Oleg Deripaska, defying a Democratic-led push in Congress. The decision was made after the companies reduced Deripaska's stake and severed his control, ensuring independent directors on the boards. The Treasury Department said the action met the conditions to lift sanctions, but Deripaska remains subject to US sanctions. The move was seen as a victory for the Trump administration and some Republicans who opposed maintaining the restrictions.

site_title: Australian's detention in China 'not linked to Canberra policies'
summary: Australian Defence Minister Christopher Pyne said there's no evidence Yang Jun's detention in China is linked to Canberra's policies. Yang, a Chinese-Australian author, was detained for allegedly endangering China's national security. Pyne met with Chinese officials, ensuring consular access and fair treatment. The detention comes amid heightened tensions between Western countries and China, with Australia previously banning Huawei from its 5G network. Pyne played down US-China tensions, stating Australia is not interested in containing China.

site_title: Lufthansa launches Singapore innovation hub, its first outside Germany
summary: Lufthansa has launched its first international innovation hub outside of Germany in Singapore, marking a significant expansion for the digitalization and innovation unit, Lufthansa Innovation Hub (LIH). The hub aims to focus on market developments in the digitalization of travel and establish strategic partnerships. LIH has partnered with local businesses, including Insead and WeWork, to test research findings in real-world conditions. The hub's expansion to Singapore follows its launch in Berlin in 2014, with plans to also establish a presence in Shanghai later this year.

site_title: Dubai airport handles 89.1m passengers in 2018, misses target
summary: Dubai International Airport handled 89.1 million passengers in 2018, missing its target of 90.3 million. This marked the weakest annual growth rate in at least a decade, with a 1% increase in passenger traffic. The airport's growth slowed due to the Gulf's economic slowdown caused by low oil prices. Despite this, Dubai airport remains the world's busiest for international travellers, surpassing London's Heathrow. The airport aims to become the world's busiest overall by 2021, but faces competition from Atlanta's Hartsfield-Jackson airport.

site_title: Suu Kyi to investors: Myanmar is open for business
summary: Myanmar leader Aung San Suu Kyi urged global investors to invest in the country, citing its economic potential, attractive location, and young population. She launched the first official investment conference, aiming to offset the negative impact of the Rohingya crisis and slow economic reforms. Suu Kyi highlighted reforms undertaken by her government since 2016, including building an investment-friendly environment.

site_title: Budget 2019 expected to support vulnerable PMETs: DBS economist
summary: DBS economist Irvin Seah expects the upcoming Singapore Budget 2019 to support vulnerable professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs) with "forceful policy measures". PMETs are facing difficulties in maintaining employability, with the share of retrenched PMETs surpassing lower-skilled workers. The budget is likely to enhance schemes like the Professional Conversion Programme and increase wage support, training grants, and job matching resources. It may also review guidelines for skilled foreign workers and introduce health-related taxes to manage healthcare costs and mitigate the challenges of an ageing population.

site_title: A second mining dam threatens to collapse in Brazil
summary: A second mining dam in Brazil's Brumadinho town is at risk of collapse, prompting evacuations and sparking outrage over the lack of accountability for the country's mining industry. The dam, owned by Vale S.A., is heavily raining and has high water levels, prompting sirens to sound and residents to flee. The disaster is the second in two days, following a deadly dam rupture that killed 58 and left 305 missing. Brazil's new president, Jair Bolsonaro, has promised to ease regulations on mining, raising concerns about environmental and human safety.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Monday, gaining 0.46% to 27,695.81, driven by gains in the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index. The increases come as high-level China-US trade talks, global data releases, and a Brexit vote are set to shape the week.

images.alt_text:
jecielo22 - il Cielo - Fritto Misto.



Credit Il Cielo restaurant##########jecielo22 ##########Il Cielo restaurant

site_title: Macron says France wants to keep Renault-Nissan 'balance'
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron expressed concerns over the ongoing detention of Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn, stating France wants to maintain a "balance" in the Renault-Nissan alliance. Macron discussed the situation with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, criticizing the harsh conditions of Ghosn's detention. Renault has appointed new executives, Thierry Bollore and Jean-Dominique Senard, to address potential influence loss due to Ghosn's arrest. Macron believes the individual case will not reverse the alliance's stability, but the situation remains a concern for France.

site_title: Thai startup fills gap in tech talent recruiting
summary: A Thai startup, GetLinks, has filled a gap in tech talent recruiting by matching companies with specific tech skills to candidates. The platform, which has raised "eight figures" in funding, has placed over 1,000 candidates across companies such as Tencent and Siam Commercial Bank. GetLinks focuses on matching skills like app development and programming languages, and charges companies 15% of the candidate's first-year salary. The startup's success is seen as a model for matching companies with candidates, but may face challenges in recruiting more seasoned executives.

site_title: New dam disaster puts Vale CEO, deals and dividends under scrutiny
summary: Vale SA, the world's largest iron miner, has faced a devastating tailings dam disaster in Brazil, leaving hundreds missing and presumed dead. The company's CEO, Fabio Schvartsman, has been criticized for his handling of the 2017 Mariana disaster, and his promises to prioritize safety appear to be in jeopardy. Analysts and shareholders are questioning the company's ability to continue its high dividend payout strategy, and a full review of Vale's governance is needed. The disaster has also raised concerns about the company's expansion plans, including its pursuit of mid-sized acquisitions, and may lead to a loss of operating license in the affected area.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.31 points to 1,705.34 at 9am on Monday, with a trading volume of 48.2 million lots worth RM18.24 million. Gainers outpaced losers 123 to 43.

site_title: Hybrid cloud gains traction in Asia Pacific
summary: In the Asia Pacific region, a survey by 451 Research found that over 90% of companies have multiple cloud environments, with more than half already using hybrid cloud. Despite interest in hybrid cloud, a significant portion of large enterprises lack a formal hybrid-cloud strategy. The main drivers for hybrid cloud adoption are security and compliance, with 95% of enterprises rating security as their top requirement. To overcome technical complexity, many enterprises are turning to managed services providers to support hybrid cloud design, implementation, and ongoing operation.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,210.79, up 0.3% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Monday afternoon at 3,210.79, up 0.3% on the day. The Straits Times Index rose 8.54 points, driven by gains in Spackman Entertainment, which traded at 2.9 Singapore cents with 10.1 million shares changing hands. The market saw 497.3 million securities worth S$325.8 million in total change hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 147 to 136.

site_title: Hot stock: Y Ventures down 21% on accounting errors for H1 2018 earnings
summary: Shares in Y Ventures plummeted 20.8% in early trading after the e-commerce firm revised its H1 2018 earnings to a net loss of $1.2 million, down from an initial profit of $130,000. Accounting errors, including overstating inventories and revenue, and understating costs and expenses, were cited as the cause. DBS Equity Research has cut its earnings estimates and suspended coverage on the stock, citing a need for sustainable revenue and earnings growth.

site_title: Chinese rights lawyer jailed for 'subversion'
summary: Chinese human rights lawyer Wang Quanzhang, 42, was sentenced to 4.5 years in prison for state subversion. Wang, who defended activists and victims of land seizures, disappeared in 2015's "709" crackdown. He was the last of over 200 lawyers and activists to be tried or released. Wang was found guilty of subverting state power and deprived of political rights for five years, after a closed-door trial in Tianjin.

images.alt_text: Prominent Chinese human rights lawyer Wang Quanzhang was sentenced on Monday to four and a half years in prison for state subversion, a northern Chinese court said.

site_title: Billionaire Cheng family explores buying Varo Energy
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Cheng family is exploring a potential bid for European fuel supplier Varo Energy BV, valued at around $2.3 billion. The deal, if reached, would be the family's second major acquisition after buying Australian power producer Alinta Energy in 2017. Varo, backed by investors including Carlyle Group LP, has scrapped plans for an initial public offering due to unfavorable market conditions. The proposed Amsterdam Stock Exchange listing would see each shareholder sell a third of their shares, with the Cheng family's involvement marking their expansion into the energy sector.

site_title: Indian tycoon races to end mess that erased US$1.6b off Zee's value
summary: Indian media tycoon Subhash Chandra's company Zee Entertainment Enterprises Ltd. saw its market value drop by $1.6 billion after a report questioned its links to a company being investigated by India's Serious Fraud Investigation Office. Chandra denied the allegations and reached an understanding with lenders, who agreed not to declare a default due to the share plunge. Despite the crisis, Chandra remains committed to selling a stake in Zee to help reduce debt and compete with streaming services like Netflix.

site_title: Asia: Most markets climb at start of crunch week
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Monday as investors await crucial events including high-level trade talks between China and the US. Despite conflicting reports on a potential trade deal, analysts believe both sides have little incentive to escalate tensions. The Federal Reserve's policy meeting and US jobs data will also be closely watched. Markets have been fueled by hopes of a deal, with global equities rallying in December after being hammered.

site_title: Rex International requests trading halt
summary: REX International has requested a trading halt as of January 28, pending an announcement. The company had divested a 20% stake in its Barents Sea licence in October 2018 to focus on core assets near infrastructure in the Norwegian North Sea. On January 25, REX International's shares closed at S$0.081, up 0.2 cents from the previous day. The reason for the trading halt is not specified.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly higher on Monday, STI up 0.05% to 3,203.93
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.68 points, or 0.05%, to 3,203.93 on Monday, driven by a gain in Spackman Entertainment. About 27.6 million shares changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 73 to 42. The market's rally continued ahead of GDP data, with investors shrugging off US trade tensions.

site_title: First Sponsor enters into 4th supplemental agreement over Chengdu project disposal
summary: First Sponsor Group has entered into a fourth supplemental agreement with Minyoun Industrial Group Corporation Limited regarding the proposed disposal of certain parts of the Chengdu Cityspring project in China. The agreement involves the transfer of the second floor of Block 9 and basement car park lots to individuals for a total of 33.1 million yuan. The payment terms have been amended, with some funds from the sale to be used to settle outstanding debts of 18 million yuan. The transactions aim to facilitate the disposal of the project assets.

site_title: China's December industrial profits fall for 2nd straight month; full-yr up 10.3%
summary: China's industrial profits declined 1.9% in December to 680.8 billion yuan, marking the second consecutive month of decline. Despite this, full-year industrial profits rose 10.3% to 6.64 trillion yuan. China's economic growth showed its weakest annual growth in 28 years, with rising downward pressure due to trade disputes.

site_title: Saudi Arabia frees Ethiopian-born tycoon amid flurry of releases
summary: Saudi Arabia has freed Ethiopian-born businessman Mohammed Hussein al-Amoudi, one of the most high-profile detainees in a crackdown on corruption, after 14 months in detention. Al-Amoudi's release comes amid a flurry of other releases and follows a global backlash over the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi and the reported torture of women activists. The kingdom is facing intense scrutiny over its human rights record, and the releases suggest a possible shift in the government's stance.

site_title: Oil prices fall on rising US rig count, economic slowdown
summary: US oil prices fell on Monday as energy firms added rigs for the first time this year, signaling a rise in crude production. US crude oil futures dropped 32 cents to $53.37 per barrel, while Brent crude oil futures fell 27 cents to $61.37 per barrel. Analysts attribute the decline to high US production and a potential economic slowdown amid a trade dispute between the US and China. Despite this, oil prices are expected to range between $50-$60 per barrel for US crude and $61-$71 per barrel for Brent.

site_title: Second Vale dam disaster in Brazil likely to curb mining risk appetite
summary: Brazil's second Vale dam disaster in less than four years has raised concerns about the mining industry's risk appetite, with investors and lawyers warning of potential financial liabilities for the company.
