site_title: Indonesia floods, landslides death toll climbs to 59
summary: Indonesia's floods and landslides have claimed at least 59 lives, with 25 still missing, according to the government. Heavy rain on Sulawesi island forced thousands to flee their homes, inundating dozens of communities and damaging homes, government buildings, and infrastructure. The hardest-hit area, Gowa district, reported 44 fatalities. Authorities have evacuated 3,400 people to temporary shelters, but floodwaters are receding, leaving behind a trail of destruction.

site_title: Tokyo stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.97% to 20,773.56, and the broader Topix index gaining 0.87%. The market's rally was supported by a weaker yen, while investors remain cautious ahead of major events, including US-China trade talks set for next week. Nissan jumped 2.45% after Renault named new executives, while Hitachi fell 0.23% after its chairman expressed concerns over its nuclear power project.

site_title: 3,100 flats to be launched in first BTO exercise of 2019
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) announced its first Build-To-Order (BTO) exercise of 2019, offering approximately 3,100 flats in Jurong West, Kallang/Whampoa, and Sengkang. A concurrent reoffer of balance flats exercise is also planned, with around 15,000 new flats to be launched this year. Resale transactions fell 20.2% in the fourth quarter, while the resale price index (RPI) declined 0.2% and the full-year 2018 RPI dropped 0.9%. The rental market saw a 2.3% increase in approved applications to rent out HDB flats in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Pan Ocean to spend 121.6b won on two new bulk carriers
summary: Pan Ocean Co, a South Korean shipping company, has approved a 121.6 billion won (S$147 million) investment for two new bulk carriers, valued at 5.05% of its share capital. The vessels are expected to be delivered between September 30, 2020, and April 29, 2021. The company has also signed a five-year contract with Vale International to transport 8.12 million tonnes of Brazilian iron ore from the second half of 2020, aiming to secure a stable source of revenue and profit.

site_title: SIIC Environment extends concessionary period at Shandong waste water plant
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings has extended the concessionary period of a waste water plant project in Shandong province, China, from 20 to 30 years. The deal also increases the base water tariff from 0.89 yuan to 1.264 yuan per tonne and upgrades the discharge standard from Grade 1B to Grade 1A. The upgraded plant, designed for 100,000 tons daily, is expected to positively contribute to SIIC Environment's future performance.

site_title: URA office rental index grows at slower clip in Q4, points to smaller hike in office rents this year
summary: Singapore's office rental index grew 0.5% in Q4 2018, slower than the 2.5% increase in Q3, suggesting a smaller hike in office rents this year. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's data shows a 7.4% increase in office rents for 2018, down from 0.4% in 2017. Despite this, property consultants expect CBD Grade A office rents to continue rising, albeit at a slower pace, driven by demand from various sectors and new office space completions.

images.alt_text: CBRE's head of research for Singapore and South-east Asia Desmond Sim says there was a flight to quality in Q4. URA's vacancy rate for Category 1 office space tightened from 15.7 per cent at end-Q4 2017 to 11 per cent at end-Q4 2018.

site_title: Next BOE governor could be another foreigner, Hammond says
summary: The UK government is open to hiring another foreigner as the next Bank of England (BOE) governor, following Canadian Mark Carney's departure in 2020. Chancellor Philip Hammond said the process will start later this year, considering a wide pool of talent, including UK candidates like Andrew Bailey and Andy Haldane. Foreign candidates, such as Raghuram Rajan and Ravi Menon, from India and Singapore, may also be considered. Hammond stated that the BOE governor can be someone from outside the UK, citing Carney's own non-British background.

site_title: Malaysia police seek Jho Low's parents to help with 1MDB probe
summary: Malaysian police are seeking the parents of Jho Low, the alleged mastermind of a massive 1MDB scandal, and his associate Eric Tan, as part of their investigation. Low's father, Low Hock Peng, and Tan are facing joint charges for allegedly receiving illicit funds. The police are also seeking Shabnam Naraindas Daswani, a Singaporean linked to the scandal, and have requested Interpol's help to track down Low and his father. US prosecutors have accused Low of siphoning millions from 1MDB into personal accounts. Low has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing.

site_title: Singapore office rents ease to 0.5% rise in Q4; vacancy rate climbs to 12.1%
summary: Singapore office rents rose 0.5% in the fourth quarter of 2018, slower than the 2.5% increase in the third quarter. The rental index rose 7.4% for the year, while the vacancy rate climbed to 12.1% at the end of Q4 2018, up from 12.0% in the previous quarter. The total supply of office space in the pipeline decreased slightly to 732,000 sq m, while occupied space increased by 39,000 sq m in net lettable area.

site_title: From brutal year to stellar start, tech stocks now Asia darlings
summary: Technology stocks in Asia have staged a comeback, with the MSCI AC Asia Pacific Information Technology Index rising 7.8% this year. Despite disappointing results from chipmakers like SK Hynix and Intel, investors expect a second-half recovery. Analysts point to momentum and nimble investment spending as factors driving the rebound. Key contributors include Samsung, Hynix, and China's Internet giants, with Tencent and Alibaba also seeing significant gains. However, doubts remain over the sustainability of the rally, with some analysts forecasting a 30-40% drop in dynamic random-access memory chip prices.

site_title: Maybank shuts Hong Kong, China institutional research desks
summary: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank) is closing its Hong Kong and China institutional equity research desks to focus on South-east Asian operations. The move affects 13 positions in Hong Kong and seven to eight research jobs. This decision comes in response to new European regulations requiring securities firms to separate research fees from trading commissions. Maybank Kim Eng will continue to provide execution and trading services to institutional clients in Hong Kong, while assisting affected personnel. The closure is part of Maybank's ambition to become a leading bank in South-east Asia by 2020.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS keeps 'buy' on ComfortDelGro amid optimism about new ride-hailing rules
summary: DBS analyst Andy Sim maintains a "buy" call on ComfortDelGro, with a target price of S$2.56, amid optimism over Singapore's new ride-hailing rules. The proposed licensing framework is seen as positive for ComfortDelGro, which operates Singapore's largest taxi fleet, and is expected to boost earnings growth. Sim cites a bottoming-out of Singapore taxi fleet numbers, recent acquisitions, and a public transport fare increase as supporting factors. ComfortDelGro's shares rose 4.02% to S$2.33 in mid-day trading.

site_title: Global shipping rates slump in latest sign of economic slowdown
summary: Global shipping rates for dry-bulk and container ships have plummeted by 47% since mid-2018, indicating a significant economic slowdown. The decline in shipping rates is attributed to ongoing trade tensions between the US and China, as well as other economic factors. Analysts say the slump in dry-bulk commodities, used in core industrial sectors, points to a serious economic slowdown. This is further supported by weakening manufacturing data from Asia, Europe, and North America, and warnings from policymakers about the impact on the job market.

site_title: Chinese scientists successfully clone five gene-edited monkeys
summary: Chinese scientists successfully cloned five monkeys from a gene-edited macaque with circadian-related disorders, marking the first time multiple monkeys have been cloned from a gene-edited adult male. The cloned monkeys were born in Shanghai with a uniform genetic background, useful for studying human diseases such as sleep disorder, depression, and Alzheimer's. This achievement comes after Chinese scientist He Jiankui's international backlash for genetically-altering human embryos, and demonstrates the feasibility of batch cloning gene-edited male monkeys with diseases.

site_title: US warships pass through Taiwan Strait amid China tensions
summary: US warships passed through the Taiwan Strait on Thursday, marking the first such operation this year amid heightened tensions with China. The move, which Taiwan views as a sign of US support, comes as China has increased pressure on Taiwan since President Tsai Ing-wen took office in 2016. China has not ruled out using force to bring Taiwan under its control, while US President Trump's administration has reaffirmed its commitment to Taiwan through the Asia Reassurance Initiative Act.

site_title: Remains found of explorer who put Australia on the map
summary: Remains of British explorer Matthew Flinders, who circumnavigated Australia and popularized its name, have been found near a London railway station. The discovery was made by archaeologists sifting through a burial ground near Euston station, where Flinders was buried in 1814. The remains were identified by a coffin plate, and further study of the skeleton will provide insights into Flinders' life at sea. The discovery comes ahead of Australia Day, a national holiday that has sparked controversy over its treatment of Aboriginal societies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6 points to 1,699.59 at 9am. The market saw 58.8 million lots traded worth RM15.8 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 116 to 45.

site_title: Asia: Markets on course to end week with rally
summary: Asian markets are on track to end a shaky week on a positive note as investors await crucial trade talks between China and the US. The US semiconductor sector saw strong earnings, while oil prices rallied due to concerns over Venezuela's supply. Despite Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross tempering expectations, analysts believe a deal could be reached, with many focusing on the positive comments made by Ross and market analyst Edward Moya. Markets in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, and other regions rose, with hopes for a resolution to the US-China trade war and the US government shutdown.

site_title: US to begin blocking asylum-seekers from entering over Mexican border
summary: The US government announced a plan to block a small number of asylum-seekers from entering the country from Mexico, starting with the San Ysidro border crossing near San Diego. The policy aims to dissuade immigrants, mostly from Central America, from making the long and dangerous journey to the US-Mexico border. Asylum-seekers generally have been allowed to wait in the US, but under the new protocol, they may be turned back or blocked from entering. The move is expected to intensify pressure on Mexican authorities and is likely to be challenged in court by immigrants' rights groups.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.42% to 3,204.22
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.42% to 3,204.22 on Friday, driven by positive starts in Australia and Japan. Gainers outnumbered losers 88 to 49, with DBS Group Holdings and Singapore Exchange leading the gains. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid ongoing US trade talks.

site_title: Power outages as Australia swelters through extreme temperatures
summary: Tens of thousands of Australians experienced power outages as a severe heatwave hit southern states, particularly Melbourne. Authorities ordered forced outages to reduce the risk of the entire grid failing due to surging demand, affecting around 60,000 customers. Temperatures soared to 42.8°C (109°F) in Melbourne, with reports of up to 100 traffic lights without power and some businesses forced to close. The heatwave, which peaked in South Australia, also led to fire warnings and bushfires in Tasmania.

site_title: China to grant more licenses to Wall Street in six months
summary: China's top regulator, Fang Xinghai, announced that more licenses will be granted to global banks in the next six months to allow majority ownership in local securities ventures. This move aims to increase foreign participation in China's financial sector, providing a boost to the domestic industry amid an economic slowdown. UBS Group AG, Nomura Holdings Inc, and JPMorgan Chase & Co have already filed applications, with the goal of allowing Wall Street firms to reap billions of dollars in profit from a new market.

site_title: 85-year-old man loses HK$580m in gold scam: SCMP
summary: An 85-year-old Hong Kong man lost HK$580 million in a gold trading scam over two years. The scam, known as the "London gold fraud," involved fake precious metal transactions and hefty commission fees. The victim, one of seven investors who lost nearly HK$620 million, received cold calls about trading gold in 2016. The scam, which has been ongoing in Hong Kong for years, targeted ethnic Chinese from various countries. Hong Kong police arrested 14 people related to the deception.

images.alt_text: An 85-year-old man has become Hong Kong's biggest victim of a bullion trading scam after being conned out of HK$580 million (S$100.5 million) over two years, according to South China Morning Post.

site_title: 'We don't sell people's data' says Facebook's Zuckerberg
summary: Mark Zuckerberg defended Facebook's business model in a Wall Street Journal opinion piece, stating that targeting ads based on interests is different from selling people's data. Facebook uses "signals" such as liked pages and shared content to target ads, and provides users with controls to block advertisers. Zuckerberg denied selling user data, citing that it would undermine trust and give competitors an advantage. He also claimed that Facebook is not intentionally spreading divisive content, and is investing in artificial intelligence to review and remove violating content.

images.alt_text: Facebook co-founder and chief Mark Zuckerberg on Thursday renewed his defense of the social network's business, arguing that targeting ads based on interests was different from selling people's data.

site_title: Flash: Singapore office rents up 0.5% q-o-q in Q4 2018: URA
summary: Singapore office rents rose 0.5% quarter-over-quarter in Q4 2018, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA). The vacancy rate increased to 12.1%, indicating a moderate market. The slight increase in rents suggests a stable property market in Singapore.

site_title: Senator Warren proposes 'ultra-millionaire tax' of as much as 3%
summary: Senator Elizabeth Warren proposes a "ultra-millionaire tax" with a 2% annual tax on net worth above $50 million, rising to 3% on wealth above $1 billion. The tax aims to address income inequality and fund middle-class relief. Critics argue the tax would be difficult to administer and may not raise as much revenue as expected. The proposal is part of Warren's economic populist message and is likely to face challenges on its constitutionality.

site_title: Singapore private home prices slip 0.1% in Q4 2018, up 7.9% for full year: URA
summary: Singapore's private home prices rose 7.9% in 2018, with non-landed homes increasing 8.3% and landed homes rising 6.3%. However, the Q4 2018 price drop was largely due to landed properties, which fell 2%. Rents also edged up 0.6% for the year, while the vacancy rate dropped to 6.4%. Developers launched 8,769 uncompleted units in 2018, with 8,795 sold. The market is expected to slow down this year, with estimates suggesting a 1-3% increase in prices.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on materials, energy; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Friday, driven by gains in materials and energy stocks, led by iron ore and oil price increases. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 25.3 points to 5,891, its third consecutive week of gains. However, concerns over the US-China trade war and slowing global growth kept risk sentiment in check. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 4.57 points to 9,104.34, with defensive healthcare stocks declining.

site_title: Flash: Singapore retail rents rose 1.2% q-o-q in Q4 2018, says URA
summary: Singapore retail rents rose 1.2% on a quarterly basis in Q4 2018, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA). The vacancy rate increased to 8.5%. This is the first time retail rents have increased since 2017. The Q4 2018 results indicate a slight uptick in the retail market, suggesting a recovery from the previous year's decline.

site_title: Singapore retail rents rise 1.2% in Q4; vacancy rate rises to 8.5%: URA
summary: Singapore's retail rents rose 1.2% in Q4 2018, contrasting with a 1.2% drop in Q3, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. For the year, rents weakened by 1.0% and the price index expanded 0.6%. The islandwide vacancy rate of retail space rose to 8.5% at the end of Q4 2018, up from 7.6% at the end of the previous quarter.

site_title: First Sponsor acquires Milan hotel property for 9.3m euros
summary: REAL estate developer First Sponsor Group has acquired a six-storey hotel property in Milan, Italy for approximately 9.3 million euros (S$14.4 million) in cash. The property, formerly a four-star hotel, remains vacant and unleased. The acquisition is expected to have no material impact on First Sponsor's financials, and the company has taken an insurance policy to cover potential losses in a pending litigation dispute with an ex-tenant. The litigation may take up to eight years to resolve, with a court ruling expected by the end of 2019.

site_title: Flash: Singapore private home prices slip 0.1% in Q4 2018, up 7.9% for full year
summary: Singapore's private home prices dropped 0.1% in Q4 2018, marking a slight decline, but still up 7.9% for the full year. The data from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) reflects the ongoing market trends.

site_title: Kvitova and Osaka will play for Australian Open title and no. 1 ranking
summary: Petra Kvitova and Naomi Osaka will compete in the Australian Open women's final on Saturday, with Kvitova seeking her first major title since 2014 and Osaka aiming to become the first Japanese singles player to hold the No. 1 ranking. Kvitova, who overcame a knife attack in 2016 that left her with nerve and tendon damage, advanced with a 7-6 (2), 6-0 win over Danielle Collins. Osaka, the reigning US Open champion, defeated Karolina Pliskova 6-2, 4-6, 6-4. The winner will claim the Daphne Akhurst Memorial Cup and the No. 1 ranking.

site_title: New cybersecurity roadmap for telecom industry underway
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has launched a multi-year cybersecurity roadmap to protect the country's connectivity infrastructure. The initiative will identify areas for improvement and recommend policies and strategies to develop solutions to cyber threats. Senior Minister Janil Puthucheary announced the plans, emphasizing the need for a balance between driving innovation and protecting citizens' interests. The roadmap will also include new initiatives such as an electric Know Your Customer guide and a public consultation on IoT cybersecurity. Recommendations are expected later this year.

site_title: Subaru probe finds 3,400 staff were not paid for overtime work
summary: Subaru Corp revealed it did not pay overtime wages to 3,400 employees over a two-year period due to under-reported hours. The outstanding wages, totaling 776 million yen (S$9.63 million), were paid retroactively to the affected workers in March 2018. The discovery was made after the 2016 suicide of an overworked employee, and the company has since taken steps to prevent false reporting of work hours. Subaru also owes the deceased worker 4.08 million yen (S$50,607) in overtime pay, with settlement talks ongoing.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Friday, building on previous gains, with the technology sector boosted by US firms' healthy earning reports. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.60% to 27,282.88, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained. The rally came despite global market uncertainty, with US stocks near fresh records despite tariff concerns.

site_title: Singapore seeing unprecedented mortgage slowdown
summary: Singapore's mortgage demand has slowed significantly, growing just 1.9% in the first 11 months of 2018, down from 4.2% in 2017. Rising interest rates and property curbs are attributed to this slowdown. Analysts predict housing prices may drop 3% and new home sales could plummet 20% this year. The credit slowdown threatens to accelerate the decline in residential prices, further impacting the city's housing market.

images.alt_text: Rising interest rates and the latest round of property curbs have put the brakes on mortgage demand at Singapore's banks, potentially further dragging down the city's housing market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.22% or 45.64 points to 20,620.27, and the Topix index increasing 0.13% or 2.09 points to 1,554.69. This follows the benchmark's third consecutive decline. The gains are attributed to investors buying on dips after the recent losses.

site_title: Singapore factory output misses forecasts for December with 2.7% growth
summary: Singapore's factory output missed forecasts for December with a 2.7% growth, lower than the 4% expected by economists. This decline was largely due to the electronics and general manufacturing sectors, which saw output fall 6.8% and 5.7% respectively. Biomedical manufacturing and transport engineering were the only sectors to expand in December, with output increases of 29.9% and 23.7% year-on-year, respectively. The overall manufacturing output rose 7.2% in 2018, but the sector is expected to slow in the months ahead.

site_title: Olam eyes US$1.6b from sale of rubber, sugar arms under new 6-year plan
summary: Olam International plans to sell four business segments worth US$1.6 billion over the next six years as part of its new strategic plan. The segments include rubber, sugar, wood products, and fertilizers, which will be divested or partially sold to focus on more attractive and proven businesses. Olam will invest US$3.5 billion in 12 segments, including e-commerce and co-manufacturing, aiming to improve margins and achieve financial targets such as a return on equity of at least 12% by 2024.

site_title: Trump says if Senate leader reach deal to end shutdown, he would back it
summary: President Donald Trump stated that he would support a deal to end the partial government shutdown if Senate leaders Mitch McConnell and Chuck Schumer reach a reasonable agreement. Trump made the comment after meeting with Republican lawmakers and following a meeting between McConnell and Schumer, who expressed they were "talking."

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust Q4 DPU down 5.9% to 1.502 S cents
summary: Cache Logistics Trust reported a 5.9% decline in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.502 Singapore cents, primarily due to a payment to perpetual security owners and withholding tax on a warehouse divestment. Despite a 4.8% increase in gross revenue to S$31 million, net property income dipped 0.6% to S$23.4 million. The trust's full-year DPU slipped 3.9% to 5.903 Singapore cents, while its aggregate leverage remained at 36.2%. The manager, ARA Trust Management, aims to rebalance the portfolio through asset sales to invest in freehold sites with longer weighted average lease expiry.

site_title: UK launches inquiry to find advantages for banks in Brexit
summary: The UK's Treasury Committee is launching an inquiry to explore how to utilize Brexit to remove regulatory barriers for British banks, aiming to make the country an attractive place to do business. The investigation will examine whether aligning with EU financial rules or pursuing trade with other countries is in the UK's long-term interests. The inquiry follows concerns that lenders are planning to move billions of pounds to the EU post-Brexit, potentially leaving the UK's financial sector at a disadvantage.

images.alt_text: UK lawmakers will investigate how the country can take advantage of Brexit to remove regulatory barriers for British banks.

site_title: China blocks Microsoft's Bing due to technical error: sources
summary: Microsoft's search engine Bing was blocked in China due to a technical error, not censorship, according to sources. The Cyberspace Administration of China stopped Bing's service this week, but it has since been restored. The incident highlights the risks faced by technology companies in China, where regulatory bodies frequently ban or block services without explanation. Microsoft has built a local operation in China, adhering to the government's censorship guidelines, and its Azure cloud computing service remained available. The incident may not be an isolated issue, according to Microsoft President Brad Smith.

images.alt_text: The temporary shutdown of Bing had raised concerns that Microsoft's search engine was the latest victim of online censorship in China, which authorities have ramped up in recent years.

site_title: US airlines still see higher profits but warn of shutdown delays
summary: US airlines, including American Airlines, Southwest Airlines, and JetBlue Airways, warn of significant travel delays if the US government shutdown continues, despite still expecting solid profits in 2019. The shutdown's impact on airport operations and employee morale is increasing, with some airports facing rising absenteeism and air transport workers cautioning that the prolonged shutdown endangers travel. However, airline executives express confidence in the safety of the system, citing strong demand for air travel and expecting the shutdown to end soon.

site_title: A US$41b flash crash in Singapore gives traders fright
summary: A US$41 billion flash crash occurred in Singapore's stock market on January 25, 2019, when Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd plummeted 83% in pre-market trading. Despite speculation about a human or machine error, the Singapore Exchange found no evidence of manipulation. The price drop, which reversed quickly, left three market makers with losses and over a dozen counterparties with profits. The incident highlights the risks of lightning-fast financial markets and the need for better protection mechanisms during pre-market hours.

site_title: 2018 was fourth hottest year on record: researchers
summary: US research group Berkeley Earth reports that 2018 was the fourth hottest year on record, with temperatures 1.16 degrees Celsius above the pre-industrial baseline. This is despite 2018 being cooler than the previous three years. The European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service also found 2015-2018 to be the hottest years on record. The slight decline in 2018 is attributed to short-term natural variability, but the overall trend remains consistent with long-term global warming.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, SGX, Keppel Corp, Keppel-KBS US Reit, Ascendas India Trust, FLT
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singapore stocks saw notable developments on Friday. Olam International plans to sell off four business segments to unlock US$1.6 billion, while investing US$3.5 billion in 12 segments deemed attractive. SGX posted a 9.2% jump in Q2 net profit, while Keppel Corp reversed a loss of S$492 million in Q4 earnings. Keppel-KBS US Reit's DPU fell 16.7% due to dilution from a recent rights issue. Ascendas India Trust's results improved despite a depreciating Indian rupee, and Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust's DPU fell 1.1% due to foreign exchange translation changes.

site_title: US oil production is 23 years ahead of schedule
summary: US oil production is now projected to reach 14.53 million barrels a day in 2031, 23 years ahead of schedule. The Energy Information Administration credits higher near-term prices boosting production, combined with slower demand growth. This will make the US a net exporter of petroleum and energy by next year, years sooner than previously estimated. The accelerated production growth is attributed to faster increases in crude and natural gas liquids production.

site_title: Heathrow turns to AI to cut gap between flights by 20 seconds
summary: Heathrow airport is testing AI-powered cameras to reduce the gap between flights by 20 seconds. The system, developed by Searidge Technologies, uses ultra-high-definition cameras to determine when runways are clear of planes, allowing for more efficient flight management. The trial, led by NATs, aims to improve safety and efficiency, potentially paving the way for deployment this year. The technology could also be used for Heathrow's $22 billion third runway, which is set to open by 2025.

site_title: Carlos Slim buys businesses from rival Telefonica for US$648m
summary: Carlos Slim's phone empire, America Movil, has acquired operations in Guatemala and El Salvador from rival Telefonica for $648 million. The deal, subject to regulatory approval, allows Telefonica to exit underperforming units and reduce debt. This follows a long-standing rivalry between the two companies in Latin America, with America Movil dominating Mexico and Telefonica ruling Brazil. The acquisition is expected to expand America Movil's presence in the region, bolstering its market share in Mexico.

site_title: Canada's envoy to China 'misspoke' on Huawei CFO case
summary: Canada's ambassador to China, John McCallum, has admitted to "misspeaking" about Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou's extradition case, stating she has "good arguments on her side." McCallum's comments created confusion, as the US has until January 30 to request her extradition. The case has strained Canada-China relations, with two Canadians detained in China. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has focused on releasing detained Canadians, saying McCallum's removal wouldn't help their case.

site_title: Time is running out for first quarter's US IPO hopefuls
summary: US companies with initial public offerings (IPOs) are running out of time, with the first quarter likely to be disappointing due to the US government shutdown. To avoid providing outdated financial information, IPOs must be priced before February 14, with only the first nine months of numbers required until then. Experts warn that the window to complete an IPO before third-quarter financials go stale is closing, making it challenging for companies to meet the deadline.

site_title: Argentina economy suffers worst shrinkage of Macri era
summary: Argentina's economy suffered its worst shrinkage during President Mauricio Macri's tenure, with a 7.5% drop in GDP compared to 2017. This is the fourth consecutive month of economic decline, with a 2.2% shrinkage in 2018. The worst-hit sectors include commerce, industrial manufacturing, and construction. The country entered recession in December after the International Monetary Fund predicted a 2.6% GDP decline in 2018, with a further 1.7% shrinkage expected this year.

site_title: European bank mergers are alive in Davos executives' dream deals
summary: European bank executives at the Davos conference are calling for consolidation, citing the need to match Wall Street competitors' strength after a difficult year for European bank stocks. Speculation surrounds potential deals, including a merger between Deutsche Bank AG and Commerzbank AG, and a possible acquisition by BNP Paribas SA. Other scenarios include BNP Paribas acquiring Barclays Plc or Credit Suisse Group AG expanding. Despite the lack of a single European market, executives express urgency due to the growing gap with US firms, which are now posting record profits.

site_title: BlackRock appoints new global head of renewable power
summary: BlackRock has appointed David Giordano as the new global head of renewable power, replacing Jim Barry. Giordano, who joined the team in 2011, oversees renewable-energy assets worth over $5 billion across four continents. The company also named Rory O'Connor global chief investment officer for the renewables group, and made other management changes. These moves come as pension funds, insurers, and sovereign wealth funds show increasing interest in renewable-energy investments.

site_title: Group of giant new tankers lines up to ship diesel out of Asia
summary: A fleet of five newly built oil tankers, known as Very Large Crude Carriers (VLCCs), is positioned off China's eastern and southern coasts, preparing to ship diesel out of Asia. The tankers, which can carry 2 million barrels of oil each, are expected to disperse diesel to northwest Europe, with possible partial discharges in West Africa. This surge in Asian exports mirrors an increase in shipments of oil products, much of it diesel, from India and the Middle East into Europe, driven by weak local demand and the start of refinery maintenance season in Europe.

site_title: Malaysia police seek 1MDB documents from Goldman's lawyer
summary: Malaysian police have asked Goldman Sachs' lawyer, Rahmat Lim & Partners, to hand over documents related to 1MDB bond sales arranged by the US lender. The police raided the law firm's offices on Thursday, seeking documents not subject to attorney-client privilege. Goldman Sachs is facing its first criminal charges related to its role in arranging $6.5 billion for the scandal-plagued state investment fund 1MDB. The bank has denied misleading investors and will vigorously defend against the allegations. The police obtained a court order to raid the law firm after it refused to provide the requested documents.

site_title: Coca-Cola, Pepsi tout plastic recycling in rare joint appearance
summary: Coca-Cola and Pepsi have pledged to reduce plastic waste by 2030, a goal of the Alliance to End Plastic Waste, a joint effort by 30 multinationals. The companies aim to minimize and manage plastic waste, donating $1 billion to the cause. Soft drink executives James Quincey and Ramon Laguarta expressed optimism about solving the problem, with Quincey noting that some countries have already made progress in reducing plastic waste. However, activists remain skeptical about the alliance's effectiveness, citing the significant impact of plastic pollution on humans, wildlife, and oceans.

site_title: Intel's forecast misses on slowing China, data centre; shares tumble
summary: Intel Corp forecasted current-quarter revenue and profit below analysts' estimates, missing on fourth-quarter sales expectations due to a slowdown in China and sluggish demand for its data centre and modem chips. Shares fell 7.7% in extended trading, while smaller rival Advanced Micro Devices dropped 2% and Nvidia fell 1%. The company forecast $16 billion in revenue and 87 cents per share in adjusted earnings, below analyst expectations of $17.35 billion and $1.01 per share.

site_title: Soros calls China's Xi 'most dangerous' foe of free societies
summary: Billionaire investor George Soros has labeled Chinese President Xi Jinping as "the most dangerous enemy" of free societies due to his high-tech surveillance regime. Soros expressed concerns over US tech giants, particularly Facebook, and urged authorities to rein them in for democracy's sake. He also warned of the security risks posed by Chinese tech giants ZTE and Huawei in the rollout of 5G wireless networks, calling for a focused effort on China. Soros believes a new alliance among those who value open societies is necessary to counter Xi's control.

site_title: 'We are losing the race' on climate change: UN chief
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres warned at the World Economic Forum in Davos that the world is "losing the race" against climate change, urging governments to take bolder action to stop runaway warming. He criticized the lack of political will and pointed to the withdrawal of the US and threats from Brazil as major obstacles. Guterres called for stronger commitments, financial aid for poorer countries, and measures to mitigate and adapt to climate change. Despite growing concern, corporate executives and activists differ on the pace and scale of action needed to address the crisis.

site_title: Rising Star
summary: Singer-songwriter Glen Wee, a Singapore-born musician, has released his debut album "Sounds in the City" after finishing third on The Final One reality singing competition. The album blends folk, blue-eyed soul, and old school blues, drawing comparisons to Damien Rice and Sam Cooke. Wee views the album as a "log book" of his life journey, and it is available for download and streaming on digital platforms.

site_title: Germany expected to slash growth estimates for 2019: report
summary: Germany's government is expected to lower its economic growth forecast for 2019 to 1.0% due to a slowing global economy and uncertainty around Brexit, according to a report by Handelsblatt. Despite this, Germany still expects to mark its 10th consecutive year of expansion, with estimated growth of 1.6% in 2020. This adjustment is not a surprise, as Europe's top economy has faced industrial difficulties for several months.

site_title: Can South-East Asia sustain investment boom?
summary: South-east Asia's venture capital and private equity investment has reached record levels, driven by new investors and a growing pool of startups. The region's technology sector attracted 40% of new capital in 2017, with 10 unicorns created since 2012, valued at US$34 billion. To sustain the momentum, investors must focus on value creation and organic growth, as competition and higher valuations increase. The region's maturing ecosystems and government initiatives, such as Singapore's Startup SG Founder programme, are creating a favorable environment for investment. Investors targeting sectors like healthcare and education will face intense competition, and those who build regional businesses, secure top talent, and improve commercial excellence will be best positioned for solid returns.

site_title: Plant Food
summary: A hotel in Singapore, Novotel on Stevens, introduces new vegan options to its menus, including scrambled eggs made from JUST Eggs and plant-based burgers from Beyond Meat and Omnipork. These alternatives offer more protein and iron than traditional eggs and meat. The move aims to cater to the growing demand for environmentally friendly protein sources. The hotel's all-day dining eatery also serves pea-based dishes with Thai basil. This shift towards plant-based options reflects the growing trend towards alternative protein sources.

site_title: Huawei eyes smartphone supremacy this year after record 2018 sales
summary: Huawei forecasts becoming the world's biggest-selling smartphone vendor this year, despite US market restrictions and global scrutiny. The company reported a 50% jump in consumer business revenue to over $52 billion last year. Huawei's smartphone division shipped 208 million handsets, and the company aims to launch a foldable smartphone with 5G chipset next month. Despite weakening sales in China, Huawei believes it will maintain its momentum and become number one in the world, even without the US market.

site_title: US oil up 1% on Venezuela turmoil, but hefty stock build weighs
summary: US oil prices rose 1% on Thursday, driven by a US threat to sanction Venezuela's crude exports, amid growing political and economic turmoil in the country. The US, top importer of Venezuelan crude, aims to ensure opposition leader Juan Guaido receives oil revenue, while cutting off funds to President Nicolas Maduro. However, record high gasoline inventories and a large build in US crude stocks weighed on gains, with US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rising 51 cents to settle at $53.13 a barrel.

images.alt_text: US oil prices rose by 1 per cent on Thursday, boosted by the US threat of sanctions on Venezuela, but gains were capped by record high gasoline inventories and an unexpected big build in crude stocks in the United States.

site_title: Venezuela's military backs Maduro, as standoff hardens with US
summary: Venezuela's military has backed President Nicolas Maduro, defying US recognition of opposition leader Juan Guaido as interim president. The US has declared Maduro's regime "illegitimate" and imposed sanctions, while 12 regional powers, including Brazil and Argentina, support Guaido. The death toll from protests has risen to 26, with Maduro vowing to defend his authority. International recognition of Guaido may elevate his profile, but analysts suggest removing Maduro would require military backing, which appears unlikely. The crisis has plunged the oil-rich country into uncertainty, with economic sanctions and potential military intervention looming.

site_title: Keppel reverses losses to post S$135m Q4 profit
summary: Keppel Corporation posted a quarterly profit of S$134.5 million in Q4 2018, reversing losses of S$492 million a year ago. Excluding a one-off financial penalty, the group's net profit would have been 6% higher year-over-year. The property division contributed to the group's profits, but revenue growth was flat. The company is investing in new businesses, such as senior living and renewable energy infrastructure, to drive future growth.

site_title: Europe: Downbeat Draghi curbs gains on European shares as tech shines
summary: European shares ended the day with modest gains, despite downbeat comments from ECB President Mario Draghi, who acknowledged weaker-than-expected economic growth in the euro zone. Tech stocks, however, continued to shine, with chipmaker STMicro's upbeat forecast for the second half of the year driving gains. The euro zone's banking index fell 0.5% due to Draghi's remarks, while tech stocks rose between 2-7%. Investors remain cautious due to global economic headwinds and unresolved trade tensions.

images.alt_text: European shares ended off highs on Thursday as a bounce in tech stocks after results from chipmaker STMicro was offset by late slide among banks following downbeat comments from ECB President Mario Draghi over the health of the region's economy.

site_title: Singapore, China to set up mediator panel for Belt and Road projects
summary: Singapore and China have agreed to establish a mediator panel to resolve disputes from Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) projects. The panel, comprising professionals from China, Singapore, and BRI countries, will develop rules and procedures tailored to Asian needs. The move aims to provide a "new way of settling cross-border commercial disputes" that reflects Asian values. This collaboration is seen as a way to leverage Singapore's reputation for having a strong rule of law and impartiality in resolving BRI-related disputes.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust Q4 DPU up 6.7% to 2.22 S'pore cents
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 6.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter of 2018, reaching 2.22 Singapore cents. The higher DPU was attributed to increased net property income from its portfolio and dividends. Unitholders will receive the DPU on February 28, 2029.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business: SMEs are complacent and NOT cyber prepared
summary: A Money FM podcast highlighted the complacency and cyber unpreparedness of Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore. Experts emphasized the need for SMEs to prioritize cybersecurity to protect against increasing cyber threats. The discussion was part of the "Mind Your Business" podcast series, which aims to provide insights on business and finance topics.

site_title: Commodity investors fear the future in the Trump era: Goldman
summary: Commodity investors are increasingly cautious due to global geopolitical uncertainty, according to Goldman Sachs. Traders are shifting to shorter-term contracts, with trading volume for front-month contracts rising for commodities like oil, soyabeans, and wheat. However, this trend is not universal, with some markets like London metals experiencing a decline. The uncertainty is fueled by ongoing trade wars, sanctions, and a partial US government shutdown, keeping investors on edge.

site_title: Indonesia releases new rules on export revenue repatriation for resources
summary: Indonesia has issued new rules requiring exporters of natural resources to receive earnings in local banking industry, effective immediately. The regulation, signed by President Joko Widodo, mandates that export revenues from mining, plantation, forestry, or fishery sectors be kept in a special banking account, with 90% of earnings already flowing through local banks. Non-compliance may result in fines, export bans, or revocation of business permits.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit Q4 DPU falls below forecast after rights issue
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit (KORE) reported a lower-than-forecast fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.25 US cents due to dilution from a recent rights issue. Excluding the effects of the acquisition and rights issue, DPU would have been 1.51 US cents, in line with the Reit manager's forecast. The rights issue partially funded the acquisition of the Westpark portfolio in Seattle in November.

site_title: Dubai developer looking to invest as much as £1b in London property sector
summary: Damac Properties, a Dubai-based developer, plans to invest up to £1 billion in London's real estate market, despite a weak pound and potential Brexit uncertainty. The company's chairman, Hussain Sajwani, believes in taking advantage of market opportunities, even in a hard Brexit scenario. Damac aims to trim costs and pay down debt in Dubai, and is focusing on international acquisitions as the local market may not recover before the end of 2020.

site_title: Let's do business, forget about journalist killing: Riyadh
summary: Saudi Arabia appears to have successfully contained the fallout from the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, with the kingdom hosting a strong delegation at the World Economic Forum in Davos. The Saudi economy minister and finance minister met with Western businessmen, including Total's CEO and Morgan Stanley's boss, and secured a top spot on a panel debate. Western allies have called for accountability, but the damage control efforts seem to be working, with no Western investors pulling out and new foreign direct investment licenses doubling last year.

site_title: Bank of Korea stands pat on interest rates
summary: The Bank of Korea (BOK) maintained its key interest rate at 1.75% on January 24, 2019, amid rising economic risks. Governor Lee Ju-yeol stated that the central bank will keep its policy accommodative but not consider a near-term rate cut. The BOK trimmed its growth outlook to 2.6% and inflation forecast to 1.4%. The decision was seen as a response to mounting economic risks, including weakening exports and global uncertainties, and was influenced by US monetary policy. The BOK will continue to monitor conditions and adjust its policy as needed.

site_title: Mercedes C-Class review: A face-lift you can hardly C
summary: The Mercedes C-Class has undergone a minor face-lift, with subtle changes to the exterior and interior. The updates include new front and rear lamps, reshaped bumpers, and thousands of new parts, many of which are borrowed from larger E-Class and S-Class models. The car now features a 10.25-inch infotainment screen, virtual instruments, and touchpads on the steering wheel. A new 1.5-liter turbo engine with mild hybrid drive will be available in the C 200 model later this year, offering improved performance and efficiency. The C-Class maintains its appeal in its compact package, offering the signature Mercedes qualities with refined features.

site_title: SGX Q2 profit up 9.2%; derivatives remain sweet spot
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 9.2% increase in Q2 net profit to S$96.5 million, driven by higher revenue in its derivatives segment, which rose 35% to a record S$113 million. The equities and fixed income businesses were impacted by global market volatility. Operating profit rose 10.4% to S$113.7 million, with expenses increasing 8.3%. SGX shares finished at S$7.50, up 9 cents or 1.2%.

site_title: Consortium awaits MAS nod to test market for private-company shares
summary: A consortium of brokers, including Phillip Securities and PrimePartners, is awaiting approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to test a market for trading private-company shares. The proposed exchange, Hg Exchange, aims to promote transparency by sharing transaction data among market makers and private companies. If approved, it will join existing platforms like CapBridge's 1exchange, which has already been approved to operate as a private securities exchange. The goal is to bring liquidity to private companies prior to an exit event, such as an IPO.

site_title: About 50 industry groups appeal for end to US metals tariffs
summary: US industry groups, including the Motor & Equipment Manufacturers Association and the National Association of Egg Farmers, sent a letter to the Trump administration pleading for an end to the economic pain caused by US tariffs on steel and aluminum. The tariffs have increased costs for US companies importing metal products or components, and have led to retaliatory moves by countries like China and Mexico. The groups warned that the damage from the tariffs far outweighs any benefits to the steel industry, and urged the administration to resolve the matter to resume zero-tariff North American trade.

site_title: MAS revises takeover rules for dual-class shares
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) revised its takeover rules for dual-class shares, clarifying that independent shareholders won't be required to make a general offer if their share of voting rights exceeds regulatory thresholds under certain circumstances. The new rules also mandate the same offer price for multiple-voting and ordinary-voting shares. The revisions aim to provide greater certainty and safeguard holders of ordinary voting shares.

site_title: Temasek's ST Telemedia takes majority stake in cloud computing firm
summary: Temasek's ST Telemedia has acquired a majority stake in Singapore-based cloud computing firm Cloud Comrade. The deal aims to enhance STT's multi-cloud capabilities in Asia and bring complementary capability and market reach. Cloud Comrade will leverage STT's resources and international network to pursue market opportunities and accelerate customer expansion. Established in 2014, Cloud Comrade offers a range of cloud IT services, and the acquisition is seen as a strategic move by STT to tap into Asia's digital transformation market, driven by growing demand for advanced AI and cloud implementation services.

site_title: Art giant remembered
summary: Renowned Malaysian artist Cheong Soo Pieng, known for his unique blend of Chinese and South-east Asian sensibilities, has left a lasting legacy in the art world. A showcase of his 52 works, featuring various materials, highlights his innovative approach to composition and materiality. His art remains relevant to art historians and collectors, who continue to clamour for his works. Pieng's unique style has ensured his practice remains influential, even decades after his passing in 1983.

site_title: Ford falls into the red for the fourth quarter
summary: Ford Motor Co reported a net loss of $116 million for the fourth quarter of 2018, missing analysts' estimates and marking the company's second quarterly loss since 2009. The loss was attributed to deeper deficits overseas and a loss on its pension fund. CEO Jim Hackett has been trying to overhaul the company through cost-cutting measures and shifting focus to SUVs and trucks. Ford faces significant headwinds, including commodity costs, tariffs, and unfavorable foreign exchange swings, which could impact its 2019 outlook if the UK leaves the European Union.

site_title: Euro falls to three-week low ahead of ECB meeting
summary: The euro fell to a three-week low ahead of the European Central Bank's meeting, losing 0.3% at US$1.133. Investors expect the ECB to reaffirm plans to raise interest rates by the end of the year, but focus on policymakers' caution about slowing economic growth. French business activity fell unexpectedly, and Germany, France, and Italy's economies barely grew in the fourth quarter. The euro's decline is seen as a risk of modest dovish bias from ECB President Mario Draghi, potentially hurting the currency.

site_title: Outlook for S'pore industrial space stable: analysts
summary: The Singapore industrial space market experienced a stable outlook in Q4 2018, with rentals and prices remaining unchanged compared to the previous quarter. The occupancy rate increased to 89.3%, the highest in seven quarters. Analysts predict a stabilisation phase that may last for a couple of years, with some expecting a slight downward pressure due to new supply and economic concerns. Experts forecast that industrial property prices and rentals will remain largely unchanged in 2019.

site_title: Too many cooks in catering?
summary: Singapore's catering industry faces intense competition, thin margins, and rising costs, making it a challenging business. Key players share their struggles as the market becomes increasingly saturated. Meanwhile, investors are advised to be cautious amid volatility, and the media prepares to relocate to a new office. This weekend, the Australian Open women's tennis final and a new column on iconic cocktails and Singapore's best bars will be featured.

site_title: Can we make artificial intelligence ethical?
summary: The US must lead in developing AI in a way that increases public confidence that it benefits society. An ethics-driven approach to AI involves addressing biases, privacy concerns, and workforce disruption. Companies must take the lead in exploring how to avoid biases, disclose AI use to consumers, and address job impact. The federal government must provide significant funding for AI research and development at universities, which are best positioned to employ a multidisciplinary approach to AI. An ethics-driven approach ensures AI's powerful capabilities are a net positive for people and workers, guaranteeing US leadership in the long term.

site_title: ECB chief warns of headwinds for the eurozone economy
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) chief Mario Draghi warned of growing headwinds for the eurozone economy, citing slowing global momentum, Brexit uncertainty, and US-China trade tensions. Eurozone growth slowed to 0.2% in the third quarter of 2018, and experts expect the fourth quarter to also disappoint. The ECB ended its massive bond-buying scheme in December, removing a key economic support. Despite this, Draghi said the ECB is prepared to face economic headwinds and has not ruled out future policy changes, including a rate hike later this year.

site_title: Romantic Getaway
summary: Luxury travel company andBeyond offers an 11-day Valentine's Day getaway combining culture, wildlife, and history with relaxation in Sri Lanka and the Maldives. The trip includes visits to the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic, hot air balloon rides, and time with giant Asian elephants. Couples can also snorkel in the Maldives or enjoy the beach. The package starts at USD 5,420 and includes four nights in the Maldives.

site_title: Harried South Koreans pamper pets instead of having babies
summary: In South Korea, a growing trend of pet ownership has led to a booming pet industry, as many couples opt to prioritize pampering their pets over having children due to high education and housing costs, as well as long working hours. Pet-related businesses, including tailored diets and photo shoots, are thriving, with the industry expected to double in size by 2027. This phenomenon is attributed to social pressures and economic stress, with 28% of South Korean households now owning pets, up from 18% in 2012.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands' Q4 earnings slide on weaker VIP gaming
summary: Marina Bay Sands' Q4 earnings declined 20.8% to US$362m due to weaker VIP gaming, with casino rolling chip volume tumbling 13.9% to US$6.8 billion. This offset growth in hotel and non-gaming businesses. The parent company, Las Vegas Sands Corp, also reported a 4.7% decline in Ebitda to US$1.34 billion, with a net loss of US$170 million. Despite this, the group's net revenue rose 2.5% to US$3.48 billion.

site_title: MAS halts ICO over public LinkedIn advertisement
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has halted an initial coin offering (ICO) due to non-compliance with regulatory requirements. The issuer failed to obtain a prospectus exemption under the Securities and Futures Act when it openly advertised the ICO on LinkedIn. The MAS stated that the issuer planned to rely on the exemption, which allows issuers to make offers to accredited investors without registering a prospectus. The MAS has stopped the ICO from proceeding, citing non-compliance with regulations.

site_title: What makes a Ferrari worth a million dollars in Singapore?
summary: In Singapore, the luxury car market is driven by exclusivity and brand value rather than raw performance, as seen in the Ferrari Portofino's $855,000 price tag. Despite its high performance capabilities, the car is praised for its day-to-day driveability and user-friendliness, making it a desirable option for those seeking a Ferrari experience. Ferrari's CEO, Dieter Knechtel, attributes the brand's appeal to its exclusivity, innovation, and iconic status, which attracts loyal customers willing to invest in a Ferrari and potentially build a collection over time.

images.alt_text: Above: With a highly tuned twin-turbo V8 engine, the Ferrari Portofino can scamper from 0 to 100 km/h in just 3.5 seconds, and reach a scarcely believable top speed of 320 km/h.
Above: The brand's sporting heritage is a big draw for customers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust posted a 1.1% dip in distribution per unit due to foreign exchange translation changes. Great Eastern Holdings will contribute RM2 billion to Malaysia's health insurance scheme, exempting it from foreign ownership limits. Ascendas India Trust saw higher interest income and a one-off tax benefit lift its results. SATS Ltd entered two joint ventures in China to boost its business. KPMG Corporate Finance was appointed as the independent financial adviser for Courts Asia's cash offer from a Japanese electronics retailer.

site_title: Let there be iLight
summary: The iLight Singapore festival will return from Jan 28 to Feb 24, 2019, with 33 light art installations in Marina Bay, the Civic District, Singapore River, and Raffles Terrace. The festival features five distinct locations, including Raffles Terrace with acoustic music acts and guided tours, and Prudential Marina Bay Carnival with thrill rides and family performances. For more information, visit ilightsingapore.sg.

site_title: A French revolution in luxury
summary: The Citroen DS 7 Crossback, a luxury SUV from French carmaker Citroen, has been released to address the brand's reputation for quirks and imprecision. The DS 7 boasts an opulent interior, with features such as a 12.0-inch touchscreen, ventilated massage seats, and a 14-speaker sound system. The vehicle's performance is also praised, with a turbocharged 1.6-litre engine delivering 225hp and an 8-speed automatic gearbox. While it has some drawbacks, such as a busy ride quality and a less-than-perfect infotainment system, the DS 7 is a significant step forward for the brand, offering a convincingly upper-crust motoring experience at a price of S$185,999.

site_title: China deletes 'malicious' mobile apps
summary: China's cyber watchdog, the Cyberspace Administration of China, has deleted nearly 8,000 "malicious" mobile apps, including a Tencent Holdings game that overcharged and cheated users. The campaign targets apps that infringe on users' rights, such as information theft and spamming. The move is part of China's efforts to tighten control over the internet, following a recent suspension of new video game approvals and a broader crackdown on dissent on social media.

site_title: Sabana Reit Q4 DPU falls to 0.71 Singapore cent
summary: Sabana Reit reported a decline in its fourth-quarter Distribution Per Unit (DPU) to 0.71 Singapore cent, down from 0.83 cent in the same period last year. This decrease was attributed to lower occupancies and negative rental reversions for some master leases, resulting in a 15.3% decline in Q4 income available for distribution to S$7.44 million.

site_title: US Congress seeks information on who posted viral video of Native American taunt
summary: The US House Intelligence Committee is investigating the viral video of a Native American protester being taunted by white teenagers in Washington. The committee requested information from Twitter about the rapid spread of the video and the accounts that first uploaded and retweeted it. The investigation aims to identify the individuals responsible for the initial posting of the video, which sparked widespread outrage and racial tensions.

site_title: Singapore Showcase
summary: Design Orchard, a 2.5-storey retail and incubation space, has opened on Orchard Road in Singapore, featuring over 60 local brands showcasing fashion, beauty, home furnishings, souvenirs, and food. The project aims to support local lifestyle brands and emerging talents, with a focus on sustainability and longevity. The space includes a rooftop amphitheatre and incubation facilities, such as The Cocoon Space, operated by the Textile and Fashion Federation Singapore, which will nurture independent designers and fashion businesses. Experts predict that the space will attract shoppers seeking unique, artisanal products, while retail shops in malls are unlikely to be affected.

site_title: StanChart makes its first S'pore trade finance deal on blockchain
summary: Standard Chartered has completed its first cross-border trade finance transaction on a blockchain-based platform in Singapore, streamlining the documentation process and providing security and transparency for participants. The bank used Distributed Ledger Technologies' platform to facilitate a deal between Agrocorp International and BSM Global, resulting in a shipment of chickpeas from Australia to Bangladesh in just one day. This marks a significant expansion of StanChart's blockchain-based supply chain solution, which aims to support more clients regionally and globally.

site_title: Hyundai Motor posts first net loss in 8 years as China sales tumble
summary: Hyundai Motor reported its first quarterly net loss in eight years, with a net loss of 129.8 billion won (S$156.3 million) in the fourth quarter due to weakness in emerging market currencies and rising investments. China sales tumbled 23% in the fourth quarter, despite the company's efforts to boost exports and expand sales by 9% this year. The company blamed one-off costs and a decline in the Chinese car market, which contracted for the first time in over two decades, for the weak results.

site_title: Bank of China unveils first perpetual bond amid capital pressure
summary: Bank of China Ltd has unveiled its first perpetual bond, a landmark deal that paves the way for similar fundraising from Chinese financial institutions. The 40 billion yuan (S$8 billion) bond aims to replenish additional Tier 1 capital, as Chinese regulators encourage banks to diversify their capital structure. The move comes as Chinese banks face pressure to boost support to the real economy, with capital buffers under strain due to a slowing economy and soured loans. This is a new way for banks to boost capital, with other lenders planning to issue similar securities.

images.alt_text: Bank of China is looking to issue as much as 40 billion yuan of perpetual bonds to replenish additional Tier 1 capital.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) and Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) have been downgraded to "neutral" by Phillip Capital, citing negative rent reversion and stagnant back-filling of The Strategy. MCT reported strong Q3 FY19 results, with physical occupancy and rental reversions improving, but tenant sales at VivoCity fell. OCBC Investment Research retains its "hold" rating for MCT, citing limited upside potential.

site_title: Business Class
summary: Key fashion trends for Spring/Summer 2019 include Dior's remake of its iconic saddle bag, Bottega Veneta's Maxi Cabat tote, and Miuccia Prada's pop-out print bags. Ermenegildo Zegna's Pelle Tessuta fabric and Celine's debut men's collection also made a statement. Louis Vuitton's Steamer bag was reimagined with a metallic strap pin closure and bright orange chain accents. Meanwhile, Silvia Venturini Fendi introduced the Peekaboo X-lite for men, and Hedi Slimane's Celine collection featured handsomely crafted bags.

images.alt_text: Dior Saddle backpack in calfskin, S$5,000, by DIOR.
Maxi Cabat in calfskin, S$13,630, by BOTTEGA VENETA.
Saffiano leather tote bag, price unavailable, by PRADA.
Pelle Tessuta leather backpack (with detachable top handle), S$3,600, by ERMENEGILDO ZEGNA.
Peekaboo X-lite bag in calfskin, S$5,490, by FENDI.
Medium Soft Bucket bag in lambskin price unavailable, by CELINE.
Monogram Steamer bag in canvas and calf leather, S$5,200, by LOUIS VUITTON.

site_title: Asia's thirst for beer adds fizz to mega-brewer's plans for IPO
summary: Asia's growing demand for beer is driving Anheuser-Busch InBev's plans for an initial public offering (IPO) of its Asian operations. The world's largest brewer is considering listing its Singapore-based businesses, which include Budweiser and Stella Artois. The IPO is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on the region's increasing beer consumption, with Asia's thirst for beer expected to continue growing. This move could mark a significant transformation similar to the one in the US in 1934, when canned beer was introduced, revolutionizing the industry.

site_title: Into the arena for camel wrestling in Turkey
summary: In Turkey's Selcuk town, a centuries-old tradition of camel wrestling takes place, with over 2,000 people attending the event. The fights, which date back to the 19th century, are part of a nomadic culture that originated with the Yoruks people. Animal rights groups have called for an end to the practice, citing cruelty, but owners claim necessary measures are taken to protect the camels. The festival, which also includes a beauty contest and an international symposium, aims to preserve the tradition and potentially secure a place on the UNESCO list for intangible cultural heritage.

site_title: Q4 numbers fail to lift hopes; muted outlook for local firms
summary: Analysts predict a muted Q4 earnings season in Singapore due to weaker economic growth and investment sentiment. Banks, certain blue-chip property developers, and a handful of other companies are expected to fare better, driven by higher net interest margins, revenue recognition from completed projects, and improved operational performances. However, the sector's growth prospects are uncertain due to ongoing trade tensions and a year-end lull. Analysts expect only 80 of 733 listed companies to report earnings that meet expectations, with the majority at risk of disappointing investors.

site_title: Crunching big data enables targeted service
summary: The hospitality industry is leveraging big data and analytics to enhance customer experience and increase revenue. Hotels like Hilton, Hotels.com, and InterContinental Hotels Group use data analytics to gain a 360-degree view of customers, personalize amenities, and optimize pricing. This approach has led to increased repeat visits and happier guests. Data-driven marketing also enables hotels to create targeted advertising and improve customer satisfaction. The industry is also embracing emerging technologies such as facial recognition, payment wallets, and wearable technology to create personalized experiences. By harnessing the power of big data, hotels can improve customer relationships and achieve sustainable growth.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Tourism Board, seeing the need for digital transformation, has a plan in the works to develop 'smart hotels'.

site_title: Thailand's March 24 post-coup election must be inclusive, fair and credible
summary: Thailand's March 24 general election, delayed five times, is now set to take place, marking a major step in the country's return to democracy. The election, first held since 2014, will be the first to include the military's own political party. Many Thais remain skeptical about the election's fairness and transparency, citing concerns about the military's influence and past violent protests. The country's tourism industry, a significant contributor to its economy, cannot afford a similar setback, and the election's success is crucial for Thailand's reputation as a stable and democratic nation.

site_title: Davinder Singh to leave Drew & Napier to start own firm
summary: Leading Singaporean lawyer Davinder Singh is leaving Drew & Napier after 37 years to start his own law firm. He will depart by end of Q1 and will be joined by Drew & Napier directors Jaikanth Shankar and Pardeep Singh Khosa. Singh, 61, will train young lawyers and oversee the transition of his responsibilities. The firm has expressed gratitude for his contributions and wishes him well in his new venture.

site_title: The Sauce of Good Cooking
summary: This article highlights artisanal sauces and condiments perfect for Chinese New Year feasting. Cheng Yew Heng Candy Factory offers rock sugar at $3.50, while Kwong Woh Hing Factory produces traditional soya sauce and plum sauce. HAOS' XO abalone sauce is a premium condiment made with dried abalone and chicken stock. Kampot pepper from Hong Spices adds a unique flavor profile to dishes. Tetsuya Wakuda's oyster sauce and mustard are made from pure shellfish and deliver a rich umami taste. Pat Chun's Flounder Powder and Osmanthus Syrup add depth to various dishes. Handpicked's Nyonya Roast Pork Mix and aged tangerine peel are also recommended. Chinese sausages from Teck Sang and Wing Wing Co. Ltd offer traditional flavors.

site_title: Burgundy aspirations at Gaston
summary: Gaston Burgundy Bistro & Wine Bar, a new wine bar in Singapore, delivers decent food but its concept needs more convincing. The restaurant attempts to evoke a French Burgundy experience, but its authenticity is unclear. The menu features dishes like escargot, gougeres, and jambon persille, which are enjoyable but sometimes lackluster. Standout dishes include the grilled barramundi, crayfish and chicken fricasee, and addictive mashed potatoes. The restaurant's desserts are a letdown, with a cassis custard cream eclair and a poorly presented Valhorna chocolate mousse. Overall, the restaurant scores 6 out of 10 for its promising food and enjoyable atmosphere.

site_title: Renault names new leaders as Ghosn bows out
summary: Renault has appointed Jean-Dominique Senard as its new chairman, replacing Carlos Ghosn who was forced to resign amid a financial scandal. Senard will take over immediately, with Thierry Bollore becoming full CEO. The moves aim to ease the Renault-Nissan leadership crisis following Ghosn's arrest in Japan. The appointments come as the French carmaker and its Japanese alliance, Nissan, face ongoing challenges.

site_title: Property players should aim to diversify amid volatility: panel
summary: Asian real estate players are advised to diversify amid volatility by taking smaller bets and investing in alternative asset classes such as senior housing and multi-family sectors. Experts warn that the age of growth by cap rate compression is over, emphasizing the need to value-add. Overseas investment is also being considered, with some firms looking at UK offices, business parks, and logistics. The impact of the US-China trade war and Brexit is uncertain, with some investors taking a wait-and-see attitude, while others are seeking higher returns or value-add opportunities.

site_title: Legend Reborn
summary: Omega has rebooted its iconic Calibre 321 chronograph movement, a fan favorite since the 1940s, after production stopped over half a century ago. The movement, known for its intricate design and technical feat of using a monobloc column-wheel, powered notable models including the Speedmaster ST 105.003 and ST 105.012, which were worn by astronauts during spacewalks and on the moon. A team of experts worked over two years in secrecy to bring the project to life under the codename Alaska 11.

site_title: He's privy to the stars' dirty laundry - because he washes it
summary: Hans-Jürgen Topf, a 62-year-old laundry specialist, has revolutionized the music industry's laundry practices. As the world's top specialist for tour laundry, he has worked with top acts like U2, Madonna, and Beyoncé, providing equipment and laundry staff for touring productions. Topf's company, Rock 'n' Roll Laundry, has streamlined the logistics of tour laundry, providing pristine and folded clothes to performers. Despite mishaps, Topf is known for his reliability and attention to detail, and his services have become a staple on the European festival circuit.

site_title: LTA looking at level playing field for ride-hailing and taxi market
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore has proposed licensing all ride-hailing operators, with smaller ones exempted, to create a "level playing field" between ride-hailing firms and incumbent taxi operators. The move aims to end "driver exclusivity arrangements" and ensure safety standards. Major ride-hailing operators, including Grab and Gojek, have welcomed the proposal, while taxi operator ComfortDelGro has expressed caution. The LTA's move could indicate the maturing of the ride-hailing industry, but some experts warn against over-regulation, citing the need for a "light-touch" approach.

images.alt_text: Ride-hailing players in Singapore may soon find themselves regulated as transport companies rather than tech upstarts under new proposals by the Land Transport Authority (LTA).

site_title: The Joy Of Being Tidy
summary: A decluttering movement, inspired by Marie Kondo's "Tidying Up With Marie Kondo," encourages individuals to thank and let go of items that no longer bring joy, promoting a more organized and fulfilling life. The KonMari method, with its emphasis on gratitude and mindfulness, has sparked a global movement with over 100,000 social media posts using its hashtags. By adopting this approach, people can reduce stress, save money, and create a more positive living space, ultimately benefiting their mental and financial well-being.

site_title: America's most pricey home sold to billionaire Ken Griffin
summary: Ken Griffin, billionaire founder of Citadel, has purchased the US$238 million penthouse at 220 Central Park South in New York, setting a record for the most expensive home in the US. The 24,000 square foot apartment will serve as a workspace for Griffin when he's in New York. The sale price surpasses the previous record of US$100.5 million for a residential sale in Manhattan, achieved in 2014. Experts compare luxury property deals like Griffin's to the art market, where high prices don't necessarily reflect broader demand.

site_title: Brief US$41b dive in JMH yields S$12m paper gain for buyer
summary: In a rare and significant market event, Jardine Matheson Holdings shares plummeted 83% in a single session, wiping out US$41 billion in value, equivalent to two months of trading on the Singapore Exchange. The trades, executed based on pre-market quotes and bids, were deemed orderly and transparent, with sell-orders greatly exceeding buy-orders. Despite the initial plunge, shares recovered quickly to regular levels, closing at US$66.82. The exchange has ruled out cancelling the trades, citing the complexity of the transactions and the difficulty in identifying the counterparties involved.

site_title: US: S&P, Dow open flat after Ross's trade comment; chips lift Nasdaq
summary: US stocks opened flat on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rising 0.02% and 0.01% respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.23% after a rally in chipmakers. US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross expressed skepticism about resolving the US-China trade dispute, stating they were "miles and miles" away from a resolution.

site_title: Spain's existing home prices jump 7.8% in 2018, most in a decade
summary: Spain's existing home prices rose 7.8% in 2018, the largest annual increase in at least 12 years, driven by economic expansion and easing credit terms. Madrid saw the largest price jump, with a 19.5% increase, while Murcia dropped 3.3%. Despite being down almost 40% from its peak in 2007, the market is still recovering from a property crash and banking crisis.

site_title: Happy Birthday Billy
summary: Ikea's popular bookcase, Billy, is celebrating its 40th birthday. Designed by Gillis Lundgren, the bookcase was named after a colleague, Billy Liljedahl, who wanted a "proper" bookcase. Since its launch, Billy has been a favorite among millions worldwide. For its 40th birthday, Ikea is releasing a bright yellow version, along with optional add-ons such as display shelves and bookends. The bookcase, priced at $129, is available in various styles, including black, white, and white-stained oak veneer, and glass doors.

site_title: US, China 'miles and miles' from trade deal: Ross
summary: US Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross stated that the US and China are "miles and miles" from resolving trade issues, despite a planned high-level meeting next week. The talks aim to meet a March 1 deadline, but Ross downplayed expectations, saying the two countries are unlikely to resolve all disputes. The meeting will focus on structural reforms and enforcement mechanisms, with the US seeking to address intellectual property abuses and forced technology transfers. A fair chance of a deal exists, according to Ross.

site_title: Gojek in talks with Philippines, expects to be in market soon
summary: Gojek, a ride-hailing service backed by Google, is in talks with Philippine authorities to reconsider its rejected application, with co-founder Kevin Aluwi expressing optimism about a soon market entry. The startup, which has seen $12.5 billion in transactions in 2018, aims to expand its presence in Southeast Asia, where Grab dominates the market. Gojek has raised billions from investors and recently acquired a majority stake in Philippine fintech company Coins.ph, further solidifying its regional ambitions.

site_title: Chew's Group restores free float to above 10%, plans to resume trading on Friday
summary: Chew's Group has restored its free float to above 10%, meeting regulatory requirements, and plans to resume trading on Friday. The company's controlling shareholder, Goldhill Trust, sold 19.5% of its shares to 42 independent purchasers at S$0.2107 per share.
