This sale resulted in Goldhill Trust holding 73.9% of the firm, while one purchaser, Ang De Yu, becomes a substantial shareholder with 5.6% stake. The free float now stands at 20.5%.

site_title: KL probes how Jho Low may have made gains from pre-1MDB deal
summary: Malaysian investigators are probing Jho Low's potential financial gains from a 2009 bond sale by Terengganu Investment Authority (TIA), a sovereign wealth fund that later became 1MDB. The $1.6 billion bond sale involved local bankers and Thai brokerage companies, with US$126 million of illicit funds allegedly linked to Low and his associate Eric Tan. Authorities are examining whether officers concealed or misrepresented statements related to the bond sale and if funds were misappropriated. The probe is part of a broader investigation into 1MDB, which has ensnared Goldman Sachs and sparked investigations globally.

site_title: MAS clarifies takeover rules on general offers for dual-class shares
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has revised its Code on Take-overs and Mergers to clarify takeover rules for dual-class share companies. Independent shareholders will not be required to make a general offer if their share of voting rights is pushed past regulatory thresholds under certain circumstances, such as when shares are converted or voting rights are reduced. The new rules also require the same offer price for multiple-voting shares as for ordinary-voting shares.

site_title: Great retsina - an oxymoron no more
summary: Greek wine enthusiasts are reevaluating their stance on retsina, a wine infused with Aleppo pine resin, after discovering high-quality, full-bodied examples. Contrary to the common warning, many modern retsinas are now made with rich, full-bodied wines and balanced resin levels, offering complex flavors. The Greeks have long prized retsina, using pine resin since ancient winemaking days, and its popularity is now experiencing a resurgence. With proper production and aging, retsina is no longer a one-dimensional, pungent wine, but rather a nuanced and enjoyable drinking experience.

images.alt_text: The Black Label from the Georgas Family winery in Spata, Greece, is a cloudy wine resonant with pine flavours made from the savatiano, which has been long been considered a vehicle for bad retsina.

site_title: Fewer COEs for next three months starting from February
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced that there will be fewer certificates of entitlement (COEs) for the next three months starting from February. Category A COEs, which are for cars up to 1,600cc, will decrease by 9.1% to 3,300 a month. This move is aimed at managing the supply of COEs and maintaining a balance in the market.

site_title: Cycle Back in Time
summary: Local tour agency Let's Go Tour Singapore offers a four-hour cycling tour, "Trails of Tan Ah Huat," that takes participants through historic Singapore in the 1920s. The tour follows the story of a fictional Chinese immigrant, Tan Ah Huat, who peddled medicated oil to make ends meet after arriving in Singapore in the 1920s. The tour price is S$99 and includes a bicycle, helmet, guide, drinks, and snacks. Participants will also receive a straw hat and "Good Morning" towel to enhance the experience. The tour is available for booking at letsgotoursingapore.com/trails-of-tan-ah-huat.

site_title: US: Stocks end mixed amid trade, shutdown stalemates
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Thursday amid uncertainty over the trade stalemate between the US and China, with the Dow Jones falling 0.1% and the S&P 500 edging up 0.1%. A top US official downplayed the chances of a trade resolution, while the Senate blocked proposals to reopen the government. Strong earnings from semiconductor and airline companies boosted the Nasdaq and Dow, respectively, but pharma stocks declined. The market awaits a catalyst to drive further direction.

site_title: Sterling rises as no-deal Brexit risk recedes
summary: The UK's no-deal Brexit risk appears to be receding as calls for a delay to the UK's exit from the European Union gain momentum. Senior EU officials have expressed openness to extending the Brexit deadline, while British Prime Minister Theresa May remains unpersuaded. A proposal to mandate a delay if there is no deal Parliament can support is gaining traction, with over 58 politicians backing the plan. However, hardline Brexit-backing colleagues are threatening to bring down May's government if she delays the Brexit deadline. The UK's exit from the EU on March 29 is now at risk of being disorderly, with potential economic and financial consequences.

site_title: No one wants to buy an infamous US$130m yacht seized in 1MDB scandal
summary: A 300-foot yacht, Equanimity, seized in the 1MDB scandal, failed to sell at auction after being seized by the Malaysian government. Despite efforts by Burgess to find a buyer, none have come forward, making it difficult to persuade buyers to travel to Malaysia. The yacht, previously owned by fugitive financier Low Taek Jho, remains docked at a navy base near Kuala Lumpur. The sale process has been challenging, with buyers hesitant to travel to Malaysia, highlighting the difficulties in finding a buyer for the infamous vessel.

site_title: Great Eastern secures exemption from M'sia foreign-ownership cap via contribution to health scheme
summary: Great Eastern Holdings, a majority-owned Singaporean insurer, secured an exemption from Malaysia's foreign ownership cap by contributing RM2 billion to the country's B40 National Protection Scheme, a health insurance program for low-income groups. This contribution allows Great Eastern to operate without meeting the foreign ownership limit. The scheme, underwritten by Great Eastern Takaful Berhad, provides coverage against 36 critical illnesses and began on January 1.

site_title: Blackgold's false accounts go back to before acquisition by Vibrant
summary: Blackgold International Holdings, a Chinese coal miner owned by Singapore-listed Vibrant Group, has been found to have falsified accounts and grossly inflated sales figures since its acquisition by Vibrant in July 2017. An EY audit report revealed that the company's management may have recorded fictitious mining fees from subcontractors prior to the acquisition and that Peng Yuguo, the former CEO, and Ou Jun, the former general manager of a subsidiary, may have been involved in the fraud. The report also found that Blackgold's financial statements were not consolidated into Vibrant's financial statements and that the company had overstated its sales and accounts receivables.

site_title: Low Cheong Kee
summary: Low Cheong Kee, Managing Director of Homefix, has adapted his business to the changing market by shifting from a DIY (Do It Yourself) model to a DIFY (Do It For You) model. Over the past 25 years, Homefix has grown from 26 outlets to 11, and now offers online retailing, rentals, and services such as smart home networks and painting. Cheong Kee attributes this transformation to the rise of online shopping and changing consumer behavior, where consumers prefer to pay for services rather than doing tasks themselves. His brother, Cheong Yew, provides a cautious approach, while Low Cheong Kee relies on his gut feel.

site_title: Saudis make money talk in Davos bid for global rehabilitation
summary: Saudi Arabia is using the World Economic Forum in Davos to attempt a global rehabilitation after the murder of Jamal Khashoggi, with plans for economic reform, capital market deals, and global investments. The kingdom has scheduled over 100 meetings with policymakers and businessmen, including major bankers and executives like Jamie Dimon and John Flint. Despite the controversy surrounding the Khashoggi crisis, Saudi officials are confident that investors will return to the kingdom, with Aramco considering investments in the US and planning its first international bond issue.

site_title: China allows insurers to invest in banks' tier-2 capital bonds and perpetual bonds
summary: China has allowed insurance institutions to invest in tier-2 capital bonds and perpetual bonds issued by banks to boost banks' capital and strengthen their lending and risk-fending capabilities. The move aims to improve banks' capital structure and encourage banks to replenish capital via perpetual bond issuance. This follows China's central bank's announcement to set up a central bank bills swap to improve liquidity of perpetual bonds. The regulator believes the move will help commercial banks improve their capital structure and reduce financial risks.

site_title: Sonos plans headphones in move outside the home
summary: Sonos plans to launch high-end wireless headphones, targeting a similar price range of $300 or more, with a focus on audio quality and compatibility with multiple music services and digital assistants. The headphones are still in early development stages and could be launched by next year. This move represents a potential new growth area for Sonos, which has seen its stock value decline since going public in August. The company will compete with established brands such as Bose, Sennheiser, and Beats in a growing but crowded headphone market.

images.alt_text: Sonos Play:3, speaker system that can be used with an Android, iPhone or iPad device, or with a dedicated Sonos wireless controller. Speaker maker Sonos Inc is planning to expand beyond the home with high-end headphones, according to people familiar with the plans.

site_title: Courts Asia appoints KPMG as independent adviser over Nojima offer
summary: Courts Asia appoints KPMG as independent financial adviser for a conditional cash offer from Japanese electronics retailer Nojima Corp at S$0.205 per share. The offer aims to gain a strong foothold in South-east Asia. The independent directors of Courts Asia will receive KPMG's advice.

site_title: Automation: The leader of digital transformation
summary: Singapore's manufacturing industry is adapting to Industry 4.0 technologies, such as robotics, to enhance efficiency and competitiveness. Despite growing enthusiasm, many manufacturers struggle to adopt automation due to internal challenges, including worker concerns about redundancy. However, research shows that automation will create up to two million jobs globally and 65% of future jobs do not exist yet. Singapore is well-positioned to drive growth in robotics and automation, with initiatives such as the Singapore Institute of Manufacturing Technology and the Technology Adoption Programme to support small and medium enterprises. The government has set aside S$450 million to help companies adopt robotics technology, and online courses and training programs are available to nurture a pipeline of talent.

site_title: ECB keeps policy unchanged but may acknowledge weak growth
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained its policy stance unchanged, keeping interest rates at record lows 'through' the summer, despite the euro zone economy suffering its biggest slowdown in half a decade. The euro zone's biggest economies, Germany, France, and Italy, barely grew in the fourth quarter of 2018, and business activity expanded at the slowest pace since 2013. The ECB may acknowledge weak growth and consider delaying a rate hike, potentially providing more stimulus by tweaking its guidance and offering long-term loans to banks.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank left its policy stance unchanged as expected on Thursday, keeping a rate hike later this year on the table even as the euro zone economy suffers its biggest slowdown in half a decade.

site_title: ECB's Draghi warns of growing economic risks
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) chief Mario Draghi warned of growing economic risks in the eurozone, citing waning global momentum as a factor. For the first time, Draghi acknowledged that risks are tilted "to the downside." However, he stressed that the ECB has available tools to tackle worsening headwinds and is not rushing to tighten monetary policy. Draghi stated that the ECB is prepared to use its instruments, including adjusting them according to changing circumstances.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi on Thursday warned that risks to the eurozone economy were now tilted "to the downside", acknowledging for the first time that waning global momentum was weighing on the region's outlook.

site_title: British Airways Owner IAG won't bid for Norwegian Air
summary: IAG, the parent company of British Airways, will not bid for Norwegian Air after an eight-month pursuit. Norwegian Air's CEO, Bjorn Kjos, rejected earlier offers as undervaluing the business. IAG will sell a 3.9% stake in the airline and will not engage in a bidding war. Norwegian Air's shares plummeted 26% after the announcement, while IAG's shares rose. The move leaves Norwegian Air reeling as it faces a cash crunch during the slow winter season.

site_title: Trump to delay speech until after shutdown, as Democrats draft border security plan
summary: President Donald Trump announced he will deliver his State of the Union address after the federal government reopens, following a day of brinkmanship with Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Trump initially agreed to deliver the speech in the House chamber but changed his mind after Pelosi suggested a later date due to the shutdown. Meanwhile, House Democrats drafted a border security plan that includes $5.7 billion for border security but no wall, and Senate lawmakers prepared for votes on competing proposals to end the partial shutdown. The shutdown, now in its 33rd day, affects 800,000 federal employees and is unlikely to end by the scheduled address date of Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks closed higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index up 0.62% to 3,190.73. About 1.45 billion securities worth S$1.02 billion changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 198 to 184. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Malaysia probes how Jho Low may have gained from pre-1MDB deal
summary: Malaysian investigators are probing how fugitive financier Jho Low gained financially from a pre-1MDB deal involving a 5 billion ringgit bond sale in 2009 by the Terengganu Investment Authority. The probe focuses on tracing money flows that led to Low, as well as officers at the authority and local bankers, who may have abetted him in the dealings. Authorities believe US$126 million of illicit funds came from the deal, which involved local bankers and a Thai brokerage, and is linked to a series of complex transactions that involved bonds issued by the authority changing hands twice in the same day at vastly different prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 5.45 points to 1,693.59. The market saw 2.4 billion lots traded worth RM2.1 billion, with 458 gainers and 375 losers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore to license all taxi and private-hire car operators, streamlining rules. Davinder Singh leaves Drew & Napier to start own practice. Temasek's ST Telemedia acquires majority stake in cloud computing firm Cloud Comrade. The Monetary Authority of Singapore clarifies takeover rules for dual-class shares. Singapore and China form panel of mediators for Belt and Road project disputes. Singapore stocks close higher, with the Straits Times Index up 0.62%.

site_title: Airbus warns no-deal Brexit could spark 'very harmful decisions'
summary: Airbus CEO Tom Enders warned that a no-deal Brexit could lead to "very harmful decisions" for Britain, threatening 14,000 jobs at its UK sites. He criticized the UK government's handling of Brexit, branding it a "disgrace," and stated that up to 110,000 jobs rely on Airbus's British plants. The company expressed frustration over Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit strategy, saying businesses are unable to plan for the future due to lack of clarity. Airbus urged Britons not to believe that multinationals will always stay in the UK, warning that it could re-direct future investments if a no-deal Brexit occurs.

site_title: MAS halts ICO over public LinkedIn advertisement
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) halted an initial coin offering (ICO) issuer from proceeding with its securities token offering due to non-compliance with regulatory requirements. The issuer had advertised the ICO on LinkedIn, violating the condition that prospectus exemptions under the Securities and Futures Act (SFA) do not allow advertising. The MAS will now review the issuer's application for a prospectus exemption.

site_title: StanChart makes its first Singapore trade finance deal using blockchain
summary: Standard Chartered's Singapore unit has completed its first cross-border trade finance transaction on a blockchain-based platform, streamlining documentation and providing security and transparency for participants. The deal, involving agri-business supply chain, took just one day to complete, compared to the usual 5-7 days. The bank plans to expand the blockchain-based solution to more clients regionally and globally, citing benefits of increased transparency, trust, and cost efficiency.

site_title: Southeast Asia journey to adopt clean and low carbon technologies a bumpy one
summary: Southeast Asian countries are transitioning to a low-carbon economy, but the journey has been bumpy due to a high dependency on coal. Experts surveyed in a white paper found that countries like Indonesia, Vietnam, and the Philippines face significant obstacles, including insufficient policies and lack of funding. The top three sectors in need of investment are renewable energy and storage, clean energy public transport systems, and energy-efficient technologies. Business leadership, local government initiatives, and consumer pressure are key drivers of the transition, while insufficient policy and lack of funding are major barriers.

site_title: China highly concerned about EU tariffs on e-bikes
summary: China is highly concerned about the European Union's decision to impose tariffs on Chinese electric bicycles, citing unfair subsidies and market opposition. The EU's anti-dumping and anti-subsidy duties are the latest in a series of measures against Chinese exports. China's commerce ministry said it will take necessary measures to safeguard its interests, following a ruling that European producers say will curb cheap imports.

site_title: Keppel reverses Q4 losses, posts S$135 million net profit
summary: Keppel Corporation reported a net profit of S$135 million in its fourth-quarter earnings, reversing a loss of S$492 million a year ago. Excluding a one-off financial penalty, the group's net profit would have been 6% higher year-over-year. Revenue increased 9% to S$1,677 million, with all divisions except property registering higher revenues. The company's operating profit decreased 97% to S$5 million due to lower fair value gains and higher provisions for expected losses. A final dividend of 15 cents per share is proposed, totaling 30 cents per share for the full year.

site_title: SATS invests 136m yuan in two China JVs
summary: SATS Ltd has invested 136 million yuan (S$27.3 million) in two joint ventures with Capital Airports Holding Company and Juneyao Airlines in Beijing to boost its China business. The first JV will provide ground and cargo handling services at Beijing Daxing International Airport, while the second JV will offer in-flight catering services. SATS will hold a 40% stake in the first JV and a 10% stake in the second JV. This investment aims to enhance its presence in the Chinese market and was made after the company's shares closed at S$4.88, up 13 Singapore cents.

site_title: Europe: Stocks stumble at open before ECB
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.1%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.2%, and Paris' CAC 40 marginally lower. Investors awaited the European Central Bank's interest rate decision, which had little impact. Markets were also influenced by US-EU trade talks and ongoing tariff uncertainty, with some sectors like mining and healthcare seeing gains. Despite this, investors remained cautiously optimistic, with the Singapore STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: No-deal Brexit risk recedes as calls grow to delay the divorce
summary: The risk of a no-deal Brexit appears to be receding as UK calls for a delay to the UK's exit from the European Union gain momentum. Senior EU officials, including French and German governments, have expressed openness to extending the Brexit deadline. However, UK Prime Minister Theresa May remains unpersuaded, despite opposition from her own party and pressure from influential voices. A vote in Parliament next week could force a delay, with a proposal to mandate a delay if there's no deal Parliament can support gaining support from Labour Party leaders.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust Q3 DPU up to 2.05 S cents
summary: Ascendas India Trust reported a 38.9% jump in income available for distribution to 2.05 Singapore cents per unit in its Q3 2018 results, driven by higher interest income and a one-off tax benefit. Despite a 3.4% decline in Singapore dollar property income, net property income rose 4% to S$33.9 million. The trust's properties, including BlueRidge 2 in Pune and Atria in Hyderabad, contributed to the increase in Indian rupee terms. The trust's units ended at S$1.08, up 0.9%.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit Q4 DPU falls below forecast owing to rights issue
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit reported a fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.25 US cents, 16.7% lower than forecast due to dilution from a recent rights issue. Excluding the effects of the acquisition and rights issue, DPU would have been 1.51 US cents. The Reit's distributable income rose 8.6% to US$10.3 million, driven by a US$707,000 contribution from the Westpark portfolio.

site_title: Vibrant's Blackgold unit may have falsified accounts since the day it was acquired
summary: A special audit report by EY Advisory has found that Blackgold International Holdings, a Chinese coal miner owned by Vibrant Group, may have falsified accounts and grossly inflated sales figures since its acquisition by Vibrant in July 2017. The report suggests that Blackgold's management may have recorded fictitious mining fees, overstated sales, and concealed irregularities by destroying records. The findings have raised concerns about a possible breach of Singapore listing rules and have prompted Vibrant to write off its investment in Blackgold and seek legal advice.

site_title: Southeast Asian merchants lead in benefiting from Chinese mobile payment: Nielsen report
summary: Southeast Asian merchants are leading in benefiting from Chinese mobile payment, according to a Nielsen report. 3/4 of Chinese tourists used mobile payments on their most recent trips to Singapore, Thailand, or Malaysia, surpassing other regions. Mobile payments overtook cash for 32% of transactions, with 93% of Chinese tourists saying they'd increase spending if mobile payment was more widely accepted. Currently, 58% of merchants in these areas accept mobile payment, with 70% accepting Chinese mobile payment.

site_title: Phillip Securities, PrimePartners, RHT Capital join startup Fundnel to test exchange for private investments
summary: A consortium of Phillip Securities, PrimePartners, RHT Capital, and Fundnel is testing a private investment exchange, Hg Exchange, to trade private-company shares. The exchange aims to promote transparency and liquidity for investors in South-east Asia. Fundnel, the co-founder and CEO, expects sandbox approval in 120 days and plans to have 20 members. This follows a similar private exchange, 1exchange (1X), which was approved by Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The proposed market aims to address the challenges faced by startup employees and early investors who are delaying IPO plans.

site_title: Renault names Bollore CEO, Senard chairman
summary: Renault has named Thierry Bollore as its new CEO and Jean-Dominique Senard as chairman, replacing Carlos Ghosn following his arrest in Japan. Senard will represent Renault in its alliance with Nissan and Mitsubishi, and will oversee the alliance's management. Renault's board has given Senard full responsibility for managing the alliance on behalf of Renault, in liaison with Bollore. This move comes after Ghosn's arrest for alleged financial misconduct.

images.alt_text: Jean-Dominique Senard, newly-appointed Chairman of Renault, and Thierry Bollore, newly-appointed Chief Executive Officer of Renault, talk to journalists after French carmaker Renault's board of directors meeting in Boulogne-Billancourt, near Paris, France, January 24, 2019.

site_title: Trendlines tripled its Singapore medtech startup count in 2018
summary: Trendlines Group, a Catalist-listed incubator, tripled its Singapore medtech startup count in 2018, reaching six startups through its Trendlines Medical Singapore subsidiary. The new startups include Medulla Pro Technology and AyzerSense Technology, which focus on developing imaging systems and tackling pressure ulcers, respectively. The incubator's CEO Eric Loh emphasized the importance of partnerships among entrepreneurs, clinicians, and researchers in realizing the full potential of medtech companies.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,181.70, up 0.33% on day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.33% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) advancing to 3,181.70 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 152 to 137, driven by 813.62 million securities worth S$514.34 million traded. Notable stocks included Genting Singapore and Golden Agri-Resources. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite US trade uncertainty, with investors staying positive.

site_title: FLT's Q1 DPU falls 1.1% as Australian dollar weakens against Sing dollar
summary: FLT's Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) fell 1.1% to 1.78 Singapore cents due to foreign exchange translation changes, as the Australian dollar weakened against the Singapore dollar. Despite this, distributable income rose 16.3% to A$29.7 million (S$28.7 million) due to property acquisitions. The trust's quarterly DPU in Australian dollars increased 6.5% to 1.81 Australian cents. FLT's units closed at S$1.08, up one Singapore cent.

site_title: Rents, prices of Singapore industrial space unchanged in Q4 2018: JTC
summary: Singapore's industrial space rentals and prices remained unchanged in Q4 2018 compared to the preceding quarter, according to JTC Corp. The occupancy rate of the overall industrial property market rose 0.2 percentage points to 89.3% year-over-year. About 60 units of uncompleted strata-titled developments remained available for sale, totaling 22,000 square meters. Transaction volume decreased 5% from the previous quarter but increased 34% year-over-year, with 1.5 million square meters of new industrial space expected to come online this year.

site_title: New Look Watches
summary: Several high-end watch brands unveiled new models at the SIHH watch show. Christophe Claret's Angelico features a gravity-defying tourbillon and anti-pivot mechanism, while Ferdinand Berthoud's Chronometre FB 1 "Oeuvre d' Or" boasts hand-crafted gold decorations and a diamond-encrusted case. TAG HEUER's Carrera Calibre Heuer 02T Tourbillon Nanograph features a patented carbon-composite hairspring, and HUBLOT's Classic Fusion Aerofusion Chronograph Orlinski Red Magic showcases vibrant red ceramic. Other notable models include De Bethune's DB28GS Grand Bleu with a built-in lighting system and F P Journe's Tourbillon Souverain Vertical with a vertical tourbillon cage. Limited edition models from Bovet, Moser & Cie, and De Bethune also made their debuts.

images.alt_text: 02. FERDINAND BERTHOUD Chronometre FB 1 "Oeuvre d' Or".
03. TAG HEUER: Carrera Calibre Heuer 02T Tourbillon Nanograph.
04. HUBLOT: Classic Fusion Aerofusion Chronograph Orlinski Red Magic.
06. F P JOURNE: Tourbillon Souverain Vertical.
07. H MOSER & CIE: Endeavour Tourbillon Concept Cosmic Green.

site_title: Singapore and China to form panel of mediators for Belt and Road project disputes
summary: Singapore and China have agreed to establish an international panel of mediators to resolve disputes arising from Belt and Road Initiative projects. The panel, comprising professionals from China, Singapore, and Belt and Road countries, aims to develop a new approach to settling cross-border commercial disputes that reflects Asian values. A memorandum of understanding was signed at the first China-Singapore International Commercial Dispute Resolution Conference, where Singapore and China agreed to jointly develop rules and procedures for handling dispute cases. This move is seen as a way for Singapore to leverage its reputation for a strong rule of law and impartiality.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as investors track trade talks, shutdown
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday as investors awaited updates on US-China trade talks and the ongoing government shutdown. The pound edged higher on optimism about Britain's potential exit from the EU. Despite upbeat earnings from Procter & Gamble and IBM, markets were volatile, with few catalysts driving trade. The White House denied reports that officials had rejected China's offer of preparatory discussions ahead of high-level talks in Washington, and the talks are seen as crucial in reinvigorating China's struggling economy.

site_title: Go-Jek in talks with Philippines, expects to be in market soon
summary: Indonesia's ride-hailing service Go-Jek is in talks with Philippine authorities to reconsider its rejected application for ride-hailing services. Co-founder Kevin Aluwi expressed optimism that the service will be in the market soon. Go-Jek has seen consistent and explosive growth, with $12.5 billion in transactions in 2018, and has raised billions from investors. The company aims to expand to Malaysia and is examining its e-commerce space, with no current plans for a purchase of JD.com's Indonesia business.

site_title: Debt-hit Ryobi Kiso's JV awarded more work on ongoing project
summary: Ryobi Kiso Holdings' construction joint venture has been awarded additional work on an existing project tender, boosting its order book by S$19.2 million since October last year. The award follows a successful tender in October 2018 for bored piling works at a public housing development. The company, which is undergoing a court-supervised reorganisation process due to debt issues, expressed confidence in its joint venture platform and its ability to expand and serve clients.

site_title: Alibaba-backed Easyhome to float new retail unit in RMB38.3b reverse merger
summary: Alibaba-backed home improvement chain Easyhome will go public through a reverse merger deal worth up to $5.65 billion with Chinese state-backed listed retail conglomerate Wuhan Zhongshang Commercial Group Co Ltd. The deal values Easyhome's new retail arm at $7.26 billion to $7.66 billion and will result in a backdoor listing on the Shenzhen bourse. Easyhome will become the listed firm's controlling shareholder, while Alibaba and other investors will also hold stakes.

site_title: Temasek's ST Telemedia acquires majority stake in cloud computing firm
summary: ST Telemedia, a subsidiary of Temasek, has acquired a majority stake in Singapore-based cloud computing firm Cloud Comrade. The investment aims to enhance ST Telemedia's multi-cloud capabilities in Asia and bring complementary capability to its existing portfolio. Cloud Comrade will leverage ST Telemedia's expertise, resources, and international network to pursue market opportunities and accelerate customer expansion. The acquisition is seen as a move to capitalize on Asia's growing digital transformation market, with ST Telemedia's executive vice-president expressing confidence in the potential of the market.

site_title: Doctor World launches telemedicine app, secures Raffles Medical partnership
summary: Doctor World, a telehealth startup, has launched its healthcare services app and secured a partnership with Raffles Medical Group. The app offers comprehensive healthcare services, including teleconsultation, home care, and appointment management. A proprietary app, RafflesConnect, has been created for Raffles Medical clients. The partnership aims to expand Doctor World's services and reach.

site_title: Singapore to streamline rules governing taxis, private-hire cars
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority plans to license all street-hail and ride-hail operators, viewing them as fundamental transport providers. This marks a significant change from the past, when the authority viewed them as "tech companies." The move aims to streamline rules and ensure a level playing field for all transport operators. The proposed licensing system will provide a framework for operators to operate safely and efficiently, benefiting commuters and the transport industry as a whole.

site_title: Google's proposal for Chrome browser threatens ad blockers, developers say
summary: Google is developing a Chrome browser proposal that could limit the functionality of ad blockers, prompting complaints from developers. The change aims to improve security and privacy for Chrome users but may render ad blocker software useless, benefiting Google's online advertising business. Google is working with developers to ensure "fundamental use cases" remain possible. The move is seen as a misuse of Google's market-dominating position, threatening the livelihoods of ad blocker software makers.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.75 points to 1,688.89 at 9:01am on Thursday, driven by gains. Volume reached 51.1 million lots worth RM17.82 million, with 101 gainers outpacing 44 losers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Thursday with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.25% to 27,075.37, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains of 0.14% and 0.10%, respectively. The market's positive trend was attributed to investors' optimism despite ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: South Australia heatwave smashes temperature records
summary: A severe heatwave has struck southern Australia, shattering temperature records in multiple towns across South Australia. Temperatures reached 47.9°C north of Adelaide and 46.2°C inside the city, with some areas forecast to reach 50°C by the end of the day. Residents received free beer to help cope with the heat, while municipal services and emergency services are being tested. The heatwave is also threatening possible bushfires in over 13 districts, and power consumption is expected to peak, potentially leading to brownouts.

site_title: Microsoft's Bing search engine goes offline in China
summary: Microsoft's Bing search engine went offline in China, sparking speculation of censorship. Users reported error messages when attempting to access the site, leading to fears it may be blocked by China's "Great Firewall". Microsoft is investigating the issue, but its China service may be experiencing technical difficulties. This comes amid heightened tensions between the US and China, with the two countries set to engage in new trade negotiations. The incident raises concerns about the impact on users and potential implications for Microsoft's operations in the country.

images.alt_text: Microsoft was investigating a disruption in its Bing search engine in China on Thursday, with social media users fearing it could be the latest foreign website to be blocked by censors.

site_title: China's Huawei unveils 5G modem Balong 5000, "world's most powerful"
summary: China's Huawei unveiled its 5G modem Balong 5000, described as the world's most powerful 5G modem, supporting both Non-Standalone (NSA) and Standalone (SA) 5G network architectures. The head of Huawei's consumer business group, Richard Yu, made the announcement. The Balong 5000 is the first 5G modem to fully support both architectures, marking a significant milestone in the development of 5G technology.

site_title: SGX's Q2 net profit jumps 9%
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 9.2% jump in Q2 net profit to S$96.5 million, driven by a 10.4% increase in operating profit and 9.3% growth in revenue. Derivatives revenue rose 35%, while equities and fixed income revenue fell 12%. SGX attributed the performance to robust institutional demand for its risk management tools. Despite concerns over global economic growth and trade tensions, the company saw increased interest in its securities products.

site_title: Jakarta ex-governor freed from prison after blasphemy sentence
summary: Jakarta's former governor, Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, also known as Ahok, has been released from prison after serving a two-year blasphemy sentence. The release comes nearly two years after his conviction sparked fears of religious intolerance in Indonesia, the world's largest Muslim-majority nation. Purnama's case drew international criticism, including from the UN, and highlighted concerns about the country's blasphemy law, which can jail individuals up to five years for expressing hostility towards religion.

site_title: Apple hires Samsung battery executive to help lead its own work
summary: Apple has hired Soonho Ahn, a senior vice president at Samsung SDI, to lead its battery development efforts. Ahn, who joined Apple in December, previously led the development of lithium battery packs and next-generation battery technology at Samsung SDI. The move suggests Apple is seeking to reduce reliance on third-party components, including batteries, as it develops its own MicroLED display technology and builds its own processors and cellular modems. Apple is also exploring direct sourcing of cobalt from miners to gain a competitive advantage in battery life and performance.

site_title: Fewer COEs for bidding in February-April
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced that there will be fewer certificates of entitlement (COE) for the next three months, starting in February. Category A COEs for cars up to 1,600cc will decrease by 9.1% to 3,300 a month, while Category B COEs will drop by 2.9% to 2,399 a month. The overall COE supply is 12.9% smaller than the November-January quota at 8,752.

site_title: Malaysian royals pick new king after historic abdication
summary: Malaysia's Sultan Muhammad V has abdicated the throne after reports of his marriage to a Russian ex-beauty queen, sparking a historic abdication in the Muslim-majority country. The sultan's likely replacement, Sultan Abdullah of Pahang state, is a sports-loving monarch with a strong background in football and hockey. He will be sworn in as the new king on January 31, marking the first abdication of a monarch in Malaysia's history, where the throne changes hands every five years between state rulers.

site_title: Indonesia releases new rules on export revenue repatriation for resources
summary: Indonesia has introduced new rules requiring exporters of natural resources to receive earnings in local banking, aiming to support the rupiah currency. The move was announced last year to address capital outflows linked to rising interest rates and the US-China trade war. The rupiah has regained some ground but still faces gaps in merchandise trade and the current account deficit.

site_title: Davinder Singh to leave Drew & Napier and set up own practice
summary: Legal bigwig Davinder Singh is leaving Drew & Napier after 37 years to start his own practice, citing the need to "train young lawyers." As executive chairman of the firm, Singh will oversee the transition and ensure the firm is in capable hands. He will be replaced by Cavinder Bull, who was appointed as CEO in 2017. Singh's departure comes after he initiated a management renewal process, which included appointing a successor. He will continue to train young lawyers and focus on training the next generation of lawyers.

site_title: Renault to ask Senard to mend Nissan alliance as chairman
summary: Renault is expected to appoint Jean-Dominique Senard as chairman, tasked with mending the strained relationship with partner Nissan Motor Co. Thierry Bollore, currently interim CEO, would handle daily operations if his position becomes permanent. The move aims to strengthen the alliance and address issues with Japanese authorities, following Carlos Ghosn's arrest and ouster as chairman. The French government favors dual leadership, with Senard overseeing long-term strategic planning, and has expressed confidence in his ability to bring a change of style to Renault.

site_title: Philippines Q4 GDP grows less than expected at 6.1% y-o-y
summary: The Philippine economy grew 6.1% in the fourth quarter of 2018, slightly faster than the previous quarter but below market expectations. This brings the annual growth rate to 6.2%, below the government's target of 6.5-6.9%. The fourth-quarter pace is the slowest expansion in three years, following a 6.7% growth rate in 2017.

site_title: America's most expensive home sold to hedge fund billionaire Ken Griffin
summary: Ken Griffin, billionaire founder of Citadel, has purchased the US$238 million penthouse at 220 Central Park South in New York, setting a record for the most expensive home in the US. The 2,200 sqm apartment will serve as a workspace for Griffin. The sale, made by Vornado Realty Trust, surpasses the previous record of US$100.5 million for a Manhattan penthouse, highlighting a resurgence in luxury property deals. Experts attribute Griffin's purchases to his "global trophy hunting" nature, rather than market trends.

site_title: China's Huawei books record sales in its smartphone business
summary: China's Huawei reported record smartphone sales of $52 billion in 2018, a 50% increase, surpassing its carrier business as its largest segment. The company unveiled its first 5G base station chipset and modem, which it claims is the most powerful 5G modem in the world. Despite facing global scrutiny and US-led allegations of spying, Huawei continues to grow its consumer business. The company's finance chief, Sabrina Meng Wanzhou, was arrested in Canada on allegations of fraud.

site_title: Singapore telcos will have to consolidate in next 3 years, warns Moody's
summary: Singapore's telcos face consolidation within the next 3 years due to market overcrowding, with analysts from Moody's warning of declining market share and revenue. Singtel is expected to remain the market leader, but its domestic profitability may be threatened. The arrival of mobile virtual network operators (MVNOs) and competition-driven price wars could wear down Singtel's market share, despite revenue contributions from MVNOs. Moody's also notes that Singtel's overseas operations and significant revenue scale will offset stress in its domestic market.

site_title: Bank of Korea stands pat on interest rates
summary: The Bank of Korea maintained its seven-day repurchase rate at 1.75% on January 24, 2019, defying expectations of a rate cut amid rising economic risks. Governor Lee Ju-yeol stated that the central bank will remain accommodative but not consider further monetary easing. The growth outlook for the year has been trimmed to 2.6% and inflation forecast to 1.4%, with the central bank expecting inflation to fluctuate at the 1% level before increasing to mid-1% in the second half of the year.

site_title: Bank of China unveils first perpetual bond amid capital pressure
summary: Bank of China Ltd is set to issue the first perpetual bond from a Chinese lender, aiming to raise up to 40 billion yuan (S$8 billion) to replenish additional tier 1 capital. The move is in response to capital pressure on Chinese banks due to a slowing economy and increased soured loans. The bank's perpetual bond will have an indicative pricing range of 4.50-4.80% and will not have a coupon step-up. This deal is expected to pave the way for similar fundraising from financial institutions in China, which are under pressure to boost support to the real economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on global economy jitters
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday due to lingering uncertainty over the global economy. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.57% or 117.38 points to 20,476.34, while the Topix index fell 0.55% or 8.54 points to 1,538.49. The decline was attributed to a lack of fresh trading clues and ongoing concerns about the global economy.

site_title: Texas Instruments, other chip maker results spark rally
summary: Texas Instruments and other chip makers posted quarterly results, beating expectations despite concerns over US-China trade tensions and a slowing smartphone market. Texas Instruments missed revenue estimates but beat profit forecasts, while Xilinx and Lam Research Corp surged after their results and outlook exceeded analyst expectations. The rally boosted shares of other chip makers, including Applied Materials Inc and Nvidia Corp, as investors cautiously look for signs of a recovery in the microchip industry.

site_title: Is there a 'circular' solution to the world's food problems?
summary: A new report by a foundation set up by Ellen MacArthur suggests that adopting a "circular economy" model in the food industry could prevent 5 million deaths annually by 2050 due to pesticide exposure, pollution, and other industrial food production issues. This model involves producing food locally, using eco-friendly methods, eliminating waste, and designing healthier products. Cities are seen as key catalysts in this change, with the potential to save $2.7 trillion annually and reduce health costs, while the current linear system costs society $5.7 trillion globally.

site_title: Kim expresses 'great satisfaction' over Trump letter: KCNA
summary: North Korea's Kim Jong Un expressed "great satisfaction" after receiving a letter from US President Donald Trump ahead of their planned summit. The letter, according to KCNA, showed Trump's "unusual determination and will" and "great interest" in the second DPRK-US summit.

site_title: 'Fat finger' blamed as Jardine Matheson loses US$41b in share value
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd, a 186-year-old conglomerate, experienced a 83% share price drop before recovering in pre-market trading. The sudden drop, attributed to a "fat finger" error, involved the sale of 167,500 shares at US$10.99, causing a US$41 billion loss in value. The company acknowledged an electronic trading error and is investigating the incident with the Singapore Exchange. The price recovery of 0.3% suggests that the error may have been caused by human error, according to traders.

site_title: British pound rises as markets await ECB decision
summary: The British pound rose to a two-month peak against the euro and dollar on January 23, 2019, amid expectations of a likely dovish message from the European Central Bank. Traders believe a delayed Brexit or a second referendum could mitigate the economic impact. Despite weak factory data, the pound's resilience suggests a greater chance of a delayed Brexit. The European Central Bank is expected to maintain its patient course, with no major announcements anticipated.

site_title: Brazil stocks in new record territory
summary: Brazil's stock market reached a new record of 96,558 points, driven by Economy Minister Paulo Guedes' reassurances on cutting public spending during the World Economic Forum. The market rose 1.53% on Wednesday, making up for a 0.94% drop on Tuesday. The Ibovespa index has increased by 9.86% since the start of the year, with the real also firming up to 3.76 reais to the dollar.

site_title: BuzzFeed to cut 15% of jobs in latest digital media retrenchment
summary: BuzzFeed is cutting 15% of its jobs, or around 250 positions, due to a challenging advertising market. The company, which has been examining the "evolving economics of digital platforms," aims to reduce costs and improve its operating model. This move is part of a wave of media layoffs, including Verizon's 7% cut and Gannett's journalist layoffs. CEO Jonah Peretti believes the restructuring will allow BuzzFeed to "thrive and control our own destiny" without needing to raise funding again.

images.alt_text: BuzzFeed, a pioneering site that spans hard news, personality quizzes and listicle-style features, was long seen as a way for journalism to prosper in a post-print era.

site_title: Iraq parliament approves budget ending weeks of deadlock
summary: Iraq's parliament approved its 2019 budget after weeks of deadlock, with oil exports projected at 3.88 million barrels per day at $56 per barrel. The budget includes payment of salaries for the Peshmerga military force in the semi-autonomous Kurdish region, aimed at easing tension between Baghdad and Erbil. The budget totals 133 trillion dinars ($152.3 billion) and includes a 95% share of oil exports from southern Basra fields. The approval comes despite an incomplete government due to vacant cabinet posts.

site_title: White House says US could see zero growth this quarter with shutdown
summary: The White House Council of Economic Advisers Chairman Kevin Hassett warned that a partial US government shutdown could lead to zero economic growth this quarter if it extends through March. However, he predicted "humongous" growth would follow once federal agencies reopen. Hassett also downplayed the risk of a recession in 2020, stating it was "very, very close to zero".

site_title: World leaders at Davos call for global rules on tech
summary: World leaders at the Davos forum have called for global rules on technology, with Japan, South Africa, China, and Germany pushing for international oversight of data usage. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan proposed expanding World Trade Organization (WTO) rules to include data governance, while Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany emphasized the need for a "common digital market" in the European Union. The proposals were echoed by other leaders, but there was no consensus on a unified global architecture. The call for greater regulation comes amid growing concerns over data security, privacy, and the impact of technology on work and society.

site_title: The Place Holdings returns to profit in Q4 on new events business
summary: The Place Holdings, a Singapore-listed investment holding company, returned to profit in Q4 2018 with a net profit of S$162,000, reversing a loss of S$795,000 in the same period last year. Revenue improved 53% to S$926,000, driven by new events management business. Full-year net profit was S$1.92 million, down 79% year-over-year. The company has retained its cash for expansion purposes and is awaiting approval for a share subscription in a Chinese property development project.

site_title: P&G confident of payoff from Gillette's 'Me Too' ad
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) is confident in the success of its "Me Too" Gillette ad, which targets "toxic masculinity," despite criticism from conservatives. The ad has resonated with younger consumers, generating significant media coverage and consumer engagement. Retail sales of Gillette have remained stable, while online sales continue to grow. P&G's second-quarter earnings report showed a decline in grooming sales, but the company boosted its full-year sales targets. The ad's success has been credited to its ability to connect with younger consumers and spark conversation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Commercial Trust, Keppel T&T, Mapletree Commercial Trust, Sino Grandness Food
summary: Singapore stocks to watch include CapitaLand Commercial Trust, which reported a 2.22 Singapore cent distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter, a 6.8% increase from the same period last year. Keppel T&T saw a 10.6% fall in net profit due to impairment losses and higher operating expenses. Mapletree Commercial Trust's DPU rose 1.3% to 2.33 Singapore cents, driven by higher net property income. Sino Grandness Food is locked in negotiations with lender Soleado Holdings, which has served a letter of demand for approximately US$22 million.

images.alt_text: CapitaSpring - the former Golden Shoe Car Park - is still under redevelopment.

site_title: Real Madrid beats Man Utd as world soccer's richest club
summary: Real Madrid has surpassed Manchester United as the world's highest-earning soccer club, according to Deloitte's annual Football Money League. Real Madrid's revenue surged 11% to $1.16 billion, while Manchester United's rose 1.5% to $1.04 billion. The change reflects Real Madrid's success in the Champions League and dominance in Spain, while Manchester United's under-performance on the pitch has impacted its revenue.

images.alt_text: European champion Real Madrid displaced Manchester United as the world's highest-earning soccer club as the English team's under-performance on the pitch in recent seasons ate into its dominance off it.

site_title: Ford reports fourth quarter loss on weakness in China, Europe
summary: Ford reported a fourth-quarter loss of US$112 million due to weak performance in China and Europe, despite a 12% revenue increase to US$41.8 billion. Operating losses were reported in Asia Pacific, South America, and the Middle East and Africa regions, driven by weak sales in China. The company cited US$877 million in one-time pension expenses as a factor in the loss. Ford has been restructuring its European operations and halting production of sedans and small cars in the US to boost profitability.

site_title: Europe: Shares sluggish as poor updates add to macro gloom
summary: European shares ended down 0.1% on Wednesday, weighed by poor corporate updates and concerns over a global growth slowdown. Top fallers included Metro Bank, which fell nearly 39%, and ASML Holding, which fell 4.8% due to weak sales forecasts. Despite this, European retailers rose 1.6% and the autos sector fell due to trade negotiations with China. Investors remain cautious, with doubts about global growth and market expectations still high.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.11% to 3,174.59
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.11% to 3,174.59 on Thursday, following a mild overnight advance on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers 44 to 37, with notable movers including ComfortDelGro up 2.78%, Venture Corp up 0.92%, and Singtel up 0.99%. The Straits Times Index ticked higher by 3.48 points, driven by positive investor sentiment despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE shares inched up on Thursday, taking their cue from a mild overnight advance on Wall Street.

site_title: Apple supplier sheds half its value but foreign funds not spooked
summary: Han's Laser Technology Industry Group Co, a Chinese laser tools maker, has lost half its value since summer due to a global rout of companies in Apple's supply chain. Despite this, foreign investors remain invested, holding 17% of the company's shares. Analysts expect revenue growth to rebound to over 20% this year, driven by advances in laser technology and a diversified business. The company's valuation is seen as undervalued, with a price target of 50.9 yuan (S$10.19) set by Citigroup, implying a potential 70% climb.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands' Q4 earnings slide on weaker VIP gaming
summary: Marina Bay Sands' Q4 earnings dropped 20.8% to US$362 million due to a 13.9% decline in VIP gaming revenue. Total casino revenue fell 17.6% to US$500 million, while hotel revenue rose 4.4% to US$94 million. Net revenue decreased 11.6% to US$726 million, despite a 8.5% increase in mall revenue. Las Vegas Sands Corp's parent company saw a 4.7% decline in Q4 Ebitda to US$1.34 billion, resulting in a net loss of US$170 million.

site_title: Alec Baldwin to attend anger management after pleading guilty to harassment
summary: Actor Alec Baldwin, 60, pleaded guilty to a harassment charge stemming from a parking spot dispute in New York, agreeing to attend a short-term anger management program. He was initially charged with harassment and assault but pleaded to the lesser charge. Baldwin was released on conditional discharge and is due back in court on March 27. The incident occurred in November after Baldwin punched a 49-year-old man in the face during a parking dispute.

site_title: Oil slips as EU seeks to trade with Iran, US petrol prices fall
summary: Oil prices slipped 0.6-0.7% as the EU sought to circumvent US trade sanctions against Iran, with Brent futures falling to $61.14 a barrel and WTI crude settling at $52.62. EU efforts to establish a non-dollar trade system with Iran, combined with falling US petrol prices and rising US crude output, pressured the market. US crude stockpiles rose sharply, and petrol and distillate inventories built, further contributing to the decline.

site_title: Regional powers recognise Maduro opponent as interim leader
summary: Regional powers, including the US, Canada, Brazil, Colombia, Chile, Peru, and Argentina, have recognized Juan Guaido as Venezuela's interim leader, leaving President Nicolas Maduro increasingly isolated. Major South American nations have given their backing to Guaido's self-proclamation, while Mexico has taken a lukewarm stance. The US has warned that it will use "all options" if Maduro tries to quash the opposition, and Trump has called Guaido's National Assembly the "only legitimate branch of government" elected by the Venezuelan people. Maduro has responded by cutting off diplomatic ties with the US and threatening to expel US diplomats.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Influence: The price of a 120ml bag of life
summary: Around six Singaporeans are diagnosed with a blood disease daily, with bone marrow transplants often the final treatment option. However, finding a successful match is rare, posing risks to patients. The Bone Marrow Donor Programme's executive committee president, Dr Lim Zi-Yi, and a patient and donor discuss the costs and risks involved. The programme relies on donations, with no guarantee of a successful match, and patients face risks of graft-versus-host disease and other complications.

site_title: Once the world's greatest port, Hong Kong sinks in global ranking
summary: Hong Kong's container port has slipped to seventh place globally, overtaken by neighboring Guangzhou and South Korea's Busan, according to 2018 data. The city's decline is attributed to increased competition from mainland Chinese ports and the US-China trade war. Hong Kong International Terminals Ltd, the city's largest container-terminal operator, has frozen staff salaries and formed an alliance with rival operators to cut costs. The company has also been hindered by years of debate over port expansion, with no new terminal planned. The decline marks a significant shift in Hong Kong's role as a global trade hub.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher after mostly good earnings
summary: US stocks ended higher on Wednesday after strong earnings from IBM and other companies, lifting the Dow 0.7% to 24,575.62. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with Procter & Gamble and United Technologies advancing 4.9% and 5.4%, respectively. However, concerns over US-China trade relations and a government shutdown weighed on the markets, prompting economists to downgrade growth estimates for 2019. Despite this, investors remain cautiously optimistic, with Art Hogan stating that resolving trade and shutdown issues is crucial for market confidence.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust bumps Q4 DPU up 6.7% to 2.22 S cents
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 6.7% increase in its fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.22 Singapore cents, driven by higher net property income from its expanded portfolio. The full-year payout rose 0.5% to 8.7 Singapore cents, surpassing the 2017 DPU of 8.66 cents. The company's net property income increased 16.6% year-over-year to S$79.3 million, while gross revenue rose 14.8% to S$99 million.

images.alt_text: Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) unit holders will get a heftier distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter from higher net property income from a beefed-up portfolio, as well as dividends.

site_title: ATM security: Banks, firms must stay a step ahead
summary: Cybercriminals are targeting ATMs in the Asia-Pacific region due to high digital connectivity, low cyber security awareness, and weak regulations. ATM malware has developed rapidly, with sophisticated hacks, such as "cashout" or "jackpotting" attacks, becoming increasingly common. These attacks involve hacking into ATMs to access customer data and funds, often using cloned cards or malware. The region's high reliance on cash and lack of cyber security measures make ATMs a vulnerable target, resulting in significant financial losses. To stay ahead, banks and businesses must prioritize ATM security, implement robust measures, and monitor for threat risks.

site_title: China's Evergrande sells US$3b in bonds; coupons top 10%
summary: China's Evergrande Group sold $3 billion in dollar bonds with coupon rates ranging from 8.25% to 10.5%, significantly higher than previous offerings. The sale, part of the company's efforts to cut its massive debt, saw the order book reach $4 billion. Evergrande's debt, which stood at 671.1 billion yuan, has been under pressure, with the company's junk-rated debt seeing value in recent weeks as investors seek better yields.

site_title: China resists US, EU talks on global digital trade deal, sources say
summary: The US, EU, and other nations are set to launch talks on a global digital trade deal, aiming to establish new rules for the $25 trillion e-commerce marketplace. However, China is resisting the plan's ambition, seeking to curb its scope, which may lead to the country being locked out of the negotiations. The US and European nations are concerned that China's participation could hinder the deal's progress, particularly on issues like cross-border data flows.

site_title: Toyota finally has the power in electric cars
summary: Toyota has formed a 51-49 joint venture with Panasonic to produce electric car batteries, marking a significant shift in the industry. The partnership aims to cut costs and streamline operations for Toyota, while also expanding Panasonic's presence beyond Tesla. The move could make electric car batteries more affordable for consumers, and Toyota's deep pockets will help offset the costs of producing the batteries. This partnership may disrupt the traditional battery-making business model, where companies pass on costs to car manufacturers.

site_title: Building smart for the future
summary: Australian built environment companies are expanding their capabilities and business in Singapore through innovation and strategic partnerships. Australian High Commissioner Bruce Gosper emphasizes the need for leveraging emerging technologies such as cleantech and data analytics to support the industry. This collaboration is seen as crucial in addressing global economic and social challenges, and Singapore's developed country status provides opportunities for growth and development in the built environment sector.

site_title: US industries plead for end to US metals tariffs
summary: US industry groups sent a letter to the Trump administration pleading for an end to the economic pain caused by US tariffs on steel and aluminium, citing increased costs and retaliation from countries like China and Mexico. The letter, signed by four dozen industry groups, warned that the damage from the tariffs far outweighs any benefits to the steel industry, particularly for farmers, ranchers, and manufacturers. The groups urged the administration to resolve the matter to resume zero-tariff North American trade and gain Congressional approval of the USMCA.

images.alt_text: Dozens of US industry groups sent a letter to the Trump administration on Wednesday pleading for an end the economic pain caused by steep US tariffs on steel and aluminium.

site_title: Hotel projects capturing interest of investors, developers
summary: Investors and developers are showing increased interest in hotel projects in Singapore, with several notable transactions in 2018. The latest example is IBIS Singapore Novena, which is on the market for S$240 million. Hotel investment sales in Singapore reached a four-year high of S$1.36 billion in 2018, driven by optimism in the hospitality sector. Industry players expect demand to catch up with supply, with the supply pipeline expected to taper in the next few years. Experts attribute the renewed interest to the government's flexibility in allowing hotel conversions and the challenges faced by the residential development market.

site_title: Danske 'has hurt Denmark's national reputation'
summary: Denmark's reputation as a least-corrupt country has been damaged by Danske Bank's money laundering scandal, according to the Financial Supervisory Authority. The report highlights the bank's role in changing international perceptions, making it harder for Danish banks to raise funding. The scandal has raised concerns about the country's financial sector, potentially undermining its status as a stable and trustworthy economy.

images.alt_text: Danske Bank has assets about 11/2 times Denmark's total GDP, making it the country's systemically most important bank.

site_title: Charity pilots app that lets seniors redeem meals using QR code
summary: Singapore's Food from the Heart charity has launched Project Belanja!, a cooked food initiative allowing vulnerable seniors to redeem hot meals at food stalls near their homes using a Food Trust app. The app, developed by CCS Group Pte Ltd, offers convenience and choice for seniors and minimizes administrative work for participating hawkers and the charity. OCBC Bank donated S$50,000 to support the pilot, which will serve around 50 seniors for a year. The program aims to alleviate hunger and empower seniors to socialize.

site_title: Catalist: to grow or to heal?
summary: A Singaporean Catalist board review sparked debate on whether the regime should be more "forgiving" to troubled companies. A report suggested disallowing transfers from the mainboard to Catalist unless beneficial for both the company and shareholders. However, corporate lawyers disagreed, arguing that troubled companies should be given time to recover and that Catalist would provide better support. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to review the findings and balance the needs of companies, investors, and itself in evolving the platform.

site_title: Gear and JV partner bag 25.5% share in Stanmore
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) and its joint venture partner, Ascend Global Investment Fund, have secured a 25.5% stake in Australian coker Stanmore Coal through a takeover bid. The deal gives Gear a strategic shareholder in the same business, complementing its thermal coal interests in Kalimantan and Sumatra. Gear plans to seek an "appropriate" number of board seats, but negotiations have yet to begin. The takeover bid valued Stanmore Coal at A$240.2 million.

site_title: China's LNG imports hit new high in Dec
summary: China's LNG imports surged 25% in December to a record 6.29 million tonnes, surpassing the previous record of 5.99 million tonnes set in November. For 2018, LNG imports grew 41% to a record 53.78 million tonnes, making China the world's second-largest LNG buyer after Japan. Analysts forecast slower growth this year due to a more moderate stance on coal-to-gas switching, with temperatures this winter being higher than normal, leaving suppliers with inventories.

site_title: Sudden attention on Fed's balance sheet policy throws its communications into disarray
summary: The Federal Reserve's plan to quietly review its $4.1 trillion balance sheet has been derailed, with investors and President Donald Trump criticizing it for contributing to the recent stock market sell-off. The Fed had aimed to minimize attention on the review, but instead, it has become a focal point, highlighting potential policy implications. The review's timing and potential impact on the economy remain unclear, adding to the uncertainty surrounding the Fed's decision-making process.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust DPU up 3.1% to S$0.0299 for Q4
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) reported a 3.1% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0299 for Q4, driven by a 4.3% rise in net property income and 4.7% growth in gross revenue. The trust's acquisition of a 70% stake in Westgate contributed to the revenue increase. CMT's portfolio occupancy rate remained at 99.2% and its weighted-average lease expiry was 1.9 years. The trust's leverage ratio increased to 34.2% at Dec 31, 2018.

site_title: Hedge fund billionaire buys £95m London home
summary: Ken Griffin, founder of Citadel, has purchased 3 Carlton Gardens in London for approximately £95 million. The 200-year-old Georgian-era home, located near Buckingham Palace, features 20,000 square feet and was originally listed for £145 million. The property has a history dating back to World War II, when it housed Charles de Gaulle's private office. Griffin's purchase marks a significant addition to his portfolio, which already includes properties in New York and Chicago. The sale indicates a buying opportunity in London's top-end market, where prices are 19% below their 2014 peak.

site_title: Yongnam CEO selling Binjai Park GCB for S$40m
summary: Yongnam Holdings CEO Seow Soon Yong is selling his Binjai Park GCB for a guide price of $40 million. The 13,986 sq ft freehold bungalow has two floors, seven bedrooms, and can accommodate about 20 cars. Buyers have the option to renovate or redevelop the property. The tender closes on March 1. The sale price works out to $1,464 per square foot, which is expected to pique the interest of owner-occupiers and GCB investors.

site_title: US home price rise slows sharply in December
summary: US home sales plummeted to a three-year low in December, with existing home sales declining 6.4% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.99 million units. This marks the weakest level since November 2015. Higher mortgage rates, land and labor shortages, and a delayed government shutdown have contributed to the slowdown. Despite a drop in 30-year fixed mortgage rates, median existing house prices increased 2.9% from a year ago, and wage growth outpaced house price gains for the first time since February 2012.

site_title: DBS pilots QR red packets for Chinese New Year
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, will trial a digital QR red packet service for Chinese New Year, allowing customers to load cash values of up to S$999 onto unique QR codes. Customers can then share the packets with friends, who scan the code to receive the loaded amount. The service aims to preserve the traditional act of giving and receiving physical red packets while eliminating cash use. The QR red packets will be available at bank branches and POSB ATMs from Jan 25, 2019, and will be valid until March 15, 2019.

site_title: Drone flying near Newark Liberty Airport temporarily halts flights
summary: ALL FLIGHTS bound for Newark Liberty International Airport were halted on January 23, 2019, after two pilots reported seeing a drone flying nearby, approximately 3,500 feet over New Jersey's Teterboro Airport. The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) temporarily halted flights until 5:45pm, when operations resumed, causing a 90-minute disruption. The incident is under investigation by the FAA, Port Authority officials, and federal law enforcement agencies, amid concerns about drone safety near major airports.

site_title: Davos flock prays for WEF as rents ascend to heavenly heights
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) has descended upon Davos, Switzerland, drawing 3,000 attendees and nearly doubling the town's population. Local businesses, including shops and hotels, are reaping significant profits from the event, with estimated sales of 50 million Swiss francs (S$68.3 million). However, this influx has also raised concerns about gentrification, overpriced accommodations, and the strain on local residents, who are often forced to rent out their homes for exorbitant rates. The event has also sparked moral debates about the ethics of profiting from a luxury gathering.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation posted a 10.6% fall in net profit for its fiscal fourth quarter due to impairment losses and higher operating expenses. Mapletree Commercial Trust reported a 1.3% rise in distribution per unit for its fiscal third quarter. mDR Ltd agreed to subscribe for a 14.25% stake in USP, while Sino Grandness Food remains in negotiation with lender Soleado Holdings over a US$22 million debt.

site_title: Suntec Reit's Q4 DPU dips to 2.59 S cents on enlarged unit base
summary: Suntec Reit's Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) decreased to 2.59 Singapore cents due to an enlarged unit base and partial satisfaction of asset management fees. This is a dip from 2.604 Singapore cents in the same period last year. The trust issued new units to pay off fees, affecting the DPU.

site_title: At Alibaba's futuristic hotel, robots deliver towels and mix cocktails
summary: Alibaba's 290-room FlyZoo hotel in Hangzhou, China, features advanced technology, including robots that deliver towels and mix cocktails, facial recognition cameras, and voice command technology. Guests can check in using facial scans or smartphones, and rooms can be ordered with a voice command. Facial recognition cameras also add charges to the room rate automatically. While the hotel employs humans for conventional check-in procedures, it aims to showcase Alibaba's prowess in artificial intelligence and test consumer comfort levels with unmanned commerce in China.

site_title: China's Baidu pledges to improve search service after complaint
summary: China's search engine Baidu Inc has pledged to improve its media aggregating service after a complaint about low-quality content in search results went viral. The complaint, made by journalist Fang Kecheng, stated that Baidu was prioritizing low-quality pieces over high-quality content. In response, Baidu acknowledged the issue and vowed to improve its service, saying it will prioritize quality media outlets and creators. The move comes after Baidu's shares tumbled 6.4% on Tuesday due to concerns over its advertising practices.

site_title: SP Group brings Chinese New Year cheer to 2,300 underprivileged families
summary: SP Group distributed "Power Packs" containing essential food items to over 2,300 underprivileged families in Singapore during the Chinese New Year period. The gift packs were donated and packed by 300 SP Group staff volunteers, known as SP Heart Workers. This is the 7th year SP Group has organized such a distribution drive, with a focus on families in districts where their Heart Workers regularly serve seniors and provide support.

site_title: Fleeing clients are a grim reality in banks' push to manage wealth
summary: Wealth managers are facing a grim reality as fleeing clients are a growing concern. UBS Group AG and Credit Suisse Group AG reported lower revenue from asset management and wealth divisions, with UBS predicting a decline after $13 billion was withdrawn in the final months of 2018. The competition for managing fortunes has increased, with clients turning to family offices and cheaper products, making the richest clients the most prized targets. This shift has led to a re-evaluation of business strategies, with firms such as BlackRock Inc. cutting workforce and adjusting their investment approach.

site_title: Grand Venture Technology ends flat in Catalist debut
summary: Grand Venture Technology, a Singaporean manufacturing service provider, ended its first day flat at S$0.275 on the Catalist board after opening at S$0.27. The company was priced at S$0.275 in its initial public offering (IPO). No other key information is provided in the given article.

site_title: 25% auto tariffs could cause recession in EU & Japan, hit the financial markets
summary: A possible 25% tariff on US car imports from the European Union (EU) and Japan could trigger a recession in the EU and Japan, and impact global financial markets. This tariff is being closely monitored by investors and economists, particularly as trade tensions between the US and China dominate headlines. Carmakers in Japan are already responding to potential tariffs by slashing export prices to the US. The EU has not yet commented on the possibility of a 25% tariff, but its impact on the EU economy is a concern. The situation is being closely watched by financial markets.

site_title: Taking innovation further afield
summary: Australian startups and research institutions have benefited from Singapore's infrastructure and resources, with over 30 businesses participating in the Landing Pad program since its launch in 2017. The program, run by Austrade, aids market-ready startups and scaleups in entering five global innovation hubs. Landing Pad has helped Australian businesses expand into Asia, with Singapore being a key destination. The program's success highlights the growing connections between Australia and Singapore in innovation and trade.

site_title: Thailand general election to go ahead on March 24
summary: Thailand's general election will take place on March 24, as announced by the Election Commission. The new date was set after the military government expressed concerns about clashes with the coronation of King Maha Vajiralongkorn, scheduled for May 4-6. Political parties will submit parliamentary candidates and prime minister candidates by February 8. The election follows a 2014 military coup and is the first since then.

site_title: Singapore releases model governance framework on AI
summary: Singapore has released a model governance framework for artificial intelligence (AI) that companies can adopt to address emerging issues with new technology. The framework, released by Minister S Iswaran at the World Economic Forum, aims to promote responsible AI development and deployment. The move follows recent investments in AI-focused innovation hubs in Singapore, including those by BHP, Oracle, and Grab. The framework is expected to foster a more collaborative and regulated approach to AI development in the country.

images.alt_text: Mr S. Iswaran, Minister for Communications and Information, speaking at the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum in Davos on Jan 22, 2019.

site_title: Trump won't soften hardline on China to make trade deal: advisers
summary: US President Donald Trump will not soften his stance on China requiring real structural reforms, including intellectual property handling, to reach a trade deal. Despite offering to buy more American goods, Trump's advisers believe this alone won't overcome the issue, which has stalled talks. Chinese Vice Premier Liu He is set to visit Washington at the end of January to continue negotiations.

site_title: For Oscars, a new turn towards an old friend: Dollars
summary: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences has expanded its definition of a best picture, choosing a Netflix film (Roma) and a Marvel superhero film (Black Panther) among its nominees. This marks the first time in nearly a decade that three movies have grossed at least $200 million at the time of nominations.
