Analysts expect revenue growth to rebound to 20% this year, driven by advances in laser technology, and believe the company is due for a buying opportunity when its valuation dips below 15 times 2019 earnings.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chasing Cars: The winners revealed
summary: The SG Carmart Car of The Year Awards revealed 27 winners, including the overall car of the year. Julian Kho from sgcarmart and Claressa Monteiro hosted the podcast, which featured the winners. The podcast is available for download on various platforms, including Money FM 89.3, ST & BT, Spotify, iTunes, and Google Podcasts.

site_title: Who is to blame for use of illegal fuel?
summary: A Marseille court fined the captain of the cruise ship Azura, owned by P&O Cruises, 100,000 euros for using heavy fuel oil with 1.68% sulfur content, exceeding the European limit. However, the court's focus on the captain's liability raises concerns about the responsibility of non-compliant companies. P&O Cruises claims the captain used the fuel in good faith and that the company had saved 21,000 euros by buying the higher sulfur content fuel. The case has sparked debate about the regulation of cruise ships and the distribution of liability between companies and seafarers.

site_title: In Davos, investors agree: Fed must rethink tightening
summary: Investors and former policymakers attending the Davos summit agree that the US Federal Reserve should rethink its plans to tighten monetary policy in 2019 due to slowing global growth. Most attendees predict a slowdown is underway, while avoiding a recession. The International Monetary Fund has cut its forecast for global growth to 3.5%, the weakest since 2016. Central banks are warned to be cautious of causing a recession by restricting policy too much, with the ECB potentially missing its target to leave negative territory. Investors also express concerns over global social tensions and rising debt levels.

site_title: Brazil to privatise more airports, railways for grains
summary: Brazil's government plans to privatize southern airports, including Curitiba, and Ferrograo and FIOL railway projects serving the central grain belt, aiming to reduce reliance on road transport and increase rail cargo to 31% by 2025. The privatisation process is expected to be completed in the second quarter of this year, with Chinese investment being "very well received". The government aims to boost infrastructure development and improve air travel across the country for tourism, farming, and the oil industry.

site_title: US banks boost aid to customers as federal shutdown drags on
summary: US banks are boosting aid to customers amid the longest federal shutdown in history. Lenders such as Navy Federal Credit Union, US Bancorp, and PayPal are offering no-interest loans, fee waivers, and low-cost loans to support 800,000 furloughed federal workers. The assistance programs aim to bridge the financial gap until paychecks resume. More than 100 banks have programs in place to help, with some offering interest-free cash advances and low-rate loan options, totaling up to $6,000. The programs aim to ease financial uncertainty for affected workers.

images.alt_text: Lenders across the US are bolstering assistance programs and evaluating how else to help their customers as the longest partial government shutdown in history threatens to extend through a second payday for furloughed federal workers.

site_title: Looking for a compass in an economic storm
summary: Investors heading into 2019 face uncertainty, with many expecting a recession and volatility. However, the author argues that traditional asset allocation approaches may not be effective due to the complexity of the modern economy. Instead, a focus on fundamental value at the security level could prove beneficial in navigating the uncertain market backdrop. Key areas, such as the UK, emerging markets, and Europe, appear cheap due to low returns and high uncertainty. Investors must look to fundamental value to guide their decisions, potentially offering a more rewarding strategy than the predominantly bearish sentiment suggests.

site_title: S$72m fund set up to boost skills in Singapore construction sector
summary: A S$72 million training fund has been established in Singapore to boost skills in the construction sector, aiming to transition from labor-intensive methods to "smart" processes. The fund will support existing scholarship and sponsorship programs for students and adults, aiming to enhance the industry's competitiveness.

site_title: Neuron Mobility unveils e-scooter built in-house; eyes Series A funding
summary: Neuron Mobility, a Singapore-based e-scooter sharing startup, unveiled a new e-scooter built in-house. The e-scooter features a larger frame and 12-inch wheels for improved stability on uneven surfaces. The company is seeking Series A funding to further its operations. This move is seen as an effort to outcompete existing players in the market.

site_title: 'Indiana Jones of art' finds stolen Spanish carvings in English garden
summary: Dutch art detective Arthur Brand, known as the "Indiana Jones of the art world," has recovered two priceless stone reliefs stolen from an ancient Spanish church in 2004. The reliefs, weighing 50 kg each, were found in an English nobleman's garden and were later handed back to the Spanish embassy in London. Brand spent eight years tracking down the artworks, which were sold as garden ornaments for around £50,000 each. The recovery is significant, not only for the return of the artworks but also for shedding light on the mysterious Santa Maria de Lara church near Burgos.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust's distribution per unit rose 6.6% to 3.07 Singapore cents for the third quarter, with distributable income increasing 9% to S$58.3 million. The Reit also gained approval for its proposed acquisition of 18 Tai Seng from its sponsor Mapletree Investments at a property value of S$268.3 million. Meanwhile, DeClout's buyout offer from Kyowa Exeo Corp will close on Feb 18, and a subsidiary of Oxley Holdings has agreed to sell two blocks of buildings in Dublin for S$315 million.

site_title: CEO of UK builder Kier quits after poor response to rights issue
summary: Kier Group CEO Haydn Mursell has quit with immediate effect after a poor response to a rights issue in December 2018, where investors took up just 38% of the share issue. The company's chairman Philip Cox will act as executive chairman until a new CEO is appointed. Despite the poor response, Kier said it would meet its financial year expectations and has started searching for an external successor to Mursell. The company's infrastructure services and buildings businesses have won new contracts, including a £10 billion order book.

site_title: Hedge funds get key role at US$140b Swedbank money manager
summary: Swedbank Robur, a US$140 billion asset manager, is increasing its reliance on alternative strategies, particularly market-neutral hedge funds, to generate returns in whiplash-prone markets. The firm has cut its equity allocation and is focusing on alternative assets to mitigate risk. Market-neutral hedge funds now make up 20% of Swedbank's hedge fund allocation. The firm's head of asset allocation, Pia Haak, believes that a good earnings season and a positive solution to Brexit and trade disputes could support investment strategies. However, she also notes that there are risks, including systemic risk posed by investors who don't understand the markets.

site_title: Home truths are holding back China's consumers
summary: China's consumers are tightening their belts, with retail sales rising 8.2% in December, the slowest pace in 15 years. This trend is attributed to household debt, which surged to 53.2% of GDP in December, with average household debt growing 26% in the past year. The government's efforts to rebalance the economy towards consumer spending are being hindered by the weight of debt, with banks responding by lending more to consumers. The slowdown in consumer spending is an ominous sign for China's economy, which is heavily reliant on export-led growth.

site_title: US: Wall Street drops as economic outlook, corporate forecasts sour
summary: US stocks ended lower on Tuesday, snapping a four-session rally, due to a gloomy global economic growth outlook and disappointing company forecasts. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.22%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite lost 1.42% and 1.91%, respectively. The decline was partly due to the International Monetary Fund's trimmed global economic growth estimates and China's slowest economic growth rate in 28 years, which also affected chipmakers and FAANG stocks.

site_title: Keppel Infra Trust's Q4 DPU flat at 0.93 Singapore cent
summary: Keppel Infra Trust reported a Q4 DPU of 0.93 Singapore cents, unchanged from the year-ago period. Profit attributable to unitholders more than doubled to S$20.4 million, driven by higher contributions from Basslink Interconnector. Revenue increased 8.9% to S$172.2 million. For 2018, total DPU was 3.72 Singapore cents, with profit attributable to unitholders decreasing to S$32 million due to lower City Gas contribution. Net asset value decreased to 27.3 Singapore cents per unit.

site_title: Euro slumps on weak data, IMF growth forecast cuts
summary: The euro slumped to a three-week low due to weak data and a reduced European growth forecast by the IMF. The single currency fell 0.1% to $1.1347, its lowest since January 4. A survey showed German investors' morale improved slightly but their assessment of the economy deteriorated to a four-year low. The IMF cut its growth projections in the euro zone to 1.6% in 2019, 0.3 percentage points lower than previously forecast. Investors have been selling euros for the last five weeks, while hedge funds have also turned bearish.

site_title: Amazon.com launching sales of goods in Brazil after delays
summary: Amazon.com is launching its direct sales platform in Brazil after months of delays due to complex logistics and tax issues. The company will sell 11 categories of merchandise from over 800 suppliers, including 320,000 products, and aims to intensify competition for fast delivery in the country's largest economy. Amazon's Brazilian country manager, Alex Szapiro, says the company is committed to increasing its product catalogue and improving customer satisfaction. The move is expected to strengthen Amazon's presence in Latin America and potentially disrupt the market share of local retailers.

site_title: Jiayuan chairman, wife sold HK stock as price dives
summary: Hong Kong-listed property developer Jiayuan International Group's chairman, Shum Tin Ching, and his wife Wang Xinmei sold 93.6 million shares at an average price of HK$2.7611, reducing their stake to 53.92% from 57.65%. The sale occurred as the stock plummeted 89% and was attributed to false information disseminated by short-sellers. The company did not disclose a reason for the slump.

site_title: Local stocks slide on global growth fears
summary: Singapore stocks slid 0.86% on Tuesday, following the International Monetary Fund's downgrade of global growth forecasts to 3.5% for 2019, citing trade tariffs and financial market volatility. The IMF also cut global growth forecasts for 2020 to 3.6%. Key sectors, including manufacturing, transport, and communications, were particularly affected. Some stocks, such as ComfortDelGro and Soilbuild Reit, bucked the trend, while others, including DBS Bank and OCBC Bank, declined. The Straits Times Index closed at 3,192.71.

site_title: Embracing, shaping a new world order amid disagreement
summary: World leaders are gathering in Davos, concerned about the emergence of "multi-conceptual and competing narratives" that may hinder global cooperation. However, embracing disagreement and open discourse is crucial for progress, as it has driven human advancement throughout history. In contrast, the digital age's "cotton wool era" of protecting feelings and shutting down opposing views threatens to stifle intellectual debate and individual thought. To shape the future, leaders must harness multi-conceptual views, address moral implications, and promote ethical boundaries, preserving the art of intelligent disagreement.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit DPU up 5.7% in Q4 on acquisitions
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 5.7% increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.85 Singapore cents, driven by the acquisitions of Keppel DC Singapore 5 and maincubes DC in Germany. This higher distributable income is attributed to the recent acquisitions, which contributed to the growth in the Reit's income.

site_title: Sale of Ascott Raffles Place in line with 'legal and regulatory rules'
summary: Ascott Reit's manager confirmed the sale of Ascott Raffles Place to a private investor for S$353.3 million, stating it's the highest offer received during the marketing exercise. The sale price reflects the building's valuation of S$215 million as of December 31, 2018. The divestment was approved by the board of directors, and the Reit manager clarified that all divestments are carefully considered. The discrepancy between valuation and sale amount may be due to factors like development potential and market sentiment, according to a property valuation expert.

site_title: Keppel-SPH joint venture stands pat on offer price for M1, extends offer closing date
summary: Keppel-SPH joint venture Konnectivity has reaffirmed its offer price of S$2.06 per share for M1, without plans to increase it. The offer closing date has been extended to February 18 from February 4. As of Monday, Konnectivity controlled or agreed to acquire approximately 318 million shares, representing 34.4% of M1's total shares. Analysts have deemed the offer price "fair and reasonable" and advised M1's directors to recommend shareholders accept the offer.

site_title: Are India's budget numbers bogus?
summary: India's finance minister is set to present an interim budget, which may not accurately reflect the government's actual spending due to unconventional financial arrangements. The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) has accused the government of "blatantly fudging" numbers by concealing expenditure in subsidies, power sector, and railways. The government is using off-budget financial arrangements to hide the true cost of subsidies, and is also forcing public-sector enterprises to buy others, leading to a reduction in available funds for investment. This may make the fiscal deficit appear deceptively better, undermining the government's reputation for fiscal prudence.

site_title: Firm sterling points towards support for May's strategy
summary: Theresa May's Brexit withdrawal deal is gaining support from Brexiteer and DUP MPs after she revised her strategy to address concerns over the "backstop" clause. Sterling has risen 3.6% against the US dollar since its 2019 low, with the FTSE 100 index also increasing 6.4% from its December 2018 low. May's plan involves flexibility, worker rights protections, and a time-limited backstop, which she hopes will secure parliamentary support. If her strategy fails, markets believe parliament can prevent a no-deal Brexit, and a potential referendum is seen as a possible outcome.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge starts work on Phase 3 of Hangzhou project
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge Group has begun construction on Phase 3 of the Singapore-Hangzhou Science & Technology Park in China, with an estimated completion date of 2021. The 230,000 sq m development will feature office buildings, community amenities, and spaces for companies in various industries, including cultural and creative, healthcare, and life sciences. The project, valued at 1.488 billion yuan (S$304 million), marks an important milestone in China-Singapore economic cooperation and will cater to growing demand for innovation and research.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of the Phase 3 development of the Singapore-Hangzhou Science & Technology Park. The Phase 3 project will have a total gross floor area of more than 230,000 square metres, comprising multi-tenant and single-tenant office buildings, and community and lifestyle amenities.

site_title: Tesla says it has quotes on batteries from Lishen, but no deal yet
summary: Tesla has received quotes from Tianjin Lishen for battery supplies for its Shanghai electric car factory but has not signed an agreement. The US company had previously stated it would manufacture battery modules and packs locally, but negotiations are ongoing. Lishen, a Chinese battery maker, had reportedly signed a preliminary agreement with Tesla, but the details have yet to be finalized. Other companies, including Panasonic and Contemporary Amperex Technology, are also in the running for contracts.

site_title: Plans to focus on health, infrastructure in budget
summary: Singapore's finance minister Heng Swee Keat announced the country's upcoming budget will focus on infrastructure spending, healthcare for the aging population, and digital economy transition. The budget, set for release on Feb 18, comes amidst US-China trade tensions and weaker global growth. Heng emphasized the need to invest in education, healthcare, and infrastructure to maintain Singapore's growth and stability. The budget will also include a special healthcare package for seniors and a tax hike to support growing health and infrastructure spending, which is still planned to occur between 2021 and 2025.

site_title: Malaysian finance firm eyes Singapore moneylending sector
summary: Malaysian finance firm RCE Capital is investing S$40 million in Singapore fintech Credit Culture, which aims to launch a round-the-clock online loan platform by the end of February. The platform will offer loans with monthly interest rates capped at 1%, encouraging prompt debt repayment. This move is seen as a challenge to traditional moneylenders in Singapore, who often charge higher interest rates.

site_title: Google fined 50m euros in EU data privacy breach
summary: Google has been fined 50 million euros by the French data protection authority for not properly disclosing to users how data is collected across its services to present personalized ads. The fine is the largest under the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation, which took effect in May. Google's business model relies on collecting user data, and the regulator found that the company did not obtain sufficient consent from users before processing their data. The ruling signals a new phase in enforcing the EU's data protection law, which is being closely watched by policymakers in the US.

site_title: Trend Micro makes Singapore regional HQ, invests in new capabilities
summary: Trend Micro has established its Asia-Pacific, Middle East and Africa (AMEA) headquarters in Singapore, marking a significant investment in the region's growing cybersecurity demand. The company's new 12,000 square foot office will house a Managed Detection and Response (MDR) Security Operations Centre (SOC), monitoring threat activity 24/7. This move follows other international players, including CenturyLink and BT, setting up cybersecurity facilities in Singapore, and aims to capitalize on the region's growing appetite for MDR services.

site_title: Vibrant Group JV hit by winding-up petition from partner in KL
summary: Vibrant Group, a Singapore-based logistics company, has been hit by a winding-up petition from its Malaysian partner Desa Tiasa Sdn Bhd. Desa Tiasa claims that $30.9 million in advances made by Vibrant's unit broke Malaysian law, alleging that Desa Tiasa was not properly compensated. Vibrant's board denies the allegations, calling them "spurious and unfounded." The company will seek legal advice and make further announcements as the matter develops, leading to a 0.64% decline in its shares.

site_title: Using AI for social good in Singapore and Asia-Pacific
summary: Google is partnering with the UN body to create a research network focused on the benefits of AI in the Asia-Pacific region. The network aims to develop a dashboard for crises and promote the responsible use of AI. Google has also launched the Google AI Impact Challenge to support non-profit organizations in using AI to solve societal challenges. The company is working with governments and academia to establish governance frameworks that prioritize responsible AI development and applications. This includes a project in Singapore to use AI to prevent the spread of dengue fever, and a grant to fund the creation of an Asia-Pacific AI for Social Good Research Network.

site_title: Groundhog Day as May's 'Plan B' is so like 'Plan A'
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May delivered a "Plan B" for Brexit that is virtually identical to her previous "Plan A", which was rejected by the House of Commons last week. This move highlights May's limited room for maneuver as a prime minister leading a weak minority government. The Brexit process is becoming increasingly complex, with the opposition Labour Party submitting an amendment calling for a softer Brexit plan and a vote of no confidence in the government. The possibility of extending Article 50 beyond March and the need for a new domestic legislative framework to enable Brexit are also looming.

site_title: Apac AUM to hit almost US$30t by 2025, beating out global regions: PwC
summary: Asia-Pacific is expected to surpass global regions in assets under management (AUM) by 2025, reaching almost $30 trillion, driven by growth in retail funds and alternative assets. The region is also set to become a major infrastructure investment hub, with Singapore and Hong Kong likely to be joined by Shanghai. The industry shift towards transparency and lower-cost passive strategies is also expected, with robo advisers and digitalized fund advice gaining popularity.

site_title: Oil industry gaining confidence, set to up spending in 2019
summary: The oil industry has regained confidence, with 75% of senior oil and gas professionals optimistic about growth in 2019, the highest outlook since 2014. Despite this, the industry remains cautious, with concerns over price volatility and the need to maintain competitiveness. 70% of professionals plan to increase capital expenditure budgets, but risks include a potential return to inefficient spending habits. The industry also faces challenges, including an ageing workforce and skills shortages, with digitalization seen as a key area for investment.

site_title: Trump presidency at half-time: early concerns more than vindicated
summary: US President Donald Trump's presidency has been marked by early concerns being vindicated, with a lack of unifying leadership and policy experience leading to disorganisation and chaos. Two years into his term, Trump's presidency has been marred by scandals, investigations, and policy failures, including the shutdown of the federal government. Despite maintaining a stable economy, Trump's trade policies and foreign moves have antagonised allies and rewarded rivals, raising concerns about the country's global standing. The author questions whether things will improve in the second half of Trump's presidency.

site_title: 'Bear market' is an arbitrary label, but using it can hurt
summary: The term "bear market" is often used to describe a decline of 20% in the S&P 500, but this label is arbitrary and lacks scientific basis. The 20% threshold was first introduced in the 1980s, but it has been rare for a market to decline by this amount without continuing further. In fact, two such declines since 2000 resulted in net declines of over 50%. The designation itself can create market volatility, as it taps into negative emotions and can fuel further pessimism.

site_title: Michelin gives stars back to chef who didn't want them
summary: French chef Sebastien Bras, who gave back his Michelin stars in 2017, was surprised to see his restaurant Le Suquet regain two stars in the 2019 guide. Bras cited "huge pressure" as a reason for initially giving up his three Michelin stars, and he now worries about the "strategies of the guide" despite no longer seeking recognition. The 2019 guide celebrates more female chefs and young talent, with several notable changes, including Marc Veyrat losing his third star and Argentine chef Mauro Colagreco retaining his three stars.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust reported a strong Q3 FY2019, with DPU growth of 5% y-o-y, driven by higher borrowing costs and rental reversions, particularly in Hong Kong and China. The trust also diversified its portfolio with logistics acquisitions in Brisbane and South Korea. Frasers Centrepoint Trust's Q1 2019 DPU rose 0.7% y-o-y, driven by improved occupancies and strong leasing momentum at Causeway Point. Both trusts' DPU forecasts have been raised due to the acquisitions.

site_title: UBS warns market falls will hit wealth management revenues
summary: UBS warned that market declines will hit wealth management revenues, with client activity still recovering from US$13 billion in asset withdrawals in the final quarter of last year. The Zurich-based bank reported almost US$8 billion in withdrawals from its key global wealth management unit, while asset management saw the remainder. Increased volatility, rising protectionism, and geopolitical tensions continue to weigh on investors, affecting both wealth and asset management revenue this quarter.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on global growth worries
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, following a four-week rally, amid concerns of a global economic slowdown. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.40%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.48%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.67%. The International Monetary Fund's trimmed growth outlook and lingering corporate earnings worries contributed to the decline.

site_title: There's a golden shelter from recession risks with these miners
summary: Mid-sized gold miners, such as Kirkland Lake Gold and Northern Star Resources, are seen as a safe haven for investors amid recession risks. These companies have outperformed the mining industry and gold price over the past 12 months, with strong returns and leverage to gold. Analysts expect the gold price to rise to $1,425 an ounce, boosting demand for defensive assets. Investors are drawn to these companies' strong management, operational teams, and ability to grow production, making them attractive options for a diversified portfolio.

site_title: Yamada Green executive director resigns after review of draft investigation report
summary: Yamada Green Resources announced the resignation of executive director Lin Weibin, effective January 22, following a review of a draft investigation report by Foo Kon Tan LLP. Lin Weibin, 51, had been in charge of logistics and plantation since June 2014. The reason for his resignation was not specified.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.90 points to 1,702.12, closing higher on Tuesday. The index saw 3.3 billion lots worth RM2.1 billion traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 556 to 332.

site_title: Global warming - why I am less pessimistic about it
summary: A columnist has revisited his stance on global warming, acknowledging that while man-made greenhouse gases contribute to the issue, controlling their impact is challenging due to the energy status quo. Despite the enthusiasm for non-fossil fuels, global emissions remain high, and poorer countries resist environmental goals. A "carbon dividends" plan, which taxes CO2 emissions and rebates the money to households, has been proposed as a potential solution, with estimates suggesting a 33% decline in US fossil fuel use and greenhouse gases if implemented. The columnist remains skeptical about solving the problem but is less pessimistic about finding ways to slow the increase in greenhouse gases.

site_title: No US recession in 2019, although economist warn of self-fulfilling prophecy
summary: US economists do not foresee a recession in the US in the next 12 months, despite warnings of a self-fulfilling prophecy. The probability of a US recession is low, at 21%, according to published estimates. Economists at DBS Bank, United Overseas Bank, and OCBC Bank played down the slowdown in global economic growth, citing stable drivers in China's economy, such as consumption and investment spending. They also expect only one or two interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve this year, and downplayed the threat of a US-China war.

site_title: High in the Alps, igloo hotels offer epitome of no-frills luxury
summary: High in the Swiss Alps, igloo hotels offer a unique no-frills luxury experience, where guests pay upwards of $500 per night to stay in rooms carved from snow and ice. The five ski-in-ski-out "Igloo Villages" feature ice sculptures, cozy rooms, and outdoor hot tubs, with temperatures maintained at a stable degree or two below freezing. Guests typically stay for just one night, retreating to warmth after a chilly experience, and enjoy a limited menu of cheese fondue or pasta in the on-site restaurant.

site_title: France, Germany try to revive embattled EU project
summary: French and German leaders signed a new treaty on Tuesday, updating their 1963 post-war reconciliation accord to reinvigorate the European Union. The 16-page Aachen Treaty aims to give fresh leadership to the EU, addressing eurosceptic nationalism and Brexit. However, it fails to push forward eurozone economic reform, sparking concerns that the chance for a real renewal of cooperation has been lost. The treaty commits to closer foreign and defense policy ties, with Germany seeking permanent UN Security Council membership.

site_title: Financial crystal ball reveals no answers
summary: Financial markets have failed to predict key economic events, echoing the uncertainty faced by Hollywood producers. Despite economists' optimistic forecasts in 2018, the year turned out to be the worst for investors since the 2008 financial crisis. The World Bank reduced its global growth estimates, and central bankers withdrew their plans to normalize monetary policy. A perfect storm of political shocks, including oil price increases and trade tensions, contributed to market volatility. Investors' inability to predict the future may be due to their confusion with political chaos, leading to a reactive rather than predictive market.

site_title: Dyson moves head office to Singapore
summary: Dyson is relocating its corporate head office to Singapore, reflecting the growing importance of Asia to its business. The British home electronics maker plans to double its Singapore Technology Centre and increase investment in neighboring Malaysia. Dyson's CEO, Jim Rowan, stated that the shift is driven by soaring demand for Dyson products across Asia, particularly with the upcoming launch of its electric vehicle. The company's profit grew 33% in 2018 to £1.1 billion, and investments will continue to grow across its centers in 2019.

site_title: Just Eat CEO exits with threat from Uber, Deliveroo growing
summary: JUST Eat CEO Peter Plumb is leaving the company with immediate effect, citing a need for change after a surge in competition from rival apps and pressure from activist shareholder Cat Rock Capital Management LP. Plumb's departure follows a positive trading update, with Just Eat's full-year 2018 revenue reaching £780 million. The company expects to grow marketplace Ebitda margins and report its first full-year profit in Canada. Plumb's departure raises questions about the company's strategy, particularly regarding its Latin American operations and stake in Brazilian startup iFood.

site_title: Dyson moving corporate head office to Singapore
summary: Dyson is relocating its corporate head office to Singapore to reflect the increasing importance of Asia in its business. The British home electronics maker plans to double its Singapore Technology Centre and increase investment in Malaysia this year. This move follows the release of its 2018 financial results, which show the company's growing presence in the Asian market.

site_title: US top court rejects Helsinn over anti-nausea drug patent in win for Teva
summary: The US Supreme Court unanimously upheld a lower court ruling that canceled a patent on the anti-nausea drug Aloxi, allowing Teva Pharmaceutical Industries to launch a generic version of the drug. The patent, held by Helsinn Healthcare SA, was invalidated due to violating US patent law provisions that prohibit sales before patent application. This decision is a win for Teva, which began selling its generic version of Aloxi in March 2018.

site_title: New war risks insurance conditions for maritime sector
summary: Singapore has introduced the Singapore War Risks Insurance Conditions (SRWIC), an enhanced version of the existing Singapore War Risks Mutual (SWRM) insurance facility, offering improved coverage for war risks to the maritime sector. The new conditions aim to address industry gaps and simplify the coverage process. The move is seen as a local equivalent to internationally-used marine insurance plans. A Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) has also been signed to develop an inter-operability framework for electronic trade documents, marking a step towards digitalising maritime documentation.

site_title: Two YuuZoo independent directors resign
summary: Two independent directors, Joseph Lee Sien Liang and Brendan Goh Sian Hin, have resigned from YuuZoo Networks Group Corporation, citing private practice work commitments. They were appointed as independent directors in July and November 2018, respectively. The resignations follow several months after the announcement.

site_title: Saudi Arabia suspends Brazil meatpackers; JBS and BRF affected
summary: Saudi Arabia has suspended certification of five Brazilian meatpacking plants, affecting JBS SA and BRF SA, due to a possible link to Brazil's embassy move to Jerusalem. The move, reported by Folha de S Paulo, could be related to the Brazilian government's decision to relocate the embassy. This affects around 11.8% of Brazil's chicken exports to Saudi Arabia, with China being the second-largest buyer. JBS and BRF have seen share price drops as a result of the news.

images.alt_text: The measure, which the paper says was communicated to the Brazilian government by the Saudis, affected the units of listed Brazilian food processors JBS SA and BRF SA

site_title: Gatwick drone disruption leaves easyJet £15m poorer
summary: Gatwick drone disruptions in December caused EasyJet to lose £15 million (S$26.4 million) over 36 hours of travel chaos. The disruptions affected 82,000 customers and led to the cancellation of over 400 flights. The incidents occurred at London's Gatwick Airport, the largest operator at the airport. The losses were attributed to the significant disruption to EasyJet's operations during the Christmas period.

site_title: PG&E lines up US$5.5b to fund 2-year bankruptcy process
summary: PG&E Corp has secured $5.5 billion in funding to support its 2-year bankruptcy process. The funding includes a $3.5 billion revolving credit facility from four banks, allowing the company to maintain safe operations while shielding itself from potential liabilities of up to $30 billion related to 2017 and 2018 wildfires. PG&E expects the bankruptcy cases to take approximately two years, with the company aiming to begin the process on January 29.

site_title: UBS annual profits soar to US$4.9b
summary: Swiss banking giant UBS reported a 25% increase in net income for 2018, excluding the impact of US tax reforms, reaching US$4.9 billion. This marks a significant recovery from 2017, when the bank's results were also affected by US tax changes. The announcement comes as UBS continues to navigate the global banking landscape.

site_title: China drone maker DJI signals US$150m loss from graft
summary: China's drone maker DJI Technology Co Ltd reported losses of over $150 million in 2018 due to corruption cases involving employees inflating the cost of parts for personal gain. The company said it was investigating several serious cases and fired 45 individuals, mostly from research and development and procurement. DJI posted revenue of 18 billion yuan in 2017, 80% of which came from outside China. The incident highlights a growing trend of corruption cases in Chinese tech companies, following similar cases at Didi Chuxing Technology Co Ltd and Alibaba Group Holding Ltd's video streaming service Youku.

images.alt_text: Privately held DJI said late last week it was "investigating a number of serious cases of corruption at the company leading to losses of more than one billion yuan (S$200 million) for 2018".

site_title: Israel opens new international airport near Red Sea
summary: Israel has inaugurated a new international airport near the Red Sea, Ramon Airport, which is expected to boost tourism and serve as an emergency alternative to Tel Aviv's Ben Gurion airport. The airport, named after Israel's first astronaut Ilan Ramon, will initially handle domestic flights but plans to host international flights from around the globe by 2025. The airport's construction costs were $455 million, and it has sparked criticism from neighboring Jordan over its location, which Jordan claims violates international standards for airspace and territory.

site_title: Boutique fund investor takes 3.6% stake in Koufu
summary: Boutique fund investor Albizia Capital has taken a 3.6% stake in Koufu Group through a married share deal, acquiring over 20 million shares at S$0.63 per share. The deal reduced Koufu's founders' collective shareholdings to 77.1%. Koufu's executive chairman and CEO Pang Lim said the deal will tap into Albizia's consumer sector expertise to expand the company's contacts and opportunities in the F&B space. The deal came after Koufu's initial public offering (IPO) and was completed at the IPO price.

site_title: Chiropractor, 2 agents charged over insurance fraud involving more than S$14,000
summary: A chiropractor, Charles Loo Boon Ann, and two insurance agents, Priscilla Tien Ling and Mike Chew Jun Yong, have been charged with insurance fraud in Singapore. They allegedly submitted bogus personal accident claims to Manulife Singapore, cheating the insurer of over S$14,000. The trio worked together from June 2017 to April last year, with Loo and Tien facing 17 and 12 cheating charges, respectively. Chew faces nine charges. The victims received payouts of S$200 to S$1,200 each. The defendants were offered bail of S$15,000 and will return to court on February 19.

site_title: Philippine law would make 9-year-olds criminally liable
summary: A proposed Philippine law would make 9-year-olds criminally liable, sparking fierce opposition from rights advocates. The proposed amendments to the country's juvenile justice law aim to address the use of minors in drug gangs, but critics argue it would traumatize young offenders and lead to overcrowding in adult detention centers. Rights groups and lawmakers, including opposition leader Sen Francis Pangilinan, oppose the measure, citing concerns about the impact on children's development and the effectiveness of targeting high-level criminals instead.

site_title: Chris Brown questioned by Paris police over rape allegation
summary: R&B singer Chris Brown, 29, was questioned by Paris police on Tuesday over accusations of aggravated rape and drug-related infractions. A 24-year-old woman accused Brown of raping her in a Paris hotel room last week, claiming he invited her to the room after meeting at a nightclub. Two other people are also being questioned in relation to the case. Brown's arrest came after a complaint was filed against him, and he could be released without charges or charged and placed under formal investigation. This is the latest in a string of violent incidents involving Brown.

site_title: More government support for a slowing economy expected: Fitch
summary: Fitch Solutions predicts Singapore's government will unveil looser fiscal policy in the upcoming Budget, citing an impending global slowdown and pressure on the export-driven economy. The report suggests the government may adopt domestic-oriented initiatives, such as public infrastructure spending, to cushion the economy. The upcoming Budget may also hint at an early general election by the People's Action Party (PAP) in 2019, with a forecasted primary surplus of 0.6% of GDP. The government's track record of doing better than official estimates is expected to contribute to this outcome.

site_title: China's Q4 GDP growth dented by services, agriculture
summary: China's fourth-quarter GDP growth slowed to 6.4% due to weakness in the services and agriculture sectors, despite a strong rebound in construction activity. Services growth decreased to 7.4% from 7.9% in the third quarter, while agricultural growth slowed to 3.5% from 3.6%. This slowdown is despite a strong pick-up in construction activity. The data indicates a continued slowdown in China's economic growth, raising pressure on policymakers to implement measures to boost the economy.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower on lacklustre GDP data
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index closed lower on Tuesday due to disappointing GDP data, which showed the country's economy grew at a six-year low in 2018. The Bank of Korea reported a 1% growth rate in the fourth quarter, the fastest in three quarters. Global growth concerns and trade tensions also weighed on the market. The Korean won and bond yields dropped, while shares of Samsung BioLogics Co Ltd rose 1.8% after a court suspended disciplinary action against the company.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust DPU up 6.6% at 3.07 Singapore cents
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust's distribution per unit rose 6.6% to 3.07 Singapore cents for the third quarter, driven by income from its US data centers. Distributable income and net property income also increased, with average portfolio occupancy improving to 88.2% in the third quarter. The Reit's manager expects moderations in market rents and occupancy rates due to increased supply, but remains focused on tenant retention.

site_title: Experts say it's safe to treble limit for tremors at Britain's fracking sites
summary: Experts say Britain can safely raise the limit for tremors at fracking sites from 0.5 magnitude to 1.5, similar to vibrations from a heavy bin lorry. Seismologists from the British Geological Survey and University of Liverpool advise this change, citing that higher magnitude events would still be too small to cause damage. The move could help the fracking industry, which is keen to cut Britain's reliance on imported natural gas, but is opposed by environmentalists who argue it contradicts the country's goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

images.alt_text: Fracking at Cuadrilla's Preston New Road site in Lancashire, northwest England was halted several times last year after seismic activity exceeded limits put in place under Britain's traffic light regulation system.

site_title: TEE International bags new contracts, takes order book to S$484 million
summary: TEE International, a Singaporean engineering, infrastructure, and real estate group, has secured new contracts worth S$484 million, bringing its order book to that amount. The contracts include fit-out works for a data centre and mechanical and electrical engineering works for an institution building in Singapore. The company's shares closed 1.23% higher at 16.5 Singapore cents after the announcement.

site_title: Top Brazil coffee roaster is scouring for deals in South America
summary: Brazil's largest coffee roaster, Tres Coracoes, is seeking acquisitions in South America, particularly in Argentina, Chile, and Uruguay. The venture, owned by Sao Miguel and Strauss Group Ltd., aims to expand its market share in Brazil to over 40% and increase sales to more than $5 billion. Despite economic challenges in Argentina, the country is a priority target market. Tres Coracoes has already acquired eight coffee companies since its establishment in 2005 and is looking to expand its presence beyond coffee.

site_title: Raffles Place serviced residence was sold at highest offer, Ascott Reit clarifies
summary: ASCOTT Reit's manager clarified that the sale price of S$353.3 million for the Ascott Raffles Place serviced residence was the highest offer received during its marketing exercise. The building was sold to private investor and developer Cheong Sim Lam on January 9. An earlier valuation of S$215 million was done using the discounted cashflow method, which is consistent with market practice. The divestment was approved by the board of directors, and the company closed unchanged on Tuesday at S$1.150.

site_title: Toyota sees 3.8% fall in 2019 total Thailand domestic car sales
summary: Toyota Motor Corp expects Thailand's domestic car sales to drop 3.8% to 1 million units in 2019, despite predicting a 4.7% rise in its own sales to 330,000 cars. The company attributes the decline to similar economic conditions as 2018 and potential interest rate increases. Mazda Motor's Thai unit also forecasts a 5-10% rise in sales, while car exports are expected to fall due to weaker demand from the Middle East and other regions.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A report on Singapore's 2019 budget suggests the government may adopt domestic-oriented initiatives to cushion the economy due to global slowdown pressures. The report cites rising external risks as a reason for policymakers to prioritize public infrastructure spending. Meanwhile, Malaysia's agency is set to seize RM3 billion of assets belonging to Daim Zainuddin. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy has shrunk for the second month, adding to economic concerns.

images.alt_text: The report said that the rising external downside risks "are likely to prompt policymakers to adopt policies to cushion the economy through domestic-oriented initiatives" such as public infrastructure spending.

site_title: Grange Heights relaunches en-bloc bid with price unchanged
summary: Grange Heights is relaunching an en-bloc sale bid for its St Thomas Walk freehold property, with the reserve price remaining unchanged at S$820 million. The price translates to S$1,948 per square foot, including bonus balcony gross floor area. Homeowners will reopen the collective sale tender on Wednesday, marking another attempt to sell the property in a challenging market.

site_title: Sweden drops tax probe into man at centre of Nobel scandal
summary: Sweden's Economic Crime Authority has dropped a tax probe into Jean-Claude Arnault, a photographer married to a Swedish Academy member, amid a scandal that forced the postponement of the 2018 Nobel Prize for literature. The probe was launched in April last year, but was closed after it was deemed unlikely to lead to a conviction, as Arnault had already received a 2-1/2-year prison sentence for rape. The investigation was one of several factors contributing to the 2018 Nobel Prize's postponement, with two winners announced for this year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open
summary: European stock markets dropped at the start of trading on Tuesday, with the FTSE 100 index falling 0.5% to 6,933.30 points. The DAX 30 index in the eurozone also declined 0.5%, while the CAC 40 slid 0.6%. The decline was attributed to concerns over US-EU trade talks and ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.86% on Tuesday, closing at 3,192.71, with 1.57 billion shares worth S$786.6 million changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 225 to 148. Swee Hong rose 60%, while Thai Beverage remained unchanged. Genting Singapore lost 0.9%. The decline follows a 5-day rally, and investors may be cautious ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit DPU up 5.7% in Q4
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 5.7% increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.85 Singapore cents, driven by acquisitions of Keppel DC Singapore 5 and maincubes DC. Gross revenue jumped 30.5% to S$48 million, while gross rental income rose 27.9% to S$44.67 million. Portfolio occupancy was 93.1% as of December 31, with a weighted average lease expiry of 8.3 years. The Reit's full-year DPU was also up 5% to 7.32 Singapore cents.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended sharply lower on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index sinking 0.70% to 27,005.45, amid profit-taking and concerns over US-China trade talks. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.18% and the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 1.17%. The losses were attributed to a report stating that the US and China were struggling to make progress on trade talks, spooking dealers.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks turned negative Tuesday after a recent rally as profit-takers moved in, while dealers were also spooked by a report saying China and the US were struggling to make progress on parts of their trade talks.

site_title: S Korean court suspends regulator's disciplinary action against Samsung BioLogics
summary: A South Korean court has suspended disciplinary action against Samsung BioLogics Co Ltd for allegedly breaching accounting rules. The Financial Services Commission had called for the CEO and CFO to be fired, imposed fines, and requested a balance sheet correction. Samsung BioLogics filed a lawsuit to nullify the watchdog's findings, citing potential irreparable damage. The court ruled that immediate sanctions could harm the company's reputation, and the regulator plans to review the decision. The outcome of a prosecutors' investigation, which was triggered by the regulator's complaint, remains uncertain.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Q4 DPU flat at 0.93 Singapore cents
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.93 Singapore cents for Q4 2018, unchanged from the previous year. Profit attributable to unitholders more than doubled to S$20.4 million, driven by higher contributions from Basslink. Revenue increased 8.9% to S$172.2 million, primarily due to City Gas and Basslink revenue. Net asset value decreased to 27.3 cents per unit, due to distributions and marked-to-market movements. Units closed at S$0.515, down 1.91% from the previous day.

site_title: Brazil to privatize more airports, railways for grains
summary: Brazil's government plans to privatize southern airports, including Curitiba, and Ferrograo and FIOL railway projects serving the central grain belt, with auctions set for March and early 2020. Chinese investment is expected to be "very well received" in Brazilian infrastructure projects. The government aims to reduce reliance on road transport by doubling rail cargo share to 31% by 2025. Privatization of state companies, including Eletrobras, will also occur, with control passing into private investors' hands through a share sale.

site_title: Enhanced war risks coverage for Singapore maritime sector
summary: Singapore has introduced enhanced war risks insurance conditions for its maritime sector, aiming to address gaps in coverage for shipowners. The new Singapore War Risks Insurance Conditions (SRWIC) offer more breadth and certainty in terms of coverage, with simplified wording. The move is expected to benefit SSA members and those with ships registered in Singapore. The new conditions were launched at the Singapore Shipping Association's Chinese New Year cocktail reception, following the existing Singapore War Risks Mutual (SWRM) insurance facility, which has covered almost 800 ships since 2015.

site_title: Renault convenes board to turn page on Ghosn era
summary: Renault has convened a board meeting to replace Chairman and CEO Carlos Ghosn, who was arrested in Japan for alleged financial misconduct. The proposed replacement is outgoing Michelin boss Jean-Dominique Senard as chairman, and Thierry Bollore, Ghosn's deputy, as CEO. The move aims to ease tensions with Nissan, a key alliance partner. Ghosn has agreed to resign, but faces a trial in Japan and possible extended detention. French officials seek to revive a new ownership structure for the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi alliance, but Nissan is wary of changes.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday session at 3,209.12, down 0.36% on the day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday at 3,209.12, down 0.36% from the previous day. The Straits Times Index fell 11.44 points, with 920.7 million securities changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 177 to 109, with Swee Hong and Genting Singapore being the most heavily traded stocks.

site_title: Facebook to expand Ireland operations with 1,000 staff
summary: Facebook plans to expand its operations in Ireland by hiring 1,000 new staff in 2019, bringing the total number of employees to 5,000. The new hires will be distributed across various teams, including engineering, safety, and policy. The expansion comes amid scrutiny over the company's handling of user data and its role in spreading hate speech and facilitating foreign interference in elections. Facebook's Irish operations are under investigation by the Irish Data Protection Commission, and the company faces potential fines under the General Data Protection Regulation.

site_title: 'No place to hide': Twitter contacts give your preferences away, study finds
summary: A study published in Nature Human Behavior found that social media platforms like Twitter can infer a user's preferences by monitoring just eight of their one-time contacts, with machine learning algorithms achieving up to 64% accuracy. Researchers analyzed over 30 million publicly available Twitter posts and found that information shared online by friends and contacts can be used to deduce aspects of a person's life, including political affiliation, purchasing practices, and favorite TV shows. The study suggests that users' privacy is compromised on social media platforms.

site_title: Automotive startup Motorist.sg gets seed funding from JobsCentral, Zopim founders
summary: Motorist.sg, a Singapore-based automotive platform, secured seed funding from JobsCentral's co-founders and Zopim's co-founder. The undisclosed sum will be used to expand the business to Thailand in 2019. Founded in 2015, Motorist generates revenue through commissions from car purchases via its platform, with approximately 350-400 vehicles transacted monthly.

site_title: Australia shares end 5-day rally on weak miners and financials; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares ended a five-day winning streak, falling 0.5% on Tuesday due to weak miners and financials. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,858.80, while New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.4%. Financial stocks led the losses, with the Australian financial index down 0.5% and Westpac Banking Corp shedding 2.6%. BHP Group's iron ore production fell 9% in the second quarter, contributing to the market's decline. US stocks were set to open lower, with futures down 0.7-0.9%.

site_title: Israel opens new international airport near Red Sea
summary: Israel has inaugurated a new international airport, Ramon Airport, near the Red Sea, aiming to boost tourism and serve as an emergency alternative to Tel Aviv's Ben-Gurion airport. The airport, named after Israel's first astronaut Ilan Ramon, will initially handle domestic flights but plans to expand to international flights and jumbo jets. The new airport, costing $455 million, has been criticized by Jordan, which claims it threatens its airspace. The airport will have a capacity of up to 4.2 million passengers annually and is expected to bring significant revenue to Israel's tourism industry.

site_title: NEA unveils S$2m fund to support ground-up zero-waste projects
summary: Singapore's National Environment Agency (NEA) has launched a S$2 million fund to support zero-waste projects through "Towards Zero Waste Grants". The grants will fund initiatives promoting recycling, waste reduction, and recycling in packaging, food, and electronic waste streams. The program aims to rally the community to take positive actions and support Singapore's vision of a zero-waste nation. Applications are open from February 1, 2019, for individuals, organizations, and corporations.

site_title: Finance sector plays important role in directing capital for environmental benefit: Masagos Zulkifli
summary: Singapore's finance sector is increasingly directing capital towards environmental benefits, with the release of around S$2 billion in green bonds by local and foreign issuers since 2017. Major banks like OCBC and Standard Chartered are also investing in sustainability, with OCBC partnering Wilmar on a US$200 million loan linked to sustainability performance indicators. Environment Minister Masagos Zulkifli urged financial institutions to continue developing green products, citing a need for US$200 billion in green investment annually in the Asean region from 2016 to 2030.

site_title: 5 questions with Straits Interactive on General Data Protection Regulation
summary: Straits Interactive CEO Kevin Shepherdson discusses GDPR compliance for Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) in the ASEAN region. SMEs should be concerned about GDPR compliance due to its global reach, even if they are not based in the EU. Many SMEs in ASEAN are becoming more aware of GDPR requirements, but often remain unprepared. Key mistakes include believing GDPR only applies to EU-based companies, underestimating data breaches, and misunderstanding DPO and EU Representative requirements. To address these concerns, SMEs can take three actionable steps: (1) comply with the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) first, (2) appoint a DPO and Data Protection governance committee, and (3) identify and address PDPA risks through thorough policies and procedures.

site_title: Indonesia reviewing early release for Bali bombing-linked cleric
summary: Indonesia is reviewing the early release of radical cleric Abu Bakar Bashir, linked to the 2002 Bali bombings, after President Joko Widodo initially gave the green light. Bashir, 80, was sentenced to 15 years in jail for helping fund a paramilitary group but was released due to "humanitarian reasons". The decision drew criticism at home and abroad, including from Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison, who warned that Bashir remains a threat. Indonesia's Chief Security Minister Wiranto has ordered a review, citing the need for a "thorough and comprehensive study".

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on Brexit, US shutdown worries
summary: Tokyo stocks closed down 0.47% on Tuesday, shedding early gains, amid worries over Brexit and the US government shutdown. The yen strengthened, weighing on the market, and US shares were closed for the Martin Luther King Jr. Day holiday. Exporters, including Toyota and Panasonic, fell, while China-linked shares dropped after the IMF warned of global growth risks. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index closed at 20,622.91, and the Topix index fell to 1,556.43.

site_title: Amazon.com starts direct sales of merchandise in Brazil after delays
summary: Amazon.com launches its in-house fulfillment and delivery network in Brazil after months of delays due to complex logistics and tax systems. The company will directly sell 11 categories of merchandise from over 800 suppliers, including L'Oreal and Black & Decker. This shift is expected to intensify competition for fast delivery in Latin America's largest economy, which is exiting a recession. Amazon's move is seen as a response to the challenges faced by the company in Brazil, where it had initially planned to start direct sales in the Christmas selling season.

site_title: Oxley unit to sell off Dublin properties for 204m euros
summary: Oxley Holdings' subsidiary, Oxley Docklands Quay Two, has entered into an agreement to sell two Dublin properties for 204 million euros. The deal involves selling two blocks of buildings, No 4 and No 5 Dublin Landings, for 97 million euros and 107 million euros respectively. Oxley Holdings will receive 79.5% of the sale price, with a 20.4 million euro deposit paid upfront. The sale is expected to be completed in October this year, with proceeds contributing positively to the company's cash flow and earnings.

site_title: Canadian railways ration space as commodity congestion problems worsen
summary: Canada's two major railways, Canadian National Railway (CN) and Canadian Pacific Railway (CP), are rationing space on trains to deal with congestion at Port Metro Vancouver. The move has led to complaints of "discriminatory treatment" of certain commodities, prompting a transport regulator investigation. The congestion is exacerbated by free-trade deals with the EU and Pacific Nations, boosting demand for commodities. The railways have imposed embargoes on specific commodities, such as peas and lentils, causing shipping delays and contract breaches, and the investigation may consider whether the railways discriminated against shippers.

site_title: Sanli bags S$51.5m of PUB contracts at Kranji plant; order book at S$185.9m
summary: Sanli Environmental secured S$51.5 million contracts from Singapore's PUB for its Kranji water reclamation plant, boosting its order book to S$185.9 million. The contracts include a S$51 million EPC contract and a S$0.5 million maintenance contract. Sanli expects the EPC contract to contribute to revenue for two years, with CEO Sim Hock Heng citing the company's established track record and capabilities as key factors in securing the contract.

site_title: Davos elites warned on populist rage, economic uncertainty
summary: Global elites gathered at the World Economic Forum in Davos received urgent warnings from the IMF and Oxfam about the risks facing the international economy, including swelling inequality and populist rage. The IMF cut its global GDP forecast to 3.5% for 2019, citing uncertainty over Brexit, US-China trade tensions, and other sources of instability. Oxfam warned that extreme inequality is out of control, with the world's 26 richest people now owning the same wealth as the poorest half of humanity.

images.alt_text: Global elites descending on Davos for the World Economic Forum faced urgent warnings from Oxfam and the IMF on Monday that the international economy is at risk, as swelling inequality stokes public anger.

site_title: Google considering pulling news service from Europe
summary: Google is considering pulling its news-aggregation service from Europe due to the European Union's new copyright law, which gives publishers the right to demand money from web platforms when small fragments of their articles appear in search results. Google's public policy manager, Jennifer Bernal, stated that the internet giant will analyze the final text of the law before making a decision, and would withdraw its service reluctantly if necessary. The move aims to protect Google News from financial penalties under the new law, which could affect other web platforms as well.

site_title: AUM in Asia-Pacific to hit almost US$30 trillion by 2025, outpacing global regions: PwC
summary: Asia-Pacific assets under management (AUM) are expected to reach nearly $30 trillion by 2025, surpassing global regions, according to a report by PwC. The region's AUM is projected to grow at a 8.7% compound annual rate, driven by China's Belt and Road Initiative and other initiatives. Retail and alternative assets, such as real estate and infrastructure investments, are also expected to surge. Passive strategies are gaining ground, and asset managers must adapt to lower costs and changing investor preferences to remain competitive.

site_title: Ronaldo faces multi-million tax fraud fine in Madrid court
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo is set to face a Madrid court on Tuesday, where he may be fined 18.8 million euros for tax fraud as part of a deal with Spanish tax authorities. As part of the agreement, Ronaldo could receive a 23-month jail sentence, but it is unlikely he will serve time due to Spain's lenient sentencing policies for first-time offenders. The case involves Ronaldo's use of offshore companies to avoid paying taxes on his image rights between 2011 and 2014.

site_title: Asia: Markets turn lower, pound holds up against dollar
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday as profit-takers stepped in following recent gains, while the pound held up against the dollar due to optimism over Britain's potential avoidance of a hard Brexit. The International Monetary Fund lowered its global growth forecasts citing trade tensions, Brexit, and other issues. Meanwhile, oil prices extended losses due to China's slowest economy growth in nearly three decades, and the US-China trade talks remain uncertain despite a Bloomberg report stating the two sides struggle to agree on intellectual property.

site_title: USW and Shell make some progress in refinery talks -sources
summary: USW union and Shell Oil Co have made progress in contract talks for 30,000 refinery, chemical plant, and pipeline workers. However, many tough issues remain unresolved. The details of the progress were not disclosed, with sources declining to identify the specific issues. The negotiations are ongoing, with the union representing workers at US refineries and chemical plants operated by Shell Oil.

site_title: Macau, Beijing police arrest 37 in crackdown on illicit banking
summary: Chinese authorities in Macau and Beijing arrested 39 suspects in an illicit banking crackdown, involving over 30 billion yuan (S$6 billion). The operation targeted underground lending schemes, where credit card point-of-sale terminals were used to circumvent cash withdrawal limits. The crackdown comes after China's President Xi Jinping warned of "black swan" risks and economic changes. The arrests were made after a joint investigation, resulting in the seizure of 32 illegal converted point-of-sale terminals and bank cards. The operation aims to reduce economic risks and clamp down on illicit capital outflows.

site_title: China economy to stabilise without aggressive stimulus: Goldman
summary: China's economy is expected to stabilize in the second half of 2019 without aggressive stimulus, according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc chief economist Jan Hatzius. The economy's pace of expansion slowed to 6.4% in the fourth quarter, the slowest since 2009, driven by the government's policy push to curb debt. The slowdown is attributed to credit deceleration and financial imbalances, with the trade war with the US posing a risk to sentiment and investment. Goldman forecasts no major changes to global forecasts, despite the International Monetary Fund's reduced world economy prediction.

site_title: Chinese drone maker DJI says 1b yuan scam involved staff padding parts costs
summary: China's SZ DJI Technology, the world's largest drone maker, has found a 1 billion yuan ($200 million) scam involving staff padding part costs, leading to suspected corruption and losses. Employees inflated costs for personal gain, resulting in significant losses for the company in 2018. DJI stated it did not incur a full year loss in 2018, despite the corruption incidents, and is investigating the cases.

site_title: China approves third batch of video games; still no Tencent
summary: China has approved the release of a third batch of video games, featuring 93 new titles, after a freeze for most of last year. Industry leaders Tencent and NetEase Inc were absent from the list, despite previous approvals. This marks the third batch of approved games since December, following a previous 84-game batch. The move aims to boost the gaming industry, which has been impacted by the freeze.

site_title: Singapore-based investment firm eyes powering off-grid South-east Asia
summary: A Singapore-based investment firm, CleanGrid Partners, has been launched to build and run clean energy projects across South-east Asia. The firm, backed by US$60 million, aims to electrify 100 million people in the region with a portfolio of projects worth US$100 million within four years. CleanGrid Partners will focus on off-grid power projects in the Philippines, Indonesia, and Myanmar, and also target industrial estate projects in Singapore. The firm's CEO, Atem Ramsundersingh, says the move addresses the chronic lack of electricity access in parts of the Asean region.

site_title: China's ageing elite live golden years in style
summary: China's rapidly aging population is leading to a growing need for elderly care, prompting the government to develop luxury retirement communities like the Yanyuan community, where residents enjoy catered dining, ballet lessons, and on-site medical care. With one in three people expected to be over 60 by 2050, the industry is expected to boom, with private companies and insurance firms investing in facilities that offer five-star accommodations and professional medical support. However, concerns remain about the affordability and accessibility of these services for China's more destitute senior citizens.

site_title: Indonesia palm prices to rise to US$600 per tonne amid output fall: analyst
summary: Indonesian palm oil prices are forecast to rise to US$600 per tonne due to rising demand and slowing production growth. Global palm oil stocks are expected to drop by 1 and 1.8 million tonnes, while Indonesian production is forecast to slow to 1.5-2 million tonnes in 2019. Malaysian production is set to rise by 0.5 million tonnes to about 20 million tonnes. The forecast is attributed to increased demand from the food and energy sector, as well as falling global stockpiles.

site_title: High in the Alps, igloo hotels offer the epitome of no-frills luxury
summary: In the Swiss Alps, igloo hotels offer luxurious, no-frills accommodations with prices up to $500 per night. Built atop ski areas, these "Igloo Villages" feature ice structures with unique themes, heated saunas, and hot tubs. Guests stay in cozy rooms with ice beds and enjoy meals in an igloo restaurant. The hotels are built and maintained over a few weeks in autumn, with temperatures remaining stable inside despite harsh weather conditions. Located in Switzerland, Austria, and Germany, these unique hotels cater to adventurous travelers seeking an unforgettable experience.

site_title: There's a golden shelter from recession risks with these miners
summary: Mid-sized gold mining companies, such as Kirkland Lake Gold Ltd. and Northern Star Resources Ltd., are seen as a safer haven for investors amid recession fears, outperforming both the gold price and the rest of the mining industry over the past 12 months. These companies have strong management, operational teams, and leverage to the gold price, making them attractive options for diversified portfolios. Analysts forecast the gold price to rise to $1,425 an ounce this year, driven by geopolitical tensions and demand for defensive assets.

site_title: China firms funding coal plants offshore as domestic curbs bite: study
summary: China is funding over a quarter of the world's new coal-fired power plants, mainly in Bangladesh, Vietnam, South Africa, and Pakistan, despite curbing the fuel at home. The Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis found that about a quarter of the proposed capacity would use outdated technology. This is part of China's strategy to slow down domestic coal-fired power growth while exporting excess capacity.

site_title: Hedge fund billionaire Griffin buys US$122m London home
summary: Hedge fund billionaire Ken Griffin has purchased 3 Carlton Gardens in London for approximately $122 million, a 200-year-old home that overlooks St. James's Park and features a gym, pool, and underground extension. The property, which was originally listed for $186 million, is the latest in a series of high-end home purchases in London. Griffin, who has an estimated fortune of $8.8 billion, is the richest person from Illinois to feature on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index, and the purchase is seen as a significant addition to his portfolio of properties in New York and Chicago.

site_title: Hong Kong failing to tackle wildlife smuggling epidemic: study
summary: A study by the Hong Kong Wildlife Trade Working Group found Hong Kong's lax laws and lenient sentences are failing to curb wildlife smuggling. Despite being a major transit hub, the city accounts for a significant portion of global ivory and pangolin seizures. Researchers warn that the actual volume of trafficking may be 5-10 times the reported seizures, with estimated annual losses equivalent to the deaths of 3,000 elephants, 65,000 pangolins, and 51 rhinoceroses. The study calls for stricter laws and penalties to tackle the lucrative trade, which has grown by 1,600% over the past decade.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.1% to 3,216.59
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 3.97 points, or 0.12%, to 3,216.59 at 9am on Tuesday, with losers outnumbering gainers 44 to 37. The most actively traded counters were Rex International, UOB, and M1, which lost 1.25%, 1.1%, and almost 1% respectively.

site_title: BlackRock's data leak strikes 20,000 advisers
summary: A data leak at BlackRock Inc exposed the names, email addresses, and other information of approximately 20,000 advisers who are clients of the asset manager. The leak, which occurred last week, was due to human error, and BlackRock promptly removed the information from its website. The affected advisers are primarily those who work with LPL Financial, the largest US independent broker dealer. BlackRock and LPL are taking steps to investigate and communicate with affected parties, emphasizing that no sensitive personal or financial information was disclosed.

site_title: Strong 6.1-magnitude quake hits off Indonesia
summary: A 6.1-magnitude earthquake struck off Indonesia's coast early Tuesday, but no tsunami warning was issued and there were no immediate reports of damage. The quake occurred at a depth of 31km and was followed by a weaker 5.2-magnitude quake off Sumba island. Indonesia is still recovering from a deadly tsunami in December and previous earthquakes on Lombok and Sulawesi islands, which killed over 4,400 people.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall, dragged down by BHP; NZ slips too
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% on Tuesday, led by a 1.3% decline in BHP Group due to a 9% drop in second-quarter iron ore production and production disruptions. Other blue-chips, including Rio Tinto and Fortescue Metals, also fell. New Zealand's benchmark index dropped 0.2%. The decline was attributed to weak economic data from China and a downgrade of global growth forecasts by the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: US to formally seek extradition of Huawei exec Meng Wanzhou: Globe and Mail
summary: The US has informed Canada it plans to formally request the extradition of Huawei Chief Financial Officer Meng Wanzhou on US sanctions allegations against Iran. The deadline for filing the request is January 30. Huawei has no comment, while the US Justice Department remains unresponsive.

site_title: PetroChina flags US$1.5b writedown while profit doubles
summary: PetroChina reported a net income of 52.8 billion yuan (S$10.58 billion) for 2018, more than doubling from the previous year, despite a non-recurring loss of up to 10 billion yuan. The company attributed the surge to higher crude prices, despite a US$1.5 billion writedown from asset disposal. If not for the writedowns, earnings could have risen as much as 149%. PetroChina's full-year net income would have been 132% higher than the average of 13 estimates based on international standards.

site_title: Japan Princess Mako's boyfriend bids to clear path for wedding
summary: Japan's Princess Mako and her boyfriend Kei Komuro postponed their wedding in 2018 after reports of an unpaid loan, with Komuro's family allegedly owing 4 million yen to a former fiancée of his mother. Komuro has now denied the loan is an issue, stating his mother and he have settled the debt. The royal couple had planned to get married in 2018 but now plans to proceed with the wedding in 2020.

site_title: UK struggles to deliver services as Brexit bites, report says
summary: The UK government is struggling to deliver services and major projects due to Brexit-induced indecision and uncertainty, according to an Institute for Government report. The report found that over half of current Cabinet ministers took on their roles in 2018, leading to disruption and diluted expertise. Staff numbers increased to 404,160 in September, reversing job cuts made by the previous government. The report warns of a growing risk of major projects not being delivered on time and on budget, with fewer than one in five currently rated for successful delivery.

site_title: Steely Serena in 'different space', ready for record Slam win - coach
summary: Serena Williams is emotionally and physically ready to win another Grand Slam, according to her coach Patrick Mouratoglou. Unlike her meltdown at the US Open last year, Williams has regained her composure, beating Simona Halep to reach the quarter-finals at the Australian Open. Mouratoglou attributes Williams' improvement to her physical fitness and ability to adjust to her new life after having a baby. Williams is now set to face Karolina Pliskova for a semi-final spot, where she could potentially win her eighth title in Melbourne and match Steffi Graf's record.

site_title: Tokyo court denies ex-Nissan chief Ghosn's bail request
summary: A Tokyo court denied bail to former Nissan chief Carlos Ghosn, ruling he remains a flight risk due to potential evidence tampering. Despite a personal appeal, Ghosn is likely to remain in Japanese custody until his trial. Since his arrest on November 19, Ghosn's case has captivated Japan and the business world, with his lawyer acknowledging his client will likely remain in jail until the trial.

site_title: Fashion rolls up for Dior's chic strongwoman circus
summary: Italian designer Maria Grazia Chiuri presented a sublimely balanced collection for Christian Dior's Paris haute couture label, incorporating feminism and featuring an all-female acrobatic troupe in a retro big top at the Rodin Museum. Chiuri is the first woman to lead the French label, showcasing her commitment to feminism. The collection marked a significant moment for the brand, highlighting Chiuri's vision and style. The event celebrated the intersection of fashion and circus arts, providing a unique and memorable experience for attendees. Chiuri's feminist approach has been a hallmark of her tenure at Dior.

site_title: Three main points of new Franco-German treaty
summary: French and German leaders will sign a follow-up pact to the 1963 Elysee Treaty, aiming to strengthen their partnership amidst eurosceptic forces and populist-nationalist parties. The 16-page treaty commits both countries to annual government meetings and a joint Defence and Security Council, while also promoting economic cooperation, cross-border ties, and people-to-people exchanges. The pact aims to counter conspiracy theories claiming President Macron is "selling out" French sovereignty, with key elements including harmonizing military equipment exports and boosting cooperation in digital economy and renewable energies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
