images.alt_text: Paintings and statutes are displayed at one of the showrooms inside the Artist Alliance Gallery in Accra on December 11, 2018. - The Artist Alliance Gallery is one of the most known places in Ghana that sells artwork and handicrafts from all kinds of different Ghanaian artists. It's often visited by tourists and it's a reference inside the Ghanaian art scene.

site_title: China vows no leeway for underperformers in war on pollution
summary: China has vowed to punish officials in regions that fail to meet air quality targets this winter, refusing excuses for unfavorable weather or economic pressure. Despite a 9.3% reduction in PM2.5 concentrations last year, the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei area saw a 38% increase in the concentration of hazardous particles, exceeding the 35-microgram standard. This marks a significant setback in China's war on pollution, which aims to reverse four decades of environmental damage.

site_title: Death toll from Mexico fuel explosion rises to 85
summary: A deadly fuel explosion in central Mexico has claimed 85 lives, with another 58 hospitalized, as hundreds of people gathered to collect spilled fuel before it ignited. The explosion occurred in the state of Hidalgo during a crackdown on fuel thefts by the new government. Officials have vowed to hold accountable those responsible, while families of the victims have called for continued searches and forensic analysis. The death toll is expected to rise as many of the victims were burned beyond recognition, and identification efforts are underway.

site_title: Missteps in Mexican pipeline blast trigger new scrutiny of fuel plan
summary: A pipeline blast in Mexico killed at least 85 people, with the government admitting it knew of a leak but did not act quickly enough to close it. The blast occurred at a fuel pipeline in the Tula-Tuxpan pipeline, which was closed in December as part of a crackdown on fuel theft. The leak grew as people gathered to collect free fuel, and the explosion occurred after the pipeline was reopened. Critics say the government should have done more to prevent the gathering of people and acted faster to close the leak. The disaster has raised concerns about the government's strategy to fight fuel theft and has weakened President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador's resolve to crack down on the issue.

site_title: Thai tycoon resigns from Bangkok Dusit, Bangkok Airways after regulator's order
summary: Thai tycoon Prasert Prasarttong-osoth resigned as CEO of Bangkok Dusit Medical Services and Bangkok Airways after the Securities and Exchange Commission of Thailand barred him from holding executive positions due to share manipulation allegations. The regulator fined him and others $21.28 million and ordered them to step down from their positions. Bangkok Airways shares fell over 5% and Bangkok Dusit slid 7% on Monday morning, amid concerns over the tycoon's influence on the companies. The accused will "prove their innocence" in the matter.

site_title: LG to supply gesture-reading system for Mercedes-Benz, sources say
summary: LG Electronics is set to supply a gesture-reading system for Mercedes-Benz, allowing drivers to control car functions with hand gestures. The system, installed in a camera in the car ceiling, can perform tasks such as turning on cruise control and adjusting music volume. LG has a similar system in place for detecting drowsiness and has a deal with Mercedes for a camera system. This marks the latest collaboration between LG and Mercedes, following BMW's use of similar technology in its 7 Series sedans.

site_title: China has ample room for macro policy support - stats bureau chief
summary: China's economy grew at its slowest pace since the global financial crisis in the fourth quarter of 2018, but head of the National Bureau of Statistics Ning Jizhe said the country has ample room for macro policy support. China's economic growth cooled slightly, weighed down by weak investment and faltering consumer confidence, with 2018 growth the weakest in 28 years. Despite the impact of the US-China trade war, Ning expressed confidence in achieving reasonable growth this year. China's economy is expected to continue stabilizing.

site_title: World-beating baht adds to Thai challenges as exports fall
summary: Thailand's exports declined for the second straight month in December, falling 1.72% due to the US-China trade war, as the baht's 5% surge against the US dollar adds to the country's economic challenges. The baht's strength is expected to hurt shipments, and currency experts warn of a potential headwind from the upcoming general election. Despite this, some economists remain optimistic about the overall economic outlook, citing rising private consumption and investment. The Bank of Thailand has already raised interest rates, and a potential rate hike in the fourth quarter is expected.

site_title: Airline meals are stockpiled as Brexit border fears grow
summary: Airline meal stockpiling begins as Brexit border fears grow. Gate Gourmet, a caterer to 20 airlines at 10 UK airports, is stockpiling food and supplies to last about 10 days in case of airport queues due to a no-deal Brexit. The stockpile includes pizza, ice cream, roast duck, and snacks, and is being held at warehouses in Peterborough and London. This move aims to mitigate the impact of potential disruptions on airline operations and passenger services.

site_title: The world cupped: the inside story of the bra
summary: The French lingerie industry is renowned for its high-quality and intricately designed bras, which are engineered to provide ultimate comfort and support. From traditional to modern styles, bras are tested and perfected over a two-year period, with prototypes undergoing up to 40 revisions. The industry has a predominantly female workforce, and men are rarely involved in commercial women's bra design. With a focus on comfort and natural support, the industry has shifted away from push-up bras and towards more minimalist designs, and innovative materials have improved the overall experience for women.

site_title: Asia: Markets post fresh gains, China growth slows to 28-year low
summary: Asian markets posted fresh gains on Monday, driven by optimism over China's plan to eliminate its massive trade surplus with the US, which could ease tensions between the two economic superpowers. China's economic growth slowed to a 28-year low in 2018, but met forecasts. The news supported shares, which were also buoyed by hopes for a resolution to the US-China tariffs spat. Markets are now awaiting concrete evidence of a deal before the March 1st deadline.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei hits over one-month high; shippers, exporters attract buying
summary: The Nikkei share average rose 0.5% to a one-month high of 20,758.74 on Monday, driven by gains in US shares and a weaker yen, which boosted exporters. The rally followed increased hopes that the US and China would resolve their trade dispute.

site_title: Philippines holds referendum for Muslim autonomy in troubled south
summary: Minority Muslims in the southern Philippines cast votes on Monday in a referendum on autonomy, with a clear "yes" vote expected to grant executive, legislative, and fiscal powers to the Bangsamoro region. The plan, negotiated by previous administrations, aims to address poverty, banditry, and extremism in the region. A result is expected by Friday, with Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte urging voters to approve the plan to ensure peace and development. The plan's advocates say it would address the region's low levels of employment and education, while the MILF hopes autonomy would lead to greater investment and development.

site_title: Putin takes hard line on Japan island dispute before Abe's visit
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin is taking a hard line on a 70-year-old dispute over four small islands with Japan, ahead of talks with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. Putin's aide and Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov have vowed not to surrender any territory, while Japan seeks to resolve the issue for improved ties with Russia and to counterbalance rising China. The islands, known as the Northern Territories in Japan and the Southern Kurils in Russia, have been the subject of ongoing negotiations, with Japan seeking to sign a peace treaty in exchange for two islands.

site_title: Australia's solar, wind boom to power past grid woes in 2019
summary: Australia's renewable energy sector is poised to continue its growth in 2019, driven by abundant wind and solar resources, falling costs, and increasing demand for contracts to hedge against rising power tariffs. Despite grid constraints and extra scrutiny from network operators, international developers are investing heavily in wind and solar farms, with 14.7 GW of projects under construction or financial close. The Australian Energy Market Operator and industry groups are working to establish clear guidelines for new projects, aiming to move from an opportunistic approach to a more planned and coordinated integration of intermittent renewable power.

site_title: Above the concrete canopy: Hong Kong from the sky
summary: Hong Kong is a city of contrasts, offering a unique perspective from the sky. Aerial shots showcase densely packed housing blocks, Chinese cemeteries, and lush paddy fields, revealing the city's diversity beyond its finance hub reputation. With over 7 million people, Hong Kong's busy districts, such as Causeway Bay, are juxtaposed with hiking trails and protected parkland, offering a serene escape from the urban bustle. Photographer Dale de la Rey's drone footage captures the city's density and contrast, offering a fresh perspective on this vibrant, yet often overlooked, metropolis.

images.alt_text: A giant container ship sailing under a suspension bridge; Chinese cemeteries as densely packed as the housing blocks their occupants once lived in; lush rows of paddy fields -- aerial shots offer a whole new perspective on Hong Kong.

site_title: Silver is the outcast among precious-metals outcast to start 2019
summary: Silver completed its worst year in three, erasing its 2019 gain, as investors turn off the metal due to its status as both a haven and industrial commodity. Optimism over trade talks boosts equities, reducing demand for silver as a shelter from market turmoil. Silver's industrial component is also weighed down by global growth concerns and a surplus of inventory, with analysts saying investors bought silver on gold rather than solid fundamentals, which will fade quickly once gold retreats.

images.alt_text: Silver just completed its worst year in three. Investors are showing no signs of taking a shine to the metal in 2019, either.

site_title: Singapore finance minister says 2019 Budget to focus on education, healthcare, security and defence
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that the 2019 Budget will focus on education, healthcare, security, and defence, amid growing needs in these areas. The budget aims to address global uncertainties and technological changes, with a focus on transforming the economy and enabling Singaporeans to thrive. Heng emphasized the importance of being "thoughtful of the long-term implications" of economic policies and staying competitive globally.

site_title: Huan Hsin misses exit offer deadline, plans to ask SGX for more time
summary: Huan Hsin Holdings, a Singapore-listed electronics contract manufacturer, missed the deadline to submit a mandatory exit offer, which was set for January 19. The company plans to ask the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for more time to make the proposal, following repeated failures to meet listing requirements for profitability and market value. The SGX had previously declined to give a fourth extension to a March 4, 2016, deadline.

site_title: China should boost banks' active support for economy: central bank official
summary: China's central bank official, Sun Guofeng, recommends that banks actively increase support for the real economy by boosting lending, rather than relying on authorities' orders. This is crucial to improving credit availability, as problems with capital replenishment, bank liquidity gaps, and poor rate transmission hinder credit supply. The People's Bank of China is taking steps to relieve these constraints, including targeted reserve requirement cuts and the issuance of perpetual bonds. The goal is to ensure looser monetary policy is reflected in looser credit conditions, addressing the slowing Chinese economy.

site_title: Australia: Shares edge up ahead of China data; New Zealand gains
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to a two-month high, driven by banks and energy stocks, ahead of China's key economic data. China's fourth-quarter and 2018 GDP figures, along with December factory output and retail sales, are expected to show a slowdown. Financial stocks, including Macquarie Group and Insurance Australia Group, rose 0.4% and 1.3%, respectively. Energy stocks also climbed, driven by oil price surges. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.3%.

site_title: China's 2018 fixed-asset investment up 5.9%, Dec industrial output up 5.7%
summary: China's fixed-asset investment rose 5.9% in 2018, the slowest annual growth since at least 1996. Private-sector investment increased 8.7%, while industrial output grew 5.7% in December, in line with forecasts. Retail sales rose 8.2% in December. China's economic growth has slowed to near 30-year lows due to sluggish investment, softening consumer demand, and US tariffs. Analysts expect Beijing to roll out more support measures, but a sharper slowdown is feared, with activity expected to bottom out until summer.

site_title: AI policy is tricky. From around the world, they came to hash it out.
summary: Renowned computer scientist Hal Abelson led a classroom discussion with senior policymakers from 36 OECD countries on artificial intelligence, emphasizing the technology's strengths and weaknesses. Abelson highlighted that AI "does what it does because it's trained" and that human choices play a crucial role in its decision-making. The discussion aimed to provide policymakers with a sense of AI's capabilities and limitations, ahead of potential policy decisions on the technology.

site_title: UK ministers urged to clarify position on Huawei: report
summary: UK ministers are being urged to clarify their position on China's state-owned telecom giant Huawei, which is facing concerns over spying and security. Despite allies banning Huawei, the UK has not made a decision, with Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright expected to address the issue. The company's annual report has criticized its failure to address shortcomings, and the Dutch government is set to make a decision on restricting Huawei's role in its 5G network this year. The UK government is reviewing telecommunications firms' supply arrangements to ensure secure 5G deployments.

site_title: Pound will rise against all G-10 peers this year, says Goldman
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts the pound will rise against all G-10 peers this year, driven by decreasing Brexit risk and potential for a second EU referendum. Sterling has strengthened for five weeks, with a possible US$1.36 by year-end, making it the third-best performing G-10 currency. Despite uncertainty, Goldman's Zach Pandl sees "a lot of upside risks" to the pound, citing a decline in Brexit risk and a boost to the prospects of a softer Brexit or no Brexit at all.

images.alt_text: The pound may advance against all its Group-of-10 (G-10) peers this year as the risk of a no-deal Brexit has been declining, according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc.

site_title: US-China trade talks falling short on make-or-break IP issues
summary: US-China trade talks have made little progress on intellectual property (IP) issues, a crucial component of any deal. Despite President Trump's claims of progress, talks have been characterized as an airing of grievances rather than constructive negotiations. China denies allegations of IP theft and forced technology transfers, while the US seeks concrete policy changes. Business groups, including the US Chamber of Commerce, emphasize the need for IP protection in any deal, citing concerns over China's state-coordinated campaign to acquire US technologies. The IP stalemate raises questions about Trump's ability to leverage tariffs into meaningful policy changes.

site_title: Japan's LIXIL denies report it considered delisting, move to Singapore
summary: Japan's LIXIL denies a report that it considered delisting from Japan through a management buyout and moving its headquarters to Singapore. The report, which claimed LIXIL's board had considered the plan, was opposed by former president Kinya Seto. LIXIL's chairman and CEO Yoichiro Ushioda confirmed the company has no agreement or consideration for the plan. The stock price rose 7% following the denial.

site_title: British PM turns to Brexit 'Plan B'
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May unveils her "Plan B" for Brexit, aiming to break the political gridlock 10 weeks before the UK's departure from the EU. The plan involves changing her "red lines" on customs union and free movement of citizens, potentially allowing for a deal with Brussels. MPs have rejected her original EU divorce deal, and amendments tabled by lawmakers could delay or frustrate her proposals, with some aiming to delay the withdrawal process or enable backbenchers to debate and vote on Brexit issues.

site_title: Oil dips as China's economy slows. but Opec-led cuts support
summary: Oil prices dipped on Monday as China reported its weakest annual economic growth in 28 years, at 6.6%, but were supported by Opec-led supply cuts. International Brent crude oil futures fell 0.2% to $62.57 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures dropped 0.2% to $53.69 per barrel. Despite the slowdown, analysts expect supply cuts to support crude oil prices, with some predicting prices could rise to $70 per barrel by year-end.

site_title: From Mao to Trump: China's economic roller-coaster since 1949
summary: China's economy has experienced a roller-coaster of growth since 1949, with notable periods of rapid expansion and slower, steadier growth. The country's GDP grew 6.6% in 2018, the slowest rate since 1990. From Mao's communist regime to Deng Xiaoping's market-oriented reforms, China has transitioned from a basket case to a global economic powerhouse. However, the era of double-digit expansion has ended, and the country now faces challenges such as high domestic debt and US trade hawkishness, which may limit its ability to grow in the future.

site_title: Nissan, Renault not ready to discuss new capital ties: Nissan CEO
summary: Nissan CEO Hiroto Saikawa stated that the Japanese carmaker is not ready to discuss revising its capital ties with Renault, following a reported French proposal for integration under a single holding company. The proposal, allegedly made by the French government, has been met with skepticism due to cultural differences and Renault's lower productivity. Nissan's ousted chairman Carlos Ghosn remains in detention, and a decision on his bail is expected. Renault is expected to meet soon to consider potential candidates to replace Ghosn as CEO and chairman.

site_title: Trump-Kim February summit expected to take place in Vietnam
summary: US President Donald Trump is planning to meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Vietnam in late February, following a 90-minute meeting between the two in late January. The summit, expected to take place in Hanoi, aims to discuss progress on denuclearization and sanctions relief. Despite a lack of clear agreements, Trump expressed optimism, tweeting that he looked forward to meeting with Kim. However, the US still seeks North Korea's commitment to dismantle its nuclear arsenal, a goal that remains elusive.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks build on gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Monday, building on gains from the previous day, as investors remain optimistic about a breakthrough in China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.16% to 27,134.27, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.12% to 2,599.06. The rally follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a fresh record close for the US S&P 500. Despite US President Trump's new threats, traders continue to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Oil gloom turns to boom as the market's worst fears fade away
summary: Investors' optimism in the oil market has increased as fears of a global economic slowdown dissipate. Hedge funds boosted their bets on rising Brent crude prices by 9% after China proposed a ramp-up in US oil imports and the US Federal Reserve signaled no rush to raise interest rates. Oil prices have rebounded, with Brent closing at its highest in eight weeks, and US crude prices rising 18% in the first 13 trading days of the year.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed on Monday for public holiday
summary: Malaysia's financial markets closed on Monday for a public holiday, resuming trading on Tuesday. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.4% on Thursday. In other news, eSIM platform Airalo raised US$220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion, and US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singaporeans' inflation expectations stand pat at end-2018: poll
summary: Singaporeans' inflation expectations remained unchanged at 2.9% for the next 12 months, according to a poll conducted by DBS and Singapore Management University. Core inflation expectations rose to 2.99% from 2.92% in September. Despite expectations of higher cost increases outside of housing and private transport, overall inflation expectations were stable at 2% in 2018, indicating a "fairly anchored" sentiment. This suggests policymakers' efforts to manage the economy may be effective, particularly with the recent adjustment of monetary policy in October 2018.

images.alt_text: Singaporeans don't expect overall consumer costs to budge much in the next 12 months, but think that core inflation - that is, price hikes outside of housing and private transport - could still inch up.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.3% to 3,233.51
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, advancing 0.3% to 3,233.51 on the Straits Times Index. Gainers outnumbered losers 75 to 20, with active stocks including Keppel Corp and Genting Singapore. The market followed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and amid US-EU trade talks.

site_title: China's bankers face smaller bonuses, fewer job opportunities
summary: China's bankers face reduced bonuses and fewer job opportunities due to a slowing economy, tightening credit, and plunging stocks. The nation's securities industry saw its first annual headcount cut since 2014, with many firms failing to secure stock mandates and some not paying bonuses for 2018. The industry's growth has slowed, with the Shanghai Composite Index delivering the worst performance of any major global benchmark, and initial public offerings expected to decline 10% in 2019.

site_title: China's economy slows in Q4 to weakest pace since 2009 amid trade war
summary: China's economy slowed in Q4 to 6.4% growth, the weakest pace since 2009 amid trade war and debt cleanup. Despite a slowdown, some signs of resilience emerged, including accelerated consumption and factory output in December. The government's control over the process is being tested by US President Trump's trade standoff, which is also affecting the global expansion. Authorities have implemented targeted stimulus measures, and economists predict further easing if the slowdown deepens.

images.alt_text: China's economy expanded at the slowest pace since the global financial crisis, as a domestic financial clean-up, weakening global demand and trade conflict with the US all dampened momentum.

site_title: Ascott's lodging portfolio crosses 100,000 units globally with bumper signing of deals
summary: CapitaLand's serviced residence arm, The Ascott, has secured 26 contracts for over 4,600 units across 11 countries, boosting its portfolio to over 100,000 units. Half of the new properties will be established in China from 2019 to 2023, with one slated to open in Singapore this year. Ascott's CEO, Kevin Goh, attributes the growth to strategic investments and partnerships, aiming to reach 160,000 units worldwide by 2023.

images.alt_text: Somerset Yongningmen Xian. Of these properties, half will be established in China from 2019 to 2023, and one is slated to open in Singapore this year.

site_title: MMP Resources engages bank as adviser to raise US$30m
summary: MMP Resources has engaged a Singaporean bank as its financing and capital markets adviser to raise approximately US$30 million. The bank's role will provide assistance on potential transactions, including fundraising activities, but no binding agreements have been entered into. This comes after the company's acquisition of a 50% stake in a Russian gas field for S$25 million in December last year. Shares in MMP Resources remain on the Singapore Exchange's watch list due to its financial and minimum trading price criteria.

site_title: US demands regular review of China trade reform
summary: The US is pushing for regular reviews of China's progress on pledged trade reforms as a condition for a trade deal, threatening tariffs if Beijing fails to meet the agreement. The proposal for periodic assessments is part of a US negotiating document, and Chinese negotiators have expressed concerns about the idea. The US demands changes to China's policies on intellectual property protection, technology transfers, and industrial subsidies, and regular reviews would be used to enforce compliance. The threat of tariffs remains a point of contention, with a Chinese source describing the idea as "humiliation."

site_title: China drone giant DJI unearths US$150m losses from fraud
summary: DJI, China's largest drone maker, has discovered cases of fraud involving its employees, potentially resulting in losses of around $200.2 million. The company has fired multiple workers who inflated parts costs for personal gain and is investigating an "extensive" situation. DJI, which employs 14,000 people globally, is the market leader in consumer drones. The incident exposes a lapse in internal controls at one of China's prominent technology giants, highlighting a risk of corruption among fast-growing corporations in the country.

site_title: The future is now for LNG as derivatives trading takes off
summary: Liquefied natural gas (LNG) derivatives trading has seen significant growth, with volumes increasing from 2% of global LNG production in 2017 to almost 23% by the end of last year. This growth is attributed to a burgeoning Intercontinental Exchange Inc contract based on the Japan-Korea Marker (JKM) spot price assessments. The accelerating growth in LNG derivatives illustrates the market's maturation, driven by an explosion in supply from the US to Australia, which is attracting more market participants and shifting away from traditional pricing. This marks a notable development in the LNG market.

site_title: China's slowdown looms just as the world looks for growth
summary: China's economy, a major driver of global growth, is cooling, with data showing softer investment, unprofitable factories, and consumers' reduced spending. The US economy is also showing signs of a slowdown, and Europe's resurgence is beginning to slow. China's slowdown is affecting global businesses, with European investment in China decreasing due to complicated business conditions and lack of transparency. Chinese officials are considering stimulus packages to boost growth, but the country's high debt levels and trade frictions with the West pose challenges.

site_title: UK house prices make weakest start to year since 2012
summary: UK house prices experienced their weakest start to the year since 2012 due to ongoing Brexit worries, according to Rightmove. Asking prices rose 0.4% in the first two weeks of January compared to the same period last year, and 0.4% higher than December levels. Despite this, potential buyers are tuning out the political noise, with a 5% increase in property views on Rightmove's website in the first half of January compared to 2018. Experts attribute this to fundamental market trends continuing to drive demand despite Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Tokyo stocks open higher on optimism over US-China trade talks
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, extending global rallies, as optimism grew over a potential breakthrough in US-China trade talks. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.86% and the Topix index rose 0.91%. Investors await China's economic indicators and the IMF's growth forecasts for further impact. Key movers included Panasonic and Toyota, which rose after reports of a joint venture to manufacture electric vehicle batteries, and Nissan, which rose amid reports of potential merger talks between Renault and Nissan.

site_title: Japan manufacturers' mood slips to 2-year low
summary: Japan's manufacturers report a 2-year low in confidence, with a sentiment index of 18 in January, down five points from the previous month. Exporters cite weak demand in China and the US due to the trade war, while service sector confidence remains steady at 31. Despite this, companies expect conditions to worsen in the coming months, reflecting global economic concerns and trade tensions.

site_title: Erdogan: Turkey is ready to take over Syria's Manbij
summary: Turkey's President Tayyip Erdogan told US President Donald Trump that Turkey is ready to take over security in Syria's Manbij, following a suicide bombing that killed four US citizens. The bombing was seen as a provocative act aimed at affecting Trump's decision to withdraw US troops from Syria. Erdogan offered to take over security in Manbij, which is controlled by US-backed Syrian Democratic Forces, in exchange for a negotiated settlement for northeastern Syria that meets both nations' security needs. The two leaders agreed to continue pursuing a negotiated solution and accelerate discussions on a safe zone in the region.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Centrepoint Trust, MMP Resources, Rich Capital, FSL Trust
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's CEO Chew Tuan Chiong will step down by year-end, with a successor to be announced in due course. MMP Resources has engaged a Singapore banking institution to raise US$30 million. No other significant developments were reported for Rich Capital, FSL Trust, or the other listed stocks.

site_title: Henry Sy, the Philippines' richest man and a shopping mall tycoon, dies at 94
summary: Henry Sy, the Philippines' richest man and a shopping mall tycoon, died at 94. He was the "father of modern Philippine retail" and founder of SM Investments Corp, which operates a chain of super malls. Sy's company had revenues of $6.7 billion in 2016 and was named the Philippines' richest person by Forbes for the past 11 years, with a net worth of $19 billion. Sy rose from a small shop selling surplus boots to a retail empire, and his company also operates in China. He was a philanthropist and chairman emeritus of SM Investments at the time of his death.

site_title: UK launches app for EU citizens to stay after Brexit
summary: The British government has launched a phone app allowing EU nationals to apply for "settled status" to stay in the UK after Brexit. The app, which will be available until late 2020 or 2021, aims to ease concerns among the 3.5 million Europeans currently living in Britain. The scheme will become fully operational on March 30, the day after Britain leaves the European Union, allowing those to continue working and claiming benefits. The app is a test stage for the settlement process, which will be used to determine eligibility for "settled status."

site_title: World's 26 richest own same as poorest half of humanity: Oxfam
summary: Oxfam reports that the world's 26 richest people hold the same wealth as the poorest half of humanity, exacerbating global inequality. Billionaires saw their combined fortunes grow by $2.5 billion daily in 2018, while the poorest saw their wealth decline by 11% last year. Oxfam urges governments to hike taxes on the wealthy to combat poverty and inequality, citing that under-taxing the rich undermines public services and fuels public anger. The charity suggests raising taxes on the wealthy could fund education and healthcare for millions.

site_title: Ghosn vows to stay in Japan if granted bail
summary: Carlos Ghosn, the ousted former Nissan boss, has vowed to remain in Japan if granted bail. He has been detained for 64 days on charges of financial misconduct and has filed a petition for bail. The Tokyo District Court will consider his application, but has previously rejected his bids, citing him as a flight risk. Ghosn maintains his innocence and is eager to defend himself in court. A trial could take six months, and his lead lawyer believes bail is unlikely until then.

site_title: US shutdown shows weakness of the resistance
summary: The US government shutdown, now in its third week, has exposed the weakness of the progressive resistance movement. Despite their efforts to block Republican policies, the shutdown has had little impact on the government's actions. 800,000 federal workers remain unpaid, with some struggling to pay rent or buy medications. The shutdown has impaired major government functions, such as airline security and food safety. The author believes a stronger resistance movement could have made a significant difference, with many Americans shocked by the lack of widespread protests.

site_title: Diversity at work is better for business: top UK lawyer
summary: Pinsent Masons, a UK law firm, has been named the country's most LGBT-friendly workplace by Stonewall, a leading LGBT+ rights charity. The firm introduced inclusive policies and practices for lesbian, gay, and bi staff, and has launched specific trans-inclusive staff training. This move aims to promote progress and diversity in the business world, where 6% of the British population identifies as LGBT+. The firm's senior partner, Richard Foley, believes that increasing diversity is a moral and business obligation, and that it can help corporations re-earn the trust of a sceptical public.

site_title: Trump and Pelosi again butt heads but others see possible paths
summary: US President Donald Trump and Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi continued to clash over the government shutdown, with Trump offering a temporary protection extension for about a million immigrants in exchange for $5.7 billion for the border wall. Pelosi dismissed the offer as a "non-starter," but Vice-President Mike Pence said it represented a "good-faith compromise" that could lead to a deal. The Senate is set to vote on the proposal as early as Tuesday, and both sides appear to be cautiously exploring a road ahead, with some Democrats open to negotiations if Trump stops demonizing the party.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump lashed out on Twitter a day after Ms Pelosi, speaker of the House of Representatives, dismissed as a "non-starter" his offer to extend temporary protection to about a million immigrants in return for US$5.7 billion for the wall he wants on the Mexican border.

site_title: All that Jazz about his name
summary: Thai golfer Jazz Janewattananond won the US$1 million SMBC Singapore Open with a record-breaking 18-under 266 total, two strokes ahead of England's Paul Casey and Japan's Yoshinori Fujimoto. The 23-year-old Thai achieved his greatest triumph in a nine-year pro career, overcoming pressure from the high-calibre chasing pack to seal victory with an easy birdie putt on the 18th hole. Janewattananond credited a new putting style and coach Pete Cowen for his win.

site_title: Gears of WTO could soon halt amid US concerns, Canada warns
summary: Canada's trade minister, Jim Carr, warns that the World Trade Organization (WTO) may stall due to US delays in appointing new judges, potentially halting the dispute settlement system. Carr is convening reform talks in Davos, where China and the US will be absent. Canada is seeking the release of detained Canadians and a more lenient sentence for a Chinese man sentenced to death. The minister emphasizes the need for China and the US to be involved in WTO reforms, citing the importance of trade between the two nations.

images.alt_text: Jim Carr, in an interview with Bloomberg's Kathleen Hays in Tokyo, said the US refusal to appoint judges to the appellate body of the 164-nation WTO means that in "the next number of months" the WTO's dispute settlement system will effectively stall.

site_title: UOB clients cook up a storm for charity
summary: UOB clients participated in a Chinese New Year cook-off to raise funds for charity, with over 40 clients cooking their personal specialties based on the theme "Family". The event raised close to S$250,000 for various beneficiaries, including underprivileged families, schools, and arts programs. The dishes selected by a judging panel will be featured at a special reunion dinner on Jan 25. The funds will support the Central Community Development Council, The Red Pencil Singapore, and other organizations.

site_title: United passengers shiver through 16-hour ordeal on Canadian tarmac
summary: United Airlines Flight 179 was stranded on the tarmac of Goose Bay airport in Newfoundland and Labrador for 16 hours due to a medical emergency and mechanical issues. The plane, carrying 250 passengers, was forced to make an emergency landing in freezing temperatures of -30°C, causing a door to freeze. Passengers endured thin blankets and limited supplies, with food and water running out after 10 hours. A relief aircraft eventually arrived, and the passengers were transferred to it before taking off to return to Newark, New Jersey. The ordeal was marred by bitter cold and poor conditions.

site_title: Run-down buildings are hot property in land-scarce Hong Kong
summary: In land-scarce Hong Kong, rundown buildings are becoming attractive properties for developers. The number of applications for compulsory sales to acquire apartment blocks reached a six-year high in 2018, as large plots sold at government tenders fetched record-breaking prices. Developers are revamping old buildings to sustain their pipelines and gain a foothold in prime areas, taking advantage of the high land prices. This trend is driven by the limited availability of land and the lucrative prices for government tenders, forcing developers to focus on breathing new life into old buildings.

site_title: CEO of Frasers Centrepoint Trust manager Chew Tuan Chiong to retire in 2019
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's CEO Chew Tuan Chiong, 61, plans to retire by year-end, reaching the national minimum retirement age of 62 in 2019. Chew has led the trust since 2010, growing its assets from S$1.52 billion to S$2.84 billion and increasing distribution per unit from 8.2 to 12.015 Singapore cents. A successor will be announced after an effective succession programme.

site_title: Hey Amazon, UK retailers cheap but not for the faint-hearted
summary: Amazon is exploring potential acquisitions of UK retailers to bolster its presence in the market. The company has been eyeing Asos, Tesco, Sainsbury, Marks & Spencer, and Home Depot, among others, due to their strong brands and market share. However, regulatory concerns and the current market slump may pose challenges to these potential deals. If the UK's exit from the EU is successful, it could lead to a boost in consumer sentiment and valuations, making these acquisitions more attractive to Amazon.

site_title: Negotiations on government shutdown, US-China trade likely to move market
summary: US stocks may pause their rally this week due to mixed earnings and the ongoing partial government shutdown. The Dow Jones Industrial Average has risen 12% since December 26, but strategists warn of consolidation. The shutdown, the longest ever, has shaved about 1/10th of a percentage point off economic growth every week. US-China trade negotiations may move the market, with reports suggesting compromise and potential imports of US agricultural products resuming. The outcome of negotiations will determine whether the January rally continues.

site_title: American yogurt: the race to find the next blockbuster
summary: There is fierce competition in the US yogurt market, with various flavors and types vying for attention. Greek yogurt remains the top-selling yogurt, but new trends and flavors are emerging, including cotton candy, creme brulee, and coconut milk-based yogurts. The market offers a wide range of options, from low-fat to high-protein and different styles from around the world. As the market continues to evolve, yogurts are shifting towards unique flavors and ingredients to stand out and capture the latest trend.

site_title: Corporate debt mountain: A possible avalanche risk?
summary: US and European companies hold nearly $15 trillion and $18.5 trillion in debt, respectively, at the end of 2018. As interest rates rise, concerns grow about their ability to repay debts. Experts point to the ratio of net revenue to debt payments, which is 9:1 in the US and 12:1 in Europe, as a more accurate indicator of their debt burden. The risk of "fallen angels" - companies downgraded to speculative debt ratings - also looms, potentially spooking investors and causing a market downturn.

site_title: Amazon knows what you buy, and it's building a big ad business from it
summary: Amazon's advertising business is expanding, leveraging its vast database of consumer buying habits to target ads effectively. The company's ad platform can now be considered a third major pillar of its business, worth around $125 billion, surpassing industry leaders Google and Facebook. Amazon's ad capabilities include targeting users based on their interests, searches, and demographics, as well as shopping behavior, such as "International Market Grocery Shopper" or "Presence of children aged 4-6". The company's self-service option allows ad agencies and brands to access its data, enabling precise targeting and high conversion rates, with one example showing a 20% conversion rate for a crunchy dried cheese bar ad campaign.

site_title: NY's latest 'supertall' skyscraper risks running into wall of resistance
summary: New York City developer Harry Macklowe plans to build a 1,551-foot-tall skyscraper, Tower Fifth, east of Fifth Avenue between 51st and 52nd streets. If approved, it would be the second-tallest building in the Western Hemisphere, surpassing One World Trade Center. The project would require special permits, zoning changes, and approvals due to its proximity to five landmark buildings. Critics argue that the tower's construction would have a negative social and environmental impact, while proponents see it as a potential source of affordable housing and economic growth.

site_title: UK's May considering amending Good Friday deal to break Brexit impasse
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May is considering amending the 1998 Good Friday Agreement to break a Brexit deadlock. The plan would see the UK and Ireland agree on separate principles or add text to the agreement to guarantee an open border after Brexit. The move comes after May's deal was rejected by parliament, with many objecting to the backstop arrangement. Senior EU sources have deemed the plan a non-starter, while British government sources are skeptical about its effectiveness, citing potential controversy and the need for party consent in Northern Ireland.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Theresa May is considering solving a Brexit deadlock by amending a 1998 agreement that ended 30 years of violence in Northern Ireland after ditching attempts to negotiate a cross-party deal, the Daily Telegraph reported late on Sunday.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: Fish prices in Singapore on the rise
summary: Fish prices in Singapore are on the rise, according to a Money FM podcast. The podcast, "The Hot Seat," discussed the increasing cost of fish in Singapore, with no specific date or cause mentioned.

site_title: Food delivery pioneer foodpanda says it's no endangered species
summary: Foodpanda, a Singapore-based food delivery app, remains a key player in the market despite growing competition from regional and international players. The company attributes its success to factors such as service quality, ordering frequency, and restaurant partners. Revenue doubled from S$20.8 million in 2016 to S$42.2 million in 2017. Foodpanda's managing director, Luc Andreani, believes that focusing on these key areas will set the company apart from competitors. The company is also exploring subscription-based services and loyalty programs to enhance customer experience.

site_title: McConnell to pair bills to reopen government with Trump's immigration plan
summary: Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell plans to pair government funding bills with President Donald Trump's proposal for temporary immigration protections in exchange for $5.7 billion for the border wall. This move aims to pressure Democrats into negotiations, but Democrats have denied abandoning their stance on requiring a fully open government before discussing border security. McConnell's package includes funding for government agencies and disaster relief, but faces opposition from conservative critics and a public largely blaming Trump for the shutdown.

site_title: Sorrell's S4 Capital seeks more deals in digital-only drive
summary: Martin Sorrell's S4 Capital is seeking more deals to expand its digital-only advertising venture, capitalizing on industry disruption. The company has already clinched two deals, including Media Monks for €300 million and MightyHive for $150 million. Sorrell aims to build on core competences in content and programmatic advertising, offering digital content, analytics, and distribution to clients. He plans to expand S4's geographical coverage and is interested in buying first-party data assets, reflecting the rise of Google and Facebook in online advertising.

site_title: In Jerusalem's Old City, conflict means buyer and seller beware
summary: In Jerusalem's Old City, a 55-year-old Palestinian man, Adeeb Joudeh al-Husseini, is facing accusations of treason for selling a building to Israeli settlers in 2016. Joudeh claims he sold the property to another Palestinian and cannot be held responsible, but the sale has fueled Palestinian fears of losing ground in the historic area. The conflict highlights the ongoing land dispute between Palestinians and Israelis over Jerusalem and its Old City, with some 320,000 Palestinians and 210,000 Israeli settlers living in the area.

site_title: Digital playscape by young artists opens at National Museum
summary: A digital playscape titled PlayTech+ has opened at the National Museum in Singapore, showcasing the work of young artists aged 12-14 from The Little Arts Academy (LAA). The playscape features three art installations using augmented reality, projection mapping, and digital illustrations, created in under two months by the teens. The exhibit is supported by HSBC, which donated S$120,000 for Tech+Arts programmes at LAA, promoting digital literacy and arts education for underprivileged children. The exhibit runs until February 7.

site_title: What's with the rage towards robots? It's about who's in and out
summary: People are lashing out at robots, particularly those resembling humans, in a global phenomenon. The reasons behind this behavior are complex, but it may stem from fear of job loss, societal upend, and a desire to maintain control. The term "robot" has its roots in Czech playwright Karel Capek's use of the word to describe automatons, evoking feudal fears of peasant revolt. Researchers suggest that human antagonism towards robots resembles tribal psychology and dehumanization, which can be alleviated by giving robots names and treating them as in-group members.

site_title: German govt panel recommends 130-kmh cap on autobahn
summary: A German government panel recommends capping speeds on the country's famous autobahn motorways at 130 km/h, a move that could end Germany's limit-free driving policy. The proposal aims to reduce emissions and meet the country's Paris Climate accord targets. The plan also includes increasing taxes on petrol and diesel and promoting electric and hybrid vehicles. The decision is seen as a necessary step to address growing environmental concerns and is backed by environmentalists and the Green Party.

site_title: Do not hijack Brexit, minister warns Britain's Parliament
summary: UK Trade Minister Liam Fox warns Parliament against hijacking Brexit, urging lawmakers to respect the result of the 2016 referendum. Prime Minister Theresa May will return to Parliament on Monday to outline her plan to break the Brexit deadlock after her deal was rejected last week. With just weeks to go before Britain's departure from the EU, lawmakers are divided over competing visions, including a second referendum and staying in the EU. Fox says May's divorce agreement with the EU remains the best basis for a deal.

site_title: Chips are down for online gambling as US moves towards new ban
summary: The US Justice Department has announced a new policy banning all forms of online gambling, citing a 1961 law that bars the use of telecommunications for gambling. The move reverses a 2011 decision that allowed online poker, casino, and lottery offerings in several states. The new policy could shut down online wagering, including fantasy sports leagues, and lead to a significant impact on the industry. Prosecutions could begin within 90 days, but experts predict little enforcement due to the potential for legal challenges.

images.alt_text: The Justice Department stopped short of indicating how far it would go in enforcement; while there is no comprehensive breakdown of US online gambling revenues, total wagers were up nearly 22 per cent to US$298 million last year in New Jersey, which has the largest Internet segment.

site_title: India fires 2 PNB execs for lapses in US$2b fraud case
summary: India has fired two senior executives of Punjab National Bank (PNB) for allegedly failing to prevent a $2 billion US fraud. The executives, K Veera Brahmaji Rao and Sanjiv Sharan, were removed from their positions for breaching central bank guidelines and failing to use the global payments network SWIFT to detect the fraud. The move comes nearly a year after the bank's largest scam was discovered, involving billionaire diamond jeweller Nirav Modi and his uncle Mehul Choksi. The government's action is seen as a response to the bank's significant losses since the fraud was uncovered.

images.alt_text: In a stock exchange filing late on Friday, Punjab National Bank - the country's second-biggest state bank - said the government had removed K Veera Brahmaji Rao and Sanjiv Sharan "from the office of executive director" with immediate effect.

site_title: StanChart, Minds team up once again
summary: Standard Chartered Bank and the Movement for the Intellectually Disabled of Singapore (Minds) teamed up to pack over 6,000 fortune bags for the elderly and families in need over Chinese New Year. This is the sixth year of the initiative, which has seen significant growth, with 900 volunteers participating. The bags contain food items and Chinese New Year goodies. The partnership, which began in 2002, has helped both organizations and employee volunteers, with Standard Chartered CEO Patrick Lee stating that giving is important and helps unlock the collective impact.

images.alt_text: Volunteers from Standard Chartered packing fortune bags, which contain food items such as instant noodles and biscuits, and Chinese New Year goodies. This year, a group from the Movement for the Intellectually Disabled of Singapore (Minds) joined them in their packing.

site_title: How Opec helped transform US into net exporter of oil
summary: The US Energy Information Administration (EIA) forecasts that from the fourth quarter of 2020, the US will export more oil than it imports, becoming a net exporter of oil. This transformation is attributed to the extraction of crude from shale rocks, which has led to a significant increase in US oil production. Opec's output cuts and price stabilization have contributed to the growth of the US shale industry, enabling it to become a major oil producer. However, the US will still be a net importer of crude to feed its refining industry, and its exports will compete with Opec's sales, potentially forcing them to extend their output restraint.

site_title: Tokyo's top stock surges 305% in 2018, but CFO says it's still cheap
summary: Tokyo-based data analysis company BrainPad Inc. posted a 305% gain in 2018, becoming the best-performing stock in the Topix index. Its CFO, Ko Ishikawa, attributes the surge to the company's strengthening profit and ability to make money. Despite a high valuation of 86 times estimated earnings, Ishikawa believes BrainPad is still undervalued compared to peers. The company's use of artificial intelligence to analyze consumer trends is seen as a key growth driver, with more companies expected to follow suit.

site_title: ABB planning more deals to expand in robotics: CEO
summary: ABB CEO Ulrich Spiesshofer plans to acquire more companies in robotics and industrial automation, despite selling its power grid unit to Hitachi Ltd. The sale, which was supported by activist investor Cevian Capital AB, will take time due to carve-out requirements. ABB will focus on simplifying its organizational structure and bolstering its electrification arm in Latin America, South-east Asia, and sub-Saharan Africa. The company has "fundamentally robust cash flow," allowing it to fund future acquisitions, and CEO Spiesshofer has expressed his desire to continue leading the company in the long term.

site_title: Treasuries' shifting buyer base may be bond market's vulnerable point
summary: The US government's reliance on private sector buyers in its bond market may be a vulnerable point, as the nation's debt sales surpass $1 trillion annually. Foreign purchases of US Treasuries have stagnated, while domestic bids have risen, driven by growth in exchange-traded funds and other passive-investment products. This shift could lead to higher interest rates on the nation's debt, already near a nine-year high, if price-sensitive buyers start seeking better rates.

site_title: 2019's first home launches sell over 30% of units
summary: In Singapore's condominium market, the first home launches of 2019 saw over 30% of units sold, with three projects - RV Altitude, Fyve Derbyshire, and Fourth Avenue Residences - selling a significant portion of their released units. Analysts attribute the cautious sales to investors, citing ongoing demand despite cooling measures. The projects' attractive pricing and strong location attributes are seen as key factors in their success, with developers expecting a healthy take-up in the coming months.

site_title: Trump, North Korea's Kim to hold second summit in late February
summary: US President Donald Trump will hold a second summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in late February, despite maintaining economic sanctions on Pyongyang. The White House announced the agreement after Trump met with Pyongyang's top nuclear negotiator, Kim Yong Chol. The summit will focus on denuclearization efforts, which have stalled since their first meeting in Singapore in June. The US will continue to apply pressure and sanctions, while North Korea seeks tangible benefits from the diplomatic efforts.

site_title: China set to post slowest growth in 28 years in 2018; more support measures from Beijing likely
summary: China is expected to report its slowest economic growth in 28 years in 2018, with a 6.4% quarterly growth rate in the October-December period. This slowdown is attributed to weakening domestic demand and US tariffs, prompting Beijing to consider additional support measures. Analysts predict further economic contraction, with some speculating real growth levels are weaker than official data suggests. Policymakers aim to prevent deflation, recession, and a hard landing, with a focus on preventing massive job losses.

images.alt_text: China is expected to report on Monday that economic growth cooled to its slowest in 28 years in 2018 amid weakening domestic demand and bruising US tariffs, adding pressure on Beijing to roll out more support measures to avert a sharper slowdown.

site_title: Abracadabra! German executives turn to magic to up their game
summary: German executives are using magic tricks as a team-building activity, with one executive, Harold Voit, demonstrating a billfold that can withstand fire. Meanwhile, other global news includes Malaysia's plan to seize Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's GDP growth expected to slow, and Citigroup setting a mid-2026 target for the MSCI global equity index. In other regions, Thailand's PM is hopeful her daughter's suspension will be cleared, ASEAN agrees Myanmar's election is not a priority, and the UK economy shrinks for the second month.

site_title: Singapore Airlines' digitalisation plans make room for the little things
summary: Singapore Airlines is implementing a multi-million-dollar digitalization plan to boost operational efficiency and customer satisfaction. The carrier has identified three key areas for change: revamping culture, building internal capabilities, and strengthening technical infrastructure. To achieve this, SIA is providing training for ground staff on data analytics, design thinking, and agile capabilities, as well as funding and support for staff ideas. The company is also engaging with startups and external research institutions to drive innovation, with partnerships with IBM, A*Star, and the National University of Singapore.

site_title: Vietnam makes pitch as an investor safe haven in trade war
summary: Vietnam is positioning itself as a safe haven for investors amid the US-China trade war, touting its business-friendly policies, low labor costs, and proximity to China. The country aims to increase exports and become an export-driven economy, with a growth forecast of 6.6-6.8% in 2019. Despite facing challenges such as inadequate infrastructure and a lack of skilled workers, Vietnam is confident in its growth momentum and has completed 16 free trade agreements. Vietnamese Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc is meeting with global executives at the World Economic Forum in Davos to attract investors and step up imports from the US.

site_title: 'No injuries of concern' for Prince Philip, 97, after car crash
summary: Prince Philip, 97, visited a hospital for a precautionary check-up after a car crash the previous day, where he was found to have "no injuries of concern." The crash occurred near the Queen's Sandringham Estate in England, and a Kia hatchback was also involved. A 9-month-old baby was uninjured, while one woman had minor injuries. The investigation into the accident is ongoing, with no speculation on the causes of the collision allowed.

site_title: The 'travelling bandit', a bank robber who gets around
summary: The FBI is seeking the capture of the "Travelling Bandit", a bank robber who has robbed at least seven banks in six states in less than a month, covering over 5,150 km. The suspect, a man aged 40-50, uses wigs and facial hair disguises, and is described as approaching the counter, presenting a note, and leaving on foot. Authorities believe he may be driving a white Ford Explorer or Expedition. Despite the extensive use of surveillance cameras, the FBI attributes the suspect's elusion to the lack of priority given to bank robberies by the bureau since 1980.

site_title: Tech firm WWT looks to Asia-Pacific for expansion
summary: US-based tech firm World Wide Technology (WWT) is expanding its presence in the Asia-Pacific region, with a focus on Singapore. The company aims to increase its digital hires in Singapore by at least 50% in 2019. WWT's Asian Integration Centre in Singapore provides a data centre-like capability to build and integrate tech solutions for clients, including major companies like Cisco and Dell EMC. The company is also looking to replicate its success in Europe and the US by collaborating with companies in the region and investing in emerging technologies such as multi-cloud, blockchain, and artificial intelligence.

site_title: Brexit bullion: Fear of no-deal triggers Irish gold rush
summary: Investors in Northern Ireland are rushing to buy gold bullion as the UK edges closer to a no-deal Brexit, triggering a "gold rush" in Ireland. Over 70% of Merrion Vaults' clients are from Northern Ireland, with many taking physical gold out of banks to hedge against a potential devaluation of sterling. The vault, which stores 3,000 double-locked deposit boxes, has seen a 70% rise in clients and £500,000 in gold sales in the past year, with gold prices increasing by 10% in the past six months.

site_title: Taiwan's traditional medicine stores struggle on life support
summary: Taiwan's traditional medicine stores are struggling to stay afloat due to a licensing shortage. Authorities have not issued new licenses since 1998, and existing licenses cannot be passed down to younger generations, leading to a decline in the industry. As a result, over 200 stores close annually, despite traditional medicine remaining popular in Taiwan. The Health and Welfare Ministry is seeking a solution, but a change to the law may come too late for some family-owned shops, like Gu Cheng-pu's, which rely on the current system to survive.

site_title: Rich Capital sees its 6th director's resignation in a year
summary: Rich Capital Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, has seen its sixth director's resignation in a year, with independent non-executive director Chow Wen Kwan leaving due to focusing on other commitments. This is the latest in a series of director resignations, including three executive directors who quit. The company has recently announced plans to expand into the construction business with a proposed acquisition of two companies.

site_title: Rich Capital board says S$44m interested person transaction is not 'very substantial acquisition'
summary: Rich Capital Holdings, a Singapore-listed construction company, has announced plans to acquire two construction companies, Rich-Link Construction and Rich-Link Builders, for S$43.98 million. The deal, which would see the company issue almost S$35.2 million worth of new shares, was initially deemed a "very substantial acquisition" but the board has now classified it as a major transaction. The acquisition requires shareholder approval at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: #10YearChallenge: harmless trend or boon to facial recognition tech?
summary: The #10YearChallenge, a social media trend where users post side-by-side photos from 10 years ago, has raised concerns about its potential impact on facial recognition technology. A tweet by author Kate O'Neill highlighted the possibility of the photos being used to train algorithms for age progression and recognition, sparking worries about data mining and mass surveillance. Experts warn that the large trove of biometric data collected by Facebook could be used for unintended purposes, while supporters argue that facial recognition technologies can be useful for catching criminals.

site_title: Richard Mille tries to go feminine without alienating men
summary: Richard Mille, a Swiss watchmaker known for its high-end timepieces, is attempting to expand its female customer base without alienating its traditionally male-dominated market. The brand showcased a "Bonbon" collection at the Geneva watch salon, featuring colorful and playful designs, including marshmallow, licorice, and lollipop-themed watches. This move aims to redefine the brand's image and appeal to a broader audience, including women.

images.alt_text: A variety of candy colours from the Bonbon collection was showcased at the Richard Mille stand at the Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie (SIHH) in Geneva in mid-January: RM 16-01 Automatic Fraise watch (above), RM 07-03 Automatic Cupcake watch, RM 07-03 Automatic Marshmallow watch.

A variety of candy colours from the Bonbon collection was showcased at the Richard Mille stand at the Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie (SIHH) in Geneva in mid-January: RM 16-01 Automatic Fraise watch, RM 07-03 Automatic Cupcake watch (above), RM 07-03 Automatic Marshmallow watch.

A variety of candy colours from the Bonbon collection was showcased at the Richard Mille stand at the Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie (SIHH) in Geneva in mid-January: RM 16-01 Automatic Fraise watch, RM 07-03 Automatic Cupcake watch, RM 07-03 Automatic Marshmallow watch (above).

site_title: EURUSD outlook set to be fairly lacklustre
summary: The EURUSD is expected to be fairly lacklustre in 2019, following a series of negative economic indicators, including Germany's lowest GDP growth in five years and the European Central Bank's end of bond-buying scheme. The currency pair has been range-bound, with a recent upward move followed by a collapse, and is now showing signs of weakness. The UK's Brexit uncertainty and poor economic numbers from the bloc further exacerbate the gloomy outlook, potentially leading to a pullback to test resistance levels before continuing downwards.

site_title: Budget 2019 could be generous - election or not: analysts
summary: Singapore's Budget 2019 is expected to be expansionary, driven by the country's economic outlook and accumulated surpluses. Analysts predict a pre-election budget that includes goodies such as handouts, tax rebates, and targeted help for the lower-income. The government may also consider increasing the SkillsFuture credit and providing personal tax rebates. With the next general election due by April 2021, the budget is likely to address perennial issues such as healthcare costs, retirement financial adequacy, and the cost of living.

site_title: STI up 5% in 2019 YTD; tech sector leaders conducting buybacks
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 4.8% for the 2019 year through to Jan 17, outperforming other major indices such as the Hang Seng Index, Nikkei 225 Index, and S&P/ASX 200 Index. Tech sector leaders, including Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation, Venture Corporation, and Silverlake Axis, conducted share buybacks totaling S$11.2 million. The technology sector generated 6% capitalised weighted returns. Several directors and substantial shareholders made significant transactions, including GSH Corporation's chairman acquiring 56.47% of the company's shares and Prudential Plc increasing its deemed interest in Frasers Logistics and Industrial Trust to 5.0264%.

site_title: Toyota, Panasonic set to launch EV battery venture
summary: Toyota Motor Corp and Panasonic Corp are set to launch a joint venture to produce electric vehicle batteries, aiming to compete with Chinese rivals. The 51-49 joint venture will be owned by Toyota and Panasonic, respectively, and could provide batteries to Mazda and Subaru. The partnership, announced in 2017, aims to help Toyota reach 1 million zero-emission vehicles by 2030, while Panasonic seeks cost and scale advantages in battery production.

site_title: Tesla's Model 3 buyers tired of long wait for car
summary: Tesla's Model 3 buyers are growing impatient due to long wait times, with some having waited over two years for delivery. The company has collected $905.8 million in deposits, but the amount has slipped 3.9% from three months earlier. Tesla's CEO Elon Musk has acknowledged the issue, stating that selling the car at the base price of $35,000 too soon could put the company out of business. Musk plans to start shipping pricier versions of the Model 3 to Europe and Asia, but critics argue that the company is pricing out potential customers.

site_title: Lethal pipeline blast puts focus on Mexico plan to stop fuel theft
summary: A pipeline blast in Tlahuelilpan, Mexico, killed at least 73 people after they gathered to fill plastic containers from a leaking petrol geyser. The blast occurred as the government's plan to stop fuel theft, launched by President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, led to widespread petrol shortages in central Mexico. Relatives of those killed said they were desperate to find fuel, and authorities have faced criticism for not controlling the crowd and sealing the area. The disaster has brought renewed scrutiny of the strategy, and the president has vowed to fight fuel theft, including by strengthening ageing pipelines and buying more tanker trucks.

site_title: FedEx to take up to US$575m charge as it starts voluntary buyouts
summary: FedEx Corp plans to take up to US$575 million in charges as it begins voluntary buyouts of certain US-based employees to reduce costs. The company aims to save between US$225 million to US$275 million annually starting in fiscal 2020. The buyout program, primarily targeting FedEx Express and FedEx Services employees, will save the company costs related to employee departures. FedEx expects to incur charges in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2019 and has not announced how many jobs it seeks to cut.

site_title: US confirms holding Iran-based journalist, no crime alleged
summary: The US has confirmed holding Iranian journalist Marzieh Hashemi, born Melanie Franklin, in a Washington court, despite her not being accused of a crime. She was arrested at St Louis airport on a visit to see a family member and is required to testify to a grand jury investigating unspecified "violations of US criminal law." Iran considers her an Iranian citizen due to her marriage and has protested her arrest, calling it an "unacceptable political act." Hashemi will be released after completing her testimony.

site_title: France wants Renault, Nissan under a single holding company: Nikkei
summary: France is proposing to integrate Renault SA and Nissan Motor Co under a single holding company, according to Nikkei. A delegation from Renault visited Japanese officials to discuss the plan, which would likely put the two carmakers under a single structure. Renault also wants to appoint Nissan's next chairman following Carlos Ghosn's arrest, who faces financial crimes charges that could lead to decades-long imprisonment. The proposal aims to strengthen governance and address rising tensions between the two companies, which have been strained by Ghosn's arrest and plans for a potential merger.

site_title: Taking the 4R way to a green future
summary: Singapore aims to become a zero-waste nation through a circular economy, which involves capturing value throughout a product's lifecycle. Experts emphasize the need for individual and organizational actions to create a ripple effect. Key contributors include businesses, marketers, and government agencies, which have implemented various initiatives such as plastic-free policies, recycling programs, and green building practices. To achieve this goal, Singapore needs to promote awareness, transparency, and open innovation, with a focus on education, incentives, and disincentives. The government and industry leaders are working together to develop solutions, with a focus on technology, infrastructure, and policy changes.

images.alt_text: Phil Teeman, CEO, Dentsu Aegis Network Singapore & Southeast Asia

site_title: US regulators discuss fining Facebook for privacy violations: report
summary: US regulators are discussing fining Facebook up to $5 billion for violating a legally binding agreement to protect user data privacy. The Federal Trade Commission has been investigating Facebook since last year and has not finalized its findings or the penalty amount. Facebook has acknowledged several data lapses and has been scrutinized by regulators worldwide. The investigation follows the 2018 Cambridge Analytica data breach affecting 87 million users, and the FTC has taken the unusual step of announcing its investigation into Facebook's privacy practices.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week ending January 20, 2019, provides a roundup of tanker and dry bulk market trends. Capesize rates rebounded from below $6.00, with West Australia/China rates reaching the upper $6.00s after a week of decline. Timecharter rates recovered from under $10,000 daily for 180,000 tonners, with a 2010 vessel fixing a trip from CJK to east Australia/India at $12,000 with an option of China at $13,000. North Atlantic trading focused on tonnage willing to breach International Navigating Limits, with premiums for trading from these areas.

site_title: FSL Trust to take impairment on tanker sale
summary: FIRST Ship Lease Trust is selling its 14-year-old tanker, FSL Hamburg, to a third party for completion by March. The trust will take a US$6.3 million impairment charge on the vessel, which will be used to repay part of its bank debt and fund new-build vessel contracts. The sale is part of the trust's fleet renewal strategy to reduce debt and improve its risk profile.

site_title: Trade optimism yields dollar's first positive week this year
summary: The US dollar experienced its first weekly gain this year, rising 0.68% against a basket of rivals, driven by optimism over trade talks between China and the US. China offered to increase imports, and US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin discussed lifting tariffs on Chinese goods. This positive sentiment, combined with stronger-than-expected US industrial production numbers, lifted the dollar index and US stock indexes. The dollar strengthened 0.26% against the euro to its strongest level since January 4.

site_title: No one wants to buy an infamous US$130m yacht seized in 1MDB scandal
summary: A 300-foot yacht, Equanimity, valued at US$130 million, has failed to sell at auction after being seized by the Malaysian government as part of the 1MDB scandal. The yacht, owned by fugitive financier Jho Low, features luxurious amenities but has an infamous history due to its alleged connection to the scandal. Despite being listed on the market, bids have been too low, and the Malaysian government is seeking a speedy sale to recover US$4.5 billion of 1MDB funds.

site_title: Big pharma marketing spending tied to opioid deaths, study finds
summary: A study funded by the National Institute on Drug Abuse found a link between pharmaceutical companies' marketing practices and opioid overdose deaths in the US. Between 2013 and 2015, US counties with high volumes of opioid marketing saw more prescriptions and overdose deaths. Almost $40 million was spent on marketing, with unequal distribution leaving some counties vulnerable. This research comes as pharmaceutical companies face hundreds of lawsuits over their role in the US opioid epidemic.

site_title: Brexit bullion: Fear of no-deal triggers Irish gold rush
summary: In Ireland, investors are rushing to buy gold bullion as the UK edges closer to a no-deal Brexit, fearing a significant devaluation of sterling. Merrion Vaults, a gold brokerage in Dublin, has seen a 70% rise in clients from Northern Ireland, with many taking physical gold out of banks as a hedge. The vault's contents include over £500,000 worth of gold bars and coins, with prices increasing by 10% in the past six months. The Brexit uncertainty is driving a "flight to safety," with investors seeking refuge in gold and other assets.

site_title: Testing times from Beijing to Wall Street
summary: Global stock markets are poised for a test this week, with China's fourth-quarter GDP data set to set the tone for a week of policy updates from the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan. Investors are seeking reassurance on global growth and trade tensions, but economists expect China's economy to stabilize, with possible monetary stimulus and tax cuts from Beijing. Meanwhile, the US government shutdown and trade negotiations with China will continue to impact markets, with Wall Street traders bracing for updates from IBM and other blue-chip companies.

site_title: Data, trade war news to continue driving markets
summary: Asian investors focus on economic data this week, including China's Q4 GDP and Hong Kong and Singapore's December consumer price index (CPI) numbers. China's GDP is expected to show a 6.4% year-on-year increase, while inflation figures from Japan and the European Central Bank are also scheduled. Meanwhile, US stock markets are closed for Martin Luther King Jr Day, and negotiations on the US-China trade war continue, with a key meeting in Washington set for end-January. The US partial government shutdown remains unresolved, with President Trump presenting a proposal for ending it.

site_title: Bauhaus design turns 100 as disputes over its legacy churn
summary: The Bauhaus design school is marking its 100th anniversary, with celebrations taking place globally. Founded in 1919, Bauhaus aimed to make beautiful design accessible to all social classes, influencing modern design with its "form follows function" and "less is more" tenets. The movement's legacy has been marked by both praise and controversy, with some viewing it as a symbol of democratic ideals, while others see it as a threat to cultural identity. As Europe and countries around the world grapple with conflicting visions of cultural identity, the Bauhaus debate has become "explosive."

images.alt_text: Bauhaus, the design school that left its mark on everything from teapots to tower blocks and iPhones to Ikea, marks its centenary this year, touching off a politically charged debate about its lasting impact.

site_title: US: Wall Street extends rally on US-China trade optimism
summary: US stocks rose for the fourth consecutive week, driven by increased optimism over a potential resolution to the US-China trade dispute. A Bloomberg report suggested China aimed to raise annual imports from the US by over $1 trillion to reduce its trade surplus to zero by 2024. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin considered lifting some or all tariffs on Chinese imports, boosting shares across sectors. The S&P 500 advanced 1.32%, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.38%.

site_title: World economy wobbles on eve of Davos with politics to blame
summary: The world economy is experiencing a slowdown, with companies expressing bearish views on growth due to domestic and international political strife. The US and UK are skipping the World Economic Forum's annual meeting in Davos due to political issues, while other countries face challenges such as trade wars, government shutdowns, and Brexit. Economists warn that a recession is not imminent but growth could be toppled by economic data and political risks. The summit will focus on policy responses to address global uncertainty, with central banks and governments under pressure to respond.

site_title: US Treasury finalises tax rule on pass-through businesses
summary: The US Treasury has finalized regulations for a 20% tax deduction for pass-through businesses, affecting about 30 million US businesses. The regulations, released ahead of the 2018 tax filing season, allow business owners to claim the deduction on business income up to $315,000 for married couples and $157,500 for single filers. Higher-income business owners can combine ownership stakes to minimize deduction limits.
