The rules apply to sole proprietorships, partnerships, S-corporations, trusts, and estates, and exclude specified industries like healthcare and law.

site_title: Mueller disputes report that Trump told Cohen to lie to congress
summary: Special Counsel Robert Mueller has denied a BuzzFeed News report that President Donald Trump instructed his former lawyer Michael Cohen to lie to Congress. Mueller's spokesman stated that the report's description of specific statements and documents are not accurate. The report sparked criticism from congressional Democrats, who described the allegations as disturbing if true.

images.alt_text: Special Counsel Robert Mueller took the rare step of denying a media report about his Russia investigation, rejecting a story by BuzzFeed News saying that President Donald Trump instructed his former lawyer and fixer Michael Cohen to lie to Congress.

site_title: Tesla to cut 7% of workforce amid tough profit outlook
summary: Tesla announced a 7% workforce cut, affecting approximately 3,150 employees, amid a tough profit outlook. The move aims to make the Model 3 more affordable for middle-income consumers. Shares fell 9.1% following the announcement, which also signals a challenging road ahead due to the phasing-out of a tax credit for electric car purchases. CEO Elon Musk stated the company needs to continue making progress towards lower-priced variants of the Model 3 to succeed in its mission of challenging conventional autos.

site_title: Nasa and China collaborate on Moon exploration
summary: US space agency NASA has collaborated with China on Moon exploration, with the two countries coordinating efforts despite US restrictions on cooperation. NASA shared data from a US satellite to observe the historic touchdown of China's Chang'e 4 lander on January 3, but the spacecraft was not in the right place at the right time. The cooperation aims to gather science on lunar dust ejection during landings, which could inform future missions. Significant findings will be shared with the global research community in February.

site_title: STI ends mixed week in positive territory
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore ended the week up 9.90 points or 0.3% at 3,224.34, driven by positive investor sentiment following the US consideration of lifting tariffs and offering a tariff rollback on China. This lifted global equity markets, including those in Asia, Australia, Japan, and China. The STI gained 0.8% or 25.69 points since closing at 3,198.65 last Friday, with 23 of its 30 constituents ending the day in the black.

site_title: Dior declares men's fashion future to be suited and booted
summary: Dior's latest men's fashion show redefined 21st-century tailoring, featuring sleek, dark-hued suits and tailored jackets. Designer Kim Jones drew inspiration from Parisian statuary and incorporated elements of 17th-century cavaliers, with models wearing long scarfs and utility vests. The collection included streetwise luxury pieces, such as leather trousers and bomber jackets, while also nodding to the brand's founder Christian Dior's legacy. The show marked a comeback of the suit in men's fashion, a trend Jones described as elegance, tailoring, and couture.

site_title: The world's loneliest frog finds his mate
summary: Conservationists used Match.com to find a mate for Romeo, a 10-year-old Sehuencas water frog thought to be the last of his kind. Living alone in a tank in Bolivia, Romeo matched with a female frog, and the two have been inseparable. The successful match brings hope for the conservation of the Sehuencas water frog species, which was previously believed to be extinct.

site_title: Wendy Tang to join Knight Frank as group MD from April
summary: Knight Frank Singapore has appointed real estate veteran Wendy Tang as group managing director (MD) from April, replacing current group MD and executive chairman Danny Yeo. Mr. Yeo will continue as executive chairman of Knight Frank Singapore. The appointment aims to drive business performance across all service lines, with both leaders working together to build upon the company's strong foundation.

site_title: Be prepared to 'get nothing' in liquidation, Hyflux warns perp, pref holders
summary: Hyflux, a Singaporean water treatment firm, has warned its creditors that they may receive little to nothing in the event of liquidation, with senior unsecured creditors, including note holders, potentially recovering 3.8-8.7% of their investment. Perpetual and preference shareholders, including preferred and perpetual holders, are expected to receive nothing. The company is seeking support for a rescue plan, which would leave a 40% equity stake open for stakeholders to share.

site_title: Coal price rally firing up SGX-listed miners
summary: Coal prices have surged to US$33.50 per metric tonne FOB, driven by renewed demand from China and a supply crunch in Indonesia due to wet weather. The price is up US$3/mt from the start of the year and could sustain a recovery, especially with the Chinese New Year coal binge looming. SGX-listed coal miners Blackgold Natural Resources, Golden Energy and Resources, and Geo Energy Resources have seen gains of 2-17% in the year to date, with Geo Energy and Gear ending the day higher by 3.7% and 2.3% respectively.

site_title: Hedge funds rush back to stocks with leverage up the most since 2017
summary: Hedge funds are increasing their exposure to stocks, with leverage rising to its highest level since 2017, according to Goldman Sachs data. The S&P 500 has rebounded 11% as the economy shows no signs of contraction, prompting investors to boost risk appetite. Industry experts predict further gains, with some advising clients to buy stocks in US and emerging markets at the expense of bonds. The shift in momentum has prompted trend-following quant funds to consider covering their bearish wagers.

site_title: Reits
summary: US mortgage rates rose after five weeks of declines, affecting real estate markets. A Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore may test demand for projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents hit a record, with more increases predicted. Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul. UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. New World Group sold China property assets following a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants and filled more space at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore after its bankruptcy.

site_title: US drillers cut most oil rigs this week since Feb 2016: Baker Hughes
summary: US energy firms cut 21 oil rigs this week, the largest decline since February 2016, with the total count down to 852, according to Baker Hughes. Despite this, US crude output is expected to reach a record of over 12 million barrels per day this year, making the US the world's number one crude producer. This growth is driven by shale formations and is expected to put oil prices under pressure in 2019, challenging OPEC's resolve to support the market with output cuts.

site_title: World_Record_Egg finds its purpose
summary: The world-record egg (@world_record_egg) on Instagram has found its purpose after gaining 7 million followers and 47 million "likes" in just five days. The egg, now worth an estimated US$250,000, has broken its silence to share its journey of self-actualization.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ThaiBev's loan restructuring now gives the company 53% ownership of Sabeco, a positive move for long-term growth, but may dampen near-term earnings. Frasers Commercial Trust is expected to be fully occupied after Google leases 400,000 sq ft space at Alexandra Technopark, potentially lifting concerns over the Reit's ability to backfill space. Both companies maintain their "Buy" recommendations.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz C 180 Coupe review: Sporting a baby bump
summary: The Mercedes-Benz C 180 Coupe has been updated with a digital instrument panel and touch-sensitive steering wheel pads, but its old-school charm remains. The car's classic design, low roofline, and two-tone color scheme make it a desirable coupe. However, its 9-speed automatic transmission can be prone to clunky gear changes, and the sporty suspension setup results in a jiggly ride. Despite these issues, the C 180 Coupe remains a graceful and desirable option for those seeking a compact Mercedes-Benz.

site_title: Assembling the best team
summary: A business leader argues that qualification and experience are poor bases for judging potential employees, as they can be easily manipulated or exaggerated. Instead, hiring should focus on assessing an individual's attitude towards dealing with difficult situations, creativity, and ability to encourage and mentor others. Key qualities to look for include the courage to say "I don't know," a willingness to ask tough questions, and awareness of biases. By prioritizing these qualities, businesses can build a strong and effective team, rather than relying on traditional metrics.

site_title: Identical bids by linked owners can mean higher prices in govt tenders
summary: A study of 22,000 public tenders in Singapore found that identical bids from firms with common ownership connections led to higher prices, resulting in government savings of over S$4.7 million. The study, which used data from 2016 to 2018, found that identical bids were correlated with ownership connections, particularly second-degree and fourth-degree connections. The researchers estimated that removing these connections could reduce winning bid prices by 4.6-4.9%, resulting in significant cost savings for the government.

site_title: Li-Fi instead of Wi-Fi and no more draughty offices
summary: The Surbana Jurong Campus is set to test-bed new urban solutions through a "living lab" approach, with dedicated space for innovations like Li-Fi technology, which uses natural light to transmit data, and a chilled ceiling panel system for energy savings. A biological filtration system using plants will also be implemented to remove volatile organic compounds from the air. The campus aims to provide a more comfortable and sustainable work environment, with the goal of getting realistic feedback on the new solutions.

site_title: On bubbles, reflexivity, and narrative economics
summary: Nobel laureate Robert J. Shiller discusses the current market situation, citing concerns over simultaneous bubbles in the stock, housing, and bond markets. He emphasizes the need for a nuanced understanding of economic events, beyond simple models, and highlights the role of narratives and attitudes in shaping economic behavior. Shiller also notes the importance of considering historical market parallels and the potential for a recession, citing the inverted yield curve as a sign. Additionally, he discusses the concept of reflexivity, where market events can feed back into themselves, amplifying negative outcomes.

site_title: Dividend proposal stokes fires of takeover tussle for Stanmore Coal
summary: Stanmore Coal's proposed interim payout and share buyback have sparked a takeover bid by Golden Energy and Resources, with both sides releasing their fifth statements on the issue. The Australian-listed coal company's plans may have brought investors more headache than joy, with the takeover bid testing the company's resolve. The situation highlights the challenges of a potential takeover, with the dividend proposal being a key point of contention. The outcome of the takeover bid remains uncertain, with both parties engaged in a testy negotiation.

site_title: Foreign investors on record China property spree
summary: Foreign investors are increasing their presence in China's commercial real estate market, driven by the deleveraging drive and weak yuan. Overseas firms such as Blackstone Group and CapitaLand are leading the charge, purchasing properties like Shanghai's tallest twin towers. This surge is partly due to China's private conglomerates, like HNA Group, unwinding overseas property buying binges and selling domestic real estate. Foreigners accounted for 31% of commercial property nationwide last year, and may reach 40% of sales in Shanghai and Beijing in 2019, according to market research.

site_title: Surbana Jurong builds new campus in Jurong Innovation District
summary: Surbana Jurong is building a new campus in the Jurong Innovation District, Singapore, set to be completed by 2021. The 68,915 sqm campus will accommodate 4,000 employees and features sustainable design principles, including a "super-low energy building" with green technologies. The campus is being developed by Surbana Jurong's investment arm Surbana Jurong Capital, with an investment of S$400 million from M&G Real Estate, and will be fully leased to Surbana Jurong upon completion.

site_title: Challenger enters luxury audio market with concept store in ION Orchard
summary: Challenger, a Singapore-based electronics retailer, has launched its first luxury concept store, Musica Boutique, in ION Orchard, catering to high-end audio products. The 2,000 sq ft store offers a unique shopping experience with a focus on premium brands, allowing customers to compare products in a sound-proof room. Challenger aims to expand its retail footprint across Singapore and create new store experiences, with plans to open a 5,000 sq ft store at Paya Lebar Quarter in the third quarter. The company expects Musica Boutique to contribute to its bottom line in about six months.

site_title: Fun with DNA, flying taxis: 2 visions for the future?
summary: A consumer genomics firm, Orig3n, recently provided the author with a DNA test, which revealed insights into their athletic abilities, language learning skills, and potential career paths. However, the author is skeptical about the accuracy of the results, citing the limited scope of the test and the lack of scientific consensus on the genes involved. Meanwhile, a company called Bell is developing a flying taxi, the Bell Nexus, which aims to revolutionize urban transportation. The vehicle is designed to be easy to fly and could potentially reduce congestion in cities.

site_title: HSBC: Asean will be 'surprisingly resilient' in global slowdown
summary: HSBC predicts Asean economies will be "surprisingly resilient" in a global slowdown due to strong domestic demand, active fiscal policies, and regional trade liberalization. The region's economies are less credit-dependent, with underlying growth driven by demographics and job growth. While the US-China trade war will negatively impact Asean, increasing regional trade liberalization will mitigate the effects. HSBC forecasts the pound to rise against the US dollar if the UK stays in the EU, but could fall if it exits without a trade deal.

site_title: FCOT's Q1 DPU flat at S$0.024
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.4 Singapore cents for Q1 2019, unchanged from the previous year. Despite a 15% year-on-year decline in net property income to S$21.1 million, FCOT's distributable income rose 11% to S$21.6 million. The decline was attributed to divestment, lower occupancy, and the impact of Australia's currency slump. The trust's occupancy rate remained 80.7% and its weighted average lease expiry is 4.3 years.

site_title: The 3 Ls of real estate to watch in 2019
summary: Real estate investors are expected to focus on the living, logistics, and lending sectors in 2019 due to diversification benefits and relatively higher returns. The living sector is expected to see growth due to increasing demand for alternative residential arrangements, such as student accommodation and aged care, with yields of 8-14% in some cities. Logistics is also expected to expand, driven by e-commerce adoption, with significant capital targeting emerging markets. Lending is expected to be affected by interest rate hikes, but non-bank and offshore lenders are entering the market, providing flexible forms of debt or equity.

site_title: Ex-MP Tan Cheng Bock applies to form new Progress Singapore Party
summary: Former Singaporean MP Tan Cheng Bock has applied to form a new party, the Progress Singapore Party, after conversations with Singaporeans from various walks of life. He was previously a PAP MP and presidential candidate who stepped down in 2006. Tan aims to add a new voice in Parliament and build a "compassionate and truly democratic Singapore" where values and people matter. He plans to mentor and develop future parliamentarians, with a press conference to be held after party approval.

site_title: Netflix investors hit pause button as sales growth slows
summary: Netflix's Q4 revenue grew 27% to $4.19 billion, but missed Wall Street's projection of $4.21 billion. The company's slower sales growth disappointed investors, with shares down 3% in premarket trading. Despite a record 8.84 million new paid memberships, the forecast for the current quarter was lower than expected, partly due to a price increase. Netflix's operating margin shrunk due to heavy title releases, but the company expects negative cash flow of $3 billion this year, which will start to shrink thereafter.

site_title: Trading conditions positive for the metal
summary: Gold prices remain supported by looming market uncertainties, including the Brexit saga and heightened geopolitical risks. Despite a bullish US market, investors are drawn to safe-haven assets due to economic challenges and risk-off sentiment. The precious metal demonstrated sideways trading last week, but a potential bullish breakout is expected if the bullish-trend scenario unfolds, with key resistance levels at 1308 and 1325.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng's deputy CEO, Yap Ng Seng, retires after 13 years, effective Saturday. Keppel DC Reit's unit has been converted into a limited liability partnership for tax transparency. SK Jewellery Group has partnered with Bizkey Network for cryptocurrency payments. Hoe Leong Corp's Arkstar Ship Management unit lost a Hong Kong court case, ordered to pay US$336,000. Delong Holdings' Aoyu Steel received part of the compensation due from a Chinese local government, with 488 million yuan remaining outstanding.

site_title: Buffett's real estate brokerage expands into Italy
summary: Berkshire Hathaway HomeServices, a real estate brokerage led by Warren Buffett, has expanded into Italy through a partnership with Maggi Group Real Estate. The Italy-based business, Berkshire Hathaway HomeServices Maggi Properties, will start operating under the brand in late February. This marks the company's third international franchise and follows agreements in London and Berlin. The business aims to expand to Rome within two years, targeting international clients seeking properties in Milan and Tuscany.

site_title: Two new research centres set up to develop data privacy-preserving technology
summary: Two research centers in Singapore, the NUS Centre for Research in Privacy Technologies (N-CRiPT) and the Strategic Centre for Research in Privacy-Preserving Technologies & Systems (SCRIPTS), have been established to develop data privacy-preserving technology. N-CRiPT focuses on preventing privacy leaks and managing risk, while SCRIPTS aims to provide off-the-shelf solutions for businesses to collect and analyze data while maintaining user privacy. The centers are part of Singapore's Smart Nation push and will train skilled manpower to address the need for new solutions to guard against data breaches and maintain the usefulness of accessible data.

site_title: EU says Britain must hold European elections if no Brexit before July 2
summary: The European Commission has stated that Britain would need to participate in European parliamentary elections if it stays in the EU beyond July 2, sparking debate over the institution's work. The EU executive arm has not received a request from London for an extension of the March 29 Brexit deadline, but the European Parliament's legal services have a different view, suggesting Britain wouldn't have to elect its representatives even if it remained a member.

site_title: Post-Viva merger, ESR-Reit focuses efforts on Singapore assets
summary: ESR-Reit, one of Singapore's largest industrial Reits, is focusing on its existing assets following a merger with Viva Industrial Trust. The Reit has identified up to seven assets for enhancement initiatives and may accelerate plans if market demand calls for it. CEO Adrian Chui stated that the Reit's large portfolio allows for rejuvenation without affecting distribution per unit. There are no plans for asset acquisitions or overseas ventures at the moment, but the Reit aims to expand into countries where its sponsor ESR has operations.

site_title: Morgan Stanley targets rich China entrepreneurs in Singapore
summary: Morgan Stanley is expanding its services in Singapore to cater to rich Chinese entrepreneurs setting up family offices in the city-state. According to Vincent Chui, the bank's Asia wealth operations head, Singapore is a key hub for China entrepreneurs and a center for family offices. This move aims to capitalize on the growing demand for wealth management services in the region.

site_title: Falcon Energy suspends coupon payment, share trading as it embarks on debt revamp
summary: Falcon Energy Group, a Singapore-based offshore and marine company, has suspended coupon payment on notes due January 19 and trading in its shares as it embarks on a debt overhaul. The company cited a prolonged slump in the oil services market and a need to conserve liquidity. Discussions with stakeholders are ongoing, with a proposed conversion of S$50 million notes to ordinary equity and restructuring of term loans with bankers. The company's chairman and CEO, Tan Pong Tyea, expressed confidence in the company's viability and emergence as a stronger entity post-restructuring.

site_title: Huge North Korean beach resort 'nearing completion'
summary: A large North Korean beach resort, the Wonsan-Kalma Coastal Tourist Area, is nearing completion, according to a US monitor. Satellite pictures show rapid progress, including a water slide and cinema, in the area previously used for artillery drills and ballistic missile launches. The resort is located between a new airport and the country's east coast, marking a significant shift in North Korea's focus towards tourism.

site_title: Can Liverpool be toppled from their EPL perch ?
summary: Liverpool currently leads the English Premier League table with 57 points after 22 games, with 16 to go. They are the bookies' favorites to claim their first league title in nearly three decades. Manchester City and Chelsea are the top contenders, with Manchester City seeking to push Liverpool all the way until the finish line on May 12.

site_title: Microsoft pledges US$500m to ease Washington State's housing crunch
summary: Microsoft has pledged $500 million to address Washington State's housing crunch. The funds will be used for loans and grants to support affordable housing construction in the Puget Sound area. The goal is to bridge the gap between job growth and housing growth, which has led to housing prices nearly doubling in the past eight years. The funds will be allocated to middle-income housing, low-income housing, and philanthropic grants to address homelessness. This move aims to help alleviate the housing crisis in the region, where Microsoft is a major employer.

site_title: Courts Asia shares come alive with Nojima's S$0.205 a share offer
summary: Singapore retailer Courts Asia shares surged after a conditional cash offer by Japanese electronics retailer Nojima Corp at S$0.205 per share, a 35% premium above Thursday's closing price. The counter hit an intra-day high before ending the day at S$0.20, with around 2.23 million shares changing hands. This is the largest trading volume for Courts Asia in 12 months.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on trade hopes, upbeat manufacturing data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by hopes for a resolution to the US-China trade war and upbeat manufacturing data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 164.09 points, the S&P 500 gained 15.31 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 49.63 points. These gains mark the fourth week of consecutive increases, as investors remain optimistic despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: US manufacturing output posts biggest gain in 10 months
summary: US manufacturing output surged 1.1% in December, the largest gain in 10 months, driven by a 4.7% increase in motor vehicle production and a 0.8% rise in non-vehicle manufacturing. However, economists warn that this surge is unlikely to be sustained due to a slowdown in new orders and a strong dollar. The boost from last year's $1.5 trillion tax cut package is fading, and cooling growth in Europe and China is also hurting exports.

site_title: Lim Chuan Poh retiring from public service, new A*Star CEO to be appointed
summary: Executive chairman of A*Star, Lim Chuan Poh, 57, is retiring on April 1. Permanent Secretary (Education) Chan Lai Fung, 55, will take over as non-executive chairman. A new CEO will be appointed, with details to be announced later. Under Lim's leadership, A*Star spearheaded mission-oriented research, advanced scientific discovery, and created economic growth, while fostering partnerships with global industry leaders. Lim's successor will build on his work, aiming to drive A*Star's growth and development.

site_title: Asia's richest man outlines plan to take on Amazon in India
summary: Asia's richest man, Mukesh Ambani, has outlined a plan to take on Amazon and Walmart's Flipkart in India by launching a new online shopping platform for 1.2 million retailers and store owners in western India. Reliance Industries will combine its Jio telecom service, mobile devices, and physical retail network to empower small retailers. The move comes as India tightens rules on foreign-owned online retailers, expected to benefit local enterprises such as Reliance. Ambani's plan aims to bring merchants aboard through Jio's apps and devices, marking a significant expansion in the country's rapidly growing e-commerce market.

site_title: Metech International selling Malaysian e-waste business to general manager
summary: Metech International is selling its Malaysian e-waste management subsidiary, Metech Recycling (Malaysia) Sdn Bhd, to its general manager Lau Chin Guan for S$45,000 in cash. The sale is expected to be completed by Feb 9, and the proceeds will be used as working capital. The subsidiary has seen under-performance and continued losses due to regulatory permit issues, making this sale the most expedient way to exit the business in Malaysia.

site_title: Job losses mount as China factories sputter amid trade woes
summary: China's manufacturing sector is experiencing job losses and factory shutdowns due to the ongoing trade war with the US, with over 2,000 workers laid off at Maersk's Dongguan transport container factory. The prolonged tensions have curtailed orders, causing businesses to shut earlier than usual, including some factories closing 40 days ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday. China's exports unexpectedly fell the most in two years in December, and the country's GDP growth has been revised down to 6.8% in 2017. Industry experts predict further weakness in the world's second-largest economy and widespread job losses in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: As orders trickle in and some production lines grind to a halt, many Chinese businesses have reduced hours and done away with overtime in a bid to cut costs.

site_title: Your investment outlook vs the consensus one
summary: A review of investment outlooks suggests re-examining consensus views, especially when they become entrenched. Last year's crowd-consensus trades, including bitcoin and cannabis stocks, were broken, and the tech sector's growth was questioned. This year's consensus views on dollar asset diversification, ETF growth, and the trade war's impact on the S&P 500 may also be subject to change. Carefully re-analyzing reasons for holding a particular view is recommended, as consensus views can mark major turning points.

site_title: Malaysia shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.25 points to 1,692.22, closing higher on Friday. The index saw 305 million lots traded worth RM212 million, with 486 gainers and 369 losers. The rally comes despite global market uncertainty, including US trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: Indonesia to release suspected Bali bomb mastermind Bashir from prison
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has announced the early release of Abu Bakar Bashir, a radical Muslim cleric and alleged mastermind of the 2002 Bali bombings, on humanitarian grounds. Bashir, 81, will be released from prison in Bogor after serving more than a third of his 15-year sentence. The decision has sparked criticism from Australia, which was affected by the bombings, and security officials have expressed concerns about Bashir's influence in radical networks.

site_title: EU outlines trade goal with US in bid to bolster truce
summary: The European Union has outlined a blueprint for a free-trade deal with the US, aiming to lower tariffs on industrial goods, including cars, to bolster the truce between the two nations. EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom seeks permission to start negotiations, despite US resistance to covering autos due to national-security concerns. A deal could lead to zero tariffs for all industrial goods and expand US exports to the EU by 13%, while the EU's shipments to the US would increase by 10%.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust extends maturity date for loans due on Saturday
summary: Dasin Retail Trust has extended the maturity date for a tranche of offshore term loans by two years, from January 19, 2019, to January 19, 2021. The loans, totaling S$106.6 million and US$52.4 million, were originally due on Saturday. The extension lowers the weighted average term to maturity to 1.6 years and reduces the interest margin and annual all-in interest cost. The move is seen as a prudent capital management strategy, enabling a healthy capital structure for the trust.

site_title: NUS to invest S$1.5 million to co-create 15 deep-tech startups
summary: NUS is investing up to S$1.5 million to support 15 graduate students and research staff in establishing deep-tech startups through its Graduate Research Innovation Programme (GRIP). Each team will receive up to S$100,000 in funding, with the majority disbursed upon securing external investments or grants. The selected startups have developed innovative solutions in areas like engineering, biomedical science, and infocommunications, with potential for market growth and job creation in Singapore.

site_title: Saudi Arabia in talks to build an oil refinery in South Africa
summary: Saudi Arabia is in talks to build a crude-oil refinery in South Africa as part of a $10 billion investment pledge. The project will be a joint study between Saudi Aramco and South Africa's Central Energy Fund. The refinery and potential oil storage tanks and petrochemical plant are being discussed, with South African Energy Minister Jeff Radebe stating the refinery is the top priority. The project aims to support South Africa's drive to attract $100 billion in investment over five years and revive the country's flagging economy.

site_title: Knight Frank names new group managing director
summary: Knight Frank Singapore has appointed real estate veteran Wendy Tang as group managing director (MD) effective April 2019, replacing Danny Yeo. Yeo will remain as executive chairman. The appointment aims to drive business performance across all service lines, with both Tang and Yeo working together.

site_title: UK's Prince Philip 'shocked and shaken' after car crash
summary: Prince Philip, 97, was shaken but unhurt after a car crash in the UK. A nine-month-old baby in the back seat was uninjured, while one woman was hurt. The Land Rover flipped over, sparking debate about old age and driving. Police are investigating the cause of the collision, stating it's too early to speculate. No further information is available at this time.

images.alt_text: Prince Philip's car seen on its side after the crash near Sandringham. Photograph: TGKIN/Mega
Debris is seen at the scene where Britain's Prince Philip was involved in a traffic accident, near the Sandringham estate in eastern England, Britain, January 18, 2019

site_title: Asia's richest man outlines his plan to take on Amazon in India
summary: Reliance Industries, led by Asia's richest man Mukesh Ambani, plans to roll out an online shopping platform to 1.2 million retailers in western India, aiming to take on Amazon and Flipkart in the country's e-commerce market. The platform will combine Jio telecom services, mobile devices, and a vast physical retail network. Trials are ongoing in six cities, and the company plans to enlist neighborhood mom-and-pop shops as distribution centers. The move comes after India tightened rules on foreign-owned online retailers, benefiting local enterprises like Reliance.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust holds to Q1 DPU of 2.4 S cents
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust maintained its Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) at 2.4 Singapore cents, despite a 15% decline in net property income to S$21.1 million. The decline was attributed to lower occupancies and a weaker Australian dollar. However, distributable income rose 11% to S$21.6 million, driven by capital returns from hotel development rights and contributions from Farnborough Business Park. The six-property portfolio maintained an occupancy rate of 80.7% and a weighted average lease expiry of 4.3 years.

site_title: Lim Chuan Poh retiring from public service, new A*Star CEO to be appointed
summary: Lim Chuan Poh, 57, is retiring from public service as Executive Chairman of the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star) on March 31. Permanent Secretary (Education) Chan Lai Fung will be appointed as non-executive chairman on April 1. A new CEO will be appointed to lead A*Star's executive leadership role, with details to be announced later. Under Lim's stewardship, A*Star advanced scientific discovery and technological innovation, creating economic growth and improving lives in Singapore. He will be remembered for his contributions to the country's research innovation and enterprise landscape.

site_title: Huawei CFO enjoys life of luxury while under arrest
summary: Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou, daughter of the company's billionaire founder, enjoys a life of luxury while under house arrest in Vancouver. She is allowed to roam within 160km of the city until her 11pm curfew and has access to a $4.2 million mansion. Meng is wanted by the US for allegedly tricking banks into potentially violating sanctions against Iran. Her case has sparked a complex power game, with the US seeking her extradition. Despite the restrictions, Meng appears to be living a comfortable life, with access to various amenities.

images.alt_text: Nine days after Meng Wanzhou (above) was arrested during a stopover in Vancouver, China detained two Canadians on national security grounds. This week, a China court imposed a death sentence, following a one-day trial, on a Canadian found guilty of drug smuggling.
Former diplomat Michael Kovrig was one of two Canadians detained by Beijing shortly after Ms Meng's arrest.

site_title: Hyflux warns perp, pref holders they will lose everything in liquidation
summary: Hyflux, a water cleaning firm, warned its preferred and perpetual (perp) holders that they will lose everything in a liquidation scenario, as they will receive no payment. Senior unsecured creditors, such as banks and note holders, will get a 3.8-8.7% recovery rate. A consortium led by SM Investments has invested S$560 million in exchange for a 60% stake in Hyflux, leaving a 40% stake for other stakeholders. The company aims to finalize a restructuring deal by mid-February, with a third townhall meeting scheduled for March 13.

site_title: Hot stock: Courts Asia shares leap after offer from Nojima
summary: Courts Asia shares surged 31.6% to S$0.20 after a conditional cash offer by Nojima Corp at S$0.205 per share, representing a 35% premium above Thursday's closing price. The offer, which is conditional on the majority shareholder's acceptance, may lead to a strategic review and potential delisting of Courts Asia from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Why social media may be really bad for you
summary: A decade-long decline in attention spans has led to a reliance on short-form social media and digital communication. Research by Microsoft found that the average human attention span dropped from 12 seconds to eight seconds since 2000. Experts, including Assistant Professor Daniel He, attribute this to the passive nature of social media, such as YouTube and WhatsApp, which promote shallow thinking and distract from critical thinking. To combat this, experts recommend striking a balance between digital and long-form media consumption, reducing distractions, and increasing motivation to engage in deeper thinking.

images.alt_text: "Passive entertainment like YouTube promotes more shallow, superficial thinking." - Assistant Professor Daniel He of the Department of Marketing at NUS Business School.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher on Friday, STI adds 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 9.90 points or 0.3% to 3,224.34. The most actively traded stock was Ezion Holdings, while financials like DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank also gained. Gainers outnumbered losers 241 to 137, with an average unit price of S$0.44 per security.

site_title: SK Jewellery plans to accept cryptocurrency retail payments
summary: SK Jewellery plans to accept six types of cryptocurrency, including Ethereum, Binance Coin, and Zilliqa, at its stores through a new deal with point-of-sale system provider Bizkey Network. The deal will begin with the new SK Gold branch at Marina Bay Sands and is not expected to impact the company's net tangible assets or earnings per share. CEO Daniel Lim said the tie-up could bring opportunities to reach a wider pool of customers, while Bizkey CEO Ken Huang aims to reduce payment inefficiencies and improve service quality.

site_title: Challenger enters luxury audio market with ION concept store
summary: Challenger, a retail industry veteran, is expanding its luxury audio market with the launch of Musica Boutique, a 2,000 sq ft high-end concept store in ION Orchard. The store offers exclusive brands like Focal and Astell & Kern, and provides a soundproof room for customers to compare products. Sales are "good," with average prices ranging from S$1,000 to S$2,000. The store is designed to attract upgraders and high-end customers, with a focus on providing excellent customer service.

site_title: Golden Energy questions proposed Stanmore dividend in takeover tussle
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) is questioning the proposed Stanmore dividend in its takeover bid, citing concerns over the company's short-term capital management strategy. Stanmore declared an interim dividend of three Australian cents a share and a buyback scheme for up to 10% of its shares. Gear has 24.3% stake in Stanmore and has received 4.46% valid acceptances. The offer of $0.95 in cash for each Stanmore share closes on January 22. Stanmore's board believes the dividend and buyback will not impact its long-term outlook, but Gear is skeptical.

site_title: Two new research centres to develop privacy-preserving tech and train talent
summary: The National Research Foundation Singapore (NRF) has established two research centres to develop privacy-preserving technologies and train skilled manpower. The NUS Centre for Research in Privacy Technologies (N-CRiPT) and the Strategic Centre for Research in Privacy-Preserving Technologies & Systems (SCRIPTS) will focus on designing and developing solutions to protect sensitive data and maintain its usefulness. Both centres commenced operations in 2018, with N-CRiPT working on four projects and SCRIPTS on seven projects, aiming to instill trust in individuals and organizations when handling sensitive data.

site_title: China Sky selling investment-holding unit to chairman for S$190,000
summary: China Sky Chemical Fibre Company is selling its subsidiary Deluxe Dragon International Limited to Chairman He Zhidong for S$190,000. The sale is deemed in the best interest of creditors due to Qingdao Zhongda Chemical Fiber Company's debt and lack of operations. The transaction is non-disclosable as the net asset value is likely to be negative and the relative value does not exceed 5% of China Sky's market capitalisation. The sale is an "as is where is" basis, where the buyer accepts the company with all faults.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher for 4th straight day; won rises
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index closed higher for the fourth consecutive day, rising 0.82% to 2,124.28. The won strengthened against the dollar, while bond yields also rose. Foreigners were net buyers of 11.32 billion won worth of shares, marking the eighth consecutive session. Analysts expect the upturn to continue into the first half of the year, driven by easing US-China trade tensions and Chinese government stimulus measures.

site_title: Sharapova upsets defending champion Wozniacki
summary: Maria Sharapova upset defending champion Caroline Wozniacki to reach the Australian Open fourth round, winning 6-4, 4-6, 6-3. Sharapova, seeded 30, claimed her biggest scalp since returning from a 2017 drugs ban. The win sets up a last 16 clash with Ash Barty, and Sharapova praised the match, saying it was "really rewarding to win" after a dramatic momentum shift in the battle between the two former world number ones.

site_title: Tesla announces 7 per cent cut to workforce
summary: Tesla announced a 7% workforce cut to meet production demands for its Model 3, aiming to reach more affordable customers. The move follows a US tax credit drop that makes the car more expensive. CEO Elon Musk emphasized the need for "extreme effort and relentless creativity" to advance the company's mission. The staff cut is expected to impact approximately 7,000 employees, with the company seeking to produce lower-priced variants of the Model 3 to remain competitive.

site_title: Consumer giants spurn risks to chase online subscribers
summary: Major consumer companies such as Unilever, Procter & Gamble, and Nestle are launching online subscription services to offer stable revenues, lower delivery costs, and valuable customer data. These companies aim to skirt retailers, increasing profit and control over pricing and promotions. Despite some success, subscription services face challenges including high cancellation rates, marketing costs, and delivery costs. Industry analysts predict subscriptions will grow, but it remains unclear whether they will become a mass market phenomenon.

site_title: HK court rules against Hoe Leong unit in marine fuel sale case
summary: A Hong Kong court has ruled against a unit of heavy equipment supplier Hoe Leong Corp in a marine fuel sale case. Arkstar Ship Management, a subsidiary of Hoe Leong, was ordered to pay nearly US$336,000 in a January 11 judgment from the Hong Kong High Court, along with interest and costs. The court ruled against both the defence and counter-claim, excluding the alleged supply of contaminated bunkers and subsequent damage to the vessel's engines, as the bunkers were not actually contaminated.

site_title: Europe: Trade war hopes lift shares to early December highs
summary: European shares reached their highest level since early December, rising 0.9% as hopes for a Sino-US trade deal lifted markets. The STOXX 600 benchmark index led the gains, with the automotive sector and sensitive indexes up 1.3% and 0.7% respectively. Telecom Italia's profit warning and Ryanair's decline also impacted shares, but Casino's resilient fourth-quarter sales boosted its stock. The positive sentiment was attributed to improved trade talks, lifting shares from Wall Street to Asia.

site_title: Oxford says no to additional Huawei funding
summary: Oxford University has decided not to pursue new funding opportunities from Huawei due to growing scrutiny over the telecom company's relationship with the Beijing government. Existing projects with Huawei will continue, but no new funding will be accepted. The decision follows public concerns raised in recent months, amid a global campaign to blacklist Huawei's equipment over security concerns. Huawei operates in the UK, employing 1,500 people and collaborating with 20 other universities, but the company was not informed of the decision and will await Oxford's explanation.

site_title: After 600 years, night watchman still keeps vigil over Lausanne
summary: A Swiss night watchman has kept a six-century-old tradition alive by shouting out the time each hour from the Lausanne cathedral bell tower. The watchman, one of the last in Europe, no longer alerts the city to fires, but helps residents keep track of time. This tradition has been maintained for 600 years, showcasing the enduring importance of timekeeping and community services.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars get reprieve on Sino-US trade report
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars received a boost on Friday after a report suggested US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin had discussed lifting tariffs on Chinese imports, potentially advancing Sino-US trade negotiations. However, the report was later denied. This sparked a rise in Asian share markets and lifted the Aussie dollar to US$0.7201, while the kiwi dollar rose to US$0.6786. Dealers suspect speculators are shorting the kiwi due to expected soft inflation data, potentially leading to a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of New Zealand.

site_title: Bombardier on track to solve Swiss train problems -paper
summary: Bombardier is making progress in resolving issues with its double-decker passenger trains for Swiss Federal Railways (SBB), with reliability improving significantly in recent weeks. Only 12 of the 62 ordered trains have been delivered, four years after the initial agreement. SBB has apologized for delays and cancellations, demanding improvements from Bombardier, which has dismissed calls for compensation, citing no contractual claim. The technical issues primarily involve doors and entry platforms, and partners are working to reduce turbulence at low speeds. Most problems are expected to be resolved in a few weeks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on US-China trade rumours
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.29% on Friday, tracking US gains as investors took heart from a report the US could lift trade tariffs on China. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 20,666.07, while the Topix index rose 0.93% to 1,557.59. The move was seen as a positive sign for Asian markets, which have been affected by US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,221.10, up 0.2% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday at 3,221.10, up 0.2% on the day. The Straits Times Index gained 6.66 points, with about 1.12 billion shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 182 to 111, with JCG Investment being the most actively traded stock. This marks the fifth consecutive day of a rally ahead of GDP data, with investors staying positive despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Winston Toh to head bus operator Tower Transit Singapore
summary: Tower Transit Group has appointed Winston Toh as managing director of its Singapore bus operations, effective February 1, 2019. Toh, a public transport veteran with 27 years of experience in the Singapore Armed Forces, will succeed Andrew Bujtor, who left the company in September 2018. Toh brings over 10 years of corporate leadership experience, including roles at ST Engineering and Singapore Workforce Development Agency.

site_title: Canada Huawei 5G decision still months away: sources
summary: Canada's security review of 5G technology from Huawei is still months away, with a decision potentially restricted or banned. The review is ongoing amid a rising diplomatic feud sparked by Canada's arrest of Huawei's CFO Meng Wanzhou. Other Five Eyes countries, including the US and Australia, have placed restrictions on Huawei, putting pressure on Canada to make a decision. The review's outcome could impact Canada's relationships with China and the global 5G market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Key news includes: Surbana Jurong, a global headquarters building, to be completed by 2021 in Jurong Innovation District. Malaysia's agency is set to seize about RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Citigroup forecasts a 1,150 target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. Thaksin Shinawatra is confident his daughter's suspension as Thai PM in an ethics case will be cleared by the court. ASEAN agrees Myanmar's election is not a priority. The UK economy shrinks for the second month, and South Korea seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks.

site_title: Chinese tech hiring ads dive as trade tensions, slowdown bite
summary: China's technology companies cut hiring by 20% in the final quarter of 2018 due to economic uncertainty, trade tensions, and regulatory crackdowns. The decline was most pronounced in the internet and online gaming sectors, with ads falling 23% and 30%, respectively. The slowdown reflects a wider economic malaise and fears that the slowdown is here to stay, with economists predicting China's growth will slow to 6.2% in 2019.

site_title: Falcon Energy to undertake complete debt revamp, suspends trading
summary: Falcon Energy Group, a Singapore-based offshore and marine company, has suspended trading and will not pay a coupon on its notes due on January 19, citing a prolonged slump in the oil services market and the need to conserve liquidity. The company plans a complete debt overhaul, including restructuring with its bankers, noteholders, and other creditors, and may propose a conversion of its notes to ordinary equity. Discussions with stakeholders are ongoing, with the goal of emerging as a stronger entity post-restructuring.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week with gains, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.25% to 27,090.81. The move follows a report that the US is considering lifting Chinese tariffs in a bid to hammer out a trade deal between the US and China. The Shanghai Composite Index also rose 1.42%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.99%. The positive sentiment was attributed to the potential trade deal, which has lifted investor confidence and driven up stock prices.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks finished another healthy week on a positive note Friday as investors cheered a report that the US is considering lifting Chinese tariffs in a bid to hammer out a trade deal between the world's top two economies.

site_title: China revises down 2017 GDP growth to 6.8% vs 6.9% previously
summary: China's statistics bureau revised down the country's 2017 GDP growth to 6.8% from 6.9%, and also reduced the GDP size from 82.7 trillion yuan to 82.1 trillion yuan. This revision marks a slight slowdown in China's economic growth.

site_title: Canada's top diplomat praises Huawei CEO for trusting its legal system
summary: Canada's Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland praised Huawei CEO Ren Zhengfei for trusting the Canadian judicial system after his daughter Meng Wanzhou's arrest on US sanctions-linked fraud charges. Ren expressed gratitude for his daughter's fair treatment and the kindness of her cellmates, while also thanking the Canadian judicial system for its impartiality. Ottawa and Beijing remain locked in an escalating row, with China detaining two Canadians.

site_title: Ghosn received US$9m improperly from Mitsubishi-Nissan JV
summary: Carlos Ghosn, ousted Nissan chairman, improperly received $12 million in compensation from a joint venture with Mitsubishi Motors Corp without discussing it with two board members. The joint investigation found that Ghosn received 7.8 million euros in compensation, exceeding the agreed-upon amount. Ghosn faces charges in Japan of under-reporting his salary and transferring personal investment losses to Nissan. This incident occurred while Ghosn was detained in Tokyo since November 19, 2018, awaiting trial on these charges.

site_title: Australia shares rise for 4th straight day, led by resources, financials
summary: Australian shares rose for a fourth consecutive day, reaching fresh two-month peaks, driven by hopes for progress in resolving the US-China trade war. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.5% higher, advancing 1.8% for the week. Financial stocks, led by the "Big Four" banks, and resource stocks, including Rio Tinto and BHP Group, were major gainers, with London copper prices also rising. The rally was fueled by a reported US Treasury Secretary discussion of lifting tariffs on Chinese imports.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on trade hopes
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Friday, driven by hopes of the US easing tariffs on Chinese goods. The Hang Seng Index climbed 0.89%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. The positive market sentiment was fueled by reports of the US considering easing tariffs as part of a trade deal.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday, STI up 0.24% to 3,222.03
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Friday, advancing 7.59 points, or 0.24%, to 3,222.03. Gainers outnumbered losers 77 to 35, with about 57.3 million shares traded. Key movers included Rex International, Charisma Energy, and CapitaLand, which rose 1.33%, 50%, and 0.3%, respectively.

site_title: Tan Cheng Bock applies to form new Progress Singapore Party
summary: Former Singaporean presidential candidate Tan Cheng Bock has applied to form a new political party, the Progress Singapore Party, with 11 like-minded individuals, including former PAP cadres. Tan, 78, cited a sense of duty to represent Singaporeans in Parliament and form a new voice in Parliament. He stated that he will use his short window to mentor future Parliamentarians and build a compassionate and democratic Singapore.

site_title: Nissan may scrap chairman role as it rebuilds
summary: Nissan Motor is considering abolishing the chairman role as part of its governance reforms following the arrest and dismissal of Carlos Ghosn. Japanese law allows companies to operate without a chairman, and Nissan is exploring ways to distribute power among top management. The company's independent directors, including Keiko Ihara, are reviewing the role and proposing changes to improve governance. A decision on the chairman's position is expected, with Nissan aiming to rebuild its leadership structure and governance framework.

site_title: India's Jet Airways falls; lenders may take write-off: report
summary: Jet Airways shares plummeted 3.2% as lenders consider a plan to write off up to 25% of the airline's debt. The debt-laden carrier's lenders, led by State Bank of India, are discussing a plan involving a cash injection by stakeholders and board changes. Chairman Naresh Goyal's position is under consideration, and Etihad Airways is willing to invest $35 million if he steps down. The airline has suffered from high oil prices, competition, and a weaker rupee in 2018, and this is its ninth session of losses this month.

site_title: Asia: Markets boosted by fresh China-US trade hopes
summary: Asian markets rallied on Friday, boosted by hopes of a US-China trade deal. The Wall Street Journal reported that US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin had discussed lifting tariffs on China in exchange for structural reforms. Despite skepticism among analysts, investors remained upbeat, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Tokyo rising. Oil prices also increased due to the news. However, the global economy remains a concern, with slowing growth potentially impacting energy prices.

site_title: US government shutdown seen causing minor hit to broad economy: Bloomberg poll
summary: The US government shutdown, now the longest in history, is causing minor economic disruptions, according to a Bloomberg poll. Economists project the shutdown will end by mid-February, but a prolonged closure could cause economic growth to dip below 2% this quarter. The shutdown increases recession risk, with just under half of forecasters saying it will happen this year, and could affect the jobless rate as furloughed government workers are classified as unemployed. The White House has doubled its estimate of the shutdown's cost to economic output, and some economists, including Deutsche Bank, predict the economy could contract this year.

site_title: China's top movie ticketing app seeks up to US$345m in IPO
summary: Maoyan Entertainment, China's largest online movie ticketing platform, is seeking up to $345 million in a Hong Kong initial public offering. The company is offering 132.4 million shares at HK$14.80 to HK$20.40 apiece. China's box office sales reached a record high last year, driven by local films, with ticket receipts rising 8% to 56.6 billion yuan. This IPO comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Courts Asia, ESR-Reit, OUE Lippo Healthcare Limited, Chaswood, GS Holdings
summary: Courts Asia saw a conditional cash offer from Nojima Corp at S$0.205 per share, representing a 35% premium. ESR-Reit posted its first set of financial results, showing a 8.2% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit to 1.005 cents, driven by doubled gross revenue and net property income.

site_title: Surbana Jurong building global headquarters in Jurong Innovation District
summary: Surbana Jurong, a global urban and infrastructure consultancy, is building its new 68,915 square metre global headquarters in the Jurong Innovation District. The campus, expected to be completed by 2021, will accommodate up to 4,000 employees and is one of the first tenants in the district. The development is fully funded by M&G Real Estate, with Surbana Jurong managing the design, development, and operations. The campus features sustainable design and cutting-edge technologies, solidifying Surbana Jurong's position as a leader in the industry.

images.alt_text: Surbana Jurong Campus, as the building is named, will be completed by 2021 and can accommodate up to 4,000 employees.

It is one of the first tenants in the Jurong Innovation District and its location there will facilitate collaborations with research and development and capability developers, startups and technology enablers, said Surbana Jurong.

site_title: Australia: Shares touch highest point since mid-November; New Zealand gains too
summary: Australian shares rose to a two-month high, with banks and material stocks leading gains, as hopes for a US-China trade war thaw boosted risk appetites. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.5% to 5,880, driven by optimism over potential tariff relief. Financial stocks climbed 0.7% and the metals and mining sector also rose, with Rio Tinto gaining 1.3% on higher iron ore shipments. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.2% as well, with gains in financials and industrial stocks.

site_title: World's most-visited city faces battle against toxic smog
summary: Bangkok, Thailand's capital, faces its second consecutive year of toxic smog, with grey and thick air affecting the city, particularly during mornings. The air quality is worse than in cities like New Delhi and Shanghai. Authorities have responded by ordering people to stay indoors during pollution spikes, cracking down on dirty building sites and vehicles, and using rainmaking agencies to try to clear the haze. A longer-term fight to curb pollution is expected, with the city facing a battle against toxic smog.

site_title: Tesla recalls more than 14,000 cars in China over Takata airbags
summary: Tesla is recalling 14,123 cars in China due to airbags made by the now-defunct Japanese manufacturer Takata. The affected vehicles, made between 2014 and 2016, are Model S cars. This recall is part of a global effort to remove Takata parts, following the company's bankruptcy in 2017 due to its airbags causing deaths.

images.alt_text: Electric-vehicle maker Tesla will recall 14,123 cars in China over airbags that contained a part made by now-defunct Japanese manufacturer Takata, the Chinese market regulator announced on Friday.

site_title: Oil recoups some losses, but trade and supply worries dominate
summary: Oil prices stabilized on Thursday after a rebound in US equities and news that Opec sharply curtailed production in December. Brent crude oil futures settled at US$61.18 a barrel, while US crude futures rose to US$52.07 a barrel. Opec cut its forecast for average daily demand in 2019 to 30.83 million barrels and reduced oil output by 751,000 bpd in December. Despite this, concerns remain about surging US crude output and weakening global demand, with some traders worried that supply growth may outpace demand this year.

site_title: Morgan Stanley targets Singapore's rich China entrepreneurs
summary: Morgan Stanley is expanding its services for rich Chinese entrepreneurs in Singapore, targeting family offices with a focus on wealth management, investments, and financing. The US bank has hired Wee Yee Yeong to lead its Singapore wealth business and plans to add 50 relationship managers in Hong Kong and Singapore over the next three years. This move underscores the significance of Singapore as a hub for China's wealthy elite, who are increasingly setting up offshore structures to protect their fortunes from China's tax regime.

site_title: Event planning platform Delegate raises US$1m in pre-Series A round
summary: Delegate, a Singapore-based online event planning platform, has raised US$1 million in a pre-Series A funding round led by a Singapore-based family office and ex-Zopim team. The startup plans to expand into US and Australian markets, develop new product features, and blockchain technology. Delegate aims to introduce payment plans and scale its B2B offering, targeting event planners for work. Founded in 2015, the platform has over 1,700 vendors and 70,000 users. The funding will support the company's growth and transformation of the event planning experience.

site_title: Gloomy forecast for Davos: crises aplenty, but few world leaders
summary: The World Economic Forum in Davos is expected to be dominated by crises such as trade disputes, Brexit, and a potential recession, with few world leaders attending due to these concerns. The WEF's Global Risks Report warns of looming economic headwinds, fueled by geopolitical tensions among major powers. This gloomy forecast comes as the global economic outlook deepens, with issues like China's slowing GDP growth and the UK's shrinking economy adding to the uncertainty.

site_title: ESR-Reit posts Q4 DPU of 1.005 Singapore cents in first results since VIT merger
summary: ESR-Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, posted its first set of financial results after merging with Viva Industrial Trust in October 2018. The Q4 2018 distribution per unit (DPU) was 1.005 Singapore cents, up 8.2% year-over-year. Gross revenue more than doubled to S$58.4 million, while net property income (NPI) rose to S$42.3 million. The company remains cautiously optimistic about the industrial real estate market, citing improving supply and demand metrics.

site_title: African growth strong but unemployment high: AfDB
summary: Africa's economic growth is expected to accelerate in 2019, reaching 4.0% and 4.1% in 2019 and 2020, respectively, according to the African Development Bank (AfDB). Despite this growth, high unemployment and poverty remain significant challenges. The AfDB's president stated that Africa's general economic performance continues to improve, but it remains insufficient to address structural issues.

site_title: Size matters less than gold miners think
summary: Newmont Mining has acquired rival Goldcorp for $10 billion, creating the world's largest gold producer. The deal secures Goldcorp at a discount to its net asset value and brings a management team with a track record of turnarounds. Investors are skeptical, citing a faltering gold sector with fragmented companies facing production and cost challenges. The deal aims to provide steady production and dividends, but its success remains uncertain.

site_title: Corporate leadership is crucial in an increasingly fragile global landscape
summary: Corporate leadership is crucial in addressing pressing social and economic issues as governments struggle to provide lasting solutions. With market uncertainty and confidence deteriorating, companies are being held to higher standards, with stakeholders pushing for long-term, sustainable growth. Companies must reestablish their traditional leadership role in addressing issues like retirement, environmental protection, and social inequality. A clear purpose and strategy are essential for driving long-term profitability, attracting and retaining talent, and navigating the complexities of a late-cycle financial environment. Companies that prioritize purpose and stakeholder engagement will reap rewards, while those that ignore them risk failure.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 1.08 points to 1,681.89, with volume reaching 43.25 million lots worth RM17.52 million. Gainers beat losers 101 to 57. The market's performance was not directly related to the article's other sections, which covered Singapore stocks, US market records, and eSIM platform Airalo's funding round.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on report US could lift China tariffs
summary: US stocks rose for a third consecutive session as a report suggested the US was considering scaling back some tariffs on China, boosting market sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all gained 0.7-0.8% to close at new highs. The news lifted investor confidence despite ongoing trade uncertainty, with the Dow closing at 24,370.10 and the S&P 500 reaching 2,635.96.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on US-China trade rumours
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by gains on Wall Street following reports that the US may lift trade tariffs on China. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.27% to 20,456.83, while the Topix index gained 0.27% to 1,547.35. This move tracked the US stock market's gains, which edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US officials consider lifting China tariffs: report
summary: US officials are considering lifting tariffs on Chinese imports to calm volatile stock markets and encourage Beijing to make concessions in current trade talks. The decision comes as American and Chinese trade officials have until March 1 to resolve their trade war, which has led to punitive US duties on $200 billion in Chinese goods. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin raised the idea of revoking tariffs on some or all of the impacted goods, but the question has not yet reached the White House.

site_title: China to target 6-6.5% GDP growth in 2019: China Daily
summary: China is expected to set a lower economic growth target for 2019, between 6% and 6.5%, citing greater challenges to stabilizing growth. A National Development and Reform Commission official stated that more efforts will be made to boost infrastructural growth, but in a more efficient manner, with local governments required to cut costs. This decision comes amid concerns over slowing growth and increased pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Japan prices rose sluggish 0.9% last year
summary: Japan's consumer prices rose 0.9% last year, significantly below the Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target. The central bank is preparing to lower its inflation forecast for 2020 to around 1% due to falling crude oil prices. This marks the latest downward revision, as the BOJ struggles to achieve its target despite years of monetary easing. Low inflation is detrimental to the economy, stunting growth and prompting the BOJ to maintain its ultra-low policy.

site_title: Volatile market hits Morgan Stanley's trading, wealth management
summary: Morgan Stanley's quarterly profit fell short of expectations, with its trading and wealth management businesses affected by year-end market volatility. The bank reported a 4.4% decline in shares after missing analysts' average estimate of 89 US cents per share. Volatility in bond trading and a decline in wealth management revenue contributed to the decline. Despite this, Morgan Stanley's chief executive, James Gorman, characterized the quarter as a temporary blip and reaffirmed the bank's commitment to growth, with a focus on revenue expansion over profitability.

site_title: UAE hyperloop to finish initial construction in 2020: chairman
summary: Hyperloop Transportation Technologies, led by chairman Bibop Gresta, plans to complete the initial 10km construction phase of its UAE hyperloop system by 2020. The 150km route between Abu Dhabi and Dubai is estimated to cost between $3 billion and $6 billion. The first capsule has left Spain for France for testing on a prototype track. A hyperloop is a vacuum-sealed tube transportation system that could allow travel faster than the speed of sound, with initial construction expected to begin in 2020.

site_title: Prince Philip unharmed after traffic accident, two injured
summary: Prince Philip, 97, was unharmed after a traffic accident involving the vehicle he was driving near the Sandringham Estate in Norfolk, England. A Landrover and a Kia collided, injuring two people, including a female driver and her passenger, who sustained cuts and an arm injury. Prince Philip, who formally retired from public life in 2017, was shaken but unharmed after being pulled from the vehicle. Police confirmed both drivers were breath tested and provided negative readings.

site_title: UK says second Brexit vote would take over a year to organise: source
summary: The UK government says a second Brexit referendum would take over a year to organize, according to an official document shown to lawmakers. This contradicts Prime Minister Theresa May's previous stance that there will be no second referendum. May has been meeting lawmakers to find a way out of the Brexit impasse after her plan was rejected by parliament. A vocal campaign for a second referendum has the support of some lawmakers, adding to the ongoing Brexit stalemate.

site_title: JPMorgan board raises CEO Dimon's compensation to US$31m
summary: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon's compensation for 2018 has been raised to $31 million, a 5% increase. The total includes a base salary of over $1.5 million and $29.5 million in performance-based incentive compensation. This marks the first major US bank to disclose compensation for 2018 performance, following record net income of $32.5 billion. Other top executives also received significant raises, with Gordon Smith and Daniel Pinto receiving $22 million each, and Marianne Lake receiving $15 million.

site_title: UK PM May says 'impossible' to rule out no-deal Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May stated it's "impossible" to rule out a no-deal Brexit without stopping the process, as she tries to develop a strategy before the March 29 exit date. May was responding to a letter from Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, who asked her to exclude a no-deal Brexit as a precondition for talks. May said her door remains open for a meeting without preconditions, but acknowledged it's not within her government's power to rule out no deal.

site_title: Sias chief calls for answers as Hyflux's debt revamp drags on
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water cleaning company, is facing uncertainty over its restructuring plan, with investors awaiting a detailed survival plan. Despite court-sanctioned debt moratorium until April 30, the company's retail investors are concerned about the lack of involvement from majority shareholder Olivia Lum in the restructuring process. Securities Investors Association (Singapore) chairman David Gerald urged Lum to demonstrate alignment of interest with investors, and the company is set to hold its second townhall meeting to provide a status update and latest restructuring timetable.

site_title: Feuding Trump grounds Democratic speaker's foreign travel
summary: President Donald Trump has canceled Democratic Speaker Nancy Pelosi's foreign travel plans, citing the ongoing government shutdown. Trump responded to Pelosi's suggestion to postpone his State of the Union address by scrapping her Brussels, Egypt, and Afghanistan trip. In a sarcastic letter, Trump allowed Pelosi to book her own commercial flights. The move is part of the ongoing feud between Trump and Pelosi over the government shutdown, which has affected 800,000 federal employees and left many without pay. The shutdown shows no signs of resolution, with neither side backing down.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump clipped the wings of Democratic party leader Nancy Pelosi on Thursday, scrapping her foreign travel plans in a new twist to the government shutdown feud.

site_title: Philips to shut UK factory over 'geopolitical' concerns
summary: Dutch multinational Philips announced the closure of its UK factory making baby bottles, threatening 430 jobs, due to "ongoing geopolitical challenges" and uncertainties related to Brexit. The factory in Suffolk, England, is set to close in 2020 and transfer work back to Philips' Dutch base. The decision comes after Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal was rejected by parliament, throwing the process into doubt. Philips cited the need to mitigate potential impact on manufacturing operations.

site_title: The economy can't shrug off the shutdown forever
summary: The US government shutdown, caused by President Donald Trump's demand for a southern border wall, has raised concerns about the economy. About 800,000 government workers are furloughed or working without pay, and an estimated 4 million government contractors are also affected, totaling 3% of the labor force. This could lead to reduced investment by companies, resulting in a slowdown in business activity, layoffs, pay freezes, and cuts, potentially leading to a recession. Economists warn that the shutdown's macroeconomic implications could be comparable to a 2-4% increase in unemployment, and the global impact could be severe if investors lose confidence in the US economy.

site_title: Worries for LNG as prices slip amid record North Asia imports
summary: LNG prices have slipped amid record-high imports in North Asia in December, with 20.25 million tonnes delivered, a 12.4% increase from the same month in 2017. Despite strong demand growth, the spot price has trended down, reaching US$8.50 per million British thermal units (mmBtu) in the week ended January 11. This suggests ample supply is playing a greater role than demand, with prices expected to weaken further as winter ends and the market enters the lower-demand shoulder season of spring.

site_title: Brazil: Stock market keeps breaking records under Bolsonaro
summary: Brazil's stock market broke a new record on January 17, 2019, reaching 95,351 points, driven by President Jair Bolsonaro's pro-business policies and economic minister Paulo Guedes' plans for privatisations and pension reform. The Bovespa index has climbed 7.83% this year, with commodities such as Vale and Petrobras benefiting from higher steel prices. However, Embraer's decline was a notable exception, as the planemaker lowered its financial projections due to costs associated with folding its commercial planes business into a joint venture with Boeing.

site_title: From farm to tech to farm
summary: Agritech is becoming a serious business in Singapore, with the city-state aiming to transform farming. The article explores how agritech could impact agriculture and urban farming, despite challenges ahead. Lenovo's new chief diversity officer highlights the importance of diversity and inclusion, while Robert Shiller discusses bubbles and reflexivity in economics. The article also covers various other topics including investing, team building, social media, and more.

site_title: Sleepover with BFFs
summary: Pan Pacific Singapore offers a BFF Getaway Package for up to four persons, starting from S$710, which includes self-made cocktails, mini beauty kits, priority club access, champagne breakfast, and spa treatments. The package is designed for a weekend getaway with friends and can be booked at panpacific.com.

site_title: US 'jihadist' sought to attack White House: FBI
summary: A 21-year-old US man, Hasher Taheb, was arrested for attempting to carry out a "jihad" suicide attack on the White House, targeting the West Wing. He planned to use explosives and an anti-tank rocket, but the plot was foiled after he took delivery of inert explosives and weapons from undercover FBI agents. Taheb, who had become radicalized, hoped to become a martyr and was motivated by a desire to conduct jihad. The plot was discovered after a tip from the local community, and officials say no targets in Washington or Georgia were ever threatened.

site_title: Europe: SocGen warning, Huawei frictions weigh on shares
summary: Europe's shares experienced a mixed day, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index rising 0.04% despite a warning from Societe Generale and frictions over Huawei weighing on shares. The French bank's profit warning affected European banking stocks, which fell 1.2%, while Italian banks limited losses to 0.7%. The US probe into Huawei initially sparked concerns, but eased with confirmation of a meeting between Chinese officials and US officials. Other sectors, such as carmakers and steelmakers, also fell, with losses ranging from 0.4% to 4.7%.

site_title: Japan retailer Nojima makes offer for Courts Asia at S$0.205 apiece
summary: Japan's Nojima Corp is making a conditional cash offer to buy Courts Asia at S$0.205 per share, a 35% premium above the company's closing price. The offer, conditional on receiving over 50% of the shares, is part of Nojima's strategy to gain a foothold in South-east Asia. Courts Asia, which operates around 80 stores across three markets, has seen its shares on a tear since trading resumed after a halt. The acquisition could lead to a strategic review and potential delisting of Courts Asia from the Singapore Exchange.

images.alt_text: A unit of Japanese electronics retailer Nojima Corp is making a conditional cash offer for Courts Asia at S$0.205 per share as it seeks to gain a strong foothold in South-east Asia.

site_title: Indonesia's central bank holds key rate, says current level 'near its peak'
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, held its key rate unchanged at 6.00% as predicted by analysts, citing recent dovish signals from the US Federal Reserve. Governor Perry Warjiyo indicated that the current rate level is "near its peak" and the central bank will continue to direct interest rate policy to manage the current account deficit and maintain domestic financial assets. The rupiah has rebounded since rate hikes in 2018, but recent weakness amid concerns over China's economy and a large trade deficit has raised expectations for potential future rate hikes.
