site_title: I have become a Marie Kondo disciple. I am proud as well as ashamed
summary: A writer, a self-proclaimed recovering hipster snob, has become a Marie Kondo disciple, adopting the KonMari method of decluttering and organizing their home. The writer credits the Netflix series "Tidying Up With Marie Kondo" with inspiring their newfound sense of control over their possessions and life. The KonMari method, which emphasizes order and reducing consumption, resonates with the writer's desire for a more humane and sustainable approach to living. By asking "does this spark joy?" and treating each object with respect, the writer hopes to find a sense of calm and reassurance in their newly organized space.

site_title: UOBAM upbeat on investment outlook for 2019
summary: UOB Asset Management (UOBAM) has expressed an upbeat investment outlook for 2019, citing a steady earnings outlook for Singapore driven by government support, a stable property market, and improved bank profitability. The firm is "overweight" on the Singapore market in the first quarter of 2019, indicating a positive investment sentiment.

site_title: Tencent unveils test version of Game of Thrones smartphone game
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd has released a test version of a Game of Thrones smartphone game, titled Game of Thrones: Winter is Coming, developed by Yoozoo. The game is part of a pipeline hit by government scrutiny of online gaming. The test version was announced on Tencent's official WeChat account, marking a move to capitalize on the popularity of the US hit television show.

site_title: Wild Boy
summary: A 1967 play about Kaspar Hauser, a mysterious boy raised in a small cell, has been reimagined in a new production at the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts. The play, written by Peter Handke, explores Kaspar's innocence and ability to act independently as he faces societal pressures to conform. The production, running from Jan 17-20, imagines Kaspar as a vulnerable youth who struggles to express himself. The play offers a unique perspective on Kaspar's life, highlighting the complexities of his character and the challenges he faced in a society that sought to define him.

site_title: NODX down a surprise 8.5% in December
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 8.5% year-over-year in December, marking the second consecutive fall and the first since February and March last year. This contraction was largely due to declines in electronics and non-electronics exports, with contractions in personal computers, disk media products, and diodes and transistors contributing the most. Economists expect this weakness to extend into 2019, citing regional trade trends and potential trade tensions.

site_title: Craft beers bank on niche appeal and greater awareness
summary: Craft beer brewers are shifting their focus to broader appeal, investing in cultural diversity and inclusivity as sales slow and tastes change. The Brewers Association, the largest trade group, has appointed a diversity ambassador to develop guidelines and resources to help brewers create more inclusive workplaces, customers, and brands. Many breweries are now catering to under-represented drinkers, such as Native Americans and women, by offering beers with indigenous ingredients and cultural sensitivity. This effort aims to make craft beer culture more diverse, not just in its beers, but also in its target audience.

site_title: US$5.3b deal said to allow Sears chief to keep stores open
summary: US billionaire Edward S. Lampert has reached a $5.3 billion deal to acquire most of Sears' assets, keeping 425 stores open and 50,000 employees at work. The deal, if approved by a federal bankruptcy judge, would allow Sears to emerge from bankruptcy with reduced debt but faces uncertain odds in regaining market share. Lampert, a hedge fund manager, is deepening his investment in Sears, which has struggled in recent years due to declining sales and increased competition from online retailers.

site_title: Sombre mood expected at coming World Economic Forum
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos is expected to have a somber mood due to global crises, including trade disputes, Brexit, and a potential recession. Only three leaders of the G7 countries will attend, with US President Donald Trump pulling out due to a government shutdown. China will be represented by Vice-President Wang Qishan, and other attendees will include US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and central bankers. Despite the low turnout of major Western leaders, business chiefs will still attend to network and make deals, with some viewing the event as an opportunity for global leaders to present their agendas.

site_title: Lucy Liu, a woman of many talents
summary: Hollywood actress Lucy Liu held her first museum art exhibition in Singapore, showcasing her visual art alongside fellow artist Shubigi Rao. Despite being a 50-year-old actress, Liu's art received praise for its visual striking qualities and keen sense of balance, texture, color, and composition. The exhibition, "Unhomed Belongings: Lucy Liu and Shubigi Rao," aimed to introduce Liu as a visual artist to Singapore and reaffirm Rao's reputation as one of the country's best. The event drew a large crowd, with many attendees initially drawn to Liu's presence rather than the art itself.

site_title: Tunnel through an Australian mountain? No problem, says Elon Musk
summary: Elon Musk tweeted a "bargain" price to build a tunnel through a mountain to ease Sydney's traffic, offering a two-way high-speed transit for approximately $750m plus $50m per station. The estimated cost for a 50km tunnel is around $15m/km, sparking interest from Australian politician Jeremy Buckingham and billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes. The proposal aims to alleviate the city's severe traffic congestion, with the population of the Sydney region growing by 25% since 2011.

images.alt_text: Mr Musk tweeted: "About $15M/km for a two-way high speed transit, so probably around $750m plus maybe $50m/station." His response was liked more than 22,000 times on Twitter.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business: Giving the media industry a boost
summary: The article discusses various global economic and financial news. A Malaysian agency plans to seize about RM3 billion of assets from Daim Zainuddin, a prominent businessman. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The MSCI's global equity index is predicted to reach 1,150 by mid-2026. Thai Prime Minister Thaksin is confident his daughter will be cleared of ethics charges. The Asean region has downplayed Myanmar's upcoming election, and the UK economy has shrunk for the second month. South Korea seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks.

site_title: Above Ground
summary: Yang Yeo, co-chief creative officer of an advertising firm, lives in a unique two-storey house in Seletar, Singapore. The house stands on stilts, with a modern 'kampong' design, featuring an outdoor "basement" with a pool, dining table, and kitchen. The design maximizes the green plot ratio and creates a dramatic entrance, contrasting with the intimate interior spaces. The house features art galleries, including a collection of artworks by Chinese and Singaporean artists, and a unique curved staircase design. Yeo's goal was to create a home that suits his lifestyle, allowing him to spend time outdoors and showcase his art collection.

site_title: Goldman Sachs, BOA report strong earnings
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a US$2.3 billion fourth-quarter profit, beating expectations, while Bank of America's revenues jumped 11.3% to US$22.7 billion. The banks' shares surged after the results, with Goldman up 9.5% and Bank of America up 7.2%. Despite higher legal costs due to the 1MDB scandal, Goldman's CEO David Solomon described the real economy as "quite robust." The banks' collective profits exceeded US$100 billion for the first time in a year, but S&P Global Ratings cautioned that bank profit gains may moderate due to slowing economic growth and international trade wars.

site_title: Serangoon building back on market at lower price
summary: A freehold six-storey commercial building at 291 Serangoon Road in Singapore is being relaunched for sale at a lower price of S$46-49 million, down from S$52 million. The property, located near Farrer Park MRT station, offers a 35-metre dual frontage and potential for naming and signage rights. The sale price represents a land rate of S$2,300-2,450 per square foot. The property's marketing agent expects strong interest from investors and owner occupiers due to the improving office market and gentrification in the area.

site_title: Get Quacking
summary: The Tung Lok Group has opened Duckland, a London Chinese restaurant in Singapore, serving prime Silver Farm ducks from Ireland. The farm-to-fork concept showcases Ireland's produce, including Irish Lamb Stew, Bacon Cabbage & Colcannon, and Irish Oysters. The restaurant aims to highlight the quality of the ducks, known for their dense meat and crispy skin. Duckland is located at #B1-09 & 64/65, United Square Shopping Mall, and can be reached at 6259 5668.

site_title: Mrs May - in office but not in power
summary: Theresa May's government has won a vote of no-confidence in Parliament after losing a Brexit withdrawal bill, keeping her in office but not in power. She will present a new withdrawal plan within two working days, aiming to deliver a deal that honors the 2016 referendum result. May will also pursue cross-party Brexit talks, ruling out a second referendum or a full customs union with the EU. The outcome may lead to a political crisis in coming weeks, with the next formal step in the Brexit process set to unfold.

site_title: Look to India for growth, ESG urges Singapore consumer firms
summary: Enterprise Singapore's South Asia market director, Tay Lian Chew, suggests that Singapore consumer firms look to India for growth due to its large and dynamic economy. In-market production could be the next step up the value chain, according to Chew. This comes amid concerns about a global downturn, but India's economy structure makes it an attractive market for Singaporean consumer players.

site_title: Scent of Henry Jacques
summary: Henry Jacques, a renowned perfumer, has released a new crystal perfume bottle called 'Mr H and Mrs Y' as part of his Masterpieces collection. The unique design features twin tops representing the everlasting nature of love. The bottles are filled with distinct scents for men and women, including Cedar Leaf, Geranium, and Ylang-Ylang. The 'Mr H and Mrs Y' perfume is available for purchase at the Henry Jacques atelier in Marina Bay Sands.

site_title: Hipster meets sci-fi
summary: A podcast series called "Bubble" has been released, combining elements of hipster culture and science fiction. The show, produced by Maximum Fun, follows two millennials as they navigate modern-day struggles in an alien-infested city called Fairhaven. The podcast features witty commentary on social media and the gig economy, alongside action-packed moments as the characters battle monsters. The series stars Alison Becker and Keith Powell.

site_title: Couch Potato Alert
summary: HBO and Cinemax original series are premiering simultaneously in the US this month. True Detective kicked off on Monday, followed by Crashing and High Maintenance on January 21, and Strike Back on January 26. The third season of True Detective stars Mahershala Ali and features episodes set in three separate time periods. Strike Back's sixth season was shot in Malaysia, and High Maintenance's main character now delivers marijuana in an RV. The simultaneous premieres mark a new trend in the industry, providing viewers with multiple options at once.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust is proposed to acquire 18 Tai Seng for S$268.3 million, expected to generate a 6.8% initial net property income yield. OCBC Investment Research maintains a "hold" rating, raising FY20 DPU forecast and fair value to S$2.04. Singapore Airlines' parent airlines saw a 3.5% y-o-y decline in cargo traffic, leading to lowered cargo traffic growth assumptions. The airline maintains a "hold" rating, lowering fair value to S$10.20.

site_title: Japan urges G-20 to renew commitment vs protectionism
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso urged the G-20 to renew its commitment to cooperation and openness in the face of rising protectionism, warning that it would undermine economic stability. Aso's comments come amid growing trade tensions between the US and China, which have already impacted global investment and economic growth. He emphasized the need for international cooperation to address issues like global imbalances and the impact of aging populations, as Japan prepares to chair the G-20 financial leaders' meetings in June.

site_title: US homebuilder sentiment gauge rises from 3-year low in January
summary: US homebuilder sentiment gauge increased to 58 in January from a 3-year low of 56, a sign of potential stabilization in the housing market despite a broad slowdown. The National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index rose after a decline in borrowing costs and mortgage rates fell to their lowest since April. Builders' confidence is supported by a strong job market and tax cuts, with a gauge of prospective buyer traffic increasing to 44. However, the partial US government shutdown will delay housing-starts data release.

site_title: TSMC's quarterly profit meets forecasts with 0.7% increase
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd (TSMC) reported a quarterly net profit of NT$99.98 billion, meeting market expectations with a 0.7% increase. Revenue rose 10.7% from the previous quarter to US$9.4 billion. Despite concerns over sluggish smartphone demand, analysts attributed growth to TSMC's leading position in the latest generation of chip-making technology and its dominance in high-performance chips. The company's clients include Apple, Qualcomm, and Huawei Technologies.

site_title: Populism is now going mainstream
summary: Populism has shifted the global political landscape, with many politicians moving away from the center to align with a disenchanted electorate seeking change. Despite predictions of a return to the center, populism's influence endures, with nationalists and nativists gaining power in Western Europe and beyond. The anti-Trump "resistance" in the US remains optimistic about his impending impeachment and ouster, while some Republicans fantasize about a centrist challenger. However, populist ideas, including radical taxation, have gained traction, with 59% of Americans supporting a 70% top tax rate, and a socialist lawmaker like Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez gaining popularity.

site_title: 12 Months of Travel
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

In 2019, consider traveling to lesser-known destinations for a unique experience. Ethiopia offers luxury tented camps and fly camping in the Omo Valley, while Bolivia's Salar de Uyuni features a surreal salt flat landscape. Eastern Hokkaido, Japan, offers a unique ecosystem and snowshoe walks, and Puebla, Mexico, features the Giant Pyramid of Cholula. In Italy, Matera boasts dramatic rock-carved buildings and subterranean districts, and in Brazil, the Pantanal wetland offers a world of biodiversity. Other destinations include northern Peru, Kenya, and Helsinki, Finland, which prioritize sustainable tourism and unique cultural experiences.

site_title: The Swiss have been collateral victims of Brexit since 1992
summary: Switzerland has been engaged in negotiations with the European Union since 1992, after rejecting the European Economic Area status. Despite signing over 120 bilateral agreements, the EU wants a single framework agreement, which Switzerland has been hesitant to accept. The country has a complex system of referendums, which can lead to unexpected outcomes, as seen in 2014 when a referendum on freedom of movement was overridden by parliament. The EU is now adding pressure, threatening to ban EU listings in Switzerland if the country does not comply, amidst the Brexit-related uncertainty that affects both Switzerland and the UK.

site_title: Palladium hits new high on supply crunch
summary: Palladium reached a record high of $1,366.50 per ounce due to concerns over a supply crunch, with prices rising nearly 8% this month. The metal's price surge is attributed to lower supply and rising demand for auto catalysts. In contrast, gold remained steady, despite a firmer US dollar, as investors await clarity on the US growth outlook and Fed monetary policy.

site_title: CDL group GM is Redas new president
summary: Redas, Singapore's Real Estate Developers' Association, has announced its new management committee for the 2019/2020 term, led by Chia Ngiang Hong, a 40-year corporate leadership veteran from City Developments Ltd. He replaces Augustine Tan, who has served two terms. The 20-member committee includes representatives from major developers such as GuocoLand, Keppel Land, and CapitaLand. Chia expressed confidence in continuing to promote the industry's growth and development, championing excellence and sustainable developments.

site_title: US business optimism ebbs amid headwinds
summary: US businesses have become less optimistic due to financial market volatility, rising short-term rates, and elevated trade and political uncertainty, according to the Federal Reserve's Beige Book. Despite generally positive outlooks, many districts reported decreased optimism, with the Dallas Fed suggesting the Fed should pause on rate hikes to assess the economy. Tight labor markets and modest price increases were also noted, with some firms lowering educational requirements to find workers. The report offers insight into the Fed's views on the economy ahead of its next policy meeting.

site_title: UK home-sale expectations dip to 20-year low
summary: The UK housing market experienced a 20-year low in December, with real estate agents reporting falling prices and low optimism. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) attributed the decline to Brexit uncertainty and a lack of housing supply. Sales expectations for the next 12 months remained slightly positive, but near-term sales expectations reached their lowest point since 1999. Regional differences exist, with London and the south-east experiencing declines in property prices, while the rest of the country is expected to see price stability or increases.

site_title: Much to reap from Singapore's recent Asean chairmanship
summary: Singapore's Asean chairmanship has left a lasting impact, providing opportunities for growth and investment in the region. Despite expected slow growth this year, countries like Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam are expected to outperform, with some markets benefiting from the US-China trade spat. The Asean Agreement on E-commerce and Smart Cities Network will continue to drive opportunities, with Singapore firms having a key role to play. The region's venture capital scene is also seeing significant growth, with Singapore's geographical advantages ensuring its continued relevance in the region.

site_title: Founder of financial giant Vanguard, 89, dies
summary: John C. Bogle, the 89-year-old founder of financial giant Vanguard, has died from esophageal cancer. Bogle, who built Vanguard into a $4.9 trillion investment company, was a proponent of indexing and low-cost investing. He argued that investors get what they pay for and that high fees were a major obstacle to achieving long-term investment success. Bogle's ideas have been widely influential, with Vanguard's index funds outperforming actively managed funds in over 75% of cases since 1984.

images.alt_text: John C Bogle built Vanguard on a cornerstone belief that was anathema to most mutual fund companies - that over the long term, most investment managers cannot outperform the broad market averages.

site_title: Way Of Life
summary: In old Malayan shophouses, Singapore's five-foot-ways became a hub for small businesses, including barbers, fortune tellers, and knife sharpeners, catering to passersby's needs. These five-footway traders, often with little capital investment, operated from 1950s to the mid-1970s, before many professions disappeared. Although some have resurfaced, the unique aspect of these traders remains an integral part of Singapore's history and culture, offering a glimpse into the lives of its early immigrants.

site_title: How Chinese sellers of fake ware evade an online crackdown
summary: China has cracked down on its counterfeit industry, demolishing bazaars selling fake goods and introducing a new law fining online retailers up to 2 million yuan for selling bogus items on their platforms. To evade this crackdown, Chinese sellers use social messaging networks, which are not considered e-commerce and are therefore exempt from the law. This loophole allows them to continue selling counterfeit goods through these "friend-to-friend" networks.

site_title: Sunrise Shares offer turns unconditional, closing date extended to Feb 7
summary: The offer for Sunrise Shares, an electrical products trader and distributor, has turned unconditional with an extended closing date of February 7. Hong Kong-based businessman Wong Siu Fai made an offer of S$0.017 per share after acquiring a 90% stake in Quality Able, which holds a 4.49% stake in Sunrise Shares. Despite independent financial advisers advising shareholders to reject the offer due to its lack of fairness and reasonableness, Wong's total stake now represents about 53.8% of the company.

site_title: British Lotus cars to be 'Made in China' at new Geely plant, say documents
summary: Chinese automaker Geely plans to produce British sports car brand Lotus in China for the first time, starting with a new 9 billion yuan factory in Wuhan city. The move aims to boost sales and expand Lotus' global manufacturing footprint, with plans for luxury SUVs and increased production volumes. The factory, approved to produce 150,000 cars annually, is Geely's first high-end move to shake up the British brand since its purchase in 2017.

site_title: Where's the pound headed? The jury's out for now
summary: The pound's future is uncertain due to the ongoing Brexit negotiations. Analysts predict two to three possible short-term scenarios: a delay to an orderly exit, another referendum, or a no-deal disorderly Brexit. While some see a low probability of a no-deal Brexit, others warn of potential volatility and a sharp decline in the pound. A smooth orderly Brexit is expected to lead to a recovery of the pound, with some predicting a 1.40 GBP-USD and 1.90 GBP-SGD. The Bank of England warns of a 25% collapse in the pound and 6.5% inflation peak in a disorderly Brexit scenario.

site_title: Firms seek funds, labour to beef up tech: SBF
summary: Singapore companies are seeking support from the government to enhance their technology and address manpower challenges, with 63% of respondents prioritizing aid for new technology and 49% for digital transformation. However, barriers to innovation include the need to retrain staff (29%), availability of skilled workers (41%), and technology costs (59%). The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) also highlighted low investment in staff retraining and the need for reduced compliance costs and regulatory fees.

site_title: Huawei is target of US criminal probe for trade secrets theft
summary: US authorities are investigating Huawei Technologies Co for allegedly stealing trade secrets from US partner companies, including T-Mobile US Inc. A federal jury in Seattle found Huawei liable for the theft of T-Mobile's robotic technology in 2017, resulting in hundreds of millions of dollars in damages. The probe is at an advanced stage, and an indictment could come soon. This investigation is part of increasing US pressure on Huawei amid concerns that Beijing could use the company's equipment for spying.

images.alt_text: T-Mobile claims it wasn't Huawei's first victim, alleging that the Chinese tech giant also stole source code and other trade secrets from other companies.

site_title: Washington brewery sues Trump govt over shutdown
summary: A Washington brewery, Atlas Brew Works, has sued the Trump administration over a government shutdown, claiming it's preventing the shipment of its seasonal beer, "The Precious One". The shutdown has halted the review of beer labels, necessary for interstate shipping, and the brewery fears its perishable beer will spoil. The lawsuit alleges a violation of free speech rights, as the brewery's label is being denied indefinitely. The shutdown has affected many craft breweries nationwide, with some already producing and canning their seasonal beers.

site_title: Most SMEs confident about overcoming cyber breach: survey
summary: Most small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore are confident in overcoming cyber breaches, with 63% believing they are less vulnerable to cyber incidents than big companies. However, 56% of SMEs have experienced a cyber error or attack in the last 12 months, with internal factors such as system malfunction and human error being the primary causes. Only 44% of affected SMEs increased their security measures after a breach, and 70% have never bought cyber insurance. Experts emphasize the need for SMEs to implement strong cybersecurity policies, train staff, and have an effective incident response plan to mitigate cyber risks.

site_title: Angpao Bunny
summary: Singapore Airlines' KrisShop is collaborating with The Paper Bunny on a limited edition set of red packets featuring SIA's iconic batik print. The eight angpao sets are available online and in-store for a minimum nett spend of S$180, while stocks last. To celebrate, The Paper Bunny is hosting a social media giveaway to win two sets. The exclusive collaboration is available exclusively across all KrisShop channels.

site_title: Weak data drags euro down to 2-week lows
summary: The euro fell to a two-week low against the dollar, hitting US$1.1371, due to weak euro zone data, including a 1.5% growth rate in Germany's economy in 2018, the weakest rate in five years. Euro zone inflation data also showed price pressures receding further from the central bank's target, complicating the European Central Bank's plans to raise interest rates later this year. The pound remained stable at US$1.2872 as British policymakers seek a consensus on exiting the European Union.

site_title: Fly Me To The Moon
summary: Hermès unveiled its latest watch, L'heure de la lune, at the Teide Observatory in the Canary Islands, Spain. The 43mm white gold watch features a unique moon phase display, showing the moon's different phases in both hemispheres simultaneously. The watch's design is inspired by the observatory's giant telescopes and the moon's celestial beauty. Hermès' CEO, Laurent Dordet, revealed that the idea for the watch came in 2016, aiming to make the moon a central character on the dial, rather than a small detail.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: FRASERS Commercial Trust is in discussions to lease space at Alexandra Technopark, with Google reportedly in advanced talks for 400,000 sq ft. The trust has requested a trading halt on its units. Alpha Investment Partners has closed its Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund III, raising US$1.1 billion. OUE Lippo Healthcare successfully obtained a final arbitration award against David Lin Kao Kun, ordering him to pay US$32.8 million.

site_title: Christina Teo
summary: Christina Teo, a Singaporean tech and telco veteran, has launched she1K, the world's first corporate angel network for high-ranking women. The two-month-old initiative aims to support seed-stage startups by providing financial, political, and social guidance. Teo, who has held senior roles in several major companies, believes many C-suite women have the knowledge and connections to help startups succeed but are hesitant due to a lack of exposure to the startup world. Teo argues that women need coaching and networking opportunities to participate in the startup scene.

site_title: Forchn plans for second, bigger fund to shop for S-E Asian assets
summary: Forchn Holdings, the sponsor of EC World Reit, plans to launch a second, bigger fund to invest in S-E Asian assets. The new fund aims to target a 20% internal rate of return and is in talks with 3M about investment in Indonesia and business partners in Vietnam. Forchn previously launched a $150-million private equity fund last year to buy logistics real estate in South-east Asia.

site_title: China trade czar to visit US for talks ahead of March deadline
summary: China's top trade negotiator, Vice-Premier Liu He, will visit the US on January 30-31 to discuss economic and trade issues ahead of a March deadline. The talks come after a truce between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping in December to suspend planned tariff hikes. However, US authorities are investigating Chinese telecoms giant Huawei for alleged theft of trade secrets, and US lawmakers have introduced a bill to ban the export of American parts to Chinese companies. The visit may be complicated by tensions over Huawei and China's trade surplus with the US, which reached a record $323.3 billion in 2018.

site_title: Zodiac Luxe
summary: Panerai has released a limited-edition timepiece, the Luminor Sealand (PAM 859), to celebrate the Lunar New Year. The 11th model in the brand's annual series, it features the Year of the Pig, hand-engraved on the cover, using an ancient technique called 'sparsello'. Powered by the P.9010 automatic calibre, the watch has a three-day power reserve and comes with a brown leather strap. Only 88 pieces have been made and will be sold exclusively at Panerai boutiques.

site_title: Apple to cut back on hiring due to iPhone sales woes
summary: Apple plans to cut back on hiring for some divisions after missing its revenue forecast for the holiday quarter due to weaker iPhone sales. CEO Tim Cook said the company will reduce hiring in some groups, but key areas like artificial intelligence will continue to add employees. The hiring pullback won't affect plans for new offices or expanding content teams. Apple shares slipped less than 1% after Cook's announcement, which follows the company's first reduced revenue forecast in almost two decades.

site_title: Singapore asset players find calm in Brexit storm
summary: Singapore-listed property players remain calm despite the Brexit crisis, citing solid leases, diversification, and a long-term outlook as factors that will help them ride out the uncertainty. Ho Bee Land, Ascott Residence Trust, Centurion Corp, and Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) are monitoring the situation but do not expect a significant impact on their UK operations. Companies are taking a long-term view and are diversifying their investments, with some even planning to expand their presence in the UK.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare obtains final arbitration award against individual David Lin
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare Limited has successfully obtained a final arbitration award against individual David Lin Kao Kun in Singapore, ordering him to pay 58.8 million yuan, US$32.8 million, and S$842,822.66. The tribunal also granted an interim Mareva Injunction to restrain Mr. Lin from dealing with his assets in Hong Kong until the full payment is made. The company will make further announcements on enforcement proceedings against Mr. Lin's assets.

site_title: Thailand's PTT to expand trading in LNG in Singapore
summary: PTT, Thailand's state energy firm, plans to set up a liquefied natural gas (LNG) desk in Singapore to expand its trading activities. This move is part of Thailand's efforts to liberalize its power sector and boost competition. LNG imports into Thailand are expected to more than double over the next five years due to declining domestic gas production. PTT has hired an LNG trader, Daisuke Matsuoka, to handle imports, trading, and origination from its Singapore office.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to begin building homes in US$500b futuristic city
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to start building the first residential area of its proposed $500 billion futuristic city, Neom Bay, in the first quarter of this year. The area, which will feature "white beaches" and a mild climate, aims to attract foreign investment and bolster non-oil revenue. Phase 1 is expected to be completed by 2020, with a private airport set to open for commercial flights by the end of the year. The project, backed by the Saudi government and international investors, has been criticized for its high costs and uncertain economic benefits.

site_title: STI falls on disappointing export data
summary: The Singapore bourse fell 0.45% on Thursday, closing at 3,214.44, following disappointing non-oil domestic export (NODX) figures for December, which showed a 8.5% year-on-year decline. Economists now flag slower full-year GDP forecasts for 2019, citing downside risks, with ING and UOB revising their estimates downwards. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is expected to ease monetary conditions, and the bourse heads into the corporate earnings season, with several major companies reporting results over the next four weeks.

site_title: Why NBA stars do pedicures
summary: NBA stars are ditching their masculine stereotypes and embracing pedicures, with many players now regulars at nail salons. DJ Augustin, a veteran point guard, credits pedicures with helping him avoid foot pain during games. Other players, such as Shaquille O'Neal, Nate Robinson, and Amir Johnson, have also publicly shown off their pedicures, helping to normalize the practice. The NBA's occupational hazard of wearing new shoes has led to an increase in foot problems, but many players now view pedicures as a vital part of their professional routine.

site_title: Of mice, men and mazes
summary: Dr. Spencer Johnson's self-help book "Out Of The Maze" is the sequel to his bestseller "Who Moved My Cheese?", which sold almost 30 million copies in 37 languages. The new book, published in 2018, follows the same formula as its predecessor, imparting lessons on change and embracing new perspectives. However, with the rise of AI and futuristic technologies, Johnson's words may seem outdated. Despite this, the book's simple and accessible narrative may still find readers, particularly those who appreciate its folksy approach to self-help.

site_title: Airbus boosts US footprint with new A220 plant in Alabama
summary: Airbus has broken ground on its second assembly line in Mobile, Alabama, marking a significant boost to its US footprint. The new facility will produce the A220 jets, aiming to capture market share from rival Boeing. This move follows Airbus' existing plant in Mobile, which opened in 2015 for A320 passenger jets. Airbus Americas CEO Jeff Knittel expressed the company's commitment to growth, as Airbus continues to expand its presence in the US aviation industry.

site_title: India's Reliance posts 8.8% rise in Q3 profit on oil refining business
summary: Reliance Industries, led by India's richest man Mukesh Ambani, reported an 8.8% rise in Q3 consolidated net profit to 102.50 billion rupees, driven by growth in petrochemicals and oil refining. Despite a decline in refining margins to US$8.8, the company maintained robust growth in retail and telecom businesses. Revenues increased 56.4% to 1.60 trillion rupees, while Jio's subscriber base grew 27.9 million and profits rose 65%.

site_title: A promising start for 15 Stamford
summary: Chef Alvin Leung's 15 Stamford restaurant, located in the Capitol Kempinski Hotel Singapore, offers a thoughtful and respectful take on Singaporean and Asian cuisine. The menu features dishes such as grilled Bak Kut Teh pork chop and 72-hour cooked US short rib rendang, with some successful interpretations and others that need improvement. The restaurant's design, with its dark wood and leather banquettes, creates a warm and inviting atmosphere. While 15 Stamford shows promise, it still needs work to reach its full potential, with some dishes feeling overly sweet or lacking depth.

site_title: US: Wall St slips at open after Morgan Stanley results
summary: US stocks declined at open on Thursday, retreating from one-month highs, due to losses in financial stocks following Morgan Stanley's weak results and a drop in oil prices. The Dow Jones fell 0.25%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.26%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.35%.

site_title: Chaswood Resources receives statutory demand of payment for S$3m
summary: Chaswood Resources Holdings received a statutory demand of payment for S$3 million from the interim judicial managers of TAP Venture Fund I (TVF) within 21 days. The demand is related to the corporate guarantee provided for redeemable exchangeable bonds issued by Chaswood Capital. The company is seeking advice from its solicitors and is in ongoing negotiations with TVF to seek an amicable solution. If payments are made, they will have a material adverse impact on the company's financial position. The company has not made any payment to date.

site_title: Indian business leaders urge central bank to cut benchmark rate by 50 basis points
summary: Indian business leaders have urged the central bank to cut its benchmark interest rate by 50 basis points and lower the cash reserve ratio to stimulate the economy, which is showing signs of weakness. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) Governor Shaktikanta Das received the requests from industry captains, including the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry and the Confederation of Indian Industry. The cut in interest rates and cash reserve ratio aims to improve liquidity and reduce borrowing costs for small businesses.

site_title: Google faces third eu antitrust fine within weeks
summary: The European Union is set to announce a third antitrust fine against Google, targeting its AdSense advertising service, within weeks. The penalty is expected to be lower than previous fines due to Google's collaboration with regulators and changes made to AdSense. The investigation, which began over eight years ago, alleges that Google restricted rival search ads and hindered competition for online ads. This fine follows two previous EU fines, totaling $7.6 billion, and marks the culmination of a long-running antitrust investigation into the US tech giant.

site_title: Redas announces new president, management committee
summary: Redas, the Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore, has announced its new management committee for the 2019/2020 term. City Developments group general manager Chia Ngiang Hong has been elected as president, succeeding Augustine Tan, who served two terms as president. Chia brings 40 years of corporate leadership experience to the role, aiming to promote a pro-business environment and champion sustainable developments in the real estate industry.

site_title: Special Feature: A League of His Own
summary: Tod's CEO Diego Della Valle introduces the Tod's T Factory, a strategy to refresh the brand's offerings and engage customers in the digital age. The project involves creating more collections, including limited-edition collaborations, to maintain top-of-mind awareness and generate buzz. The brand will prioritize compelling narratives to accompany product launches, ensuring no compromise on production standards. The Tod's T Factory debuted with a collection designed by Alessandro Dell'Acqua, featuring seven ready-to-wear pieces and nine shoe styles. Della Valle also introduces the shoeker, a luxury sneaker that combines innovation and style, available in limited quantities.

site_title: GS Holdings forms JV to expand into F&B business
summary: GS Holdings has formed a joint venture (JV) with Zhang Li Ying to expand into the food and beverage (F&B) business, named Wish Hospitality Holdings. GS Holdings will hold an 80% stake in the JV, while Zhang holds 20%. The JV will focus on procurement, management, and distribution of F&B products and services. GS Holdings views this as a strategic opportunity to expand its F&B business with minimal investment.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 9.89 points to 1,682.97. Volume was 2.4 billion lots worth RM2 billion, with 477 gainers outnumbering losers 331.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with losses
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the day with losses, despite a positive start due to upbeat US earnings. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.54% to 26,755.63, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. Concerns about China-US tensions offset the gains from Wall Street's rise.

site_title: Disgraced Indian guru gets life for killing journalist
summary: Disgraced Indian guru Gurmeet Ram Rahim Singh was sentenced to life imprisonment for murdering a journalist who exposed widespread sexual abuses by the guru. Singh, who was convicted of rape in 2017, was found guilty of ordering the killing in 2002. Three other people, including close aides, were also given life imprisonment. The verdict came after Singh was convicted of raping two disciples in 2017. The sentence was given in response to the journalist's murder and widespread rioting by Singh's followers after his conviction.

site_title: France calls for Ghosn's ouster as Renault chairman, chief exec
summary: France has called for Carlos Ghosn's dismissal as chairman and CEO of Renault SA, eliminating one of his last potential allies in the global car alliance he has held together for 20 years. This move comes almost two months after Ghosn's arrest in Tokyo on allegations of financial misconduct. France, the biggest shareholder in Renault, refuses to follow Nissan and Mitsubishi in sacking Ghosn, but the French government's call for his ouster increases pressure on the company to take action.

site_title: Special Feature: Feasts of Abundance
summary: Chinese New Year feasts are underway, featuring various culinary delights. Tung Lok Group offers Yusheng, Prosperity Yu Sheng, and Longevity Treasure Bowl, while Crystal Jade presents auspicious dishes like Hamachi Yusheng and Eternal Bliss Platter. The Fullerton Hotel Singapore's Jade features a Grand Fullerton Golden Feast with lobster, suckling pig, and caviar. Pan Pacific Singapore's Hai Tien Lo offers set menus with Double-boiled Buddha Jumps Over The Wall and Braised Whole Abalone. Orchard Hotel Singapore's Hua Ting Restaurant features yusheng creations and prosperity menus. These restaurants cater to various tastes and dietary preferences, making them ideal for Lunar New Year celebrations.

site_title: European stocks drop at open
summary: European stocks dropped at the open on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.4% to 6,832.74 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices shedding 0.7% and 0.6% respectively. The decline was attributed to the UK government narrowly surviving a no-confidence vote and resurfaced US-China trade tensions.

site_title: AGV Group seeks 2-month extension for holding of AGM
summary: AGV Group Limited is seeking a two-month extension for its Annual General Meeting (AGM) for FY2018, initially scheduled for January 31. The company's auditors require more time to finalize and issue their audit report, which will be completed by late February. AGV Group needs additional time to prepare and distribute its annual report to shareholders, resulting in a new AGM date of March 31. The company will announce the outcome of its application for the extension in due course.

site_title: Singtel, Ericsson and Singapore Polytechnic open Singapore's first live 5G facility
summary: Singtel, Ericsson, and Singapore Polytechnic have launched Singapore's first live 5G facility, called 5G Garage, at the polytechnic's Dover Road campus. The facility is connected to Singtel's pilot 5G network and serves as a training center, test bed, and ideation lab to develop the Republic's 5G ecosystem and drive adoption by enterprises. The partnership aims to build and operate the facility, co-develop 5G solutions, and develop 5G wireless technology curriculum for the polytechnic, ultimately transforming industries such as transportation and healthcare.

site_title: S&P assigns Swiss biotech Lonza BBB+ credit rating with stable outlook
summary: Standard & Poor's assigned Lonza, a Swiss biotech company, a BBB+ credit rating with a stable outlook, considering it an investment-grade rating. This positive outcome supports Lonza's financing strategy and increases transparency for debt investors. The rating was confirmed after the company aimed to maintain an investment-grade credit profile, which Lonza's CFO stated will enhance comparability for capital market participants.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports fell 8.5% in December, contradicting expectations of a 2% rebound, according to Enterprise Singapore. This marks the second consecutive month of decline. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The Asean region also downplayed the importance of the Myanmar election. Meanwhile, Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%, below forecast.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE'S exports ended 2018 on a weak note with non-oil domestic exports (NODX) falling for the second straight month in December, dashing economists' expectations of a 2 per cent rebound, according to Enterprise Singapore figures on Thursday.

site_title: Tim Cook calls for privacy bill with right to delete data
summary: US Apple CEO Tim Cook has called for a federal privacy bill that allows consumers to see and delete their online personal data from a central clearinghouse. Cook wants the bill to give consumers more control over their data, enabling them to track and delete their information "on demand." He believes this will help tech firms win back consumer trust and prevent data breaches. Cook's proposal is in line with several lawmakers' and activist organizations' proposed data privacy measures, which contain elements of the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation.

images.alt_text: Apple chief executive Tim Cook called on US lawmakers Thursday to pass privacy legislation enabling consumers to see and delete their harvested online personal data from a central clearinghouse.

site_title: China's Tencent releases test version of Game of Thrones smartphone game
summary: Chinese tech giant Tencent Holdings has released a test version of a Game of Thrones smartphone game, titled "Game of Thrones: Winter is Coming", developed by Yoozoo. The game is a simulation that lets players take on characters from the show and experience memorable events. The release comes as Tencent faces heightened government scrutiny of online gaming, which has limited new game releases. The game is available for users with invite codes and will inherit the realist style of the HBO show, with players competing to conquer King's Landing and capture the Iron Throne.

site_title: China confirms Vice Premier Liu will visit the US from Jan 30
summary: China's Vice Premier Liu He will visit the US from January 30 to January 31 for trade negotiations, according to the Chinese government. This is his second trip to Washington to discuss trade, following a previous attempt in May that was backed away from by US President Trump. The visit comes as China faces a challenging domestic economic backdrop, with poor economic data and worsening factory sentiment. Liu He will work with US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer to implement a trade agreement.

images.alt_text: Vice Premier Liu He will visit the US on Jan 30 to Jan 31 for trade negotiations.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks steady; foreigners buy for 7th session
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index remained steady on Thursday, closing up 0.96 points at 2,107.06, with foreigners buying for the 7th consecutive session. The Korean won fell, while bond yields also decreased. China's central bank announced a large cash injection, and Premier Li Keqiang warned of economic difficulties ahead. Shares of Samsung Publishing Co Ltd surged 11.1% after its affiliate SmartStudy prepared for an IPO. The Kospi has gained 3.2% so far this year.

site_title: May faces tough talks with opponents to get new Brexit deal
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May faces tough negotiations with her opponents to secure a new Brexit deal. With just 10 weeks left before the UK's departure from the EU, May is prepared to compromise to get a deal through Parliament. Opposition parties, including Labour and the Scottish National Party, favor closer ties to the EU, while pro-Brexit Conservatives are opposed to any compromise. May's government is under pressure to avoid a no-deal Brexit, which could lead to a recession, and she is urging all parties to work together to find a solution.

site_title: Singapore stocks close 0.5% lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks closed 0.5% lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,214.44. About 1.7 billion securities worth S$961.41 million were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 206 to 167. Ezion Holdings and Rex International were among the most traded stocks, with Ezion up 2% and Rex down 1.32%. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, despite ongoing US-China trade uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Cisco CEO warns higher tariffs will force companies to cut R&D
summary: Cisco CEO Chuck Robbins warns that US companies will have to absorb the costs of higher tariffs on Chinese goods, leading to reduced research and development spending. He stated that companies like Cisco, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Dell, and Juniper Networks will have to cut back on R&D, hindering innovation. Robbins represents the views of several major US technology companies, which use contract manufacturers in Asia to make products, making them susceptible to US tariffs. The White House plans to increase tariffs to 25% on US$200 billion of Chinese goods unless trade talks produce a deal by March 1.

site_title: Indonesia's presidential challenger wants a better China trade deal
summary: Indonesian presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto vowed to seek a better trade deal with China, following Indonesia's worst-ever trade deficit. He plans to investigate and push for bilateral talks, similar to Donald Trump's strategy. Prabowo also attacked President Joko Widodo's economic performance, criticizing unfair trading policies with China, such as producer subsidies and dumping.

site_title: Gloomy forecast for Davos: crises aplenty, but few world leaders
summary: A gloomy forecast dominates the upcoming World Economic Forum in Davos, with several world leaders skipping the event due to crises such as trade disputes, Brexit, and a potential recession. Only three leaders of the G7 will attend, including Japan's Shinzo Abe, Germany's Angela Merkel, and Italy's Giuseppe Conte. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and British Chancellor Philip Hammond will attempt to reassure business chiefs, while the US delegation will discuss reforming international institutions. The event's somber mood is expected to be dominated by anxiety over the global economic outlook and geopolitics.

site_title: Keppel Capital's fund closes at US$1.1b, exceeds targets
summary: Keppel Capital Holdings' Alpha Investment Partners closed its Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund (AAMTF) III with a total of US$1.1 billion, exceeding its initial target of US$1 billion. Launched in 2007, the fund focuses on "mega trends driving long-term growth in Asia-Pacific" and targets multi-asset investments across key gateway cities. The fund's total assets under management (AUM) will be approximately US$2.4 billion when fully leveraged. This marks the third successful fund in the Alpha Asia Macro Trends series, which currently manages six real estate and data centre funds with US$9.5 billion in AUM.

site_title: UK Lords call for change in gauge used for index-linked bonds
summary: The UK's Lords Economic Affairs Committee has called for the government to change the index used for inflation-linked bonds, citing the Retail Prices Index (RPI) as a "largely discredited measure." The committee suggests an interim switch to the Consumer Prices measure, which would apply to areas not governed by private contracts. The committee also warns that the UK's statistics body may breach its statutory duty by not addressing issues with RPI calculations, which have been criticized for being outdated. This change is seen as a response to the RPI's declining quality mark from the statistics office.

site_title: Top North Korean official in Beijing en route to Washington: reports
summary: A top North Korean official, Kim Yong Chol, arrived in Beijing on his way to Washington for talks with US counterpart Mike Pompeo ahead of a possible summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Kim Yong Chol is expected to meet Pompeo on Friday and pay a courtesy call on Trump, carrying a letter from Kim Jong Un. The summit, which has stalled denuclearization negotiations, is expected to take place in either Vietnam or Thailand, despite disagreements between the two sides over sanctions and disarmament.

site_title: Freehold commercial building in Serangoon Road re-launched for sale at reduced price
summary: A freehold six-storey commercial building in Serangoon Road, Singapore, is being relaunched for sale at a reduced price of between S$46 million and S$49 million, down from its previous guide price of S$52 million. The property, located on a corner plot with a 35-metre wide frontage, offers potential for various uses including retail, entertainment, and serviced apartments. With the improving office market, the property is expected to attract strong interest from investors and owner occupiers.

site_title: Singapore wage growth to cool but strong hiring for new tech jobs to continue: Randstad report
summary: Singapore's wage growth is expected to moderate in 2019 due to global economic uncertainties. However, certain sectors such as information technology, communications, life sciences, and digital marketing are expected to continue growing and boosting headcount. The tech sector is expected to see significant salary increments, particularly for experts in cloud computing, financial technology, and cybersecurity.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei closes down as yen firms
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index closed down 0.20% or 40.48 points to 20,402.27, weighed down by a firming yen. Banking shares gained, however, to provide some support. The broader Topix index rose 0.35% or 5.43 points to 1,543.20. The yen's firming is attributed to a weaker US dollar and rising interest rates.

site_title: Thailand's Siam Commercial Bank FY profit down 7 per cent
summary: Thailand's Siam Commercial Bank reported a 7.1% fall in full-year profit to 40.1 billion baht, citing lower non-interest income from fee waivers and insurance. The bank's transformation program led to higher expenses, but its core business remains strong. Loan growth reached 5.2% year-over-year, and the bank targets 5-7% growth for 2019. Digital customer numbers reached 9 million in 2018, with a goal of 12 million by the end of 2019. The bank's cost-to-income ratio is expected to improve over time.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,222.15, down 0.22% on day
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.22% to 3,222.15 on Thursday, with 157 gainers and 142 losers. Ezion Holdings was the most actively traded stock, gaining 4% on 55.4 million shares traded. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: China Q4 growth seen slowing to 6.4% as domestic, export demand cools: Poll
summary: China's fourth-quarter economic growth is expected to slow to 6.4% in the October-December quarter, down from 6.5% in the previous quarter, according to a Reuters poll. This would mark the weakest pace since the 2009 global financial crisis. Demand for domestic and export goods is cooling amid a trade dispute with the US, and policymakers are closely watching employment levels as factories may shed workers. China's full-year growth is forecast to cool to 6.6%, the weakest pace in 28 years, and the government is expected to provide more support to the economy.

site_title: Sias chief calls for answers as Hyflux debt revamp drags on
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore water-cleaning company, is struggling with debt revamp talks that have been ongoing for months. The company's perpetual and preference share holders will receive a status update and a look at its restructuring timetable at upcoming townhall meetings. Sias chief David Gerald has urged Hyflux chairman Olivia Lum to demonstrate alignment of interest with investors by putting more skin in the game. Investors expect a detailed survival plan, but Hyflux has yet to reach a deal with creditors via a court-sanctioned scheme of arrangement by April.

site_title: China brushes off outrage over death sentence, Canada fires back
summary: China has dismissed international concerns over the death sentence handed to Canadian Robert Schellenberg for drug smuggling, stating it is "not worried in the slightest." Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has called world leaders to express concerns, accusing China of "arbitrarily" applying the death penalty. This move follows the detention of two Canadians by China last month. Trudeau's actions have strained relations between the two countries.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust: In talks with various prospective tenants to lease space at Alexandra Technopark
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) is in talks with prospective tenants to lease space at Alexandra Technopark, including Google, which is reportedly in advanced talks for 400,000 sq ft. The trust has requested the lifting of a trading halt on its units, stating there's no certainty of a definitive agreement. As of 3:23 pm, its units traded flat from Wednesday's closing price of S$1.43 apiece.

site_title: Singapore to introduce new laws to ban sale of illegal streaming devices
summary: Singapore plans to introduce new laws to ban the sale of media streaming devices offering pirated content through "add-on" services. The move comes after a three-year review of copyright laws, aiming to clarify the legality of such devices. The laws will likely address the grey area in copyright enforcement against set-top box retailers. The exact date for the laws' introduction is not specified, but it is expected to happen this year. The move is part of Singapore's efforts to protect intellectual property rights.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as Huawei report offsets US earnings
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday as concerns about China-US tensions offset a positive lead from Wall Street. The pound gained against the dollar after Prime Minister Theresa May survived a no-confidence vote. Global equities have started the year strongly, driven by optimism over China-US trade talks. Despite tariff uncertainty, Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: 'I never said there was no collusion' with Russia: Giuliani
summary: US President Donald Trump's personal attorney Rudy Giuliani clarified his previous statements, saying he "never said there was no collusion" between Trump's 2016 presidential campaign and Russia. Giuliani stated that Trump himself was not involved in any collusion, but did not rule out the possibility that others in the campaign may have worked with Russia. Giuliani's comments come as Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation continues, with several former Trump associates having pleaded guilty or been convicted of crimes related to the campaign.

site_title: Power infrastructure to drive Indonesia's energy sector growth: Fitch Solutions
summary: Fitch Solutions forecasts Indonesia's power infrastructure sector to drive energy and utilities growth with a 4.6% real growth in 2019 and 5% annual growth between 2019 and 2027. Coal-fired power plants, expected to account for 53% of generation by 2028, will be the primary driver of growth, despite risks of postponed projects due to macroeconomic pressure, including a widening current account deficit and a weakening rupiah. The water infrastructure sub-sector is expected to experience moderate growth, driven by improving rural access to clean water and upgrading urban sewerage systems.

site_title: Banksy in Tokyo? City launches probe
summary: Tokyo authorities are investigating whether a drawing of a rat holding an umbrella near a station is the work of famous street artist Banksy. The drawing, which is one of Banksy's most famous artworks, was discovered by locals and reported to the government at the end of last year. The government removed the door where the drawing was located and is now trying to verify its authenticity, but no experts in Japan have been found to confirm the artwork's origin.

site_title: Australia shares gain for third session; metal firms shine
summary: Australia's share index rose 0.3% to 5,850, marking its third consecutive session of gains, driven by a 0.7% increase in the metals and mining sector. Diversified miner South32's 3.6% gain, largely due to a near doubling of its coking coal output, was a key factor. Despite investors holding off on making big bets ahead of major resource companies' production reports, the index reached its highest in over two months.

site_title: Over half of SMEs in Singapore have experienced a cyber error or attack last year: poll
summary: A survey of 300 SME senior business and IT leaders in Singapore found that 56% of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) have experienced a cyber error or attack in the past 12 months. Despite this, 63% of respondents believe they are less vulnerable to cyber incidents than larger companies. The most common causes of cyber incidents were internal factors, including system malfunctions and human error. Only 44% of affected SMEs increased their security measures after a breach, and 70% have never bought cyber insurance.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose in the first few minutes of trade on Thursday, extending gains from the previous two days, as the US corporate reporting season started positively. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.19%, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.12%. The Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.05%. The gains come despite ongoing US-China trade tensions and uncertainty about the Fed's next move.

site_title: British Lotus cars to be 'Made in China' at new Geely plant: documents
summary: Chinese car owner Geely plans to produce British sports car brand Lotus in China for the first time, with a new 9 billion yuan factory in Wuhan city. The move aims to boost sales and production volumes, with potential new models including SUVs. This marks Geely's first significant move since purchasing a majority stake in Lotus in 2017, seeking to improve the brand's reputation for quality and design.

site_title: Nets launches fastest, same-day cash settlement for hawkers in Singapore
summary: Nets, a cashless payment services group, has launched the fastest same-day cash settlement for hawkers in Singapore. The service allows hawkers to receive sales proceeds in their bank accounts by 11pm the same day for transactions made before 5pm, and by 9am the next business day for transactions made after 5pm. This move aims to improve cash flow management for small-and-medium enterprises and encourage more hawkers to adopt e-payments.

site_title: China central bank to inject net 380b yuan, a day after record move
summary: China's central bank will inject a net 380 billion yuan into the market on Thursday, following a record 1.14 trillion yuan injection on Wednesday. The move aims to avoid a cash crunch ahead of a long holiday period, which would pressure the weakening economy. The injection will be made through open market operations, involving 250 billion yuan in seven-day reverse bond repurchase agreements and 150 billion yuan in 28-day reverse repos.

site_title: Airbus chief says British government 'optimistic' on Brexit deal
summary: Airbus chief Tom Enders expressed optimism about a Brexit deal, stating that British Cabinet members expressed a "degree of optimism" about avoiding a no-deal Brexit. This comes after British Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit plan suffered a defeat in parliament. Airbus is preparing for all possible outcomes, but hopes for the best by preparing for the worst, with the company's aircraft assembly line in Alabama already underway. The UK's scheduled departure from the EU is set for March 29.

site_title: Tunnel through an Australian mountain? No problem, says Elon Musk
summary: Elon Musk tweeted a proposal to build a 50km tunnel through the Blue Mountains in Australia to alleviate traffic woes for around $750M. The estimated cost per kilometer is $15M, which billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes deemed a "bargain" for Sydney. The proposal comes after Musk's successful tunnel project in Los Angeles and follows his previous infrastructure projects in Australia, including a massive battery. The project's feasibility and timeline remain unclear, but the exchange is seen as a potential positive publicity opportunity for Musk.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.07 points to 1,680.15 at 9am on Thursday, driven by a gain of 128 stocks to 44 losers. Volume reached 55.28 million lots worth RM19.14 million.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday, STI up 0.12% to 3,233.09
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Thursday, advancing 3.98 points or 0.12% to 3,233.09. The Straits Times Index saw 38.1 million shares worth S$80.3 million change hands, with QT Vascular rising 0.1 Singapore cent to 0.8 Singapore cent. Gainers outnumbered losers 67 to 32, as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Taiwan says it won't bow to pressure amid China tension
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-Wen has vowed not to bow to Chinese pressure, calling for international support against Beijing's "out-of-control actions". China has urged companies to change how they refer to Taiwan, labeling them "wrongly" for using the name "Taiwan" instead of "Taiwan, Province of China". This pressure has escalated since Tsai took office in 2016, with scrutiny over how companies, including airlines and retailers, refer to the democratic island. Tsai's spokesman emphasized the need for the international community to unite against China's actions.

site_title: Businesses cry out for Brexit clarity, warn of no-deal chaos
summary: Business leaders in the UK and beyond are warning of catastrophic job losses and chaos at ports if Britain does not agree a European Union withdrawal deal. The Brexit agreement rejected by lawmakers on Tuesday would have secured tariff-free trade and safeguarded just-in-time supply chains. Companies, including Ford and Volkswagen, are urging the UK government to work towards a compromise to avoid a no-deal Brexit. A disorderly Brexit would plunge Britain into recession for at least two years, according to Deutsche Bank.

site_title: 'Stealth easing' spreads in China property as debt risks mount
summary: China's property market is experiencing "stealth easing" as cities counter a faltering market, with measures including unspecified price caps and land plots for sale. Officials may unwind these measures due to a deepening economic slowdown. Analysts predict major easing in tier-one and tier-two cities, with some forecasting a 5% decline in home prices in smaller cities and a 10% drop in national sales. Experts warn of high risk profiles for builders in cities with heavy reliance on land sales, and some predict modest cooling in China's real-estate market this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wall Street gain, lower yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on January 17, 2019, driven by gains on Wall Street and a lower yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.52% to 20,548.11, while the Topix index increased 0.56% to 1,546.31. The gains followed a strong performance on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars near one-week lows as risk appetite wanes
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars held near one-week lows on Thursday due to renewed worries about global growth and a protracted Sino-US trade war. The Australian dollar slipped to US$0.7160, its lowest since January 9, while the New Zealand dollar eased 0.2% to $0.6762. Economists predict a recession in the world's biggest economies, citing a decline in the OECD's composite leading indicator and weak consumer confidence data.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars held near one-week lows on Thursday as renewed worries about global growth had investors flocking away from risk assets.

site_title: UOBAM upbeat about first-quarter Singapore earnings, US equities
summary: UOB Asset Management (UOBAM) is upbeat about the first-quarter Singapore earnings and US equities, citing a steady growth outlook. The asset manager is "overweight" on the Singapore market and "slightly overweight" on equities, with expectations for 10-15% equity returns and 4-6% bond returns in 2019. UOBAM favours defensive sectors and blue chips with high dividend yields, and expects global GDP growth to be above trend levels at 3.6-3.7%. The asset manager also does not expect a recession in 2019, despite market concerns.

site_title: Funding for tech tools tops Budget wish list of Singapore firms: SBF poll
summary: Singapore business owners' top wish list for the 2019 budget includes funding for tech tools, a relook of foreign manpower quotas, support for digital transformation, and lower compliance costs. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are particularly concerned about rising interest rates and compliance costs, with 71% saying more favorable financing mechanisms would benefit them the most. The survey also found a divide between large and small companies in implementing business innovations and tapping opportunities from Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs).

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports down 8.5% in December, confounding rebound expectations
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 8.5% year-over-year in December, contrary to economists' expectations of a 2% rebound. This was the first consecutive decline since February and March 2018, driven by drops in electronics and non-electronics exports. Domestic electronic product exports declined 11.2% year-over-year, with significant contractions in exports of personal computers, disk media products, and diodes and transistors.

site_title: CenturyLink opens its first S-E Asia security operations centre in Singapore
summary: CenturyLink has opened its first security operations centre (SOC) in Singapore, aiming to protect enterprises in the Asia-Pacific region from internal and external cybersecurity threats. The centre, the telco's second in Asia, will monitor over 114 billion network sessions and respond to 120 daily DDoS attacks. CenturyLink tracks over 5,000 command and control servers daily, removing 35 each month. The move builds on the company's existing operations in Asia, with a focus on building a cybersecurity talent pool and offering network-based security solutions to customers.

site_title: LTC to suspend trading from Feb 1, delist as exit offer crosses 90% threshold
summary: LTC Corp announced it will suspend trading from February 1, 2019, as an exit offer passed the 90% threshold, with the controlling family set to acquire shares representing 90.01% of the company. Trading will be suspended immediately after the close of the exit offer, which had been extended to January 31. The company will delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in due course, with the date to be announced later.

site_title: Ford forecasts US$112m Q4 loss amid restructuring costs
summary: Ford forecasts a US$112 million loss in Q4 2018 due to restructuring costs, despite expecting adjusted profit of 30 cents a share. The company aims to cut US$11 billion in costs, with a full-year net profit of US$3.7 billion. Ford CEO Jim Hackett said the company is transforming to improve competitiveness and profitability. The automaker also announced a global alliance with Volkswagen to build commercial vans and pickups starting in 2022, aiming to boost profitability by 2023. Ford shares lost over six percent following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Ford said on Wednesday it expected to post a US$112 million loss in the fourth quarter of 2018 as the automaker implements a massive restructuring in the United States and Europe.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit completes acquisition of Florida office property
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit has completed the acquisition of Maitland Promenade I, an office property in Orlando, Florida, for US$48.5 million. The 230,371 square-foot property has a 98.1% occupancy rate and is the Reit's 13th property, increasing its committed portfolio occupancy to 91.9%. The acquisition brings total assets under management to US$1.04 billion.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit over 2-month high; New Zealand at 3-month peak
summary: Australia's benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index rose 18.2 points or 0.3% to 5853.4, its highest level in over two months, driven by stronger financials and materials sectors. The financial sector rose in tandem with US peers, with big four banks rising 0.4-1.2%. The metals and mining sector also gained, led by diversified miner South32 and Woodside Petroleum. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index reached a 3-month high, with consumer stocks like Synlait Milk and a2 Milk rising 2.5-2%.

site_title: US in criminal probe of China's Huawei: report
summary: US authorities are investigating Huawei, a Chinese technology giant, in an advanced criminal probe that could lead to an indictment. The probe centers on allegations of trade secret theft from US business partners, including T-Mobile. This move escalates tensions between the US and China, following the arrest of Huawei's CFO Meng Wanzhou in Canada last year. The Justice Department declined to comment, and Huawei did not respond. The probe is part of broader efforts to curb Chinese espionage and influence, amid US President Donald Trump's push for more manufacturing on US soil.

site_title: UK house sales outlook weakest on record as Brexit nears: RICS
summary: The UK's house sales outlook is at its weakest on record, according to a Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) survey. The net balance of -28 among surveyors indicated a decline in short-term housing sales expectations due to Brexit uncertainty. This is the weakest reading in 20 years. Britain's housing market has slowed since the 2016 Brexit referendum, with house prices growing at the slowest pace in around five years. The survey also found that prices are expected to remain flat over the next 12 months, except in London and the south east.

site_title: UK PM May survives confidence vote after Brexit humiliation
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May survived a no-confidence vote in parliament by a 325-306 margin, narrowly escaping a humiliating defeat after her Brexit deal was rejected by 432 votes to 202. May will meet with opposition parties to discuss a new Brexit plan, with EU officials suggesting a possible delay to the Brexit date if a plan is presented. The opposition Labour Party may try to oust her government again, and May's government will tread carefully in negotiations with the EU and opposition lawmakers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel-KBS US Reit, Sunrise Shares, First Reit, ecoWise, Sino Grandness, Shanghai Turbo
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Key developments in the stock market include Keppel-KBS US Reit's acquisition of Maitland Promenade I for US$48.5 million, First Reit's flat fourth-quarter distribution, and ecoWise Holdings' non-binding MOU with Shin Tai Ho & Co. for a food processing and recycling collaboration. Sino Grandness Food Industry Group was served with a letter of demand for outstanding loan repayment, while Shanghai Turbo appointed Leow Siew Phaik as its new financial controller. Shares rose for Keppel-KBS US Reit and First Reit, while Sino Grandness shares fell due to the loan demand.

site_title: TSMP Law Corp hires to support expansion, new China desk
summary: TSMP Law Corp has appointed June Ho, a veteran lawyer with expertise in banking and finance, as a partner to support its expansion and set up a China desk. The move aims to strengthen the firm's capabilities in transactional and litigation work. June Ho will leverage her international experience to scale up the firm's offerings in banking and finance, debt finance, and mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: Airbus boosts US footprint with new A220 plant in Alabama
summary: Airbus has broken ground on its second US assembly line in Mobile, Alabama, to build its A220 jets, targeting market share from Boeing. The $300 million plant is expected to start production in the third quarter of 2019 and deliver its first A220 in 2020, with plans to produce four aircraft per month. Airbus generated $48 billion in US aircraft-related expenditures in 2017, supporting over 275,000 jobs. The company aims to capitalize on the US market, with the A220's seating capacity between traditional commuter planes and the A320 family.

site_title: Oil gains with Wall Street, but rising US fuel stocks weigh
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday, boosted by a US equity market rally and a supply cut agreement by Opec+, but gains were limited by growing US refined product inventories and record crude production. Brent crude futures rose 68 cents to $61.32 a barrel, while US WTI crude futures rose 20 cents to $52.31 a barrel. Despite the output cuts, US crude production is expected to grow to a record 12 million barrels per day this year, putting pressure on prices.

site_title: Goldman Sachs, Bank of America rock earnings
summary: Goldman Sachs reported better-than-expected profits of $2.3 billion in the fourth quarter, driven by higher equity trading, despite higher legal costs related to the 1MDB scandal. Bank of America's profits tripled to $7.2 billion, lifted by higher interest rates and loans. Both banks' shares surged after the results, with Goldman's rising 9.5% and Bank of America's gaining 7.2%. Despite S&P Global Ratings' caution that bank profits may moderate due to economic slowdown, the two banks' collective profits exceeded $100 billion in 2018 for the first time in a year.

site_title: Europe: Brexit deal defeat boosts European banks
summary: European shares closed in positive territory on Wednesday following British Prime Minister Theresa May's defeat in a parliamentary vote on her Brexit deal. Euro zone banks shares rose 2.4%, with Italian banks leading the gain, as investors bet a no-deal Brexit was less likely. The Euro Stoxx finished 0.5% up, while London's FTSE lagged 0.5% due to a firming pound. Analysts cautioned that the optimism might be short-lived, citing ongoing uncertainty and potential for new developments.
