The two companies have been discussing a partnership to develop self-driving and electric technologies, with a focus on commercial vehicles. Ford and Volkswagen CEO Herbert Diess expressed optimism about a potential partnership, which would make them highly competitive in the small commercial vehicle segment. The announcement was expected to be a significant development in the automotive industry, following similar partnerships between other major manufacturers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on slowdown fears
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on January 15, 2019, due to fears of a global economic slowdown. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.55% to 20,246.87, while the Topix index decreased 0.54% to 1,521.49. This follows a global market trend, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: As shutdown bites, Trump foots bill for fast food feast
summary: US President Donald Trump ordered an "all-American" fast food feast for visiting Clemson Tigers football team players, as he hosts them to celebrate their national championship win. The meal, which includes 300 hamburgers and pizzas, was paid for by Trump due to the ongoing government shutdown. Around 800,000 federal employees, including White House staff, have been affected by the shutdown, which has entered its 24th day. Trump cited the shutdown as the reason for the unusual gesture, saying he wants to ensure everything is "right" for the players.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump speaks in front of fast food provided for the 2018 College Football Playoff National Champion Clemson Tigers due to the partial government shutdown in the State Dining Room of the White House in Washington

site_title: A good yarn: Russia's Insta-grannies take knitting skills online
summary: Russia's "Granny's" project, an Instagram initiative promoting elderly women's hand-knitted items, has gained popularity, with over 5,000 followers. The project, launched by 27-year-old Yulia Aliyeva, aims to change public perception of their skills and provide a platform for the women to sell their knitted goods online, earning between $450 to $1,000 per month. The project highlights the "sacred role" of Russian grandmothers and provides financial support to women who struggle to make ends meet due to low pensions.

site_title: Courts Asia unit acquires Jakarta building, cancels 2 megastore leases in Indonesia
summary: Courts Asia's subsidiary, PT Courts Retail Indonesia, acquired the KHI Building in Jakarta, Indonesia, for around 97.56 billion rupiah (S$9.36 million). The acquisition includes terminating two existing leases, including the KHI Megastore and a plot of land in Tangerang, resulting in a penalty and forfeited security deposit. The move is part of Courts' efforts to restructure its store network and format in Indonesia, with the goal of optimizing or repurposing the existing store premises.

site_title: Alliance Mineral to add market pricing, drop exclusivity in restructured offtake deal
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets has restructured offtake agreements with Burwill Lithium, removing exclusivity and pre-emptive rights. The company will now sell its lithium concentrate to other customers, with market-linked pricing of US$680-1080 per tonne. Alliance has also secured a deal with Jiangxi Bao Jiang Lithium Industrial to buy 18,000 dry metric tonnes of lithium concentrate at US$15.8 million. The company expects strong interest in new offtake partners and increased production guidance for 2019, with output ranging from 65,000-80,000 tonnes of lithium concentrate.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars inch up, hope for best on Brexit
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose on Tuesday, driven by market hopes that a British government's latest Brexit plan would reduce the risk of a "no-deal" divorce. The Aussie dollar increased 0.2% to US$0.7211, while the kiwi dollar firmed to $0.6831. Investors expect a potential extension of the March 29 EU deadline, which could offer more time to broker a deal or consider a second referendum, easing concerns about the pound's value.

site_title: May pleads with MPs on eve of Brexit vote
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May urged MPs to reconsider rejecting the EU divorce deal on the eve of a crucial parliamentary vote, warning of a chaotic no-deal scenario or subverting democracy by blocking Brexit. Despite EU assurances, large numbers of Conservative MPs and Northern Irish allies remain opposed. The deal, which includes the contentious Irish backstop, faces a high chance of defeat, with May admitting it falls short of her desired assurances.

site_title: China's efforts to win trust remain Sisyphean
summary: China's efforts to win global trust remain elusive, despite achievements such as landing on the far side of the moon. A survey of 1,008 regional experts in Southeast Asia found that most view China as a "revisionist power" with an intention to dominate the region, with only 8.9% seeing it as a "benign and benevolent power". This lack of trust is a key issue for President Xi Jinping, who has called for closing the "trust gap" with other countries. The Chinese government's own trust with its people is also a concern, following the vaccine crisis and the recent constitutional change that lifted term limits for the president.

site_title: Hong Kong's rural hinterland could hold key to chronic land crunch
summary: Hong Kong's rural land crisis worsens as major developers hold approximately 1,000 hectares of agricultural land, despite the city needing around 12 square kilometers more to accommodate its growing population. The government's plan to build artificial islands to alleviate the issue has sparked controversy, with critics arguing that developers are hoarding land, potentially at the expense of public housing. Experts suggest that taking over agricultural land from developers could meet the city's land needs many times over, but the government is cautious due to the risk of protracted legal disputes and protests.

site_title: Woman suing R Kelly for sex abuse says singer threatened her
summary: A 20-year-old woman, Faith Rodgers, who sued R Kelly for sex abuse, alleging he threatened her after she filed the lawsuit. Kelly's team created a Facebook page to discredit her, posting "private" photos, and he warned Rodgers' attorney he would demand medical evidence and challenge her version of events. Rodgers claims Kelly initiated non-permissive sex and failed to inform her he had herpes, which she contracted. The case is now pending in New York's Supreme Court, with Kelly's legacy potentially facing a legacy of pain and suffering.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Lian Beng, Trek 2000, ST Engineering, CSE Global
summary: Lian Beng posted a 21.3% increase in net profit to S$7.7 million for its second quarter, driven by construction and investment holding segments. Trek 2000 International invested US$3 million in solar energy firm Terrenus Energy for a 7.5% stake. ST Engineering secured S$560 million in new marine contracts, while CSE Global secured S$84.8 million in infrastructure project contracts in the fourth quarter of 2018.

site_title: Ivanka Trump to help US choose candidate for World Bank
summary: Ivanka Trump, adviser to US President Donald Trump, will help the US choose a candidate to lead the World Bank, but she will not be the chosen candidate. The World Bank Board will start accepting nominations early next month and name a replacement for outgoing President Jim Yong Kim by mid-April. Other potential candidates include Treasury Undersecretary David Malpass and former US Ambassador Nikki Haley. The US has traditionally led the World Bank, but emerging market countries are increasing pressure to name a leader from such a country, and the Trump administration has shown little interest in the institution.

site_title: Interpreters demand to stay out as Trump row throws spotlight
summary: US President Donald Trump's relationship with Russia has raised concerns about the role of interpreters in diplomatic conversations. Trump's dismissal of top aides during his meeting with Vladimir Putin in 2017 and his alleged instruction to interpreter Marina Gross not to discuss the conversation with other administration officials have sparked debate about the confidentiality of interpreter notes. Interpreters, who are bound by a code of ethics to keep conversations private, are now in the spotlight, with some calling for greater transparency and others warning of the risks of breaching confidentiality.

site_title: Trudeau reshuffles cabinet ahead of election
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau reshuffled his cabinet ahead of the upcoming election, replacing Attorney General Jody Wilson-Raybould with Yale-educated David Lametti. The move comes as Ottawa and Beijing are at odds over the arrest of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou, who was released on bail pending an extradition hearing. Trudeau's Liberal Party is trailing in polls, raising the possibility of him losing his majority in parliament. Lametti's appointment may further strain relations with China if Meng is sent to stand trial in the US.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa: BMW Group Asia rolls out their 2019 lineup
summary: BMW Group Asia has rolled out its 2019 lineup, starting with the newly launched 3 series. Managing director Christopher Wehner discussed the company's focus on autonomous and eco mobility for the future. The conversation also touched on the importance of electric vehicles (EVs) and BMW's plans to adapt to the shift towards EVs. Wehner emphasized BMW's commitment to innovation and sustainability in the automotive industry.

site_title: China says detained Canadian lacks diplomatic immunity
summary: China has denied that a detained Canadian, Michael Kovrig, holds diplomatic immunity. Kovrig, a former Canadian embassy official, was arrested along with businessman Michael Spavor in January as retaliation for Canada's arrest of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou on a US extradition request. China's claims contradict Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's statements, which Trudeau doubled down on. The detentions have strained Canada-China relations.

site_title: Oil falls 1% on concerns about China slowdown
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Monday due to concerns about a global economic slowdown. China's weakening imports and exports, including a 2-year low in exports in December, raised worries about crude demand. Brent crude futures fell to $59.87 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell to $51.23 a barrel. The decline in oil prices is attributed to fresh concerns about global economic weakness.

site_title: Container throughput at Singapore port up 8.7% in 2018
summary: The Port of Singapore maintained a stable performance in 2018, with container throughput increasing 8.7% to 36.6 million TEUs and total cargo throughput remaining stable at 630 million tonnes. Annual vessel arrival tonnage reached 2.79 billion GT, and Singapore retained its position as the world's leading bunkering port. The country's maritime sector contributed 7% to its GDP, with over 5,000 maritime establishments generating 170,000 jobs.

site_title: China car sales shrink for first time in two decades
summary: China's car sales declined 13% in December, marking the sixth consecutive month of declines, and reached 28.1 million vehicles in 2018, down 2.8% from the previous year. The decline is attributed to the phasing out of purchase tax cuts on smaller cars and the Sino-US trade war. Despite forecasts of flat sales for 2019, analysts expect measures such as increased spending and rising demand for new energy vehicles to provide some relief, potentially driving sales growth to 7% this year.

site_title: Creative shares climb 3% on plans to tap OEMs
summary: Creative Technology's shares rose 3.08% as the company announced plans to work with original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) to integrate its Super X-Fi headphone technology into their products. The technology, which creates "three-dimensional" sound, garnered positive feedback at the CES show and received 10 awards from tech review sites. CEO Sim Wong Hoo stated that the OEM market is "potentially hundreds of times larger" than the market for Super X-Fi products, marking an exciting new phase for the company.

site_title: Brexit bravado sees UK Parliament taking back control of the process
summary: The UK Parliament is set to vote on the Brexit withdrawal deal on Tuesday, with Prime Minister Theresa May facing a potentially catastrophic defeat. If the vote fails, May must present a new Brexit plan within three days, and Brussels is preparing to delay Brexit day at least until July. A heavy defeat could trigger a no-confidence vote, a General Election, or a referendum on the Brexit deal. Markets are already pricing in the likelihood of a UK government loss, but a significantly narrower loss or a narrow win could sway the outcome.

site_title: Stiffer anti-money laundering rules for jewellers ahead
summary: Singapore is implementing stricter anti-money laundering rules for 2,500 jewellers and businesses dealing with precious stones and metals. The new Bill requires registered dealers to register with the Ministry of Law, conduct additional checks, and develop internal policies to tackle related risks. The regulations align with international standards set by the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) and will come into effect in the second quarter of this year. Businesses that fail to meet the new regulations face penalties, including suspension of registration and imprisonment.

site_title: US: Wall Street slides on China worries, earnings fears
summary: US stocks slid on Monday, marking a second consecutive negative close, as investor sentiment was dampened by concerns over the global economy. China's slowdown, highlighted by a 4.4% drop in exports and 7.6% drop in imports in December, fueled worries. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.4%, the S&P 500 lost 0.5%, and the Nasdaq declined 0.9%. The partial US government shutdown also contributed to the market's decline, with shares of Citigroup rising despite mixed quarterly earnings results.

site_title: Vallianz unit-managed vessel damaged in tanker collision
summary: A Vallianz unit-managed vessel, Star Centurion, suffered damage after colliding with a Hong Kong-flagged tanker, Antea, in Singapore waters on January 13. The incident occurred when the Star Centurion was at anchor. No injuries or casualties were reported, and all 22 crew members are safe. The subsidiary, Vallianz Offshore Marine, deployed personnel to the scene and arranged for the crew's return to Singapore. The cause of the collision is not specified.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower amid a fresh tariff salvo on Canada by President Trump. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Nissan CEO calls for Renault board to review Ghosn findings
summary: Nissan CEO Hiroto Saikawa is calling on Renault's board to review the findings of an investigation into chairman Carlos Ghosn, who was ousted by Nissan. The Japanese carmaker provided Renault lawyers with evidence more than a month ago, but Renault has not shared it with the board due to judicial confidentiality. Saikawa expects Renault's board to back Nissan's decision once they have access to the full dossier. Ghosn remains in office, with the French government supporting his position unless he is deemed incapacitated by the Japanese investigation.

site_title: AA Group signs MOU with OneAsia for data centre development
summary: AA Group signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with OneAsia Network to develop data centers at an industrial-zoned plot in Singapore. The MOU, valid for a year, aims to explore a potential joint venture or investment. OneAsia, a Hong Kong-based company, provides co-location data center services and cloud infrastructure solutions. This marks AA Group's foray into the data center industry, following its acquisition of Poh Huat Heng Corporation last month.

site_title: Indonesia recovers second black box from Lion Air crash
summary: Indonesia has recovered the second black box from the Lion Air crash, which killed 189 people. The cockpit voice recorder, found 10 meters from a previously recovered flight data recorder, is broken into two pieces but may still be useful to investigators. The discovery could provide more answers on the cause of the crash, which occurred just after takeoff. Preliminary reports suggest pilots struggled to control the plane's anti-stalling system, and the airline was criticized for its poor safety culture and recurrent technical problems. A final report is expected later this year.

site_title: Europe: Shares in reverse after shock China data; luxury stocks fall
summary: European shares fell 0.5% after China's weak trade data ended a four-day rally, with luxury goods and technology stocks leading the drop. The pan-European Stoxx 600 reversed gains that had reached a one-month high, with luxury goods firms like LVMH, Kering, and Moncler declining between 1.6% and 2.7%. The US earnings season also added to market nerves, with the S&P 500 expected to grow 14.5% in the fourth quarter, the slowest since 2017.

site_title: US car buyers swerve away from compact cars, sedans
summary: US car buyers are increasingly shifting away from compact cars and sedans, with SUVs and trucks dominating the market. Sales of traditional cars are expected to plummet to 21.5% of the US auto market by 2025, down from 31.2% in 2018. Major automakers, including Ford, General Motors, and Fiat Chrysler, have abandoned production of sedans due to lack of profitability and consumer interest. Analysts attribute the decline to consumers seeking more usable space, three-row seating, and luxury features in SUVs and trucks.

site_title: Asia on track to gain largest share of global capital markets: index
summary: Asia is poised to gain the largest share of global capital markets, with its average global share expected to increase from 31% in 2017 to 49% in 20 years. Half of this growth is attributed to China. The Global Financial Markets Association and New Financial developed the index, which tracks the size and growth of capital markets worldwide. Singapore's capital market is the 11th largest globally and second in terms of size relative to GDP. This growth opportunity is driven by the region's increasing economic influence and investment potential.

site_title: Construction demand in Singapore strong, set to hit up to S$32b this year: BCA
summary: Singapore's construction industry is expected to remain strong this year, with total demand projected to reach S$27 billion to S$32 billion. Public sector demand is expected to make up 60% of projected demand, driven by sustained public sector contracts. The industry has recovered from a challenging three-year spell, with an estimated S$30.5 billion in contracts awarded last year, a 23% increase from the previous year. The government's efforts to bring forward public projects and encourage local firms have helped the industry turn a corner.

site_title: Time to play defence, says Howard Marks
summary: Celebrity investor Howard Marks advises investors to be more defensive in their picks as the global bull run tapers off. He suggests worrying more about losing money than missing out on potential gains. Marks' warning comes as the global market experiences a slowdown.

site_title: Global auto leaders urge Trump administration to end trade turmoil
summary: Global auto leaders are urging the Trump administration to end trade turmoil, citing the impact of tariffs on US steel and aluminum prices. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles estimates US metal tariffs will increase costs by $135 to $160 per vehicle. The industry is seeking resolution on trade disputes with China and Canada, while a new regional trade agreement still requires congressional approval. Political uncertainty is costing the industry, with the auto executives calling for the government shutdown to be resolved.

site_title: Singapore will discuss outstanding issues with Malaysia calmly: Vivian
summary: Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan stated that the country will discuss outstanding issues with Malaysia in a calm and reasonable manner, despite not expecting a quick resolution. The issues include maritime and airspace boundary disputes. This approach reflects Singapore's commitment to resolving bilateral issues amicably, but acknowledges the complexity and time required for a resolution.

site_title: Online businesses in Singapore most globalised; policies a challenge: poll
summary: A survey by technology firm Stripe found that Singapore has the highest percentage of online businesses selling globally, with 72% of respondents. However, 60% of Singaporean online businesses reported it's more difficult to run an international business now compared to five years ago, citing government policies as the primary obstacle.

site_title: Antarctica ice loss increases six fold since 1979: study
summary: Scientists warn that global warming is melting Antarctica's ice six times faster than 40 years ago, with a six-fold increase in ice loss from 1979 to 2017. This has raised global sea levels by 1.4cm and is expected to lead to disastrous sea level rise in the coming centuries. The Antarctic ice sheet is shedding 252 billion tons of ice per year, with areas once considered stable now showing significant melting. If all the ice in Antarctica were to melt, it would raise sea levels by 57m, with the East Antarctic Ice Sheet holding the most ice and being the most sensitive to climate change.

site_title: Tuan Sing divests units in Century Warehouse property
summary: Singapore property developer Tuan Sing Holdings sold its majority-owned Century Warehouse property for S$48.5 million to a private investment company. The property comprises 35 strata units with a total area of 56,539 square feet. Tuan Sing will receive S$42.4 million for its part, with the deal to be completed by March 27, 2019.

site_title: How can South-east Asia produce more unicorns?
summary: South-east Asia has vast potential for startup growth, but scaling businesses remains a challenge due to the region's diverse ecosystems and regulatory environments. To overcome this, startups need access to the right ecosystems and partners to help them succeed. Joining a startup accelerator, such as Propell Asia, can provide access to mentorship, guidance, and networks, enabling startups to test, validate, and scale their solutions. Successful startups like Foyr, a proptech startup, have leveraged these resources to expand globally. By adopting a lean and dynamic approach and being open to changes, startups can better adapt to the different phases of their business and take advantage of the growing investment flows in the region.

site_title: A big step by CapitaLand and Temasek in play for global stakes
summary: CapitaLand has acquired Temasek subsidiary Ascendas-Singbridge (ASB) for S$23.6 billion, marking a significant milestone for the Singapore-listed developer and Temasek. The deal creates the largest real estate investment manager in Asia, with S$116.5 billion assets under management, propelling CapitaLand to the world's ninth biggest. The acquisition will add an interesting dimension to CapitaLand's portfolio, with over 80% of ASB's assets in business space and more than half in sectors exposed to the new economy. The union will also give CapitaLand the flexibility to deploy capital according to property cycles and increase its geographical exposure to new growth markets.

site_title: Thumb drive maker Trek invests US$3m in solar energy firm for 7.5% stake
summary: Thumb drive maker Trek 2000 International has invested US$3 million in solar energy firm Terrenus Energy for a 7.5% stake, aiming to enter the renewable energy industry. Terrenus Energy, incorporated in Singapore in 2016, operates in Singapore, Australia, and China, offering solar energy systems. Trek will collaborate with Terrenus Energy on smart renewable power systems, with Trek President Wayne Tan stating the company hopes to help Terrenus Energy grow to become a leading renewable energy provider.

site_title: UBS positive on global and Asia ex-Japan equities
summary: UBS analysts predict sharp volatility in 2019 due to geopolitics, but rule out a recession. Global growth is expected at 3.6%, slightly above the long-term trend, while Asia ex-Japan equities are forecast to reach 12-15% returns. However, Singapore's economic growth is expected at 2% due to vulnerability to tariffs, potentially slowing asset markets and job creation. UBS advises investors to stay invested according to their risk tolerance, with a focus on quality companies and value over growth.

site_title: ICP places 460m new shares at 0.85 Singapore cent apiece to CMIA
summary: Hotel management company ICP has placed 460 million new shares at 0.85 Singapore cent apiece to private equity firm CMIA Capital Partners, valuing the deal at S$3.9 million. This represents a 14.78% post-deal stake for CMIA. The shares were priced at a discount of 3.41% to the stock's volume weighted average price on Jan 10.

site_title: Detroit car show, and industry, prepare for transition
summary: The Detroit auto show, a premier event for the US car industry, is set to open on January 19, amidst concerns over the global economy and a US-China trade war. Carmakers, including General Motors, Ford, and Volkswagen, are expected to unveil fewer new models, marking a transition year for the industry. Analysts predict a contraction in North American car sales in 2019 due to rising interest rates, car prices, and tariffs on imported steel and aluminum. The show's relevance is also being questioned, with several German carmakers abandoning it this year.

images.alt_text: Luxury automobiles and supercars on display during the Gallery event at the MGM Grand Detroit ahead of the 2019 North American International Auto Show in Detroit, Michigan. The show will be noticeably light on exciting debuts this year as carmakers chase customers elsewhere.

site_title: Philip Glass tantalises with new symphony
summary: Philip Glass premiered his Symphony No. 12 at the Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles, featuring a prominent organ part and vocal lines set to David Bowie's lyrics from the Lodger album. The symphony, performed by the Los Angeles Philharmonic, showcased Glass's trademark minimalism with a freer, more expressive singing line. West African pop star Angelique Kidjo lent a jazzy feel to the score's central songs, with the performance improving as she relaxed into the unusual musical idiom. The evening also featured a surprise premiere of Gabriella Smith's Tumblebird Contrails, a stunningly scored soundscape that brought the audience to its feet.

site_title: Coffee price slump leaves farmers earning less than a cent a cup
summary: Global coffee prices have reached their lowest in nearly 13 years, with a kilogram of arabica beans trading at $2.09 per kilogram. This slump has left Ethiopian farmers, such as Gafeto Gardo, earning less than a cent per cup, threatening their livelihoods. Growers worldwide have warned of a "social catastrophe" unless struggling farmers' incomes can be boosted. Some companies, like Starbucks, are responding with initiatives to support smallholders, but a radical overhaul of the supply chain is needed to address the issue.

site_title: Hotel Marrison in Little India for sale at S$28-30m by expression of interest
summary: Hotel Marrison in Singapore's Little India is up for sale by expression of interest with a guide price of S$28-30 million. The 25-room boutique hotel has an average occupancy rate of over 85% and is located near popular attractions and amenities. Interest in commercial properties has heightened following cooling measures, with several hospitality sale transactions recently reported, including the sale of Oxley Holdings' Mercure and Novotel hotels. The EOI closes on February 26, 2019.

site_title: CapitaLand's S$11b buy is big, but will it be beautiful?
summary: CapitaLand is set to acquire Ascendas-Singbridge in a deal worth S$11 billion, expanding its assets under management to S$116 billion across 30 countries. The acquisition will add 100 properties, including logistics and data centers, and strengthen CapitaLand's presence in Singapore and other markets. State-owned Temasek Holdings will receive S$6 billion, with CapitaLand increasing its ownership to 51%. Analysts praise the deal for consolidating geographic exposure, asset types, and management expertise, but note potential challenges in managing a massive company with a global footprint.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure unit bags S$40m JTC deal for Jurong Island pipe rack project
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Holdings has secured a contract worth about S$40 million to design, build and operate pipe racks on Jurong Island for the Jurong Rock Caverns. The project involves constructing pipe racks along parts of Banyan Drive, Banyan Avenue, and the Jurong Island Highway. The contract was awarded by JTC Corporation to Pipenet, a wholly owned subsidiary of Keppel Infrastructure. The project is expected to facilitate pipeline connection to the Jurong Rock Caverns.

site_title: Saudi weddings: small is the new beautiful
summary: In Saudi Arabia, millennials are opting for smaller, more intimate weddings, defying traditional lavish celebrations and saving thousands of riyals. With the country's economy facing austerity measures and low crude prices, younger generations are cutting back on extravagant weddings. Average spending on marriages has dropped by 25% over the past year, with many hosting weddings at home, reducing costs on decorations, entertainment, and dowry. This shift is seen as a war on excess and a response to the economic strain on families, with some even starting self-help groups to counsel young men on managing social pressure to overspend.

images.alt_text: Saudi groom Basil Albani dancing with his friends at his home during his wedding in Jeddah. It was a Saudi wedding like any other, but there was one striking difference - a tiny guest list.

site_title: Hong Kong's finance chief welcomes 'orderly' declines in home prices
summary: Hong Kong's finance chief, Paul Chan, welcomed the city's 9% decline in home prices since August, describing the market correction as "orderly." He stated there are no plans to relax housing market curbs, including stamp duties and loan-to-value ratios, which were tightened to curb the market. The finance chief's comments came after a blog post by Chan sparked speculation about easing mortgage restrictions, prompting a developer rally.

site_title: MAS moves to attract listings, boost equity research talent
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a S$75 million initiative called the Grant for Equity Market Singapore (GEMS) to boost equities research and enhance Singapore's status as a hub for equity listings. The grant will co-fund listing costs and salaries of equity research hires, with a focus on the "new technologies" sector. The scheme aims to improve quality of coverage, attract more researchers, and support companies in the early growth and expansion stages. MAS will also crowdsource initiatives to drive the development of Singapore's equity research ecosystem.

site_title: England's universities flunk their finance exams
summary: England's universities are facing financial struggles due to Brexit and demographic dips, resulting in reduced student intake. Smaller, less well-funded institutions are struggling financially, with some breaching banking covenants and relying on temporary loans. The Office for Students has given all registered institutions a clean bill of health, but experts warn that financial difficulties could worsen. Universities may need to consider asset sales, redundancies, or mergers to stay afloat, and some are turning to Revolving Credit Facilities to tide themselves over until the 2020s.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust maintains a "buy" rating with a target price of S$2.11, driven by a tapering supply of new office space and an expected upturn in office rent. The trust benefits from its largest market share in Singapore's CBD with 81% of its portfolio being grade-A office buildings. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss in the second half of 2025.

site_title: Retailer Sears' bankruptcy raises issues about the cost of going broke
summary: Sears Holdings Corp, a 126-year-old US retailer, is considering bids for its assets, including a $5 billion proposal by chairman Eddie Lampert, amid its bankruptcy. The company's bankruptcy highlights the high costs of Chapter 11 bankruptcy, with estimated fees of over $1 billion, including $5 million billed by law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges. Critics blame these fees for reducing the amount left for creditors and employees, while corporate leaders are willing to pay top dollar for the company's survival. The case has sparked concerns about the cost of going broke in the US bankruptcy system.

site_title: Gin's journey in Britain: From 'mother's ruin' to a hipster drink
summary: Gin sales in Britain have surged, reaching nearly £2 billion in 2018, making it the country's second-most-popular spirit. The growth is attributed to entrepreneurial bottling and branding, as well as the rise of craft distilleries. The industry has become a tourist attraction, with many distilleries offering tours and tastings. Despite concerns of overkill, the industry is seeking new growth overseas, with international brands and smaller distilleries emerging. Gin's popularity is seen as a sign of a growing food culture in the UK, with consumers willing to spend money on premium products.

site_title: Leveraging technology in greening the future
summary: Singapore-based landscaping company Mao Sheng Quanji Construction is embracing technology to stay relevant in a competitive industry. The firm has invested in high-tech solutions, such as spider lifts and drones, to increase productivity and reduce labor hours. Mao Sheng also offers overseas university scholarships to attract young talent, with one beneficiary, Carissa Kwa, now pursuing a degree in horticulture sciences. The company's efforts aim to change the public's perception of the landscape industry and inspire the next generation of urban-greening professionals, with a goal of making Singapore a greener and more sustainable city.

site_title: Kimly chairman up for re-election amid probe
summary: Kimly, a Singaporean coffeeshop operator listed on the Catalist, is seeking the re-election of its executive chairman Lim Hee Liat at an AGM on Jan 30. The company is under investigation by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Commercial Affairs Department over a controversial purchase of a drinks firm, Asian Story Corporation. Lim and another director are up for re-election, and the AGM will also vote on a share buyback mandate and a shareholders' mandate. The company's shares closed flat at S$0.24 amid the ongoing probe.

site_title: Trump authors art of no-deal in Washington
summary: US President Donald Trump's inability to negotiate a deal to end the longest-ever government shutdown, now in its fourth week, highlights his lack of deal-making skills in Washington. The shutdown's impact on federal workers, many of whom are struggling financially, has led to some considering joining the gig economy. Trump's failure to deliver on key campaign promises, such as a border wall, has also exposed his leadership skills. A recent poll shows Americans blame Trump and Republicans for the shutdown, and he faces a difficult decision: declaring a national emergency or trying to reach a deal with Democrats without a wall.

site_title: Fintech firms want to shake up banking, and that worries the Fed
summary: The US Federal Reserve is concerned about granting licenses to fintech firms like OnDeck Capital and Kabbage, which could disrupt traditional banking. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and FDIC are exploring granting federal bank-like licenses to these tech-driven firms, offering financial services such as money transfers and lending. This move has raised concerns about the Fed's role in regulating the financial sector.

site_title: China data woes end STI upward streak
summary: Asian markets declined broadly on Monday following China's worse-than-expected December export and import figures, indicating further weakness in the world's second-largest economy and signs of a global slowdown. China's exports shrank 4.4% and imports fell 7.6% from a year earlier, overshadowing optimism from last week's trade talks. The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,173.46, down 25.19 points or 0.79%, after a six-day winning streak. Analysts predict the STI to recover to 3,500 on easing US-China trade frictions and interest rate hikes.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Karin Technology Holdings sees a 21.3% increase in net profit to S$7.7 million for its second quarter, driven by lower cost of sales. ST Engineering secured S$560 million in new contracts, including a marine contract for the Singapore Police Coast Guard and a power plant order from Seaboard Corporation. Tee International is still reviewing proposals for its subsidiary, Tee Land, after being approached by interested parties.

site_title: Samsung targets India millennials with M series phones
summary: Samsung Electronics Co unveiled the M series of inexpensive smartphones for India, targeting millennials with prices under 20,000 rupees. The three devices, including the cheapest at under 10,000 rupees, will launch on February 5, aiming to regain ground lost to Chinese rivals. The M series features a 5000mAH battery, at least two cameras, and a 6.2-inch screen, designed for entertainment, shopping, and gaming. The move seeks to tap into India's fastest-growing smartphone market, where Samsung aims to capture new customers in the mid-tier and low-tier smartphone segment.

site_title: When diffusion hits a snag
summary: Singapore's fintech sector is set to receive a boost with the passage of the Payment Services Bill, which strengthens consumer protections and regulates e-money issuance. The bill provides safeguards for personal e-wallets, including e-wallet and transfer limits, to protect vulnerable users. Despite Singapore's early adoption of cashless payments, consumer resistance to mobile payment remains a challenge, driven by concerns over security, complexity, and compatibility. To address this, the industry must focus on trust, design, and communication, with initiatives such as education and design interventions to enhance e-payment interfaces and promote good financial habits.

site_title: TSMP Law adds China desk, new staff and partners
summary: TSMP Law firm in Singapore has expanded its operations by adding a new China desk, new staff, and partners. June Ho joined as a partner on January 1, working alongside Stefanie Yuen Thio and Jennifer Chia. The move aims to increase the firm's volume of international work.

site_title: Aussie dollar, yuan sink on China export slump
summary: The Australian dollar and kiwi dollar fell 0.4% on Monday due to fears of a slowdown in China's economy, triggered by a contraction in Chinese exports. The yuan also fell as investors shifted to safe-haven assets like the Japanese yen. Market sentiment is negative, with the Aussie dollar heavily influenced by its trade relationship with China. The dollar index dropped 0.1% to 95.56, while the euro remained relatively unchanged.

site_title: Hyflux's TuasOne may get early injection of S$23m from Mitsubishi
summary: Hyflux's TuasOne waste-to-energy project may receive an early injection of S$23 million from Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (MHI) if a definitive agreement is reached by Jan 31. The additional funding would address liquidity problems and ensure project completion. The project, valued at S$750 million, is crucial for Hyflux to generate revenue and meet its debt obligations. A firm deal would also enable discussions with lenders to amend project finance agreements, potentially avoiding further cost increases.

site_title: Trump predicts US will reach trade deal with China
summary: US President Donald Trump predicted the US will reach a trade deal with China, stating Beijing wants to negotiate and talks are going well. Trump has vowed to increase tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese imports if China fails to address intellectual property theft and other non-tariff barriers. Mid-level talks in Beijing last week were the first face-to-face discussions since Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping agreed to a 90-day truce in the trade war. Vice Premier Liu He is expected to visit Washington later this month.

site_title: Best World to invest in A*Star startup with an eye on stem cell-based products
summary: Best World International is investing S$5.63 million in A*Star spinoff Celligenics, a stem cell research and development company, through a share subscription agreement. The investment aims to leverage synergies between the two companies in the health and wellness sector. Best World will have the option to increase its stake to 15% after 18 months, and the deal is contingent on certain conditions.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 115.42 points, or 0.48%, to 23,880.53, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The decline follows Citigroup's unexpected fall in revenue and resurfaced fears of a global economic slowdown. China's trade data showed an unexpected drop, adding to concerns.

site_title: Amid Oscar controversy, Kevin Hart has a number 1 movie to savour
summary: Kevin Hart's movie "The Upside" has reached No. 1 at the box office, selling $19.6 million in tickets during its first weekend. Despite receiving an unenthusiastic critical response, the film exceeded expectations and beat out "Aquaman," which had held the top spot for three weeks. The film's success comes after Hart faced controversy surrounding homophobic tweets from his past, which led to him dropping out as Oscar host.

images.alt_text: From left: Bryan Cranston, Nicole Kidman and Kevin Hart. The Upside, a drama-comedy starring Hart as a black parolee who becomes the caregiver and pal of a wealthy, white quadriplegic man played by Cranston, knocked off the titanic Aquaman to take top spot at the box office.

site_title: Ophir Energy rejects Medco's buyout offer
summary: Ophir Energy Plc has rejected Medco Energi Internasional Tbk PT's buyout offer of 340 million pounds, stating it "undervalues" the British energy company. Medco had made several overtures for Ophir, initially offering 58 pence per share before reducing it to 53.8 pence. Ophir's board unanimously rejected the offer, with analysts urging the company to lay out its vision. The decision comes after Ophir's shares lost nearly half of their value last year due to financing issues with a liquefied natural gas project in Equatorial Guinea.

site_title: Acra fines Swiber directors for failure to hold 2017 AGM by deadline
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) has fined Swiber directors for failing to hold the 2017 annual general meeting by the deadline of December 1, 2017, and not laying the FY2016 financial statements at the AGM. The directors have accepted composition fines and Acra will not proceed with further prosecution.

site_title: Lian Beng's Q2 earnings up 21%, despite revenue decline
summary: Lian Beng Group reported a 21.3% increase in net profit to S$7.7 million for its Q2 2018, despite a 15.3% decline in revenue to S$79.9 million. Lower cost of sales contributed to the earnings boost, with earnings per share rising to 1.55 Singapore cents. The revenue drop was mainly due to lower property development segment revenue, offset by increased revenue from construction and investment holding segments.

site_title: N Korea's nuclear programme quietly advances
summary: North Korea's nuclear program has continued to advance despite leader Kim Jong Un's claims of stopping nuclear production in 2018. Satellite imagery and leaked US intelligence suggest the country has produced rockets and warheads at a rapid pace, with estimates suggesting it has over 20 nuclear bombs. Analysts believe the regime has expanded its arsenal, including intercontinental ballistic missiles, and is secretly developing new technologies to strike the US. The US and North Korea are set to hold a second summit, with the US seeking verification of denuclearization, but Kim's intentions remain unclear.

site_title: Governance standards must constantly be nudged upwards
summary: Singapore's capital market is considered developed due to its openness to foreign ownership, ease of capital movement, and efficient market institutions. However, liquidity is lacking in debt and equity markets, making it still an emerging market. The country's deregulation has opened its borders to investors, providing access to various financial instruments, and there is a strong international element in listed companies. Despite these factors, the market's regulatory standards and market efficiency are not on par with advanced economies like the US, Europe, and Japan.

site_title: Weak monthly China trade data points to slower growth ahead
summary: China's exports fell 4.4% in December, its sharpest monthly drop in two years, while imports declined 7.6% due to the ongoing trade war with the US. Global trade is expected to slow, with China's shipments to major trading partners contracting in December. The trade war's impact on China's economy is growing, with manufacturing data below expectations and annual GDP growth expected to fall under 6.5% in 2019. Analysts predict the trade war will drag on into 2019, with limited positive impact on economic growth due to uncertainty and higher tariffs.

site_title: US government shutdown drags into fourth week amid stalemate
summary: The US government shutdown entered its 24th day, with President Donald Trump remaining unmoved to act amid a stalemate with congressional Democrats. Trump rejected a proposed $1.3 billion in border security funding, instead calling for $5.7 billion for his long-promised border wall. The shutdown has affected 800,000 federal employees, causing partial closures of airports and shuttering national parks. The White House is scheduled to address the issue, with Trump set to meet with farmers and lawmakers are set to reconvene on Monday to address the lapsed funding measures.

site_title: Offline and online to blend in the future of global retail
summary: The global retail industry is experiencing a shift towards blending online and offline platforms, with companies investing in e-commerce and delivery services to reach customers. However, despite the hype around online retailing, online sales' share of total retail sales remains modest, with 3% in India and 9% in the US. Meanwhile, traditional retailers are also expanding their online presence, with Alibaba and JD.com investing in physical stores and Amazon acquiring Whole Foods. The future of retail is likely to be a hybrid model, with both online and offline sales platforms co-existing to meet customer needs.

site_title: China envisions moon base after far-side success
summary: China plans to establish an international lunar base, with the first step being a mission to test equipment, scheduled for a future launch. The country aims to use 3D printing technology to build facilities. Following the success of landing a rover on the moon's far side, four more lunar missions are planned, including a probe to bring back moon samples by the end of the year. China, the US, Russia, and Europe are discussing the possibility of a research base or station on the moon.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.06 points to 1,676.16. Losers outpaced gainers 557 to 286, with volume reaching 2.2 billion lots worth RM1.4 billion.

site_title: CapitaLand courts growth with fresh Ascendas-Singbridge assets
summary: CapitaLand has acquired Ascendas-Singbridge (ASB) in a S$11 billion deal, expanding its portfolio in logistics, business parks, data centers, and other sectors. The acquisition will make CapitaLand Asia's largest and the world's ninth largest real estate investment manager, with assets under management (AUM) reaching S$116 billion. The deal is expected to boost CapitaLand's growth, with a 40% increase in AUM and "meaningful scale" added in India, the US, and Europe. The company's gearing is expected to rise, but it plans to bring it back down through asset recycling and cash from operations.

site_title: Saudi Arabia set for US$11b asset-sale blitz after slow start
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to generate approximately $11 billion by 2020 through its privatization program, including the sale of stakes in utilities, soccer clubs, flour mills, and medical facilities. Despite delays, including the IPO of oil giant Aramco, the government hopes to complete the sale of four flour milling companies and Saudia Medical Services facilities this year. However, the privatisation process has missed expectations, and market conditions do not suggest an acceleration in privatisations, according to analysts.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: CapitaLand agreed to buy Temasek's Ascendas-Singbridge unit in a S$11 billion deal, creating an Asian giant with S$116 billion in assets under management. The Monetary Authority of Singapore launched a S$75 million grant for enterprises seeking to raise capital through Singapore's equity market. Tighter anti-money laundering rules will be enforced on Singapore jewellers. Asia is expected to gain the largest share of global capital markets, with 49% expected by 2039. Singapore stocks closed 0.8% lower, while China's GDP growth is set to slow, and Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end down to snap six-day rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day down 1.38% after a six-day rally, closing at 26,298.33. The decline was attributed to profit-taking. Meanwhile, Chinese trade figures fell short of expectations, disappointing investors. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with losses of 0.71% and 0.73% respectively.

site_title: Is Corporate Singapore ready for a new tax world?
summary: The Singapore government faces complex choices in the 2019 budget to balance job and wealth creation with sufficient tax revenues to fund public spending. The country's tax system must adapt to the digital economy, where taxable profits are increasingly separate from traditional sales locations. Policymakers must ensure tax compliance and avoid aggressive tax competition, while businesses must incorporate tax into their corporate governance frameworks to balance responsibilities to different stakeholders. The government has initiatives in place to improve compliance, and businesses must take a strategic approach to their tax affairs to maintain fiscal prudence and a progressive tax system.

site_title: CSE Global clinches S$84.8m of infrastructure project deals in Q4 2018
summary: CSE Global secured S$84.8 million in infrastructure project contracts in Q4 2018, bringing its full-year 2018 orders to S$150.5 million, a 43.6% increase from 2017. The new contracts include government projects in Singapore involving process control, telecommunications, and security systems. The company expects these projects to contribute positively to its financial performance in 2019 and beyond, but are not expected to have a material impact on its earnings per share or net tangible assets per share.

site_title: India's move to probe any computer comes under top court's lens
summary: India's top court will examine a government directive allowing the interception and monitoring of information on any computer, potentially infringing on citizens' privacy. The three-judge bench sought the government's response to petitions challenging the December directive, which activists and an internet rights group describe as a surveillance scheme. The court may temporarily put on hold the decision, which has sparked a conflict with privacy rights groups and internet companies. The government defends the order as a continuation of an old policy, but opponents claim it's a move to harass those not supporting the government.

site_title: CapitaLand's S$11 billion mega deal 6 months in the making
summary: CapitaLand, a South-east Asia property giant, has announced a S$11 billion cash-plus-shares deal to buy Ascendas-Singbridge (ASB) from Temasek Holdings, creating the largest diversified real estate group in Asia. The deal, six months in the making, will vault CapitaLand into a global real estate player with combined assets under management exceeding S$116 billion. The acquisition strengthens CapitaLand's presence in core markets and adds scale in India, the US, and Europe, while bumping up fee income in the fund management space by 40%.

site_title: More interested parties make proposal for Tee Land after December's news of strategic review
summary: Tee International, the parent company of Tee Land, has received multiple proposals from interested parties following its strategic review announcement in December. The company has engaged in preliminary discussions with these parties, but no assurance has been given that a transaction will occur. Tee International is still reviewing the proposals and will make a decision on the future of Tee Land.

site_title: Top Bollywood director Hirani denies sexual assault allegations
summary: Bollywood director Rajkumar Hirani has denied allegations of sexually assaulting a subordinate over six months in 2018. The allegations, made by an unnamed woman nearly 30 years younger than Hirani, were reported in a Huffington Post India story. Hirani stated the allegations are "false, malicious and mischievous" with the intention of destroying his reputation, in a statement released through his publicist. The incident is the most high-profile Bollywood figure to face allegations since India's #MeToo movement began in September last year.

site_title: Aberdeen Standard Investments pumps US$13m minority equity in Singapore Life
summary: Aberdeen Standard Investments (ASI) has invested US$13 million in Singapore Life as a minority equity partner, bringing the total capital raised to US$97 million. This investment follows Aflac's recent US$20 million investment and will support Singapore Life's expansion plans across South-east Asia and new business technology ventures. ASI's involvement extends its strategic relationship beyond fiduciary asset management to participating in the growth of Singapore Life, a fully digital insurer. The investment adds credibility to Singapore Life's business model and sets the stage for the company's digital-first growth.

site_title: India's plunging inflation rate opens door to monetary easing
summary: India's annual retail inflation rate dropped to 2.19% in December, its lowest level in 18 months, as food prices fell for the third straight month. This has strengthened views that the central bank may ease monetary policy next month. Economists expect the Reserve Bank of India to soften its stance at its February meeting, potentially cutting interest rates. However, a substantial hike in federal spending ahead of national elections could push up prices.

images.alt_text: India's annual retail inflation rate dropped to an 18-month low of 2.19 per cent in December, strengthening views of some economists that the central bank could ease monetary policy next month as prices for many food items fell and the nation faces a manufacturing slowdown.

site_title: Thai capital fires water cannon into the air to fight pollution
summary: Thai authorities in Bangkok used water cannons to combat severe air pollution, blanketing the city in smog. The pollution, with hazardous PM 2.5 levels exceeding safe limits in 30 districts, prompted authorities to distribute masks and seed clouds to clear the air. Bangkok Governor Aswin Kwanmuang announced the measures as the city struggles with pollution issues.

site_title: India's softer wholesale inflation opens door to monetary easing
summary: India's wholesale inflation eased to an eight-month low of 3.80% in December, with food prices remaining flat and fuel costs halving. This easing of inflation strengthens views among economists that the Reserve Bank of India may ease its monetary policy stance next month. Annual industrial output growth slumped to 0.5% in November, and total passenger vehicle sales fell 0.43% in December. The data indicates rural incomes remain under pressure, while consumers benefit from easing inflation, which could impact the upcoming election.

site_title: Italy aims for decision on rail-link with France by May - minister
summary: Italy's Transport Minister Danilo Toninelli aims to decide by May whether to complete the TAV high-speed rail link between Lyon and Turin, a project opposed by the 5-Star Movement. The decision is crucial for the ruling coalition, with the far-right League wanting the project built and 5-Star opposing it. Toninelli believes a deal will be reached, and he will not consider it a defeat if the project goes ahead, stating he will ensure the project's financial viability is checked. The outcome could split the eight-month-old coalition.

site_title: PM May's no-Brexit warning sends pound to new 7-week high
summary: Sterling reached a new seven-week high against the dollar as Prime Minister Theresa May warned that a failure to approve her Brexit deal could lead to the UK staying in the European Union. May stated that a no-Brexit outcome is now more likely than a no-deal Brexit. This move boosted the pound, which rose 0.3% to a high of US$1.2879, amid dollar weakness and recent euro decline. Markets expect a last-minute deal or a disorderly exit to have different consequences for sterling, reducing expectations for significant swings.

images.alt_text: Sterling strengthened to new seven-week highs against the dollar on Monday as markets seized on Prime Minister Theresa May's warning that lawmakers' failure to approve her Brexit deal could lead to the UK staying in the European Union.

site_title: ST Engineering's marine arm wins S$560m in new contracts in Q4 2018
summary: ST Engineering's marine arm secured S$560 million in new contracts in Q4 2018. The contracts include designing and maintaining Fast Patrol Boats for the Singapore Police Coast Guard, a SeaFloat barge-mounted power plant for Transcontinental Capital Corporation, and a mechanical & electrical contract for the Jurong Island Desalination Plant. Additionally, the US shipyard received a contract from the Naval Sea Systems Command for the Oceanographic Survey Ship. These wins demonstrate the group's continued presence in the marine and engineering sectors.

site_title: JD Sports sees full-year profit at higher end of market view
summary: JD Sports Fashion Plc forecasted annual profit at the higher end of market expectations, maintaining gross profit margins despite a tough retail environment. The company reported a 5% increase in total like-for-like sales across its global stores, excluding recent acquisitions, for the 48-week period to January 5. This growth was driven by a "consistently positive like-for-like performance across Black Friday and the Christmas period." JD Sports expects full-year headline profit before tax to be at the higher end of a range between £325 million and £352 million.

site_title: Euro zone bond investors exercise caution ahead of Brexit vote
summary: Euro zone bond investors are exercising caution ahead of the Brexit vote in Britain's parliament, with yields sliding on Monday due to weak Chinese data and increased risk aversion. Despite a potential for safe haven euro zone bonds to rise after the vote, investors are awaiting further clarity. The future path of Britain's exit from the EU remains uncertain, with possible outcomes including a last-minute deal, a disorderly exit, or a new referendum. Meanwhile, Greek bond yields rose due to a potential snap election, and Italian bond yields also increased.

site_title: Singapore stocks end 0.8% lower on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks closed 0.8% lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index down 25.19 points to 3,173.46. About 1.28 billion securities worth S$727.42 million changed hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 242 to 142. Key players China Medical Group and LionGold Corp rose 0.1 Singapore cent each, while Sino Grandness Food Industry Group halted trading pending an announcement.

site_title: Australia shares end lower, miners sag on China trade slump
summary: Australian shares ended 0.02% lower on Monday, despite a positive start, due to a decline in mining and energy stocks following China's report of a 4.4% drop in exports and a 7.6% decline in imports. The ASX Metals and Mining index fell 0.3% as copper and aluminium prices dropped, while oil prices fell 1% and the ASX Energy index shed 0.8%. The financial sector, however, rose 0.4% with Westpac Banking Corp gaining 0.5%.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on disappointing Chinese trade data
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 11.05 points, or 0.53%, to 2,064.52, due to disappointing Chinese trade data, which showed exports and imports contracting in December, pointing to a weakening global economy. The Korean won lost 0.6% against the dollar, and shares of SK Hynix closed 4.6% lower on reduced DRAM sales expectations. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index fell 1.07%, amid global economic uncertainties and US-China trade tensions.

site_title: May will set out EU's sssurances to Parliament: Brexit update
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May is set to address Parliament on Monday with reassurances from the EU on her Brexit deal, amid concerns it may not pass. International Trade Secretary Liam Fox says it's "unlikely" the deal will succeed, but May will push on to find a solution. A draft law by opposition MPs aims to hand control over the Brexit process to senior Parliament members if the deal fails. The EU is expected to send a letter clarifying the Irish backstop's temporary nature, while May may consider a compromise modeled on Norway's relationship with the EU.

site_title: Thumb drive maker Trek injects US$3m in solar energy firm for 7.5% stake
summary: Thumb drive maker Trek 2000 International has invested US$3 million in solar energy firm Terrenus Energy Pte Ltd for a 7.5% stake, aiming to enter the renewable energy industry. Terrenus Energy, incorporated in Singapore in 2016, operates in Singapore, Australia, and China, offering solar energy systems through solar panel installations. This investment marks Trek 2000's foray into the renewable energy sector.

site_title: Singapore's online businesses most globalised, but government policies a hurdle: poll
summary: A report by Stripe found that Singapore has the highest percentage of online businesses selling globally, with 88% selling to markets outside their home country. However, 61% of Singaporean respondents believe that international operations are more challenging to handle now than five years ago, citing government policies as the main obstacle. The study also found that regulatory barriers and increasing protectionism are major hurdles for businesses globally, with online companies spending up to 37.8% of their net profit on regulation and compliance.

site_title: Investors should be playing defence, advises US investor Howard Marks
summary: US investor Howard Marks advises investors to be defensive due to the current market volatility, despite recent modest quantitative evidence. Marks notes that investors should consider their risk stance, focusing on not losing money rather than missing out. He believes the market is approaching the tail-end of a long bull market, but with optimism still present, particularly in FAANG stocks and Bitcoin. Marks predicts interest rates will continue to rise, but at a slower pace than in the past two years.

site_title: Asia to gain largest share of global capital markets over next few decades: index
summary: Asia is expected to gain the largest share of global capital markets over the next few decades, with the average global share of Asian capital markets increasing from 31% in 2017 to 49% in 20 years. Half of this growth is expected to come from China, according to the Global Financial Markets Growth Index. Asia-Pacific economies, including Singapore, have surpassed EMEA in capital market depth, and are fast catching up with the Americas.

site_title: Thailand to make it rain as pollution chokes Bangkok
summary: Thailand is set to deploy rainmaking planes to combat pollution in Bangkok, which has ranked as the 10th most polluted city in the world. The pollution is caused by traffic exhaust, agricultural burning, and factory emissions. Public discontent has risen on social media, with environmental group Greenpeace urging immediate action. The Thai government has downplayed the dangers, citing a PM2.5 level of 102 micrograms per cubic meter, but Greenpeace calls for smarter air quality management. Rainmaking efforts are expected to begin Tuesday, depending on wind and humidity levels.

site_title: Fintech firms want to shake up banking, and that worries the Fed
summary: The US Federal Reserve is hesitant to grant fintech firms, such as OnDeck Capital and Kabbage, access to the country's financial infrastructure, citing concerns over risk-management controls and consumer protections. Fintech firms argue that direct access to the payment system would reduce regulatory costs and allow them to compete more effectively with traditional lenders. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation are exploring granting federal bank-like licenses to tech-driven firms, which could expand access to financial services for small businesses and promote job growth.

site_title: Samsung targets Indian millenials with cheaper smartphones
summary: Samsung Electronics unveiled a new range of inexpensive smartphones for India, targeting millennials with devices priced below 20,000 rupees (S$383) each. The M series devices will launch on February 5, with the cheapest option selling for less than 10,000 rupees. The company aims to regain ground lost to Chinese rivals like Xiaomi in the world's fastest-growing smartphone market, where every vendor is seeking to boost fortunes.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets open lower
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened lower on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.5%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 losing 0.6%, and Paris's CAC 40 falling 0.9%. The decline was attributed to concerns about US-EU trade talks. In contrast, mining and healthcare stocks boosted shares in Europe. US stocks, however, edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching new highs.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets slid at the opening bell on Monday

site_title: Venture firm TRIVE spots a blue ocean in S-E Asia for NeuroTrend's grey matter
summary: TRIVE, a South-east Asia-focused venture firm, has invested $1.5 million in NeuroTrend, a market research startup that uses neuroscience to analyze consumer reactions to marketing efforts. NeuroTrend, led by CEO Natalia Galkina, has developed a proprietary algorithm and has secured clients such as Singapore Airlines. The investment is part of TRIVE's $10 million Singapore Seed Fund, which aims to support deep-tech startups in Singapore. TRIVE sees an opportunity in the emerging market of neuromarketing, where competitors are still few and barriers to entry are high.

site_title: Stiffer anti-money laundering rules for Singapore jewellers ahead
summary: Singapore is introducing stricter anti-money laundering rules for 2,500 jewellers and businesses dealing with precious stones and metals. Regulated dealers will need to register with the Ministry of Law, conduct additional checks, and file cash transaction reports. They will also need to perform due-diligence checks on customers and develop internal policies to tackle related risks. The new regulations align Singapore with global best practices, including recommendations from the Financial Action Task Force. Registered dealers have up to six months to complete registration and face penalties if they fail to comply.

site_title: As famous for beer as shops, billionaire shakes up Debenhams
summary: Billionaire Mike Ashley, owner of Sports Direct, has shaken up Debenhams by leading shareholders in ousting Chairman Ian Cheshire and removing CEO Sergio Bucher from the board after the department-store chain turned down a 40 million-pound loan offer. This move drives speculation that Ashley may acquire the struggling retailer. Analysts warn that such a step could be opportunistic and detrimental to Debenhams' future. Ashley's pursuit of retail assets comes at a challenging time for British retailers, who face threats from Amazon and Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Most Americans don't think their finances will improve in 2019
summary: A majority of Americans, 55%, expect their finances to worsen or remain the same in 2019, despite respectable economic data, according to a Bankrate.com report. The survey found that 49% blame Washington leadership, while 38% cite a heightened cost of living and 37% increased debt. However, millennials, aged 18-37, are more optimistic, with 60% expecting their finances to improve this year.

site_title: Euronext launches US$729m tender offer for Oslo Bors
summary: Euronext launched a US$729m all-cash tender offer for Oslo Bors, valuing the company at 6.24 billion Norwegian crowns. The offer, set to expire on Feb 11, is made at 145 Norwegian crowns per share. Despite Oslo Bors' board initially accepting the offer, it has since received alternative bids and will issue a recommendation by late February. The move aims to expand Euronext's portfolio and diversify its revenues, but faces competition regulator opposition to mega-mergers.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia ministers have 'productive', 'candid' talks after postponed annual meet
summary: Malaysia's Economic Affairs Minister Azmin Ali met Singapore ministers, including Vivian Balakrishnan and Khaw Boon Wan, during a visit, despite the postponement of their annual meeting. The ministers held "productive" and "candid" discussions on bilateral issues, reaffirming strong ties between the two neighbors. The meeting was postponed due to a provocative act by Johor Menteri Besar Osman Sapian, which created an "unconducive" atmosphere. Both sides expressed confidence in resolving bilateral issues and working together for the well-being of their people.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,185.27, down 0.42% on day
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.42% on Monday, closing at 3,185.27, with 187 losers outweighing 125 gainers. The Straits Times Index declined 13.38 points. The most actively traded stock was LionGold, with 72.7 million shares traded.

site_title: Bangkok residents told to stay inside as pollution reaches dangerous levels
summary: Bangkok residents are advised to stay indoors due to extremely high air pollution levels, reaching 182 on the air quality index. This surpasses pollution levels in cities like New Delhi, Beijing, and Jakarta. Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha urged people to avoid unnecessary outdoor activities or wear masks to minimize exposure. The pollution levels are considered hazardous, with readings above 300 considered extremely hazardous.

site_title: PODCAST: Wine education for F&B trade professionals and enthusiasts (Money Hacks, Ep 32)
summary: Veteran wine educator Lim Hwee Peng discusses the benefits of wine education for F&B trade professionals and enthusiasts in Singapore. He highlights that certification courses like the French Wine Scholar and Certified Specialist Of Wine programs can boost professional values. Lim suggests that Skills Future, a government initiative, may offset the costs of such courses. He emphasizes that wine education is valuable for business dealings in growing markets like China, where understanding wine can provide a competitive edge. The conversation aims to raise awareness about the importance of wine education in the industry.

site_title: Tuan Sing divests units in Century Warehouse property
summary: Property developer Tuan Sing Holdings has accepted a S$48.5 million tender bid for its majority-owned Century Warehouse property. The eight-storey industrial warehouse has 35 strata units and will be sold to a private investment company by March 27, 2019. Tuan Sing's subsidiary, Asiaview Properties, will receive S$42.4 million for their part of the property. The sale follows a public tender that closed on November 30, 2018.

site_title: Singapore building demand expected to stay strong on public sector contracts
summary: Singapore's construction demand is expected to remain strong this year, driven by sustained public sector contracts, with a projected value of S$27 billion to S$32 billion. Public sector demand is expected to make up 60% of total demand, with S$16.5 billion to S$19.5 billion in contracts awarded. The industry has recovered from a challenging three-year spell, with a 23% increase in construction demand compared to the previous year.

site_title: China doubles foreign investment limit, in further opening
summary: China has doubled the foreign investment limit for its Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor program to $300 billion, a move aimed at further opening its financial system amid trade tensions with the US. The quota increase is the first expansion since 2013 and is expected to boost the country's struggling capital markets. The move is seen as a symbolic step by Chinese policymakers to show they are committed to internationalizing markets and easing trade tensions. The expansion is also expected to attract more foreign investment and increase the country's global economic integration.

site_title: Cadillac takes aim at Tesla with SUV priced below Model X
summary: Cadillac is developing an electric SUV priced below Tesla's Model X, aiming to compete in the luxury market. The mid-sized SUV is expected to retail for around $50,000, comparable to similar gasoline-powered models. Cadillac President Steve Carlisle stated that electric vehicles need to be priced competitively to achieve sales volume, citing Tesla's Model Y as a benchmark. The vehicle will be built after 2021, and GM is using Tesla's electric vehicles as a reference point to develop its own electric models.

site_title: WeChat's star founder seeks second act for China's super-app
summary: WeChat's founder, Allen Zhang, is revamping the popular Chinese super-app, which has a billion users, to stay relevant. Zhang wants to shift from a curated, photo-centric Moments feed to a video-streaming feature that allows users to share real-life moments. He also plans to introduce a recommendation system, mini-programs, and a buildout of the lite-apps platform. Zhang aims to nurture WeChat's growth slowly, focusing on user engagement and social recommendation, and will maintain a clean interface and avoid bombarding users with ads.

site_title: Kimly to seek re-election of executive chairman who is under probe, at AGM
summary: Kimly, a catalist-listed coffeeshop operator, is seeking the re-election of its executive chairman Lim Hee Liat, who is under investigation by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Commercial Affairs Department. Lim is being probed for allegedly flouting the Securities and Futures Act in relation to a cancelled S$16 million cash purchase of a drinks firm. The company's AGM will be held on Jan 30, where shareholders will vote on renewing its share buyback mandate and the renewal of shareholders' mandate for interested person transactions.

site_title: Oil slides on China trade slump, but crude imports remain high
summary: Oil prices fell by almost 1% on Monday, with Brent crude slipping below $60 per barrel, due to weakening Chinese imports and exports. China's December exports fell 4.4% and imports 7.6%, indicating an economic slowdown. Despite this, oil imports remained high at 10.31 million barrels per day, and OPEC supply cuts have provided some support to crude prices, with Brent forecast to reach $64 per barrel and WTI at $55 per barrel.

site_title: China's exports shrink most in 2 years in December, raising risks for global economy
summary: China's exports shrank 4.4% in December, the largest decline in two years, while imports fell 7.6%, raising concerns about the global economy. The weaker-than-expected data suggests China's economy may have cooled faster than expected, despite recent growth-boosting measures. The country's trade surplus with the US widened to a record $323.32 billion, potentially leading to increased pressure on Beijing in its trade dispute with Washington. Analysts predict a further weakening in China's exports and a potential trade recession, with some warning of a more aggressive policy easing to stabilize GDP growth.

images.alt_text: China's exports unexpectedly fell the most in two years in December, while imports also contracted, pointing to further weakness in the world's second-largest economy in 2019 and deteriorating global demand.

site_title: AstraZeneca departures continue as medical chief Bohen exits
summary: AstraZeneca's chief medical officer Sean Bohen is leaving the company amid a wave of high-level departures following the reorganization of its research and development arm. Bohen will remain in his role until a successor is named. The departures, which include former Medimmune head Bahija Jallal and ex-product chief Mark Mallon, come as the company shifts focus to oncology, a rapidly growing area in the industry. CEO Pascal Soriot remains committed to the company, citing a desire to give his successor the opportunity to implement the reorganization.

images.alt_text: AstraZeneca Plc's chief medical officer is leaving, adding to a wave of high-level defections amid a reorganization of the U.K. drugmaker.

site_title: Australia Wesfarmers' department store sales sag, shares drop
summary: Australia's Wesfarmers Ltd reported slower-than-expected sales at its discount department stores, Kmart, over Christmas, with same-store sales slipping 0.6% for the first time in seven years. Clothing sales weakened, particularly womenswear, and exiting the low-margin DVD category reduced sales by 1 percentage point. Shares dropped 3% to a month low, amid broader concerns about the retail sector, following profit warnings from other companies.
