The company is undergoing a major portfolio overhaul, and investors will be watching its hardware business, Bunnings, for signs of slowing growth.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure unit bags S$40m JTC contract for Jurong Island pipe rack project
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Holdings has secured a contract worth S$40 million from JTC Corporation to design, build, and operate pipe racks on Jurong Island. The project, scheduled for completion by 2020, will facilitate pipeline connection to the Jurong Rock Caverns. The 15-year contract will not have a material impact on Keppel Infrastructure's parent company's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share. Pipenet, a subsidiary of Keppel Infrastructure, owns and operates a pipeline corridor network on Jurong Island.

site_title: Hong Kong's rural hinterland could hold key to chronic land crunch
summary: Hong Kong's government plans to build billions of dollars' worth of artificial islands to address the city's chronic land crunch, but critics argue that developers are hoarding unused land, including 1,000 hectares of agricultural land. The government's plan, estimated to cost up to $64 billion, could exhaust half of the city's financial reserves. Developers, including Henderson Land and New World Development, are sitting on the land, potentially reaping lucrative profits from holding onto it until it is rezoned for private development. Experts argue that the government should take back land from developers using a powerful colonial-era ordinance to meet the city's land needs.

site_title: Second black box from Lion Air crash found: Indonesian officials
summary: Indonesian officials have found the cockpit voice recorder from the Lion Air plane that crashed in October 2018, providing a crucial piece of evidence in the investigation. The recovery was made in the Java Sea, and the recorder is expected to be brought to shore and analyzed. The discovery of the CVR, along with the previously recovered flight data recorder, offers a real chance for investigators to determine the cause of the crash that killed 189 people. The finding is seen as a significant breakthrough in the investigation.

images.alt_text: Divers have found the second black box from a doomed Lion Air jet that crashed last year killing all 189 people onboard, Indonesian authorities said Monday.

site_title: Absences among US airport screeners jump as shutdown drags on
summary: US airport screeners experienced a 2.1 percentage point increase in unscheduled absences, reaching 7.7% on Sunday, amid a 23-day government shutdown. The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) reported that security had not been compromised, but staffing shortages forced the closure of a security checkpoint and ticket counter at George Bush Intercontinental Airport. Screeners are among the lowest-paid federal employees, who will receive pay once the shutdown ends, but may struggle to pay bills in the meantime.

site_title: US pressures Germany over Russian gas pipeline
summary: US Ambassador to Germany Richard Grenell has threatened firms involved in the under-construction Russian gas pipeline with US sanctions, amid a transatlantic dispute over Europe's natural gas supply. Germany, backed by France and Austria, insists the pipeline is an economic project, while the US argues it would deprive Ukraine of vital transit income and isolate it from its allies. Chancellor Angela Merkel has committed to protecting Ukrainian interests, but Germany has also explored options to accept US sea shipments of liquefied natural gas.

site_title: TuasOne to get S$23m equity injection if Hyflux, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries ink binding deal by January
summary: Hyflux, a debt-ridden water treatment company, is set to receive an additional S$23 million equity injection from Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (MHI) for its TuasOne waste-to-energy project. The deal is contingent on a binding agreement by January 31, 2019, and will allow Hyflux and MHI to discuss amendments to project finance agreements with TuasOne lenders to secure funding. This move comes as Hyflux implements cost-cutting measures and meets with investors to discuss its financial situation.

site_title: Weak India industries prompt calls for RBI to downgrade growth
summary: India's weak industries are prompting calls for the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) to downgrade its economic growth projection for the current fiscal year. Data showed industrial production in November grew 0.5% from a year ago, lower than expected. Analysts at SBICap Securities Ltd. and Nirmal Bang Equities Ltd. are urging the RBI to lower its growth projection to around 7% from 7.4% to reflect the likely case of below 7% expansion in the second half. Weaker growth and muted inflation are also adding to calls for interest rate cuts this year.

site_title: Asia: Markets in retreat after week-long rally
summary: Asian markets retreated on Monday after a six-day rally, with Hong Kong leading the sell-off after a 1% decline. The US government shutdown, now in its fourth week, and the upcoming Brexit vote also contributed to the losses. The losses follow a negative lead from Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. Analysts point to a lack of concrete details in US-China trade talks and growing concerns about the impact of the partial government shutdown on the US economy.

site_title: Sino Grandness requests trading halt after share price plunge prompts SGX query
summary: Sino Grandness Food Industry Group requested a trading halt in Singapore after its share price plummeted 12.7% to S$0.117 due to unusual trading volume. The company was queried by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for the unusual movement. By the time the halt was requested, 4.2 million shares had changed hands, exceeding the average three-month volume of 330,000. The cause of the sudden drop in share price remains unclear.

site_title: Unhappy with Ford's performance, CEO looks to rival for relief
summary: Ford Motor Co CEO Jim Hackett is unhappy with the company's performance, citing a need for a costly overhaul. To fund this, he's considering a broader alliance with Volkswagen AG, aiming to share costs on new models, battery-powered vehicles, and self-driving technology. Hackett believes working with rivals is necessary to fund the change and prepare for the autonomous age. The alliance could involve VW building Ford-branded products in Europe, where Ford is restructuring and cutting thousands of jobs. Hackett ruled out selling the Ford brand, instead opting for cooperation with like-minded competitors.

site_title: Best World in share subscription pact with A*star biomedical spin-off Celligenics
summary: Best World International is investing in A*Star spin-off Celligenics through a share subscription, taking a 12.5% stake in the biomedical startup. The investment, valued at S$5.63 million, will be in two phases, with the option to increase the stake to 15% within 18 months. Celligenics is in the early stages of stem-cell research and development, collaborating with local institutions.

site_title: Grab inks one-year rewards tie-up with CapitaLand
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing company, has partnered with property group CapitaLand for a one-year loyalty program tie-up. Grab users in Singapore can convert their points into STAR$ points, granting access to perks such as CapitaVouchers. Merchants can also utilize Grab's user base, while CapitaStar members will receive Grab perks like promo codes. The partnership aims to introduce GrabPay's cashless payment system to CapitaLand malls. This is the latest expansion for GrabPay, which has partnered with AsiaMalls since December 2018.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 0.12 points to 1,683.10. Volume reached 49.78 million lots worth RM9.86 million. Gainers beat losers 114 to 58. The index has not been mentioned in the other articles provided.

site_title: D&G back on fashion runway after China fiasco
summary: Dolce & Gabbana returned to the Milan Fashion Week runway after a China controversy in 2018, where the designers apologized for using derogatory language and posting insensitive content. The Autumn-Winter 2019-2020 collection, Eleganza, featured 1930s Berlin decadence and showcased quirky, glamorous styles. Although some Chinese online retailers are boycotting D&G, the designers attempted to salvage their reputation by apologizing in Mandarin. The collection's focus on Italian craftsmanship and cloth was a key aspect of the event, which received a positive response from the audience.

site_title: Chilean Patagonia: an open-air lab to study climate change
summary: Scientists from the Austral University of Chile conducted a study in Chile's Patagonia region, known as Seno Ballena, to analyze the effects of climate change on the world's oceans. The researchers found lower levels of pH, salinity, and calcium in the fjord waters, which could impact marine life, including whales, dolphins, and krill. The study aims to establish a baseline for the region's ecosystem and predict future changes due to increased carbon dioxide emissions and glacier melting. The findings could inform environmental preservation projects globally.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Monday with small losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks started trading on Monday with small losses, following a six-day rally that saw a significant gain. The Hang Seng Index eased 0.40% to 26,559.68, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw minimal changes. The losses come ahead of the corporate earnings season, which may impact investor sentiment.

site_title: Britain launches task force to tackle dirty money
summary: Britain launches a task force to combat dirty money, fraud, and corruption, involving senior banking figures. The Economic Crime Strategic Board aims to tackle offences such as bribery and money laundering, with estimated £14.4 billion in economic crime committed annually. The task force will focus on cracking down on money from Russia, Nigeria, and former Soviet states. The UK is leading the world in the fight against illicit finance, with officials seeking to increase resources to combat corruption and protect law-abiding citizens.

site_title: China's global trade surplus fell 16.2% in 2018: customs
summary: China's global trade volume rose 12.6% to $4.62 trillion in 2018, but its trade surplus fell 16.2% to $351.76 billion due to a 15.8% increase in imports and a 9.9% increase in exports. The decline in the surplus was attributed to a 7.9% decrease in soybean imports from the US, following a 25% retaliatory tariff imposed by China. This marks the second consecutive year of a trade surplus decline, raising concerns about China's economic growth and trade policies.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed on Monday for holiday
summary: Japan's financial markets were closed on January 14, 2019, for a public holiday, with trading resuming on Tuesday. In contrast, markets in Singapore, Europe, and the US continued to operate. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records in the US, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty, while the STI rose 0.4% in Singapore.

site_title: Shutdown effects being felt at airports
summary: The partial US government shutdown is affecting airport operations, with staffing shortages reported across the country. At least one major airport, Miami International Airport, has temporarily shut down a concourse due to high numbers of TSA employees calling in sick. The shutdown has led to reports of long security lines, with some airports opening food pantries to support TSA workers. Despite claims of no major delays, airport officials warn that the situation could worsen if the shutdown isn't resolved soon. Smaller airports are particularly vulnerable, and some airports are exploring contingency plans to mitigate the impact.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Creative Technology, Keppel Corp, Best World, ICP
summary: CapitaLand acquired Temasek's subsidiary Ascendas-Singbridge in a S$11 billion deal, aiming to create Asia's largest diversified real estate group. Creative Technology is ready to work with OEMs to incorporate its Super X-Fi headphone technology. The company's shares rose S$0.99 from its opening price.

site_title: Fire destroys storied Shakespearean theatre in Stratford, Connecticut
summary: A fire destroyed the 1,500-seat American Shakespeare Festival Theater in Stratford, Connecticut, a historic venue that once hosted Oscar-winning actors and Shakespearean productions. The theatre, modeled after the Globe Theatre in England, opened in 1955 and struggled with its identity before being closed in the late 1980s. Despite efforts to revive the site, the fire, which occurred on Sunday morning, was deemed a "tremendous loss" by community members and supporters, who remembered the theatre as a "national asset."

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday, STI up 0.08% to 3,201.36
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index advancing 2.71 points, or 0.08%, to 3,201.36. Gainers outnumbered losers 65 to 36, with notable movers including Jiutian Chemical, which rose 5%, and Singtel, which rose 0.65%. The market's rally continues ahead of upcoming GDP data and amid a strong US stock market.

site_title: Thanks for sharing? US politicans' online tone seeks an authentic like
summary: US politicians, including Beto O'Rourke, Elizabeth Warren, and Cory Booker, are using social media to raise their national profiles and raise millions in donations. They are sharing personal and unfiltered content, such as dentist appointments and selfies, to appear more relatable to new voters. While this approach is seen as bold and promising, it also carries risks. The article does not provide further information on the impact of this strategy on their careers or the broader implications of their online presence.

site_title: China's global trade surplus fell in 2018: customs
summary: China's global trade volume rose 12.6% to $4.62 trillion in 2018, but its trade surplus fell 16.2% to $351.76 billion due to increased imports. The surplus with the US, a key concern for President Trump, also declined. China's imports of soybeans from the US fell 7.9% after a 25% retaliatory tariff was imposed. The country aims to improve its business environment and expand foreign trade to maintain stability. Trade talks with the US are ongoing, with China committed to resolving trade frictions.

site_title: The world has loads of sustainable palm oil... but no one wants it
summary: The world's largest palm oil producers are producing more sustainable palm oil, but consumers are unwilling to pay a premium for it. Despite a record 13.6 million metric tons of sustainable palm oil being produced, only half is sold as certified sustainable oil. Companies like Mondelez and Nestle are working to source 100% certified sustainable palm oil, but demand remains low, particularly in India, China, and Indonesia. The industry is urging consumers to put their money where their mouths are, as the lack of demand is causing producers to sell certified oil at a loss.

site_title: UK rejects case for relaxation of fracking regulations: FT
summary: Britain has rejected a case for relaxing fracking regulations, with Energy Minister Claire Perry stating that the current system is "fit for purpose". The decision comes despite warnings from Cuadrilla, a shale gas developer, that the regulatory system risks "strangling" the industry. Cuadrilla has been forced to pause operations at its site in northwest England due to seismic activity exceeding 0.5 magnitude. The government is keen to reduce the country's reliance on imports of natural gas, but environmentalists argue that fracking is at odds with Britain's commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Brexit takes toll on Britain's financial sector, outlook weak
summary: Britain's financial sector faces a significant downturn due to Brexit uncertainty, with demand shrinking for the first time in five years. Profitability in the sector has been flat for the third quarter in a row, and is expected to drop for the first time in three years. Many financial institutions are opening EU hubs to avoid being locked out of the continent, while business optimism and expectations have deteriorated. The sector's outlook remains weak, with investment managers reporting a "striking loss of momentum" and a decline in overseas business.

site_title: May heads to Brexit-backing city to make last-ditch plea to rebel MPs
summary: Theresa May is set to make a final plea to rebel MPs in parliament on Tuesday, warning that rejecting her EU divorce deal would be "catastrophic" for British democracy. The Prime Minister is expected to lose the vote, with the opposition Labour Party suggesting a no-confidence vote in the government if MPs reject the plan. If the government loses, a 14-day period will be triggered, allowing parties to seek an alternative working majority or a general election.

site_title: MAS to boost Singapore's standing as enterprise financing hub with S$75m grant
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is launching a S$75 million grant, called the Equity Market Singapore (GEMS), to boost Singapore's standing as an enterprise financing hub. The three-year initiative will provide grants for companies seeking to raise capital through Singapore's equity market, including a listing grant and research talent development grant. The grants will vary depending on the enterprise sector and market capitalization, with the goal of strengthening Singapore's position as the go-to venue in Asia for enterprises seeking growth financing. The program will commence on February 14.

images.alt_text: MAS is launching a S$75 million grant for equity market Singapore (GEMS) in February to help enterprises seeking to raise capital through Singapore's equity market.

site_title: CapitaLand to buy Temasek unit Ascendas-Singbridge in S$11b deal, creating Asian giant
summary: CapitaLand is acquiring Temasek's unit Ascendas-Singbridge in a S$11 billion deal, creating Asia's largest diversified real estate group. The combined group will have over S$116 billion in assets under management across 30 countries, with a significant presence in Singapore, China, India, and the US. The deal will give CapitaLand a 51% stake in the company, boosting its ownership and adding a portfolio of operating assets and development projects. The acquisition is expected to be completed by the third quarter of this year and will create a strong and resilient company capable of delivering sustainable returns.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: Recovering from bad press & rebuilding customer confidence
summary: A Singapore-based Irvins Salted Egg faced backlash after a lizard was found in a snack pack. Branding expert Jörg Dietzel discussed strategies for recovering from bad press and rebuilding customer confidence on Money FM's "The Hot Seat" podcast. Dietzel emphasized the importance of acknowledging the issue, taking responsibility, and implementing corrective measures to restore trust with customers. By doing so, companies can minimize the negative impact and regain customer confidence.

site_title: Top Republicans oppose border 'emergency' as US government shutdown drags on
summary: Top Republican lawmakers oppose President Donald Trump's plan to declare a national emergency to secure funds for a border wall, as the US government shutdown enters its fourth workweek. Senator Ron Johnson and Representative Steve Scalise express concerns that the emergency declaration would lead to court battles and not resolve the issue. The move is opposed by Democrats, who urge Trump to put an end to the shutdown and negotiate with Congress. Public opinion is increasingly divided, with growing dissatisfaction over the shutdown, with many Americans blaming Trump and the Republicans for the impasse.

images.alt_text: Top Republican lawmakers on Sunday warned against Donald Trump declaring a national emergency to secure funds for a border wall, signaling doubts within the president's party as a government shutdown was set to enter a fourth workweek.

site_title: Creative says will enter OEM market after good response
summary: Creative Technology is entering the original equipment manufacturer (OEM) market after receiving a positive response to its Super X-Fi headphone technology at CES. CEO Sim Wong Hoo said the company will work with OEMs to incorporate Super X-Fi into their products, potentially reaching a larger market. However, revenue per unit for OEM shipments is expected to be lower than from direct sales. This marks an exciting new phase for Creative, following a surprise awards sweep at CES, where Super X-Fi Headphone Holography won 10 awards from various tech review sites.

site_title: Wife says ex-Nissan boss Ghosn suffers 'harsh' treatment in jail
summary: Carlos Ghosn's wife, Carole, has urged Human Rights Watch to highlight the "harsh treatment" her husband has received while detained in a Japanese jail. Ghosn, the former Nissan chairman, faces charges of under-reporting income and breach of trust. He is being held in a small, unheated cell and denied daily medication, resulting in a 7kg weight loss. Carole Ghosn claims prosecutors are trying to extract a confession through prolonged interrogations, and her husband believes he is "wrongly accused and unfairly detained." His lawyers predict a trial may take over six months.

site_title: Australian premier plans Fiji, Vanuatu visit to offset China influence
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison plans visits to Fiji and Vanuatu this week to counter China's growing influence in the South Pacific. Morrison will meet with Pacific island leaders and discuss Australian grants, loans, and defense ties. The trip follows China's recent meetings with Pacific Island leaders and Australia's $2 billion grant offer. Morrison also aims to resolve a citizenship issue between Australia and Fiji, revoking the citizenship of a man accused of being an Islamic State recruiter. The visits are part of Australia's "Pacific step-up" to strengthen its regional presence.

site_title: ICP places S$3.9m of shares at 0.85 Singapore cent apiece to CMIA
summary: Hotel management company ICP has placed S$3.9 million of new shares at 0.85 Singapore cent apiece to private equity firm CMIA Capital Partners, representing a 14.78% post-deal stake. The shares will be used for general corporate purposes. This placement dilutes ICP's non-executive chairman Aw Cheok Huat's stake to 20.56% from 24.14%. CMIA, focused on control and growth capital investments in China and Southeast Asia, manages the Yi Ming China Fund I LP, in which ICP had invested US$0.9 million.

site_title: Obama protege Julian Castro joins race for 2020 US presidency
summary: Former Obama cabinet member and San Antonio mayor Julian Castro has launched his bid for the 2020 US presidency, emphasizing a message of hope and diversity. Castro, a rising star in the Democratic Party, criticized President Trump's demand for a border wall, calling it a "crisis of leadership." Castro's strong oratorical skills, experience, and charisma could propel him into the top-tier of Democratic candidates, as he seeks to become the nation's first Hispanic president.

site_title: Detroit auto show, and industry, prepare for transition
summary: The Detroit auto show, a premier event for the North American auto industry, is preparing for a transition year amidst a contracting market and uncertainty. Carmakers face pressure from rising interest rates, car prices, and tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, which could impact new car sales and the industry's relevance. The show will feature fewer automakers and new car unveilings, with SUVs and trucks expected to dominate, as consumers shift away from sedans and small cars. Analysts predict a decline in North American auto sales in 2019, with potential tariffs exacerbating the issue.

site_title: Markets get lucky break during outage on Treasuries electronic platform
summary: BrokerTec, the largest electronic trading platform for US Treasury securities, experienced a technical malfunction, shutting down for over an hour on Friday. The outage, which lasted from 2:11 pm to 3:35 pm New York time, caused a market-wide slowdown but occurred at a calm time, minimizing its impact. Trading on other platforms, such as Nasdaq Fixed Income and Tradeweb Markets, remained unaffected. The incident highlights the importance of platform reliability in the $15.6 trillion US government bond market.

site_title: Macron unveils 'great national debate' to calm protests
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has launched a "great national debate" to address the country's growing protests, known as the "yellow vests," which have been ongoing for nearly two months. The debate, which will run from January 15 to March 15, will focus on 35 questions, including taxation, democracy, and the environment. Macron aims to transform "anger into solutions" and has promised to report back on the consultation in the month after the debates. The move is part of Macron's strategy to quell the protests, which have become the biggest crisis of his presidency.

site_title: MFA welcomes Malaysian minister's initiative to visit Singapore
summary: Malaysia's Economic Affairs Minister Mohamed Azmin Ali visited Singapore, despite a postponed bilateral meeting due to a provocative act by Johor's chief minister. Singapore protested the unauthorized visit to a Malaysian vessel in its territorial waters, creating an atmosphere "unconducive" for the meeting. However, the two countries welcomed the visit and agreed to hold alternative meetings to strengthen bilateral ties. The Joint Ministerial Committee for Iskandar Malaysia, aimed at studying cooperation in the South Johor economic zone, remains postponed.

site_title: EMQ goes behind the scenes to stand out in world of remittance
summary: EMQ, a Hong Kong-based startup, is building cross-border networks for business clients to simplify remittance transactions. The company connects local banks with endpoints such as mobile wallet operators, banks, and cash pick-up points, allowing for low-cost and near-real-time transfers. EMQ has partnered with Tencent to enable migrant workers to send money to the Philippines and Indonesia via WeChat Pay HK, and has grown its transaction volume by 15-20% month-on-month over the past two years. The startup aims to expand into the Middle East, Europe, and B2B space, with a focus on cross-border payments and e-commerce.

site_title: Pompeo to press Saudi prince to hold Khashoggi killers 'accountable'
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo arrived in Riyadh on Sunday to press Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to ensure the killers of journalist Jamal Khashoggi are held accountable. Pompeo's visit comes amid ongoing international outrage over Khashoggi's murder in 2018, with the US CIA concluding Prince Mohammed likely ordered the killing. Riyadh prosecutors have indicted 11 people and sought the death penalty for five, but Prince Mohammed was exonerated. Pompeo will also discuss women's rights activists being held in Saudi prisons, and will call on Gulf countries to end their diplomatic rift.

site_title: Thai developer scaling back its ambitions for new projects
summary: A Thai residential developer, Sena Development, is scaling back its ambitions for new projects in 2019 due to mortgage curbs and a weaker economy. The company expects to launch 13 projects worth 10 billion baht, down from a preference to launch more. This follows a slowdown in the Bangkok home market, with builders relying on foreigners for business. The Bank of Thailand's stricter mortgage-lending rules and the US-China trade war also contribute to the cautious approach. Despite this, Sena Development still expects 20% earnings growth in 2019.

site_title: Belt up for the ride!
summary: Key business leaders predict several significant risks for 2019, including the US-China trade dispute, a global economic slowdown, and cybersecurity threats. The US-China trade war is considered a major risk, with potential impacts on businesses worldwide. Economic indicators, such as interest rates and currency fluctuations, are also expected to have a significant impact. Cybersecurity threats, including data breaches and sophisticated malware, pose a growing concern. To mitigate these risks, businesses are advised to invest in innovations and technologies, such as machine learning, blockchain, and cybersecurity, and to prioritize customer needs and sustainability.

site_title: Sears bankruptcy raises old questions about cost of going broke
summary: Sears Holdings Corp, a 126-year-old US retailer, is considering bids for its assets after filing for bankruptcy. The company faces a $5 billion bill from going broke, which will be determined by the outcome of the bidding process. The fate of Sears highlights the high costs of bankruptcy, with armies of pricey specialists driving the system. The outcome is prioritized over costs, leaving the retailer's future uncertain.

site_title: Creating an inclusive society
summary: Pan Pacific Hotels Group's Singapore properties have made significant strides in inclusive hiring, employing 14 individuals with disabilities in full or part-time roles. The company's structured approach, in partnership with SG Enable, has led to the training of over 30 interns from special education schools. This initiative not only enhances productivity but also fosters a caring and patient work culture. With plans to expand the program across all properties, the company aims to provide a viable solution to manpower challenges and promote diversity in the workplace.

site_title: Bond traders bedeviled by absent data in gauging US economy
summary: Bond traders face challenges in gauging the US economy due to the partial government shutdown, resulting in a lack of economic data. The 10-year Treasury yield has settled into a range after rising last week, and market expectations have shifted to a patient Fed, with little movement anticipated this year. The market's pricing has swung since early January, when bets were building for a potential Fed cut. The uncertainty surrounding the US economy's outlook has created challenges for bond traders.

site_title: Saudi Aramco may issue US$10b bond for Sabic deal
summary: Saudi Aramco may issue a $10 billion bond to help fund its acquisition of petrochemicals giant Sabic, according to Energy Minister Khalid Al-Falih. The bond, expected in the second quarter, will be the company's first international bond and will require Aramco to disclose its accounts and details about oil reserves and operations. The acquisition, valued at around $70 billion, is part of Aramco's plans to buy a 70% stake in Sabic from the Public Investment Fund.

site_title: Gold: not a bull market but downside is limited
summary: Gold prices have surged in recent weeks, driven by central bank purchases and increased investor demand. The price has risen by 9.6% to US$1,288 an ounce, with other precious metals such as silver, platinum, and palladium also benefiting. Despite some bearish sentiment, analysts believe the downside of gold is limited, with central banks seen as buyers when prices dip. The World Gold Council reports that central banks have increased gold purchases, with Russia, China, and India among the top buyers.

site_title: STI leads benchmarks into 2019, Sam Goi ups GSH Corp stake
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) led major benchmarks into 2019, gaining 3.7% in the first seven trading sessions. Share buybacks accounted for 14 stocks over the five sessions ended Jan 10, totaling S$10.6 million. GSH Corporation's executive chairman Sam Goi increased his stake to 51.16% after acquiring 22,509,300 shares. Other notable transactions include director and substantial shareholder transactions, with over 40 primary-listed stocks changing hands in the same period.

site_title: Jokowi challenger moots tax cuts to stimulate economy
summary: Indonesian presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto is proposing deep tax cuts to stimulate the country's economy, aiming to lower corporate and individual taxes by 5-8 percentage points over five years. The plan, inspired by US President Donald Trump's approach, aims to boost economic growth and reduce government debt. If elected, Prabowo will also introduce a progressive individual tax rate to ensure a more equitable society. The move is seen as a response to the incumbent Joko Widodo's policy of adding to record government debt to finance infrastructure projects.

site_title: London housing shows signs of life despite Brexit uncertainty
summary: The London property market has shown signs of improvement despite Brexit uncertainty, with a 6% increase in prime London property deals in the second half of 2018 compared to the same period in 2017. Seller price discounts of up to 20% have attracted buyers, particularly from Asia, as the pound devalues. The market is expected to temporarily lift with a Brexit resolution, but medium-term, prices are likely to remain relatively stable with low growth, influenced by high stamp duties and taxes.

images.alt_text: Asian and other foreign buyers have taken advantage of discounts ranging from 10 to 20 per cent. The much cheaper pound has also been an incentive.

site_title: Singapore-backed technology firms make waves at CES
summary: Singapore-backed technology firms made a significant impact at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas. Sony unveiled its "360 Reality Audio" concept, promising a sound experience that feels like magic. Meanwhile, Creative showcased its Super X-Fi headphone holography, which can add three-dimensional detail to sound from stereo and mono tracks. Meridian Innovation demonstrated a low-cost, low-power compact thermal imaging camera that can be built into devices. Other Singapore-backed companies, such as Newton's Meter and Nanoveu, also showcased innovative products. The Singapore Pavilion at CES featured 17 companies, including startups and established firms, and attracted the attention of global leaders like Flir and Sony.

site_title: China to reduce foreign investment curbs: minister
summary: China's Commerce Minister Zhong Shan announced plans to reduce foreign investment curbs, allowing full foreign ownership in more areas of the economy and reducing restrictions on certain industries. The move aims to stimulate the slowing economy and address difficulties faced by foreign companies. Foreign direct investment into China rose 3% to $135 billion in 2018, despite a global decline of 41% in the first half of the year. The minister also emphasized the need to properly handle trade frictions with the US, which China has been pushing to resolve through diplomatic efforts.

site_title: SME business sentiment slides for third straight quarter
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have reported a slight decline in business sentiment for the third consecutive quarter, with the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) - DP Info SME Index score falling to 50.7 from 51.0. Despite this, SMEs remain marginally optimistic about the outlook for the first six months of 2019, with business expansion expectations dipping to 5.41. The sector most affected was construction/engineering, followed by retail/food and beverage, and transport/storage. SMEs are looking for opportunities to grow, particularly in the business services and transport/storage sectors.

site_title: Exuberance back after Wall St meltdown in Dec
summary: Investors have regained confidence after a December Wall Street meltdown, with the S&P 500 experiencing its largest 10-day rally in a decade. The index jumped 2.5% last week, driven by positive signals on trade, monetary policy, and growth. This surge follows a period of uncertainty, and analysts are now optimistic about the market's prospects. The rally is a stark contrast to the December downturn, which saw the S&P 500 plummet 12.9%. The rebound suggests investors are throwing down the gauntlet to those who predicted the end of the bull run.

site_title: Saudi energy minister says oil market is 'on the right track'
summary: Saudi Arabia's energy minister Khalid al-Falih stated that the oil market is on the right track and will quickly return to balance, despite recent cuts of 1.2 million barrels per day. Al-Falih said Saudi Arabia exceeded its production and export commitments, and there is no need for an extraordinary OPEC meeting before April. He emphasized the importance of collaboration with OPEC and non-OPEC partners to ensure a stable oil market.

site_title: US dollar will be under pressure against Asian currencies in 2019
summary: The US dollar is expected to be under pressure against Asian currencies in 2019 due to a weak US economy, despite a strong US economy in 2018. A potential trade truce between the US and China, US domestic growth slowdown, and political turmoil will also contribute to the downward pressure on the US dollar. A reversal of liquidity flows, as seen in the past 15 years, is also expected to benefit Asian markets, particularly the Singapore Stock Index.

site_title: Will we need boards in the future economy?
summary: The future economy's shift towards digital disruption and hyper-disintermediated business models may alter the role of boards in companies. Traditional boards will transition from fiduciary to advisory roles, focusing on driving company performance rather than ensuring conformance with regulations. The advisory board will require diverse skillsets, including industry expertise, experience, and emotional intelligence. Technology, such as AI, may also support the board, but human directors will still be necessary to bring experience and judgement.

site_title: Russia starts gradual oil output cuts as Opec+ deal kicks in
summary: Russia is gradually reducing oil production, falling over 30,000 barrels a day relative to October levels, as part of the Opec+ deal to cut 228,000 barrels a day by the end of the first quarter. The country's oil output has already dropped to 11.15 million barrels a day in January, with further reductions expected. Russia's energy minister, Alexander Novak, said the country is on track to reach about 1/5 of its pledged cut by the end of the month, with the next meeting of the Joint Ministerial Monitoring Committee potentially taking place in April.

site_title: Ministers tell Theresa May to ask opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn for help when Brexit deal dies
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is urged by senior ministers to seek help from Labour opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn if her Brexit deal is rejected by Parliament next week. Pro-European ministers want her to invite Corbyn for negotiations to agree a joint plan, which could result in a softer Brexit. If the deal fails, the UK risks a chaotic split from the EU without a new trading arrangement, potentially leading to economic recession and recession. Corbyn's Labour party wants a full customs union with the EU, which could erode the UK's red lines on Brexit.

site_title: Corbyn plans to call for no-confidence vote in May's government
summary: Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn plans to call for a no-confidence vote in British Prime Minister Theresa May's government on Tuesday evening if her Brexit withdrawal bill is heavily defeated. This comes after May's efforts to win backing for the bill have failed. If Corbyn's vote fails, he would be under pressure to back a second referendum on the UK's exit from the European Union. The UK government would have two weeks to form a new government after losing a confidence vote, before an election would be called.

site_title: Qatar Investment Authority plans to invest up to US$45b in US
summary: Qatar Investment Authority (QIA) plans to invest up to $45 billion in the US over the next two years, aiming to rebalance its portfolio away from Europe. The sovereign wealth fund currently has $30 billion invested in the US and is looking at fundamental sectors such as real estate, technology, and US exchanges. This investment is part of a five-year commitment made by QIA's predecessor to invest $45 billion in the US. The move comes as Qatar seeks to diversify its investments and develop its industry despite facing sanctions from neighboring countries.

site_title: Qualcomm CEO defends sole supply deal with Apple for chips
summary: Qualcomm CEO Steve Mollenkopf testified that the company sought to become Apple's sole supplier of modem chips to recoup a $1 billion "incentive payment" after Apple insisted on it. This was not to block rivals like Intel, but to ensure Qualcomm sold enough chips to recover the payment. The deal, which dates back to 2011, allows Apple to choose another supplier but would lose the rebate, effectively increasing the cost. Antitrust regulators argue this is part of Qualcomm's anticompetitive conduct to preserve its dominance in modem chips.

site_title: Zimbabwe plans new currency as dollar shortage bites
summary: Zimbabwe plans to introduce a new currency in the next 12 months due to a severe dollar shortage, which has caused businesses to close and imported goods to become scarce. The country abandoned its currency in 2009 and adopted the US dollar, but now lacks sufficient hard currency to back up electronic funds, prompting demands for cash. The shortage has led to fuel price increases and forced companies to import goods at a premium on the black market.

site_title: US to seek comprehensive agriculture access in EU trade talks
summary: The US has signaled it will not exclude agriculture from planned US-EU trade talks, publishing negotiating objectives that aim to reduce or eliminate EU tariffs on US farm products and break down non-tariff barriers. The move follows a US farm, food, and beverage groups' request to include agriculture in talks, which could impact a potential deal. The US seeks duty-free market access for US industrial goods and commitments not to impose duties on digital downloads of US software and services. Negotiations could launch in as little as 30 days, pending EU approval.

site_title: Storm Gia strikes US Midwest as airlines cancel flights and waive rebooking fees
summary: Storm Gia struck the US Midwest, freezing travel plans and prompting airlines to waive rebooking fees. As of Saturday, 435 flights were cancelled nationwide, with 119 combined cancellations at St Louis airport due to over 30 cm of snow. The storm was expected to persist throughout Sunday, with additional snowfall in the Ohio Valley and mid-Atlantic. Nearly 500 weather-related motor vehicle accidents were reported in Missouri, and hundreds were stranded due to impassable roads. Airlines including Southwest, Delta, and United waived rebooking fees for affected airports.

site_title: A financial health check for 2019
summary: A financial health check for 2019 is recommended as the start of a new year, considering changes in personal circumstances and reviewing asset allocations and insurance needs. In 2018, assets generated negative returns, and strategists expect volatility to remain elevated through 2019. Experts recommend reviewing strategic allocations, trimming or adding to allocations, and considering low-risk options such as CPF top-ups, Singapore Savings Bonds, and reviewing insurance plans. It is also essential to review wills, particularly for those with new circumstances, and to consider seeking professional help for complex cases.

site_title: Breadcoin: the new dough in Washington for those in need
summary: In Washington, a new form of currency called "Breadcoins" has been introduced for people in need. The quarter-size coins, worth US$2.20, can be exchanged for goods and services at participating locations like the Mission Muffins cafe trailer. This alternative to cash aims to address concerns that traditional donations might be used to fuel addiction. The initiative provides a more controlled and dignified way for individuals to access essential items.

site_title: Local stocks shaken, not stirred
summary: Singapore stocks face a mixed outlook as Q4 earnings season begins, with dimmer corporate earnings growth and rising uncertainty expected to impact markets. Analysts recommend investors focus on "quality, high-yield stocks" with low embedded expectations, such as banks and real estate investment trusts. Despite cheap valuations and attractive dividend yields, investors should be cautious of potential volatility, with some expecting mid-to-high single-digit growth in banks despite interest rate hikes and loan repricing.

site_title: Mixed response in Europe to calls for Huawei boycott
summary: European governments are divided on calls to boycott Huawei 5G equipment, with some backing a ban amid spy suspicions, while others remain untroubled. Poland recently arrested a Huawei executive suspected of spying, adding to the US-led pressure. Telecom operators in Europe are also drawn to Huawei's 5G capabilities, complicating the boycott efforts. The mixed response highlights the challenges in implementing a unified stance against the Chinese tech giant.

site_title: Gold gains as US stocks slip, en route to 4th weekly gain
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,288.47 an ounce, tracking a decline in US stocks and expectations of a possible pause in the Federal Reserve's monetary policy tightening cycle. This would be the fourth consecutive weekly gain for gold. The rise in gold prices is attributed to "flight to safety" amid market uncertainty, according to a senior market strategist.

site_title: UK retailers mull fresh wave of store closures: paper
summary: UK retailers are considering store closures as they face increased competition from online retailers and Brexit-related concerns. More than 20 chains, mostly in fashion and homeware, have instructed Deloitte to assess restructuring options, including company voluntary arrangements. This process allows businesses to close stores while leaving behind lease liabilities, but puts a financial burden on landlords. Retailers like Debenhams and John Lewis have already warned of reduced profits due to the challenges.

site_title: Resurrected bull market faces earnings test this week
summary: The US bull market has made a strong comeback, rising 9% since December, driven by progress in US-China trade talks and a shift in Federal Reserve policy. However, this week's earnings season will test the market's momentum, with expected 15% revenue growth and 5% revenue gains for the Standard & Poor's 500. Despite warnings from several high-profile companies, including Apple and Macy's, the consumer services sector has largely remained unchanged. The market's resilience suggests that the bull market could still survive, albeit in a less intense style, with business-model differentiation playing a key role in driving future growth.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's shipping market report for the first full week of the year shows a mixed performance across various segments. Capesize rates improved briefly but ended the week at $6.25, with West Australia to China rates reaching the high $6.00s. Panamax and Supramax markets saw lower activity, with the Baltic Supramax Index (BSI) falling and limited period fixtures concluded. Handysize and tanker markets also experienced declines, with West Africa to China rates dropping 6.25 points to WS 53.75. The global index jumped 10% to $1,552 due to China to US West Coast and North Europe prices increasing 16% and 13% respectively, driven by fuel-related surcharge increases and General Rate Increases (GRIs).

site_title: Impossible Burgers coming to Singapore in first half of 2019
summary: Impossible Foods, backed by Singapore investors, announced plans to bring its plant-based "ground beef" to Singapore in the first half of 2019. The company revealed a new recipe for the Impossible Burger 2.0, featuring potato proteins and cellulose, and is in advanced discussions with Singaporean restaurants. The product will initially be shipped to Singapore but may be manufactured there in the future. The new recipe is said to be more juicy and nutritious than the previous version and will be sold in US grocery stores shortly.

images.alt_text: The firm that made the biggest splash was Temasek-backed Impossible Foods, which held a cookout at the Mirage hotel the night before the annual tech show opened in Las Vegas.

site_title: 'Grandfather of golf' makes 44th appearance at Singapore Open
summary: Singapore Open veteran Loh Ah Joo, known as the 'Grandfather of Golf,' is making his 44th appearance at the tournament at 80 years old. He has been an ever-present at the event since 1970. The Singapore Open, which started in 1961, has grown from a S$20,000 event to a US$1 million showcase, with Spanish golfer Sergio Garcia defending his title this week. Loh Ah Joo reminisced about the early days of the tournament, praising the passion and pride of players from various countries, including Burmese, Taiwanese, and Filipino golfers.

site_title: More startups have an unfamiliar message for venture capitalists: Get lost
summary: A group of 50 startup founders gathered in a New York City bar to discuss their frustrations with venture capital. They shared testimonials about feeling misaligned with VC expectations and the hype surrounding fundraising. Founders like Josh Haas of Bubble and Seph Skerritt of Proper Cloth expressed concerns about the trap of raising money and the pressure to meet unrealistic expectations. The gathering aimed to challenge the traditional VC model and promote a more authentic approach to startup funding.

site_title: Apple demanded US$1b for chance to win iPhone: Qualcomm CEO
summary: Qualcomm CEO Steve Mollenkopf testified that Apple demanded a $1 billion "incentive payment" to allow Qualcomm to become the sole supplier of modem chips for iPhones. This payment was part of a 2011 deal between Apple and Qualcomm. Mollenkopf stated that the size of the payment was unusually large, but not uncommon in the industry. The payment was meant to ease technical costs, not block rivals from the market, according to Mollenkopf.

site_title: Shopee fully leases 5 Science Park Drive
summary: Shopee, the e-commerce arm of Sea Ltd, has fully leased a six-storey building at 5 Science Park Drive in Singapore, with a net lettable area of 240,000 sq ft. The building is expected to receive a Temporary Occupation Permit (TOP) soon. Shopee is paying a monthly rental of nearly S$6 per square foot, according to market expectations. This move reflects the strong demand for high-quality business park space in Singapore's city fringe submarket, where the vacancy rate is low.

site_title: Cathay Pacific makes second first class blunder in two weeks
summary: Cathay Pacific has offered discounted first-class tickets from Lisbon to Hong Kong for $1,512, following a similar incident two weeks ago where business and first-class tickets were sold for $670. The airline attributed the error to an "input issue" and will honour the cheap fares for the "very small number" of affected travellers. This comes after Cathay experienced a data breach in October and struggled with competition from cheaper mainland Chinese rivals in 2018, resulting in a $33 million loss in the first six months of the year.

site_title: Vietnam startup Bamboo Airways to launch first commercial flight Jan 16
summary: Vietnam's startup Bamboo Airways will launch its first commercial flight on January 16, connecting major cities and tourist destinations. The airline secured an Air Operator Certificate and will start selling tickets from Saturday. Bamboo Airways plans to launch international flights to Japan, Korea, and Singapore in 2019, and has ordered 44 aircraft worth $10.4 billion. Vietnam's fifth airline aims to spur tourism with visa exemptions and investment promotion, following the country's double-digit expansion in domestic and inbound passenger numbers.

site_title: US government shutdown hits record length with no end in sight
summary: The US government shutdown has reached a record 22 days, with no end in sight, as President Donald Trump demands funding for a border wall. Approximately 800,000 federal workers have missed pay, and negotiations between Trump and Democrats remain at a standstill. Trump is considering declaring a national emergency, but has stated he won't rush to use the option. The shutdown surpasses the 1995-1996 funding lapse and has raised concerns about the impact on federal workers and the economy.

site_title: Tennis: Nadal shrugs off injury concerns, pays tribute to Murray
summary: Rafael Nadal has addressed concerns about his fitness ahead of the Australian Open, declaring himself ready to compete despite a thigh strain and a history of injuries. The 32-year-old Spaniard pulled out of the Brisbane International warmup, but plans to start his campaign at Melbourne Park with a first-round match against James Duckworth. Nadal paid tribute to fellow 'Big Four' rival Andy Murray, who revealed plans to retire. Nadal's Australian Open campaign is his 14th in Melbourne.

site_title: Obama protege Julian Castro set to join 2020 race
summary: Former US Housing Secretary and San Antonio Mayor Julian Castro is set to launch his presidential bid, becoming the first Hispanic candidate to run for the Democratic nomination in 2020. Castro, a 44-year-old protege of Barack Obama, will announce his candidacy in a border state central to America's immigration debate. He faces competition from established candidates like Joe Biden and Elizabeth Warren, but his strong oratory skills and charisma could propel him into the top tier, potentially reviving enthusiasm among Latino voters.

site_title: L'Occitane agrees to buy skincare brand Elemis for US$900m
summary: L'Occitane International SA agreed to purchase skincare brand Elemis for approximately US$900 million, aiming to expand its presence in the UK and US. The acquisition, expected to close in the first quarter of 2019, will bolster L'Occitane's global growth. The deal will be funded by cash and bank borrowings, marking L'Occitane's largest acquisition since listing in 2010. The acquisition is expected to leverage Elemis' presence to enter new markets, with L'Occitane boasting a global presence in 90 countries and 3,285 retail outlets.

site_title: British police tell retailers to mull extra security ahead of Brexit
summary: British police advise retailers to consider extra security measures ahead of Brexit, citing potential panic-buying and large crowds. The deadline for Britain's departure from the EU approaches without a divorce deal, with Prime Minister Theresa May's withdrawal agreement set to be rejected by parliament. Retailers are reacting cautiously, with some planning to work with police to maintain security. The move aims to minimize policing demands and prevent chaos, particularly in ports.

site_title: SpaceX to lay off 10%of workforce
summary: SpaceX plans to lay off 10% of its workforce, approximately 600 employees, to become a leaner company and succeed in developing interplanetary spacecraft and a global space-based Internet. The decision is made to continue delivering for customers and achieve long-term success. This move is compared to other organizations that have attempted similar developments separately, which have bankrupted them.

site_title: Citadel folds Fundamental Strategies into other units, lays off manager
summary: Citadel, a US$30 billion hedge fund, folded its Fundamental Strategies unit into Aptigon Capital and Global Credit, two businesses also led by Eric Felder. Michael Doniger, a portfolio manager, was laid off. The move follows Felder's takeover of Aptigon and responsibility for managing Global Credit. Citadel's main multi-strategy fund returned 9.1% last year, outperforming the average hedge fund. Felder oversees roughly two dozen portfolio managers.

site_title: It's your friendly neighbourhood ISOTeam
summary: ISOTeam, a Catalist-listed building maintenance and estate upgrading company, is experiencing a record growth in its order book due to increased public sector calls for tender for repairs and redecoration (R&R) projects. The company's CEO, Anthony Koh, is optimistic about the next six months, citing a growing backlog of contracts and a focus on cross-selling between business units. ISOTeam's R&R business, which accounts for 30-40% of its work, is expected to drive growth, with the company aiming to win more HIP (Home Improvement Programme) contracts. The company has also diversified into solar panel installations and is in talks to draw up a long-term maintenance programme with solar player Sunseap. Additionally, ISOTeam is launching a bike-sharing joint venture, SG Bike, and is working on a pest control product, the Cockroaches & Odour Remover (CnO), which is expected to be approved soon.

site_title: Portugal to welcome British tourists post-Brexit
summary: Portugal plans to exempt British tourists from entry visa requirements if the UK exits the EU without a negotiated deal. The move aims to maintain a smooth flow of visitors, with 2.6 million British tourists arriving in Portugal annually. The Portuguese government will reinforce consulate staff in the UK and provide assistance to British residents in Portugal. Foreign Minister Augusto Santos Silva has assured that British qualifications will remain valid until March 29. The plan follows concerns that a no-deal Brexit could disrupt tourism and trade between the two countries.

site_title: Dollar gains, but outlook suggests weak trend
summary: The US dollar rose against the euro, boosted by technical factors after the euro hit key resistance levels, despite a bleak outlook due to cautious signals from the Federal Reserve about further rate hikes. The Fed's intention to shrink its balance sheet and its dovish rate outlook have triggered dollar selling, while cyclical, structural, and secular trends are expected to pressure the dollar in 2019. The dollar was also slightly higher against the yen and Canadian dollar, but its medium-term weakness is expected due to widening fiscal and current account deficits.

site_title: Indonesia resurgence gathers pace as global investors pile in
summary: Global investors are piling into Indonesia, buying $795 million of debt so far this year, as the country's currency rebounds 2.4% in 2019. This influx of capital is seen as a sign that the worst may be over for Indonesia, with yields down 90 basis points from their October peak. The Federal Reserve's more cautious approach to policy tightening is also contributing to the relief. This trend is a welcome relief for Bank Indonesia, which has been seeking to stem a foreign capital outflow since 2018.

site_title: US dollar gains, but outlook suggests weak trend
summary: The US dollar rose against the euro on Friday, boosted by technical factors after the euro hit key resistance levels. However, the dollar's outlook remains bleak due to cautious signals from the Federal Reserve about further rate hikes. The Fed's rate outlook and plans to shrink its balance sheet further indicate that monetary policy tightening is not yet done, despite no further rate hikes expected this year. The dollar index rose 0.1% to 95.66, while the euro fell 0.3% to US$1.1465.

site_title: China's Wanda files for US IPO of sports unit to raise up to US$500m: sources
summary: Dalian Wanda Group, a Chinese conglomerate, has filed a confidential US initial public offering (IPO) for its sports unit, which could raise up to $500 million. The IPO, expected to happen in the first half of 2029, will include sports marketing company Infront Sports & Media AG and World Triathlon Corp, acquired in 2015 for $1.2 billion and $650 million respectively. The move comes as Wanda offloads domestic and overseas holdings amid government pressure to cut irrational overseas deals.

site_title: Rise in male infertility in Singapore mirrors global sperm crisis
summary: In Singapore, male infertility is on the rise, with fertility clinics reporting a spike in cases, attributed to changing societal attitudes towards reproduction. Hospitals and fertility centers have seen a significant increase in male infertility cases, with Virtus Fertility Centre Singapore reporting a 72% increase from 2015 to 2017. This mirrors the global phenomenon of declining sperm quality over the past 40 years, with the World Health Organisation assessing "normal" human semen to contain at least 15 million sperm per millilitre of semen. Lifestyle changes, such as quitting smoking and exercising, can help men with fertility problems, and treatments include surgery and hormone medication.

site_title: Poland accuses Huawei employee of spying for China
summary: Poland has arrested a Huawei employee and a former security agent on charges of spying for China, amid growing concerns over Beijing's use of the company's equipment for espionage. The detention follows increasing pressure on Huawei across the European Union, with US President Donald Trump's administration pushing European allies to block the company from telecom networks. The move raises questions about Europe's ability to be autonomous in dealing with Huawei, with some countries considering restrictions on the company's role in their telecom infrastructure.

site_title: Trump stops short of emergency declaration in border wall fight
summary: US President Donald Trump announced Friday he won't declare a national emergency to end the border wall standoff, ensuring the longest government shutdown in US history. The shutdown, now in its 31st day, has affected 800,000 government workers and disrupted services like air travel and tax collection. Trump urged Congress to provide $5.7 billion for border security, while Democrats say the wall is ineffective and barbaric. The White House and Senate have adjourned for the weekend, with no possible action until next week.

site_title: Alibaba-backed AI startup Megvii said to be weighing IPO this year
summary: Megvii, an Alibaba-backed AI startup, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong to raise $500 million to $1 billion. The Beijing-based firm, which owns facial recognition developer Face++, is competing with rival SenseTime Group Ltd for clients in the financial, retail, and government sectors. Deliberations are at an early stage, and no final decision has been made. Megvii's software uses facial scans from a Ministry of Public Security database of 1.4 billion Chinese citizens, and the startup has investors including Ant Financial and sovereign wealth funds.

site_title: Thai developer holds back as mortgage curbs sap Bangkok's condo boom
summary: A leading Thai developer, Sena Development Pcl, plans to scale back its new project launches in 2019 due to mortgage curbs and a weaker economy, affecting Bangkok's condominium market. The company expects to start marketing 13 projects worth 10 billion baht, down from previous plans. The market slowdown is attributed to the Bank of Thailand's stricter mortgage-lending rules, a cooling economy, and the US-China trade war. Sena Development still expects 20% earnings growth in 2019, driven by sales of older projects and a partnership with a Japanese developer.

site_title: Oil falls nearly 2% amid global economy concerns but ends week higher
summary: Oil prices fell nearly 2% on Friday, ending the week higher despite concerns about a global economic slowdown. Brent crude futures dropped $1.20 to $60.48 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell $1 to $51.59 a barrel. The decline followed a nine-day winning streak sparked by US-China trade hopes, but was supported by supply cuts and lower oil exports from Iran. The week still saw gains for both benchmarks, with Brent rising 6% and WTI up 7.6%.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell nearly 2 per cent on Friday as investors worried about a global economic slowdown, snapping a nine-day winning streak spurred by US-China trade hopes, but clung to some gains from that rally to end the week higher.

site_title: Nissan top exec Munoz resigns amid broadened Ghosn probe
summary: Nissan top executive Jose Munoz has resigned amid a broadened investigation into ousted Chairman Carlos Ghosn's alleged financial misconduct. Munoz, 53, had been a close ally to Ghosn and a possible successor to lead the Nissan-Renault partnership. His resignation follows Ghosn's removal as chairman and firing of Greg Kelly, and comes as Nissan struggles to shore up profitability in the US and expand in China. Munoz had been placed on leave and was not cooperating with the internal investigation, citing the need to assist Nissan in its investigations.

site_title: How income investors cope with volatile markets
summary: Investors who focus on income-generating stocks can benefit from volatile markets, as they can buy shares at lower prices. Volatility is a natural part of investing and can drive portfolio values higher. However, it's essential to separate the benefits of volatility when markets rise from its drawbacks when they fall. By adopting a contrarian approach and buying shares at lower prices, income investors can potentially increase their returns. Warren Buffett's investment philosophy emphasizes buying wonderful companies at fair prices, rather than fair companies at high prices.

site_title: ST Index ends week 4.6% higher at 3,198.65 points
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore ended the week 4.6% higher at 3,198.65 points, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks and the Federal Reserve's dovish stance. This lifted Singaporean markets, despite initial concerns.

site_title: Miami airport to close terminal early as TSA screener absences rise
summary: Miami International Airport will close Concourse G early on Saturday, Sunday, and Monday due to a shortage of TSA screeners. The airport has 12 planes typically flying out of G after 1pm, but will relocate them to either Concourse F or H. The TSA's 51,000 officers are among the lowest-paid federal employees and are missing paychecks due to the 21-day government shutdown. The airport is taking precautions to ensure security effectiveness, but passengers can expect minimal wait times, with the longest wait being 23 minutes.

site_title: European shares gain in first week of 2019 but caution persists
summary: European shares rose 1.7% in the first week of 2019, driven by investor appetite for risk, despite caution over trade and economic growth. The Stoxx 600 closed higher for a fourth straight day, while China-sensitive autos and parts suppliers fell. The UK's housebuilders gained, with Taylor Wimpey and Persimmon rising over 4% after a BAML upgrade. The rally was partly fueled by dovish comments from Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, with equity funds drawing $6.2 billion in inflows.

site_title: More PMEs from fintech, banking, finance get union representation
summary: A union in Singapore, the Banking and Financial Services Union (BFSU), has expanded its membership to include higher-level professionals, managers, and executives from the financial services industry. Previously only administrative and managerial staff were represented. The union change aims to provide broader representation to workers in the sector, including relationship managers and asset managers.

site_title: Workspace provider IWG takes space at Capitol Singapore
summary: IWG, a global workspace provider, has leased over 20,600 sq ft of space at Capitol Singapore from Perennial Real Estate Holdings. The premium co-working space concept, branded No18, will be located at Level 2 of Capitol Piazza. This is IWG's first presence in Singapore, marking the company's entry into the local market.

images.alt_text: IWG's premium co-working space concept with private offices and club amenities - branded No18 - will be at Level 2 of Capitol Piazza.

site_title: US: Stocks edge lower as five-day winning streak ends
summary: US stocks closed lower on Friday, ending a five-day winning streak, as markets await the start of the fourth-quarter earnings period. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined. Despite a sleepy session, stocks recovered losses and investors largely set aside concerns over a global economic slowdown and US-China trade talks. Key companies reported mixed results, including General Motors' surge and Activision Blizzard's plunge. The focus shifts to earnings season, which begins next week with results from JPMorgan Chase and other large banks.

site_title: The role of real estate in a diversified portfolio
summary: Real estate investments can offer key diversification and inflation hedging benefits, potentially enhancing risk-adjusted returns in a mixed-asset portfolio. Institutional investors often include real estate in a systematic asset allocation approach, while individual investors view it separately from stocks, bonds, and cash. This article discusses the value-add of real estate and its potential to drive growth in Asia, driven by dollar asset diversification.

site_title: Rolls-Royce is on a roll
summary: Rolls-Royce achieved its best year in its 115-year history, selling 4,107 cars in 2018, with the Phantom being a major growth driver. The company credits US President Donald Trump's tax reforms and favourable global winds, including a 40% surge in sales in China. Despite a decline in Singapore's sales, Rolls-Royce remains optimistic, with the new Cullinan model expected to drive growth. CEO Torsten Muller-Otvos expects another record year in 2019, despite concerns about production targets and exclusivity.

site_title: Yoma in Thai bond offering of 2.3b baht
summary: Yoma Strategic, a Myanmar-focused conglomerate, has filed a 2.3 billion baht (S$97.3 million) bond offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission of Thailand, making it the first Myanmar-focused firm to raise foreign debt. The company aims to diversify its investor base and market itself to Thai investors. This move follows Thailand's promotion as a hub for investments and capital raising for companies from Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, and Vietnam.

site_title: Of timing and catching a 'Rising Star'
summary: A fund manager's new fund was initially set to launch in September 2018 but was delayed due to operational issues, coinciding with the market downturn in Asia. The delay turned out to be a blessing in disguise, as the fund will now launch in February. Research by CrossBorder Capital found that young hedge funds tend to outperform older ones, with a median return of 23.2% for the youngest decile compared to 13.4% for all deciles. The study also found that failure rates decrease over time, with 4.2% of funds failing in the first three years and 4.9% in subsequent years.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers' Take: SATS downgraded to "Hold" by OCBC Investment Research, citing diminishing upside due to recent price appreciation. The airline ground handler's share price dropped 9.1% despite upgrading to "Buy" on Nov 29. Meanwhile, Mapletree Logistics Trust maintained its "Buy" rating, expecting positive rental reversion of 2-3% for FY19 driven by Hong Kong, China, and Vietnam.

site_title: US$13m cliffside mansion up for sale in Mexico
summary: A US$13 million cliffside mansion in Careyes, Mexico, is up for sale. The 11-month-old property features five pools, a six-car garage, and was developed by real estate developer Dick Butera. The mansion sits on a three-acre peninsula and is located on the Pacific Coast south of Puerto Vallarta. The sale comes as Butera regularly leaves Aspen for Mexico during Christmas and has owned properties in the area for over a decade.

site_title: The players to watch at the Australian Open
summary: The Australian Open is set to begin in Melbourne, with top players including Novak Djokovic, Rafael Nadal, and Roger Federer vying for the title. Djokovic, seeking a sixth title, and Nadal, looking to regain form after injury, are considered favorites. Meanwhile, a new generation of players such as Alexander Zverev and Naomi Osaka are also expected to make a strong showing. Serena Williams, also competing, aims to equal Margaret Court's record of 24 Grand Slam singles titles. The tournament is expected to be a closely contested one, with several players capable of winning the title.

site_title: Australia's housing sector slump shows up in another sickly set of data
summary: Australia's construction activity has slowed to its weakest in five-and-a-half years, according to the Australian Industry Group Performance of Construction Index, which fell 1.9 points to 42.6 in December 2018. The sector shrank for a fourth straight month, with apartment building being the weakest performer, contracting for a ninth straight month. Tighter lending conditions and falling housing prices are contributing to the decline, which could weigh on fourth-quarter GDP and jobs data.

site_title: The poor sick day is in declining health
summary: Working from home has led to a decline in sick days, with some employees opting to work remotely from home even while ill. This shift is attributed to the highly competitive work environment and the expectation of being available and productive at all times. Companies are adapting by offering flexible hours policies and redefining sick days as "personal emergency days" to prioritize employee well-being and discretion. This new model allows employees to work from home, even when ill, and still maintain a sense of productivity and connection with colleagues.

site_title: OCBC Cycle launches new corporate category with BT
summary: OCBC Cycle, the 11th edition, will be held at the Singapore Sports Hub on May 11 and 12, featuring a new corporate category, The Business Times Corporate Rally. The event includes the OCBC Cycle Corporate Chase and Speedway Corporate Championship, with a free six-month subscription to The Business Times for participants. The event also focuses on environmental conservation, with initiatives such as tree planting, reusable trophies, and recycling. The event has seen 230 registrants and will offer cashback for early online registration.

site_title: Sunvic Chemical to ask for trading halt after receiving demand over 222.5m yuan in loans
summary: Sunvic Chemical Holdings, a Singapore-based manufacturer of intermediate chemical products, will request a trading halt due to claims from Yixing Futao Credit and Bank of China (BOC) over corporate guarantees for loans totaling 222.5 million yuan (S$44.3 million). The company's subsidiaries have received letters of demand, and if enforced, the guarantees may impact its ability to continue as a going concern. Sunvic's board has informed shareholders of the situation and will seek legal advice.

site_title: Finding new value in the work of anonymous shutterbugs
summary: Vernacular photography, amateur snapshots taken since 1888, are being reassessed as collectibles and cultural artifacts. Billions of images have been created, offering a unique window into social history and personal archives. Experts, such as Artur Walther, consider these images as valuable representations of everyday life, with exhibitions and museums dedicated to the medium. The focus is on albums and scrapbooks from the 1890s to the 1970s, showcasing the diverse and often quirky subjects of these anonymous photographers.

site_title: Don't burn your bridges at work
summary: Departing employees are often advised to leave on a good note to maintain mutual respect with their former employers. However, navigating the exit interview process is crucial to improve retention rates and manage reputation. Companies tend to dismiss exit interviews, but it can help them improve talent management and leadership. A well-handled exit interview can turn a departing employee into a long-term "corporate ambassador" and help build the brand's reputation as an employer. Employers should create an open and safe environment for departing employees to provide honest feedback and suggestions.

site_title: Japan to revise wage calculation in GDP; likely also to revise budget based on data errors
summary: Japan's government plans to revise the calculation of workers' compensation in the nation's gross domestic product (GDP) and likely revise its budget after underestimating monthly regular wage data from 2004 to 2017 due to inaccurate polling methods. The revisions are expected to be minor and won't change economic growth pace, but raise questions about the credibility of data. The government will publish revised wage data from 2016 to 2017 by the end of the month and earlier data in the coming month. The revisions may also lead to a rare budget revision to address employment insurance benefits.

site_title: PCs have valuable lessons for the smartphone industry
summary: The smartphone market is experiencing a growth-challenged period, similar to the personal computer (PC) industry, with worldwide shipments declining for the second consecutive year in 2018. This trend is driven by consumers buying replacements less often due to devices being "good enough." As a result, companies like Apple and Samsung blame weak sales for disappointing revenue. The PC industry's experience suggests that fresh thinking, like that found in PCs, could benefit the smartphone industry and provide relief for consumers.

images.alt_text: The smartphone market has entered a phase that the PC industry hit several years ago - devices are useful and good enough that people are buying replacements less often, which pinches sales of new devices, hitting the profits of Samsung and Apple.

site_title: Creative shares surge 36% on positive CES launch of new SXFI headphone technology
summary: Creative shares surged 36% on the positive launch of its new SXFI headphone technology at the CES show in Las Vegas, with 3.8 million shares changing hands. The stock reached a high of S$5.42 before closing at S$5.19. This significant trading volume came after the launch, exceeding the average daily trading volume of 300,000 shares.

site_title: Reits
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

US mortgage rates rose for the first time in five weeks, with a significant impact on the global real estate market. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents reached a record high, with further increases expected. Goldman Sachs acquired a large portfolio of Seoul hotel and retail assets. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. New World Group is selling its China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants at its Singapore office post-bankruptcy.

site_title: Bulls born to buck, spin and kick their riders rule the rodeo roost
summary: Bucking bulls have been intensively bred over 15 years to make them harder to ride, using high-tech reproductive techniques. The Professional Bull Riders circuit has seen a significant increase in difficulty, with cowboys now riding for only 29% of the time. Breeders have created a registry of 180,000 bulls and cows, and some bulls can sell for hundreds of thousands of dollars as semen producers. Despite the risks, riders and breeders say the bulls are becoming increasingly difficult to master, with some bulls now throwing riders 71% of the time.
