The market capitalization value of listed companies reached S$936.87 billion, while two new listings raised S$15.2 million and 28 new bond listings raised S$14.2 billion. Derivatives volume increased 17% year-over-year to 18.35 million, with a record 217.4 million in 2018.

site_title: Saudi private jet industry stalls after crackdown
summary: Saudi Arabia's private jet industry has stalled due to the kingdom's anti-corruption drive, which has shattered investor confidence and led to dozens of planes being stranded at airports. The crackdown, launched in 2017, has resulted in the seizure of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of assets, including private jets. The government has collected over $18 billion in settlements, but it's unclear how the jets will be transferred to the state, as many are owned through offshore firms or are mortgaged. The impact has also led to a decrease in private jet flights and a shift to commercial airlines to avoid government scrutiny.

site_title: Qualcomm says Apple CEO's comment on settlement talk 'misleading'
summary: Qualcomm has responded to Apple CEO Tim Cook's comments on settlement talks, calling them "misleading." Cook stated that there were no recent settlement discussions between the companies, while Qualcomm CEO Steve Mollenkopf previously mentioned efforts to resolve the dispute. The two companies are disputing remarks made by their CEOs, with Qualcomm maintaining that Mollenkopf's remarks were accurate. The legal battle between the companies is set to go to trial in April, with Apple accusing Qualcomm of engaging in illegal patent licensing practices.

site_title: Millennium & Copthorne Hotels to reopen London hotel after £50m revamp
summary: Millennium & Copthorne Hotels' London hotel, The Millennium Hotel London Mayfair, will reopen as The Biltmore, Mayfair under Hilton Worldwide Holding's LXR Hotels & Resorts luxury hotel collection. The £50m refurbishment, completed in spring 2019, offers 257 guest rooms and 51 suites. The 10-year agreement allows Hilton to manage the hotel under its LXR brand, with M&C having the option to manage it after five years. The hotel's repositioning aims to establish it as a new five-star deluxe hotel.

site_title: Sunrise Shares Holdings' IFA says general offer "not fair and not reasonable"
summary: Sunrise Shares Holdings' IFA has stated that the S$0.017 per share general offer by its largest shareholder, Wong Siu Fai, is "not fair and not reasonable". The IFA advised the company's directors to recommend that shareholders reject the offer, citing a significant discount of approximately 64.4% to the company's volume-weighted average price over the past year. The offer price is also a discount to previous acquisitions and placements.

site_title: French consumer confidence drops to lowest since November 2014
summary: French consumer confidence has dropped to its lowest since November 2014, falling to 87 points in December, according to the INSEE statistics agency. This decline is attributed to a broader economic slowdown in Europe and the impact of anti-government protests, known as the "yellow vests" movement, which has led to increased consumer uncertainty and reduced confidence in personal finances. The protests, which started in mid-November, have resulted in violence and closures of major shopping areas in Paris.

site_title: Singapore condo rents dip 0.2% in Dec; HDB rents up 0.6%: SRX flash estimates
summary: Singapore condominium rents decreased 0.2% in December, while HDB rents rose 0.6% after a 0.5% dip in November. Non-landed private rental volume has been on a downward trend, while HDB rentals may face increased downward pressure due to more flats reaching the five-year minimum occupancy period. Despite this, analysts expect some respite due to reduced private home completions and demolition of existing units.

site_title: Japan's fear that PM May's Brexit plan will be shot down is real
summary: Japan is concerned that the UK's Brexit plan may be rejected, potentially harming its own companies with significant investments in the UK, including Nissan Motor Co and SoftBank Group Corp. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will visit the UK to show support for Theresa May's deal, which could be the only safeguard for Japanese businesses. Abe's visit and removal of the 23-year-old ban on UK beef imports aim to demonstrate Japan's commitment to mitigating the effects of Brexit.

site_title: Mercedes claims luxury car crown as analysts eye challenger Tesla
summary: Mercedes-Benz sold 2.31 million passenger cars in 2018, likely making it the top-selling premium automotive brand, but analysts question how long German manufacturers can dominate the luxury car industry. US manufacturer Tesla delivered 245,240 vehicles in 2018, raising concerns about the impact of electric and self-driving cars on traditional manufacturers. Mercedes-Benz's success is largely based on sales of combustion engines, while Tesla's electric vehicles are gaining popularity. Analysts predict a shift towards electric cars could open the door to new challengers, with Tesla potentially disrupting the industry.

site_title: France, Germany approve extension of reconciliation treaty to shore up EU
summary: France and Germany have agreed to extend the 1963 Elysee Treaty, a post-war reconciliation treaty, to deepen cooperation in foreign affairs, defense, and internal security. The treaty extension, set to be signed on January 22, aims to strengthen the European Union's main axis against growing eurosceptic nationalism. The agreement will also enhance Europe's ability to act independently.

site_title: US-China trade talks conclude amid hopes of a breakthrough
summary: US-China trade talks concluded in Beijing on Wednesday, with officials expressing optimism that a breakthrough is possible, potentially averting a global trade war. The talks, which lasted longer than expected, fueled market optimism, with share prices jumping in Asia. While progress was made on issues like US farm and energy commodity purchases, the two sides remain apart on Chinese structural reforms and technology transfer. If a deal isn't reached by March 2, US President Trump plans to raise tariffs to 25% on $200 billion in Chinese imports.

site_title: Suspicious packages sent to up to 14 diplomatic missions in Australia: police, media
summary: Police in Australia are investigating suspicious packages sent to up to 14 diplomatic missions, including the US and British embassies, in Melbourne and Canberra. The packages were received by embassies and consulates in cities such as Melbourne, Canberra, and Sydney, with no reports of harm to staff. The Australian Federal Police are examining the packages and investigating the circumstances surrounding the incidents, which are believed to have occurred in January 2019.

site_title: Singapore stocks climb 1.12% higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.12% on Wednesday, extending a fourth consecutive gain, as US-China trade talks concluded. The Straits Times Index reached 3,158.07, with Singtel and Genting Singapore among the top gainers. Local banks also finished in the black. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite US President Trump's recent threats to stocks.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher for fourth straight day on trade hopes
summary: US stocks opened higher for a fourth consecutive day, driven by gains in the energy and technology sectors, as well as optimism over a potential trade deal between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.24%, the S&P 500 gained 0.22%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.38%. Despite ongoing trade uncertainty, the US stock market continues to rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging towards fresh records.

site_title: Duty Free International's net profit jumps on the back of forex gains, revenue increase
summary: Duty Free International reported a net profit of RM15.2 million (S$5 million) for its third quarter ended Nov 30, 2018, a significant jump from RM3.3 million previously due to foreign exchange gains and revenue increase of 19.3%. The company declared a second interim dividend of S$0.01 per share. Despite an expected soft and challenging operating environment, the group plans to identify new market opportunities, intensify marketing efforts, and monitor key cost drivers to remain competitive and profitable.

site_title: VIX is plummeting but market reality may yet pull it higher
summary: Wall Street's "fear gauge," the Cboe Volatility Index (VIX), has dropped to 20, defying recent market swings. Despite large realized swings in US stocks, the VIX's divergence from implied volatility may be unsustainable. Strategists expect the VIX to "catch up" in the next month, but a more dovish US monetary stance and easing trade tensions may justify lower premiums for equity price swings. The gap between implied and historic price swings may narrow as market internals imply a fair value of 31.

site_title: Eurozone unemployment falls to decade-low in November
summary: Eurozone unemployment fell to a 10-year low of 7.9% in November, near pre-crisis levels. The rate has been steadily decreasing since 2016, when it first fell below 10%. Unemployment rates vary across countries, with Germany at 3.3% and Greece at 18.6%. The EU-wide rate remains stable at 6.7%, the lowest since 2000.

site_title: Gulf Air says its niche will be to offer premium service
summary: Gulf Air, Bahrain's national carrier, plans to offer premium services to increase passenger numbers and revive its fortunes. The airline will expand its destinations, introduce a more spacious economy class, and launch a luxury business class product. It aims to add around 8 new destinations and carry 5.8 million passengers this year. Over the next few years, Gulf Air plans to add more cities in Europe, the Middle East, and the Indian Ocean, and launch flights to the US and China. The airline has 39 aircraft on order, including Boeing Dreamliners and Airbus A320neos.

site_title: Raffles United to undertake rights issue of up to 234m new shares at S$0.05 per share
summary: Raffles United Holdings plans to issue up to 234 million new shares at S$0.05 each, representing a 39% discount to its closing market price. The rights issue aims to reduce bank borrowings, finance working capital, and strengthen its balance sheet. Under the maximum subscription scenario, net proceeds would be approximately S$11.6 million. The company has been placed on the Singapore Exchange watch list and its top executives have been under investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rally at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened higher on Wednesday, driven by easing US-China trade war concerns. London's FTSE 100 rose 0.8%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 increased by 1%, and Paris' CAC 40 rose 1%. Asian equities also surged, fueled by optimism over a potential US-China trade deal. The rally was attributed to gains in mining and healthcare sectors, while US stocks reached fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: What will cause the next US recession?
summary: The next US recession is likely to be triggered by a sudden, sharp "flight to safety" in financial markets, rather than a sudden shift by the Fed from a growth-nurturing to an inflation-fighting policy. This pattern has generated downturns since at least 1825, and investors, speculators, and financial institutions are generally hedged against the foreseeable shocks. The near-inverted yield curve, low nominal and real bond yields, and equity values all suggest that US financial markets have begun to price in the likelihood of a recession, which could arrive whenever the next financial shock comes.

site_title: China says trade talks with US have concluded, results to be released soon
summary: China's trade talks with the US have concluded, with results to be released soon, according to China's Foreign Ministry. This comes after the talks took place in Beijing.

images.alt_text: Trade talks in Beijing between China and the United States have concluded and the results will be released soon, China's Foreign Ministry spokesman Lu Kang told a daily news briefing on Wednesday.

site_title: China's car market faces more gloom after first drop in decades
summary: China's car market experienced its first decline in decades, with sales falling 6% to 22.7 million units in 2018, according to the China Passenger Car Association. The trade war and economic uncertainty are contributing factors, with consumers tightening their belts. The industry is expected to continue struggling, with some manufacturers scaling back operations. However, electric vehicles are gaining popularity, with sales predicted to rise by 30% in 2019, driven by government policies and environmental concerns. The market is expected to remain unchanged in 2019, with a possible rebound in 2020.

site_title: Making the most of AGM season as an investor
summary: Retail investors can make the most of AGM season by personally interacting with company boards and management to address queries and concerns. AGMs provide a rare opportunity for investors to meet with those overseeing company management, allowing for direct communication and potentially influencing investment decisions. This face-to-face encounter can be valuable for investors seeking to better understand companies and make informed investment choices.

site_title: BOJ mulls unpleasant policy options if Fed puts rate hikes on hold
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is considering more stimulus to counter a potential yen surge if the US Federal Reserve pauses interest rate hikes, which could harm Japan's economic recovery. The US dollar's recent flash crash against the yen has heightened concerns, and the BOJ's focus has shifted from reducing its massive monetary stimulus to maintaining it. If the Fed stops hiking rates, the BOJ may need to act, potentially including cutting interest rates, to prevent a sustained yen rise and economic downturn.

site_title: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, wife MacKenzie set to divorce
summary: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos and his wife MacKenzie Bezos announced their decision to divorce in a joint statement on Twitter, citing a long trial separation. The move comes as Amazon surpassed Microsoft as the world's most valuable company, with Bezos' fortune reaching over $160 billion. The couple founded Amazon in 1994, which has grown into a retail giant. The divorce news comes after a decade-long separation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore incorporated businesses will have access to subsidised digital solutions through a new initiative launched by the Infocomm Media Development Authority and Enterprise Singapore. The Straits Times Index climbed 1.12% on Wednesday, driven by US-China trade talks. Daily securities turnover on the Singapore Exchange fell 13% year-on-year in December to S$837 million. Condo rents in Singapore decreased 0.2% in December, while HDB rents rose 0.6%.

site_title: China's HNA Group sells Manhattan building near Trump Tower
summary: HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate, has sold a Manhattan building near Trump Tower for $422 million, helping to alleviate debt concerns and address US national-security worries. The 90% stake was owned by HNA, with minority partners MHP Real Estate Services and Atco Properties & Management retaining a share. The sale is part of HNA's efforts to dispose of over $20 billion in assets since last year, following a US government decision to aid the company in addressing liquidity challenges. The sale satisfies concerns from the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US regarding HNA's ownership.

site_title: Kim Jong Un leaves China after talks with Xi on Trump sanctions
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un left Beijing after a day-long visit with Chinese President Xi Jinping, where they discussed ways to strengthen ties and lay out strategy for a potential summit with US President Donald Trump to curb Pyongyang's nuclear ambitions. The talks, which included a banquet, suggest negotiations over North Korea's nuclear arsenal are gaining momentum. Kim's delegation included officials focused on diplomatic and security policy, and he may leverage his relationship with Xi to push for US concessions in nuclear talks.

site_title: China stocks end higher on trade talk hopes, policy support plans
summary: China's stocks closed higher on Wednesday, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks and Beijing's plans to boost consumer spending. The CSI300 index rose 1.0% to 3,078.48, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.7% to 2,544.34. Shares of automakers and consumer firms, particularly home appliance makers, rallied as Beijing encourages domestic spending. The US trade delegation in Beijing extended its meetings with Chinese officials, indicating progress on trade issues, and the yuan strengthened against the US dollar.

site_title: US oil exports to Asia set to rise in Q2 as freight costs fall
summary: US oil exports to Asia are expected to rise in the second quarter as freight costs fall and prices drop by 50 US cents a barrel. This makes US crude more competitive against Middle Eastern oil. US crude grades popular with Asian buyers include light oils like West Texas Intermediate. The increased exports are due to weaker US demand and sellers cutting prices following lower freight rates.

site_title: Air France expansion lags behind KLM, stoking sibling tensions
summary: Air France-KLM's annual traffic figures show KLM outpacing Air France in revenue passenger kilometers, with a 4% gain versus 1.9% at Air France. The Dutch arm's higher profit margins have fueled sibling tensions within the group. New CEO Ben Smith must balance French pilots' demands for higher pay without alienating Dutch counterparts. Despite a 3.5% rise in group traffic, Air France-KLM shares fell 30% last year, lagging rival IAG SA's 5% drop.

images.alt_text: Air France-KLM Group's annual traffic figures show that the company's Dutch arm again grew faster than its French sister carrier, where flights were disrupted by strikes as pilots pushed for higher pay.

site_title: Obike creditors' meeting to be held on Jan 23 at Shaw Tower
summary: A meeting has been scheduled for January 23 for the liquidators of defunct bicycle-rental firm oBike to update creditors on the winding-up process. Creditors can find more information and submit claims through the provided website or in-person at the meeting. No payments or distributions will be made at the meeting, and creditors can still submit claims after the meeting. This follows oBike's placement under liquidation due to creditor application.

site_title: EU banking watchdog says new cryptoasset rules may be needed
summary: The European Banking Authority (EBA) suggests that new EU rules may be needed to regulate cryptoassets, citing the need to protect consumers from risks and prevent unfair competition. The EBA warns of the potential for cryptoassets to diverge from EU financial rules, and recommends a comprehensive review of EU anti-money laundering legislation. The watchdog also emphasizes the need for a technologically neutral approach to regulation, considering factors such as energy usage and climate change. A report by the EBA marks a step towards regulating the sector in Europe, with the aim of developing a common monitoring template and studying business models involving cryptoassets.

site_title: CDL prices S$125m of five-year notes at 3% coupon; 96 bps over 5-year SOR
summary: CDL has priced S$125 million of five-year notes at a 3% coupon, 96 bps over the 5-year SOR. The unrated notes will be sold at 100% of principal to institutional investors. The proceeds will be used for general working capital and corporate funding, potentially including refinancing outstanding loans.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump on US-China trade optimism; won gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose nearly 2% on Wednesday, driven by optimism over a potential trade deal between the US and China. The won also gained, while bond yields rose. Analysts attribute the gains to expectations of trade negotiations and reports on a US trade delegation's meetings with Chinese officials. The Kospi's largest daily percentage gain since November 2018, it marked a significant rebound from the previous 30 days' decline.

site_title: Jho Low dismisses WSJ report about China's offer to bail out 1MDB
summary: Fugitive businessman Jho Low has dismissed a Wall Street Journal report claiming China offered to bail out 1MDB, a Malaysian state investment fund, as "a continuation of a trial by media" led by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. The report alleged China would use its influence to drop US probes into 1MDB's alleged graft scandal in exchange for lucrative stakes in Chinese infrastructure projects. Malaysia and former Prime Minister Najib Razak have also denied the allegations, calling them "groundless" and "politically motivated".

site_title: Easing SME loan demand could frustrate Malaysian banks
summary: Malaysian banks face a challenge in meeting corporate lending targets, with SME loan growth expected to moderate in 2019 due to weak demand. Despite this, banks' net interest margins are likely to remain squeezed. Analysts warn of risks from construction and real estate exposure, as well as the oil and gas sector, which is experiencing volatility and restructuring. Household loan growth is expected to ease, while commercial property loans may see a pick-up but are unlikely to be sustainable due to an over-supply of office space and shopping malls.

site_title: November trade rebound little comfort for Germany
summary: Germany's trade surplus grew 6.1% in November, reaching 19 billion euros, but the increase offered little comfort for the country's economy, which has been impacted by global trade tensions and uncertainty. Exports fell 0.4% and imports dropped 1.6% month-on-month. The data suggests Germany may have suffered a "technical recession" in the second half of 2017, but private consumption and government spending could prevent a full economic contraction. The trade surplus remains a point of contention in US-EU trade talks, with US President Donald Trump targeting the EU's car imports.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on US-China trade talks
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 1.10% to close at 20,427.06, as signs of progress in US-China trade talks boosted investor sentiment. Global bourses also rallied, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records. The rally extends a five-day rally in Singapore stocks, which are set to release GDP data on Thursday.

site_title: Factory tour for North Korea's Kim on secretive Beijing visit
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un visited a pharmaceutical factory in Beijing during his secretive trip to China, seeking economic support and diplomatic backing ahead of his expected summit with US President Donald Trump. The meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping focused on Kim's expected meeting with Trump, and Chinese officials likely aimed to impress Kim on the benefits of their economic transformation. The trip is seen as a strategic turning point for North Korea, with experts stating that China's cooperation is crucial for Kim's economic transformation and denuclearization efforts.

site_title: Tencent unveils a Siri-like digital assistant for WeChat
summary: Tencent is introducing a Siri-like digital assistant, dubbed "Xiaowei", for its WeChat messaging service, helping users with tasks like playing music and hailing rides. The assistant will link to various services, including Tencent's own and third-party apps. This is Tencent's first integration of a digital assistant into WeChat, a move to boost advertising and user engagement. The company aims to accelerate monetization of advertising on Mini Programs and expand its services to attract more users, particularly in the mobile payments market.

site_title: World's priciest housing market set for most densely-packed apartment blocks
summary: Hong Kong's world's least-affordable housing market is set to become even denser with the planned construction of a 47-storey residential block containing 5,000 apartments. The development, by CK Asset Holdings Ltd, will feature an average of 53 units per floor, or about 300 square feet per apartment, making it the city's densest private residential project. The units may fetch around HK$14,000 (S$2,423) per square foot, further contributing to the city's high property prices.

site_title: Landlord Capital World grants share options worth S$1.75m to marketing consultancy One World
summary: Property developer Capital World granted Hong Kong-based marketing consultancy One World Corporation share options worth S$1.75 million, a 2.78% stake in the company, at a discounted price of S$0.035 per share. One World obtained the options due to its role as referrer for a previous deal involving PRG Holdings. The deal, which saw PRG Holdings take up to 26.3% stake in Capital World, included a referral fee paid to One World. The grant is subject to shareholder approval at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Xiaomi sinks after billions of shares are unlocked for sale
summary: Xiaomi's stock price plummeted after billions of shares were unlocked for sale, shedding US$14 billion in market value. The company's Hong Kong debut saw a six-month lockup period expire, allowing investors to sell their shares. Over 3 billion shares, or 19% of outstanding shares, were sold, leading to a 6.9% drop in value. The stock is now trading at 16 times projected earnings, less than half its previous July multiple. Analysts predict a rebound to HK$16.72 within the next year, but hedge funds have increased their bearish bets on the company.

site_title: UK government will consider new law to tackle illegal drone use
summary: The UK government will consider introducing new legislation to combat illegal drone use, following disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports. Cabinet Office Minister David Lidington stated that the government is looking to strengthen the law and that airports should invest in technology to detect and stop drones. The move comes after flights were halted for about an hour at Heathrow due to a drone sighting, raising concerns about the potential for similar disruptions at larger airports.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Theresa May's de-facto deputy said the government will consider toughening the law to tackle the illegal use of drones after flights were disrupted at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares hit 8-week high on optimism over Sino-US trade talks
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1% to an eight-week high, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index also climbed 1.5% to its highest level since December 14. Energy stocks surged 1.9% and miners like Rio Tinto and Fortescue Metals Group rose 1.1% and 2.7% respectively. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index jumped 1.4% to an over eight-week high, while healthcare stocks also rose. US President Donald Trump said talks with China were going "very well."

site_title: Philippines' regulator rejects Indonesia's Go-Jek's application for Manila ride-hailing service
summary: The Philippines' transport regulator, the Land Transportation Franchising and Regulatory Board (LTFRB), has rejected an application by Go-Jek's subsidiary, Velox Technology Philippines Inc, to launch a ride-hailing service in the country due to foreign ownership issues. The regulator stated that Velox did not meet the citizenship requirement and its application was not verified in accordance with rules. This decision comes despite Go-Jek's significant investment from major players such as Tencent Holdings Ltd and JD.com Inc.

site_title: SGX: Daily securities turnover fell 13% year-on-year in December
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 13% year-on-year decline in daily securities turnover to S$837 million in December. Total market turnover stood at S$16.7 billion, down 22% from November. Two new listings occurred, raising S$15.2 million, and 28 new bond listings raised S$14.2 billion. Derivatives volume rose 17% year-on-year to 18.35 million, while market turnover of all securities products increased 22% to S$23.5 billion in 2018.

site_title: Buying a diamond, with more clarity on where it's from
summary: Tiffany & Co. is launching a program to provide customers with information on the origin of their diamonds, including the country where they were mined. The program, set to begin Wednesday, will initially provide the country of origin but will expand to include information on where each diamond was cut, polished, and set in 2020. Despite the effort, the company acknowledges that it cannot provide precise location information due to the opaque nature of the diamond supply chain. The move aims to attract younger shoppers who prioritize transparency and sustainability.

site_title: AIIB sets up US$500m fund to invest in infrastructure corporate bonds
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) has established a US$500 million fund to invest in corporate bonds for infrastructure projects, aiming to boost private capital and promote ESG investments in Asia. The fund will focus on developing infrastructure as an asset class, growing debt capital markets, and attracting investments with ESG considerations. The move aims to address Asia's estimated US$460 billion infrastructure investment gap, and the AIIB hopes to establish a ESG market in the region through its initiatives. The fund will initially deploy its own capital and support other investors to set up similar platforms.

site_title: HNA's haphazard selloff keeps getting trickier
summary: HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate, is selling a slew of assets to pay down debt, totaling nearly US$100 billion. The company showcased at least 20 assets to bankers in Beijing, including stakes in an online lender, life insurer, and brokerage. However, a lack of clear strategy and market perceptions of creditor clout make it challenging to unwind the US$50 billion buying spree. Falling asset prices and the presence of China Development Bank monitoring sales also raise doubts about the existence of a coherent vision.

site_title: SP Group sets up 38 high-speed charging points for electric vehicles
summary: SP Group has launched 38 high-speed charging points for electric vehicles, with 19 43kW AC and 19 50kW DC chargers, across 8 locations in Singapore. The chargers can power up a mid-sized electric car within an hour, offering "at least 50% cost savings" compared to petrol-powered models. The rollout is part of SP Group's plan to launch 1,000 charging points by 2020, with discounted rates for Grab's electric fleet.

site_title: China to propose wider 2019 fiscal deficit amid slowdown
summary: China's Finance Ministry is set to propose a 2.8% budget deficit target for 2019, a slight increase from 2.6% in 2018, amid a slowing economy and trade war with the US. Officials aim to balance support for the economy with controlling debt levels. This expansion is smaller than forecasted and can be supplemented by special bonds for local infrastructure projects. The proposal will be presented to China's National People's Congress in March for approval.

site_title: Nissan unveils new Leaf electric car delayed by Ghosn's arrest
summary: Nissan unveiled the new Leaf electric car after delaying its launch due to former chairman Carlos Ghosn's arrest. The Leaf e+ boasts a 40% increased range, reaching up to 226 miles, and will be available in Japan this month, followed by the US and Europe in mid-2019. The new model narrows the driving-range gap with Tesla's Model 3 and General Motors' Chevrolet Bolt, and the Leaf e+ starts at around $30,000 in the US. Nissan sold over 380,000 Leaf vehicles globally since its 2010 launch.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 5.39 points to 1,678.15. Volume was 68.42 million lots worth RM21.21 million, with 153 gainers surpassing 43 losers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start day with more gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose more than one percent on Wednesday, extending a rally into a fourth day, driven by hopes for success in China-US trade talks. The Hang Seng Index gained 1.40%, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.39% and the Shenzhen Composite Index put on 0.29%. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and comes despite US President Trump's new threats.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars firm as Sino-US talks extended
summary: The Australian dollar rose to a three-week high, up 0.3% to US$0.7162, as speculation about US-China trade talks boosted Asian share markets and risk sentiment. The New Zealand dollar also firmed 0.4% to US$0.6752. US-China trade talks extended into Wednesday, with signs of progress on farm and energy commodity purchases and increased market access. However, disappointing home building data in Australia and a cooling job market in New Zealand offset the gains, with bond prices falling.

site_title: Singapore ecotourism plan sparks squawks of protest
summary: Singapore is developing a vast ecotourism zone in the Mandai district, but environmentalists are protesting the project, citing concerns about habitat destruction and animal deaths. The zone will include a bird park, rainforest park, and a 400-room resort, despite warnings from wildlife experts that the development will harm biodiversity. While the developer claims to be taking precautions to mitigate the impact, green groups argue that the project is too large and will lead to further loss of natural habitats in the area.

site_title: Qualcomm says Apple CEO's comment "misleading"
summary: Qualcomm has disputed Apple CEO Tim Cook's claim that there have been no recent settlement discussions between the two companies, calling his statement "misleading". Qualcomm claims to have been in talks with Apple for a resolution to their licensing dispute for 18 months, contrary to Cook's statement. The dispute revolves around patent licensing practices and trade secrets, with Qualcomm accusing Apple of not fairly compensating it for its innovations. The issue is also relevant to an ongoing antitrust trial with the US Federal Trade Commission.

site_title: Asia: Markets power ahead on rising trade-talks hopes
summary: Asian markets surged on Wednesday, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks, with Hong Kong and Shanghai rising 2.4% and 1.6% respectively. Tokyo and Sydney also gained, with Seoul adding 1.8% amid speculation of a potential North Korean meeting with US President Donald Trump. The dollar fell against higher-yielding currencies, and oil prices rose, boosted by hopes of reduced production by Opec and other major producers. Investors are cautiously optimistic about a potential end to the trade war, with analysts predicting a slowdown in growth but still acceptable earnings.

site_title: Apple cuts Q1 production plan for new iPhones by 10%: Nikkei
summary: Apple has cut its Q1 production plan for new iPhones by about 10% due to a request from the company to its suppliers. This decision was made late last month, according to sources. The reduction in production is a response to declining demand and the company's efforts to manage inventory. The exact reasons behind the decrease are not specified, but it is believed to be a strategic move to avoid overproduction and ensure a smoother supply chain.

site_title: Stop holding Americans 'hostage' over shutdown, Pelosi tells Trump
summary: Top congressional Democrats accused President Trump of holding Americans "hostage" by refusing to strike a deal to fund shuttered government agencies, and using fear mongering to justify his demand for a border wall. Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi called for the government to reopen, while President Trump claimed that Democrats were manufacturing a crisis and refusing to fund border security. The standoff has left about 800,000 federal workers unpaid, with no signs of a breakthrough imminent.

site_title: PAL Network to develop insurtech products for Toyota Tsusho and Allianz Malaysia
summary: PAL Network, a Singapore-based insurtech startup, has signed two MOU agreements with Toyota Tsusho and Allianz Malaysia to develop proof-of-concept for new smart contract-based insurance products using its blockchain technology. The partnerships aim to facilitate underwriting and creation of new insurance products in South-east Asia and Malaysia, with personalized, pay-as-you-go microinsurance products to be launched later. PAL Network's blockchain protocol was launched in 2018, and the company plans to launch a b2b insurer's dashboard for insurers on January 14.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Rich Capital, KrisEnergy, OKP Holdings, Chew's Group
summary: Rich Capital plans to expand into construction with a proposed S$43.98 million acquisition. KrisEnergy restarted oil production at the Wassana field after Tropical Storm Pabuk. OKP Holdings' pre-trial conference has been rescheduled to January 21. Chew's Group aims to change its name and diversify its business following the sale of its four units.

site_title: Bored and stressed, US workers hit by shutdown head back to school
summary: US federal workers, affected by a 3-week partial government shutdown, attended a one-day college event at American University to tackle boredom and stress. Over 550 workers, including 800,000 impacted, signed up for free classes and networking opportunities. Many cited financial concerns and the uncertainty of the shutdown's duration. Participants expressed a desire to return to work, with some fearing the shutdown could demoralize public service workers and lead to financial strain. The event aimed to provide a welcome distraction and support for affected workers.

site_title: Singapore condo rents dip 0.2% in December; HDB rents up 0.6%: SRX flash estimates
summary: Singapore condominium rents decreased by 0.2% in December, while HDB rents rose 0.6% after dipping in November, according to SRX flash estimates. Non-landed private residential rents have stabilized within a narrow 1% growth band over the past year. HDB rental increases may be a blip, with potential downward pressure in the coming months due to flats reaching the five-year minimum occupancy period.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday, STI up 0.5% to 3,139.03
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 16.09 points, or 0.5%, to 3,139.03. Gainers outnumbered losers 83 to 27, with Ezion rising 1.9% and UOB and Singtel also gaining 0.9% and 0.7%, respectively.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,155.29, up 1.04% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 1.04% to 3,155.29. Advancers outnumbered decliners 229 to 116, with top gainers including Venture Corp, Jardine Matheson Holdings, and Jardine Cycle & Carriage. This marks the fourth consecutive session of gains, ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks opens higher on US-China trade talks
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.85% or 171.41 points at 20,375.45, driven by signs of progress in US-China trade talks. This follows global rallies, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Trump wants trade deal with China to boost stock market, sources say
summary: US President Donald Trump is pushing for a trade deal with China to boost the stock market, which has slumped due to concerns over the ongoing trade war. Talks between mid-level US and Chinese officials in Beijing have been extended for a third day, with Trump tweeting that progress is being made. The US delegation is seeking to address China's alleged trade abuses and demand structural economic reforms, while Trump's economic advisers are urging a quick resolution to soothe battered markets. A deal must be reached by March 1, when US tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese goods are set to rise to 25%.

site_title: Singapore SMEs get help going digital from the get-go with new initiative
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) and Enterprise Singapore have launched an initiative providing subsidised digital solutions to newly incorporated SMEs. The program offers costs waived for at least six months and affordable pricing for the remaining period, covering five categories of core business functions, including accounting, digital marketing, and cybersecurity. This initiative aims to help SMEs go digital from the start, promoting their growth and competitiveness in the market.

site_title: Tesla sued over 2018 fatal crash
summary: Tesla was sued by the family of a passenger who died in a 2018 fatal crash in Florida. The lawsuit alleges the Tesla battery was inadequately protected, making the vehicle defective. The driver lost control while trying to pass another car, and the vehicle crossed a sidewalk, hitting a wall and erupting in flames. The suit claims the Tesla S battery was prone to intense fires that couldn't be extinguished. The case seeks damages for the family's loss.

site_title: Billions of Xiaomi shares are about to be unlocked for sale
summary: Xiaomi's 6-month lockup period for investors has expired, allowing over 3 billion shares to be sold, accounting for 19% of outstanding shares. The company's stock price has dropped 7.5% due to a JPMorgan Chase & Co. recommendation cut. Despite this, analysts still predict a rebound to the IPO price, and some investors may want to hold on. The stock trades at 17 times projected earnings, 44% more than Apple, which is experiencing its worst quarterly rout in over a decade.

site_title: US retail imports level off after China tariff avoidance rush
summary: US retail imports have leveled off after a months-long rush to bring in Chinese merchandise before higher tariffs hit, according to a retail trade report. Imports at major US container ports handled 1.81 million TEU in November, a 2.5% year-over-year increase but a 11.4% drop from October's record. Retailers, including apparel sellers, brought in spring merchandise early to protect against higher prices due to tariffs, which are expected to continue impacting the global economy.

site_title: US startup eyes next generation of burgers with relish
summary: US startup Impossible Foods unveiled its "next generation" burger, version 2.0, at CES in Las Vegas. The plant-based patty has no gluten, hormones, or antibiotics and is kosher and halal-certified. With 5,000 restaurants serving its product, the company plans to expand globally, including markets in Singapore, Hong Kong, and Macau. Impossible Foods aims to reduce land usage for livestock production and claims its technology can transform the global food system.

site_title: Tim Cook's US$12m bonus for 2018 is his biggest ever
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook collected his largest annual bonus of $12 million in 2018, following record revenue and profit, and a market value temporarily exceeding $1 trillion. Cook also received a $3 million salary, $121 million in shares from a 10-year stock award, and $682,000 in perks. The bonus was tied to revenue and operating income targets, both of which rose 16% from the previous year. However, the company's recent announcement of lower-than-anticipated iPhone demand in China and elsewhere may make it challenging for Cook to repeat this feat.

site_title: The shoe does not fit: Australia PM tripped up by doctored footwear
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison laughed off widespread mockery over photoshopped images of him wearing clean, white sneakers, replacing his battered old shoes. The images, which featured his family, drew public attention and ridicule on social media. Morrison decided to respond, saying he was happy with his original shoes and not bothered by the attempts to Photoshop him into cleaner footwear. The incident was seen as a lighthearted moment in the midst of Morrison's busy schedule.

site_title: Heathrow Airport halts departures after drone sighting
summary: Heathrow Airport suspended all departing flights on January 8, 2019, after a drone sighting. Arriving planes continued to land. The incident came two weeks after similar drone sightings at Gatwick Airport, which led to travel disruptions. The UK government is extending drone exclusion zones around airports to 5km and introducing registration and online pilot competency tests for drone operators. Police will be able to fine users up to £100 for non-compliance.

site_title: Olam International to shut sugar trade desk: spokesman
summary: Olam International Ltd will shut its sugar trade desk amid a global supply glut and low sugar futures prices. The decision follows a second consecutive annual decline in sugar futures and comes after other trading companies have scaled back or sold sugar businesses. Olam owns two sugar mills in India and crushes over 1 million tonnes of sugarcane. The move is seen as a sign of pressure on trading houses, with sugar trading margins considered "terrible."

site_title: HPH Trust, 4 Hong Kong port operators form alliance to manage Kwai Tsing container terminals' berths
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) has formed an alliance with four Hong Kong port operators to manage 23 berths across nine terminals in Kwai Tsing container terminals. The alliance aims to improve efficiency, maximize customer benefits, and reduce environmental impact. Key terms include shared revenue and costs, and the agreement can be terminated with six months' written notice. The partnership is expected to enhance service for customers and increase competitiveness, enabling better utilization of existing capacity and accommodating growing shipping alliances.

site_title: Australia actress Margot Robbie to portray Barbie in first live-action film
summary: Margot Robbie will portray Barbie in the first live-action film, set to celebrate the doll's 60th birthday. The film, co-produced with Robbie's production company and Mattel Films, will be the first live-action adaptation of the iconic character. Robbie will play the role of the original blonde, blue-eyed Barbie. The film aims to have a positive impact on children and audiences worldwide, following Mattel's efforts to revive the brand after facing competition from video games and screens. The project is part of Mattel's new studio and follows CEO Ynon Kreiz's ambitions to revive the company.

site_title: Rich Capital plans to buy 2 construction firms for up to S$43.98m via issue of new shares
summary: Rich Capital, a Singapore-based construction firm, plans to acquire two construction companies, Rich-Link Construction and Rich-Link Builders, for up to S$43.98m via the issuance of new shares. The acquisition, valued between S$53.5m and S$62.9m, aims to expand the company's asset base and increase its business operations. The deal, subject to regulatory approval and shareholder approval, will see Mr. Wang and Rich-Link Group collectively own up to 64.74% of the enlarged share capital.

site_title: London remains top destination for European tech funding
summary: London maintained its position as Europe's top tech funding destination in 2018, with £1.8 billion in venture capital funding, accounting for 72% of UK tech businesses' total £2.5 billion. This is nearly double the amount Berlin received. London's strong position as a global financial hub and its universities' focus on AI helped attract investment. However, the UK's exit from the EU has raised concerns about its appeal, with investors asking more questions about hiring from abroad.

site_title: US policy seen offering 'Pop & Gridlock' for markets this year
summary: US policy developments may offer near-term relief for markets, as trade-related market weakness and economic-data impact are now "clearly on display" in the US and China. Strategists at Morgan Stanley expect policy drag to keep stocks range-bound over the year, with lower year-end estimates for the S&P 500. Concerns include potential healthcare policy proposals and drug pricing, but Asia's markets may benefit from easing trade tensions and policy easing in China.

site_title: World Bank flags rising debt and other economic dangers
summary: The World Bank has warned of rising debt and economic dangers in its semi-annual Global Economic Prospects report. The report highlights a surge in borrowing by the poorest nations, mostly in foreign currency, and debt from private lenders without concessional terms. Rising trade tensions are also a major concern, with the World Bank citing these as the most high-profile risk to the global economy. The report's findings underscore the need for policymakers to address these issues to prevent economic instability.

site_title: US-China trade talks extended amid some signs of progress
summary: US and Chinese trade talks are set to continue for a third day in Beijing amid signs of progress, including increased purchases of US farm and energy commodities and access to China's markets. The talks, which began on Monday, are focused on structural reforms, intellectual property, and enforcement. US officials have confirmed the extension, despite differences on Chinese reforms and technology transfer. The talks aim to avoid a 25% tariff hike on $200 billion of Chinese imports by March 2, which would harm China's slowing economy.

site_title: World Bank cuts global growth forecast amid US-China trade conflict
summary: The World Bank cut its global growth forecast due to the US-China trade conflict, predicting 2.9% growth this year and 2.8% in 2020. US economic growth is expected to slow to 2.5% this year and 1.7% next year. The downgrade warns rising risks and urges policymakers to prepare for a potential economic downturn.

site_title: Facebook CEO plans 2019 forums on tech's role in society
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced his goal for 2019: hosting public forums on how technology can better serve society. The move comes after a challenging period for the company, marked by criticism over data handling and its approach to critics. Zuckerberg aims to discuss the opportunities, challenges, hopes, and anxieties surrounding technology's role in society. The forums are intended to foster open discussions and better understand the impact of technology on society.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on optimism over trade talks
summary: US stocks rose for the third consecutive session on Tuesday, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1.1% to 23,787.45, while the S&P 500 advanced 1.0% to 2,574.41 and the Nasdaq Composite Index climbed 1.1% to 6,897.00. The gains were attributed to positive developments in US-China trade talks, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Gold falls on better risk sentiment, dollar recovery
summary: Gold prices fell 0.6% to $1,281.32 due to improved risk sentiment and a recovering dollar, as investors bet on a potential trade deal between the US and China. The dollar index rose 0.3% after US Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell hinted at pausing interest rate hikes. Gold has gained 11% since its 11/2-year low in mid-August, but profit-taking is expected if trade talks progress.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: LTC Corporation's controlling family extended its S$0.925 per share exit offer to the end of January 31. The offer has garnered 89.77% acceptance. Singapore's SGX signed a strategic cooperation agreement with China's CCI Administrative Bureau, expanding financial collaborations. Chew's Group will change its name to OneApex and diversify its business. Swee Hong won a S$32.5 million contract from PUB for the DTSS phase 2 project.

site_title: Newest Indian bank plans US$11.7b merger to meet rules
summary: India's newest bank, Bandhan Bank Ltd, is set to merge with mortgage financier Gruh Finance Ltd in a $11.7 billion deal, aiming to meet shareholding rules and accelerate expansion. The deal will see investors in Gruh receive 568 shares of Bandhan for every 1,000 they own. The merger is expected to help Bandhan founder Chandra Shekhar Ghosh comply with the Reserve Bank of India's ownership rules, while also allowing the micro lender to expand into new loan categories.

site_title: KrisEnergy says oil production restarts at Wassana field after Tropical Storm Pabuk in Thailand
summary: KrisEnergy reports that oil production has resumed at the Wassana field in the Gulf of Thailand after Tropical Storm Pabuk. The company's mobile offshore production unit and floating storage and offloading vessel have been reconnected, and the infill drilling program has resumed. The Wassana field, operated by KrisEnergy with a 89% working interest, covers 1,525 sq km in the Southern Pattani Basin.

site_title: High-tech border wall plan on display at CES
summary: A US startup, Quanergy Systems, is showcasing a high-tech border wall solution at CES, utilizing Lidar technology, widely used in self-driving cars, to detect and track intruders along the US-Mexico border. The system is claimed to be more capable than a physical wall, costing around 2-3% of the price of a physical barrier, and offers environmental benefits. Quanergy Systems has deployed the technology in pilot projects on the India-Pakistan frontier and a small section of the US border, with CEO Louay Eldada stating it can see day and night in any weather and automatically track intruders.

images.alt_text: The same technology used in self-driving cars is being touted as a potential high-tech solution to the US border wall conundrum - with some added benefits.

site_title: Trump campaign chief gave polling data to Russian
summary: Donald Trump's former campaign chairman Paul Manafort admitted in a court filing that he provided polling data to a Russian with ties to intelligence during the 2016 US presidential election. Manafort denied allegations that he lied about his dealings with Konstantin Kilimnik, arguing he forgot details due to the hectic campaign schedule. The revelation adds to evidence of contacts between Russians and the Trump campaign, though Mueller has yet to prove a conspiracy. Manafort has already been convicted and pleaded guilty to financial crimes and witness tampering related to his work in Ukraine.

site_title: Europe: Trade hopes buoy shares to three-week high
summary: European shares rose to a three-week high on Tuesday, driven by hopes of a possible US-China trade deal. The Stoxx 600 index climbed 0.9%, while the FTSE 100 and DAX indices rose 0.7% and 0.5%, respectively. Retailers and technology stocks also rebounded, with the sectoral index rising 2.1%. Analysts expect the trade talks to continue, but warn that tariffs could still impact markets, particularly during earnings season.

site_title: HNA touts assets for sale as funding crunch intensifies
summary: HNA Group, a China-based conglomerate, is shedding non-core businesses as it faces a cash crunch. The company presented a list of at least 20 assets, including hotel projects, stakes in online lenders and insurers, and a brokerage unit, to bankers. HNA is looking to raise funds through asset sales, following a $50 billion acquisition spree that has left the company with soaring debt. The company is scaling back operations to focus on core assets, with China Development Bank supervising asset disposals.

site_title: Apple CEO confident of prospects despite naysayers
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook expressed confidence in the company's prospects despite naysayers, citing a "culture of innovation" that will keep Apple a major force in technology. In an interview with CNBC, Cook dismissed concerns about the company's future, referencing past criticisms. Apple shares rose 2.2% after the interview, following a 10% drop in the previous session after the company cut its revenue outlook for the latest quarter. Cook's comments helped alleviate concerns about the company's future, with shares now trading at $151.19.

site_title: UK Brexit vote set for January 15 amid talk of delay
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May's EU withdrawal deal is set to be voted on by MPs on January 15, amid speculation of a possible delay. The deal, which includes a backstop to maintain open borders with Ireland, has faced opposition from lawmakers on all sides, including the Conservative Party and Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party. May is seeking further assurances from the EU, and has hosted drinks parties for lawmakers to win them over. The UK government denies plans to delay Brexit, but EU officials consider it a "hypothetical option" that could have significant economic and legal consequences.

site_title: Kimly receives S$1.4m advance repayment from aborted sale of ASC
summary: Kimly, a Singapore-listed coffee shop operator, received S$1.4 million in advance repayment from vendor Wang Chia Ye for its aborted acquisition of Asian Story Corporation (ASC). The balance of S$2.6 million is repayable in two equal instalments by Nov 29, 2020 and 2021. This comes after the company cancelled its S$16 million cash deal for ASC in November last year. The security for payments has been changed to quoted equity securities held by Wang, with dividends applied towards repayment. Executive chairman Lim Hee Liat and director Chia Cher Khiang are under investigation by Singapore authorities.

site_title: Eli Lilly makes US$8b bet on drugs for rare cancers with Loxo Oncology buy
summary: Eli Lilly has acquired Loxo Oncology for $8 billion, its largest deal in 143 years, betting on a pipeline of cancer drugs targeting rare genetic mutations. The acquisition comes after Bristol-Myers Squibb's $74 billion Celgene deal, and analysts say it may signal a new wave of large healthcare acquisitions. Loxo's drug, Vitrakvi, has shown impressive results in clinical trials, with 80% of patients experiencing dramatic improvement, and Lilly aims to expand its oncology portfolio through its own research and deals.

site_title: Oil prices rise over 2% on trade talk optimism
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% on Tuesday, supported by optimism over US-China trade talks. US WTI crude oil futures settled at $49.78 a barrel, up 2.6%, while Brent crude futures rose 2.4% to $58.72. The increase is driven by hopes that a resolution to the trade dispute could boost crude demand.

site_title: Germany's Daimler is selling a truck that can brake, accelerate, steer on its own
summary: Daimler, the parent company of Mercedes-Benz, is set to launch a heavy-duty truck in the US that can brake, accelerate, and steer autonomously at all speeds. The updated Freightliner Cascadia will utilize radar and camera data to enable partially autonomous technology, aiming to improve safety and logistics efficiency. Daimler plans to offer highly automated vehicles on some routes within a decade, competing with Tesla, Volvo, and Paccar. The move is part of a $500 million investment in autonomous technology, with 200 new jobs added in the US, as the company seeks to maintain its lead in the market and expand sales and profits.

site_title: China increases US patent holdings tenfold from 2008 but IBM holds on to top spot
summary: China increased US patent holdings tenfold from 2008, with 12,589 US patents issued in 2018, a 12% jump. Chinese inventors now pace to overtake Germany in the No 4 position of top recipients. The US still dominates the field, with 46% of 308,853 US utility patents issued last year, followed by Japan, South Korea, and Germany.

site_title: Bring an end to the Trump-led mess and gridlock in Washington
summary: The US government shutdown, led by President Donald Trump, has left many allies dismayed and created uncertainty in the global economy. Trump's plan to build a $6 billion wall along the US-Mexico border has been met with opposition from Congress, and his decision to declare a "national emergency" has been seen as impulsive. The shutdown has paralyzed government operations and imposed a burden on taxpayers, while also unnerving financial markets. Experts argue that Trump needs to work with Congress to end the gridlock and respect the system of checks and balances established by the Founding Fathers.

site_title: Singapore banks may serve up enough of a lukewarm gruel
summary: Singapore banks may experience a "Goldilocks" year in 2019 due to current market uncertainty, which could lead to lower yield expansion and loan growth but also increase interest in them as a safe harbour. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate target range is expected to remain between 2.25-2.5% in 2019, indicating a likely pause in rate hikes. This could benefit Singapore banks, which may benefit from the uncertainty and stability offered by the Fed's cautious stance.

site_title: Oil tanker fire in Hong Kong waters kills one; rescue on
summary: An oil tanker, the Aulac Fortune, caught fire in Hong Kong's southern waters, killing one crew member and rescuing 21 others. The 17,500 deadweight tonne tanker, built in 2010 and flying the Vietnamese flag, was listing with black smoke pouring from the hull. The fire occurred about one nautical mile south of Lamma Island, with witnesses reporting a loud blast that shook windows several kilometers away. Rescue operations are ongoing, with some crew members still unaccounted for.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: EC World Reit's seven logistics assets in China are expected to remain resilient despite trade tensions due to their focus on domestic consumption. The company's 70% income-backed by master leases from Forchn is also seen as a positive factor. RHB Research Institute initiates a buy recommendation with a target price of S$0.81, citing steady lease ramp-up and above-lease income.

site_title: What the analyst who predicted US market plunge sees in 2019
summary: James Stack, president of InvesTech Research, predicted a US market plunge in 2019, which ultimately occurred. Despite low unemployment and rising wages, Stack remains bearish, expecting the Dow and S&P 500 to decline 20% from their peaks and potentially enter a bear market. He cites a lack of economic warning signs and a shaky housing market as concerns. Economist Jeremy Siegel disagrees, predicting a 5-15% market rise despite an economic slowdown, citing lower stock prices and projected earnings.

site_title: Foldable phones and roll-up TVs are finally here
summary: Folding phones and roll-up TVs have finally arrived after years of development. LG unveiled its ultra-high definition television that rolls into and out of a base stand, while Chinese startup Royole showcased the first foldable smartphone, the FlexPai. Royole also demonstrated the flexibility of its display technology for various commercial and industrial uses. The technology is expected to bring "freedom of design" and new applications, with other device makers expected to introduce foldable handsets this year.

site_title: Hi-P falls 4.66% as Maybank downgrades it to 'sell'
summary: Hi-P International's shares fell 4.66% after Maybank Kim Eng downgraded the stock from "hold" to "sell" due to margin pressures and a decline in consumer sentiment. The brokerage firm cut its target price to S$0.68 from S$0.84.

site_title: Condo resale prices drop 0.8% in Dec
summary: Resale prices of private non-landed homes in Singapore dropped 0.8% in December, following a 0.3% increase in November, according to flash estimates by SRX Property. The decline is attributed to the July 2018 cooling measures, which have "substantially stabilised" price growth. Resale prices are still up 7.5% from last year, but transactions have fallen 50.7% year-on-year, with 479 units resold in December, down 24% from November.

site_title: Liner shipping under attack - yet again
summary: The International Transport Forum (ITF) and OECD are pushing to end vessel-sharing alliances between shipping companies, despite these arrangements making sea transport cheaper. The ITF claims alliances have led to overcapacity, lower service frequencies, and increased delivery uncertainty, harming the transport system. However, the shipping industry disputes this, arguing that alliances promote competition, operational efficiency, and reduced emissions. The ITF's stance is seen as hypocritical, given its support for the EU's ban on liner conferences, which also led to consolidation and instability in the industry.

site_title: Oil prices steady on trade talk hopes and Opec cuts, but slowdown looms
summary: Oil prices remained stable on Tuesday due to hopes of a trade deal between the US and China, as well as Opec-led supply cuts. International Brent crude futures rose 9 cents to $57.42 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures increased 4 cents to $48.56 per barrel. However, analysts warn that a worldwide economic slowdown could dent fuel consumption and hedge fund industry positions in crude futures have been cut back.

site_title: Companies' bill payments worsen for 3rd straight quarter
summary: Companies' bill payments worsened for the third consecutive quarter, according to the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau. The economy is expected to continue worsening due to a slowing economy, with manufacturing and trade-related services hit by the US-China trade spat. Prompt payments dropped 6.57 percentage points, while slow payments rose 1.1 percentage points, and partial payments increased 5.47 percentage points. The manufacturing and wholesale sectors experienced the greatest stress in payment performance.

site_title: US govt shutdown forces economists to turn to other data
summary: The US government shutdown, now in its third week, has forced economists to rely on alternative data to gauge the effects of a trade war and economic growth. The Commerce Department, which tracks key economic indicators, is among the agencies affected by the shutdown, delaying reports on international trade, factory orders, and construction spending. Economists are turning to business surveys, port-traffic data, and private-sector reports to fill the gaps, but analysts warn that the shutdown's impact on growth will increase as it drags on, potentially affecting investment and hiring decisions.

site_title: Kim discusses expected summit with Trump in China talks: report
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un met with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing, discussing an expected US-North Korea summit and strengthening bilateral ties. The talks followed a private train arrival on Monday, coinciding with Kim's 35th birthday. The visit comes amid plans for a second summit with US President Donald Trump aimed at denuclearizing the Korean peninsula. China supports resolving the North Korean crisis, with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo praising Beijing's role in reducing the risk from North Korea's nuclear capability.

site_title: ISR Capital confident of ability to fund commercialisation of mining asset
summary: ISR Capital, a Singapore-based investment firm, is confident in its ability to fund the commercialization of a mining asset in Madagascar. The company's chairman has estimated initial development costs at $10-15 million, with access to $22 million from an existing bond program. Despite waiving conditions regarding a budget and liquidity plan, the board believes the project is unlikely to be delayed or abandoned due to funding concerns, safeguarding shareholders' interests.

site_title: China Taiping Insurance Singapore eyes regional growth, wealth management
summary: China Taiping Insurance Singapore has launched its life insurance business in Singapore, citing the significant market for savings, retirement, and protection products fueled by increasing wealth in the Asia-Pacific. The firm, owned by China's fourth-largest life insurer, has a paid-up capital of about S$120 million and plans to expand its life team to 50 in 12 months. The company aims to tap into Singapore's growing wealth of 110,000 millionaires, with a total wealth estimated to be US$11.8 trillion.

site_title: Euro slips on slowdown fears while dollar advances
summary: The euro declined 0.2% to $1.1463, weighed down by a third consecutive drop in German industrial output, sparking concerns about a slowdown in the eurozone economy. The eurozone's European Central Bank is expected to maintain interest rates through the summer of 2019, with some strategists predicting no policy tightening until 2020. The dollar rose 0.1% to 95.734, supported by growing expectations that the Federal Reserve will pause its rate hike cycle, and traders' concerns about the dollar's downward pressure.

site_title: Toymaker sues Louis Vuitton for right to keep making Pooey purses
summary: MGA Entertainment, the toymaker behind the popular "Poopsie Surprise" products, has sued Louis Vuitton for the right to continue producing its "Pooey Pooey Puitton" purse, a toy that resembles the luxury brand's handbags but is meant to be a parody of the rich and famous. The toy's design and name are similar to Louis Vuitton's, but MGA argues it is not a knockoff and is intended to comment on the brand's luxury lifestyle. The lawsuit claims Louis Vuitton has a history of not respecting parody rights and will likely lose the case.

site_title: Coastal Oil troubles hit Singapore banks, others with US$350m exposure
summary: Coastal Oil Singapore, a crude oil products supplier, has filed for liquidation, affecting 10 banks, including Singapore's three major banks, with a total debt of US$354 million. The company owes US$122.7 million to OCBC HK, US$29.9 million to DBS HK, and US$19.5 million to UOB HK. Cosco Shipping International, a related company, claims that "false" debt claims have been made, with its subsidiary Sinfeng Marine Services owing US$357 million to 79 companies. The board of Cosco Shipping International expects revenue to decrease significantly unless alternative suppliers are found.

site_title: Nasdaq-listed Equinix to invest US$85.3m to build fourth data centre in Singapore
summary: Equinix, a Nasdaq-listed interconnection and data centre company, plans to build a fourth data centre in Singapore, SG4, at an initial cost of US$85.3 million. The seven-storey facility will provide over 132,180 sq ft of co-location space and enable customers to interconnect with approximately 600 companies from various industries. The data centre will be directly connected to Equinix's existing facilities and offer software-defined interconnection to over 1,300 businesses, including major cloud-service providers.

site_title: Plunge in Germany's industrial activity sparks recession talk
summary: Germany's industrial activity plunged in November, posting its worst year-on-year drop since the financial crisis, sparking recession talk. Production fell for the third consecutive month, with weakness in consumer goods and energy. The euro slipped 0.3% as investors and economists fret about slower global momentum. Despite some economists predicting a potential stabilization, Germany's central bank remains cautious, citing temporary challenges. The situation may take longer to improve, potentially leading to a quarter of shrinking output.

site_title: Prophet of real estate gloom warns of US property slide
summary: James Stack, a renowned real estate expert, warns of a potential US property slide in 2019, citing a downward trend in home sales and a significant downside risk to housing prices if a recession takes hold. This prediction comes after he accurately forecasted the 2008 real estate crash and the 2018 housing slowdown. Home purchase contracts fell 7.7% in November, and consumer confidence dropped in December, with a gauge of US manufacturing plummeting by the most since 2008.

site_title: Cloudy, with a chance of tech stock dips
summary: US-China trade tensions continue to weigh on global markets, with regional stocks trading lower on Tuesday. Despite this, Singapore's local bourse bucked the trend, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.65% to 3,122.94. Technology stocks, however, fell, with analysts warning of potential profit warnings from tech companies in Q4 earnings season. Analysts cite heightened macro uncertainty and costs associated with the trade war, with companies like Venture Corp and Valuetronics emerging as potential resilient performers.

site_title: Golden Mile Complex to be potentially conserved, used for integrated development
summary: The Golden Mile Complex in Singapore may be developed as an integrated development with a gross floor area of 85,977.5 sq m if sold en bloc. The project must conserve the existing 16-storey building. The proposed development will include retail, office, residential, serviced apartments, and hotels. The property has a land area of 1.3 hectares and is zoned for commercial use under the URA's Master Plan 2014. The tender exercise for the sale will close on January 30, 2019.

site_title: FSL Trust files claim against charterer in UK courts
summary: FIRST Ship Lease (FSL) Trust has filed a claim of US$1,892,789 against charterer Torm in UK courts for breaches of redelivery obligations. The claimant claims Torm redelivered the vessel late and in a deficient condition, causing damage and loss. The dispute dates back to 2018 when Torm failed to deliver two product tankers in poor condition, leading FSL Trust to pursue litigation. A hearing is scheduled for February 7, and the trust has arrested Torm-owned tanker Torm Amazon in Taiwan for security purposes.

site_title: Slowing growth and its consequences
summary: The global economy faces slowing growth, debt, and uncertainties, with many risks both known and unknown. The US economy finished 2018 with low unemployment and inflation, but investors are nervous about variables. The International Monetary Fund forecasts a 3.7% global growth rate, but this is fragile and dependent on a lack of major shocks. The trade war between the US and China is expected to slow growth, while emerging markets are stressed due to high debt and weak demand for raw materials. The EU faces uncertainty due to Brexit, Italy's debt, and political instability, which could lead to a debt implosion and economic contraction.

site_title: Workers on boards? Germany has had them for decades
summary: Germany has a long-standing system of "co-determination" where workers elect up to half of the members of supervisory boards, making high-level strategic decisions. This practice has been adopted in the US, with proposals to give workers the right to vote for two-fifths of all corporate board seats. The idea aims to give workers more power and voice in the workplace, potentially leading to better pay, benefits, and job security. Germany's example shows mixed results, but co-determination has helped workers minimize job losses and secure wages in the past.

site_title: Singapore calls on Asean countries to tap new trade route to access western China
summary: Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing has urged Asean countries to consider using a new land and sea trade corridor linking western China to South-east Asia, which he claims is faster and cost-effective than the existing route. The new trade route, part of the Chongqing Connectivity Initiative, aims to spur economic growth and improve connectivity between China's western region and the world. Eight Chinese provinces have officially joined the network, and Chan believes the open and inclusive platform will bring benefits to both Singapore and China.

site_title: Heathrow plans to add 25,000 flights before new runway opens
summary: Heathrow airport plans to add 25,000 flights per year before its new runway opens in 2026, boosting capacity by 5% and allowing jets to use existing runways for both landing and take-offs in the same direction. The project may cause disruption to local residents years before the new runway is built. The third runway is expected to lift annual capacity by 75% to 135 million travellers, but may also overfly areas not affected by current Heathrow arrivals.

site_title: Search for new World Bank head to test Trump's 'America First' mantra
summary: US President Donald Trump's choice of candidate for the new World Bank head will be a test of his "America First" mantra. The current president, Jim Yong Kim, abruptly resigned, sparking an international tussle over who replaces him. The World Bank's purpose may be questioned by the Trump administration, potentially leading to controversy. Trump's nominee could face backlash if they share his disdain for international bodies.

site_title: Amazon, worth US$796.8b, is world's most valuable company
summary: Amazon surpassed Microsoft as the world's most valuable company, with a market capitalization of $796.8 billion, surpassing its peak in September. The e-commerce giant's remarkable growth has expanded its business beyond online book sales, reaching $232.3 billion in projected revenues for 2018. Founded in 1995, Amazon has continued to invest heavily in warehouses, distribution networks, and data centers, making notable acquisitions like Whole Foods Market and emerging as a major creator of original entertainment content.

site_title: Widodo administration's authoritarian measures continue to weaken Indonesian democracy
summary: Indonesian President Jokowi's administration continues to implement authoritarian measures, weakening the country's democracy. Experts, including Madeleine Albright and Eric Posner, warn that leaders can accumulate power incrementally, often without resistance, and use it to further suppress democratic institutions. US President Donald Trump has also expressed concerns about the potential for authoritarianism, stating that a crisis is not necessary for a leader to slide into authoritarianism. These trends have raised concerns about the erosion of democratic values in Indonesia and other countries.

site_title: Singtel Dash partners UNCDF for remittance to Myanmar
summary: Singtel has partnered with the United Nations Capital Development Fund (UNCDF) to launch a remittance service for Myanmar nationals in Singapore. The three-year partnership aims to provide safe and affordable remittance for the over 180,000 Myanmar expats in Singapore, using Singtel's e-wallet Dash.

site_title: 12,000-year-old Turkish town is about to be engulfed
summary: A 12,000-year-old Turkish town, Hasankeyf, is on the verge of disappearing due to an artificial lake created by the Ilisu hydroelectric dam project. The town, inhabited by 3,000 people, will be flooded in the coming months, despite efforts to relocate its monuments and cultural heritage. The Turkish government argues that measures have been taken to save the site, but residents are divided, with some welcoming the economic benefits promised by the government while others oppose the destruction of their town and heritage.

site_title: British MPs to hold key Brexit vote on Jan 15: official
summary: British MPs will hold a key Brexit vote on January 15 on the agreement negotiated by Prime Minister Theresa May with the European Union. The House of Commons will resume debate on the deal, which was halted in December, after May secured assurances from the EU on Northern Ireland issues. The vote is contingent on MPs approving the agreement, which has faced widespread opposition.

site_title: Recession likely in next 2 years
