summary: Luckin, a Chinese coffee startup, aims to overtake Starbucks as the largest coffee chain in China by opening 2,500 new stores this year, targeting a total of 4,500 stores by the end of 2019. The company's expansion is driven by technology, delivery, and heavy discounting, despite mounting losses of 800 million yuan (S$159 million) last year. Luckin's aggressive growth strategy has raised concerns, but the company remains focused on scale and speed, with a valuation of US$2.2 billion after raising US$200 million in a funding round last month.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business: Getting MNCs and startups together
summary: In a recent Money FM podcast, "Mind Your Business: Getting MNCs and startups together," Unilever's Director of Unilever Foundry for SEA & Australia, Barbara Guerpillon, discussed how corporations and startups can synergistically work together. Guerpillon emphasized the importance of partnerships to unlock deep tech innovation and navigate the future of work. By collaborating with startups, large established corporations can tap into new ideas and technologies, ultimately driving growth and innovation. Guerpillon's insights aim to benefit business leaders in the startup world and established corporations alike.

site_title: Clothing retailer Next trims profit forecast following lacklustre Christmas sales
summary: Next, a UK clothing retailer, trimmed its profit forecast to £723 million due to a lacklustre Christmas sales period. Despite a 1% gain in Christmas sales, the extended reporting period until after the holiday muddied the comparison with last year's performance. This decision is a warning sign for retailers struggling with customer shifts to the internet.

site_title: Grim news in US prompts worry: are good times over?
summary: The US economy experienced a string of negative economic indicators, including a drop in Chinese demand for iPhones, a decline in manufacturing, and reduced sales forecasts from major companies such as Apple and auto giants General Motors and Ford. The Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeted over 600 points, and the tech-heavy Nasdaq entered bear market territory. Despite this, economists suggest that the impact on growth in advanced economies has been minimal, with the US economy still experiencing expansion. The New York Federal Reserve Bank has estimated a 16% chance of a recession within the next year, but economists caution against panic.

site_title: Star Appeal
summary: Celebrity chef Guillaume Bracaval of the two Michelin-starred Michel Troisgros in France will visit Resorts World Sentosa's Art at Curate Dining Series from Jan 18-24, bringing a classic French sensibility to Japanese ingredients. Highlights include signature dishes such as Jerusalem Artichoke and Beef Entrecôte. Priced at S$138 for lunch and S$308 for dinner, reservations can be made by calling 6577 7288 or emailing curate@rwsentosa.com.

site_title: Taste Of Lebanon
summary: Julian Youssef, head bartender at Central Station in Beirut, will be guest bartender at Tippling Club's BIN 38 on Jan 30, as part of their Once Upon A Time series. Youssef will create five cocktails using Grey Goose vodka and offer Lebanese dishes. The event starts at 7pm and costs S$155 for five drinks and five dishes. This is part of Tippling Club's 27th best bar in the world, according to The World's 50 Best Bars 2018.

site_title: Fast, no-knead focaccia is a peek into the world of bread-baking
summary: A food enthusiast revisits a classic cookbook, "Artisan Bread in Five Minutes a Day" by Zoe Francois and Jeff Hertzberg, after letting it collect dust. The author was initially enthusiastic about the book's fast, no-knead focaccia recipe, but eventually lost interest. The article serves as a reminder to explore new recipes and cookbooks, as they can often lead to renewed passion for cooking.

site_title: Chances of US-China trade deal rising: ex-official
summary: A former Chinese trade official, Wei Jianguo, expressed optimism about a US-China trade deal, citing both sides' clearer goals and intentions. China won't negotiate on core interests, including sovereign integrity and national security, while the US seeks to maintain its global leadership role. The two countries' trade officials will meet in Beijing next week for the first face-to-face negotiations since a 90-day truce was agreed upon last month. Wei expects a deal with specific agreements, but notes China's determination to protect its core interests.

site_title: UBS chairman calls for European banks to rival US counterparts
summary: UBS chairman Axel Weber called for European banks to rival US counterparts by becoming larger and more pan-European. He stated that European champions are needed to compete with American firms, which will increasingly take a stake in Europe and Asia due to client demand for global banking. Weber, who isn't considering a merger for UBS at this time, wants the bank to grow organically before merging with a rival. He also signaled that he could stay on as chairman until 2022 if supported by shareholders.

site_title: Sugar tax, green perks, friendlier tax regime for startups: Deloitte
summary: Deloitte Singapore has released Budget 2019 recommendations, including a sugar tax, incentives for green investment, and a tax regime that favors startups. The budget is expected to maintain steady economic growth and avoid major mid-course corrections. Deloitte expects a "steady as she goes" approach, with no major changes amid continued implementation of strategies set in 2017. The recommendations aim to aid startups and small and medium enterprises, with a focus on promoting economic growth and sustainability.

site_title: Enter Sandman
summary: Adam Sandler's Netflix-exclusive film "100% Fresh" has been viewed over half a billion hours by subscribers, earning an 88% rating on Rotten Tomatoes. Despite critics panning his work, Sandler's earnest charm and offbeat humor make his films worth watching. The special also pays tribute to late comedian Chris Farley, with featured singles "Farley" and "Phone-Wallet-Keys" available on Spotify and YouTube.

site_title: Stock market turmoil, volatile currency lead to fall in oil prices
summary: Oil prices fell due to volatile currency and stock markets, with US West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures dropping 75 cents to $45.79 a barrel and International Brent crude futures down 50 cents to $54.41 a barrel. Supply surged despite expected demand slowdown, with top exporter Saudi Arabia expected to cut February prices by up to 50 cents a barrel. Economic concerns, including a slowdown in China and US tech giant Apple's sales forecast, contributed to market jitters.

site_title: Hollywood buying up hit podcasts in the race for content
summary: The entertainment industry is aggressively buying up ready-made programming, including podcasts, to fill their expanding slates. Executives at Netflix, Amazon, and Apple are spending wildly for content, with companies like Gimlet Media and Wondery seeing their shows adapted into scripted series. Podcasts have become more elaborate, with complex stories and cliffhangers, making them attractive to Hollywood. Companies like Amazon's Lore and Bravo's Dirty John have made the transition, and others are in development, including Welcome to Night Vale and The Bright Sessions.

site_title: Scrapping the retirement age
summary: Singapore-based insurer Prudential has scrapped the retirement age for its employees, easing anxieties of senior workers and paving the way for other companies to follow suit. With 1 in 4 of Singapore's labour force being 55 and older, the move highlights the need for striking a balance between supporting workers and promoting business interests. Technology, social media, and human rights are changing the employment landscape, requiring managers to upgrade their skills to handle the new challenges.

site_title: US government shutdown could last a 'long time', warns Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump warned that a partial government shutdown could last a "long time" after meeting with top Democratic lawmakers, who failed to reach an agreement to end the standoff over border wall funding. Trump insisted on $5.6 billion for the wall, despite Democrats' refusal to compromise, and showed no signs of backing down. The shutdown, which has furloughed hundreds of thousands of federal employees, could continue indefinitely until a deal is reached.

site_title: The blue economy and seasteading: A key growth driver for Singapore
summary: Singapore is poised to capitalize on the blue economy and seasteading, with the potential to become a prime mover in the development of floating cities. The city-state has the necessary infrastructure, expertise, and experience to build, launch, and maintain very large floating structures (VLFSs). With an estimated 700 sq km of territorial waters, Singapore can tap this space using VLFS technology. The city-state's maritime and offshore engineering cluster, as well as its capital markets, can support the development of floating charter cities, which could generate profits through city-backed corporates and tax revenue.

site_title: Brent prices likely to rise, but not enough to hasten O&M recovery
summary: Oil prices are expected to rise to between $65 and $80 a barrel this year, driven by Opec's production cuts, but the recovery of the Singapore offshore and marine (O&M) sector is unlikely to be swift. Non-Opec producers, such as the US, are unlikely to trim output, which may cap the upward trajectory on oil prices. Analysts predict that the O&M sector will remain weak, with improved day rates and activity levels, but debt burdens and interest expenses will continue to challenge profitability.

site_title: A bite of Apple's poison and markets sell in a flash
summary: Apple's first revenue caution in almost 12 years, citing slowing Chinese demand, sparked a flash crash in currency markets and dragged the Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore down 0.9% to close at 3,012.88. Other Asian markets also declined, with South Korea's Kospi hitting a two-month low. However, Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.4% on the back of a cheaper Aussie dollar. Global sentiment remains cautious, with investors concerned about the slowdown in consumer spending in China and potential impact of US President Trump's trade war.

site_title: Tesla cuts US prices on all vehicles, shares drop
summary: Tesla Inc cut US prices on all vehicles by $2,000 to offset lower green tax credits, but shares fell 7% due to concerns over future profitability. The move may signal lower US demand, and analysts question whether it will undermine profitability. The company fell short on quarterly deliveries of its mass-market Model 3 sedan. This price cut comes as Tesla has never posted an annual profit.

images.alt_text: Tesla has fallen short on quarterly deliveries of its mass-market Model 3 sedan on display (above) at Automobility LA in Los Angeles, California, in November 2018.

site_title: Green Luxury In Langkawi
summary: The 25-year-old Datai luxury resort in Langkawi, Malaysia, has undergone a $60 million transformation after 12 months. The resort, which opened in 1993, has reclaimed its original magic, offering stunning views of Datai Bay and ancient rainforest. Langkawi's fortunes changed in the 1980s with the declaration of a duty-free zone and the birth of a descendant of Mahsuri, a noblewoman wrongfully executed for adultery in the 18th century. The resort's transformation marks a new chapter in the island's history as a top resort destination.

site_title: Back To Basics
summary: Michel and Sébastien Bras, a father-son duo of acclaimed chefs, have returned to their roots by leaving the Michelin Guide behind. After two decades of adhering to the guide's constraints, they opted to break free and focus on what makes them happy. The Bras, known for their farm-to-table approach, have found success at The Datai Langkawi, where they showcased their locally sourced ingredients and cooking ethos. The decision has allowed them to be more spontaneous and creative, while maintaining a loyal customer base.

site_title: Make new friends wining & dining
summary: Two Singaporean eateries, Komyuniti and The Wine Gourmet & Friends, cater to individuals seeking convivial dining experiences. Komyuniti, a half-cafe and co-working space, offers reasonably priced meals in a quiet environment, ideal for introverts. The menu features simple yet thoughtful dishes, such as charred Brussels sprouts and buttermilk fried chicken. The Wine Gourmet & Friends, a wine bar with a Singaporean twist, serves locally inspired cooking and offers a welcoming atmosphere, making it a place to meet new people.

site_title: Dairy Farm hikes price to S$1.84b in push for 80% owner sign-up
summary: Dairy Farm estate in Singapore has raised its reserve price from S$1.688 billion to S$1.84 billion ahead of an April 2019 deadline to secure an 80% owner sign-up. The move aims to persuade owners to join the collective sale, which will then be put to tender. This comes as the market cools, with only two signatures added in the last two months, leaving 68% of owners to sign up. Other estates, such as Pine Grove and Mandarin Gardens, have also increased their reserve prices to attract buyers.

images.alt_text: Dairy Farm's reserve price just went up from S$1.688b to S$1.84b as the sale committee tries to get more owners to come on board. Its current signature count is 68 per cent.

site_title: What to read while you wait for the Downton Abbey movie
summary: The Downton Abbey movie trailer has arrived, but the film won't be released until autumn. To prepare for the movie, readers can choose from a variety of books, including "The Husband Hunters" for history buffs, "House of Gold" for fiction fans, "The Country House" for stately home lovers, "The Mitford Murders" for mystery enthusiasts, and "Oxford Film Locations" for travel enthusiasts. There's also a book for cat lovers and zombie zealots, titled "The Downton Tabby" and "Zombie Abbey" respectively, although the latter won't be released until September.

site_title: Home Away From Home
summary: Singapore hoteliers are expanding their brand of hospitality overseas, with several brands opening new properties in Australia, New Zealand, and Asia. Naumi Hotels, a Singapore-based private hotel owner and operator, opened its first overseas hotel in Auckland, New Zealand in 2018, featuring Singaporean cuisine on its menu. Banyan Tree, another Singaporean brand, has signed 26 new hotel agreements for its four brands, with properties set to open in several countries including Australia, Fiji, and China. Serviced residences like Ascott Limited are also expanding globally, with over 600 properties in 32 countries. Singaporean brands are well-received overseas, with many citing the country's reputation for trustworthiness, transparency, and innovation as key factors in their success.

site_title: Lenders are thriving on bitcoin's bust by aiding both fanatics and shorts
summary: Lenders in the cryptocurrency industry are thriving during the current bitcoin bust, with many reporting significant growth in demand for their services. Companies such as BlockFi, Aave, and Salt Lending have seen their revenues and customer bases increase, with some planning to expand their product offerings. The shift in lending focus from buying and holding cryptocurrencies to short selling has created strong demand from big investors, while borrowers who don't want to sell at depressed prices are also seeking loans. This trend is expected to continue, with lenders positioning themselves for growth in the coming year.

site_title: China's population shrinks despite two-child policy: experts
summary: China's population declined by 1.27 million in 2018, marking the first time since 1949, according to researcher Yi Fuxian. The decline, attributed to factors such as a decrease in the number of women of childbearing age and rising education costs, has raised concerns about a "demographic crisis" that may worsen the country's ageing problem and economic vitality. The decline in births, despite the relaxation of the two-child policy, has led experts to warn of a severe demographic crisis, potentially more severe than Japan's, if the government does not intervene.

site_title: China Southern shares up after Qatar Airways buys 5% stake
summary: China Southern Airlines Co. shares rose 4% in Shanghai and 1.9% in Hong Kong after Qatar Airways purchased a 5% stake in the mainland carrier. This investment makes Qatar Airways the fourth-largest shareholder of China Southern and aligns with its strategy of global deals. The move is part of China Southern's efforts to bolster its network in China and form closer ties with Oneworld alliance members. Qatar Airways may seek to increase its stake further in the next 12 months.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng launches two new pre-school centres
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation has launched two new pre-school centres in Singapore, including one Repton-brand centre and a new pre-school and childcare centre by its subsidiary White Lodge Education Group Services. The company aims to diversify and grow its education business, with plans to expand in the Asia Pacific region. With a total investment of around S$20 million in the education segment, Chip Eng Seng expects significant growth in the early years.

site_title: Home For Life
summary: A pair of brothers, both in their 40s, have transformed a childhood house into a lifelong home by combining two separate houses on the same property. The design, created by architect Foo Yong Kai, features expansive glass doors and private gardens, blending the indoor and outdoor spaces. The brothers, who work in medical IT and piloting, have always lived together and wanted to maintain their family bond. The 4,000 sq ft home is designed with sustainability in mind, using natural ventilation and energy-efficient features to reduce consumption. The brothers' father had a vision for the new home and had input in its design, which was largely left to the brothers to execute.

site_title: A Gentleman's Guide
summary: GQ magazine has published a handbook titled "GQ: How To Win At Life" offering advice on various life skills, including etiquette, travel, and self-improvement. The book features step-by-step guides and illustrated tips from experts and celebrities such as Richard Branson, Jamie Oliver, and Tom Daley. It covers topics like giving a great foot massage, folding a suit, and cooking a perfect steak. The handbook is available in bookstores.

site_title: Slash And Burn
summary: Slash, the guitarist of Guns N' Roses, is set to perform a one-night-only show in Singapore on January 8 with Myles Kennedy and the Conspirators. The band is part of the Living the Dream world tour, which includes stops at major music festivals in Europe. The concert will feature a mix of new and old riffs, including some Guns N' Roses covers. Tickets are available from S$148.

site_title: Ryanair passenger traffic grew 8% in 2018, slowest since 2015
summary: Ryanair reported an 8% increase in passenger traffic in 2018, the slowest since 2015, due to labour issues, bad weather, and strikes. The airline sold 139.2 million tickets, a smaller rise than the 10% increase in 2017 and 17% in 2016. Smaller rival Wizz Air reported a 20% passenger jump for 2018. Ryanair cut its profit guidance by 12% in October due to labour strife and fuel costs, and the company's unions are unlikely to reach an agreement. Strikes and labour issues continue to affect the airline's operations.

images.alt_text: RYANAIR Holdings Plc posted another year of slower passenger growth as the discounter's battle with unions, bad weather and industry wide air-traffic control strikes took their toll.

site_title: Blockchain technology giving smaller countries the chance to leapfrog bigger rivals
summary: Smaller countries, such as Singapore, Gibraltar, and Malta, are emerging as leading blockchain hubs, leveraging the technology to attract business and investment. These jurisdictions have successfully demonstrated their "crypto-friendliness" by promoting innovation, adopting dynamic regulation, and providing a stable environment for blockchain companies. As the technology matures, smaller countries are likely to reap the benefits of increased investment, while larger economies may struggle to adapt, giving them a competitive advantage.

site_title: China to improve funding conditions amid tight liquidity
summary: China plans to cut the reserve requirement ratio and inject significant funds to address liquidity issues ahead of the Spring Festival holidays. The move is expected to amount to nearly 4.3 trillion yuan, with cash withdrawals, corporate tax payments, and lender maturities draining liquidity. Authorities will reduce the reserve requirement ratio and provide funding for lenders to private companies, aiming to alleviate the liquidity hole. This is the latest easing measure, following four previous RRR cuts last year, as the nation grapples with slower economic growth and a trade war.

site_title: HDB resale transactions down 24% in December 2018
summary: HDB resale transactions declined 24% in December 2018 compared to November, with a 9.6% drop in absolute numbers. Prices also fell 0.3% in December, marking a 14.3% decrease from their peak in April 2013. The decline is attributed to the effects of recent cooling measures and concerns about ageing flat values. Certain segments, such as four- and five-room flats, saw a relatively larger premium, while prices in non-mature estates increased by 0.2%, whereas those in mature estates dropped by 1%.

site_title: Apple's China trouble makes Trump's trade war harder to defend
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade war with China is facing increased scrutiny as tensions between the two economies backfire, undercutting his assurances of America's growth. Apple's China slowdown, which lowered its first-quarter revenue outlook, is a significant blow to the US, with the company's shares dropping in extended trading. China's manufacturing sector is showing signs of a sharper slowdown than expected, while retail sales posted the worst performance since 2003. The timing of Apple's announcement could chip away at the US's political leverage ahead of trade talks resuming, putting pressure on the US and China to reach a deal sooner than expected.

site_title: Apple's cut in revenue outlook triggers slump for suppliers
summary: Apple has cut its revenue outlook for the first time in almost two decades, citing weaker demand in China, which led to a slump in Asian suppliers and lower price targets on Wall Street. The company's CEO, Tim Cook, attributed the slowdown to economic deceleration in Greater China and rising trade tensions with the US. Apple's shares fell 7.8% in pre-market trading, and suppliers such as SK Hynix and Samsung Electronics also plummeted. The company's services segment, however, grew 27% year-over-year, and other product categories, including the iPad, also saw growth.

images.alt_text: Customers browse inside an Apple store in Hong Kong on Jan 3. Apple is reporting a holiday quarter slowdown for the first time since Tim Cook became CEO in 2011.

site_title: Oil: Higher prices perhaps, speed bumps ahead
summary: Oil prices may rise due to potential US tariffs on Canada and other countries. Despite this, oil prices fell amid a bearish Trump tariff outlook. Gold prices rose after Trump announced new tariffs on Canada. Meanwhile, China's solar stocks surged as Beijing calmed price wars. OPEC trimmed oil demand forecasts for the next four years, and Chinese tycoons are investing in Indonesia to become the country's largest aluminium producer.

site_title: Clear Vision
summary: L'OCCITANE, a cosmetics brand, partners with Sight to Sky, a Singaporean NGO, to provide high-impact eye care to communities in need. Since 2000, the brand has been fundraising for eye care in South Africa, Burkina Faso, and China. In 2019, L'OCCITANE aims to treat 5,000 more patients in the Himalayan belt and Ladakh, a remote region with a third of the population believed to have eye problems. A limited-edition #RaceForVision SG Race Pack is available, with all sales proceeds supporting Sight to Sky's vision mission.

site_title: Manhattan median home price falls to below US$1m
summary: Manhattan's median home price has dropped to below $1 million for the first time in three years, falling 5.8% from the same period last year to $999,000. The decline is attributed to ample inventory allowing buyers to negotiate better deals. This marks a significant change in the market, with condo and co-op prices also decreasing. The decrease in prices is a result of the competitive market conditions.

site_title: Singapore Reits start the year well, 'likely to continue to shine'
summary: Singapore Reits started the year on a strong note, with the Reits sub-index rising 1% since the start of the trading year. Despite a decline in the Straits Times Index, the Reits sector has outperformed, with a 1.9% year-on-year growth in distribution per unit (DPU). DBS Group Research attributes this to a more dovish Federal Reserve, which will lead to fewer interest rate hikes and set the stage for Reits to continue performing well. The sector's conservative hedging of debt and acquisitions made last year are also expected to contribute positively to growth.

site_title: Hidden Figures
summary: A photo exhibition is taking place across bus shelters in Singapore, showcasing images of migrant workers posing in front of construction sites. The images, commissioned by the M1 Fringe Festival 2019, aim to draw attention to their contributions to the country. Photographer Sean Cham has been documenting the community since 2015, highlighting the true ambitions and aspirations of various workers. The exhibition runs until the end of January, aiming to remind the public of the people behind the construction of homes, offices, and roads.

site_title: New digital exchange heralds age of tokenising securities
summary: A new digital exchange, DX.Exchange, is set to launch next week, allowing investors to trade digital tokens representing shares of US companies like Apple, Facebook, and Tesla outside of the US market. The exchange, backed by Ethereum, will offer digital stocks that can be traded even when traditional markets are closed and can be bought in fractions. DX will expand to the NYSE and other international markets, with plans to offer digital securities for other companies. The move is seen as a test of investor appetite for blockchain-based financial products.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge acquires India land parcel to develop IT park
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge Group has acquired a 4.9-hectare land parcel in Chennai, India, to develop an IT park called International Tech Park Chennai (ITPC) - Radial Road. The 2.3 million square foot site has a development potential of 1.10 million square feet of Grade A business space. Located in an upcoming IT corridor region, the park will be connected to two major IT corridors and is accessible by several main roads. This acquisition strengthens Ascendas-Singbridge's presence in Chennai and demonstrates its commitment to the city and state of Tamil Nadu.

site_title: Sea Games
summary: The New Year Sea Sports event, which involved boat races and a non-boat-related activity, was a popular celebration in Singapore from the 1950s to the 1960s. The event, which featured traditional boats such as the "koleh" and "tub boat", was highly regarded and attracted notable guests, including Singapore's first president and the first Maharaja of Johor. The event eventually died away in the 1960s, but its legacy remains as a nostalgic reminder of Singapore's cultural heritage.

site_title: Art Makes A Statement In Kochi
summary: India's Kochi-Muziris Biennale, a visual arts event, has opened with a bold and locally-focused lineup of 94 artists, tackling issues like #MeToo, environmentalism, and LGBTQ rights. The event, which runs till March 29, features works by prominent international artists, including China's Song Dong and Iran's Shirin Neshat, alongside Indian artists such as Jitish Kallat and Shilpa Gupta. The biennale aims to create a sense of community and connection among individuals, with some installations sparking controversy and conversation in public spaces.

site_title: Kaisa's US$150m shanty town development at risk
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings' US$150 million investment in a shanty town redevelopment project in Xi'an, China is at risk after a local builder, Xi'an Xingzhengyuan, removed Kaisa's legal title to the project. Tensions between the two companies escalated last week, resulting in damage to the construction site and a medical treatment for a Kaisa executive. Kaisa is now seeking to pursue Xingzhengyuan in China's highest court to win back its rights to the site, which could cost the company its entire investment.

site_title: GM US new vehicle sales fall 2.75% in Q4
summary: General Motors reported a 2.7% decline in US new vehicle sales in Q4, with declines across most brands, including Chevrolet, Cadillac, and Buick. Passenger car sales fell significantly, while larger SUVs like the Suburban, Escalade, and Yukon saw declines. Despite this, GM remains bullish on pickups and expects the US economy to support sales. Industry-wide US new vehicle sales are expected to hit 17.3 million units for 2018, a slight increase from 2017.

site_title: Fashion Statement
summary: In Sweden, fashion brands like HOPE, Residus, and mini rodini are prioritizing social and environmental responsibility. HOPE, founded in 2001, creates androgynous, sustainable clothing, while Residus uses discarded fabric to produce limited-edition dresses. mini rodini emphasizes sustainable materials and fair labor practices. These brands reflect Sweden's conscious consumption culture, aiming to make a positive impact on the environment and promote social awareness. By choosing these brands, consumers can support a more sustainable and inclusive fashion industry.

site_title: Hyflux gets more time to report financials, conduct AGM
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water treatment company, has received a 4.5-month extension to report its financials and conduct its annual general meeting for fiscal 2018. The company now has until June 30, 2019, or before lifting its trading suspension to announce its second and third-quarter results and full-year 2018 results. This extension is linked to its debt moratorium, which provides time for the company to reorganize its liabilities and businesses. Hyflux also announced a three-month extension to report its first-quarter 2019 results.

site_title: A crucial election year for India, Indonesia
summary: India and Indonesia, two of the world's largest democracies, are set to hold crucial elections in 2019 that will determine the fate of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and President Joko Widodo. The elections come at a time of global uncertainty, with the rise of illiberal democracy and the attack on globalization. Despite facing significant challenges, both leaders have demonstrated a stubborn attachment to democracy, which is seen as an outlier in a world increasingly embracing authoritarianism. The outcome of the elections will be closely watched globally, with many expecting a significant challenge to the leaders' re-election bids.

site_title: Alfonso Cuaron
summary: Mexican director Alfonso Cuaron's film Roma, released on Netflix in December 2018, received widespread acclaim for its semi-autobiographical story about his family's life in 1970s Mexico City. Shot in black-and-white and featuring long takes, the film explores everyday life and the struggles of a working-class family. Cuaron retained artistic control by making the film independently, which allowed him to compress his family's story into 10 months instead of 2.5 years. Roma won the top prize at the Venice International Film Festival and received three Golden Globe nominations, including Best Director.

site_title: Apple-induced 'flash crash' jolts currency markets
summary: A sudden spike in volatility hit currency markets on Thursday, triggered by Apple's cut in quarterly sales forecast, citing slowing iPhone sales in China. The US dollar and Japanese yen surged, with the yen gaining 8% on the Australian dollar and 10% on the Turkish lira. Most Asian currencies weakened against the greenback and yen, considered safe havens. Gold prices also rose, reaching a six-month high, as investors sought safe havens amid risk-off attitudes. Analysts expect markets to continue facing decelerating growth from economies, potentially leading to further currency depreciation.

site_title: Tourists flee Thai islands as storm closes in
summary: Thailand cancelled flights to the island of Khao Lak, evacuated offshore oil rigs, and battened down beachside resorts due to Tropical Storm Pabuk, its first in nearly 30 years. The storm approached southern Thailand with winds of up to 65 kph, bringing high waves and gusty winds. The storm is expected to make landfall on Friday, posing a threat to the island's tourist infrastructure. Authorities took precautions to protect tourists and prevent damage to the island's economy.

site_title: Rexhep Rexhepi
summary: Kosovo-born watchmaker Rexhep Rexhepi, 31, has gained recognition in the luxury mechanical watch industry for producing complicated timepieces. Since starting his brand AkriviA in 2012, Rexhepi has created five ultra-complications, including a tourbillon and mono-pusher chronograph, focusing on the tourbillon. He credits his experiences at Patek Philippe and BNB Concept, where he learned perfection, craftsmanship, and discipline, for his success. Rexhepi's latest achievement is winning the Grand Prix d'Horlogerie de Geneve's Best Men's Watch prize for his Chronometre Contemporain model, which has sold out its 25-piece limited edition.

site_title: Saudi prosecutor will seek death penalties in Khashoggi case
summary: Saudi Arabian prosecutors will seek the death penalty for five suspects in the Jamal Khashoggi murder case, as a Saudi court held its first hearing on the case. The move comes amid ongoing diplomatic tensions with Turkey, where Khashoggi's remains are believed to be hidden. The Saudi government has rejected accusations that Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman ordered Khashoggi's murder, and is seeking information from Turkish officials to support its case. The death penalty for five suspects marks a significant escalation in the investigation.

site_title: All fun, no fear for Sim Leisure Group
summary: Sim Leisure Group (SLG) plans to list on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board this year, with IPO proceeds used for its first theme park in China and Penang parks. The company's Escape theme parks in Penang focus on traditional learning and playing activities, offering climbing structures, jumping, sliding, and exploring dark tunnels. SLG's founder hopes his stock will soar, despite not featuring rollercoasters or expensive brand attractions.

site_title: With central banks' normalisation at risk, governments need to step up
summary: The US Federal Reserve's softer stance on monetary policy amid market downturns raises concerns about the central bank's ability to revive the economy. Governments in the US, Europe, and Japan need to step up with fiscal and structural support to avert economic stagnation. The Fed's balance sheet remains bloated, and its interest rate target is still near the zero lower bound, limiting its ability to respond to future crises. Governments must increase fiscal spending to offset the impact of central banks becoming more hawkish, and wise governance can provide short-term relief while investing in the long term.

site_title: Netflix to Bird Box Fans: please open your eyes
summary: Netflix has issued a cautionary plea to fans of the movie Bird Box, urging them to avoid the "Bird Box Challenge" that has gone viral, where people upload videos of themselves doing everyday tasks blindfolded. The company warned that the challenge, which has no reports of serious injuries, is spreading widely enough that it could lead to harm. Netflix asked people to be careful and not to hurt themselves with the challenge, referencing the two children in the movie who are the main characters.

site_title: US factory gauge tumbles by most since 2008 as orders cool
summary: A US factory gauge plummeted to a two-year low of 54.1 in December, missing estimates, as orders cooled and production slid. The decline was the largest since October 2008, with all five main components falling. Employment, delivery, and inventory gauges also declined, with only 11 of 18 industries reporting growth. The weakness adds to signs of a trade war and fading fiscal stimulus weighing on American producers, and may prompt the Federal Reserve to pause interest-rate hikes.

site_title: Singapore's Nova Buildings acquires BlueScope's pre-fab buildings business in Vietnam
summary: Singapore-based private equity firm Fintonia Group has led a management buyout of BlueScope's pre-fab buildings business in Vietnam, forming Nova Buildings. The company will take over operations of BlueScope's key fabrication assets and serve as its main export hub for the South-east Asia region. Nova Buildings will establish a market presence in the Philippines and emerging Indochina countries, with a focus on the high-growth pre-engineered buildings market in Asean.

site_title: ISR Capital says 'no' to SGX order to hold shareholder vote on mining acquisition
summary: ISR Capital has refused to seek shareholder approval for its acquisition of a 60% stake in Tantalum Holding (Mauritius) after waiving a condition related to a cash flow budget and liquidity plan. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) had ordered the company to obtain shareholder approval before proceeding with the deal. ISR argued that the waiver did not prejudice shareholders and would not have an adverse impact, and therefore, shareholder approval is not required. Despite the disagreement, ISR has proceeded with the acquisition, issuing 747.26 million new shares to the vendor.

site_title: With May's agreement in balance, ministers warn against no-deal Brexit
summary: UK ministers warn that a no-deal Brexit is more likely if lawmakers reject Prime Minister Theresa May's agreement, which is set to be voted on January 14. Brexit minister Stephen Barclay says a no-deal exit would hit the farming sector hard, while Environment Minister Michael Gove warns of rising costs for British farmers and food firms. The government is seeking extra reassurances from Brussels to persuade lawmakers to back May's plan, which would result in a structured exit and relatively close economic ties.

site_title: Drugmaker Bristol-Myers Squibb to buy Celgene in US$74b deal
summary: Bristol-Myers Squibb has agreed to acquire Celgene in a $74 billion deal. The new company, focused on treating serious conditions like cancer, will own 69% of the merged entity, with Celgene shareholders receiving one Bristol-Myers Squibb share and $50 in cash for each Celgene share. The deal is expected to drive sustainable growth and deliver new treatment options for patients. Bristol-Myers Squibb Chairman and CEO Giovanni Caforio will continue to lead the company, with two Celgene board members joining the board of directors.

site_title: Tesla's Musk says Singapore government has been 'unwelcome'
summary: Elon Musk reiterated that the Singapore government has been "unwelcome" to Tesla, contradicting the country's claims of supporting electric vehicles. Musk stated this in response to a tweet, without elaboration, reiterating his previous assertion that the government wasn't supportive of electric vehicles. This comes after Singapore's Land Transport Authority said it supports the adoption of hybrid and electric vehicles.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Equity Research has re-initiated coverage on Silverlake Axis with a "buy" call and a target price of S$0.60, citing a growing project orderbook and potential for more contracts. The company's orderbook has improved significantly, with potential for more orders, and its market leader position in the financial industry can secure more contracts as financial institutions upgrade their systems. The analyst expects a turnaround for the company and a potential upside of 45% from the current price.

site_title: Gas market braces for slump as it eyes record flow from Russia
summary: European natural gas prices are expected to fall for the first time in four years in 2019 due to a record flow of gas from Russia, which reached a record 201 billion cubic meters in 2018. With a healthy amount of fuel in storage, buyers are closely monitoring Russia's gas deliveries, which could lead to a collapse in prices in the summer months. LNG imports are also expected to increase, which could offset declining production in the region.

site_title: Changes in petroleum law could give Myanmar a boost in oil and gas investments
summary: Myanmar's new petroleum law draft aims to attract oil and gas investments by restructuring production sharing contracts and strengthening incentives for upstream investors. The law, expected to be reviewed by parliament, will focus on maximizing benefits for the state while reducing high taxation and royalty obligations, which currently average 77% of revenues. This change could revive exploration interest in Myanmar's oil and gas blocks, currently under-explored in the region.

site_title: Fresh clashes in India temple dispute
summary: Clashes broke out in southern India's Kerala state for a second day as Hindu hardliners protested the entry of two women into the Sabarimala temple. The women, escorted by police, entered the site via a side entrance, defying a ban on menstruating women. Authorities arrested 266 protestors, and tensions escalated with reports of stone-throwing, bus damage, and journalist assaults. The violence resulted in one man's death and 15 injuries, with police using tear gas and water cannons to disperse crowds. The state's chief minister accused the BJP and RSS of trying to turn the temple into a "battle zone."

site_title: US private payrolls surge in December; weekly jobless claims rise
summary: US private payrolls surged by 271,000 jobs in December, the largest increase in nearly two years, despite financial market volatility. However, initial claims for unemployment benefits rose more than expected, with a seasonally adjusted 231,000 filings for the week ended December 29. Economists caution that year-end holiday volatility may impact the accuracy of the data, and the pace of job growth is slowing due to labor market being at or beyond full employment.

site_title: LTC Corp to suspend trading from Jan 11
summary: LTC Corp will suspend trading of its shares from January 11, following a voluntary delisting resolution passed by the controlling Cheng family. The steel trading and property group will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange at a later date. As of December 27, acceptances for the exit offer were over 89.7% of total shares.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 7.72 points to 1,675.83. Volume reached 1.7 billion lots worth RM1.1 billion. The market saw an evenly matched 367 losers and gainers.

site_title: Dredging starts at UK port that may be used in no-deal Brexit
summary: The UK government has begun dredging at the Ramsgate port, which could serve as a backup in the event of a no-deal Brexit. The project, worth £14 million, aims to increase access for roll-on roll-off ships and alleviate potential congestion. However, concerns have been raised over Seaborne Freight's lack of ships and trading history, with critics questioning the government's preparedness for the UK's exit from the EU. The dredging work is expected to take about 25 days to complete.

site_title: Creative expands Super X-Fi products to headphones with built-in tech
summary: Creative Technology has launched the SXFI AIR headphone series, featuring built-in technology based on its Super X-Fi system. The headphones offer better compatibility with Apple's iOS devices and provide a three-dimensional sound effect. The company aims to integrate Super X-Fi into all future headphones. This move follows the release of the SXFI headphone amplifier in September last year and comes as investor interest in SXFI technology has increased, despite Creative's shares falling 1.11% to S$3.55 on the news.

site_title: AsiaMedic CEO resigns to pursue personal interests
summary: AsiaMedic CEO Choo Kin Poo has resigned to pursue personal interests, effective April 1. Choo had been CEO since June 2016. The company's board extends its best wishes to Choo and will search for a new CEO, overseeing the transition period. Non-executive director Guo Wenfei has also resigned to pursue personal interests, with Koh Boon How appointed as his replacement. The board's decision comes after AsiaMedic shares last traded at S$0.021 on December 20, 2018.

site_title: Alpha Energy extends long-stop date to Feb 28
summary: Alpha Energy has extended the long-stop date for its oilfield acquisition to February 28, from June 30, 2018. The company aims to raise its working interest in the Mustang field to 90.1% by acquiring shares from other owners. This move is part of its plan to consolidate its working interest, with the goal of increasing its ownership stake. The company's shares fell 2.62% to S$0.112 following the announcement.

site_title: Singapore's manufacturing activity eases for the 4th straight month in December
summary: Singapore's manufacturing activity declined for the fourth consecutive month in December, with the Singapore Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 51.1, its lowest reading since July 2017. The sector's slower expansion was attributed to declining new orders, exports, and employment, as well as a contraction in the electronics sector PMI. Economists attribute the weaker print to trade war uncertainties and peaking electronics cycles, with potential buffers from non-electronics industries, such as the biomedical sector.

site_title: Teho International to distribute vendors shares as part of settlement
summary: Teho International, a CATALIST-listed oil and gas company, will distribute up to 53.7 million shares to its shareholders as part of a settlement agreement with two vendors. The shares were held by directors of TIEC Holdings, who Teho claimed breached their duties in 2017. The settlement was reached in January last year, following an out-of-court agreement. The shares last traded at S$0.028 on December 26, 2018.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Apple sales warning drags tech
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday due to a drop in the technology sector, following Apple's rare sales warning that fueled fears of a Sino-US trade war and a slowing China economy impacting corporate profits. The Dow Jones fell 0.73%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.72%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 1.22%. The tech sector's decline was attributed to concerns that the trade war and China's economic slowdown would reduce profits, leading to a weaker stock market opening.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

The number of Housing Board flats sold in December 2018 dropped 23.9% due to cooling measures. Deloitte proposed a sugar tax on drinks manufacturers to fund healthier food options. Hyflux received a 4.5-month extension to report its financial results. Cavenagh Gardens aims to sell 11,800 sq ft of state land for S$480m. The STI generated a 9.2% annualised return in 2009-2018, while Singapore shares closed lower on Thursday with the Straits Times Index down 0.9%. Internationally, Malaysia's agency may seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as Apple guidance cut whipsaws tech stocks
summary: European shares fell 0.8% due to Apple's cut in its sales forecast, citing a slowdown in China and fewer iPhone upgrades. This reinforced concerns over global growth and pummeled technology shares. The Stoxx Europe 600 dropped, with ams AG and Dialog Semiconductor losing 12% and 7% respectively. Analysts attributed the move to growing worries about a trade war and slowing global growth, echoing recent data on China's slowing manufacturing activity.

site_title: Netlink NBN, Singtel, Axiata Group top picks among Asean telcos: DBS analysts
summary: DBS analysts have named Netlink NBN, Singtel, and Axiata Group as top picks among Asean telcos due to their stable capital expenditure and positive economic value added (EVA) predictions. Netlink NBN offers a 6.6% yield and 4% distribution CAGR, while Singtel has a 10% earnings CAGR and fixed dividend of 17.5 cents. Axiata Group boasts a 30% earnings CAGR and 4% yield, driven by Celcom and XL Axiata growth. The analysts also predict 5% contraction in Singapore's mobile revenue in 2019, but expect revenue stabilization from 2020 onwards.

site_title: China's population shrinks despite two-child policy: experts
summary: China's population shrank by 1.27 million in 2018, marking the first decline in 70 years, according to researcher Yi Fuxian. The country's two-child policy, introduced in 2016, failed to boost fertility rates, with live births decreasing by 2.5 million year-on-year. Experts warn of a "demographic crisis" that threatens China's economy and pension systems, with the number of working-age individuals expected to fall by 39% over the next decade. If left unchecked, China's ageing crisis could be more severe than Japan's, with severe economic implications.

site_title: Australian shares end higher as weak dollar boosts export stocks
summary: Australian shares rose 1.4% on Thursday, driven by a weak dollar that boosted export-oriented stocks, particularly gold stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,633.4. This follows a 1.6% drop on Wednesday. Meanwhile, broader Asian shares were affected by Apple's revenue warning, which fueled concerns about slowing global growth and weaker earnings.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,014.57, down 0.8% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Thursday with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 24.32 points or 0.8% to 3,014.57. The most actively traded stock was KLW Holdings, which fell S$0.002 to S$0.004. Losers outnumbered gainers 178 to 137.

site_title: Thailand's headline inflation at 0.4% in Dec
summary: Thailand's headline inflation rose 0.4% in December, below economist estimates of 1% and down from 0.9% in November. Core inflation remained stable at 0.7%, suggesting stable domestic demand. The inflation rate for 2018 was 1.06%, just above the policy target of 1-4%. Despite this, Citi economist Nalin Chutchotitham suggests it's difficult to justify a rate hike in 2019 due to downside risks to the inflation outlook.

site_title: Cavenagh Gardens tries again for en bloc sale; keeps S$480m reserve price
summary: Cavenagh Gardens is attempting an en bloc sale for S$480 million, with a land rate of S$1,695 psf ppr. The site, comprising three blocks of 172 apartments, spans 128,255 sq ft with a gross plot ratio of 2.1. Marketing agent JLL says in-principle approval was granted in 2018, and a developer is likely to secure approval due to the site's location between the CTE and central area. The tender closes on Jan 31.

site_title: Chinese coffee startup Luckin plans to open 2,500 stores this year
summary: Chinese coffee startup Luckin plans to open 2,500 new stores this year, aiming to surpass Starbucks as the largest coffee chain in China. The company has expanded rapidly, opening over 2,000 locations in the past year and gaining a valuation of $2.2 billion. Luckin aims to reach a total of over 4,500 stores by the end of 2019, overtaking Starbucks' 3,600 stores in the country.

site_title: China lands probe on far side of moon: state TV
summary: China successfully landed its Chang'e-4 lunar rover on the far side of the moon on January 3, 2019, marking the first time a probe has achieved this feat. The rover relayed a photo of the "dark side" of the moon to the Queqiao satellite, which will facilitate communication between controllers on Earth and the far side. This historic achievement showcases China's advancements in space exploration and technology.

site_title: Vietnam clocks 7.1% growth in 2018; growth to ease this year
summary: Vietnam's economy grew 7.1% in 2018, driven by agriculture, industry, and services. Manufacturing production and foreign direct investment remained significant growth drivers, with US$19.1 billion in FDI and US$16.6 billion in foreign investment. The economy is expected to grow 6.7% in 2019, with high transport and energy infrastructure investments and industrial production boosted by multinational enterprises. However, unfavourable weather conditions and the US-China trade dispute may undermine growth, and the State Bank of Vietnam may normalise monetary policy by hiking interest rates.

site_title: Singapore shares end lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares closed 0.9% lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index falling 26.01 points to 3012.88. The most actively traded stock, ThaiBev, dropped S$0.015 to S$0.59. Losers outnumbered gainers 218 to 154, and about 1.16 billion shares worth S$886 million changed hands. This marks a reversal from the previous day's 0.4% gain, as investors remained cautious despite positive sentiment.

site_title: Australian dollar left bloody after computer-driven crash
summary: The Australian dollar plummeted to multi-year lows on January 3, 2019, after a computer-driven crash, falling 5% on the yen and almost 4% on the US dollar. The sudden drop, attributed to a lack of liquidity and automated selling, was one of the largest intra-day falls in its history. As trading calmed, the currency recovered some losses, but the incident highlighted the vulnerability of financial markets to computer-driven crashes.

site_title: Chances of trade deal with US rising, says ex-China official
summary: A former Chinese trade official, Wei Jianguo, expressed optimism about a potential US-China trade deal, citing both sides' clearer goals and intentions. China won't negotiate on core interests, including sovereignty, national security, and energy, while the US is concerned about maintaining its global leadership. Trade officials will meet in Beijing next week for the first face-to-face negotiation since a 90-day truce in the trade war. Wei anticipates a deal with specific agreements, but emphasizes China's resolve to protect its core national interests.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks suffer more losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.26% on Thursday, extending losses from the previous day, due to Apple's revenue forecast cut citing slowing Chinese sales. The Hang Seng index closed at 25,064.36, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes fell 0.93% and 0.80% respectively. The losses come as investors weigh the impact of US-China trade tensions on global markets.

site_title: STI generates 9.2% annualised total return in 2009-2018 period: SGX
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) generated an annualised total return of 9.2% from 2009-2018, driven by the reinvestment of dividends, which would have yielded 5.7% without it. The report also notes that the current STI constituents average an indicative dividend yield of 3.8%. This highlights the importance of dividend reinvestment in the index's performance.

site_title: Eyeing China, US to hold missile drill in Japan's Okinawa: report
summary: The US military plans to conduct its first-ever missile drill around the Japanese island of Okinawa, aimed at countering an increasingly assertive China. The drill, scheduled for this year, involves deploying surface-to-ship missiles in response to potential Chinese attacks. This move is part of Washington's efforts to counter China's growing maritime activities in the region, which experts believe are part of a plan to establish control of key waters. The drill is seen as a counter-measure to China's rapidly expanding military presence in the western Pacific.

site_title: Deloitte's Budget ideas: sugar tax, green incentives, startup-friendly tax regime
summary: Deloitte Singapore has released Budget 2019 recommendations, suggesting a sugar tax on drinks manufacturers to fund healthier food options, enhanced green incentives such as 200% capital allowances for energy-efficient equipment, and a startup-friendly tax regime. The sugar tax revenue could also be used to support sustainable initiatives. These proposals aim to tackle sweetened beverages, promote environmental sustainability, and support local startups, aligning with the government's goals.

site_title: Vietnamese investors to inject shipyard asset, take substantial stake in EMS Energy
summary: EMS Energy has entered into a binding MOU to acquire a 52.76% stake in Vietnamese shipyard Nosco Shipyard Joint Stock Company for S$16.6 million. The deal, expected to be completed on April 15, 2019, will see EMS issue 11.06 billion new shares, representing a 96.1% stake in the enlarged share capital. The acquisition is aimed at resolving EMS's viability and operational issues, and the company will seek a waiver from making a mandatory general offer. Completion of the deal is contingent on shareholder approval and a waiver from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge acquires India land parcel to develop IT park
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge Group has acquired a 4.9-ha land parcel in Chennai, India, to develop an IT park called International Tech Park Chennai (ITPC) - Radial Road. The 2.3 million sq ft development will offer 1.10 million sq ft of Grade A business space and is located in a high-growth area. The acquisition is part of Ascendas-Singbridge's commitment to Chennai and Tamil Nadu, with the company already owning two IT parks and logistics facilities in the city. Construction will begin once approvals are obtained, further strengthening the company's presence in the Indian IT market.

site_title: Manhattan home prices fall under US$1m for the first time since 2015
summary: Manhattan home prices fell to US$999,000 in the fourth quarter, the first time below US$1 million since 2015. The median dropped 5.8% from a year earlier, with many apartments sold for 6.2% less than their original list price. This marked the first time the median was under US$1 million in three years, indicating ample inventory and buyer demand for sweeter deals.

images.alt_text: Manhattan home prices fell in the fourth quarter, with the median slipping to less than US$1 million for the first time in three years, as ample inventory continued to allow buyers to demand sweeter deals.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS restarts coverage on Silverlake Axis with 'buy'
summary: DBS Equity Research has re-initiated its coverage on Silverlake Axis with a "buy" call and a target price of 60 Singapore cents, citing the company's growing project orderbook and potential for higher-margin software licensing business. The research house believes Silverlake can leverage its market leader position to secure more contracts as financial institutions upgrade their systems. The analyst expects a turnaround and a potential 45% upside, but notes key risks include a potential slowdown in IT spending and corporate governance issues.

site_title: PUB fines two contractors S$77,000 for damage to water mains
summary: Two Singaporean construction companies, HSC Pipeline Engineering and SNK Engineering & Trading, have been fined a total of S$77,000 for causing damage to potable water mains. The damage resulted in water lost equivalent to three Olympic-sized swimming pools. HSC was fined S$47,000 for damaging a 1,200mm diameter water main in 2016, while SNK was fined S$30,000 for damaging a 300mm diameter water main in 2017. Both companies failed to follow PUB's guidelines for working near water mains, leading to a serious disruption in water supply.

site_title: Forget about repeating strong 2018 US job gains, say economists
summary: The US economy is expected to see a slowdown in job growth in 2019, with economists forecasting an average monthly pace of 156,000 jobs, down from 180,000 in 2018. This would result in a total of 1.87 million jobs added in 2019, and 1.44 million in 2020. The jobless rate is expected to edge down to 3.5% by the end of 2019, and wage gains are projected to ease to 3% year-over-year. The slowdown in job growth is attributed to intensifying economic headwinds and a waning boost from President Trump's tax cuts and government spending.

site_title: China's 'Jack the Ripper' executed
summary: China's serial killer, dubbed "Jack the Ripper," Gao Chengyong, was executed on Thursday morning in the northwest city of Baiyin, Gansu province. Gao, 54, was convicted of robbing, raping, and murdering 11 women and girls between 1988 and 2002. The youngest victim was eight years old, and some had their reproductive organs removed. Gao was sentenced to death in March 2018 and his execution was approved by China's supreme court. The case, which took 28 years to solve, was linked to a DNA match with one of Gao's relatives.

site_title: Carousell snags ex-SPH deputy marketing chief, ex-RedMart COO to boost SE Asia operations
summary: Online marketplace Carousell has appointed Tan Su Lin as vice-president of operations and Colin Bryar as adviser to its executive leadership team to drive innovation and enhance user experience in Southeast Asia. The appointments come as Carousell seeks to support growth and expand its presence in seven markets across the region. The company is backed by Rakuten Ventures, 500 Startups, and DBS, among others.

site_title: Bigger drop in HDB resale flats sold in December from cooling measures
summary: The number of HDB resale flats sold in December 2018 decreased by 23.9% compared to November, a bigger drop than the 20.1% seen in 2017. The resale volume in December 2018 was 1,434 flats, 9.6% lower than December 2017. HDB resale prices also dropped 0.3% in December, with a 14.3% decrease from their peak in April 2013. However, certain segments saw bright spots, with four- and five-room flats commanding higher premiums over market value.

site_title: China easing expected as US$625b 'liquidity hole' opens up
summary: China is expected to cut the reserve requirement ratio and inject liquidity this month to address a potential liquidity shortage ahead of the Spring Festival holidays. The country's largest securities firm, Citic Securities Co, estimates a $854 billion liquidity hole due to increased demand for funds from residents, corporate tax payments, and lenders' interbank debt. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) will likely reduce the reserve requirement ratio and provide funding for lenders to make loans to private companies, aiming to plug the liquidity hole and support economic growth.

site_title: Asia: Markets stage slight recovery but tech firms soured by Apple
summary: Asian markets experienced a slight recovery on Thursday, with most markets rising after the previous day's sharp losses, but technology firms were hit by Apple's revenue forecast cut due to slowing China sales. The yen surged after the announcement, briefly reaching its lowest level since March, before recovering. Investors remain cautious due to uncertainty over China-US trade, China's economic woes, the US government shutdown, and Brexit, with sentiment remaining weak.

site_title: Tourists flee Thai islands as Tropical Storm Pabuk looms
summary: Tens of thousands of tourists have fled Thai resort islands of Koh Phangan and Koh Tao ahead of Tropical Storm Pabuk, which is expected to bring heavy rains, wind, and seven-meter waves. The storm, Thailand's first outside of the monsoon season in 30 years, is set to hit the islands on Friday night. Tourists packed onto ferries bound for the southern Thai mainland, with swimming banned and boat services suspended. Authorities have not issued an official evacuation order, but tourists are leaving in droves, with 30,000 to 50,000 estimated to have departed since New Year's Eve.

site_title: Robots aren't yet killing off all our jobs, says World Bank
summary: The World Bank's chief economist Pinelopi Koujianou Goldberg says the rise of automation has had a negligible impact on jobs globally, contradicting common predictions that humans will be replaced by machines. While advanced economies have lost industrial jobs, East Asia's growth has compensated for the loss. The World Bank reports that technological advances will create opportunities for more productive and creative jobs, but workers will need to develop advanced cognitive skills. To ease the transition, governments should guarantee universal social protection, and salaries may become less relevant in countries trying to catch up to peers.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.52 points to 1,674.63 at 9am on Thursday, driven by gains. The index saw 17.85 million lots traded worth RM9.97 million, with 101 gainers outnumbering losers 53-53.

site_title: World's largest cigarette maker plans IPO for its international business
summary: China National Tobacco Corp, the world's largest cigarette maker, plans to list its international unit, China Tobacco International (HK), on the Hong Kong stock exchange. The unit, responsible for procuring overseas tobacco leaf, accounts for a small portion of the parent company's business but represents a rare opening up of the state monopoly. The listing comes amid growing domestic concerns over China's high smoking rates and the government's reluctance to increase taxes to curb smoking. The unit's revenue dropped 21% in the past nine months, but it had a gross profit margin of 5.8%.

site_title: Singapore's DBS Group hits near 6-week low; chart suggests more downside
summary: DBS Group Holdings Ltd shares fell as much as 1.96% to S$23.03, their lowest since November 23, 2018. The stock broke below a support level, suggesting further downside. The company's wave pattern indicates it's in the final wave of a three-wave downtrend, with a possible next support at S$22.059. The stock has declined 8.35% in the last three months, outperforming the broader index.

site_title: Hyflux gets more time to report financials, conduct AGM amid restructuring
summary: Hyflux, a cash-strapped water treatment company, has received further extensions from the Singapore Exchange to report its financials and conduct its annual general meeting. The company now has until June 30, 2019, to announce its second and third quarter results for fiscal 2018, and until April 30, 2019, to hold its annual general meeting. The extensions are linked to its debt moratorium, which will provide time for the company to reorganize its liabilities and businesses.

site_title: ISR Capital says no to SGX request for shareholder nod for mining asset purchase
summary: ISR Capital has rejected a request by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to seek shareholder approval for waiving a condition precedent in its US$44.5 million acquisition of a stake in a mining asset in Madagascar. The SGX had deemed the waiver material and potentially detrimental to the company and its operations. ISR Capital argued that the waiver was not prejudicial to shareholders and would not have a negative impact on the project's development. The company had already announced the acquisition's completion on or around December 31, pending the waiver.

site_title: SoftBank's early-stage venture arm to open Singapore office in Q1 2019
summary: SoftBank Ventures Asia, a US$1.1 billion early-stage investment arm, will open a Singapore office in Q1 2019. The venture is seeking AI-related startups, especially in Asia, to invest in. With existing offices in Seoul, Beijing, San Francisco, and Tel Aviv, the company has invested in over 250 companies across 10 countries, focusing on AI, IoT, and robotics startups. CEO JP Lee aims to support promising entrepreneurs with access to SoftBank's community, resources, and network.

site_title: Trump says received 'great' letter from North Korea's Kim
summary: US President Donald Trump stated he received a "great letter" from North Korea's Kim Jong Un, amid ongoing nuclear talks. Trump expressed confidence in a potential second summit, despite Pyongyang's warning that sanctions may change their approach. The US President also reiterated his commitment to denuclearization, following a pledge signed in Singapore last June.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said Wednesday he had received a "great letter" from Kim Jong Un, after the North Korean leader warned Pyongyang may change its approach to nuclear talks if Washington persists with sanctions.

site_title: Apple isn't the only casualty of China's slowdown
summary: Apple is the latest major company to face challenges in China due to the country's slowdown, joining a growing list of companies struggling with a trade war and equity selloff. The smartphone maker cited a slowdown in China as a reason for its reduced revenue outlook. Other companies, including car manufacturers and coffee chains, are also experiencing difficulties in selling products in China. The country's economic slowdown raises pressure on policymakers, with GDP growth expected to slow further. This trend is expected to continue, affecting global markets and economies.

site_title: Giving up beef could reduce diet-related deaths by 5%: World Economic Forum
summary: A report by the World Economic Forum suggests that switching to alternative protein sources from beef could reduce diet-related deaths by 5% in high and upper-middle-income countries by 2050. This reduction could also lower food-related greenhouse gas emissions by a quarter. The report notes that global meat consumption is rising, particularly in China and developing regions, and that meeting the protein needs of a projected 10 billion population sustainably will be challenging. Innovation in alternative and traditional proteins is seen as a key solution to this challenge.

site_title: Asia: Shares skid as Apple warning stokes growth fears, 'flash crash' sweeps currencies
summary: Shares in Asia plummeted on Thursday after Apple Inc issued a rare revenue warning, citing weaker sales in China and fewer iPhone upgrades. The tech giant's 8% drop in after-hours trade sparked a 'flash crash' in currency markets, with the Japanese yen surging against most major currencies. Global growth concerns were exacerbated by the warning, leading to losses in US stock futures and a decline in Asian shares. The dollar weakened against the yen, while oil prices rose, driving gains in energy shares.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Industries, ISOTeam, Aspen Holdings, ISR Capital
summary: Sembcorp Industries will install rooftop solar panels at three logistics warehouses in Singapore, with a combined capacity of 7.9 megawatts peak. ISOTeam has been awarded a second Home Improvement Programme project worth around S$26.3 million. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investors' positivity despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge lower at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell at the open on Thursday, extending the previous day's slump. The Hang Seng Index eased 0.21% to 25,077.68, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The decline was attributed to technology firms taking a hit after Apple slashed its revenue outlook due to slowing sales in China.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.5% to 3,022.27
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.5% to 3,022.27 on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index losing 16.62 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 60 to 36, with Singtel being the most actively traded counter, falling 0.3%. The decline came despite a 5-day rally, as investors awaited GDP data.

site_title: 'Flash-crash' moves hit Asia currency markets on Thursday morning
summary: A flash crash in Asia's currency markets occurred on Thursday morning, with Japan's yen surging 3.7% to its highest level since March 26, while the Australian dollar plummeted 3.5% to its lowest since March 2009. The sudden move was attributed to algorithmic-platform pricing hitting thin liquidity amid concerns over global growth, triggered by Apple's lowered revenue outlook citing weakness in China's economy. The volatile currency swings were also influenced by Japanese retail investors and a "very thin" market as New York trading ended and Tokyo is closed.

site_title: Here's what to expect from oil in 2019
summary: Oil prices are expected to be volatile in 2019 due to oversupply and demand concerns. A deal between Opec and Russia in December aimed to curb output, but US President Donald Trump's tweets and US shale producers' increased production threaten to undo this effort. Geopolitical uncertainty poses a significant risk to the industry, with major uncertainties and forecasting trends making 2019 a hazardous time for predicting oil prices. Experts anticipate a lack of "shock and awe" in Opec policy, potentially tempering volatility.

site_title: Apple cuts outlook, sees 'challenges' in China, emerging markets
summary: Apple cut its revenue outlook for the latest quarter, citing "economic deceleration" in China and emerging markets due to trade frictions. The company slashed its revenue guidance to $84 billion, below analyst forecasts of $91 billion. Apple cited supply constraints, iPhone sales, and a strong dollar as factors contributing to the decline. Despite this, the company expects "all-time revenue records" in some developed countries, including the US, Canada, and South Korea.

site_title: Tesla cuts US prices on all vehicles, shares drop
summary: Tesla Inc. cut US prices on all vehicles by $2,000 to offset lower green tax credits, but shares dropped nearly 7% amid concerns over future profitability. The move comes as the US tax credit for electric vehicles phases out, and Tesla fell short on quarterly deliveries of its mass-market Model 3 sedan. The company delivered 63,150 Model 3s, missing forecasts, and its third-quarter pretax profit was around $3,200 per vehicle delivered, which could be eliminated by the price cut.

site_title: Lenders are thriving on bitcoin's bust by aiding both fanatics and shorts
summary: Lenders in the cryptocurrency industry are thriving during the current bitcoin bust, with growing demand from both enthusiasts and big investors. Companies such as BlockFi, Aave, and Salt Lending have seen significant growth in revenue and customer base, with some lenders even nearing profitability. The lending niche has proven to be resilient, with lenders able to capitalize on the market downturn by offering loans to borrowers who don't want to sell their virtual coins at depressed prices. As the market continues to fluctuate, lenders are expanding their product offerings and planning to enter new markets, positioning themselves for long-term growth.

site_title: Oil volatile, ends up 2% but demand concerns still weigh
summary: Oil prices rose 2% in choppy trading on Wednesday, driven by a slight recovery on Wall Street. Despite this, concerns about weakening global economic growth and potential supply cuts from OPEC remain, weighing on demand. Brent crude futures settled at $54.91 a barrel, while US WTI crude rose to $46.54 a barrel. Manufacturing data from China and the Euro zone also raised concerns about a slowing global economy, with China's factory activity contracting for the first time in over two years.

site_title: Trump warns US government shutdown could last 'a long time'
summary: US President Donald Trump warned that a federal government shutdown could last "a long time" as he stood firm on his demand for billions of dollars in funding for a border wall with Mexico. The shutdown, now in its 12th day, is due to a dispute between Trump and Democratic lawmakers over the wall's funding. Trump will meet with top Democrats Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer in an attempt to break the impasse, which has resulted in swaths of the federal government being shut down.

site_title: Shanahan takes Pentagon helm as Trump blasts Mattis
summary: US Acting Defense Secretary Patrick Shanahan took the Pentagon's helm on January 1, succeeding Jim Mattis, who quit amid disagreements with President Donald Trump. Trump attacked Mattis, claiming he had "essentially fired" him, despite Mattis' resignation. Shanahan sought to lay out his priorities, focusing on the National Defense Strategy and addressing geopolitical concerns, including China's military and economic espionage. Trump also requested Shanahan to classify reports and mull a 50% drawdown in Afghanistan, raising concerns among lawmakers and allies.

site_title: Disney hauls in US$7.3b at box office in 2018
summary: Disney achieved its second-best year at the box office, earning US$7.325 billion worldwide in 2018. This surpasses its previous record of US$7.6 billion in 2016. Notable hits included "Black Panther," "Avengers: Infinity War," and "Incredibles 2," which collectively earned over US$4.64 billion worldwide. Disney remains the only studio to reach US$7 billion in annual box office receipts. The studio's success is attributed to the support of fans worldwide and has set the stage for a promising 2019, with upcoming films like "Captain Marvel," "Avengers: Endgame," and "Frozen 2."

site_title: US: Oil shares close higher, boosting stocks
summary: US stocks closed higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.1% to 23,346.24, the S&P 500 rising 0.1% to 2,510.03, and the Nasdaq Composite Index increasing 0.5% to 6,665.94. A rally in petroleum-linked shares, driven by a Bloomberg report on Saudi Arabia cutting oil output, offset losses from weak Chinese economic data. US stocks are coming off their worst year in a decade, with President Trump predicting a market surge after a trade deal with China is reached.

site_title: Apple sales warning is an ominous sign for the global economy
summary: Apple has issued a warning about slowing Chinese sales, eroding over $50 billion of its market capitalization. The company expects $84 billion in revenue in the latest quarter, a 8% decline from earlier guidance. This is attributed to a sharp deceleration in emerging markets, particularly in Greater China, where iPhone sales have rapidly slowed. The decline in Chinese demand may be an ominous sign for the global economy, which is heavily reliant on Chinese output.

images.alt_text: Apple's warning about slowing Chinese sales eroded more than US$50 billion of its US$750 billion market capitalisation on Wednesday afternoon. It will also have taken a chunk out of confidence in the global economy.

site_title: Romney launches blistering attack on Trump's character
summary: Mitt Romney, the incoming US Senator, has launched a scathing attack on President Donald Trump's character, stating that Trump has "not risen to the mantle of the office" and his actions have alienated America's allies. Romney, who had previously endorsed Trump for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination, vowed to "vote with my conscience" and treat Trump as he would any other president.
