Romney's comments come after he published an op-ed piece in The Washington Post criticizing Trump's leadership and character, with Trump responding with a tweet calling Romney a " Flake" and urging him to focus on border security.

site_title: World's biggest ultra-high voltage line powers up across China
summary: China has successfully powered up the world's longest and most powerful ultra-high voltage (UHV) power line, spanning 3,293km from northwest to the east. The 40.7 billion yuan project, dubbed the "Power Silk Road," can transmit 12 gigawatts of power and supply 66 billion kilowatt hours of electricity annually to eastern China, reducing coal use by 30.24 million tons. The line runs through four provinces before ending in Xuancheng, Anhui province, and is part of China's strategy to shift electricity from the west to the east to ease electricity surplus.

site_title: Latin America's weak economic recovery
summary: Latin America's economies have experienced five consecutive years of anaemic growth, averaging 0.5% annual GDP growth from 2014 to 2018, with only Panama and the Dominican Republic exceeding 4% growth. Venezuela's economy has collapsed, while Argentina faced a currency crisis and IMF bailout. Brazil's recession has ended slowly, and Mexico's growth has been mediocre. However, the UN projects an average growth rate of 1.7% for 2019, and the region's prospects are expected to improve, albeit slowly. Deep reforms, including industrial manufacturing support and increased infrastructure investment, are needed to boost growth.

site_title: Cathay sells US$16,000 premium seats for US$675 in ticketing error
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways sold business class tickets from Vietnam to Canada and the US at economy prices, starting at $675, in a ticketing error. The airline, which is struggling to turn its fortunes around, has not yet said whether it will honour the bookings. The pricing gaffe comes after a 2018 data breach exposed private information of 9.4 million passengers. This is not the first time Cathay has made a similar pricing error, as Singapore Airlines and Hong Kong Airlines have also honoured tickets sold at economy fares after being mistakenly sold at business class prices.

site_title: Nasa's New Horizons space probe 'phones home'
summary: NASA's New Horizons space probe successfully "phoned home" after a 6.4 billion km journey to Ultima Thule, a 32-km-long space rock in the Kuiper Belt. The probe came within 3,540km of the rock, providing scientists with new insights into its composition and creation. This marks the most distant world ever explored by humans, offering secrets to the early solar system's formation. The probe's findings will aid in understanding the origins of our solar system.

site_title: Soilbuild Construction wins S$28.3m HDB contract
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group has secured a S$28.3 million contract with the Housing & Development Board (HDB) for design and upgrading works at two housing blocks in Singapore, with a 20-month project timeline.

site_title: Nasa says faraway world Ultima Thule shaped like 'snowman'
summary: NASA's New Horizons mission has confirmed that Ultima Thule, a 4.5 billion-year-old celestial body, is shaped like a giant snowman. The first detailed images revealed two lobes, Ultima and Thule, formed when they slowly gravitated towards each other and merged. The discovery provides a rare glimpse into the early formation of the solar system, and scientists believe it is the first object to be born in this way. Ultima Thule's surface reflects light like garden dirt and completes its rotation in about 15 hours.

images.alt_text: Four billion miles from the sun floats Ultima Thule, an icy celestial body that Nasa scientists announced Wednesday is aptly shaped like a giant snowman.

site_title: Singapore hotel brands take on the world
summary: Singapore hotel brands are expanding overseas, offering a taste of home to travelers. The article highlights these brands, but no specific hotels are mentioned. It also features an interview with Oscar-winning director Alfonso Cuaron, who stepped away from bigger projects to make the indie movie Roma. The piece is part of a larger section on Singaporean travel and culture, including stories on The Datai in Langkawi and India's biggest visual arts event in Kochi.

site_title: HDB resale flat prices fall 0.2% in Q4; full-year 2018 prices dip 0.9% over 2017
summary: Singapore's HDB resale flat prices fell 0.2% in Q4 2018 compared to the previous quarter, and 0.9% from the same period in 2017. Market watchers attribute this decline to cooling measures, concerns over the value of older flats, and a larger supply of resale flats. This marks the end of a three-year price increase streak.

site_title: Temasek unit creates new private equity team
summary: TEMASEK Holdings' subsidiary Fullerton Fund Management is establishing a new private equity team, led by Tan Huck Khim, to build the business and address clients' long-term needs. The team will initially focus on fund of funds before expanding to other areas. The move aims to complement Fullerton's existing range of investment strategies and solutions. The new team's appointments include Kenneth Chia as vice-president and Mark Yuen as chief business development officer, both from previous roles at AIA Investment Management and Eastspring Investments, respectively.

site_title: S&P affirms NTUC Income's 'AA-' rating
summary: S&P Global Ratings has affirmed NTUC Income Insurance Co-operative's 'AA-' rating for its local currency long-term issuer credit and financial strength. The stable outlook predicts the co-operative will remain among Singapore's top five insurers for the next two years. NTUC Income's risk position has improved due to reduced dependence on non-traditional capital and managed exposure to risky assets. The agency expects moderate growth in total premium income, maintaining the co-operative's competitive position and strong linkage with the Singapore government.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Influence: Deutsche's Swapnil Mishra inspiring kids to change the world
summary: Money FM podcast "Influence" features Swapnil Mishra, managing director at Deutsche, who inspires kids to change the world through his work. Mishra shares his vision for a better future and encourages young people to take action. The conversation highlights the importance of corporate social responsibility and the role of businesses in driving positive change.

site_title: UK factories rush to stockpile goods ahead of Brexit
summary: UK factories are stockpiling goods ahead of the country's Brexit departure from the European Union in March, with the manufacturing PMI rising to 54.2 in December, the highest in six months. Despite this, economists warn that the gains are short-lived and that the economy may face a bumpy ride due to customs delays at the border. The UK's manufacturing output shrank slightly in the fourth quarter of 2018, and the country's economy has lagged behind stronger growth in other economies.

site_title: Crystal-balling 3D printing for 2019 and beyond
summary: The Asia-Pacific manufacturing industry achieved steady growth in 2018, with additive manufacturing (AM) expected to grow at a 27% CAGR from 2018 to 2023, reaching US$5.66 billion. Rising trade tensions and protectionism will spur decentralization and regionalization, making digitalization and AM key enablers for distributed manufacturing. Companies adopting AM can reduce production costs and time, while a growing talent gap in AM skills poses a risk to industry growth, prompting investment in education and training programs.

site_title: Withers KhattarWong members form fully integrated practice
summary: Withers KhattarWong, a fully integrated law firm, has been formed after the member firms of the formal law alliance (FLA) combined into a single entity. The integrated practice, also named Withers KhattarWong LLP, brings together over 90 lawyers qualified in various jurisdictions, including Singapore, the US, the UK, and others. The firm's partners believe this structure eliminates duplication of resources and will enable them to expand their leading position in the market. The integration closes down Withers Singapore and ends the FLA, which had allowed the two firms to collaborate while remaining freestanding law practices.

site_title: Europe: Shares start 2019 shakily as China, EU figures deepen gloom
summary: European shares began 2019 with a loss, as fears over global growth, trade wars, and instability weighed on investors. The Euro zone's manufacturing activity barely expanded at the end of 2018, deepening concerns. Euro zone stocks closed 0.3% down, while the Stoxx 600 declined 0.2%. Investors sought safer options, but Wall Street turned positive.

site_title: Singtel CEO is first woman to be appointed to Council of Presidential Advisers
summary: Singtel CEO Chua Sock Koong has become the first woman to be appointed to the Council of Presidential Advisers in Singapore. She was nominated and appointed by President Halimah Yacob along with Eddie Teo and Chua Thian Poh. The council advises the President on various matters, including the use of discretionary powers and appointments of key personnel. This appointment marks a significant milestone for women in Singapore's public service.

site_title: China warns cities to cut reliance on property; developers' shares fall
summary: China's Communist Party warns regional cities to reduce their reliance on the property market for growth, citing concerns over rapid expansion at the expense of new industry development. The warning comes as hundreds of cities across China have seen upswings in their local property markets. Shares of top developers fell 6-7% as the People's Daily cited an analyst saying a thriving property market boosts demand for raw materials and downstream items. The sector is expected to enter a period of stable growth this year, with annual sales growth rate slowing to 20-30%.

site_title: Brazil: Stocks hit record as Bolsonaro takes charge
summary: Brazil's stock market closed at a record high on January 2, 2019, with the Ibovespa index rising 3.56% to 91,012 points. The market's optimism was fueled by President Jair Bolsonaro's promises to cut spending and debt, sparking hopes for a turnaround in the country's economy. The move comes after Brazil exited its worst-ever recession two years prior.

site_title: Australian home prices mark worst year since 2008
summary: Australian home prices fell nearly 5% in 2018, marking their worst year since 2008, due to tighter credit conditions and decreased investor interest. The national index of home prices dropped 1.8% in December and 2.3% for the quarter, with Sydney and Melbourne experiencing the largest declines. Regional centers fared better, with prices staying almost flat. The slowdown is attributed to regulators clamping down on risky lending and a heightened regulatory focus following the banking royal commission inquiry.

site_title: Medco in takeover talks with Ophir
summary: Medco Energi Internasional Tbk PT, a Singapore-based oil and gas company, is in talks with London-listed Ophir Energy about a potential cash offer. The takeover would boost Medco's valuations and gain access to international assets, analysts say. Medco, which earns most of its revenue from oil and gas operations in Indonesia, is seeking to expand its international presence. The deal, if successful, would follow Medco's previous acquisitions, including a $2.6 billion deal in 2016. Financial details of the potential transaction have not been disclosed.

site_title: The 10 books to read in 2019, based on what you loved in 2018
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

The article highlights 10 books to read in 2019, based on popular titles from 2018. The books cover a range of genres, including thrillers, memoirs, and romance. Some notable titles include "The 7 1/2 Deaths of Evelyn Hardcastle" and "The Family Chao", which explore themes of family, marriage, and forgiveness. Other books, such as "Bitcoin Billionaires" and "Killers of the Flower Moon", delve into true crime and financial history. The list also includes books on personal safety, mental health, and Native American history, offering a diverse range of perspectives and stories.

site_title: Horizon Towers gives collective sale another shot; Tanah Merah Mansion launches collective sale
summary: Horizon Towers, a 211-unit Leonie Hill development in Singapore, is relaunching its collective sale tender at the same S$1.1 billion reserve price. The tender, initially closed in September without a bid, will last around a month and close on January 28. Owners must conclude a sale contract by May 21 and apply to the Strata Titles Board for a sale order. The reserve price translates to a land rate of about S$1,977 per square foot per plot ratio, with a 99-year leasehold estate built in the 1970s.

site_title: Silkroad Nickel surges 31% to near 2-month high after married trade
summary: Silkroad Nickel's shares surged 31.4% to a near 2-month high of 46 Singapore cents after a sizeable married trade in the morning, with 1.48 million shares changing hands. The stock's usually thin trading activity was boosted by the trade, which occurred before the company's executive directors were named defendants in a writ of summons by four Malaysian-based lawyers. Silkroad Nickel debuted on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board in July 2018 and has since posted a net loss of US$3.1 million for the third quarter of 2018 due to expenses related to its reverse takeover.

site_title: Yellow Pages Building renamed Braddell House
summary: The Yellow Pages Building in Singapore has been renamed Braddell House, reflecting the owner GYP Properties' shift in business focus to property. The building, located near Braddell MRT station, serves as the group's headquarters and drives its corporate strategy. The company, formerly known as Global Yellow Pages, restructured its digital business and ceased print directory publication in 2018. The name change aims to underscore GYP Properties' Singapore origins.

images.alt_text: Above (from left): Mr Chua; director Loo Wen Lieh; director Ng Tiong Gee; chairman Mah Bow Tan; director Andrew Tay; and chief executive officer Stanley Tan at the ribbon-cutting ceremony.
Above: Braddell House, the corporate headquarters of GYP Properties, sits above Braddell MRT station.

site_title: Did troubles clip wings of Big Tech? Not just yet as it keeps growing
summary: Big Tech continues to expand despite growing concerns over its power and influence. Despite regulatory scrutiny, tech companies are investing heavily in new campuses, acquiring human capital, and pushing into emerging areas like artificial intelligence. Google and Facebook are leading the charge, with Google planning a massive 8 million square foot campus in Silicon Valley and Facebook expanding its workforce and operations. The companies' revenue continues to soar, with Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Alphabet generating $166.9 billion in revenue in the third quarter of 2018 alone. Many experts argue that Big Tech needs regulation, but it remains unclear whether the companies will self-regulate or if government intervention is necessary.

site_title: Oil slides into 2019 amid surging supply, economic slowdown
summary: Oil prices slid 1% in the first trading day of 2019 due to surging US and Russian output and concerns over an economic slowdown, particularly in China. Brent crude futures fell to $53.22 per barrel, while WTI futures dropped to $44.89 per barrel. Analysts attribute the decline to a weakening factory activity in Asia, cutting crude import quotas, and a slowdown in Chinese demand. The outlook for 2019 is uncertain, with factors including US-China trade concerns, Brexit, and Middle East instability affecting oil markets.

site_title: Barbie will soon be 60 - and is still going strong
summary: Barbie, the iconic doll, is turning 60 and remains a beloved favorite among young girls worldwide. Since its debut in 1959, Barbie has sold over 1 billion dolls and has evolved to keep up with the times, offering diverse body types, skin tones, and careers. Despite initial controversy over its pinup measurements, Barbie has introduced numerous changes and now boasts 55% of dolls sold worldwide with non-traditional features. With a massive social media presence and a focus on empowering young girls, Barbie continues to thrive, with 58 million dolls sold annually in over 150 countries.

site_title: Dubai powers ahead with blockchain
summary: Dubai has made significant progress in its blockchain-powered city initiative, launching over 20 city-wide pilot projects since 2016. The city aims to streamline government services, improve efficiency, and attract businesses with a blockchain hub. Dubai's first blockchain use case, a payment reconciliation system, went live in September, and pilot studies have been conducted in various sectors. The government plans to announce official blockchain implementation policies in early 2019, addressing challenges such as scalability, regulation, and governance. Dubai's digital transformation journey began in 1999, and it is currently considered the top smart city in its region.

site_title: Global tech show to celebrate innovation amid mounting concerns
summary: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) is set to take place in Las Vegas from January 8-11, showcasing innovative technologies amid mounting concerns about public trust in new technology. The event will feature "smart" devices using artificial intelligence, including AI-powered TVs, robots, and voice-activated devices. However, concerns about data privacy and security will be a major focus, with experts warning that skepticism about the tech industry may slow growth. The event also highlights emerging technologies such as autonomous transportation, 5G networks, and facial recognition, which raises questions about consumer readiness and data protection.

site_title: Gold hits its highest peak since June 2018
summary: Gold prices reached a six-month high of $1,287.31 per ounce, surpassing its peak in June 2018, due to the dollar's decline and concerns over global economic growth. The weaker dollar makes gold cheaper for investors holding other currencies, while China's disappointing data has fueled worries about a slowdown in global economic growth. Analysts predict that gold prices will continue to rise due to uncertainties in the global economy and geopolitical concerns.

site_title: Alcohol companies are unlikely victims of India's farm waiver
summary: India's farm waiver program is expected to negatively impact alcohol companies as states increase liquor taxes to plug the fiscal hole. The tax hike, which brings in nearly 25% of revenue, is likely to reduce demand as companies pass the additional levy to consumers. Seven states have announced waivers totaling 1.75 trillion rupees, with Maharashtra increasing the tax on Indian-made liquor by 20%. Analysts predict a decline in liquor volumes due to price hikes, impacting companies like United Spirits Ltd.

site_title: China's dismal PMI triggers mixed trading among S-chips
summary: China's manufacturing sector contracted in December, its first contraction since May 2017, due to the ongoing trade dispute with the US. This news triggered a mixed performance among Singapore stocks with China exposure, with CapitaLand and Ying Li International losing 1.3% and 2.6% respectively. Despite this, other Asian markets, including the STI, fell into negative territory.

site_title: Hyundai flags tough 2019 as US, China demand stays slow
summary: Hyundai Motor Group has set a conservative target of 7.6 million vehicle sales for 2019, citing slow sales growth in the US and China. The company faces challenges, including missed sales goals, US tariffs, and a US investigation over a vehicle recall. Group heir-apparent Chung Eui-sun has outlined plans for restructuring and launching new models, including autonomous taxis, to drive future growth.

site_title: More are warming to high-rise timber buildings
summary: Developers are increasingly using high-rise timber buildings, a material not commonly used in construction since the horse-and-buggy days. The choice of timber is driven by a desire for greener projects, as consumers continue to favor environmentally friendly options despite a growing anti-environmental mood in Washington. This shift is seen in offices, apartments, and campus buildings, offering a more sustainable alternative to traditional concrete and steel constructions. The use of engineered timber is considered both aesthetically pleasing and environmentally friendly.

site_title: Raffles Medical opens its first China hospital in Chongqing
summary: Raffles Medical Group has opened its first international tertiary hospital in China, located in Chongqing. The 700-bed hospital, with a gross floor area of over 100,000 square meters, offers specialist services and centers of excellence in various fields. The hospital aims to meet the demand for international quality healthcare in Chongqing and its surrounding regions. This marks the group's 14th presence in Asia, including eight cities in China, with plans to open a second hospital in Shanghai in 2019.

site_title: Data protection laws will be top focus in global IT industry
summary: Global data protection laws will be a top focus in the IT industry in 2019, following the success of Europe's Global Data Protection Regulation. The push for similar laws globally aims to protect online user data, but national and regional legislation is still not enough to combat cross-border cyberattacks. With data theft becoming a lucrative criminal enterprise, organizations and cybersecurity experts are preparing for attacks on IoT devices. Nation states also use cyberattacks as part of state policy, making global cooperation and a set of rules governing cyber traffic necessary to ensure the safe flow of information and data.

site_title: Marginal home price growth expected for 2019
summary: Singapore's private home prices are expected to remain flat or rise slightly in 2019, supported by new project launches. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) reported a 7.9% increase in private residential property prices in 2018, despite a 0.1% dip in the fourth quarter. Analysts predict a 3% rise in overall private home prices this year, driven by economic growth and demand from en bloc sellers. New launches will dominate the market, with up to 19,000 units available, and prices may rise by 5% or more.

images.alt_text: Private home prices are expected to remain flat or rise slightly this year, supported by a slew of new projects poised for launch.

site_title: UK factories build up stockpiles before Brexit, boosting PMI
summary: British factories built up stockpiles in December ahead of Brexit, boosting the manufacturing PMI to 54.2, the highest reading in six months. This is largely due to manufacturers stockpiling inputs and finished goods to protect against customs delays at the border after March 29. However, IHS Markit director Rob Dobson warns that any positive impact will be short-lived, as safety stocks are eroded or become obsolete. The PMI reading does not signal a big change in the outlook for Britain's stuttering economy.

site_title: China's manufacturing sector contracts in Dec as trade war hits factories
summary: China's manufacturing sector contracted in December, with its private Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) shrinking to 49.7, the lowest since 2017. This marks the first time in nearly two years that the sector has contracted. The contraction is attributed to ongoing trade tensions with the US, which have subdued external demand and weakened domestic demand. The data suggests the Chinese economy may face greater downward pressure, with analysts calling for more government support to stimulate growth.

site_title: Xi not ruling out use of force on Taiwan
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has stated that Beijing reserves the right to use force to bring Taiwan under its control, but will strive for peaceful "reunification". Xi made the comments amid increased pressure on Taiwan, which China claims as its sacred territory. Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen rejected Xi's call, urging China to adopt democracy instead.

site_title: New Year's dip: Europe enjoys a frosty tradition
summary: Europe celebrates New Year's with a chilly tradition, with thousands taking a dip in icy waters across the continent. From Edinburgh to Lisbon, people braved temperatures ranging from 5-10 degrees Celsius to take the plunge. The events, often themed, featured costumes, champagne, and charity fundraisers. In the Netherlands, 10,000 people swam in the North Sea, while in Germany, 500 people jumped into the Oranke lake. The tradition, which began in the 1980s, is a unique way to ring in the new year and is enjoyed by people of all ages.

site_title: Passenger aviation deaths up sharply in 2018
summary: Passenger aviation deaths worldwide increased sharply in 2018, with over 500 fatalities resulting from crashes. The fatality rate for large commercial passenger flights rose to 0.36 per million flights, up from 0.06 in 2017. Despite this, 2018 was still the third safest year ever, with 13 fatal crashes worldwide. The Aviation Safety Network attributed the increase to a single fatal crash involving a Lion Air-operated Boeing 737 MAX 8, which killed 189 people.

site_title: Q4 growth dips to 2.2%; all eyes on Budget boost
summary: Singapore's economy experienced a slowdown in Q4 2018, with year-on-year growth of 2.2%, according to flash estimates. This brings full-year GDP growth to 3.3%, slightly below the 3.5% target. Analysts expect the government's Budget in February to provide relief, with potential growth-friendly initiatives. Despite a hazy outlook for monetary policy, economists believe a hard landing is unlikely, with policymakers likely to maintain a gradual slowdown. The manufacturing sector showed a slight improvement, while services and construction sectors continued to contract.

site_title: Sri Lanka to halve maximum foreign holding limit in govt securities
summary: Sri Lanka's central bank plans to restrict foreign holdings of government securities to 5% from 10% to prevent "hot money flows" and improve reserve quality. The move comes after a $1 billion foreign outflow in 2018, largely due to a political crisis. The central bank aims to encourage long-term foreign investment and reduce volatility in the system. This decision is part of Sri Lanka's efforts to attract long-term foreign investment and improve its economic stability amid rating downgrades and policy inconsistency.

site_title: Qatar Airways buys 5% stake in China Southern Airlines
summary: Qatar Airways has acquired a 5% stake in China Southern Airlines, aiming to establish a presence in the Asian aviation market. This deal comes as Qatar seeks new partners and routes due to a regional diplomatic dispute. The move follows warming relations between Qatar and China, with bilateral trade reaching over $10 billion in 2017. This investment is part of Qatar Airways' strategy to invest in the world's strongest airlines.

site_title: UK unveils plans to boost ties with the Asia-Pacific post-Brexit
summary: The UK is unveiling plans to boost ties with the Asia-Pacific region post-Brexit, with Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt and Prime Minister Theresa May emphasizing the need for the UK to tap into the region's prosperity and build ties with key nations. The UK aims to remain a global power, with a focus on trade, security, and defense cooperation. Informal talks are underway with at least a dozen countries, and the UK is exploring potential membership in the Trans-Pacific Partnership. The UK's departure from the EU will also lead to negotiations with the World Trade Organization to replicate current commitments.

site_title: Indonesia posts narrowest budget deficit in six years in 2018
summary: Indonesia posted its narrowest budget deficit in six years in 2018, reaching 1.76% of GDP, exceeding the initial 2.19% and 1.83% projections. Despite capital outflows and currency fluctuations, the government managed to cover additional spending and cut bond issuance. The finance minister attributed the surplus in the primary balance to increased tax compliance and higher revenues from coal and crude oil prices. The country's economy expanded 5.15% in 2018, slightly better than the previous year but slower than the target of 5.4%.

site_title: STI, Asian equities see red to start 2019
summary: Asian stocks plummeted on the first trading day of 2019, with the Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 1% to 3,038.89, as China's manufacturing activity contracted for the first time in 19 months. The contraction was triggered by weak demand and growth stressors, including the US-China trade tensions. The decline was also attributed to lower-than-expected Singapore GDP growth for the fourth quarter. The sell-off affected markets in Hong Kong, Australia, South Korea, and Malaysia, with the Hang Seng index falling by 2.8%.

site_title: India's North-east eyes S-E Asia as trading partner via Myanmar
summary: India's North-east states, including Arunachal Pradesh, Assam, and Sikkim, are seeking to expand trade with Southeast Asia via Myanmar, leveraging their 98% border with neighboring countries. The region has seen a surge in new companies, including those producing unique products like He Man 9000 Beer and Elrhino dung paper, which aim to integrate with Asean states. This move is driven by the region's desire to shake off militant insurgencies and ethnic turmoil, and to tap into the growing Southeast Asian market.

site_title: Saudis seek advisers for biggest bank merger since 2016
summary: Saudi Arabia's National Commercial Bank and Riyad Bank are seeking advisers for a potential $182 billion merger, creating the Gulf region's third-largest lender. The banks have sent out requests for proposals to major firms, with the Public Investment Fund backing the deal. This would be the largest bank merger since 2016, surpassing Abu Dhabi's $110 billion combination. The merger aims to boost Saudi Arabia's financial services industry, following the recent combination of Saudi British Bank and Alawwal Bank.

site_title: Sell Singapore residential, buy office? Not a foregone conclusion for all
summary: Singapore's private residential market may not decline as expected, despite cooling measures and a supply overhang, according to a contrarian view by Savills Singapore research head Alan Cheong. The market's stability is supported by strong CPF savings and the security of capital, which may outweigh returns on investments. In contrast, the office market may be more vulnerable to external developments, including global equity market fluctuations and US-China trade tensions, which could impact demand for office space.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 22.47 points to 1,668.11. Losers outnumbered gainers 532 to 256, with a total of 1.68 billion lots traded worth RM951 million.

site_title: SingTel CEO becomes first woman ever to be appointed to Council of Presidential Advisers
summary: Singtel CEO Chua Sock Koong has become the first woman to be appointed to the Council of Presidential Advisers (CPA) in Singapore. She was joined by new chairman Eddie Teo and council member Chua Thian Poh. This historic appointment marks a milestone for women in Singaporean leadership.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Artivision Technologies is in talks to extend the deadline for its acquisition of Mobile Credit Payment, a long stop date of December 31, 2018. Citic Envirotech won two EPC projects worth 490 million yuan, while Sembcorp Industries will install solar panels at three logistics warehouses in Singapore. ISOTeam secured a second Home Improvement Programme project, and Koon Holdings appointed a new CFO. Pan Ocean revised its shipping contract with Vale International due to bunker fuel oil prices. Additionally, Luzhou Bio-Chem Technology appointed a new CFO, and NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: US: Stocks open sharply lower in 1st session of 2019
summary: Wall Street opened 2019 with sharp losses, as weak Chinese manufacturing data fueled worries over slowing global growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.6%, the S&P 500 dropped 1.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index plummeted 1.7%. The losses marked the latest in a downward spiral from December, highlighting concerns about the global economy.

site_title: China approves US$33.8b railway projects in Jiangsu and Anhui
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission approved eight inter-city railway projects in Jiangsu and Anhui with a combined investment of US$33.82 billion, covering 1,063 km. The projects will be developed by state-owned companies and are expected to boost economic growth in the region. The approval marks a significant investment in China's railway infrastructure and is seen as a key component of the country's development strategy.

site_title: Saudi PIF entertainment company plans to build leisure complex in Riyadh
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) plans to build a 100,000 square-meter entertainment complex in Riyadh, the latest in a series of state-backed leisure projects. The complex will feature sports, live performances, restaurants, and cinemas. SEVEN, a subsidiary of PIF, aims to establish 20 entertainment centers nationwide, creating jobs and diversifying the economy. However, the project's success may be impacted by the fallout from the Jamal Khashoggi murder, which has led some foreign companies to distance themselves from the kingdom.

site_title: Eurozone factories ended 2018 on a low note: survey
summary: Eurozone manufacturing activity ended 2018 with a broad-based slowdown, according to a survey, with the IHS Markit December PMI falling to 51.4, its lowest reading since February 2016. This follows the European Central Bank's end of its 2.6 trillion euro asset purchasing scheme. The slowdown raises concerns about a possible recession, with 20% of respondents in a Reuters poll believing a recession is likely this year. Manufacturing growth in key countries like Germany and Spain was also modest, with new orders and hiring at their weakest in several years.

site_title: Selling drugs is no longer a free lunch in China
summary: China's pharmaceutical industry is undergoing a shift as the government takes control of procurement for 11 cities, giving 60-70% of orders to the lowest bidder. This has led to a price war, with generic medicines seeing a 55% price drop. The move aims to reduce costs for the state's basic medical insurance programme, which is facing a deficit by 2020. The government is also opening the door to foreign pharma giants and allowing generic drugs that have passed bio-equivalence tests overseas to be fast-tracked. This change marks a shift away from the lucrative but low-margin business model of selling low-cost generic medicines.

site_title: Yen stands tall as growth concerns curb risk appetite
summary: The Japanese yen rose sharply on the first trading day of 2019 due to growing concerns about global growth and volatile equity markets. The yen reached a seven-month high against the US dollar, with a 2.2% gain in the last four days. Investors are becoming increasingly cautious about the US economy, leading to a decline in the Australian dollar and euro, while the yen benefits from perceived risk and is seen as a safe-haven currency. Experts expect the yen to continue its upward trend as the US dollar's vulnerabilities become more apparent.

site_title: Norway's electric cars zip to new record: almost a third of all sales
summary: Norway achieved a record 31.2% of new car sales being electric in 2018, surpassing the 2025 goal of emissions-free vehicles by 2025. This marks a significant shift towards reducing carbon emissions and air pollution. Despite this, two-thirds of sold cars still rely on fossil fuels or hybrids, and concerns about charging access and tax revenue remain. Norway's global lead in electric car sales per capita solidifies its position as a leader in transforming to a greener economy.

site_title: CITIC Envirotech clinches two EPC contracts worth 490m yuan
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED CITIC Envirotech clinched two EPC projects worth 490 million yuan, employing its proprietary membrane bioreactor technology to treat wastewater. The first project is the Andongyuan Integrated Wastewater Treatment Plant in Jinjiang City, Fujian Province, valued at 350 million yuan. This contract follows the group's efforts to utilize its advanced technology in wastewater treatment.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore-listed US Reits Manulife US Reit and Keppel-KBS US Reit have announced that the recently released proposed US tax regulations will not impact their current tax structure. The entities, used to repatriate cash from the US and Singapore, were not classified as hybrid entities, reducing the potential tax burden. Although tax rates in Barbados have increased, the proposed regulations suggest a potentially lower tax rate for the Reits, leading analysts to reiterate "buy" calls and target prices, with Manulife US Reit's units closing at US$0.79 and Keppel-KBS US Reit's units closing at US$0.61.

site_title: Singapore shares end lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Wednesday, down 29.87 points or 1% to 3,038.89, due to weak Chinese PMI figures weighing on Asian markets. The Straits Times Index saw an average unit price of S$0.52 per share, with losers outnumbering gainers 231 to 174. Key stocks, including Singtel, fell, while DBS, OCBC, and UOB also declined.

site_title: ISOTeam clinches S$26.3m contract from HDB
summary: ISOTeam, a Singapore building maintenance and estate upgrading company, has secured a S$26.3 million contract from the Housing and Development Board (HDB) for a Home Improvement Programme (HIP) project. The project, expected to be completed by June 2020, involves upgrading 35 HDB blocks across four precincts. This is ISOTeam's second HIP project from the HDB, with two of the company's subsidiaries, Raymond Construction and ISOTeam Corporation, qualified to tender for such projects.

site_title: Singapore insurer NTUC Income gets rated 'AA-' by S&P Global
summary: Singapore insurer NTUC Income has received a 'AA-' local currency long-term issuer credit rating and financial strength rating from S&P Global, affirming its positive views on the insurer. The rating reflects NTUC Income's reduced dependence on non-traditional capital sources and its managed exposure to risky assets. The insurer also earned an "A+" long-term issue rating for its subordinated debt.

site_title: Aspen completes acquisition of Penang land
summary: Aspen (Group) Holdings has acquired approximately 45 acres of land in Penang, Malaysia, for RM98 million. The land is intended for development as part of Aspen Vision City, which was previously disclosed in 2017. A deposit of RM19.6 million was paid in 2017, with the remaining purchase price paid through internal resources and Islamic financing.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy grew 2.2% in Q4, slightly lower than the 2.3% expansion in the previous quarter. Private home prices rose 7.9% in 2018, while slipping 0.1% in Q4. The Straits Times Index fell 1% on Wednesday due to weak Chinese PMI figures. Meanwhile, NTUC Income was rated 'AA-' by S&P Global, and Temasek's Fullerton Fund Management created a private equity team. Globally, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy shrank for the second month.

site_title: British teacher who arrived in Pakistan with the Raj dies aged 101
summary: Major Geoffrey Douglas Langlands, a 101-year-old British teacher who arrived in Pakistan with the British Raj, has died in Lahore. Langlands, who stayed in Pakistan for over seven decades, taught students including Prime Minister Imran Khan and was a principal at Aitchison College. He was briefly kidnapped by militants in the 1970s but was released after a group of elders intervened. Langlands was awarded two of Pakistan's highest civilian awards and left a lasting legacy as a teacher and humanitarian in the country.

site_title: 2 women defy protesters and centuries of tradition by entering Sabarimala temple
summary: Two women in southern India defied centuries of tradition by entering the Sabarimala temple, a Hindu shrine dedicated to Lord Ayappa, on January 2, 2019. The women, both in their 40s, a university professor and a government employee, entered the inner sanctum at 3:45 am, despite a ban on women of childbearing age. This marks a significant milestone, as tradition has prohibited women of menstruating age from entering the temple for centuries. Their bold move is seen as a challenge to centuries-old traditions and a step towards women's rights in India.

site_title: Sembcorp to build solar farms atop three Cache Logistics Trust warehouses
summary: Sembcorp Industries will build and operate rooftop solar panels at three Cache Logistics Trust warehouses in Singapore, with a combined capacity of about 7.9 megawatts peak. The project will include Singapore's largest rooftop solar facility to date, with the Commodity Hub warehouse housing 6.2 megawatts in peak capacity. The agreement aims to reduce the companies' carbon footprint and contribute to Singapore's renewable energy goals.

site_title: Hot stock: Silkroad Nickel shares up 14% up after married trade deal
summary: Silkroad Nickel shares surged 14% to a near two-month high at 40 Singapore cents after a married trade deal. The stock debuted on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board in July 2018 and has the mining business license to carry out nickel ore mining operations in Sulawesi, Indonesia. The company recently signed a new offtake agreement worth over S$400 million. Despite a decline in revenue for the third quarter of 2018, the surge in the stock's price indicates optimism for the company's future prospects.

site_title: Formal Law Alliance Withers KhattarWong to be a fully integrated practice
summary: Withers KhattarWong, a law firm formed in 2015 as a partnership between Withers Worldwide and KhattarWong, has become a fully integrated practice, operating as a single entity called Withers KhattarWong LLP. The two firms decided to merge after three years of collaboration, citing benefits of eliminating duplication in resources. Withers KhattarWong is the largest international law firm focused on private capital in Singapore, with over 90 lawyers qualified in various jurisdictions. The integration marks the end of Withers Singapore, which will be closed down.

site_title: Temasek unit Fullerton Fund Management creates private equity team
summary: Fullerton Fund Management, a Temasek Holdings subsidiary, has established a private equity team to expand its investment capabilities. Tan Huck Khim, formerly with Credit Suisse, joins as head of private equity, while Kenneth Chia from AIA Investment Management will serve as vice-president. The team will initially focus on fund of funds and aims to build a meaningful private equity business in phases. The move complements Fullerton's existing investment strategies and enhances its comprehensive range of solutions for clients.

site_title: Britain can punch above its weight even after Brexit: Hunt
summary: Britain can maintain its global influence despite leaving the EU, according to Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt. The country has significant economic, military, and diplomatic resources, including the 5th largest economy and the 2nd largest military budget in NATO. Hunt cited Singapore's economic model as a potential example for post-Brexit Britain, emphasizing the importance of creating a network of trade and economic links. Despite Brexit uncertainty, Hunt believes Britain can "survive, prosper and prosper in security" and remain a major global player.

site_title: Pan Ocean could see US$13b fall in sales from long-term Vale shipping contract
summary: Pan Ocean, a Singapore-listed dry bulk carrier, expects a US$13 billion decline in sales due to a revised shipping contract with Vale International. The contract, valued at US$58 billion, has been changed to a contract of affreightment, with bunker fuel oil prices affecting the sales amount. The revised contracts, effective from December 31, 2018, will transport 238.4 million tons of iron ore from Brazil to China over 19 years, with existing terms and conditions remaining unchanged.

site_title: Taiwan president defiant after China calls for reunification
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen has expressed defiance towards China's call for reunification, stating that Taiwan will not accept a "one country, two systems" arrangement. Tsai emphasized the need for government-to-government negotiations and urged China to respect Taiwanese democratic values. China's President Xi Jinping reiterated that Taiwan is part of China, and both sides should seek reunification. Tsai's stance comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: European stock markets slump at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets slumped on the first trading day of the new year, with London's FTSE 100 down 1.3%, the Paris CAC 40 1.9% lower, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 0.8% lower. The decline follows a five-day rally in Singapore stocks. US markets continued to reach fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions between the US and EU.

site_title: Spain factory activity grows in Dec at slowest pace since Aug 2016
summary: Spain's manufacturing sector grew at its slowest pace since August 2016 in December, with a Purchasing Managers' Index of 51.1, down from 52.6 in November. Output expanded at a slowest pace since August 2016, falling to 51.5. Business confidence improved, but the sector ended 2018 on a muted note due to unsustainable growth levels, exacerbated by rising economic and political instabilities.

site_title: Leveraged loans suffered biggest monthly decline in seven years
summary: US leveraged loans suffered their largest monthly decline in seven years, posting a 2.5% loss in December, the worst since August 2011. Despite this, the asset class eked out a slim gain for 2018, rising 0.44% for the year. This follows a 2.1% loss for US junk bonds and a 0.9% drop in November. The S&P/LSTA Leveraged Loan Index reported its third-worst return in 20 years, with only two down years this century. Historically, returns after down years have been the best in the index, with potential gains of up to 6% in 2019.

site_title: Australian shares kick off 2019 in the red on weak China factory survey
summary: Australian shares dropped 1.6% on the first trading day of 2019, closing at 5,557.8, due to a disappointing Chinese manufacturing survey that raised concerns about the world's second-largest economy. The survey showed China's factory activity contracted for the first time in 19 months. Global risk sentiment soured, with financial stocks and miners leading the decline. The benchmark was closed on New Year's Day and saw occasional relief from US President Trump's call with Chinese President Xi Jinping, but uncertainty about a trade war resolution continues to cloud investor sentiment.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks plunge after private survey hints at softening economy
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index plummeted 1.5% on its first trading session of the year, following private surveys indicating a softening economy. Factory activity in South Korea and China contracted for the first time in months, with South Korea's economy shrinking for a second consecutive month. The won and bond yields declined, while oil prices fell, affecting refineries. The Kospi closed at 2,010.00, and foreigners were net sellers of 26.354 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks plunge on first day of the year
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted on the first day of 2019, with the Hang Seng index falling 2.77% to close at 25,130.35. The decline was attributed to fresh signs of weakness in China's economy, causing investors to become spooked. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 1.15% and the Shenzhen Composite Index shedding 0.91%. The market's poor start marked a disappointing beginning to 2019.

site_title: Yen gains as new year trade starts on cautious note
summary: The US dollar eased against the yen on the first trading day of the new year, with the yen gaining 0.1% to 109.60, as caution prevailed due to concerns over global economic growth and the US government shutdown. This is the third straight week the yen has gained, driven by risk-off sentiment. Trading volumes remain light as global markets reopened after the New Year's Day public holiday.

site_title: Thailand's future monetary policy tightening would be gradual: central bank minutes
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, raised its one-day repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 1.75% in December, its first rate hike since 2011. The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) expects future policy tightening to be gradual, citing a strong economy and a moderation in growth. The committee views the current rate as accommodative and conducive to growth across economic sectors. The next policy review is scheduled for February 6, with most analysts expecting no policy change.

site_title: Selling drugs is no longer a free lunch in China's pharma industry
summary: China's pharmaceutical industry is facing a significant shift as the government takes over procurement of drugs for hospitals, forcing companies to reduce prices. Starting this year, 11 cities will award at least 60-70% of orders to the lowest bidder, leading to a 55% drop in average tender prices. This move aims to control rising healthcare costs and improve consumer protection, with the goal of reducing profits for drugmakers. The government is also opening the door to foreign pharmaceutical companies and accelerating the approval process for generic drugs that have passed bio-equivalence tests overseas.

site_title: Cathay sells US$16,000 premium seats for US$675 in ticketing blunder
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways sold US$16,000 premium business-class tickets to Canada and the US at economy prices, with return fares starting at US$675, in an apparent error. The airline has not yet confirmed whether it will honor the bookings, adding to the carrier's embarrassment as it struggles to regain its fortunes amidst increased competition. This mistake follows a 2018 data breach that exposed 9.4 million passengers' private information.

site_title: Factory activity in Asia weakens on China slowdown, trade disputes
summary: Factory activity in Asia weakened in December due to the Sino-US trade war and a slowdown in Chinese demand. China's Caixin/Markit PMI contracted for the first time in 19 months, while Malaysia's manufacturing activity shrunk to its weakest pace since 2012 and Taiwan contracted to its lowest since 2015. The US economy showed steady growth, but at a slower pace than expected. With growth slowing and inflation below target, Asian central banks are unlikely to continue interest rate hikes in 2019, barring any shocks in currency markets.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,034.98, down 1.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday afternoon at 3,034.98, down 1.1% from the previous day. The Straits Times Index fell 33.78 points, driven by disappointing China purchasing managers' index figures. About 838 million shares changed hands, with Ezion Holdings being the most actively traded stock. Losers outnumbered gainers 180 to 149, and key financials like DBS, OCBC, and UOB also declined.

site_title: World's largest cigarette maker plans Hong Kong IPO for its international business
summary: China National Tobacco Corp, the world's largest cigarette maker, plans to list its international business unit, China Tobacco International Inc, on the Hong Kong stock exchange. The unit, which procures overseas tobacco leaf, reported revenue of HK$5.1 billion for the nine months ended in September, a 21% drop from the same period last year. The listing, which could generate more profit than HSBC Holdings and Walmart combined, represents a rare opening up of the state monopoly facing growing concerns over China's high smoking rates and related diseases.

site_title: Indian father and son battle for billion-dollar empire
summary: An Indian father, Vijaypat Singhania, gifted control of his billion-dollar textile empire, the Raymond Group, to his son Gautam three years ago. However, their relationship has deteriorated, with the father accusing the son of cheating him and kicking him out of company offices. Vijaypat now regrets the decision, citing "emotional blackmail," amid a long line of high-profile family feuds in corporate India. The dispute highlights the challenges of family succession in large businesses, with the father's bitter regret serving as a cautionary tale for other Indian families.

site_title: Australian shares start year in wary mood, miners lend support
summary: Australian shares started 2019 in a cautious mood, with the S&P/ASX 200 index flat at 5,647.0, as mining stocks supported gains while financials lost ground. The benchmark index fell 6.9% in 2018, its worst year since 2011, due to investor anxiety over trade disputes and slowing economic growth. Analysts expect volatile markets with double-digit returns but warn of lingering trade tensions and a looming inquiry into Australia's financial sector.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly lower on January 2, 2019, as investors assessed the US government shutdown and the outlook for a trade deal between China and the US. The Hang Seng Index eased 0.08%, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.16%. Meanwhile, the US stock market reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to new highs.

site_title: Australian dollar caught in rut, bonds surge to two-year high
summary: The Australian dollar plummeted 3.4% in December, its worst monthly performance since February 2018, due to global growth and trade concerns. Investors sought safe-haven bonds, driving Australian government bond futures to a two-year peak. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep rates at record lows, adding to the bearish outlook for the Aussie. The country's export-driven economy is heavily leveraged to global trade, making it vulnerable to economic slowdowns.

site_title: China's Xi Jinping says Taiwan must be unified with mainland
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping reiterated the need for Taiwan's unification with the mainland, stating it's an "inevitable requirement for the historical rejuvenation of the Chinese nation." Xi warned those advocating for Taiwan's independence, saying it's a "legal fact" that both sides of the straits belong to one China. This statement comes as the 40th anniversary of a landmark Beijing overture to Taipei after the US and China established relations is marked.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping said Taiwan must be unified with the mainland to achieve his goal of completing the country's rejuvenation.

site_title: Chinese city economies need to cut reliance on real estate: state media
summary: China's regional economies need to reduce their reliance on the property market for growth and focus on sustainable development. The Communist Party's People's Daily emphasized the importance of a stable and healthy property market for China's changing economy. Despite average new home prices rising for a 43rd straight month, the rate of increase slowed, and soft home sales suggest a dim outlook for the sector. Chinese city authorities are seeking to ease existing curbs on property markets, despite Beijing's directives to keep prices in check. A shift towards diversified growth is necessary for long-term development.

site_title: Asia: Shares blindsided by dismal China data
summary: Asian shares plummeted 1.1% on the first trading day of the year as China's manufacturing activity contracted for the first time in 19 months, according to a private survey. The Shanghai blue chip index fell 1%, while South Korea's market dropped 0.8%. The Australian dollar hit its lowest since 2016, and the US dollar fell to its lowest since June. The disappointing data darkened the mood, erasing early gains in US stock futures, and led to a rally in the yen and gold.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday's open; STI up 0.16% to 3,073.76
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on January 2, 2019, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.16% to 3,073.76. Gainers outnumbered losers 74 to 25, driven by 24.7 million securities worth S$24.7 million. Key gainers included Rex International and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data, with investors remaining positive despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Yidai shuts shop as China intensifies crackdown on P2P lenders
summary: China's P2P lending market is shrinking as Yidai, an online P2P lending intermediary, shuts down operations. The company has about 32,000 lenders with a principal balance of $795.4 million and plans to repay them in 3-5 years. Authorities are cracking down on the market, citing tougher regulations and rising bankruptcies, with analysts predicting the number of P2P lenders will contract to fewer than 200 in three years. This move is part of President Xi Jinping's broader crackdown on shadow banking, which has led to the nation's biggest Ponzi scheme and life-altering losses for thousands of savers.

site_title: Koon Holdings appoints new CFO
summary: Koon Holdings appointed Yee May Yo, 47, as CFO on Dec 31, 2018, replacing Ron Loi Lup Sheng who resigned to pursue personal interests. Loi had overseen financial management and regulatory compliance since his appointment in Jan 2018. The change comes nearly a year after Loi's initial resignation.

site_title: Raffles Medical opens its first China hospital in Chongqing
summary: Raffles Medical Group has opened its first international tertiary hospital in China, located in Chongqing, with a 700-bed capacity. The hospital offers specialist services in various fields, including gastrointestinal surgery, obstetrics, and oncology. This marks the group's 14th presence in Asia, including eight cities in China. The hospital aims to provide quality healthcare to the region's growing middle and upper-income population, as well as meet the needs of foreigners working in Chongqing. A second hospital in Shanghai is also planned for 2019.

site_title: China's Didi launches credit, crowdfunding services in diversification push
summary: China's Didi Chuxing has launched financial products, including crowdfunding and lending, as part of its diversification push following safety scandals. The new services, tested in 10 cities and now nationwide, target short-term workers with options for wealth management, credit, and lending for critical illnesses. This move comes after a company-wide reorganisation aimed at improving safety and efficiency. The diversification aims to reduce reliance on the ride-hailing business, following a year of safety incidents.

site_title: Oil starts 2019 with gains, as traders gear up for volatile year
summary: Oil markets began 2019 in positive territory, with International Brent crude futures up 51 cents to $54.31 per barrel and West Texas Intermediate spot crude oil futures up 44 cents to $45.85 per barrel. This follows a 25% decline in US WTI futures and 20% decline in Brent futures in 2018. Traders attribute the gains to a rise in stock markets, despite overall weak oil market sentiment. The outlook for 2019 is uncertain due to US-China trade concerns, Brexit, and Middle East instability, with oil prices expected to trade below $70 per barrel.

site_title: Disasters rock Indonesia's '10 New Balis' tourism push
summary: Indonesia's tourism push, "10 New Balis," has been dealt a blow after a deadly tsunami struck the beachside town of Tanjung Lesung, killing several members of the Indonesian band Seventeen and over 100 others. The disaster has raised concerns about disaster preparedness and the future of the multi-billion-dollar tourism industry. Tourism Minister Arief Yahya has vowed to rebuild the town in six months, but some experts question the government's ability to promote the area due to the recent volcanic eruption and destruction of buildings. The tsunami has also highlighted Indonesia's woeful state of preparedness, with early warning systems in some areas not functioning due to budget shortfalls and bureaucratic issues.

site_title: Finding female friends over 50 can be hard. These women figured it out
summary: A group of women over 50 in Los Angeles formed a meetup, Finding Female Friends Past Fifty, to connect with others of similar age and interests. Founded by Dale Pollekoff in 2015, the group has grown to over 800 members and offers various activities, including art gallery visits, screenings, and social events. The group's success highlights the importance of female friendships for older women's well-being, as studies have shown that friendships can be key to happiness and alleviate loneliness. Members have reported forming meaningful connections and friendships, which would not have been possible without the group.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Raffles Medical, Aoxin Q & M Dental, Artivision Technologies
summary: Raffles Medical Group opened its first international tertiary hospital in Chongqing, China, with a 700-bed capacity. Aoxin Q & M Dental Group proposed acquiring Youxin Dental Clinic in China for 19.6 million yuan. Artivision Technologies is in discussions to extend its acquisition stop date for Mobile Credit Payment Pte Ltd.

site_title: Nasa's New Horizons space probe 'phones home' in landmark mission to solar system's edge
summary: NASA's New Horizons space probe successfully "phoned home" from its historic mission to the edge of the solar system, reaching 3,540km of the frozen rock Ultima Thule in the Kuiper Belt. Launched in 2006, the probe has traveled 6.4 billion km, sending back images and data from the dwarf planet Pluto and its moons. The latest signals indicate a healthy spacecraft, and scientists will study Ultima Thule's atmosphere and terrain for months to uncover secrets about the solar system's formation.

site_title: Trump invites congressional leaders to border security briefing, says source
summary: US President Donald Trump has invited congressional leaders to a bipartisan briefing on border security at the White House, amid a partial government shutdown over his demand for a $5 billion border wall. The briefing is set for Wednesday and is not a negotiating session. The House and Senate will reconvene briefly on Wednesday, with no signs of a workable plan to end the shutdown. A two-part spending package is set to be approved by House Democrats, but its prospects are grim in the Republican-led Senate, which has fallen in line with Trump's wall funding demands.

site_title: India's Jet Airways defaults on debt payment to banks
summary: Jet Airways Ltd, a 25-year-old Indian airline, has delayed a debt payment to a consortium of Indian banks, including State Bank of India Ltd, due to a temporary cash flow mismatch. The airline is in talks with the consortium to resolve the issue. Jet Airways is facing financial difficulties, owing money to pilots, lessors, and vendors, amid intense competition, a weak rupee, and rising fuel costs. The airline's financial struggles come after it missed a payment deadline of December 31, 2018.

site_title: 'Just calm down', Trump tells detractors in New Year tweet
summary: US President Donald Trump kicked off 2019 with a belligerent tweet, telling critics to "CALM DOWN AND ENJOY THE RIDE" and assuring them it will be a "FANTASTIC YEAR". The tweet came after Trump attacked opposition Democrats and accused retired General Stanley McChrystal of being dishonest and immoral. Trump also launched into a personal attack on McChrystal, comparing him to a "dog" who was "fired like a dog" by Obama. The tweet was followed by a more subdued greeting, with Trump later focusing on his proposed wall along the southern border with Mexico.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic wins first match of 2019 in just 55 minutes
summary: Novak Djokovic won his first match of the 2019 season, defeating Damir Dzumhur 6-1, 6-2 in the Qatar Open first round in 55 minutes. Djokovic, the world number one, showcased his dominant form, converting his first match point to complete the match in under an hour. This win followed a high-quality match between Stan Wawrinka and Karen Khachanov, with Wawrinka emerging victorious. The two players could meet at the semi-final stage in Doha.

site_title: Artivision in talks to extend long stop date of MC Payment acquisition
summary: Artivision Technologies is in talks to extend the Dec 31, 2018 long stop date for its acquisition of MC Payment, a Singapore-based electronic payment and online retail business. The total consideration for the acquisition includes up to S$125 million. The company advised shareholders to exercise caution as there is no certainty the acquisition will be completed.

images.alt_text: Anthony Koh (left), founder & CEO of MC Payment Pte Ltd, and Ching Chiat Kwong, controlling shareholder of Artivision Technologies Ltd.

site_title: HDB resale prices dip 0.2% in Q4, fall 0.9% for whole of 2018: Flash estimates
summary: HDB resale flat prices in Singapore dipped 0.2% in Q4 2018 and 0.9% for the whole of 2018, according to HDB flash estimates. The final figures will be released on Jan 25. For 2019, HDB will launch approximately 15,000 new flats for sale, including 3,100 in the first Build-to-Order exercise in February.

site_title: Horizon Towers gives collective sale another shot at same S$1.1b reserve price
summary: Horizon Towers, a 211-unit condominium in Singapore, is relaunching its collective sale tender at the same S$1.1 billion reserve price as before. The tender, which closes on Jan 28, follows the first tender's failure to attract a bid. Owners have until May 21 to conclude a sale contract and apply for a sale order. The reserve price translates to S$1,977 per square foot per plot ratio, with no development charge or differential premium for intensified use of the site.

site_title: Australian home prices mark worst year since 2008
summary: Australian home prices dropped nearly 5% in 2018, marking their worst year since 2008. The decline was driven by tighter credit conditions and waning investor interest. The national home price index fell 1.8% in December and 2.3% for the quarter, with Sydney and Melbourne experiencing the worst declines. Regional centers saw minimal changes. Analysts expect the weakness to persist in 2019, citing access to credit as the primary factor weighing down the housing market.

site_title: Luzhou Bio-Chem appoints Koh Pee Keat as new CFO
summary: Luzhou Bio-Chem Technology has appointed Koh Pee Keat as its new chief financial officer (CFO), effective January 1. Mr. Koh, who has held the director of finance role since 2008, will oversee accounting, financial reporting, and other financial functions.

site_title: The future of food
summary: Singapore's food manufacturing sector is thriving, with companies like The Soup Spoon and Seng Hua Hng Foodstuff investing in technology to extend shelf-life and develop new products. Premium meat products company Huber's Butchery, a family business, is also boosting productivity and online presence. Meanwhile, CrowdFarmX, a blockchain-based cooperative farming platform, connects farmers directly to the global market. Local food and beverage brands Sunfresh and Song Fa share their journeys in the industry, highlighting the importance of technology investment for growth. These developments showcase Singapore's commitment to the food manufacturing sector.

site_title: India misses power goal as more than 1m homes still in the dark
summary: India failed to meet its self-imposed target to electrify every home by December 31, 2018, with over 1 million households still without power. Despite bringing electricity to 23.9 million households across 25 states, the government missed its goal, which was set to showcase before national elections in early 2019. The government aims to achieve full energy access and reliable uninterrupted supplies in the coming months.

site_title: Bill Gates' nuclear venture hits snag amid US restrictions on China deals: WSJ
summary: TerraPower LLC, a nuclear energy venture chaired by Bill Gates, is seeking a new partner for its technology trials due to new US restrictions on China deals. The company had agreed with China National Nuclear Corp in 2017 to build an experimental reactor, but Gates wrote that US restrictions have made it unlikely to proceed. TerraPower is now uncertain about which country to work with to conduct trials of its technology, which uses depleted uranium to improve safety and costs. The company's plans have been impacted by the US's new rules on technology deals with China.

site_title: Gold dips as renewed risk appetite lifts Asian stocks
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.2% to $1,279.31 per ounce on Wednesday, following gains in US stock futures that signaled improved risk appetite. This comes as Asian equities rose, despite US President Donald Trump's partial government shutdown. Trump invited congressional leaders to a border security briefing, while North Korean leader Kim Jong Un expressed readiness to meet Trump again to denuclearize the Korean Peninsula. US Mint gold and silver coin sales declined to their lowest in 11 years in 2018.

site_title: Netflix blocks show in Saudi Arabia critical of Saudi Prince
summary: Netflix blocked an episode of "Patriot Act With Hasan Minhaj" from streaming in Saudi Arabia after the Saudi government complained that the episode, critical of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, violated cybercrime laws. The episode critiques the US-Saudi relationship after Jamal Khashoggi's murder. The move comes after the Saudi government complained about the episode's content.

site_title: Why Porsche's electric Taycan will make the marque in 2019
summary: Porsche's electric Taycan is expected to contribute significantly to the brand's success in 2019. Following a record-breaking 2018, US auto sales are forecasted to reach 17.2 million units in 2019, according to Cox Automotive. Porsche's Taycan, launched in 2019, is poised to play a key role in the company's growth, with the electric vehicle's potential to drive sales and establish the brand as a leader in the EV market.

site_title: Treasuries may have to wait till after new year for better results
summary: US Treasury yields have fallen to around 2.71% due to risk-averse trading sentiment, which may not improve until after the new year. Investors are concerned about tightening financial conditions and a souring economic outlook, with some predicting a possible mistake from the Federal Reserve with further interest-rate hikes. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's interview on Friday may provide insight, but weak inflation could be a signal that the Fed will hold rates steady in the first quarter, potentially calming market volatility.

site_title: The future of farming
summary: CrowdFarmX, the world's first cooperative farming platform on blockchain, connects farmers directly to the global market, promoting end-to-end visibility of the supply chain. Powered by IoT and blockchain technology, the platform equips smallholder farmers with technology know-how to deliver higher yields. By cutting out intermediaries, CrowdFarmX aims to increase quality and quantity of pesticide-free produce, benefiting end consumers.

site_title: Investors are still cautiously optimistic about 2019
summary: Investors remain cautiously optimistic about 2019, despite a tumultuous 2018, with the US stock market narrowly avoiding a 20% decline from its high. The economy is expected to continue growing, but borrowing costs and interest rates pose a risk to corporate profits and investors' appetite for stocks. The trade war with China and President Trump's unpredictable declarations on Twitter also contribute to market uncertainty. Key factors will determine 2019's performance, including the Fed's interest rate decisions, global growth, and the tech sector's performance.

site_title: Kim ready to meet Trump 'anytime', but warns of 'new path'
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un stated he is ready to meet US President Donald Trump anytime to achieve denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, but warned that if US sanctions and pressure continue, North Korea may have to explore a new path to defend its sovereignty. Kim reiterated his "firm will" to denuclearize and expressed willingness to work with the US and South Korea, but emphasized that North Korea will not be forced into negotiations. The US has maintained strict sanctions on North Korea until full denuclearization, which Kim sees as an obstacle to progress.

site_title: India cuts tax on palm oil imports; Malaysia to benefit the most
summary: India has reduced import taxes on crude and refined palm oil from South-east Asian countries, benefiting Malaysia the most. The move aims to narrow the price difference between palm oil and competitors like soya and sunflower oil, leading to higher imports of palm oil by India, the world's largest edible oil buyer. This change is expected to impact the global palm oil market.

site_title: Commodities cap another dismal year; 2019 offers little respite
summary: Commodities experienced another dismal year in 2018, with the Bloomberg Commodity Index projected to drop 12% due to concerns over slowing global economic growth and the US-China trade war. Energy and base metals, such as West Texas Intermediate crude and copper, declined by over 20% and 18% respectively. Manufacturing in China and the steel industry also showed signs of contraction. Experts predict a further slowdown in 2019, with China's central bank acknowledging "downward pressure on the domestic economy".

site_title: Why France's centre-left resists globalisation
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's centre-left government is facing a crisis after popular uprisings, known as the Yellow Vests, protest against his labour-market and fuel tax reforms. Macron's reforms aimed to modernize France's economy and meet EU deficit rules, but they benefited the rich and alienated his core centre-left constituency. The protests have led to Macron's retreat, highlighting the need for a new centre-left social contract to address globalisation, technological disruption, and climate change. Macron's inability to balance economic reform with social welfare and international cooperation has left him vulnerable to criticism and opposition.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chasing Cars: Overall Car of The Year Nominees
summary: Money FM's "Chasing Cars" podcast reveals the three nominees for Overall Car of The Year. The nominees include the MG ZS Hybrid+, BMW's i4, and the Jaecoo J7. The podcast, hosted by Claressa Monteiro, discusses the key features and performance of each car, providing insights into the competition for the top award. The nominees will be announced soon, and listeners can share their feedback on the podcast's website or social media platforms.

site_title: Private home prices slip 0.1% q-o-q in Q4, rise 7.9% in 2018: URA flash estimate
summary: Singapore's private home prices declined 0.1% in Q4 2018, but rose 7.9% for the year, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA). Landed home prices fell 1.8% in the fourth quarter, while non-landed home prices inched up 0.3%. The decrease is attributed to the landed segment, with prices expected to remain steady for new launches in 2019, driven by a healthy volume of transactions and sustainable growth in the non-landed segment.

site_title: Shipping confidence dips as New Year approaches
summary: Shipping confidence has dipped to 6.0 out of 10.0, down from 6.3 in August 2018, according to Moore Stephens' latest survey. Confidence levels fell across all main categories, except brokers, which increased to 5.2. Shipowners' confidence fell to 6.4, while charterers' confidence decreased to 6.8. The survey also found that 67% of respondents expect finance costs to increase over the coming year. Despite this, the appetite for new investment remains, with 71% of respondents expecting to make significant investments.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Key Singapore Government Bonds quotation on January 1, 2019, for taxable book-entry bonds has not been mentioned in the provided articles. However, other notable events include NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer being 9.8 times oversubscribed, Creative Technology warning of potential revenue shortfall, and Singapore stocks experiencing a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Tennis: Federer emerges victorious in historic clash with Serena
summary: Roger Federer emerged victorious in a historic first meeting with Serena Williams in the Hopman Cup, defeating her 6-4, 6-1 in singles. The match, billed as one of the most anticipated clashes between men and women since the 1973 "Battle of the Sexes," was won by Federer, who praised Williams' serve as "killer" and "super-underestimated." The victory helped Switzerland secure a 2-1 win over the US, with Federer and Belinda Bencic also winning the mixed doubles match.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia foreign ministers to meet on Jan 8 in Republic
summary: Singapore and Malaysia's foreign ministers will meet on January 8 to discuss issues including the dispute over airspace, particularly the Seletar Airport, which will pass through the airspace over Pasir Gudang, Johor. Malaysia has protested the plans, claiming it will impact their port operations, while Singapore argues that management of the skies is delegated to their management under an agreement with regional states. The meeting aims to find a win-win solution for both countries.

images.alt_text: Mr Teo Chee Hean, Deputy Prime Minister and Coordinating Minister for National Security

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Aoxin Q&M Dental Group, a Catalist-listed company, is proposing to fully acquire Youxin Dental Clinic in Jinzhou, China for 19.6 million yuan (S$3.9 million). The deal is expected to be completed by June 30, 2019.

site_title: Big tech may look troubled, but it's just getting started
summary: Lawmakers across the US say Big Tech has too much power, accusing it of inflaming, radicalizing, and dumbing down the masses. Despite this, tech companies are not taking steps to alleviate concerns, and regulation looms. Instead, they are focusing on their business and investing their vast resources. Tech executives are calling for regulation, but so far, the companies are not taking this path. The companies' refusal to address concerns may lead to further scrutiny and potential changes in the industry.

site_title: Singapore economy grows by 2.2% in Q4: advance estimates
